An ornamental appendage of wood at the ship's stern, usuallyspreading like a fan and curved like a bird's feather. Audsley.
One who, or that which, blanches or whitens; esp., one whoanneals and cleanses money; also, a chemical preparation for thispurpose.
A rebate or chase in masonry left to receive a permanent slabor other filling.
A book in which are described the sufferings of saints andmartyrs. T. Warton.
Bad legislation; the enactment of bad laws. Cockeram.
A nickname for auricular confession; shrift. [Obs.] Cartwright.
A Chinese governor general; a tsung tu (which see).
A white amorphous substance, the insoluble part of cherry gum;-- called also meta-arabinic acid.
The grasshopper warbler; -- so called from its note. [Prov.Eng.]
A small yellow-headed bird (Auriparus flaviceps) of LowerCalifornia, allied to the titmice; -- called also goldtit.
Any part of a rampart or parapet which deviates from thegeneral direction.
One who explains geological phenomena by the Noachian deluge.Lyell.
The Baltic or variable cod (Gadus callarias), by some believedto be the young of the common codfish.

In general, any signal announcing information concerning winds,and esp. the expected approach of winds whose direction and force aredangerous to shipping, etc. The wind-signal system of the UnitedStates Weather Bureau consists of storm, information, hurricane, hotwind, and inland storm signals.
A burning or searing, as of morbid flesh, with a hot iron, orby application of a caustic that will burn, corrode, or destroyanimal tissue.
To ordain or appoint beforehand; to preordain; to predestinate;to predetermine. Hooker.
The man who occupies a central position in a file of soldiers.
To lay or put to sleep; to stupefy. [Obs.] Cudworth.
A writer of hierograms; also, one skilled in hieroglyphics.Greenhill.
An unorganized ferment or enzyme present in pancreatic juice.It decomposes neutral fats into glycerin and fatty acids.
One who decorates, adorns, or embellishes; specifically, anartisan whose business is the decoration of houses, esp. theirinterior decoration.
The process of forming hummocks in the collision of Arctic ice.Kane.
A combination of a stop, or explosive, with an immediatelyfollowing fricative or spirant of corresponding organic position, aspf in german Pfeffer, pepper, z (= ts) in German Zeit, time.

A believer in the theory (called encasement theory), currentduring the last century, that the egg was the real animal germ, andthat at the time of fecundation the spermatozoa simply gave theimpetus which caused the unfolding of the egg, in which allgenerations were inclosed one within the other. Also called ovist.
An under dean; the deputy or substitute of a dean. Ayliffe.
A notice or notion which precedes something else in time;previous notion or thought; foreknowledge. Bacon.
Extreme hatred or detestation; the feeling of utter dislike.
Having different minds at different times; unsettled;undetermined.A double-minded man is unstable in all his ways. Jas. i. 8.
One who pushes a principle or measure to extremes; anextremist; a radical; an ultra.
a flat heap of moist, crushed silver ore, prepared for thepatio process.
The quality of being commutable; interchangeableness.
To take from the tomb; to exhume; to disinter. Fuller.
A set or squad of ten men under a decurion. Sir W. Raleigh.

To walk through or over; especially, to travel over for thepurpose of surveying or examining; to inspect by traversing;specifically, to inspect officially the boundaries of, as of a townor parish, by walking over the whole line.
A small New Zealand owl (Sceloglaux albifacies). It has shortwings and long legs, and lives chiefly on the ground.
An instrument to measure the growth of plants. Goodale.
The formation of an aposteme; the process of suppuration.[Written corruptly imposthumation.] Wiseman.
Act of enwrapping; a wrapping or an envelope. Shuckford.
Like a giant; mighty; gigantic. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
An ornament in the form of a rose or roundel, -much used indecoration.
Without error, mistake, or deviation; unerringly. Glanvill.
The wedging, as of a horse or car, against the top of anunderground passage. Raymond.
Opened; in blossom or having blossomed, as a flower. Shak.
The slope or angle to which the cutting edge of a tool, as aplane, is ground. Grier.
Of or pertaining to ambrein; -- said of a certain acid producedby digesting ambrein in nitric acid.
A machine for cropping, as for shearing off bolts or rod iron,or for facing cloth.
Round and without a cella; consisting of a single ring ofcolumns supporting a roof; -- said esp. of a temple.
A variety of sugar isomeric with sucrose, extracted from cottonseeds and from the so-called Australian manna (a secretion of certainspecies of Eucalyptus).
Consisting of, or having, many cells or more than one cell.
One who, or that which, disinfects; an apparatus for applyingdisinfectants.
A kind of amulet or magical charm. [Obs.] J. Gregory.
Of or pertaining to glosses or to a glossary; containing aglossary.
Of or pertaining to pleas or pleading, in courts of law. [Obs.]Clayton.
A description, or the doctrine, of death. Dunglison.
A pointed projection, like a four-sided pyramid, used forornament in lines or groups.
An extensive tribe of bivalve mollusks of which the genus Venusis the type. The shells are usually oval, or somewhat heartshaped,with a conspicuous lunule. See Venus.
An idle, worthless fellow, who is without any visible means ofsupport; a dissipated sponger. [Slang, U.S.]
The mixing of the food with the saliva and other secretions ofthe mouth in eating.
To make the noise, or utter the call, of a brooding hen. Ray.
Either one of two handles on the back of a piece of ordnance.
A genus of large and voracious two-winged flies, including thebee killer and robber fly.
To cause to resemble porphyry; to make spotted in composition,like porphyry.
On, or toward, the dorsum, or back; on the dorsal side of;dorsad.
To wish mutually in regarded to each other. [Obs.] Donne.
A palace; a seraglio; also, in the East, a place for theaccommodation of travelers; a caravansary, or rest house.
To divide or distribute proportionally; to assess pro rata.[U.S.]
A genus of extinct herbivorous mammals, abundant in theTertiary formation of the Rocky Mountains. It is more or less relatedto the camel, hog, and deer.
The act or process by which chyle is formed from food in animalbodies; chylification, -- a digestive process.
Thickest in the middle, and tapering to both ends; fusiform; --applied chiefly to roots.
A general or commander of land forces in the Turkish empire;especially, the commander-in-chief of minister of war.
A genus of cephalopods, including numerous species of squids,common on the coasts of America and Europe. They are much used forfish bait.
Having the quality of drying up; causing a drying up.-- n. (Med.)
The lower reef of fore and aft sails; also, the upper reef oftopsails. Ham. Nav. Encyc.
The replacement of an edge or solid angle by a plane,especially when the plane is equally inclined to the adjoining faces.
A small wheel formerly fixed to the pan of firelocks fordischarging them. Crabb.
A cannon capable of being trained at very high angles for useagainst aircraft.
An officer in London whose duty was to weigh wool. [Obs.]
A framework on which dishes, food, etc., are passed from oneroom or story of a house to another; a lift for dishes, etc.; also, apiece of furniture with movable or revolving shelves.
A chronic lung disease, common among coal miners, due to theinhalation of coal dust; -- called also collier's lung and miner'sphthisis.
One of the numerous small spinning tubes on the spinnerets ofspiders.
A glassy colorless mineral occurring in rhombohedral crystals,sometimes used as a gem. It is a silicate of glucina, and receivesits name from its deceptive similarity to quartz.
A writ which lies for a party against whom judgment isrecovered, but to whom good matter of discharge has subsequentlyaccrued which could not have been availed of to prevent suchjudgment. Wharton.

The type of religion which once prevalied among all the Ural-Altaic peoples (Tungusic, Mongol, and Turkish), and which stillsurvives in various parts of Northern Asia. The Shaman, or wizardpriest, deals with good as well as with evil spirits, especially thegood spirits of ancestors. Encyc. Brit.

An officer or magistrate chosen by the people, to protect themfrom the oppression of the patricians, or nobles, and to defend theirliberties against any attempts that might be made upon them by thesenate and consuls.
Pine wood abounding in pitch, used for torches in the SouthernUnited States; pine knots, dry sticks, and the like, for kindling afire quickly or making a blaze.
The lump of pasty wrought iron as taken from the puddlingfurnace to be hammered or rolled.
The quality or state of being movable; mobility; susceptibilityof motion.
The condition of being mendicant; beggary; begging. Burke.
A division of Foraminifera including those having amanychambered shell.
Pertaining to, or derived from, intuition; characterized byintuition; perceived by intuition; intuitive.
One of those who supported greenback or paper money, andopposed the resumption of specie payments. [Colloq. U. S.]
The art of memory; a system of precepts and rules intended toassist the memory; artificial memory.
A marked prominence or process on any part of a bone.
To fertilize, as the stigmas of a flower or plant, with thepollen from another individual of the  same species.
A chirping or creaking, as of a cricket. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Cherry-colored; a light bright red; --- applied to textilefabrics, especially silk.
The Spanish dollar; -- called also patacoon. [Obs.]
A machine used in making paper; -- so named from an earlyinventor of improvements in this class of machinery.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, the Jews (the Sephardim,also called Spanish or Portuguese Jews) descended from Jewishfamilies driven from Spain by the Inquisition.
A game at cards in which the object is to make fifteen points.
Good of its kind; -- variously used as implying substantial,real, fixed, sure, etc., and specif., of buildings, made of brick andmortar. [India]
An engagement between ships at sea; a naval battle.
The act or process of irrigating, or the state of beingirrigated; especially, the operation of causing water to flow overlands, for nourishing plants.
Tending or serving to titillate, or tickle; tickling.
A bare, naked contract, without any consideration. Tomlins.
Of or pertaining to cork; specifically, designating an acid, C
A hypothetical land, or continent, supposed by some to haveexisted formerly in the Indian Ocean, of which Madagascar is aremnant. Herschel.

A short glass jar fitted with an air-tight cover, andcontaining some desiccating agent, as sulphuric acid or calciumchloride, above which is suspended the material to be dried, orpreserved from moisture.
The technical name of the form by which either party, inpleading, accepts the issue tendered by his opponent; -- calledsometimes a joinder in issue.
One of a breed of fancy frilled pigeons allied to the owls andturbits, having the body white, the shoulders tricolored, and thetail bluish black with a large white spot on each feather.
Having a head; -- applied chiefly to the Cephalata, a divisionof mollusks.
A tumor having the structure of a sacroma in which there is adeposit of bone; sarcoma connected with bone.
To move quickly, but with great effort; to gallop. [Prov. Eng.& Scot.]
A bay of a barn; also, a slight addition to a cottage. [Prov.Eng.]
Having a surface dressed by cutting with a hammer the head ofwhich consists of broad thin chisels clamped together.
A bulbous iridaceous plant (Crocus sativus) having blue flowerswith large yellow stigmas. See Crocus.
A syllogism which assumes as one of its premises a propositionwhich was the conclusion of a preceding syllogism, called, inrelation to this, the prosyllogism.

A stanza of eight lines of heroic verse, with three rhymes, thefirst six lines rhyming alternately and the last two forming acouplet. It was used by Byron in "Don Juan," by Keats in "Isabella,"by Shelley in "The Witch of Atlas," etc.
The reply of a plaintiff to a defendant's rebutter.
The science or practice of instructing by questions andanswers.

One who, in the 17th century and the early part of the 18th,claimed to belong to a secret society of philosophers deeply versedin the secrets of nature, -- the alleged society having existed, itwas stated, several hundred years.
Thin; lean; meager; scrawny; scrannel. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]

Originally, the art of managing engines; in its modern andextended sense, the art and science by which the mechanicalproperties of matter are made useful to man in structures andmachines; the occupation and work of an engineer.
A part of a book or literary composition printed and deliveredby itself; a number; a part.
That branch of physics which treats of heat and electricity. R.Park.
The soft tissue, or substance, which, in developing bone,ultimately undergoes ossification.
A hard and strong substance made of a pulp from paper, mixedwith sise or glue, etc. It is formed into various articles, usuallyby means of molds.
The central column of parenchyma in a growing stem or root.
A lively dance (called also galliard), the steps of which wereregulated by the number five. [Obs.] Nares. Shak.
A person who favors the abolition of any institution,especially negro slavery.
Plaited lengthwise and twisted in addition, as the bud of themorning-glory. Gray.
To put into the gut; to swallow greedily; to gorge; togormandize. [Obs.] L'Estrange. Dryden.
An unidentified plant mentioned by Shakespeare, perhapsequivalent to burdock.
Cloth or flax dipped in warm water or medicaments and appliedto a hurt or sore.
To unyoke or disengage, as oxen from a wagon. [S. Africa]

A Persian measure of length, which, according to Herodotus andXenophon, was thirty stadia, or somewhat more than three and a halfmiles. The measure varied in different times and places, and, as nowused, is estimated at from three and a half to four English miles.
A name given to a free-booting, unenlisted, armed man orguerrilla.
A modified form of dentine, which is permeated by bloodcapillaries; vascular dentine.
The edges or lower borders of the roof of a building, whichoverhang the walls, and cast off the water that falls on the roof.
To make malign or malignant. [R.] "A strong faith malignified."Southey.
The act of recurving, or the state of being recurved; a bendingor flexure backward.
The fit, attack, or exacerbation, of a disease that occurs atintervals, or has decided remissions or intermissions. Arbuthnot.
A general term applied to the tissues formed of elongatedcells, especially those with pointed or oblique extremities, as theprincipal cells of ordinary wood.
A bag or case, usually of leather, for carrying wearingapparel, etc., on journeys. Thackeray.
A colorless viscous substance having a bitter-sweet taste.
The head violinist or leader of the strings in an orchestra;the sub-leader of the orchestra; concert master.
Of or pertaining to the presphenoid bone; presphenoid.
The doctrine or theory that psychical phenomena are functionsor products of the brain only.
Falling or coming between; happening accidentally. [Obs.]Boyle.
To turn into a star; to cause to appear like a star; to placeamong the stars, or in heaven. [Obs. or R.] B. Jonson.
The quality or state of being like summer. [R.] Fuller.
That variety of xylene in which the two methyl groups are inthe ortho position; a colorless, liquid, combustible hydrocarbonresembling benzene.
That branch of physics which relates to the determination ofthe humidity of bodies, particularly of the atmosphere, with thetheory and use of the instruments constructed for this purpose.
The anemone; -- so called because formerly supposed to openonly when the wind was blowing. See Anemone.

A gentlewoman; -- an appellation or courteous form of addressgiven to a lady, especially an elderly or a married lady; -- muchused in the address, at the beginning of a letter, to a woman. Thecorresponding word in addressing a man is Sir.
The art or act of encamping; the making or laying out of acamp.
Zinc; -- especially so called in commerce and arts.
A brown, bitter substance found in some of the cells ofhoneycomb. It is made chiefly from the pollen of flowers, which iscollected by bees as food for their young.
A stick or device for removing the hook from a fish's gullet.
A person engaged in procuring or holding a woman or women forunwilling prostitution.
The hole in the deck through which the rudderpost passes.
A disease or diseases, or adventitious circumstances orconditions, coexistent with and modifying a primary disease, but notnecessarily connected with it.

A sharp, shrill, disagreeable sound suddenly utered, either ofthe human voice or of any animal or instrument, such as is made bycarriage wheels when dry, by the soles of leather shoes, or by a pipeor reed.
An exact enunciation of the constituents which make up thelogical essence.
The state of being surety; the obligation of a person to answerfor the debt, default, or miscarriage of another. Bouvier.
Having masts smaller than the usual dimension; -- said ofvessels. Totten.
One who holds the opinion that all events are ordered for thebest.
A digesting furnace, formerly used by alchemists. It was soconstructed as to maintain uniform and durable heat. Chambers.
To fray; to wear or pull into tatters or tag ends; to tatter; --used literally and figuratively. [Prov. Eng. & U. S.]
A dynamometer to which is attached a device for automaticallyregistering muscular power.
The act of interlacing, or the state of being interlaced; also,that which is interlaced.
A musical stringed instrument, similar in form to a guitar; apandore.
Seasonable; timely; sufficiently early. [Obs.] Sir W. Raleigh.
A white waxy solid obtained from Chinese wax, and by thedistillation of cerotin.
Of or pertaining to ancient Scandinavia, or to the languagespoken by its inhabitants.
The American red squirrel (Sciurus Hudsonius); -- so calledfrom its cry.
The title of the native sovereigns of Hyderabad, in India,since 1719.
A thin membrane existing in the pollen grains of some plants,and situated between the extine and the intine, as in .
A meadow, or piece of low, flat land, capable of being kept ina state of fertility by being overflowed with water from someadjoining river or stream.
Zinc sulphide; -- called also blende, black-jack, false galena,etc. See Blende (a).

An officer of the peace whose principal duty is to inquire,with the help of a jury, into the cause of any violent, sudden ormysterious death, or death in prison, usually on sight of the bodyand at the place where the death occurred. [In England formerly alsowritten and pronounced crowner.]

An instrument for measuring the quantity of dew on the surfaceof a body in the open air. It consists of a balance, having a plateat one end to receive the dew, and at the other a weight protectedfrom the deposit of dew.
In the manner of a kitchen; in connection with a kitchen orcooking.
A measure by the ell; formerly a sworn officer in England,whose duty was to inspect act measure woolen cloth, and fix upon it aseal.
A small flat bastion, raised in the middle of an overlongcurtain.
To gargle; to rinse or wash, as the mouth and throat. [Obs.]Bacon.
The quality or state of being insoluble; insolubility. Boyle.
Containing larval tapeworms; -- said of pork and beef.
The answer of a plaintiff to a defendant's rejoinder.
An elector or chooser; one of two persons appointed by a courtto return a jury or serve a writ when the sheriff and the coronersare disqualified.
An East Indian insectivorous mammal (Gymnura Rafflesii),somewhat like a rat in appearance, but allied to the hedgehog.
A rock trout (Pleurogrammus monopterygius) found on the coastof Alaska; -- called also striped fish, and Atka mackerel.
Of or pertaining to Tiro, or a system of shorthand said to havebeen introduced by him into ancient Rome.
Characterized by cunning or shrewdness; crafty. [R.]
A flattened marine univalve shell of the genus Haliotis; --called also sea-ear. See Abalone.
the act or process of diminishing the quantity of fluid in thevessels by bloodletting or otherwise; also excessive evacuation, asin severe diarrhea.
A strongly alkaline base, CN3H5, formed by the oxidation ofguanin, and also obtained combined with methyl in the decompositionof creatin. Boiled with dilute sulphuric acid, it yields urea andammonia.
Having erect, pointed ears; prick-eared; -- said of certaindogs.
The quality of being diffusible; capability of being poured orspread out.
A building separate from, and subordinate to, the main house;an outhouse.
A series of strata, of the Middle Tertiary period, of France,abounding in shells, and used by Lyell as the type of his Miocenesubdivision.
One of a breed of small dogs with short crooked legs, and longbody; -- called also badger dog. There are two kinds, the rough-haired and the smooth-haired.
To turn, or to be turned, over; to be upset. Mortimer.
The act or process of increasing to the highest degree.Bentham.

Any one of six metameric hydrocarbons, (CH3)2.C6H3.NH2,resembling aniline, and related to xylene. They are liquids, oreasily fusible crystalline substances, of which three are derivedfrom metaxylene, two from orthoxylene, and one from paraxylene. Theyare called the amido xylenes.
A small compartment in a desk or case for the keeping ofletters, documents, etc.; -- so called from the resemblance of a rowof them to the compartments in a dovecote. Burke.
To deprive or rid of interest in, or regard for; to disengage.[Obs.]

The upward pressure exerted upon a floating body by a fluid,which is equal to the weight of the body; hence, also, the weight ofa floating body, as measured by the volume of fluid displaced.Such are buoyancies or displacements of the different classes of hermajesty's ships. Eng. Cyc.
A cordial made of the kernels of apricots, nectarines, etc.,with refined spirit.
The edible fruit of the Gaultheria Shallon, an ericaceous shrubfound from California northwards. The berries are about the size of acommon grape and of a dark purple color.
The district, office, or residence of an archdeacon. SeeBenefice.Every diocese is divided into archdeaconries. Blackstone.
An instrument for measuring the transparency of the air.
Mutually assisting or operating; helping. J. Philips.
Not aneled; not having received extreme unction. Shak.
Any aquatic animal whose external covering consists of a shell,either testaceous, as in oysters, clams, and other mollusks, orcrustaceous, as in lobsters and crabs.
Not placing a high estimate on ecclesiastical organizations orforms; -- applied especially to Episcopalians, and opposed to high-church. See High Church, under High.
An engine of war used for throwing viretons, large stones, andother missiles; a springal.
The aggregate of risks covered by the terms of a contract ofinsurance.
The doctrine that the geological changes in the earth's crusthave been caused by the sudden action of violent physical causes; --opposed to the doctrine of uniformism.

The widening and duplication, triplication, etc., of spectrallines when the radiations emanate in a strong magnetic field, firstobserved in 1896 by P. Zeeman, a Dutch physicist, and regarded as animportant confirmation of the electromagnetic theory of light.
A frame of adjustable boards erected on a post, and havingholes through which the head and hands of an offender were thrust soas to be exposed in front of it. Shak.
To form or tell stories of; to narrate or describe in a story.[Obs.]
Inscribed with a posy.In poised lockets bribe the fair. Gay.
Pertaining to Argolis, a district in the Peloponnesus.
The doctrine that there is but one immortal soul or intellectwith which all men are endowed.
The state of being gibbous or gibbose; gibbousness.
The inferior vena cava.-- Post"ca`val, a. B. G. Wilder.
Lying outside the visible spectrum at its violet end; -- saidof rays more refrangible than the extreme violet rays of thespectrum.
A very venomous viper (Daboia Russellii), native of Ceylon andIndia; -- called also cobra monil.

An American and European composite plant (Achillea Millefolium)with very finely dissected leaves and small white corymbed flowers.It has a strong, and somewhat aromatic, odor and taste, and issometimes used in making beer, or is dried for smoking. Called alsomilfoil, and nosebleed.
An aboriginal weapon consisting of a stone or piece of antlerfastened to the end of a slender wooden handle, used by AmericanIndians from the Great Plains to the Mackenzie River.
Want of fecundity or fruitfulness; barrenness; sterility;unproductiveness.
A division of Coleoptera including those which have but threejoints in the tarsi.
The act of depriving, as of furniture, apparatus, or agarrison. [R.]
The act of darkening, or state of being dark; darkness;obscurity. Johnson.
An acetate containing an excess of the basic constituent.
The connective tissue framework and sheath of a nerve whichbind together the nerve bundles, each of which has its own specialsheath, or perineurium.
A soluble product (proteose) formed in the gastric andpancreatic digestion of casein and caseinogen.
A large, coarse herb (Inula Helenium), with composite yellowflowers. The root, which has a pungent taste, is used as a tonic, andwas formerly of much repute as a stomachic.
Having the nature, qualities, taste, form, consistency, orappearance of cheese.
An adherent of a theory, the transmission theory, that thebrain serves to "transmit," rather than to originate, conclusions,and hence that consciousness may exist independently of the brain.
An instrument having two handles and two grasping jaws workingon a pivot; -- used for griping things to be held fast, drawingnails, etc.
A wide mouth; a mouth stretched in derision. Dryden.
A knot in which a portion of the string is drawn through in theform of a loop or bow, so as to be readily untied.
The European green woodpecker; -- also called ecall, eaquall,yaffle. [Prov. Eng.]
The act of reducing to any state, as of mixing two bodiescombletely. [Obs.] Bacon.
A long-tailed monkey of Borneo (Semnopithecus rubicundus). Ithas a tuft of long hair on the head.
An extensive artificial group of birds including the wading,swimming, and cursorial birds.
An apparatus for testing or proving the strength of gunpowder.
To destroy the force of habit in; to wean from a custom.Johnson.
The timber forming the ridge of a roof, into which the raftersare secured.
(Anat.) Of or pertaining to the prescapula; supraspinous.
The condition, character, or conduct of a cotquean. [Obs.] B.Jonson.
The back, or posterior, part of the head or skull; the regionof the occipital bone.
A crystalline, nitrogenous substance, closely related toxanthin and uric acid, widely distributed through the animal body,but especially in muscle tissue; -- called also sarcin, sarkin.
Having the tongue finely notched along the sides, so as to havea featherlike appearance, as the toucans.
One of the four pursuivants of the English college of arms.

In the western United States, one who settles on governmentland before it is legally open to settlement in order to gain theprior claim that the law gives to the first settler when the land isopened to settlement; hence, any one who does a thing prematurely oranticipates another in acting in order to gain an unfair advantage.
The form of Neo-Kantianism developed by French idealists,following C. Renouvier.  It rejects the noumena of Kant, restrictingknowledge to phenomena as constituted by a priori categories.
A low stool to support the feet of one when sitting.
A kind of boat or junk used in the seas of the MalayArchipelago.
The act or process of sterilizing, or rendering sterile; also,the state of being sterile.
A vitreous form of basalt; -- so called because decompposableby acids and readily fusible.
A greenish yellow crystalline coloring matter found withpyocyanin in pus.
An idol or symbolical figure which the Templars were accused ofusing in their mysterious rites.
Without ears; hence, deaf or unwilling to hear. Pope.
A gambling game in vogue in the eighteenth century. Thackeray.
The quality or state of being vacillant, or wavering. [R.] Dr.H. More.
A name of Allium Scorodoprasum and A. Ascalonium, two kinds ofgarlic, the latter of which is also called shallot.
Having the color or properties of the rust of iron.
The act of disinterring, or taking out of the earth;exhumation.
The relation of freedom from the interventionof a medium;immediateness. Shak.
To shelter by means of a sanctuary or sacred privileges. [Obs.]Shak.

The keeping back of an approaching consonant chord byprolonging one or more tones of a previous chord into theintermediate chord which follows; -- differing from suspension byresolving upwards instead of downwards.
Unpleassantness; disagreeableness. [Obs.] Cockeram.
A staith or framework from which coal is discharged from carsinto vessels.
To hide; to skulk. [Scot.]He at length escaped them by derning himself in a foxearth. H.Miller.
A collection of sashes; ornamentation by means of sashes. [R.]Distinguished by their sasheries and insignia. Carlyle.

A leguminous plant of the genus Lupinus, especially L. albus,the seeds of which have been used for food from ancient times. Thecommon species of the Eastern United States is L. perennis. There aremany species in California.
Of or pertaining to tabes; of the nature of tabes; affectedwith tabes; tabid. -- n.
The act of developing a new coat of hair, a new set offeathers, scales, etc.; -- opposed to ecdysis.
The holding or occupation of an inheritable estate whichdescends from the ancestor to two or more persons; coheirship.
A highly elastic wood, used for fishing rods, etc. The tree isunknown, but it is thought to be East Indian.
A kind of pudding or sausage made of liver or pork. [Obs.]Chapman.
A name given to several species of stonecrop, used asingredients of vermifuge medicines. See Stonecrop.
Doubled and twisted thread, made of coarse silk, and used fortassels, fringes, etc. McElrath.
Pertaining to bishops, or government by bishops; episcopal;specifically, of or relating to the Protestant Episcopal Church.
A genus of spreading shrubs with many stems, from one speciesof which (K. triandra), found in Peru, rhatany root, used as amedicine, is obtained.

The shaft, mandrel, or arbor, in a machine tool, as a lathe ordrilling machine, etc., which causes the work to revolve, or carriesa tool or center, etc.(b) (Mach.) The vertical rod on which the runner of a grinding millturns.(c) (Founding) A shaft or pipe on which a core of sand is formed.
Having many poles; -- applied especially to those ganglionicnerve cells which have several radiating processes.
A vessel whose deck consists almost wholly of movable hatches;-- used mostly in the fisheries.
A two-stroke cycle for an internal-combustion engine. --Two"-cy`cle, a.
A defensive work of moderate height, hastily thrown up, ofearth or other material.
A yellowish red crystalline substance related to anthracene,and obtained from opianic acid.

An extinct tribe of fossil corals, including numerous species,many of them of large size. They are characteristic of the Paleozoicformations. The radiating septs, when present, are usually inmultiples of four. See Cyathophylloid.

A style of painting, popular in England in the 19th century, inwhich a thick opaque color is applied without background and withscarcely any shading, to thin paper, producing flowers, birds, etc.,in imitation of Oriental work. Hence: Poonah brush, paper, painter,etc.
A liquid hydrocarbon of the terpene series extracted from theseeds of a Japanese prickly ash (Xanthoxylum pipertium) as anaromatic oil.
Causing a discharge of water or phlegm.-- n. (Med.)
One who, or that which, bisects; esp. (Geom.) a straight linewhich bisects an angle.
A name of certain curious orchids which bear three kinds offlowers formerly referred to three genera, but now ascertained to besexually different forms of the same genus (Catasetum tridentatum,etc.).
Any plant of the composite genus Rudbeckia, coarse herbssomewhat resembling the sunflower; -- so called from their conicalreceptacles.
Any crustacean of the genus Palinurus and allied genera, as theEuropean spiny lobster (P. vulgaris), which is much used as anarticle of food. See Lobster.
One who kicks up the dust; a streetwalker; a low manner. [Obs.]Beau. & Fl.
One who soliloquizes; esp., one who monopolizes conversation incompany. De Quincey.
A nitrogenous substance closely resembling diastase, obtainedfrom bran, and possessing the power of converting starch intodextrin, sugar, and lactic acid. Watts.
A south African proteaceous tree (Protea grandiflora); also,its tough wood, used for making wagon wheels.
A political union, confederation, or league. [R.] Burke.
A raised shelf or stand on the back of an altar, on whichdifferent objects can be placed; a predella or gradino.
The wood of several West Indian trees, mostly of the genusCitharexylum.
The office or profession of an attorney; agency for another.Shak.
A native or inhabitant of the Lowlands, especially of theLowlands of Scotland, as distinguished from Highlander.
The quality or state of being pilose; hairiness. Bacon.
In an apt or suitable manner; fitly; properly; pertinently;appropriately; readily.
Restoration to an original state; renewal of purity. [R.] R.Browning.
That which serves to set or fix colors or drawings, as amordant.
One who makes known or proclaims; that which exhibits. Udall.

A term used by Sir William Hamilton to define propositionshaving their quantity indicated by a verbal sign; as, all, none,etc.; -- contrasted with preindesignate, defining propositions ofwhich the quantity is not so indicated.
The son or husband of Gaia (Earth), and father of Chronos(Time) and the Titans.
A woman whose occupation is to sell goods or merchandise.
Of or pertaining to a tetrarch or tetrarchy. Bolingbroke.
The state or quality of being jocund; gayety; sportiveness.
A cock or faucet having a bent down nozzle. Knight.
A mechanocal contrivance for exercesing the fingers of apianist.
An instrument for recording minor fluctuations of atmosphericpressure, as opposed to general barometric surges.
That which comes forth or results; effect; yield; issue;product; sum accruing from a sale, etc.
A game resembling ninepins, but played with ten pins. SeeNinepins. [U. S.]
By day, or every day; in the daytime. [Obs.] Fielding.
The state of being puzzled; perplexity. Miss Mitford.
One who makes a tour, or performs a journey in a circuit.
Of or pertaining to a parish; parochial. [R.] Bp. Hall.
The chief police officer of a large city. [East Indies]
A colorless, crystalline hydrocarbon, C20H14, obtained fromnaphthylene, and consisting of a doubled naphthylene radical.
Any coarse seaweed growing on sea-washed rocks, especiallyFucus.
An instrument formerly used at sea for taking the altitudes ofheavenly bodies, now superseded by the sextant; -- called also cross-staff. Brande & C.
An instrument used, especially in trigonometrical surveying,for the accurate measurement of horizontal angles, and also usuallyof vertical angles. It is variously constructed.
Double; formed by reduplication; reduplicate. I. Watts.
An inclosure where the tanning of leather is carried on; atannery.
The act or process of restoring an injured perineum.
The quality or state of being soft; -- opposed to Ant:hardness, and used in the various specific senses of the adjective.
The quality of being dastardly; cowardice; base fear.
Having the form of a pencil; furnished with a pencil of finehairs; ending in a tuft of hairs like a camel's-hair brush, as thestigmas of some grasses.
Of or pertaining to the period immediately following thePliocene; Pleistocene. Also used as a noun. See Quaternary.
The external or outermost layer of a fructified or ripenedovary. See Illust. under Endocarp.
That branch of agriculture dealing with the methods ofconversion of agricultural products into manufactured articles;agricultural technology.
The head of a family; in a large sense, the proprietor of anestate; one who is his own master.
The fifth book of the Pentateuch, containing the second givingof the law by Moses.
A small cannon supported by a swiveled rest on the back of acamel, whence it is fired, -- used in the East.
A body of cavarly comparising two companies or troops, andaverging from one hundred and twenty to two hundred men.
A small inclosed area; esp. one of the small spaces on thewings of insects, circumscribed by the veins.
The act or process of paging a book; also, the characters usedin numbering the pages; page number. Lowndes.
The motion of a small stream running among obstructions; also,the murmur it makes in so doing.
A part of a French newspaper (usually the bottom of the page),devoted to light literature, criticism, etc.; also, the article ortale itself, thus printed.
A coarse perennial grass of several species of Elymus, esp. E.Canadensis, and the European E. arenarius.
To indicate, as by a symptom, some method of treatment contraryto that which the general tenor of the case would seem to require.Contraindicating symptoms must be observed. Harvey.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the tinkling of a bell;having a tinkling sound; tintinnabular. De Quincey.
A wooden lever with a movable iron hook. hear the end; -- usedfor canting or turning over heavy logs, etc. [U. S.] Bartlett.
Silver, pounded into ingots of the shape of a shoe, and used ascurrency. The most common weight is about one pound troy. [China]McElrath.
Reflexive; -- applied to pronouns and verbs, but sometimeslimited to such pronouns as express mutual action.
One who makes or uses needles; also, a dealer in needles. PiersPlowman.
The largest of the different kinds of drums, having two heads,and emitting a deep, grave sound. See Bass, a.
A leather strap supporting the body of a carriage, and attachedto springs, or serving as a spring. See Illust. of Chaise.

The science of life; that branch of knowledge which treats ofliving matter as distinct from matter which is not living; the studyof living tissue. It has to do with the origin, structure,development, function, and distribution of animals and plants.
Of or pertaining to a pipe (flute) or piper. [R.] Ash.
Contamination by illegality, as in cases of contraband goods;implication.
The American larch (Larix Americana), a coniferous tree withslender deciduous leaves; also, its heavy, close-grained timber.Called also tamarack.
Pertaining to, or corresponding with, the palm of the hand.
The phenomenon of turning towards a source of warmth, seen inthe growing parts of some plants.
A lunch, or slight repast between breakfast and dinner; --originally, a Provincial English word, but introduced into India, andbrought back to England in a special sense.
A genus of plectognath fishes having the body covered withsolid, immovable, bony plates. It includes the trunkfishes.
Related to or resembling the marsupials; furnished with a pouchfor the young, as the marsupials, and also some fishes and Crustacea.
To give a feud, or right in land, to; to invest with a fief orfee; to invest (any one) with a freehold estate by the process offeoffment. Mozley & W.
Pertaining to, or involving, the right of postliminium.
A company or troop, especially the company pf performers in aplay or an opera.
Future duration without end; the relation or state of beingsempiternal. Sir M. Hale.
One of a breed of small dogs having long and thick hair andlarge drooping ears. The legs are usually strongly feathered, and thetail bushy. See Illust. under Clumber, and Cocker.
A postponement of the decision of a cause, for furtherconsideration or re-argument.
In a pale manner; dimly; wanly; not freshly or ruddily.Thackeray.
To smirch or soil; to discolor; to obscure. Hence: To dishonor;to sully. Shak.
Capable of being pressed together or forced into a narrowercompass, as an elastic or spongy substance.
The act of equalizing; act or result of making adequate; anequivalent. [Obs.] Bp. Barlow.
A wooden lining or boarding of the walls of apartments, usuallymade in panels.
Having the leaves or petals arranged in the form of a cross;cruciform.

A final proposition, concession, or condition; especially, thefinal propositions, conditions, or terms, offered by either of theparties in a diplomatic negotiation; the most favorable terms anegotiator can offer, the rejection of which usually puts an end tothe hesitation.
Pertaining to, or derived from, hydantoin. See Glycoluric.
A poisonous narcotic alkaloid extracted from the leaves ofIndian tobacco (Lobelia inflata) as a yellow oil, having atobaccolike taste and odor.
Resembling the smell or taste of roast meat, or of corruptanimal matter. [R.]
A trailing plant (Lysimachia Nummularia), with rounded oppositeleaves and solitary yellow flowers in their axils.
A slave warehouse, or an inclosure where slaves are quarteredtemporarily. Du Chaillu.

A peculiar forcepslike organ which occurs in large numbers uponstarfishes and echini. Those of starfishes have two movable jaws, orblades, and are usually nearly, or quite, sessile; those of echiniusually have three jaws and a pedicel. See Illustration in Appendix.
To be equivalent or equal to; to counterbalance. [R.] Sir T.Browne.
The act of flowing forth; emanation; efflux. [Obs.] Dr. H.More.
The end of a verse or psalm, or something added thereto, to besung by the people, by way of a response.
The pupa state of certain insects, esp. of butterflies, fromwhich the perfect insect emerges. See Pupa, and Aurelia (a).
Manner of linking or of being linked; -- said of the union ofatoms or radicals in the molecule.
Adhering closely; embracing; -- applied to certain creepinganimals, as caterpillars.
An ornamental foliation having four lobes, or foils.
A genus of showy herbaceous or shrubby plant, biought fromSouth America; slipperwort. It has a yellow or purple flower, oftenspotted or striped, the shape of which suggests its name.
That may be kneaded; capable of being worked into a mass.

The state of growing up from childhood to manhood or womanhood;youth, or the period of life between puberty and maturity, generallyconsidered to be, in the male sex, from fourteen to twenty-one.Sometimes used with reference to the lower animals.
Erroneous thought; mistaken opinion; error. [Obs.] Spenser.

An instrument for detecting or measuring minute extension ormovements of solid bodies. It consists essentially of a small rod,disk, or button of carbon, forming part of an electrical circuit, theresistance of which, being varied by the changes of pressure producedby the movements of the object to be measured, causes variations inthe strength of the current, which variations are indicated by asensitive galvanometer. It is also used for measuring minute changesof temperature. T. A. Edison.
Pertaining to Mons Aventinus, one of the seven hills on whichRome stood. Bryant.
The small pyramid which crowns or completes an obelisk.
The protoplasmic matter of which bacteria are composed.
A deadly alkaloid extracted from the curare poison and from theStrychnos toxifera. It is obtained in crystalline colorless salts.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid, HNCS, isomeric withsulphocyanic acid.
Distorted vision, in which straight lines appear bent.
The state or quality of being feudal; feudal form orconstitution. Burke.
To tie with a ligature; to bind around; to bandage.
In Cuba, Mexico, etc., a booth, stall, or shop wheremerchandise is sold.
Sought out with care; choice. Hence: of rare quality, elegance,or attractiveness; peculiar and refined in kind.
Capable of being committed; liable to be committed. [R.] Sir T.Browne.
A fine wide wooled fabric much used for women's dresses.
A place where bricks are made, especially an inclosed place.
Worthy of rebuke or reprehension; reprehensible. Shak.
Having the property of transmitting radiant heat; diathermal; -- opposed to athermanous.
A longitudinal rank, or row, of leaves along a stem.
The act or process of pouring out of one vessel into another.[Obs.] Holland.
To hasten away or along; to move rapidly; to hurry; as, therabbit scurried away.
Standing, but with the wings spread, as if about to fly; --said of a bird borne as a charge on an escutcheon.
A genus of small, hardy trees, including the hawthorn, muchused for ornamental purposes.
A genus of small insectivores including the common Europeanmole.
The science which treats of the nature of truth and evidence.Sir W. Hamilton.
The order of Crustacea which includes the shrimps, lobsters,crabs, etc.
Any one of numerous species of small insectivorous singingbirds belonging to Parus and allied genera; -- called also tit, andtomtit.
Half crystalline; -- said of certain cruptive rocks composedpartly of crystalline, partly of amorphous matter.
The lining of the mantle borne about the shield or escutcheon.
Barium sulphate, generally called heavy spar or barite. SeeBarite.
Particularly concerned for one's own interest or happiness.
The act of arraigning, or the state of being arraigned; the actof calling and setting a prisoner before a court to answer to anindictment or complaint.
A crystalline substance (C5H5N5O) contained in guano. It isalso a constituent of the liver, pancreas, and other glands inmammals.
A hypothetical radical constituting the characteristic residueof tartronic acid and certain of its derivatives.
Of or pertaining to lice; having the lousy distemper(phthiriasis); lousy. Southey.
A prolate spheroid; a figure described by the revolution of anellipse about its greater axis. Cf. Oblatum, and see Ellipsoid ofrevolution, under Ellipsoid.
An earth of a white color resembling lime in appearance, andbaryta in many of its properties. It is an oxide of the metalstrontium.
One who summons; one who cites by authority; specifically, apetty officer formerly employed to summon persons to appear in court;an apparitor.
An oppressive, relaxing wind from the Libyan deserts, chieflyexperienced in Italy, Malta, and Sicily.
One of the joists which rest one end on the wall and the otheron a girder; also, the space between a wall and the nearest girder ofa floor. Cf. Case-bay.
The method of laying on different tints so that they may mingletogether while wet, and shade into each other insensibly. Weale.
The produce of animals yielding milk; milk and that which ismade from it.

An apparatus consisting of a slowly revolving disk, usuallyregulated by  clockwork, by means of wich the action of externalagents, as light and gravity, on growing plants may be regulated oreliminated.
One of a sect which maintained that Christ was the Son of Godnot by nature but by adoption.
A natural or artificial purgation of any passage, as of themouth, bowels, etc.
A kind of helmet worn in the 14th, 15th, and 16th centuries.
Pertaining to a part of the columella of the ear, between thestapes and the mediostapedial.-- n.
Having the surface covered with a fine yellow dust, likepollen.
Presenting hemihedral forms, in which half the sectants havethe full number of planes.
One who watches over another; an overseer; a spy; a supervisor.
The quality or condition of being reciprocal; mutual return;alternateness.

An Australian bird (Ptilonorhynchus violaceus or holosericeus),allied to the starling, which constructs singular bowers orplayhouses of twigs and decorates them with brightcolored objects;the satin bird.
A chloride having a higher proportion of chlorine than anyother chloride of the same substance or series.
The salt of wisdom of the alchemists, a double salt composed ofthe chlorides of ammonium and mercury. It was formerly used as astimulant. Brande & C.

One of the highest classes to which the objects of knowledge orthought can be reduced, and by which they can be arranged in asystem; an ultimate or undecomposable conception; a predicament.The categories or predicaments -- the former a Greek word, the latterits literal translation in the Latin language -- were intended byAristotle and his followers as an enumeration of all things capableof being named; an enumeration by the summa genera i.e., the mostextensive classes into which things could be distributed. J. S. Mill.
The distinctive tenet of the humanitarians in denying thedivinity of Christ; also, the whole system of doctrine based uponthis view of Christ.
To turn form the original or plain meaning; to pervert; towrest. Hammond.
A shovel with a turned-up edge, for frit, sand, etc. [Writtenalso strocal, strocle, strokal.]
The black currant; also, the wild plum. [Prov. Eng.]
To wander as a pilgrim; to go on a pilgrimage. [Obs.] B.Jonson.
A discharge pipe with a valve and spout at which water may bedrawn from the mains of waterworks; a water plug.
To adapt one's self; to be conformable or adapted. [R.] Boyle.
The rapacious larva of a large water beetle (Hydrophiluspiceus), and of other similar species. See Illust. of Water beetle.

. (Bot.) A perennial plant of the genus Caltha (C. palustris),growing in wet places and bearing bright yellow flowers. In theUnited States it is used as a pot herb under the name of cowslip. SeeCowslip.
To feel or express undue care and anxiety; to manifestdisquietude or pain; to be fretful; to chafe; as, the child worries;the horse worries.
To make a dissonant, discordant noise one with another; to talkor chatter noisily. [R.] Daniel.
A pack sack to be swung on either side of a packsaddle.[Western U. S.]
Relating to exogamy; marrying outside of the limits of one'sown tribe; -- opposed to endogenous.
Unsuitableness; unaptness; unfitness; inability. [Obs.] Barrow.
A colorless oily hydrocarbon, C6H5.C3H7, obtained by thedistillation of cuminic acid; -- called also cumol.
The state of being indivisible; indivisibility. W. Montagu.
Many-chambered; -- applied to shells of Foraminifera andcephalopods. See Illust. of Nautilus.
A game at cards, called "High, Low, Jack, and the Game."
Timorous; feeble-minded. [Obs.] "A fainting, silly creature."Arbuthnot.
A small weir or dam in a river to direct the stream to gapswhere fish traps are placed. Knight.
Any one of the numerous species of reptiles belonging to theorder Lacertilia; sometimes, also applied to reptiles of otherorders, as the Hatteria.
A peculiar amyloid substance, colored blue by iodine andsulphuric acid, occurring mainly as an abnormal infiltration into thespleen, liver, etc.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid (commonly calledsulphocyanic acid) which frms a red color with ferric salts.[Obsoles.]
Exposure to the fumes of burning sulphur, as in bleaching; theprocess of bleaching by exposure to the fumes of sulphur.
A genus of endogenous plants, native to Australia, having athick, sometimes arborescent, stem, and long grasslike leaves. SeeGrass tree.
A compound of hydriodic acid with a base; -- distinguished froman iodide, in which only the iodine combines with the base.
Capable of being crumbed or broken into small pieces.
A kind of ordnance, carrying a ball weighing from nine tothirteen pounds.
In the manner of the Latin language; in correct Latin. [Obs.]Heylin.
Work looped or linked after the manner of a chain; chain stitchwork.
One who, or that which, slices; specifically, the circular sawof the lapidary.
A distinction of character; a characteristic. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
The state or quality of being mediate. Sir W. Hamilton.
Reliant upon one's self; trusting to one's own powers orjudgment.
A place where things are or may be reposited, or laid up, forsafety or preservation; a depository. Locke.
Having a covering of bony plates, resembling a cuirass;- saidof certain fishes.
An organ in which spermatozoa are developed; a sperm gland; atesticle.
Made hard, or compact; made unfeeling or callous; madeobstinate or obdurate; confirmed in error or vice.

Am alkaloidal principle obtained from the celandine, and namedfrom the red color of its salts, It is a coloriess crystallinesubstance, and acts as an acrid narcotic poison. It is identical withsanguinarine.
To sail again; also, to sail back, as to a former port.
The act or process of subjecting anything to the action ofchlorine; especially, a process for the extraction of gold byexposure of the auriferous material to chlorine gas.
A rude four-wheeled, springless wagon, used among the Russians.
A melted mass of turpentine, tallow, etc., with which themasts, sides, and bottom of a ship are smeared for lubrication. Ham.Nav. Encyc.
One of two small sticks of wood, ivory, etc., used by theChinese and Japanese to convey food to the mouth.
Without a placenta, as marsupials and monotremes.-- n.
The obtaining of benefice from Rome by solicitation, whichbenefice belonged to the disposal of the king or other lay patron ofthe realm.
Pertaining to, or having the character of, a digression;departing from the main purpose or subject. T. Warton.
A mineral of a violet-blue color, inclining to gray and white.It is a hydrous fluoride of cerium, yttrium, and calcium.
Default of apperance, as in court, to prosecute or defend;failure to appear.
Tendency to emission; comparative facility of emission, or rateat which emission takes place, as of heat from the surface of aheated body.
A small mortar on a gun carriage, in use before the howitzer.

A liberty, privilege, or advantage, which one proprietor has inthe estate of another proprietor, distinct from the ownership of thesoil, as a way, water course, etc. It is a species of what the civillaw calls servitude. Kent.
A genus of trees, some species of which produce edible fruit;the mulberry. See Mulberry.
An order of reptiles including the crocodiles, gavials,alligators, and many extinct kinds.
An instrument for examining the condition of the ear.

Designating, or pertaining to, an important linguistic stock ofNorth American Indians of the southwestern United States andnorthwestern Mexico, nearly all agriculturists and adept potters andbasket makers. Their usual dwelling is the brush wikiup, and in theirnative state they wear little clothing. The Yuma, Maricopa, Mohave,Walapi, and Yavapai are among the chief tribes, all of fine physique.
An ornament in the form of two or more bands or strings twistedover each other in a continued series, leaving circular openingswhich are filled with round ornaments.
A woven fabric originally made of camel's hair, now chiefly ofgoat's hair and silk, or of wool and cotton. [Sometimes writtencamelot and camblet.]

In some columns, that part of the capital between thetermination of the shaft and the annulet of the echinus, or the spacebetween two neck moldings; -- called also neck of the capital, andhypotrachelium. See Illust. of Column.
A kind of silk lace or light netting, used for veils, etc.
Tending or serving to heal; healing. [Obs.] Ecclus. xv. 3.
An allowance of a certain rate per cent for the leaking ofcasks, or waste of liquors by leaking.
A piece of lean meat without bone; sometimes, a long striprolled together and tied.
An Austrian silver coin equal to ten kreutzers, or about fivecents.
One of an extinct sect, named after Ludovic Muggleton, anEnglish journeyman tailor, who (about 1657) claimed to be inspired.Eadie.
An adjustable gage, with double points for transferringmeasurements from one timber to another, as the breadth of a mortiseto the place where the tenon is to be made. Knight.
Any one of a series of unsaturated metameric hydrocarbons,C7H12, of the acetylene series.
Belonging to, or partaking of the nature of, a pronoun.
To practice the business of insuring; to take a risk ofinsurance on a vessel or the like.
Low, wet ground; a marsh; a fen; a bog; a moor. [Archaic]Milton. Tennyson.
The region of the skull between the two parietal foramina wherethe closure of the sagittal suture usually begins.
The condition or quality of being immobile; fixedness in placeor state.
Capable of being compelled or constrained. Blackstone.
A liquid hydrocarbon, C5H8; -- called also pentine.
Robbery on the high seas; the taking of property from others onthe open sea by open violence; without lawful authority, and withintent to steal; -- a crime answering to robbery on land.
One who, or that which, crisps or curls; an instrument formaking little curls in the nap of cloth, as in chinchilla.
A polygon or plane figure with nine sides and nine angles; anonagon.
Something done or said in honor of the dead; obsequies. [Obs.]Abp. Potter.
In a polite or courtly manner; like a gallant or wooer.
Daring without judgment; foolishly adventurous and bold.Howell.
Contrived, done, or existing subsequently. "Postliminious afterapplications of them to their purposes." South.
Filings of metal. [Obs.] "An ounce . . . of silver lymaille."Chaucer.
In a solid manner; densely; compactly; firmly; truly.
A train whose coaches are connected so as to have through itsentire length a continuous corridor, into which the compartmentsopen. [Eng.]
Of or pertaining to movement produced by action of the mind orwill.
A process in which mercury, or some of its salts, is employedto impart the property of felting to certain kinds of furs. Ure.
A small intrenchment or work of palisades, or of sacks ofearth.
The act of connoting; a making known or designating somethingadditional; implication of something more than is asserted.
The quality or state of being mute; speechlessness.
To separate, as the more volatile or soluble parts of asubstance, by distillation or other chemical processes. In this senseextract is now more generally used.
A feather which has a plumelike web, with the shaft of anordinary feather.
The arrangement and proportioning of windows; -- used by modernwriters for the decorating of an architectural composition by meansof the window (and door) openings, their ornaments, and proportions.
Full of tact; characterized by a discerning sense of what isright, proper, or judicious.
A hanger-on to noblemen, or persons of quality, especially inEnglish universities; a toady. See 1st Tuft, 3. [Cant, Eng.]Halliwell.
Characterized by unequal toes, three turned forward and onebackward, as in most passerine birds.
A delirious picking of bedclothes by a sick person, as if topick off flocks of wool; carphology; -- an alarming symptom in acutediseases. Dunglison.
Farthest inward; most remote from the outward part; inmost;deepest within. Prov. xviii. 8.
A piece of metal prepared to be made into something by afurther operation, as a coin, screw, nuts.
A live or glowing coal; a glede. [Archaic] Chaucer. Longfellow.
Having a completely idiomorphic structure; -- said of certainrocks.
To bid less than, as when a contract or service is offered tothe lowest bidder; to offer to contract, sell, or do for a less pricethan.
A material for carpeting or floor covering, made of ground corkand caoutchouc or India rubber.
A man who makes and leaves a will, or testament, at death.
A secondary spiral in phyllotaxy, as one of the evident spiralsin a pine cone.
The quality of being advisable or expedient; expediency;advisability.
An ideal machine; a combination of movable bodies constitutinga machine, but considered only with regard to relative movements.
The calling sound made by cows and other bovine animals.
The Greek goddess of love, corresponding to the Venus of theRomans.
In a bad manner; poorly; not well; unskillfully; imperfectly;unfortunately; grievously; so as to cause harm; disagreeably;seriously.
1. To place in a spread-eagle position, especially as a meansof punishment. 2. being in a position with the arms and legs extendedfully.
A tincture with more than one base; a compound tincture ormedicine, composed of various substances, held in solution by alcoholin some form.
A large, handsomely colored, marine univalve shell (Fasciolariatulipa) native of the Southern United States. The name is sometimesapplied also to other species of Fasciolaria.
A size of type between long primer and brevier. See Type.
An assembly; hence, the place of assembly, especially themarket place, in an ancient Greek city.
A breed of dogs having erect ears and long silky hair, usuallywhite; -- called also Pomeranian dog, and louploup.
The trichloride of gold combination with the chloride ofanother metal, forming a double chloride; -- called also chloraurate.
A diminutive scale or bractlet, such as those found on thereceptacle in many composite plants; a palea.
Water breaking in upon the miners at their work; -- so calledamong tin miners. [Prov. Eng.]
A plant (Subularia aquatica), with awl-shaped leaves.
The series or division of flowerless plants, or those neverhaving true stamens and pistils, but propagated by spores of variouskinds.
A longitudinal opening in a body, made by cutting; a cleft; afissure. Hammond.

A coil of small resistance and large inductance, used in analternating-current circuit to impede or throttle the current, or tochange its phase; --called also reactance coil or reactor, theseterms being now preferred in engineering usage.
Fine white bread; a loaf of fine bread. [Archaic] Bacon.Tennyson.
The state of being a mother; the character or office of amother.
A division of marine gastropods in which the gills aredeveloped on both sides of the body and the renal organs are alsopaired. The abalone (Haliotis) and the keyhole limpet (Fissurella)are examples.
The tendency of a root to place its axis in the line of agalvanic current.
A house where a stage regularly stops for passengers or a relayof horses.
A rock of igneous origin, consisting of augite and triclinicfeldspar, with grains of magnetic or titanic iron, and also bottle-green particles of olivine frequently disseminated.
A paramour; a loose woman; also, a gay, idle fellow. [Obs.]Spenser.
To make a series of small, sharp, rapidly repeated explosionsor sounds, as salt in fire; to crackle; to snap.
An extinct Miocene mammal of the Horse family, closely relatedto the genus Anhithecrium, and having three usable hoofs on eachfoot.
The quality or state of being popular; popularity. Coleridge.
A brownish black mineral with a metallic luster, found inNorway. It contains niobium, titanium, yttrium, and uranium, withsome other metals.
Serving no purpose; superfluous; needless. [Obs.] Howell.
Tawny; dull yellow, with a mixture of gray and brown. Lindley.
One who serves an emperor; one who favors imperialism.
Flour made of aleurone, used as a substitute for ordinary flourin preparing bread for diabetic persons.
A king and lawgiver of Crete, fabled to be the son of Jupiterand Europa. After death he was made a judge in the Lower Regions.
That branch of Christian science which treats of the methods ofsecuring unity among Christians or harmony and union among thechurches; -- called also Irenical theology. Schaff-Herzog.
Pertaining to, or advocating, the non-extension of slavery; --esp. applied to a party which was active during the period 1846-1856.[U.S.] -- Free"soil`er, n. [U.S.] -- Free"-soil`ism, n. [U.S.]
To cut or clip with a knife; to whittle. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]Chaucer.
One of the family of fishes of which the sturgeon is the type.
An extravagant or absurd report or story; a fabricatedsensational report or statement; esp. one set afloat in thenewspapers to hoax the public.
A fibrous material used for tying plants, said to come from theleaves of a palm tree of the genus Raphia. J. Smith (Dict. Econ.Plants).
A motor car to which the current is conveyed by means of atrolley.
A curve, of the fourth degree, first made use of by the Greekgeometer, Nicomedes, who invented it for the purpose of trisecting anangle and duplicating the cube.

The indirect division of cells in which, prior to division ofthe cell protoplasm, complicated changes take place in the nucleus,attended with movement of the nuclear fibrils; -- opposed tokaryostenosis. The nucleus becomes enlarged and convoluted, andfinally the threads are separated into two groups which ultimatelybecome disconnected and constitute the daughter nuclei. Called alsomitosis. See Cell development, under Cell.
Work or things made for sale; hence, work done carelessly orslightingly. Shak.

One of certain public pawnbroking establishments whichoriginated in Italy in the 15th century, the object of which was tolend money at a low rate of interest to poor people in need; --called also mount of piety. The institution has been adopted in othercountries, as in Spain and France. See Lombard-house.
To deny and reject; to abjure. Sir E. Sandys. Farrar.
An apartment or division in a building; a room or chamber.
Of or pertaining to health, or the laws of health; sanitary.
Producing by propagation, or by a process of growth.
To pack, or prepare for packing, by means of a press.
The quality or state of being profound; profundity; depth.Hooker.
Having a structure entirely cellular, and no distinct sexualorgans; -- a term applied by De Candolle to the lowest order ofplants.
A racing stroke, in which the swimmer, lying flat on the waterwith face submerged, takes alternate overhand arm strokes whilemoving his legs up and down alternately from the knee.
The quality of that which is fungous; fungous excrescence.Dunglison.
Any one of several species of parrots of the genus Coracopsis,native of Madagascar; -- called also vasa parrot.
One who adheres to the letter or exact word; an interpreteraccording to the letter.
An order of extinct Mammalia found in the Tertiary formations.
Having tufts of soft hairs, which are often deciduous.

An instrument consisting essentially of a glass tube providedwith a graduated scale, for exhibiting to the eye the changes ofvolume of a gas or gaseous mixture resulting from chemical action,and the like.
Naked; having no floral envelope, neither calyx nor corolla.
That which is in the form of prose writing; a prosaic manner.Coleridge.
The state of being productible; producibility. Ruskin.
Earth flax, or mountain flax; a soft silky variety of asbestus.
A sail sometimes carried in light winds, above a skysail. R. H.Dana, Jr.
A woman who becomes sponsor for a child in baptism. SeeGodfather
A hypothetical radical, CH3O, analogous to hydroxyl.
One who makes or fits stocks, as of guns or gun carriages, etc.
A hook for holding the blubber while cutting it away. [Writtenalso cranging hook.]
A kind of cloth, usually cotton, made in imitation of velvet;cotton velvet.
Pertaining to, or consisting of, a topic or topics; accordingto topics.
Having no antecedent cause; uncreated; self-existent; eternal.A. Baxter.
Having the shape of a placenta, or circular thickened disksomewhat thinner about the middle.
One skilled un, or attached to, a ritual; one who advocates orpractices ritualism.
Situated beyond, or outside of, the tropics; extratropical;also, having an excessively tropical temperature; warmer than thetropics.
The art of writing or inscribing characters on pillars. [R.]Stackhouse.
A method of sinking through water-bearing ground, in which theshaft is lined with tubbing and provided with an air lock, work beingproceeded with under air pressure.

In law and common usage: An undertaking to answer for thepayment of some debt, or the performance of some contract or duty, ofanother, in case of the failure of such other to pay or perform; aguarantee; a warranty; a security.
Relating to the inspection of entrails for prognostication.[Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A widely used system of electric night signals in which aseries of double electric lamps (white and red) is arrangedvertically on a mast, and operated from a keyboard below.
The sound of a patient's voice so modified as to resemble thebleating of a goat, heard on applying the ear to the chest in certaindiseases within its cavity, as in pleurisy with effusion.
In a nautical manner; with reference to nautical affais.
The yellowlegs; -- called also stone snipe. See Tattler, 2.[Local, U.S.]
With one breve, or four minims, to measure, and sung fasterlike four crotchets; in quick common time; -- indicated in the timesignature by
One who saps; specifically (Mil.), one who is employed inworking at saps, building and repairing fortifications, and the like.
Tending to prove; having the power to demonstrate;demonstrative; indicative.
Under, or at the foot of, the Apennine mountains; -- applied,in geology, to a series of Tertiary strata of the older Plioceneperiod.

A species of divination, which was perforned by letting down amirror into water, for a sick person to look at his face in it. Ifhis countenance appeared distorted and ghastly, it was an ill omen;if fresh and healthy, it was favorable.
Arrayed, prepared, or furnished, unsuitably. [Archaic] Bp.Hall.
One who has care or custody, as of some public building; akeeper or superintendent.
Of or pertaining to a ventriloquist or ventriloquism.
The act of pounding or breaking in a mortar; pestillation.[Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
The two canonical books of the Old Testament in whichimmediately follow 2 Kings.
Consisting or partaking of marl; resembling marl; aboundingwith marl.

In the Buddhist system of religion, the final emancipation ofthe soul from transmigration, and consequently a beatificenfrachisement from the evils of wordly existence, as by annihilationor absorption into the divine. See Buddhism.
Measurement of the heart, as by percussion or auscultation.
Supported on both sides by other charges; also, side by side.
A biennial plant of the Parsley family (Carum Carui). The seedshave an aromatic smell, and a warm, pungent taste. They are used incookery and confectionery, and also in medicine as a carminative.
One of the round variety of bacteria, a vegetable organism,generally less than a thousandth of a millimeter in diameter.
A master in any art, especially in music; a composer.
Educated by one's own efforts, without instruction, or withoutpecuniary assistance from others.
Communion with one's self; thoughts about one's self.
Of or relating to, or using, a double metallic standard (asgold and silver) for a system of coins or currency.
A crystalline substance closely related to xanthin, present insmall quantity in urine.
History of the evolution of forms; that part of ontogeny thatdeals with the germ history of forms; -- distinguished fromphysiogeny. Haeckel.
One who testifies; one who gives testimony, or bears witness toprove anything; a witness.
Pertaining to, or having the characteristics of, negroes, or ofthe Negritos, Papuans, and the Melanesian races; negritic.

A genus of plants, several species of which have very beautifulflowers; -- so called because the elastic capsules burst whentouched, and scatter the seeds with considerable force. Called alsotouch-me-not, jewelweed, and snapweed. I. Balsamina (sometimes calledlady's slipper) is the common garden balsam.
A denier or opponent of Christ. Specif.: A great antagonist,person or power, expected to precede Christ's second coming.

A fatty substance, extracted from animal fats and certainvegetable oils, formerly supposed to be a definite compound ofglycerin and margaric acid, but now known to be simply a mixture orcombination of tristearin and teipalmitin.
That portion of the labium which bears the palpi in insects.
The act or art of using a typewriter; also, a print made with atypewriter.
A genus of small, crooked trees, growing in tropical America.
To twitch; to cause to twitch convulsively.Convulsions, arising from something vellicating a nerve in itsextremity, are not very dangerous. Arbuthnot.
The act of floating on the surface of a fluid. Sir T. Browne.

A substance contained in both Brazil wood and Sapan wood, fromwhich it is extracted as a yellow crystalline substance which iswhite when pure. It is colored intensely red by alkalies. [Writtenalso brezilin.]
Shaped like a club; grasped like, or used as, a club. Skelton.
Very busy; attentive to business; active. [R.] D. Rogers.
A continuous level range of brick or stones of the same heightthroughout the face or faces of a building. Gwilt.
Bearing inscription; of the character or nature of aninscription.
A prominence on the posterior part of the thalamus of the humanbrain.
Concord or correspondence of one word with another in gender,number, case, or person.
Carelessness; heedlessness; thoughtlessness; unconcern.
To run with affected precipitation; to hurry; to bustle; toscuddle.With the first dawn of day, old Janet was scuttling about the houseto wake the baron. Sir W. Scott.
A channel cut behind the brick lining of a shaft. Raymond.
A round piece of timber at the bow or stern of a whaleboat,around which the harpoon lone is run out when the whale darts off.
A crystallizable compound of a salt with alcohol, in which thelatter plays a part analogous to that of water of crystallization.Graham.
An affection of the eye, in which the patient perceivesluminous rays, flashes, coruscations, etc. See phosphene.
To cover or decorate with slender pieces of wood, metal, ivory,etc.; to inlay. [Obs.] Spenser.
Forwards; towards the head or anterior extremity of the body;opposed to caudad.
Systematized knowledge of the action and functions of thelarynx; in pathology, the department which treats of the diseases ofthe larynx.
A genus of endogenous bulbous plants with handsome flowers,having a cup-shaped crown within the six-lobed perianth, andcomprising the daffodils and jonquils of several kinds.
A line used to get a straight middle line, as on a spar, orfrom stem to stern in building a vessel.
The state of being unpolluted; purity. [Obs.] Donne.
A prism of an orthorhombic crystal between the macropinacoidand the unit prism; the corresponding pyramids are calledmacropyramids.

A strong nitrogenous base, C3H6N6, produced from severalcyanogen compounds, and obtained as a white crystalline substance, --formerly supposed to be produced by the decomposition of melam.Called also cyanuramide.
A kind of pudding made of paste spread with fruit, rolled intoa cylindrical form, and boiled or steamed.-- a.
A leather case for a pistol, carried by a horseman at the bowof his saddle.
The act or process of combining or impregnating with sulphur orits compounds; also, the state of being so combined or impregnated.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by theoxidation of sycoceryl alcohol.
Dividing into three parts; -- said of a number which exactlydivides another into three parts.
A liquid hydrocarbon, C11H24, of the methane series, found inpetroleum; -- so called from its containing eleven carbon atoms inthe molecule.
That which loosens; -- esp., a muscle which by its contractionloosens some part.
The yard or inclosure attached to a barn, or the space inclosedby the farm buildings.

The science of the refraction of light; that part ofgeometrical optics which treats of the laws of the refraction oflight in passing from one medium into another, or through differentmediums, as air, water, or glass, and esp. through different lenses;-- distinguished from catoptrics, which refers to reflected light.
To harden, as a metal, by hammering it in the cold state.
The act of operation of drying; evaporation or expulsion ofmoisture; state of being dried up; dryness. Sir T. Browne.
The conversion of food, in the stomach and intestines, intosoluble and diffusible products, capable of being absorbed by theblood.
The cavity in the skull in which the parts of the internal earare lodged.
A fee, or toll, paid for the weighing of merchandise.
A mineral of the feldspar family, triclinic in crystallization,and in composition a silicate of alumina and soda. It is a commonconstituent of granite and of various igneous rocks. See Feldspar.
A light fabric, originally made in the East Indies, of silk andlinen, usually having alternating stripes, and a slightly craped orpuckered surface; also, a cotton fabric of similar appearance.
Literally, inflammation of the spine, but commonly applied tothe rickets. See Rickets.
The scaly covering of the foot of a bird or reptile.
To slip on the whelps or the barrel of a capstan or windlass; -- said of a cable or hawser.
A gradual passing from one tint to another or from a darker toa lighter shade, as in painting or drawing.
A body of soldiers serving on foot; foot soldiers, indistinction from cavalry.
To render trifling or futile; to make silly. [R.] Coleridge.
(Anat.) One of the bones at the base of a paired fin of a fish.
A case in which certain goods, as tea, opium, etc., aretransported; hence, the quantity which such a case contains.
A person appointed by law to take charge of goods, etc., thrownon shore after a shipwreck.
A condition of bone cartilage occurring in certain diseases ofthese tissues, in which they acquire an unnatural density, and cometo resemble ivory.
The art or practice of constructing verses correctly; the lawsof correct versification.
The yellow gentian (Gentiana lutea), which has a very bittertaste.
To act as a pettifogger; to use contemptible tricks. DeQuincey.
An instrument of the saxhorn family, used exclusively inmilitary music, often replacing the French horn. Grove.
A silk-producing moth (Attacus Pernyi) which feeds upon theoak. It has been introduced into Europe and America from China.

Calcium carbonate, or carbonate of lime. It is rhombohedral inits crystallization, and thus distinguished from aragonite. Itincludes common limestone, chalk, and marble. Called also calc-sparand calcareous spar.
A glass which makes a single object appear as many; amultiplying glass. Hutton.
By right; of right; by law; -- often opposed to be facto.
Pertaining to the dauphin of France; as, the Delphin classics,an edition of the Latin classics, prepared in the reign of LouisXIV., for the use of the dauphin (in usum Delphini).
Alluvial matter on the surface of land, not of recent origin.R. Jameson.
To plow the third time before sowing, as land. Mortimer.
A genus of free-swimming macruran Crustacea, having a slenderbody and long appendages.
Any plant of the genus Trifolium, which includes the whiteclover, red clover, etc.; -- less properly, applied also to thenonesuch, or black medic. See Clover, and Medic.
As much as a trunk will hold; enough to fill a trunk.
A summoner; esp., one who summons to an ecclesiastical court.[Obs.] Piers Plowman.
A kind of baize of which the ward is cotton and the weftwoolen. Blakely.
To transport with pleasure; to delight beyond measure; toenravish. Shenstone.
To bore through; to pierce through with a pointed instrument;to make a hole or holes through by boring or piercing; to pierce orpenetrate the surface of. Bacon.
An instrument for ascertaining the strength of an indigosolution, as in volumetric analysis. Ure.
The fluid portion of the cell protoplasm, in opposition tostereoplasm, the solid or insoluble portion. The latter is supposedto be partly nutritive and partly composed of idioplasm.
To disclose, or lay open; to unbosom. [Obs.] P. Fletcher,
A tool applied to the top of the work, in distinction from atool inserted in the anvil and on which the work is placed.
An end; conclusion. It is often placed at the end of a book.
A little finger or toe, or something resembling one.
An extensive genus of fossil ferns, of which species have beenfound from the Devonian to the Triassic formation.
The act of torturing; torture; torment. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
The small, whitish brown fruit of an East Indian tree (Lansiumdomesticum). It has a fleshy pulp, with an agreeable subacid taste.Balfour.
Having large hands, Fig.: Taking, or giving, in largequantities; rapacious or bountiful.
The want of likelihood; improbability. Sir W. Scott.
A person appointed according to law to try challenges ofjurors; a trior. Burrill.
Intermediate; not final or definitive; made or done during theprogress of an action.
An incision of the urethra, esp. incision for relief ofurethral stricture.
False or depraved sight; imaginary vision of objects. Forsyth.
Incapable of being daunted; intrepid; fearless; indomitable.Bp. Hall.
The keyboard of an organ, pianoforte, or harmonium.
A tracing of the respiratory movements, obtained by apneumatograph or stethograph.
