That part of a pilaster which is between the base and thecapital, corresponding to the shaft of a column.
A condition in which, from insufficient aCyanopathy.
Bromine; -- formerly so called from its being obtained from seawater.
The repetition of a word, or part of a sentence, for the sakeof greater emphasis; as, "The living, the living, he shall praisethee." Is. xxxviii. 19.
The days immediately preceding Ash Widnesday, especially theperiod between the evening before Quinguagesima Sunday and themorning of Ash Wednesday.
Small shot which scatter like hailstones. [Obs.] Hayward.
One who holds the doctrine that the space between the bodies ofthe universe, or the molecules and atoms of matter., is a vacuum; --opposed to plenist.
The liberty or right of pasture in the forest or in the groundsof another man. Blount.
To affect or be affected with anchylosis; to unite orconsolidate so as to make a stiff joint; to grow together into one.[Spelt also ankylose.] Owen.
The science of figures having equal perimeters or boundaries.
The act or operation of clearing of knots, or of untying;hence, also, the solution of a difficulty. [R.] Bailey.
An officer who ascertains meres or boundaries. [Eng.]
Applied under the glaze, that is, before the glaze, that is,before the glaze is put on; fitted to be so applied; -- said ofcolors in porcelain painting.
Examination of the abdomen to detect abdominal disease.
A cannon mounted on wheels, for the use of a marching army; apiece of field artillery; -- called also field gun.
The act or business of instructing; also, that which is taught;instruction.
One of the small nodules sometimes found in the neighborhood ofthe spleen; an accessory or supplementary spleen.
The supreme deity, king of gods and men, and reputed to be theson of Saturn and Rhea; Jove. He corresponds to the Greek Zeus.
To black or foul with soot. [R.]Sootied with noisome smoke. Chapman.
A measure of length; the thousandth part of one millimeter; themillionth part of a meter.
Satisfied with one's own character, capacity, and doings; self-satisfied.
Movables of an inferior description; especially, such as havebeen collected by depredation. [Scot]
One who advocates the undulatory theory of light. Whewell.
To domineer over; to affront; to treat with indignity. [Obs.]Chaucer.
A tap or stamp of the foot as a warning of intent to attack; --called also attack.
The coloring matter of saffron; -- formerly so called becauseof the change of color on treatment with certain acids; -- calledalso crocin, and safranin.
The fine shag or nap of velvet; a piece of velvet; velvetgoods.
Not stratified; -- applied to massive rocks, as granite,porphyry, etc., and also to deposits of loose material, as theglacial till, which occur in masses without layers or strata.
A shrub (Cephalanthus occidentalis) growing by the waterside; -- so called from its globular head of flowers. See Capitulum.

In its etymological signification, the science of the stars;among the ancients, synonymous with astronomy; subsequently, the artof judging of the influences of the stars upon human affairs, and offoretelling events by their position and aspects.
A thorough searching; a minute inquiry or scrutiny. Carlyle
A kind of cake filled with custard made of cream, eggs, etc.
A division of mammals including the apes and monkeys. Sometimesused in the sense of Primates.
Canary seed, hemp, millet or other small seeds used for feedingcaged birds.
The act or process of freeing from nitrogen; also, thecondition resulting from the removal of nitrogen.
The seaman or seamen stationed on the poop or after part of theship, to attend the after-sails. Totten.
A soldier of a privileged military class, which formed thenucleus of the Turkish infantry, but was suppressed in 1826. [writtenalso janissary.]

A name given to several species of Arctostaphylos, but mostlyto A. glauca and A. pungens, shrubs of California, Oregon, etc., withreddish smooth bark, ovate or oval coriaceous evergreen leaves, andbearing clusters of red berries, which are said to be a favorite foodof the grizzly bear.
An instrument for determining the size or distance ofinaccessible objects by means of two reflectors on a common sextant.
The state or quality of being heavenly. Sir J. Davies.
A building or place where salt is made by boiling or byevaporation; salt works.
The act of filling up with earth, or of forming land withalluvial earth. [Obs.]
A common American singing bird (Harporhynchus rufus), allied tothe mocking bird; -- also called brown thrasher.
An oscillating bar in a machine, as the lever of the bellows ofa forge.

Hard and fine stones in general, such as are used for inlay andthe like, as distinguished from the softer stones used in building;thus, a Florentine mosaic is a familiar instance of work in pietradura, though the ground may be soft marble.
A white, waxy substance, forming the essential part ofspermaceti.
The invasion, approach, or commencement of a disease; a fit orparoxysm.
A group of mammals which formerly included the Carnivora,Insectivora, Marsupialia, and lemurs, but is now often restricted tothe Carnivora.
A disease of horses and cattle accompanied by carbuncles in themouth and on the tongue.
A mixture of constituents, as of the blood; constitution;temperament.

A type of orange in which the fruit incloses a small secondaryfruit, the rind showing on the exterior a navel-like pit ordepression at the apex. There are several varieties; they are usuallyseedless, or nearly so, and are much grown in California.
The quality or state of being univocal. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Native sulphate of copper. Cf. Blue vitriol, under Blue.
The first five books of the Old Testament, collectively; --called also the Law of Moses, Book of the Law of Moses, etc.
To place in huts; to live in huts; as, to hut troops in winterquarters.The troops hutted among the heights of Morristown. W. Irving.
To exalt to a superior degree; to exalt above others. Barrow.
One who forms ideas or conceptions; one who contrives. Bacon.
An aromatic and pungent plant of the genus Mentha (M.piperita), much used in medicine and confectionery.
A lifting or sliding door covering an opening in a roof orfloor.
A native prince or king; also, a landholder or person ofimportance in the agricultural districts. [India]
One who, or that which, expounds or explains; an expounder; acommentator. Bp. Horsley.
A singular nocturnal quadruped, allied to the lemurs, found inMadagascar (Cheiromys Madagascariensis), remarkable for its longfingers, sharp nails, and rodent-like incisor teeth.
Freedom from agitation or excitement of mind; coolness intrying circumstances; indifference; calmness. Burke.
A picture representing or symbolizing the early infancy ofChrist. The simplest form is the babe in a rude cradle, and the headsof an ox and an ass to express the stable in which he was born.
Having a sour, disagreeable countenance. Beau & Fl.
To energize or excite (the field magnets of a dynamo) byinduction from the residual magnetism of its cores, leading all or apart of the current thus produced through the field-magnet coils.
To ingraft by cleaving the stock and inserting a scion.Mortimer.
The monthly courses of women; menstrual discharges; menses.
One who raises coal out of the hold of a ship. [Eng.] Dickens.

An apparatus for delivering measured quantities of liquid orfor measuring the quantity of liquid or gas received or discharged.It consists essentially of a graduated glass tube, usually furnishedwith a small aperture and stopcock.

Originally, a covered porch with seats, at a house door; theDutch stoep as introduced by the Dutch into New York. Afterward, anout-of-door flight of stairs of from seven to fourteen steps, withplatform and parapets, leading to an entrance door some distanceabove the street; the French perron. Hence, any porch, platform,entrance stairway, or small veranda, at a house door. [U. S.]
Actuated by avarice; greedy of gain; immoderately desirous ofaccumulating property.

An exceedingly faint roundish or somewhat oblong nebulous lightnear the ecliptic and opposite the sun, best seen during Septemberand October, when in the constellations Sagittarius and Pisces. Itscause is not yet understood. Called also Gegenschein.
The revocation or taking away of a grant donation, legacy, orthe like. Bouvier.
Of or pertaining to the sinciput; being in the region of thesinciput.
The side or slope of a hill; sloping ground; a descent. [U. S.]
Pertaining to the order of plants including the soursop,custard apple, etc.
A thorny leguminous tree (Gleditschia monosperma) which growsin the swamps of the Mississippi valley.
A carbonate of baryta and lime, intermediate between witheriteand strontianite; -- called also alstonite.
The emblem of the increasing moon with horns directed upward,when used in a coat of arms; -- often used as a mark of cadency todistinguish a second son and his descendants.
The primitive formative juice, from which the tissues,particularly the cellular tissue, are formed.
A level plain, usually with a steep front, bordering a river, alake, or sometimes the sea.
A vessel for holding hot water in which another vessel may beheated without scorching its contents; -- used for warming orpreparing food or pharmaceutical preparations.
In drawing and line engraving, shading with lines that crossone another at an angle.
A European skate (Raia clavata) having thornlike spines on itsback.
The act of one who, or that which, succeeds; also, that whichsucceeds, or follows after; consequence. Shak.
A figure of speech in which the orator implores the assistanceof God or man.
One of the calicles which, in some Hydroidea (Thecaphora),protect the hydrants. See Illust. of Hydroidea, and Campanularian.

One of the shooting stars which constitute the star shower thatrecurs near the fourteenth of November at intervals of about thirty-three years; so called because shooting stars appear on the heavensto move in lines directed from the constellation Leo.
Destitute of mettle, that is, or fire or spirit. [R.]Llewellyn.
Paper covered on one side with sand glued fast, -- used forsmoothing and polishing.

A plant belonging to one of the greater part of the vegetablekingdom, and which the plants are characterized by having c woodbark, and pith, the wood forming a layer between the other two, andincreasing, if at all, by the animal addition of a new layer to theoutside next to the bark. The leaves are commonly netted-veined, andthe number of cotyledons is two, or, very rarely, several in a whorl.Cf. Endogen. Gray.
The jet piece of a gas fixture where the gas is burned as itescapes from one or more minute orifices.
One who enhances; one who, or that which, raises the amount,price, etc.
A series or group of brackets; brackets, collectively.
Pulpy throughout, like a berry; -- said of fruits. Gray.
A performer on some instrument, as the violin or the piano, whoexcels in the technical part of his art; a brilliant concert player.
The act of turning into allegory, or of understanding in anallegorical sense.
Originally, a laborer on canals for internal navigation; hence,a laborer on other public works, as in building railroads,embankments, etc. [Eng.]
One who punctuates, as in writing; specifically, a punctator.
The line of junction or cohering face of two carpels, as in theparsnip, caraway, etc.
A group intermediate between a family and a suborder.
Given to wine; drunken; intemperate. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A stalk or shoot of sugar cane of the first growth from thecutting. The growth of the second and following years is of inferiorquality, and is called rattoon.
A violent whirlwind; specifically, a violent whirlwindoccurring in the Chinese seas.
The frontier of a country; confines. [Obs.] Shelton.
To deprive of an elder or elders, or of the office of an elder.[Obs.] Fuller.
Of or pertaining to phantasmagoria; phantasmagorial. Hawthorne.
One of a number of processes by which an impression from anengraved plate is obtained in relief, to be used for printing on anordinary printing press.
The bone or shell of cuttlefish. See Illust. under Cuttlefish.
A joint heir; one of two or more heirs; one of several entitledto an inheritance.

Indigo red, a product of the decomposition, or oxidation, ofindican. It is sometimes found in the sediment of pathologicalurines. It is soluble in ether or alcohol, giving the solution abeautiful red color. Also called indigrubin.
Excessive and constant thirst occasioned by disease.
One who, or that which, cremmates or consumes to ashes.
One of a group which includes the higher orders of mammals,having a large size as a typical characteristic.
The state or quality of being near; -- used in the varioussenses of the adjective.
Pertaining to, or situated in, the region of the front of theorbit.-- n.

A mineral having many varieties differing in color and in theirconstituents, but with the same crystallization (isometric), andconforming to the same general chemical formula. The commonest coloris red, the luster is vitreous, and the hardness greater than that ofquartz. The dodecahedron and trapezohedron are the common forms.
Very strongly; mightily; to a great degree. [Obs.] Bacon. Shak.
A compound, originally made from gun cotton and castor oil, butlater from different materials, and used as a substitute forvulcanized India rubber and for ivory; -- called also xylotile.
The territory or authority of a seignior, or lord. Milman.
An instrument used for the purpose of obtaining specimens ofwater from any desired depth, as in a river, a lake, or the ocean.
A post at the fork of a road, with a guideboard on it, todirect travelers.
That departnent of historical theology which treats of thelives and doctrines of the Fathers of the church.
To give too important or difficult a part to. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
Resembling the olive; of the color of the olive; olive-green.
The act of affixing, or the state of being affixed; attachment.
A laminated, granular, siliceous rocks, often occurring inregions where the diamond is found.
A machine for breaking open the kernels of wheat or other grainand removing the germs.
A tumor composed mainly of bone; a tumor of a bone.
One who wastes time in trifling employments; an idler; atrifler.
Change of termination of words, as in declension, conjugation,derivation, etc.
To form into, or put in the form of, a participle. [R.]
A covering placed over the upper part of a horse's head.
The act of forming in resemblance; an effigy. Fuller.
The branch of paleontology which treats of fossil birds.
In a beneficial or advantageous manner; profitably; helpfully.
The state or quality of being flinty; hardness; cruelty. Beau.& Fl.
One who reclaims; one who cries out against or contradicts.
The act or process of repairing lesions made by ulcers,especially by a plastic operation.
A highly contagious distemper or murrain, affecting neatcattle, and less commonly sheep and goats; -- called also cattleplague, Russian cattle plague, and steppe murrain.

A genus of extinct mammals from the eocene tertiary of Europeand America. Its species varied in size between the tapir andrhinoceros, and were allied to those animals, but had short,plantigrade, five-toed feet, like the elephant.
An instrument or apparatus employed in the ancient mysteries toimitate thunder and lightning. T. Moore.
Pertaining to accession; additional. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
A pilot who has a branch or commission, as from Trinity House,England, for special navigation.
The act of writing the name under something, as forattestation. [R.] Shelton.
A very lean person; one whose bones show through the skin.Shak.
A term applied by Kant to those laws which are imposed on usfrom without, or the violence done to us by our passions, wants, ordesires. Krauth-Fleming.
Very fine mineral matter held in suspension in water. Raymond.
As much as a shovel will hold; enough to fill a shovel.
Of or pertaining to neuropathy; of the nature of, or sufferingfrom, nervous disease.
The fruit of a Brazilian tree (Attalea funifera of Martius.).
Meteoric iron; a meteorite consisting of metallic iron withoutstony matter.

In Japanese costume and decorative art, a small object carvedin wood, ivory, bone, or horn, or wrought in metal, and pierced withholes for cords by which it is connected, for convenience, with theinro, the smoking pouch (tabako-ire), and similar objects carried inthe girdle. It is now much used on purses sold in Europe and America.
To acquire desert; to gain value; to receive benefit; toprofit. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
Of the color of red or vermilion. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
An instrument for estimating the amount of cream contained inmilk by ascertaining its relative opacity.
A counterclaim; a cross debt or demand; a distinct claim filedor set up by the defendant against the plaintiff's demand.
One who, or that which, incloses; one who fences off land fromcommon grounds.
One of a class of compounds which may be regarded as amides inwhich more or less of the hydrogen has been replaced by phenyl.
The act of utilizing, or the state of being utilized.
Rotation in the direction of an outgoing right-handed screw;counter-clockwise rotation; -- applied chiefly to the turning of theplane of polarization of light.
The office of a phylarch; government of a class or tribe.
To invest with the office of prebendary; to present to aprebend. [Obs.] Grafton.
A quill of the crow, or a very fine pen made from such a quill.
A division of edentates having the body covered with large,imbricated horny scales. It includes the pangolins.
A previous liking; a prepossession of mind in favor ofsomething; predisposition to choose or like; partiality. Burke.
Race; offspring; stock; breed; strain. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Opposition by which the quality opposed asquires strength;resistance or reaction roused by opposition or by the action of anopposite principle or quality.
1. (Mil.) An engine used in ancient times to beat down thewalls of besieged places.
A dropsical habit of body, or the commencement of anasarca;paleness, with viscid juices and cold sweats.
A small boat, esp. one used on rivers or near the shore.

A tyrant flycatcher (Milvulus forficatus) of the SouthernUnited States and Mexico, which has a deeply forked tail. It is lightgray above, white beneath, salmon on the flanks, and fiery red at thebase of the crown feathers.
One of a sect, in the ancient church, who maintained that thehuman and divine in Jesus Christ constituted but one compositenature. Also used adjectively.
One who makes a practice off discovering others' faults andcensuring them; a scold.
A stitch used in stem work to produce a fine line, much used inold church embroidery to work the hands and faces of figures.

the festival of Saturn, celebrated in December, originallyduring one day, but afterward during seven days, as a period ofunrestrained license and merriment for all classes, extending even tothe slaves.
A band in the same position as the bend sinister, but only halfas broad as the latter.
In a doctrinal manner or for; by way of teaching or positivedirection.
The inversion or turning in of the border of the eyelids.
The act of fenerating; interest. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
To grow hard, stiff, or thick, from cold or other causes; tobecome solid; to freeze; to cease to flow; to run cold; to bechilled.
A number of fishhooks rigidly fastened back to be pulledthrough the water to catch fish.
A squad of inapt recruits assembled for special drill.
A hydrous carbonate of alumina and soda, occuring in white,bladed crustals.
The metamorphosis of various floral organs, usually stamens,into petals.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a hypothetical sulphacid ofgold (aurum), known only in its salts.
To free from a state of confusion, or of being confounded.Milton.
A red or violet dyestuff having a greenish metallic luster. Itis produced artificially, by the chemical dehydration of thionine, asa brown amorphous powder.
The inmeats, or edible viscera (heart, gizzard, liver, etc.),of poultry.
The act or state of coming or falling between; occurrence;incident. [Obs.] Holland.
An alkaloid obtained from a white bark resembling that of thecinchona, first brought from Payta, in Peru.
Hydroxy quinoline; a phenol derivative of quinoline, -- calledalso carbostyril.
The warm-blooded vertebrates, comprising the mammals and birds;-- the antithesis to hematocrya.
The sickness occasioned by intemperance; surfeit. Bailey.
A kind of decoration for the breast of a coat, sometimes only afrog with a loop, but in some military uniforms enlarged into a broadhorizontal stripe.
The dividing line between the illuminated and the unilluminatedpart of the moon.
A bleacher of lines; a whitener; a whitster. [Prov. Eng.]
One of the divisions of Flagellata, including the monads andallied forms.
To ascertain; to verify; to establish; to prove. F. P. Cobbe.
A projecting piece of timber or iron near the bow of vessel, towhich the anchor is hoisted and secured.
To agree with, or teach, the doctrines of Puritans; to conformto the practice of Puritans. Bp. Montagu.
A water jar; esp., one with a large rounded body, a small neck,and three handles. Some of the most beautiful Greek vases are of thisform.
To insert, as a day or other portion of time, in a calendar.
Of or pertaining to a rheometer or rheometry. Lardner.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by thedecomposition of vulpinic acid, as a white crystalline substance.
A good state of he blood and other fluids of the body.
A glycoside, related to salicin, found in the bark of certainspecies of the poplar (Populus), and extracted as a sweet whitecrystalline substance.
The man who manages a barge, or one of the crew of a barge.
Not responsive; not able, ready, or inclined to respond.
A kind of ordnance, carrying a ball weighing from thirty tothirty-six pounds. Shak.
Pertaining to, or acting as, a succedaneum; supplying the placeof something else; being, or employed as, a substitute for another.Sir T. Browne.
A room for refreshment; originally, a dining hall inmonasteries or convents.
Acicular rutile occurring in reticulated forms imbedded inquartz.
The science which treats of the ancient life of the earth, orof fossils which are the remains of such life.
The act of making popular, or of introducing among the people.
A sheath in the embryo of grasses, inclosing the caulicle.Gray.
One versed in herpetology, or the natural history of reptiles.
Examination of the interior of the trachea by means of amirror.
An exaggerated fear of death or horror of dead bodies.
A place set apart for equestrian and chariot races.
Salts of potassium used in the manufacture of fertilizers.
A row of small bracts, at the base of the calyx, on theoutside.
Fiery; violent; rash; hasty; impetuous; vehement. Macaulay.
To do less than is requisite or proper; -- opposed to overdo.Grew.
The taking of lands into the hands of the king where a generallivery, or oustre le main, was formerly mis-sued, contrary to theform and order of law.
The act of erasing; a rubbing out; expunction; obliteration.Johnson.
Any reptile of the order Ophidia; a snake, especially a largesnake. See Illust. under Ophidia.
A whorl of flowers apparently of one cluster, but composed oftwo opposite axillary cymes, as in mint. See Illust. of Whorl.

A neuropterous insect of the genus Ephemera and related genera,of many species, and inhabiting fresh water in the larval state; theephemeral fly; -- so called because it commonly lives but one day inthe winged or adult state. See Ephemeral fly, under Ephemeral.
Half lenticular or convex; imperfectly resembling a lens.Kirwan.
A native oxide of antimony occurring in masses of a yellowcolor.
Of an age suitable for marriage; marriageable. Prior.
To deprive of utility; to render useless. [R.] Mrs. Browning.
Capable of assuming a molten state; meltable; fusible. [Obs.]
A stone or fossil which has on it impressions or figures ofplants and animals.
Of a gray color, somewhat resembling that of iron freshlybroken.-- n.
A band of white matter in the wall of fourth ventricle of thebrain.
Staid; fixed; settled; sober; -- now written staid. See Staid.Bacon. Pope.
The process of generation by development of blastema, orfission of cells, in which the new formation is in all respect likethe individual from which it proceeds.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid found of a urine of neatcattle, and probably identical with cresol.
A form or mode of syllogism of which the first proposition is auniversal affirmative, and the other two are particular negative.
Having very dark or black hair; black-haired. Prichard.
Moderation in doctrines or opinion, especially in politics orreligion.
To free from acids, salts, or other soluble substances, bywashing; to purify. [R.]
A nonsense poem of five anapestic lines, of which  lines 1, 2,and 5 are of there feet, and rime, and lines 3 and 4 are of two feet,and rime; as --
Indulging in a vagrant or idle exercise of the imagination;roaming upon a fruitless quest; idly fanciful.
To send, give, or grant back; torelease a claim to; to resignor surrender by deed; to return. Blackstone.
A mop or sponge attached to a jointed staff for swabbing out acannon.
A genus of ranunculaceous plants (Myosurus), in which theprolonged receptacle is covered with imbricating achenes, and soresembles the tail of a mouse.
Having such a structure as to be diaphanous when moist, andopaque when dry.
Harm; ruin; also, reproach; disgrace. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A crossbowman; one who used the arcubalist. Camden.
A breakfast; sometimes, also, a lunch or collation.
The act of embittering; also, that which embitters.
The act of sacrificing one's self, or one's interest, forothers; self-devotion.
One who does well; one who does good to another; a benefactor.
In an inglorious manner; dishonorably; with shame;ignominiously; obscurely.
A subdivision of the Devonian system of America; -- so namedfrom Hamilton, Madison Co., New York. It includes the Marcellus,Hamilton, and Genesee epochs or groups. See the Chart of Geology.

Prepared leaves or bark of certain plants; -- used by theIndians of the Northwest for smoking, either mixed with tobacco or asa substitute for it. Also, a plant so used, as the osier cornel(Cornus stolonijra), and the bearberry (Arctostaphylus Uva-ursi).[Spelled also kinnickinnick and killikinick.]
A condition characterized by a tendency to profuse anduncontrollable hemorrhage from the slightest wounds.

One who has entered upon a portion of the public land with thepurpose of acquiring ownership of it under provisions of thehomestead law, so called; one who has acquired a homestead in thismanner. [Local, U.S.]
The defendant in replevin, who avows the distress of the goods,and justifies the taking. Cowell.
A benefice or prebend in a cathedral or collegiate church; aright to a place in chapter and to a portion of its revenues; thedignity or emoluments of a canon.
Destitute of a siphon or breathing tube; -- said of manybivalve shells.-- n.
The upper and superficial part of the head, including thescalp, muscles, etc.
Of, pertaining to, or in the region of, the back, or nape, ofthe neck; -- applied especially to the anterior median plate in thecarapace of turtles.
A trench guarded with a parapet, constructed by besiegers, tosecure themselves and check sallies of the besieged.
Analysis of the structure of materials from careful observationof photomicrographs.
To curve in an opposite or unusual direction; to bend back ordown.
Brisk; lively; bold; self-complacent. [Scot.] Burns.
A substance of a strongly marked yellow color, extracted fromthe yelk of eggs, and from the tissue of the corpus luteum.
The state of being pure (in any sense of the adjective).
A lieutenant or first officer, who is the real commander whenthe captain is unfit for his place.

Popularly, any modern artist thought to be a would-be restorerof early ideas or methods, as one of the German painters often calledNazarenes, or one who paints and draws with extreme minuteness ofdetail.
The part of a projecting stone or brick inserted in a wall.Gwilt.
The state or quality of being pendulous. Sir T. Browne.
A white, crystalline glucoside, of an irritating taste,extracted from the convallaria or lily of the valley.
A soft and moist substance applied externally to some part ofthe body; a poultice. Dunglison.
A chain or tie rod, in a boat or barge, to prevent the vesselfrom hogging.
The act of habituating, or accustoming; the state of beinghabituated.
Made of hemp; hence, hard; rough; harsh. [Obs.] Johnson.
A preparation of casein from milk, used in printing calico.
A back chamber; especially, that part of the naos, or cella,farthest from the main entrance, sometimes having an entrance of itsown, and often used as a treasury.
Causing no resistance to a body sliding along its surface;frictionless.
A rare metallic element, found in certain zinc ores. It iswhite, hard, and malleable, resembling aluminium, and remarcable forits low melting point (86
Of or pertaining to Monogynia; having only one style or stigma.
Lamentation; loud weeping; wailing. [Obs.] Bp. Hacket.
A figure by which, in pretending to pass over anything, asummary mention of it is made; as, "I will not say, he is valiant, heis learned, he is just." Called also paraleipsis.
One who is versed in neurology; also, one skilled in thetreatment of nervous diseases.
A violent assault on a fortified place; a furious attempt oftroops to enter and take a fortified place by scaling the walls,forcing the gates, or the like.
The surrender or delivery of an alleged criminal by one Stateor sovereignty to another having jurisdiction to try charge.
Of or pertaining to the Brahmans or to their doctrines andworship.
In a conjoint manner; untitedly; jointly; together. Sir T.Browne.
Pertaining to the bone, or carts, large, below the epihyal inthe hyoid arch.-- n.
An Australian parrakeet (Polytelis Barrabandi); -- called alsothe scarlet-breasted parrot.
Admitting specification; capable of being specified.
The expressed juice of apples. It is used as a beverage, formaking vinegar, and for other purposes.
A grass used for making ropes or for plaiting, esp. AgrostisSpica-ventis. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.] Shelley.
To plow up; also, to engrave; to write. [Obs.] Blount.
Expressing, or used in, entreaty; supplicatory. [R.] Bp. Hall.
The common tern; -- called also tarret, and tarrock. [Prov.Eng.]
To degrade from the state of deity; to deprive of the characteror qualities of a god; to deprive of the reverence due to a god.Addison.

An order of tailed aquatic amphibians, including Siren andPseudobranchus. They have anterior legs only, are eel-like in form,and have no teeth except a small patch on the palate. The externalgills are persistent through life.

One of a system of tubular excretory organs having externalopenings, found in many invertebrates. They are believed to beanalogous in function to the kidneys of vertebrates. See Illust.under Trematodea, and Sporocyst.

An argument consisting of only two propositions, an antecedentand consequent deduced from it; a syllogism with one premise omitted;as, We are dependent; therefore we should be humble. Here the majorproposition is suppressed. The complete syllogism would be, Dependentcreatures should be humble; we are dependent creatures; therefore weshould be humble.
The act or art of working or forging metals, as iron, into anydesired shape. Moxon.
The first coating of plaster in work of three coats upon laths.Its surface is scratched once to form a better key for the next coat.In the United States called scratch coat. Brande & C.
An oven in which glazed pottery is fired; -- also called glazekiln, or glaze.
Of or pertaining to Machiavel, or to his supposed principles;politically cunning; characterized by duplicity or bad faith; crafty.
A substance produced by the action of an alkali upon albumin,and resembling casein in its properties; also, a compound formed bythe union of albumin with another substance.
Paleness produced by absence of light, or by disease.Dunglison.
A white, crystalline substance, C12H13NO3, obtained as aproduct of the decomposition of narcotine. It has weak basicproperties, and is usually regarded as an alkaloid.
A yellow-green, transparent variety of garnet found in theUrals. It is valued as a gem because of its brilliancy of luster,whence the name.
The outer layer of the blastoderm; the ectoderm. SeeBlastoderm, Delamination.
A variety of pyroxene, from the Mussa Alp in Piedmont;diopside.
A sluice or lock, as in a river, to make it more navigable.[Obs.] Pepys.
The head of a buffer, which recieves the concussion, inrailroad carriages.
The art of representing dancing by signs, as music isrepresented by notes. Craig.
A title, denoting a Spanish nobleman of the lower class.
To breed by crossing different stocks of animals or plants.
A colorless, mobile, inflammable liquid, C2H5.NH2, veryvolatile and with an ammoniacal odor. It is a strong base, and is aderivative of ammonia. Called also ethyl carbamine, and amido ethane.
To make bloody; to stain with blood. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A North American nocturnal carnivore (Procyon lotor) allied tothe bears, but much smaller, and having a long, full tail, bandedwith black and gray. Its body is gray, varied with black and white.Called also coon, and mapach.
A second moving; the grass which grows after the first crop ofhay in the same season; rowen. Holland.
An instrument for dividing the cornea in operations forcataract.
The operation of breaking a stone in the bladder into smallpieces capable of being voided.
The quality of being explicit; clearness; directness. Jer.Taylor.
The amount which a vessel, as a cask, of liquor lacks of beingfull; wantage; deficiency.
A kind of small pinchers with long jaws, -- used for bending orcutting metal rods or wire, for handling small objects such as theparts of a watch, etc.
A reproductive bud of a hydroid; a simple gonophore.
The doctrine of nutrition; a treatise on nutrition.
A path, as over mountains, followed by pack animals.
A kind of crystallite resembling a bunch of hairs, common inobsidian. See Illust. of Crystallite.
A house in which distillation is carried on; a distillery.
The root of a handsome erect herb (Leptandra, syn. Veronica,Virginica) common in most moist woods of North America , used as anactive cathartic and emetic; also, the plant itself.
Marrying within the same tribe; -- opposed to exogamous.
A variety of cabbage (Brassica oleracea), cultivated for itsseeds, which yield an oil valued for illuminating and lubricatingpurposes; summer rape.
One who makes reqisition; esp., one authorized by a requisitionto investigate facts.
To overpower by talking; to exceed in talking; to talk down.Shak.
A wooden frame or grid for roasting, smoking, or drying meatover fire.
A second quantity added to a given quantity to make equal to athird given quantity.
To accompany with harmony; to provide with parts, as an air, ormelody.
A fermented drink, or milk beer, made by the Turks.
Something commonplace, hackneyed, or trivial; the commonplace,in speech.The highest things were thus brought down to the banalities ofdiscourse. J. Morley.

According to the French notation, which is used on theContinent and in America, the cube of a million, or a unit witheighteen ciphers annexed; according to the English notation, a numberproduced by involving a million to the fifth power, or a unit withthirty ciphers annexed. See the Note under Numeration.
A morbid growth or deposit of bony matter and at the sides ofthe coronet and coffin bone of a horse. J. H. Walsh.
The nutlike seed of the areca palm, chewed in the East withbetel leaves (whence its name) and shell lime.
One who distrains; the party distraining goods or chattels.Blackstone.
A painter; an artist; esp.:(a) One who paints portraits.(b) One who illuminates books. [Archaic]
A canoe-shaped float attached to the foot, for walking onwater.
Of or pertaining to the scaphoid and lunar bones of the carpus.-- n.
Any moth of the genus Pterophorus and allied genera; a plumemoth. See Plume moth, under Plume.
A yellowish green resin from Lobelia, used as an emetic anddiaphoretic.
Having the side planks (af a boat) so arranged that the loweredge of each overlaps the upper edge of the plank next below it likeclapboards on a house. See Lapstreak.
A group of the Carnivora, that includes the bears, weasels,etc.
A substance associated with nuclein in cell nuclei, and by someconsidered as the fundamental substance of the nucleus.
The state of being fallible; liability to deceive or to bedeceived; as, the fallibity of an argument or of an adviser.
To blow upon; to breath upon or into; to use insufflation upon.
A white crystalline compound of acetyl and salicylic acid usedas a drug for the salicylic acid liberated from it in the intestines.
A thick sort of jaconet muslin, plain or striped, formerly madein India.
The bow, strung with horsehair, used in playing the fiddle; afiddle bow.
Methyl ketol; also, any of various homologues of the same.
a small piece of paper on which women roll up their hair tomake it curl; a curl paper.
A curve traced by the end of a string wound upon another curve,or unwound from it; -- called also evolvent. See Evolute.
Turning or bending at night into special positions.
A wasting away of flesh; decay. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A lease by a tenant or lessee to another person; an underlease.Bouvier.
A bridle check; a jerk of one rein, given to a horse when herefuses to turn.
In a politic manner; sagaciously; shrewdly; artfully. Pope.
A diagram or picture which represents objects in such a way asto give the impression of relief or solidity; also, a stereograph.
The act of burning different things together. [Obs.]

A sort of tunic or mantle formerly worn for protection from theweather. When worn over the armor it was commonly emblazoned with thearms of the wearer, and from this the name was given to the garmentadopted for heralds. [Spelt also taberd.]
A court or meeting of a burgh or borough; a borough court heldthree times yearly.
A substance, present in the protoplasm of the retinalepithelium cells, and resembling, if not identical with, thesubstance (myelin) forming the medullary sheaths of nerve fibers.
A genus of lowly organized arthropods, found in South Africa,Australia, and tropical America. It constitutes the order Malacopoda.
A precious stone, probably a carnelian, one of which was set inAaron's breastplate. Ex. xxviii. 17.
The technical name for isocyanic acid. See under Isocyanic.
A genus of marine gastropods, having rough, and frequentlyspinose, shells, which are often highly colored inside; the rockshells. They abound in tropical seas.
The quality or rank of a don, gentleman, or knight. Hudibras.

In Mexico and the southwestern United States, a kind ofplastered house or hut, usually made by planting poles or timber inthe ground, filling in between them with screen work or wickerwork,and daubing one or both sides with mud or adobe mortar; also, thismethod of construction.
One who, or that which, stands by one in need; something uponwhich one relies for constant use or in an emergency.
A liquid organic base, C10H13.NH2, derived from cymene.
The state or quality of being a lady; the personality of alady.
Pertaining to the complexion, or to the care of it. Jer.Taylor.
The act of expurgating, purging, or cleansing; purificationfrom anything noxious, offensive, sinful, or erroneous. Milton.
A long wrought iron tube, on the end of which the workmangathers a quantity of "metal" (melted glass), and through which heblows to expand or shape it; -- called also blowing tube, andblowpipe.
A soft, earthy substance, of a white, grayish, or yellowishwhite color, consisting of calcium carbonate, and having the samecomposition as common limestone.
A small silver coin and money of account of Germany, worthabout two cents. It is not included in the new monetary system of theempire.
The formal statement of an offense, as framed by theprosecuting authority of the State, and found by the grand jury.
Act or state of lying hid, or lurking. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
One who, or that which, animates; an animater. Sir T. Browne.
A kind of glass which is very hard and difficult to fuse, usedas an insulator in electrical lamps and other apparatus.
A genus of plants related to the clover, having their flowersarranged in little heads or tufts resembling coronets.
The quality of being applicable or fit to be applied.
A view if one's self; specifically, carefulness or regard forone's own interests
A week; a period of seven days. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
A sapling left standing in a fallen wood. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
One who receives relief for a night in a parish to which hedoes not belong; a vagrant.
One who forms structures; a builder; a constructor. [R.]
A thick plank on the inner part of a ship's side, used tosustuan the ends of beams.
The act of giving out or bestowing. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
A functionary in ancient Athens answering nearly to the modernjuryman.
A man who attends at the counter of a shop to sell goods.[Eng.]
To percolate, trickle, or ooze, as water through a crack. [Alsowritten sigger, zigger, and zifhyr.] [Prov. Eng.]
A hinge joint; an articulation, admitting of flexion andextension, or motion in two directions only, as the elbow and theankle.
The operation of dispersing worm casts over the walks withpoles.
The chemical basis of cartilage, converted by long boiling inwater into a gelatinous body called chondrin.
A division of chelonians which comprises Trionyx and alliedgenera; -- called also Trionychoides, and Trionychina.
One who is versed in anthropotomy, or human anatomy.
One who, or that which, malaxates; esp., a machine forgrinding, kneading, or stirring into a pasty or doughy mass. [R.]
A minister, official agent, or envoy to a foreign court; adiplomatist.
To make local; to fix in, or assign to, a definite place. H.Spencer. Wordsworth.
A variety of ruby of a yellowish red color, from Brazil.
A superior quality of Turkish smoking tobacco, so called fromthe place where produced, the ancient Laodicea.
A small iron rod which suspends the core of the mold in castinga shell.
A rapid, esp. one where the channel is narrowed between rockwalls. [Northwestern U. S. & Canada]
1. A person hired to murder or physically attack another; a hitman.
Bachelorhood; also, a manner or peculiarity belonging tobachelors. W. Irving.
A money of account in Persia, whose value varies greatly atdifferent times and places. Its average value may be reckoned atabout two and a half dollars.
One who adheres to, or is skilled in, the objective philosophy.Ed. Rev.
Undue pretensions to skill; quackery; wheedling; empiricism.
Attached to the main wall of the ovary, and not to the axis; --said of a placenta.
The state or quality of being conversant; habit of familiarity;familiar acquaintance; intimacy. [R.]
Like a home; comfortable; cheerful; cozy; friendly.
Superabundant fecundity or multiplication of the species.
The act of surrounding or encompassing. Sir T. Browne.
One who slays; a killer; a murderer; a destrroyer of life.
Toward the ventral side; on the ventral side; ventrally; --opposed to dorsad.
An assistant to a corporal; a private performing the duties ofa corporal; -- called also lance corporal.
An officer appointed to supervise the forest. Cowell.
A commissioned officer in the navy who had charge of theprovisions, clothing, and public moneys on shipboard; -- now calledpaymaster.
Of or pertaining to Hungary or to the people of Hungary.-- n.
A number or mark placed opposite the lower part of a letter orsymbol to distinguish the symbol; thus, a0, b1, c2, xn, have 0, 1, 2,and n as subindices.
One who legally transfers property from himself to another.
An arm attached to a swinging notched arc or rack, to let offthe striking mechanism of a repeating clock.
A bias on the part of judge, juror, or witness which interfereswith fairness of judgment.
The use of local or provincial words, as in the peculiar styleor diction of Livy, the Roman historian; -- so called from Patavium,now Padua, the place of Livy's nativity.

Any arboreal ape of the genus Hylobates, of which many speciesand varieties inhabit the East Indies and Southern Asia. They aretailless and without cheek pouches, and have very long arms, adaptedfor climbing.

A grand division of the animal kingdom, intermediate, in somerespects, between the invertebrates and vertebrates, and by somewriters united with the latter. They were formerly classed withacephalous mollusks. The body is usually covered with a firm externaltunic, consisting in part of cellulose, and having two openings, onefor the entrance and one for the exit of water. The pharynx isusually dilated in the form of a sac, pierced by several series ofciliated slits, and serves as a gill.
An executioner; a headsman or hangman. [Obs.] Shak.
A division, at one end of a tennis court, for spectators.
To give glory to God, as in a doxology; to praise God withdoxologies.
A variety of fluor spar, which, when heated, gives a beautifulemerald green light.
Not merchantable; not fit for market; being of a kind, quality,or quantity that is unsalable. McElrath.
An insulating material, usually some variety of compressedcellulose, made of sawdust, paper pulp, cotton waste, etc.
A yellow cylindrical mass of egg capsule of certain species ofwhelks (Buccinum), which resembles an ear of maize.
The act or art of engraving on copper or brass, especially ofengraving for printing.
A tribe of bivalve mollusks in which the posterior mantleborder is prolonged into two tubes or siphons. Called alsoSiphoniata. See Siphon, 2 (a), and Quahaug.
A low outwork before a bastion or ravelin, consisting of twolines of rampart parallel to the faces of the bastion, and protectingthem from a breaching fire.
One of the higher hydrocarbons, C10H15, of the acetyleneseries; -- called also decenylene.
Capable of being electrolyzed, or decomposed by electricity.
The act or crime of murdering one's own father or any ancestor.
A photometric standard used in France, having the value of onetwentieth of the Violle platinum standard, or slightly less than aBritish standard candle. Called also decimal candle.
The right of presenting to a vacant benefice or living in thechurch. [Originally, the relation of a patron (advocatus) orprotector of a benefice, and thus privileged to nominate or presentto it.]
A hard tough alloy of tin, copper, and iron, which can be usedfor guns.
One who, or that which, puzzles; a difficult or inexplicablequestion or fact. Bacon.
Pertaining to an Attic festival at the naming of a child; -- socalled because the friends of the parents carried the child aroundthe hearth and then named it.
To perforate; to bore; to pierce. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
One skilled in botany; one versed in the knowledge of plants.

A stone or mineral on or in which are branching figuresresembling shrubs or trees, produced by a foreign mineral, usually anoxide of manganese, as in the moss agate; also, a crystallizedmineral having an arborescent form, e. g., gold or silver; anarborization.
An oily liquid hydrocarbon extracted from the creosote ofbeechwood tar. It consists essentially of certain derivatives ofpyrogallol.
A medicine made by mixing oils with sirups. John Quincy.
The act of leaping on anything. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.

A figure by which one striking circumstance is added, in duegradation, to another; climax; e. g., "He not only spared hisenemies, but continued them in employment; not only continued, butadvanced them." Johnson.
In a gentle or hoble manner; frankly. [Obs.] Chaucer.
In a privative manner; by the absence of something; negatively.[R.] Hammond.
A pipe wrench having an adjustable L-shaped jaw piece slidingin a sleeve that is pivoted to, and loosely embraces, the handle.Pressure on the handle increases the grip.
A professor of canon law; one skilled in the knowledge andpractice of ecclesiastical law. South.
The act of diminishing, or the state of being diminished;diminution. [Obs.]

A figure composed of two equilateral triangles intersecting soas to form a six-pointed star, -- used in early ornamental art, andalso with superstitious import by the astrologers and mystics of theMiddle Ages.
Breaking and entering the dwelling house of another, in thenighttime, with intent to commit a felony therein, whether thefelonious purpose be accomplished or not. Wharton. Burrill.
A laving or lading from one vessel to another. [Obs.] Holland.
One who, or that which, pacifies; a peacemaker.  Bacon.
Personal property, as distinguished from realty or realproperty.
Exemption from error; inerrability; infallibility. Hammond.
A Mexican dish made of crushed maize mixed with minced meat,seasoned with red pepper, dipped in oil, and steamed.
Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, rhodium andammonia; -- said of certain complex compounds.
A plant Whose radicle is not inclosed or sheathed by thecotyledons or plumule. Gray.
An instrument which consists of links and is used in measuringland.

A genus of fresh-water or river turtles which have the shellimperfectly developed and covered with a soft leathery skin. They arenoted for their agility and rapacity. Called also soft tortoise,soft-shell tortoise, and mud turtle.
Having sides inclining inwards, as a ship; -- opposed to wall-sided.
One who contrives, devises, plans, or schemas. Swift.
A nickname given to any "poor white" living in the pine woodswhich cover the sandy hills in Georgia and South Carolina. [U.S.]
A believer in the old theory that the newly created being isformed by the admixture of the seed of the male with the supposedseed of the female.
The anterior part of the medulla oblongata. B. G. Wilder.
To surpass nature in the picture or representation of. [Obs.]"O'erpicturing that Venus." Shak.
Of or pertaining to a fixed camp, or military posts orquarters. [Obs. or R.]
An abnormal formation foreign to the economy, and composed ofelements different from those are found in it in its normalcondition. Dunglison.
A French girl or young married woman of the lower class; morefrequently, a young working woman who is fond of gallantry. Sterne.
An instrument for detecting the presence or movement ofcurrents, as of electricity.
A genus of acalephs, having a bell-shaped body with eightgroups of short tentacles around the margin. It attaches itself by asucker at the base of the pedicel.
A female pope; i. e., the fictitious pope Joan. [Obs.] Bp.Hall.

A white, crystalline substance, C8H7N, obtained from blueindigo, and almost all indigo derivatives, by a process of reduction.It is also formed from albuminous matter, together with skatol, byputrefaction, and by fusion with caustic potash, and is present inhuman excrement, as well as in the intestinal canal of someherbivora.
Not astigmatic; --said esp. of a lens system which consists ofa converging lens and a diverging lens of equal and oppositeastigmatism but different focal lengths, and sensibly free fromastigmatism.
To speak reproachfully of; to twit; to upbraid. [Obs.]
Containing, or resembling, a cyst or cysts; cystic; bladdery.
Serious injunction; solemn demand or entreaty. [Obs.] Milton.
Having the main artery of the leg parallel with the sciaticnerve; -- said of certain birds.

One of several lepidopterous insects which construct, in thelarval state, a baglike case which they carry about for protection.One species (Platoeceticus Gloveri) feeds on the orange tree. SeeBasket worm.
More or less permanent erection and rigidity of the penis, withor without sexual desire.
A piece of iron in a saddle near a horse's withers, tostrengthen the bow.
A low or subdued tone or utterance; a tone less loud thanusual.
One who, or that which, stems (in any of the senses of theverbs).
A piece of meat, especially of veal or mutton, cut forbroiling.
The act or process of naturalizing, esp. of investing an alienwith the rights and privileges of a native or citizen; also, thestate of being naturalized.
A process of reproduction intermediate between fission andgemmation.
A greenish blue pigment prepared in various ways, consistingessentially of cobalt stannate. Unlike other cobalt blues, it doesnot change color by gaslight.
Reverence; honor. [Obs.]In redoutyng of Mars and of his glory. Chaucer.
Easy to be led; governable, as a woman by her husband. [Obs.]Jacob.
The act of furnishing with timber; also, timbers, collectively;timberwork; timber.
A liquid metameric with xylenol, belonging to the class ofphenols, and obtained by distilling certain salts of phloretic acid.
Remembrance; recollection; also, a record. [Obs.] Shak.
The small space beneath the base line of a subject engraved ona coin or medal. It usually contains the date, place, engraver'sname, etc., or other subsidiary matter. Fairholt.
A woman's cape; especially, a fur cape that is longer in frontthan behind.
Want of application, attention, or diligence; negligence;indolence.
A sculptured ornament, representing an ox skull adorned withwreaths, etc.
The act of erasing; a scratching out; obliteration.
Mycose; -- so called because sometimes obtained from trehala.
One who keeps the entrance to an edifice, public or private; adoorkeeper; a janitor, male or female.
The grantee of a fief, feud, or fee; one who holds land ofsuperior, and who vows fidelity and homage to him; a feudatory; afeudal tenant. Burrill.
The act or process of freeing from zinc; also, the conditionresulting from the removal of zinc.
Being in the middle, or nearest the middle; midmost.
An element of the rare earth-group. Symbol Dy; at. wt., 162.5.

A drink served after coffee at dinner, usually one of severalliqueurs, or cordials, of different specific gravities poured so asto remain separate in layers; hence, such a drink of cordials servedat any time.
A female servant or maid who dresses provisions and assists thecook.
Becoming a workman, especially a skillful one; skillful; wellperformed.
Cutting a cask into two pieces lengthwise, to enable it to passa narrow place, the two parts being afterward united and rehooped.
To admit into the church by confirmation; to confirm; hence, toreceive formally to favor.
A division of pulmonate mollusks having the breathing organsituated on the neck, as in the common snail.
The first week day after Christmas, a legal holiday on whichChristmas boxes are given to postmen, errand boys, employees, etc.The night of this day is boxing night. [Eng.]

The part which first meets the eye; as:(a) (Arch.) The principal front of a building. [Obs. or R.](b) An ornamental figure or illustration fronting the first page, ortitlepage, of a book; formerly, the titlepage itself.

A group of minerals having, a micaceous structure. They arehydrous silicates, derived generally from the alteration of some kindof mica. So called because the scales, when heated, open out intowormlike forms.
Pertaining to, or involving, vitalism, or the theory of aspecial vital principle.
The act of begetting; generation and production of young.South.
To cause to loathe, or feel disgust at. [Scot. & Prov. Eng.]
, the grain of timber which is transverse to the annular ringsor plates; the direction of the medullary rays in oak and some othertimber. Knight.
A name given in the sixteenth century to those German reformerswho rejected both the Roman and the Lutheran doctrine of the holyeucharist.
The quality of being a baby; the personality of an infant.
A furnace or stove in which the fuel is contained in a hopperor chamber, and is fed to the fire as the lower stratum is consumed.
The process of obtaining an etched or engraved plate from thephotographic image, to be used in printing; also, a picture producedby such a process.
An order of fishes including the anglers. See Illust. of Anglerand Batfish.
A hole, or crevice, through which one may peep without beingdiscovered.
Of or pertaining to Nemea, in Argolis, where the ancient Greekscelebrated games, and Hercules killed a lion.
To roam. [Obs.]In this fair plot dispacing to and fro. Spenser.
The act of resorbing; also, the act of absorbing again;reabsorption.

Formerly, a writ issuing out of chancery, upon certificategiven by the ordinary, of a man's standing excommunicate by the spaceof forty days, for the laying him up in prison till he submit himselfto the authority of the church. Crabb.
One of a sect of Socinians or Unitarians in Poland.
A hypochondriacal condition verging upon insanity, occurring inthose whose brains have been unduly taxed; -- called also brain fag.
Turning on pivots at the top and bottom; -- said of a door.
One who, or that which, amalgamates. Specifically: A machinefor separating precious metals from earthy particles by bringing themin contact with a body of mercury with which they form an amalgam.
A female friend who attends on a bride at her wedding.
Embroidery. [Obs.]Of goldsmithrye, of browdying, and of steel. Chaucer.
The yellow fever in its worst form, when it is usually attendedwith black vomit. See Black vomit.
Having no seed lobes, as the dodder; also applied to plantswhich have no true seeds, as ferns, mosses, etc.
A patch of granular bodies on the surface of the thallus oflichens.
Capable of being relieved; fitted to recieve relief. Sir M.Hale.
A machine for picking fibrous materials to pieces so as toloosen and separate the fiber.
Pertaining to an episode; by way of episode; episodic.
The quality or state of being whole, entire, or sound;entireness; totality; completeness.
The quality or state of being suicidal, or self-murdering. [R.]
The part of a plow which projects downward beneath the beam,for holding the share and other working parts; -- also calledstandard, or post.
The honor or position of being a wrangler at the University ofCambridge, England.
A spotted European fish of the genus Lucioperca, resembling aperch.
Of or pertaining to a prophet; prophetical. Bp. Hall.
The kiling of another in self-defense upon a sudden andunpremeditated encounter. See Chaud-Medley.
A discharge of a white, yellowish, or greenish, viscid mucus,resulting from inflammation or irritation of the membrane lining thegenital organs of the female; the whites. Dunglison.
Lying at, or extending toward, the side; away from the mesialplane; external; -- opposed to mesial.
The lower house of the Norwegian Storthing. See Legislature.

The sweetbread, a gland connected with the intestine of nearlyall vertebrates. It is usually elongated and light-colored, and itssecretion, called the pancreatic juice, is discharged, often togetherwith the bile, into the upper part of the intestines, and is apowerful aid in digestion. See Illust. of Digestive apparatus.
A kind of plum of medium size, roundish shape, greenish flesh,and delicious flavor. It is called in France Reine Claude, after thequeen of Francis I. See Gage.
With slightly overlapping borders; -- said of a suture.

Lit., one who has been reconcentrated; specif., in Cuba, thePhilippines, etc., during the revolution of 1895-98, one of the ruralnoncombatants who were concentrated by the military authorities inareas surrounding the fortified towns, and later were reconcentratedin the smaller limits of the towns themselves.
To make French; to infect or imbue with the manners or tastesof the French; to Gallicize. Burke.
To let in light upon, as by cutting away branches. [Obs.]
Pertaining to, or designating, an artificial acid of the oleicacid series, isomeric with linoleic acid.
To peel off in the form of scales; to scale off, as the skin incertain diseases.
Superior to the angels in nature or rank. [R.] Milman.
The act of making rich, or that which enriches; increase ofvalue by improvements, embellishment, etc.; decoration;embellishment.
Having the form of the letter U; specif. (Phys. Geog.),
A Turkish open summer house or pavilion, supported by pillars.
The teledu of the East Indies. It emits a disagreeable odor.
To call before a judge or judicature; to summon; to convene.[Obs.] Shak.

A simple form of moving-picture machine in which the series ofviews, exhibiting the successive phases of a scene, are printed onpaper and mounted around the periphery of a wheel. The rotation ofthe wheel brings them rapidly into sight, one after another, and theblended effect gives a semblance of motion.
One skilled in the laws; a writer on law. Milman. J. Morley.
A scarf, band, or kerchief of silk, etc., passing around theneck or collar and tied in front; a bow of silk, etc., fastened infront of the neck.
An involuntary discharge of urine; incontinence of urine.
Combined with carbon in the manner of a carburet or carbide.
A fleecy cloud formation consisting of large whitish or grayishglobular cloudlets with shaded  portions, often grouped in flocks orrows.
An officer who discharged the duties of a consul without beinghimself consul; a governor of, or a military commander in, aprovince. He was usually one who had previously been consul.
A space in the galley; a part of the hatches. Ham. Nav. Encyc.
A displacement forward of an organ, esp. the uterus, in suchmanner that its axis is bent upon itself. T. G. Thomas.
One of a hundred equal parts into which one whole is, or maybe, divided; the quotient of a unit divided by a hundred.
Mutually visible, or in sight, the one from the other, asstations.
An argillaceous rock which readily splits into thin plates;argillite; argillaceous schist.
A morbid condition in which albumin is present in the urine.
A genus of fungi embracing a great number of species, some ofwhich are remarkable for their regular cuplike form and deep colors.
A Roman coin equivalent to one twenty-fourth part of a Romanpound.
Any protoplasmic filament or irregular process projecting fromany unicellular organism, or from any animal or plant call.
A rich slimy deposit in salt marshes and along the seashore,sometimes used as a manure; -- called also sea ooze.
One who, or that which, ratifies; a confirmer. Shak.
A building where meat or fish is cured by subjecting it to adense smoke.
A stringed musical instrument having a head and neck like theguitar, and its body like a tambourine. It has five strings, and isplayed with the fingers and hands.
The quality or state of being turbid; muddiness; foulness.

A law enacted to provide for the regulation and supervision ofinvestment companies in order to protect the public against companiesthat do not intend to do a fair and honest business and that offerinvestments that do not promise a fair return; -- so called becausethe promises made by some investment companies are as boundless oralluring as the blue sky, or, perhaps, because designed to clear awaythe clouds and fogs from the simple investor's horizon. [Colloq.]
A peculiar marine worm. See Enteropneusta, and Tornaria.
Pertaining to clairvoyance; discerning objects while in amesmeric state which are not present to the senses.
Of or pertaining to scoria; like scoria or the recrement ofmetals; partaking of the nature of scoria.
Food or sustenance for cattle, obtained from bushes and trees;also, a tax on wood.
So as to be inexpugnable; in an inexpugnable manner. Dr. H.More.
As much as a tray will hold; enough to fill a tray.
The quality or state of being parochial in form or nature; asystem of management peculiar to parishes.
A carnivorous mannual (Helictis moscatus, or H. orientalis),native of Eastern Asia and the Indies. It has a dorsal white stripe,and another one across the shoulders. It has a strong musky odor.
Having two ocelli (eyelike spots); -- said of a wing, etc.
Not feat; not dexterous; unskillful; clumsy. [Obs.] Sir P.Sidney.
The capability of being placed or located. [Obs.] Barrow.
A mill for sawing, especially one for sawing timber or lumber.
One engaged in effecting a change of government; a favorer ofrevolution. Burke.
Wise; knowing; skillful; sapient; erudite; prudent. Ex. xxviii.3.
A genus of gelatinous fungi found in moist grounds.
A broad flat limb used for swimming, as those of seals, seaturtles, whales, etc.
The one to whom a pledge is given, or to whom property pledgedis delivered.
The art or process of engraving or etching on zinc, in whichthe design is left in relief in the style of a wood cut, the rest ofthe ground being eaten away by acid.
A group of corals in which the coral is not porous; -- opposedto Perforata.
In a puissant manner; powerfully; with great strength.

A group of small insects having the anterior wings rudimentary,and in the form of short and slender twisted appendages, while theposterior ones are large and membranous. They are parasitic in thelarval state on bees, wasps, and the like; -- called also Rhipiptera.See Illust. under Rhipipter.
Broken, as an ordinary; cut off, or broken at the top, as achevron, a bend, or the like.
To intermeddle with the effects or goods of another.
A tearing apart; violent separation. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Offerings formerly made to the mother church of a diocese onMid-Lent Sunday.
Of or pert. to a microphone; serving to intensify weak sounds.
One who, or that which, grooms horses; especially, a brushrotated by a flexible or jointed revolving shaft, for cleaninghorses.
To pommel; to beat, as with a stick; figuratively, to assail orcriticise in conversation, or in writing. Thackeray.
Admitting of being refuted or disproved; capable of beingproved false or erroneous.
A controller; a public officer whose duty it is to examinecertify accounts.
To cry as cats in rutting time; to make a harsh, offensivenoise. Coleridge.
The state barge of Venice, used by the doge in the ceremony ofespousing the Adriatic.
Of or pertaining to Assam, a province of British India, or toits inhabitants.-- n. sing. & pl.
A perivisceral cavity which arises as an outgrowth oroutgrowths from the digestive tract; distinguished from aschizocoele, which arises by a splitting of the mesoblast of theembryo.
A line of fortifications, usually rough, constructed to preventthe passage of an enemy across a region. [Sp. Amer.]
An absorption of bone so that the tissue becomes unusuallyporous.
A genus of small spiral pteropods, common in the Arctic andAntarctic seas. It contributes to the food of the right whales.
The quality or state of being invincible; invincibleness.
A large triangular sail set upon a boom, -- used when runningbefore the wind.
An Irish or Welsh melody for the harp, sometimes of a mournfulcharacter.
in a convincing manner; in a manner to compel assent.
A promise without mutuality; a promise which has not beenaccepted by the person to whom it is made. Bouvier.
A large, venomous serpent (Trigonocephalus lanceolatus) ofBrazil and the West Indies. It is allied to the rattlesnake, but hasno rattle.
The varnish tree of Burmah (Melanorrhoea usitatissima).
Causing infliction; acting as an infliction. Whitehead.
In a technical manner; according to the signification of termsas used in any art, business, or profession.
One of the microsporic siliceous spicules which occurabundantly in the texture of sponges, and are sometimes found fossil,as in flints.
Composed of convex convex concretions, somewhat resembling thebreasts in form; studded with small mammiform protuberances.
The hypothetical radical characteristic of stearic acid.
A reptile whose teeth are rooted in sockets, as the crocodile.
Outside of the walls, as of a fortified or walled city.
Any substance supposed to be capable of absorbing, retaining,and transporting contagious or infectious germs; as, woolen clothesare said to be active fomites.
The division of Aves which includes all the typical birds, orall living birds except the penguins and birds of ostrichlike form.
The state of being incalescent, or of growing warm. Sir T.Browne.

A follower of the Rev. Richard Cameron, a Scotch Covenanter ofthe time of Charies II.Cameron and others refused to accept the "indulgence" offered thePresbyterian clergy, insisted on the Solemn league and Covenant, andin 1680 declared Charles II deposed for tyranny, breach of faith,etc. Cameron was killed at the battle of Airdmoss, but his followersbecame a denomination (afterwards called Reformed Presbyterians) whorefused to recognize laws or institutions which they believedcontrary to the kingdom of Christ, but who now avail themselves ofpolitical rights.
Half drunk. [Slang: used only predicatively.] Spectator.
The state of being in revolution; revolutionary doctrines orprinciples.
Of or pertaining to styloid process and the tongue.
A thick oily liquid, C10H13.OH, of a strong taste anddisagreeable odor, obtained from oil of caraway (Carum carui).
Of the nature of an impediment; hindering; obstructing;impeditive.Things so impediental to success. G. H. Lewes.
A native or natives of Madagascar; also (sing.), the language.
One of the divisions of Articulata in which there are nojointed legs, as the annelids; -- opposed to Arthropoda.

A projection downward from the keel of a yacht, resembling inshape the fin of a fish, though often with a cigar-shaped bulb oflead at the bottom, and generally made of metal. Its use is toballast the boat and also to enable her to sail close to the wind andto make the least possible leeway by offering great resistance tolateral motion through the water.
The act, art, or process of vitrifying; also, the state ofbeing vitrified.
That phase of the moon in which it appears bisected, or showsonly half its disk, as at the quadratures.

The elevation of a point, or star, or other celestial object,above the horizon, measured by the arc of a vertical circleintercepted between such point and the horizon. It is either true orapparent; true when measured from the rational or real horizon,apparent when from the sensible or apparent horizon.
Capability of shedding the skin periodically. Craig.
An officer who presided over the great public games in Greece.
A woman who assists other women in childbirth; a femalepractitioner of the obstetric art.
A grackle (Quiscalus crassirostris) native of Jamaica. It oftenassociates with domestic cattle, and rids them of insects.
A kind of light vessel used on the coast of China, having thehull built on a European model, and the rigging like that of aChinese junk. Admiral Foote.
A horse which carries an officer's baggage during a campaign.
The final adult, and usually winged, state of an insect. SeeIllust. of Ant-lion, and Army worm.
A hunting for game in a quiet and cautious manner, or undercover; stalking; hence, colloquially, the pursuit of any objectquietly and cautiously.-- Still"-hunt`er, n.-- Still"-hunt`ing, n. [U.S.]
An alloy of lead and tin, of which the Chinese make teacanisters.

That science, or class of sciences, which treats of the exactrelations existing between quantities or magnitudes, and of themethods by which, in accordance with these relations, quantitiessought are deducible from other quantities known or supposed; thescience of spatial and quantitative relations.

Lit., a shot fired simply to fill the pot; hence, a shot firedat an animal or person when at rest or within easy range, or firedsimply to kill, without reference to the rules of sport; a shotneedling no special skill.
To adopt as son or daughter; to establish filiation between.[R.] Southey.
A rheumatic pain in the loins and the small of the back.
A genus of nocturnal lemurine mammals having very large eyesand ears, a long tail, and very long proximal tarsal bones; -- calledalso malmag, spectral lemur, podji, and tarsier.

An area in the pigmented layer of the choroid coat of the eyein many animals, which has an iridescent or metallic luster and helpsto make the eye visible in the dark. Sometimes applied to the wholelayer of pigmented epithelium of the choroid.
A keel.(a) That part of a papilionaceous flower, consisting of two petals,commonly united, which incloses the organs of fructification.(b) A longitudinal ridge or projection like the keel of a boat.
One who, or that which, winnows; specifically, a winnowingmachine.

The decoration of a fluted shaft of a column or of a pilasterwith reeds, or rounded moldings, which seem to be laid in the hollowsof the fluting. These are limited in length to about one third of theheight of the shaft.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, an Ishmaelite or theIshmaelites.
The quality of being charitable; the exercise of charity.
One of a sect of anchorites in the early church, who lived onthe tops of pillars for the exercise of their patience; -- calledalso pillarist and pillar saint.
The quality of being ambitious; ambition; pretentiousness.
A bleb; a vesicle, or an elevation of the cuticle, containing atransparent watery fluid.
One who, or a work which, narrates wonderful things; one whowrites of wonders. [Obs.] Bacon.

A porch or waiting room, usually at the west end of an abbeychurch, where the monks collected on returning from processions,where bodies were laid previous to interment, and where women wereallowed to see the monks to whom they were related, or to hear divineservice. Also, frequently applied to the porch of a church, as at Elyand Durham cathedrals. Gwilt.
The wife or widow of a duke; also, a lady who has thesovereignty of a duchy in her own right.
A red hand, as in the arms of Ulster, which is now thedistinguishing mark of a baronet of the United Kingdom.
Disinterestedness; impartiality; fairness. [Obs.] Prior.
Divided in such a manner as to resemble the two lips when themouth is more or less open; bilabiate.
One who is versed in the science of physiology; a student ofthe properties and functions of animal and vegetable organs andtissues.
A person with a large head; a numskull; a dunce. [Low] Knowles.
A porous earthen jar for cooling water by evaporation.
Any fish of the genus Diodon, and allied genera, whose body iscovered with spines. See Illust. under Diodon.
The act of interspersing, or the state of being interspersed.
Having the quality of excreting, or throwing offexcrementitious matter.
Resembling the parotid gland; -- applied especially tocutaneous glandular elevations above the ear in many toads and frogs.-- n.
Confirmation or approbation, as of an act or contract. [Obs.]Jer. Tailor.
A tall tree (Simaruba amara) growing in tropical America. It isone of the trees which yields quassia.
One of the posterity of Moab, the son of Lot. (Gen. xix. 37.)Also used adjectively.
In a scrappy manner; in scraps. Mary Cowden Clarke.
A species of agalloch, or aloes wood, of a dusky or mottledcolor, of a light, friable texture, and less fragrant than calambac;-- used by cabinetmakers.
A genus of labiate plants, including the catnip and ground ivy.
To treat disdainfully or with indignity; to contemn. [Obs.]Spenser.
Any sea snake of the genus Hydrophys and allied genera. Thesesnakes are venomous, live upon fishes, and have a flattened tail forswimming.
Having flavor or taste; yielding a taste. [R.] Bailey.
That branch of paleontology which treats of fossil plants.
Having four sides and four equal angles. Sir W. Raleigh.
The act of superinducing, or the state of being superinduced.South.
A woman who advocates the right to vote for women; a womansuffragist.
A blackish gray mineral, a sulphide of antimony, bismuth, andlead.
To cause to become not secular; to detach from secular things;to alienate from the world.
One who objects; one who offers objections to a proposition ormeasure.
The character or manner of a bluestocking; female pedantry.[Colloq.]
A kerchief for the neck; -- called also neck handkerchief.
To deprive of fibrin, as fresh blood or lymph by stirring withtwigs.
An instrument for measuring the amount of osmotic action indifferent liquids.
Washing away; carrying off impurities; detergent.-- n. (Med.)

The sudden removal of lands or soil from the estate of one manto that of another by an inundation or a current, or by a suddenchange in the course of a river by which a part of the estate of oneman is cut off and joined to the estate of another. The property inthe part thus separated, or cut off, continues in the original owner.Wharton. Burrill.
A line above or below a hanging net, to which the net isattached in order to strengthen it.
A small, portable, keyed wind instrument, whose tones aregenerated by play of the wind upon free metallic reeds.
To place or hide in a thicket; to ambush. [Obs.] Shelton.
Any one of the acalephs, esp. one of the larger species, havinga jellylike appearance. See Medusa.
A removable case or covering for a pillow, usually of whitelinen or cotton cloth.
To ominate beforehand; to portend. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
One skilled in legerdemain or sleight of hand; a juggler.
A grayish or whitish mineral occurring in orthorhombic,prismatic crystals, also in columnar masses. It is a silicate ofalumina and lime, and is allied to epidote.
An intercepting mound, erected in any part of a fortificationto protect the defenders from a rear or ricochet fire; a traverse.Farrow.
The measurement or determination of the quantity of ozone.
The outer portion of a fruit, as the flesh of a peach or therind of an orange. See Illust. of Drupe.
Any instrument by which electricity can be measured incoulombs.
Of or pertaining to one or more median and posterior elementsin the hyoidean arch of fishes.-- n.
Of or pertaining to Wallachia, a former principality, now partof the kingdom, of Roumania. -- n.
Created by one's self; not formed or constituted by another.
A tribe of Indians formerly inhabiting the region near OneidaLake in the State of New York, and forming part of the Five Nations.Remnants of the tribe now live in New York, Canada, and Wisconsin.
A separating; removal; also, an abscess. [Obs.] Gauden.Barrough.

One who, or that which, repeats. Specifically:(a) A watch with a striking apparatus which, upon pressure of aspring, will indicate the time, usually in hours and quarters.(b) A repeating firearm.(c) (Teleg.) An instrument for resending a telegraphic messageautomatically at an intermediate point.(d) A person who votes more than once at an election. [U.S.](e) See Circulating decimal, under Decimal.(f) (Naut.) A pennant used to indicate that a certain flag in a hoistof signal is duplicated. Ham. Nav. Encyc.
The state or quality of being leprous or scaly; also, a scale.Bacon.
Honored or worshiped as a deity; treated with supreme regard;godlike.

Effected or produced by a flood or deluge of water; -- said ofcoarse and imperfectly stratified deposits along ancient or existingwater courses. Similar unstratified deposits were formed by theagency of ice. The time of deposition has been called the Diluvianepoch.
An appearance of Christ, as to his disciples after thecrucifixion.
An umbelliferous biennial plant (Daucus Carota), of manyvarieties.
A hard compact mineral, of a dark green color, formerly worn asa remedy for diseases of the kidneys, whence its name; kidney stone;a kind of jade. See Jade.
The third tine above the base of a stag's antler; the royalantler.
A gown or case of skin, or one trimmed or lined with fur.[Obs.]
The quality or state of being involuntary; unwillingness;automatism.
A small Scotch coin worth about one sixth of an English penny.Sir W. Scott.
A rare element said to be contained in gadolinite.-- Hol"mic, a.

A genus of tall conifers of the pine family. The species areconfined mostly to South America and Australia. The wood cells differfrom those of other in having the dots in their lateral surfaces intwo or three rows, and the dots of contiguous rows alternating. Theseeds are edible.
Tender feeling; fondness. [Obs., except as a French word]
A peculiar rounded body lying near the nucleus of a cell. It isregarded as the dynamic element by means of which the machinery ofcell division is organized.
Conveying sensory or afferent impulses; -- said of nerves.
A form of double monster, in which two individuals are unitedby a common umbilicus.
To vomit forth what anything contains; to discharge; to makerestitution.See where it flows, disgorging at seven mouths Into the sea. Milton.
A passenger; a bird or boat of passage. [Obs.] Ld. Berners.
Pertaining to, or exhibiting, formularization. Emerson.
