One who adapts his opinions and manners to the times; one whoobsequiously compiles with the ruling power; -- now used only in abad sense.
The act or process of oxidizing, or the state or result ofbeing oxidized.
Same as Stilbite. It commonly occurs in bundles or tufts ofcrystals.
Pertaining to a stage; becoming the theater; theatrical. [Obs.]Jer. Taylor.
Bent down, and hollow in the back; sway-backed; -- said of ahorse. Shak.

A genus of large, extinct, wingless birds from the Cretaceousdeposits of Kansas, belonging to the Odontornithes. They had teeth,and were essentially carnivorous swimming ostriches. Several speciesare known. See Illust. in Append.
The wife or the widow of a marquis; a woman who has the rankand dignity of a marquis. Spelman.
The garment for the legs and feet and for the body below thewaist, worn in Europe throughout the Middle Ages; applied also to thearmor for the same parts, when fixible, as of chain mail.
That may be ruled; subject to rule; accordant or conformable torule. Bacon.

Applied to those actions, or muscular movements, which areautomatic expressions of dominant ideas, rather than the result ofdistinct volitional efforts, as the act of expressing the thoughts inspeech, or in writing, while the mind is occupied in the compositionof the sentence. Carpenter.
Without prospect of betterment in the future. W. D. Howells.
The act of pouring or spreading round; the state of beingspread round. Swift.

A highly volatile mixture of fluid hydrocarbons, obtained frompetroleum, as also by the distillation of bituminous coal. It is usedin making air gas, and in giving illuminating power to water gas. SeeCarburetor.
A rock consisting of granular red garnet, light greensmaragdite, and common hornblende; -- so called in reference to itsbeauty.
A large, strong rope, reaching from the foremast head to thebowsprit, to support the mast. See Illust. under Ship.
To cover with a casque or as with a casque. Sherwood.
A book of the Old Testament attributed to the prophet Jeremiah,and taking its name from the nature of its contents.
Capital letters, as found in manuscripts of the sixth centuryand earlier.
That branch of knowledge which deals with personal names andtheir origin; the study of patronymics.
A day on which courts are not held, as Sunday or any legalholiday.
The upper robe worn by a bishop, to which lawn sleeves areusually attached. Hook.
Resembling the domestic fowls and pheasants; of or pertainingto the Gallinae.
An acrid, poisonous, crystallizable substance, obtained from,the anemone, or from anemonin.
An order of Amphibia, having a long, annulated, snakelike body.See Ophiomorpha.
The palace of immortality, inhabited by the souls of heroesslain in battle.
A small, oval, transparent jellyfish, belonging to theCtenophora.
A heart-shaped bulbous root, about the size of a finger,brought from Turkey, formerly used as a cathartic.
The process of becoming or making gangrenous; mortification.
Inherent existence; existence possessed by virtue of a being'sown nature, and independent of any other being or cause; -- anattribute peculiar to God. Blackmore.
Of or pertaining to an assessor, or to a court of assessors.Coxe.
The soft and easily-worked wood of the tulip tree(Liriodendron). It is much used in cabinetwork, carriage building,etc.

The science of the world or universe; or a treatise relating tothe structure and parts of the system of creation, the elements ofbodies, the modifications of material things, the laws of motion, andthe order and course of nature.
A native of the Philippine Islands, specif. one of Spanishdescent or of mixed blood.
Interlaced one with another; -- said of charges and ordinaries.
Relating to, accompanied by, or containing, endosperm.
One of a long-established English breed of large pigs. They arered, often spotted with black, with a long snout and erect orforwardly pointed ears, and are valued as bacon producers.
Repeatedly compound; made up of complex constituents.
A chief of a tribe of the American Indians; a sagamore.
An unsaturated hydrocarbon, C5H8, of the acetylene series. Sameas Valerylene.
The act or process of torrefying, or the state of beingtorrefied. Bp. Hall.
A scheme to unite all the Greeks in one political body.
A double triplet; a group of six equal notes played in the timeof four.
Originally, a large hound used in hunting wolves; now, any oneof certain breeds of large dogs, some of which are nearly identicalwith the great Danes.
Relating to the comitia, or popular assembles of the Romans forelecting officers and passing laws. Middleton.
A West Indian palm; also the fruit of this palm, the seeds ofwhich are used as a remedy for diseases of the chest.
The middle or inferior horn of each lateral ventricle of thebrain. B. G. Wilder.
One who deals in oils; formerly, one who dealt in oils andpickles.
One of the disks forming the ends of a lantern wheel or pinion.
The conjugal state; sexual intercourse. [R.] Milton.
All that is, or can be, contained in a purse; enough to fill apurse.
The anacardiaceous tree Pistacia vera, which yields thepistachio nut; also, the nut itself and the flavoring extractprepared from it.

Any lophobranch fish of the genus Siphostoma, or Syngnathus,and allied genera, having a long and very slender angular body,covered with bony plates. The mouth is small, at the end of a long,tubular snout. The male has a pouch on his belly, in which theincubation of the eggs takes place.
One who breaks horses; especially (Mil.), a noncommissionedofficer in the British cavalry, whose duty is to assist the ridingmaster.
A woman who instructs; a preceptress; a governess. Johnson.
A solemn declaration made under the penalties of perjury, bypersons who conscientiously decline taking an oath, which declarationis in law equivalent to an oath. Bouvier.
A change-speed gear in which the gears are changed by slidingendwise.
A shark (Sphryna tiburio) allied to the hammerhead, and nativeof the warmer parts of the Atlantic and Pacific oceans; -- calledalso bonnet shark.
To foretell the fate of; to predict; to destine to. [Scot.]Jamieson.
Having strong or large thews or muscles; muscular; sinewy;strong.
Formed into, or characterized by, voice; vocalized; -- said ofall the vowels and the semivowels, also of the vocal or sonantconsonants g, d, b, l, r, v, z, etc.
A stone running through a wall from one face to another, tobind it together; a binding stone.
A process, now no longer used, invented by J. N. Niepce, aFrench chemist, in 1829. It depends upon the action of light inrendering a thin layer of bitumen, with which the plate is coated,insoluble.
An extensive division of gastropod Mollusca in which the loopor visceral nerves is twisted, and the sexes separate. It is nearlyto equivalent to Prosobranchiata.
A space under a roof; a tabernacle; a dwelling. [Obs.] Davies(Holy Roode).
A quaternary deposit, usually consisting of a fine yellowishearth, on the banks of the Rhine and other large rivers.
A case for sewing materials. See Housewife. Cowper.
A hole in the earth to which a fox resorts to hide himself.
A genus of plants including the common nettles. See Nettle, n.
One of the rudimentary front wings of certain insects(Stylops). They resemble the halteres, or rudimentary hind wings, ofDiptera.
Any gorgonian which branches in a fanlike form, especiallyGorgonia flabellum of Florida and the West Indies.
Abnormal breathing, due to slightly deficient arterializationof the blood; -- in distinction from eupnoea. See Eupnoea, andDispnoea.
A selection or extract from a book; especially (Theol.), aselection from the Bible, appointed to be read in the churches orused as a text for a sermon.
A genus of large, stalked crinoids, of which several speciesoccur in deep water among the West Indies and elsewhere.
To work over coarsely, without regard to nicety, smoothness, orfinish. Moxon.
To use words or phrases borrowed from the Latin. Dryden.
A piece of parchment bearing the Decalogue and attached to thedoorpost; -- in use among orthodox Hebrews.
A dealer in the cakes called wafers; a confectioner. [Obs.]Chaucer.

A device, consisting essentially of an electric arc and acamera, by which a series of photographs of the variations of the arcdue to sound waves are obtained for reproduction by means of aselenium cell and a telephone.
That which is worn under the outside clothing; underclothes.
A large ship, esp. a merchant vessel of the largest size.Where your argosies with portly sail . . . Do overpeer the pettytraffickers. Shak.
A cutaneous disease characterized by numerous tumors, ofvarious forms, filled with a thick matter; -- so called from theresemblance of the tumors to some molluscous animals. Dunglison.

In Athens, originally, the military commanderin-chief; but,afterward, a civil magistrate who had jurisdiction in respect ofstrangers and sojourners. In other Grecian cities, a high militaryand civil officer.
The seed of one or more leguminous plants of the genusDolichos; also, the plant itself. Many varieties are cultivated inthe southern part of the United States.
As, or in the manner of, an adjective; adjectively.
Situated or growing under water, as leaves; submersed.
Partnership in inheritance; joint heirship; joint right ofsucession to an inheritance.
A figure by which a grave and magnificent word is put for theproper word; amplification; hyperbole.
An anvil ending in a beak or point (orig. in two beaks); also,the beak or horn itself.
A kind of large drinking cup, -- used by Greeks and Romans,esp. by poor folk.
A crab in the act of casting its shell, or immediatelyafterwards while still soft; -- applied especially to the ediblecrabs, which are most prized while in this state.
One who transplants; also, a machine for transplanting trees.
To bring forth young, as a cat; to kitten; to litter. [Prov.Eng. & Scot.]
Having the quality of being viscous or adhesive; soft andsticky; glutinous; damp and adhesive, as if covered with a coldperspiration.
A member of the Congress of the United States, esp. of theHouse of Representatives.
An attracting of attention, as a lion; also, the treating orregarding as a lion.
A remedy or antidose for poison; theriaca. [Obs.] Parr.

Any one of several species of mice belonging to the genusHydromys, native of Australia and Tasmania. Their hind legs arestrong and their toes partially webbed. They live on the borders ofstreams, and swim well. They are remarkable as being the only rodentsfound in Australia.

The enriched block or horizontal bracket generally found underthe cornice of the Corinthian and Composite entablature, andsometimes, less ornamented, in the Ionic and other orders; -- socalled because of its arrangement at regulated distances.
A Danish coin worth about fifty-four cents. It was former unitof value in Denmark.
Between molecules; situated, or acting, between the moleculesof bodies.
To mark, as sheep, by cropping or slitting the ear.
A wheel used for measuring, by its motion when submerged, thevelocity of flowing water; a current wheel.
A group or series of four dramatic pieces, three tragedies andone satyric, or comic, piece (or sometimes four tragedies),represented consequently on the Attic stage at the Dionysiacfestival.
Feats of the acrobat; daring gymnastic feats; high vaulting.
An instrument for noting or recording phenomena attendant onthunderstorms.
The act of suspending, or the state of being suspended,especially for a short time; temporary suspension.
One who believes that past changes in the structure of theearth have proceeded from cataclysms or causes more violent than arenow operating; -- called also nonuniformitarian.
A thing to be believed; an article of faith; -- distinguishedfrom agendum, a practical duty.The great articles and credenda of Christianity. South.
The doctrine of symptoms; that part of the science of medicinewhich treats of the symptoms of diseases; semeiology.
The act or process of matriculating; the state of beingmatriculated.
A light repast between meals; a lunch. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
The process of separating soap from spent lye, as with salt.
A commissioned or noncommissioned officer posted in the rear ofa line, or on the flank of a column, of soldiers, to rectify mistakesand insure steadiness and promptness in the ranks.
One who vends; one who transfers the exclusive right ofpossessing a thing, either his own, or that of another as his agent,for a price or pecuniary equivalent; a seller; a vendor.
The state of a daughter, or the conduct becoming a daughter.
To move one way and the other so as to get a close place; tolie close for comfort; to cuddle; to nestle.
Acting momentarily, or by impulse; not continuous; -- said offorces.
A meteor or atmospheric phenomenon dependent upon the vapor ofwater; -- in the pl., a general term for the whole aqueous phenomenaof the atmosphere, as rain, snow, hail, etc. Nichol.
The highest or covering course of masonry in a wall, often withsloping edges to carry off water; -- sometimes called capping. Gwill.
The solid rock underlying superficial formations. Also Fig.
A method of teaching reading in which words are first taken assingle ideograms and later analyzed into their phonetic andalphabetic elements; -- contrasted with the alphabet and sentencemethods.
Capable of being translated into, or expressed in, English.
A kind of militia in Poland, consisting of the gentry, which,in case of invasion, was summoned to the defense of the country.
Weeds, collectively; also, a place full of weeds or for growingweeds. [R.] Dr. H. More.
To charge upon with reproach; to upbraid. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
A small branching shrub (Dirca palustris), with a white, softwood, and a tough, leathery bark, common in damp woods in theNorthern United States; -- called also moosewood, and wicopy. Gray.
In Germany, a young lady; an unmarried woman; -- as a title,equivalent to Miss.
A bag pudding; a name of reproach or ridicule formerly appliedby the Scotch to the English.
The act or process of intensifying, or of making more intense.
A vessel of porous earthenware, used for cooling liquids byevaporation from the exterior surface.

A European gold wasp (Chrysis ignita) which has the under sideof the abdomen bright red, and the other parts deep bluish green witha metallic luster. The larva is parasitic in the nests of other waspsand of bees.
Impurities separated from spices, drugs, etc.; -- also calledgarblings.
Either of the first two propositions of a syllogism, from whichthe conclusion is drawn.
Having an ovate form, but with a subulate tip or extremity.
Pertaining to, containing, or resembling, oxygen; producingoxygen.
A utensil to hold a chamber vessel, for the use of the sick andinfirm. It is usually in the form of a box, with a seat and tightcover.
A division of Nudibranchiata, in which the mantle itself servesas a gill.
A bully; a blustering, turbulent, insolent, fellow; one whovexes or provokes.
The African sugar cane (Holcus saccharatus), -- resembling thesorghum, or Chinese sugar cane.
Bearing Children; (Fig.) productive; fruitful. [R.] Shak.
To ascribed diabolical qualities to; to change into, or torepresent as, a devil. [R.] Farindon.
Of or pertaining to the middle of the ethmoid region or ethmoidbone.-- n. (Anat.)
The murder of an infant born alive; the murder or killing of anewly born or young child; child murder.
A common American minnow (Fundulus majalis). See Minnow.

The sending or placing back of a person to a title or right hehad before; the restitution of one who obtains possession of propertyunder a defective title, to his rights under some valid title byvirtue of which he might legally have entered into possession only bysuit. Bouvier.
Either of several tropical aquatic plants of the genusEichhornia, related to the pickerel weed.
Wrong conduct; bad behavior; mismanagement. Addison.
A petiole dilated into the form of a blade, and usually withvertical edges, as in the Australian acacias.
A mingling of different things; admixture. Glanvill.
The division of a nerve, for the relief of neuralgia, or forother purposes. Dunglison.
Having a reverential and loving feeling towards God; religious.A brave good-fearing man. Tennyson.
A kind of fungus with an irregularly wrinkled, somewhatglobular pileus (Helvella, or Gyromitra, esculenta.).
An American climbing shrub (Celastrus scandens). It bears aprofusion of yellow berrylike pods, which open in the autumn, anddisplay the scarlet coverings of the seeds.
A method of transferring pictures from photographic negativesto hardened gelatin plates from which impressions are produced onpaper as by lithography.
Having two wings, as certain insects; belonging to the orderDiptera.
A crystalline acid substance, CH2N4, which may be regarded aspyrrol in which nitrogen atoms replace three CH groups; also, any ofvarious derivatives of the same.
A game at cards, a modification of seven-up, or all fours.
The male organ of flowers for secreting and furnishing thepollen or fecundating dust. It consists of the anther and filament.
A suborder of aquatic carnivorous mammals including the sealsand walruses; -- opposed to Fissipedia.
A mild cathartic oil, expressed or extracted from the seeds ofthe Ricinus communis, or Palma Christi. When fresh the oil isinodorus and insipid. Castor-oil plant. Same as Palma Christi.
A wave, or two or three successive waves, of great height andviolence, at flood tide moving up an estuary or river; -- commonlycalled the bore. See Bore.
One who buys or sells the parliamentary seats of boroughs.
A moss or mosslike plant which cellular stems, having usuallyan upward growth and distinct leaves.
To eject from a post; to displace. [R.] Davies (Holy Roode).
One that Pasteurizes, specif. an apparatus for heating andagitating, fluid.
A genus of ophiurans having the arms much branched.
To practice auscultation; to examine by auscultation.
To harass; to torment; to distress. [Obs.] Spenser.
Composed by candlelight, or by night; of or pertaining to nightstudies; laborious or painstaking. Pope.
A setting out; a going forward; advance; progression. [Obs.]Sir T. Browne.
An officer of the customs, whose duty it is to search vessels.[Eng.]
Any one of a tribe of anomuran crustaceans, of which Pagurus isa type; the hermit crab. See Hermit crab, under Hermit.
Of or pertaining to sciolism, or a sciolist; partaking ofsciolism; resembling a sciolist.
Having an evennumber of digits on the hands or the feet. Qwen.
The native language of the Irish; that branch of the Celticlanguages spoken by the natives of Ireland. Also adj.
A game at cards, played usually by two persons, in which theplayers may discard any or all of the cards dealt and receive othersfrom the pack.
Rum, whisky, brandy, gin, and other distilled liquors havingmuch alcohol, in distinction from wine and malt liquors.
Any one of a group of metametric hydrocarcons (C8H18) of themethane series. The most important is a colorless, volatile,inflammable liquid, found in petroleum, and a constituent of benzeneor ligroin.

A basic, dark-colored, holocrystalline, igneous rock,consisting essentially of a triclinic feldspar and pyroxene withmagnetic iron; -- often limited to rocks pretertiary in age. Itincludes part of what was early called greenstone.
A vassal or voluntary follower of Frankish princes in theirenterprises.
A nickname given to an inhabitant of the State of Indiana.[U.S.]
Discoverable by scrutiny, inquiry, or critical examination.[R.] r. H. More.
To make a place kick; to make (a goal) by a place kick. --Place"-kick`er, n.
A hydrate of alumina, often occurring in white lamellar masseswith brilliant pearly luster; -- so named on account of itsdecrepitating when heated before the blowpipe.
Of or pertaining to tricrotism; characterized by tricrotism.
A variety of the common cabbage (Brassica oleracea major),having curled leaves, -- much cultivated for winter use.
A scoop with a long handle, used to wash the sides of a vessel,and formerly to wet the sails or deck.
To collect (illustrations from books) for decoration of otherbooks. G. A. Sala.
Half-rotten straw, or any like substance strewn on the ground,as over the roots of plants, to protect from heat, drought, etc., andto preserve moisture.
In a mad manner; without reason or understanding; wildly.
Freedom or exemption from error; infallibility. Eikon Basilike.
The act of making loyal to a king. [R.] Saintsbury.
To invest with imperial authority, character, or style; tobring to the form of an empire. Fuller.
To make different; to vary; to variegate. [R.] Sylvester.
Of or pertaining to Norway, its inhabitants, or its language.
A kind of pump for exhausting air from a vessel or closedspace; also, a pump to condense air of force in into a closed space.
A twelfth part of the heavens; a house. See 1st House, 8.Chaucer.
The hair grass (Agrostis scabra). So called from its lightpanicle, which is blown to great distances by the wind.
An inclosure constructed to entrap wild elephants; an elephanttrap. [India]
The acquiring of property by other means than by inheritance;acquisition. Blackstone.
A division of birds including Turnix and allied genera,resembling quails in appearance but differing from them anatomically.

A contrivance consisting of a slat of wood tied to the end of athong or string, with which the slat is whirled so as to cause anintermittent roaring noise. It is used as a toy, and among some racesin certain religious rites.
A division of holothurians having an internal gill, orrespiratory tree.
A group of lamellicorn, plant-eating beetles; -- called alsoLamellicornes.
Of or pertaining to the sea, or arm of the Mediterranean sea,east of Greece. See Archipelago.
In an accidental manner; unexpectedly; by chance;unintentionally; casually; fortuitously; not essentially.
Of or pertaining to prophecy; prophetic. T. Warton.
Leaning; fitted for a reclining posture. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
The common American bittern (Botaurus lentiginosus); -- socalled because one of its notes resembles the sound made in driving astake into the mud. Called also meadow hen, and Indian hen.
A genus of chilognathous myriapods. The body is long and round,consisting of numerous smooth, equal segments, each of which bearstwo pairs of short legs. It includes the galleyworms. SeeChilognatha.
The doctrine of Leibnitz, that all substance involves force.

Steel made directly from cast iron, by burning out a portion ofthe carbon and other impurities that the latter contains, through theagency of a blast of air which is forced through the molten metal; --so called from Sir Henry Bessemer, an English engineer, the inventorof the process.
A person who waits at the mouth of the shaft to receive thekibble of ore.
Moving easily; hence, mild-tempered; ease-loving; inactive.
Of or pertaining to Castalia, a mythical fountain ofinspiration on Mt. Parnassus sacred to the Muses. Milton.
An instrument for arresting hemorrhage. It consists essentiallyof a pad or compress upon which pressure is made by a band which istightened by a screw or other means.
Not conformed to rule or system; deviating from the type;anomalous; irregular. "That deviating from the type; anomalous;irregular. " Froude.
To choose; to wish for; to desire. [Obs.] Cotgrave.
A stool or other thing supported by three legs; a trivet.
A thatched or tiled house or cottage, of a single story,usually surrounded by a veranda. [India]
The act or process of laying bare the roots of trees to exposethem to the air and water. [Obs.] Evelyn.
One who makes tatting. Caulfield & S. (Doct. of Needlework).
The small table by the side of the altar or communion table, onwhich the bread and wine are placed before being consecrated.
Affected with purse pride; puffed up with the possession ofriches.
A somewhat aromatic composite weed (Artemisia vulgaris), at onetime used medicinally; -- called also motherwort.
Eager for novelties; desirous of changing. [Obs.]So newfangel be they of their meat. Chaucer.
In early Christian and eccesiastical art, an emblematic fish,or the Greek word for fish, which combined the initials of the Greekwords
The act of reappointing, or the state of being reappointed.
A condiment made from the sap of the bitter cassava (Manihotutilissima) deprived of its poisonous qualities, concentrated byboiling, and flavored with aromatics. See Pepper pot.
A stone for the lap, on which shoemakers beat leather.
Belonging to the Alemanni, a confederacy of warlike Germantribes.
To cross at an acute angle; to cut or divide in the form of X;to intersect; -- said of lines in geometrical figures, rays of light,nerves, etc.
The line drawn through a focus of a conic section parallel tothe directrix and terminated both ways by the curve. It is theparameter of the principal axis. See Focus, and Parameter.

A genus of hexactinelline sponges, having a long stem composedof very long, slender, transparent, siliceous fibres twisted togetherlike the strands of a color. The stem of the Japanese species (H.Sieboldii), called glass-rope, has long been in use as an ornament.See Glass-rope.
Pertaining to, or having the character of, an exogen; -- theopposite of endogenous.
An Egyptian or Persian measure of length, varying from thirthy-two to sixty stadia.
An instrument for marking time in musical movements. SeeMetronome.
A haulage system for canal boats, in which an electriclocomotive running on a monorail has its adhesion materiallyincreased by the pull of the tow rope on a series of inclinedgripping wheels.
To wax or grow too rapindly or too much. [Obs.] R. ofGloucester.

An armadillo (Xenurus unicinctus), native of the tropical partsof South America. It has about thirteen movable bands composed ofsmall, nearly square, scales. The head is long; the tail is round andtapered, and nearly destitute of scales; the claws of the fore feetare very large. Called also tatouary, and broad-banded armadillo.
The parts of a ship above the water when she is laden.
Any one of numerous species of beautiful humming birds of thegenus Eriocnemis having large tufts of downy feathers on the legs.
A public building in certain Greek cities; especially, a publichall in Athens regarded as the home of the community, in whichofficial hospitality was extended to distinguished citizens andstrangers.
Having the form of, or a structure modified from, a pentadactyllimb.

A slight frame of wood three or four feet long and about onethird as wide, with thongs or cords stretched across it, and having asupport and holder for the foot; -- used by persons for walking onsoft snow.
A contract under, or subordinate to, a previous contract.
Situated over, or on the dorsal side of, the sacrum.
With an intent to commit burglary; in the manner of a burglar.Blackstone.
An English dry measure, being, at London, 36 bushels heaped up,or its equivalent weight, and more than twice as much at Newcastle.Now used exlusively for coal and coke.
To deposit in a tomb, as a dead body; to bury; to inter; toinhume. Hooker.
A dog used in hunting the wild boar; a leamer. Spenser.
A sentinel, usually on horseback, stationed on the outpost ofan army, to watch an enemy and give notice of danger; a vidette.
Resembling a rowdy in temper or conduct; characteristic of arowdy.
A walk for foot passengers at the side of a street or road; afoot pavement. [U.S.]
A thin layer of peculiar contractile tissue directly beneaththe skin of the scrotum.

Specifically, a small body of cavalry, light horse, ordragoons, consisting usually of about sixty men, commanded by acaptain; the unit of formation of cavalry, corresponding to thecompany in infantry. Formerly, also, a company of horse artillery; abattery.
Pertaining to, or resembling, a labyrinth; intricate;labyrinthian.
Imperfectly vitalized; having naturally but little vital poweror energy.
Capable of being funded, or converted into a fund; convertibleinto bonds.
A young human being; a child; also, a young animal, as a colt.
A genus of coniferous trees, having deciduous leaves, infascicles (see Illust. of Fascicle).
Dying together or at the same time. [R.] Sir G. Buck.
To render more grievous; to aggravate. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
One who forestalls; esp., one who forestalls the market. Locke.
To separate, as substances in combination; to release fromcombination or union. [R.] Daniel.

The act of reconcentrating or the state of beingreconcentrated; esp., the act or policy of concentrating the ruralpopulation in or about towns and villages for convenience inpolitical or military administration, as in Cuba during therevolution of 1895-98.
To make like a woman; to make effeminate. [Obs.] V. Knox.
A heavy-armed foot soldier from Ireland and the Western Islesin the time of Edward Shak.
Apt to let things fall, or to let them slip away; slippery;careless.
Capable of being drunk; suitable for drink; potable. Macaulay.Also used substantively, esp. in the plural. Steele.
Of or pertaining to printing; typographical. [Obs.] Fuller.
A caster of accounts; a reckoner; a bookkeeper; -- usedconteptuously.
A cloud formation similar to cirro-stratus, but heavier and ata lower level.
To exceed in weight; to overbalance; to weigh down. Drayton.Hooker.
The state of being at one or reconciled. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
A compound of boric acid and glycerin, used as an antiseptic.
A additional charge to a coat of arms, given as a mark ofhonor. Cussans.
One who governs by terrorism or intimidation; specifically, anagent or partisan of the revolutionary tribunal during the Reign ofTerror in France. Burke.
A district, or part of a province. See Sircar. [India]
Originally, work done by the day; work done by a journeyman athis trade.
Unseasonable or unseasonably; unsuitable or unsuitably.
A form of machine for dressing the surface of wood, metal,stone, etc.

The answer of a jury given to the court concerning any matterof fact in any cause, civil or criminal, committed to theirexamination and determination; the finding or decision of a jury onthe matter legally submitted to them in the course of the trial of acause.
Accustomed to speak without reserve. Bacon.-- Free"-spo`ken-ness, n.
A false persuasion; wrong notion or opinion. Dr. H. More.
The basal part of the labium of insects. It bears the mentum.
Any theory which conceives chance as an objective reality;esp., a theory of evolution which considers that variation may bepurely fortuitous.

A term used for lace of different kinds; most properly for alace of large pattern and heavy material which has no ground or mesh,but has the pattern held together by connecting threads called barsor brides.
An inference which does not follow from the premises.
To cause to pass through a sieve or colander; to strain, asthrough a sieve. [Obs.] Harvey.
Having the teeth consolidated with the inner edge of the jaw,as in some lizards.
The quality of being true; reality; genuineness; faithfulness;sincerity; exactness; truth.
Conversion of the cell walls into cork tissue by development ofsuberin; -- commonly taking place in exposed tissues, as when acallus forms over a wound. Suberized cell walls are impervious towater.
Contrived for the purpose of making a show, or gainingapplause; deceptive; unreal.
The science which treats of the chemical properties, actions orrelations of substances in quantity; -- distinguished from micro-chemistry.
An inscription, label, or the like, in a book indicating itsownership; esp., a bookplate.
A publication which appears regularly once a month.
To impair or become impaired; to injure. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The official title applied to that one of the Anglo-Saxonchieftains who was chosen by the other chiefs to lead them in theirwarfare against the British tribes. Brande & C.
A continuous composition, not divided into what are calledmovements, or governed by the ordinary rules of musical design, butin which the author's fancy roves unrestricted by set form.
A renewing, or making whole again. See Redintegration.
A plant (Solanum Melongena), of East Indian origin, allied tothe tomato, and bearing a large, smooth, edible fruit, shapedsomewhat like an egg; mad-apple.
A process of electric welding in which heat is developed by alarge current passing through the metal.
Of or pertaining to trap; being of the nature of trap.
An instrument for tightening the parts of a bedstead.
Having the quality of entering into composition; compounded.[R.]
A suborder of Gephyrea, including those which have the bodyunarmed and the intestine opening anteriorly.
A hydrous borate of lime occurring in transparent colorless orwhite crystals, also massive, in Southern California.
A compound containing in the molecule two atoms of hydrogenunited with some other element or radical. [Obs.]
A plant of the genus Prunus (P. Padus); the bird cherry.[Scot.]
Of or pertaining to vines; containing vines. [R.] Sir T.Browne.
A building or inclosure used for the cultivation of grapes.
A black or greenish black mineral occurring in foliated flates,also in velvety bronze-colored incrustations. It is a hydroussilicate of iron and alumina.
The Parliament of Norway, chosen by indirect election once inthree years, but holding annual sessions.
A genus of trilobites, of many species, common in the UpperSilurian and Devonian rocks.
A strain given on the horn to call back the hounds when theyhave lost track of the game.

A judicatory consisting of all the ministers within a certaindistrict, and one layman, who is a ruling elder, from each parish orchurch, commissioned to represent the church in conjunction with thepastor. This body has a general jurisdiction over the churches underits care, and next below the provincial synod in authority.
The inner or body garments taken together. See Cuerpo. Dryden.
An officer or person in a merchant ship, whose duty is tomanage the sales, and superintend the commercial concerns, of thevoyage.
A cart with wooden wheels, drawn by bullocks. [Bengal] Malcom.
Not equipped like a soldier; unsoldierlike. [Obs.] J. Fletcher.
To swear solemnly; to take an oath. [Obs.] Cockeram.
The member of a family whose labor supplies the food of thefamily; one who works for his living. H. Spencer.
To store up; to inclose; to contain. [Obs.] Wyclif.
To insult; to flout; to mock; to snub. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
The meadow fescue (Festuca elatior). See under Grass.
The aititude through which a heavy body must fall to acquire avelocity equal to that with which a ball is discharged from a piece.
Fugitive concealment; secret retirement; hiding. [R.] Phillips.
A peculiar bony tissue beneath the enamel of a ganoid scale.
Any one of several species of Manis, Pholidotus, and relatedgenera, found in Africa and Asia. They are covered with imbricatedscales, and feed upon ants. Called also scaly ant-eater.
One of a large and fleet breed of hounds used in hunting deer;a staghound.
A bright brown polished calfskin binding of  books, stainedwith a conventional treelike design.
Customs; habits; esp., customs conformity to which is more orless obligatory; customary law.
The clothing (esp., an outer, wooden covering), as of a steamcylinder, applied to prevent the radiation of heat; a covering oflags; -- called also deading and cleading.
Not conversant; not acquainted; not versed; unfamiliar.

The process of repeating, or adding to itself, any given numberor quantity a certain number of times; commonly, the process ofascertaining by a briefer computation the result of such repeatedadditions; also, the rule by which the operation is performed; -- thereverse of division.
In an accurate manner; exactly; precisely; without error ordefect.

A large bird, of the genus Casuarius, found in the east Indies.It is smaller and stouter than the ostrich. Its head is armed with akind of helmet of horny substance, consisting of plates overlappingeach other, and it has a group of long sharp spines on each wingwhich are used as defensive organs. It is a shy bird, and runs withgreat rapidity. Other species inhabit New Guinea, Australia, etc.
A mixed woven fabric of silk and cotton; or silk and wool;sayette; also, a light woolen fabric.
Having joint or equal signification; synonymous. [R.] Spelman.
Having all four toes united by a web;-said of certain seabirds, as the pelican and the gannet. See Illust. under Aves.
A hydrocarbon, C11H24, of the paraffin series; -- so calledbecause it has eleven atoms of carbon in each molecule. Called alsoendecane, undecane.
The state of being insanable or incurable; insanableness.
Too busy; too ready to intermeddle; too officious. Collier.
Connecting, or adapted to connect; involving connection.Connection tissue (Anat.) See Conjunctive tissue, under Conjunctive.

An aquatic carnivore (Enhydris lutris, or marina) found in theNorth Pacific Ocean. Its fur is highly valued, especially by theChinese. It is allied to the common otter, but is larger, with feetmore decidedly webbed. Sea-otter's cabbage (Bot.), a gigantic kelp ofthe Pacific Ocean (Nereocystis Lutkeana). See Nereocystis.
A name anciently given to an itinerant minstrel or musician.
Moodly silent; sullen; sour; obstinate; morose; splenetic.
The fundamental forms of organic life, that are composed of twoequal and symmetrical halves. Syd. Soc. Lex.
To inclose, or nearly inclose, as a harbor or a vessel, withland.
Money or other valuable thing given to evidence a contract; apledge or earnest.
Any species of burrowing toads of the genus Scaphiopus, esp. S.Holbrookii, of the Eastern United States; -- called also spade toad.
Having the bill cleft beyond the horny part, as in the case ofswallows and goatsuckers.
One of a sect of Asiatic Gnostics of the time of the EmperorTrajan.
To print surreptitiously a work belonging to another. E.Phillips.
A machine the operation of which is started by dropping a coininto a slot, for delivering small articles of merchandise, showingone's weight, exhibiting pictures, throwing dice, etc.
Having the properties of a nonmetal; nonmetallic; acid;negative.
The operation of cutting into the thyroid cartilage.
A genus of small, polished, marine univalve shells, native ofall warm seas.
The state of a hermit; a living in seclusion from social life.
To hold fast; to grasp something firmly; to seize or grasp oneanother.
Having the back hollow or sagged, whether naturally or as theresult of injury or weakness; -- said of horses and other animals.
In an ignominious manner; disgracefully; shamefully;ingloriously.
A public hall or room, for the use of visitors at wateringplaces and health resorts in Germany.
To reckon below what is right or proper; to underrate. Bp.Hall.
A fish of the genus Diodon or the genus Tetraodon, having thepower of distending its body by taking air or water into itsdilatable esophagus. See Globefish, and Bur fish.
The state or quality of being eminent; greatness; grandeur;glory; fame.
The hard pearly internal layer of several kinds of shells, esp.of pearl oysters, river mussels, and the abalone shells; nacre. SeePearl.
(Chem.) A salt of palmic acid; a ricinoleate. [Obsoles.]

A corporation, such as a railroad company, lighting company,water company, etc., organized or chartered to follow a publiccalling or to render services more or less essential to the generalpublic convenience or safety.
A genus of long, slender, wormlike bivalve mollusks which boreinto submerged wood, such as the piles of wharves, bottoms of ships,etc.; -- called also shipworm. See Shipworm. See Illust. in App.
A net to be drawn along the bottom of a body of water, as infishing.
A bath for the feet; also, a vessel used in bathing the feet.
One who is very exact in observing forms and ceremonies.Milton.
The sixth joint of a typical leg of a crustacean; usually, thepenultimate joint.
A plant which has its seeds inclosed in a pericarp.
A division of gastropod mollusks having a large number of long,divergent, hooklike, lingual teeth in each transverse row. Itincludes the scutibranchs. See Illustration in Appendix.
To play the philosopher; to moralize. [Obs.] Barrow.
Devoid of nitrogen; as, a nonnitrogenous principle; anonnitrogenous food. See the Note under Food, n., 1.
The distribution of religious books, tracts, etc., bycolporteurs.
A division of Foraminifera, including those in which the shellis not porous.
A kind of crystallite having a (slender) acicular form.
Belonging to, or resembling, the oldest and simplest of thethree orders of architecture used by the Greeks, but ranked as secondof the five orders adopted by the Romans. See Abacus, Capital, Order.
A beak flute, an older form of the flute, played with amouthpiece resembling a beak, and held like a flageolet.
The obtaining in a suit at law of a right to something by averdict and judgment of court.
The principles of those who advocate extreme measures, asradical reform, and the like. Dr. H. More.
Beset with snares; insnared, as with birdlime. L. Addison.
A shell consisting of one valve only; a mollusk whose shell iscomposed of a single piece, as the snails and conchs.
At frequent or short intervals; many times; often; repeatedly;commonly.
A house for the reception of waste matter; a privy. [Obs.] 2Kings x. 27.
The line which forms the communication between the steeringwheel and the telltale.

Ornamental work, formerly with grains or breads, but nowcomposed of fine wire and used chiefly in decorating gold and silverto which the wire is soldered, being arranged in designs frequentlyof a delicate and intricate arabesque pattern.
The semifluid, granular interior of certain unicellularorganisms, as the inner layer of sarcode in the amoeba; entoplasm;endoplasta.
A path traveled by men or animals in towing boats; -- calledalso towing path.
A kind of delicate forcemeat, commonly poached and used as adish by itself or for garnishing.
Situated above, or in the upper part of, the carpus.
Having the qualities of balsam; containing, or resembling,balsam; soft; mitigative; soothing; restorative.
A loose gown used for undress; also, a gown used for a sleepinggarnment.
Circumscribing or tending to circumscribe; marcing the limitsor form of.
Act of knocking out, or state of being knocked out.
Divided into three parts or segments by incisions extending tothe midrib or to the base; -- said of leaves.
The soft, spongy wood of a species of Magnolia (M. Umbrella).
The Song of Songs or Song of Solomon, one of the books of theOld Testament.
An ornamental tray, dish, or the like, used as a salver.
Capable of being carried by, or as by, post. [Obs.] W. Montagu.
A division of passerine birds including the humming birds,swifts, and goatsuckers. It is now generally considered an artificialgroup.
Resembling a scale; also, covered with scales; scaly.
Of or pertaining to the middle portion of the nasal region.
That which locks or unlocks a movement; a catch, pawl, or dog;especially, in clockwork, the catch which locks and unlocks thewheelwork in striking.
The man-eater, or white shark (Carcharodon carcharias); -- socalled on account of its causing requiems to be sung.
An arguing over again, as of a motion made in court.
A military engine acting like a sling, which threw stones froma bag or wooden bucket, and was operated by machinery. Fairholt.
Any species of lamellicorn beetles belonging to Rurila andallied genera, as the spotted grapevine beetle (Pelidnota punctata).
Capable of being insnared or entrapped. [R.] Cudworth.
A wild dog found in Australia, but supposed to have introducedat a very early period. It has a wolflike face, bushy tail, and areddish brown color.
A genus (Bromus) of grasses, one species of which is the chessor cheat.
A suborder of Hemiptera, in which the base of the anteriorwings is thickened. See Hemiptera.
A shot in which the ball struck with the cue comes in contactwith two or more balls on the table; a hitting of two or more ballswith the player's ball. In England it is called cannon.
The operation of removing the tonsil, or a portion thereof.

A compound in which tar or asphaltum combined with animal orvegetable oils is vulcanized by sulphur, the product closelyresembling rubber; -- used principally as an insulating material intelegraphy. Knight.
A structure of bedded rocks in which the beds on both sides ofan axis or axial plane dip away from the axis; an anticlinal.
An igneous rock consisting largely of chrysolite, with pyroxeneand picotite (a variety of spinel containing chromium).
Of or pertaining to a monolith; consisting of a single stone.
The Department of Foreign Affairs in the Chinese government.
A barrulet, or, rarely, a bendlet, with pendants, or points,usually three, especially used as a mark of cadency to distinguish aneldest or only son while his father is still living.
The act of discoursing; discourse; instruction; preaching.[Obs.] Chaucer.
Turned in a direction which is not the usual one; -- said of ananimal turned to the sinister which is usually turned to the dexter,or the like.
Of or resembling flour; mealy; covered with flour. Dickens.
The act of transcending, or surpassing; also, passage over.[Obs.] Chapman.
A piece of wood or stiff hide placed over shrouds and otherrigging to prevent chafe by the running gear. Ham. Nav. Encyc.
One of the stalls of the lower range where there are tworanges. See Illust. of Stall.
Depression of the jaw; hence, depression of spirits. M.Griffith (1660).
Scratched; -- said of decorative painting of a certain style,in which a white overland surface is cut or scratched through, so asto form the design from a dark ground underneath.

The permanent court of arbitration created by the"International Convention for the Pacific Settle of InternationalDisputes.", adopted by the International Peace Conference of 1899. Itis composed of persons of known competency in questions ofinternational law, nominated by the signatory powers. From thesepersons an arbitration tribunal is chosen by the parties to adifference submitted to the court. On the failure of the parties toagree directly on the arbitrators, each chooses two arbitrators, anumpire is selected by them, by a third power, or by two powersselected by the parties.
A kind of divination, performed by selecting passages ofScripture at hazard, and drawing from them indications concerningfuture events.
Existing in the state of a protoxide; -- said of an oxide. [R.]
A light field cannon, or stocked gun mounted on a swivel.
To decompose, or resolve into parts; to destroy the form of; tounmake. [R.] Good.
A genus of poisonous plants of the Nightshade family; henbane.
To make like a brute; to make senseless, stupid, or unfeeling;to brutalize.Any man not quite brutified and void of sense. Barrow.
A group somewhat lessdistinct than speciesusually are, butbased on characters more important than those which characterizeordinary varieties; often, a geographical variety or race.
A group of wading birds having the toes webbed, as the avocet.
Having a sweet, musical voice, as the nightingale. Cf. Breast,n., 6. [Obs.]
The act or process of obtaining; attainment. Milton.
A room in which goods are stored or exhibited for sale.
The periosteum which covers the cranium externally; the regionaround the cranium.
In a stark manner; stiffly; strongly.Its onward force too starky pent In figure, bone, and lineament.Emerson.

The law of likeness; similarity of structure; regularity inform and arrangement; orderly and similar distribution of parts, suchthat an animal may be divided into parts which are structurallysymmetrical.
A silicate of aluminium, occurring usually in thick rhombicprisms, nearly square, of a grayish or pale reddish tint. It wasfirst discovered in Andalusia, Spain.
Telegraphy using the radiant energy of electrical (Hertzian)waves; wireless telegraphy; -- the term adopted for use by theRadiotelegraphic Convention of 1912.
A dissuasive. [R.]This virtuous and reasonable person, however, has ill luck in all hisdissuasories. Jeffrey.
To alleviate; to lighten, as a burden or a trouble. [Obs.]Wyclif.
Early fruit or vegetables; especially, early pease. Mortimer.
The time during which the sun is up, or above the horizon; thetime between sunrise and sunset.
Any leguminous plant of the genus Vicia, some species of whichare valuable for fodder. The common species is V. sativa.
Half turned round; half inverted; (Crystallog.) having atwinned structure.
One who possesses or holds anything subject to the superior ofanother. Jer. Taylor.
The change or reduction of one figure or body into another ofthe same area or solidity, but of a different form, as of a triangleinto a square. [R.]
A union, or bond of union; an intimacy; especially, an illicitintimacy between a man and a woman.
The act of surrounding with a bank; a bank or mound raised fordefense, a roadway, etc.; an embankment. See Embankment.
A private friend; a confidential friend; a confidant. [Obs.]Fuller.
A house or shed in which wood is stored, and sheltered from theweather.
A rough-haired East Indian variety of the greyhound.
One of the side ropes to the gangway of a ship. Totten.
To cut off (a limb or projecting part (of the body). Wiseman.
The science of seals, their history, age, distinctions, etc.,esp. as verifying the age and genuiness of documents.
A secdond trial, experiment, or test; a second judicial trial,as of an accused person.
A nonoxygenous ptomaine, formed in the putrefaction ofalbuminous matters, especially of horseflesh and mackerel.
One whose occupation is to manufacture utensils, ornaments,etc., of silver; a worker in silver.
Traversed by barrulets or small bars; -- said of the field.
Growing together; cohering, as in the organic cohesion ofsimilar parts; uniting.
A burner consisting of two or more concentric Argand burners(the inner rising above the outer) and a central tube by which oxygengas or common air is supplied.
The principle of supporting a religious system and itsinstitutions by voluntary association and effort, rather than by theaid or patronage of the state.
The science or theory of church building and decoration.
Cast skins, shells, or coverings of animals; any parts ofanimals which are shed or cast off, as the skins of snakes, theshells of lobsters, etc.
Having two screw threads instead of one; -- said of a screw inwhich the pitch is equal to twice the distance between the centers ofadjacent threads.
Of or pertaining to a concession. -- n.; pl. -ries.
Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, methyl;specifically, designating methyl alcohol. See under Methyl.
The shafts or thills of a wagon or carriage. [Prov. Eng.]
To endow with a nature or qualities; to refer to nature. [Obs.]B. Jonson.
The figurework, often fantastic and delicate, which moisturesometimes forms in freezing, as upon a window pane or a flagstone.

A period of from four to six weeks, in the summer, variouslyplaced by almanac makers between the early part of July and the earlypart of September; canicular days; -- so called in reference to therising in ancient times of the Dog Star (Sirius) with the sun.Popularly, the sultry, close part of the summer.
A rare and doubtful metallic element said to have beendiscovered in the mineral samarskite.
Having a distorted neck; having the deformity called wryneck.
Pertaining to, or in the region of, the malar, or cheek bone.
Having the property of crystallizing by the agency of fire.
A disease of bovine cattle, consisting of a swelling under thethroat, which, unless checked, causes strangulation.
One who instructs; one who imparts knowledge to another; ateacher.

A large heavy knife resembling a broadsword, often two or threefeet in length, -- used by the inhabitants of Spanish America as ahatchet to cut their way through thickets, and for various otherpurposes. J. Stevens.

A kind of tobacco with medium-sized leaf, small stem, tough andgummy fiber, raised in Louisiana, and cured in its own juices, so asto be very dark colored, usually black. It is marketed in tightlywrapped rolls called carottes.
A discourse or treatise on fevers; the doctrine of fevers.Hooper.
An article of food made by boiling together bits or scraps ofmeat, usually pork, and flour or Indian meal.
A circular or ringlike formation; a ring or belt. Nicholson.
The science which treats of the means of increasing theintensity of low or weak sounds, or of the microphone.
The external branch of the appendages of Crustacea.
A medicinal substance obtained in the East Indian, having afragrant smell, and a warm, bitter, aromatic taste. It is used inmedicine as a stimulant.
The contents of a glass; as much of anything as a glass willhold.
One who, or that which, strips; specifically, a machine forstripping cards.
The larval form of a trematode worm having the shape of atadpole, with its body terminated by a tail-like appendage.
Lasting three lays; also, happening every third day. [R.]Blount.
The band of the sleeve of a shirt, or other garment, whichcovers the wrist.
A pack or bag of wool weighing two hundred and forty pounds.
That which is introduced into the body by the stomach oralimentary canal; -- opposed to egesta.
A variety of feldspar found in crystals in the county ofChester, Pennsylvania.
A compound crystal, consisting of three individuals.
In an available manner; profitably; advantageously;efficaciously.
To betake one's self to flight, as if in a panic; to flee; torun away. [Slang, U. S.]
An alkaloid found in nux vomica, and extracted as a whitecrystalline substance.
Inclining or nodding downward; pendulous; drooping; -- said ofa bud, flower, fruit, or the capsule of a moss.
The quality or state of being irrefragable; incapability ofbeing refuted.
An agreeing to the action of another, by some act which bindsthe person in law.
The offspring of a Spaniard and an Indian; a Spanish-Indianmestizo. [Sp. Amer.]
The quality or state of being fell or cruel; fierce barbarity.Spenser.
Having the guardianship or charge of protecting a person or athing; guardian; protecting; as, tutelary goddesses.This, of all advantages, is the greatest . . . the most tutelary ofmorals. Landor.
A tribe of bats including the common insectivorous bats ofAmerica and Europe, belonging to Vespertilio and allied genera. Theylack a nose membrane.
Induration; hardening; especially, that form of indurationproduced in an organ by increase of its interstitial connectivetissue.
Capable of self-nourishment; -- said of all plants in whichphotosynthetic activity takes place, as opposed to parasitism orsaprophytism.
The distinct articulation of the sounds of a patient's voice,heard on applying the ear to the chest in auscultation. It usuallyindicates some morbid change in the lungs or pleural cavity.
A rosary, consisting of a hundred and fifty beads,corresponding to the number of the psalms.
One who doubts; one whose opinion is unsettled; one whoscruples.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid which is obtained fromgallic acid as a brown or red crystalline substance, and is relatedto rufiopin and anthracene.
A white crystalline resinous substance extracted from gutta-percha by the action of alcohol or ether.
A division of serpents which have some of the posteriormaxillary teeth grooved for fangs.
An error in chronology, by which the date of an event is setlater than the time of its occurrence. [R.]

A genus of endogenous plants growing in the North Temperatezone, and consisting of about eighty species. They are perennialherbs growing from a tuber (beside which is usually found the lastyear's tuber also), and are valued for their showy flowers. SeeOrchidaceous.
The religious doctrines or tenets of the Arminians.
A bill brought by a defendant, in an equity or chancery suit,against the plaintiff, respecting the matter in question in thatsuit. Bouvier.
A camera in which a number of plates can be exposed withoutreloading.
One who importunes; an importuner. [Obs.] Sir E. Sandys.
A figure in which the speaker professes to be at a loss whatcourse to pursue, where to begin to end, what to say, etc.
An imperfect organ or part, or one which is never developed.

A morbid condition due to intestinal obstruction. It ischaracterized by complete constipation, with griping pains in theabdomen, which is greatly distended, and in the later stages byvomiting of fecal matter. Called also ileac, or iliac, passion.
Ornamental work with a needle or hook, as embroidery,crocheting, netting, etc.
A gold coin formerly current in Egypt and Turkey, of the valueof about 9s. 6d., or about $2.30; -- also, in Morocco, a ducat.
A variety of paralysis, peculiar to India and the Malabarcoast; -- considered by many to be the same as beriberi in chronicform.
Having the spirit of a male; vigorous; courageous. [R.] B.Jonson.

The belly, or that part of the body between the thorax and thepelvis. Also, the cavity of the belly, which is lined by theperitoneum, and contains the stomach, bowels, and other viscera. Inman, often restricted to the part between the diaphragm and thecommencement of the pelvis, the remainder being called the pelviccavity.
A chapel within the jurisdiction of a church; a subordinateecclesiastical foundation.
The black-bellied plover, or bullhead (Squatarola helvetica).See Plover.
Having eyes like a cat; hence, able to see in the dark.
A hydrocarbon, C13H28, of the methane series, which is aprobable ingredient both of crude petroleum and of kerosene, and isproduced artificially as a light colorless liquid.
A salt formed by the union of benzoic acid with any salifiablebase.
One that has the same name as another; especially, one calledafter, or named out of regard to, another.
A powerful alkaloid, C17H21NO4, obtained from the leaves ofcoca. It is a bitter, white, crystalline substance, and is remarkablefor producing local insensibility to pain.
A natural mixture of a terebinthinate oil and a resin.
Not in accordance with nature; unnatural. [Obs.] Milton.
The act or practice of buying goods beyond the means ofpayment; a glutting of the market.
A palace and mausoleum of the kinds of Spain, being a vast andwonderful structure about twenty-five miles northwest of Madrid.
The act of laying on varnish; also, materials for varnish.
The Thursday in Passion week, or next before Good Friday.
A genus of South American amaryllidaceous plants with large andbeautiful white blossoms.
The quality or state of being scraggy; scraggedness.
One of the essential male genital glands which secrete thesemen.
One of the upright pieces in a frame; one of the primarymembers of a frame, into which the secondary members are mortised.
Any large holothurian, especially one of those belonging to thegenus Pentacta, or Cucumaria, as the common American and Europeanspecies. (P. frondosa).
Of or pertaining to both the rectum and the bladder.
One of the free-swimming sexual zooids of Siphonophora.
Of or pertaining to histolysis, or the degeneration of tissues.
A wig having a tie or ties, or one having some of the curlstied up; also, a wig tied upon the head. Wright. V. Knox.
An engraving on wood; also, a print from it. Same as Wood cut,under Wood.
The act of terrorizing, or state of being terrorized; a mode ofgovernment by terror or intimidation. Jefferson.
A follower of Priscillian, bishop of Avila in Spain, in thefourth century, who mixed various elements of Gnosticism andManicheism with Christianity.
By or with love, esp. the love of the sexes; -- sometimeswritten as two words. [Obs.]For par amour, I loved her first ere thou. Chaucer.
Having a sucker at each extremity, as certain entozoa, by meansof which they adhere.
Having no visible sexual organs; asexual. In Bot.,cryptogamous.
A remarkable accretion of fat upon the buttocks of Africans ofcertain tribes, especially of Hottentot women.
Counteractive of bilious complaints; tending to relievebiliousness.

One who holds the doctrines of the New Jerusalem church, astaught by Emanuel Swedenborg, a Swedish philosopher and religiouswriter, who was born a. d. 1688 and died 1772. Swedenborg claimed tohave intercourse with the spiritual world, through the opening of hisspiritual senses in 1745. He taught that the Lord Jesus Christ, ascomprehending in himself all the fullness of the Godhead, is the oneonly God, and that there is a spiritual sense to the Scriptures,which he (Swedenborg) was able to reveal, because he saw thecorrespondence between natural and spiritual things.
To extend the front of (a column), bringing it into line.Farrow.
A kind of mineral coal of a black color, sufficiently hard andsolid to be cut and polished. It burns readily, with a clear, yellowflame, and on this account has been used as a substitute for candles.
Having trunnions the axes of which lie below the bore; -- saidof a cannon.
A ptomaine discovered by Vaughan in putrid cheese and otherdairy products, and producing symptoms similar to cholera infantum.Chemically, it appears to be related to, or identical with,diazobenzol.
A group of very lowly organized, wormlike parasites, includingthe Dicyemata. They are found in cephalopods. See Dicyemata.
An unlined or undyed waistcoat; a single garment; -- opposed todoublet. [Prov. Eng.]

Aniline red; an artificial coal-tar dyestuff, of a metallicgreen color superficially, resembling cantharides, but when dissolvedforming a brilliant dark red. It consists of a hydrochloride oracetate of rosaniline. See Rosaniline.
The art or science of dialing, or of constructing dials to showthe hour of the day by the shadow of a gnomon.
A larval crustacean in a stage following the nauplius, andhaving about seven pairs of appendages.
An instrument for measuring the evaporation from water, ice, orsnow. Brande & C.
One who appears to speak from his stomach; a ventriloquist.
The operation of cutting into the larynx, from the outside ofthe neck, for assisting respiration when obstructed, or for removingforeign bodies.
Having the orbital index relatively small; having the orbitsbroad transversely; -- opposed to Ant: megaseme.
One who travels on snowshoes; an expert in using snowshoes. W.G. Beers.
To wade or move about with splashing; to dabble; also, topotter; trifle; idle. [Scot. & Dial. Eng.]
Of or pertaining to separatists; characterizing separatists;schismatical.
A sheriff's deputy, appointed to make arrests, collect fines,summon juries, etc.
To smear with saliva issuing from the mouth; to defile withdrivel; to slabber.
A small annual plant (Euphrasia officinalis), formerly muchused as a remedy for diseases of the eye.

A mineral of a brown to black color occurring in prismaticcrystals, often twinned so as to form groups resembling a cross. Itis a silicate of aluminia and iron, and is generally found imbeddedin mica schist. Called also granatite, and grenatite.
slender or narrow; -- said of type the letters of which havethin lines, or are unusually narrow in proportion to their height. W.Savage.
An extract of madder by sulphuric acid. It consists essentiallyof alizarin.
A sworn statement in writing; a declaration in writing, signedand made upon oath before an authorized magistrate. Bouvier. Burrill.
The broad-billed singing birds, such as the swallows, and theirallies.
To behave ill; to conduct one's self improperly; -- often usedwith a reciprocal pronoun.
A worshiper; one given to devotion. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
A lantern, or louver covering, placed on a roof, forventilation or escape of smoke.
One who explores; also, an apparatus with which one explores,as a diving bell.
, adv. In a tralatitious manner; metephorically. Holder.
Pertaining to the membrane covering the gills of fishes.-- n. (Anat.)
Any fish belonging to the Dipnoi; -- so called because theyhave both lungs and gills.
A genus (Utricularia) of aquatic or marshy plants, whichusually bear numerous vesicles in the divisions of the leaves. Theseserve as traps for minute animals. See Ascidium.
A follower of Eunomius, bishop of Cyzicus (4th century A. D.),who held that Christ was not God but a created being, having a naturedifferent from that of the Father.-- a.
To drink immoderately; to carouse; to booze. See Booze.
Soft clayey matter in the vein, or surrounding it. [Writtenalso flookan, flukan, and fluccan.]
A stimulant, restorative, or tonic; a bracer. [Colloq.]

The fruit of certain species of passion flower (esp. Passifloraquadrangularis) found in Brazil and the West Indies. It is as largeas a child's head, and is a good dessert fruit. The fruit ofPassiflora edulis is used for flavoring ices.
A period in the American eocene, the lowest in the tertiary ageexcept the lignitic.
An American sparrow (Zonotrichia albicollis) having aconspicuous white throat. The name is imitative of its note. Calledalso White-throated sparrow.
Represented as burning, or as adorned with tongues of flame.
Pertaining to the dichroscope, or to observations with it.
A subdivision of Carnivora having plantigrade feet. It includesthe bears, raccoons, and allied species.
A short wooden club having a deeply concave face, seldom used.
A meteor or brilliant shooting star, followed by a train oflight or sparks; esp. one which explodes.
Having the vertical diameter shorter than the horizontal ortransverse; -- said of the bodies of animals, or of parts of thebodies.
A genus of marine shells; the ear-shells. See Abalone.
A sertularian hydroid, especially Sertularia abietina, whichbranches like a miniature fir tree.
The order that includes rapacious birds. They have a hookedbill, and sharp, strongly curved talons. There are three families,represented by the vultures, the falcons or hawks, and the owls.
To deal in small articles, or in petty bargains. Swift.
A kind of divination by means of the dough of the cakes offeredin the ancient sacrifices, and the meal strewed over the victims.
A sloping roof; a lean-to; a penthouse. [Obs.] Fairfax.
A concave surface, or the space bounded by it; the state ofbeing concave.
A thin silk or woolen goods, for women's dresses, woven invarious styles and colors.
A partisan or adherent of James the Second, after hisabdication, or of his descendants, an opposer of the revolution in1688 in favor of William and Mary. Macaulay.
An electric generator or dynamo for producing alternatingcurrents.
Of or pertaining to the earliest Stone age; -- applied to aprehistoric period preceding the Paleolithic age.
A beam with projecting spikes, used to make a breachimpassable.
The quality of being demonstrable; demonstrableness.
The process of forming a cicatrix, or the state of beingcicatrized.
An arc of a circle which is equal to the radius, or the anglemeasured by such an arc.
A condition in which there are two beats or waves of thearterial pulse to each beat of the heart.
A horizontal vane revolving over the surface of wort in acooler, to produce a circular current in the liquor. Knight.
A kind of rawhide consisting of hide, esp. of the buffalo,which has been soaked in crude wood-ash lye to remove the hairs, andthen dried.
A somersault made with the assistance of the hands placed uponthe ground.
A yellow pigment identical with hydrobilirubin, abundant in thehighly colored urine of fever, and also present in normal urine. SeeUrochrome.
A curve of the fourth degree, invented by Pascal. Its polarequation is r = a cos + b.
The bare end of the nose between the nostrils; -- used esp. ofruminants.
A spiritual or ghostly double or counterpart; esp., anapparitional double of a living person; a cowalker.
That branch of mathematics which treats of the relations andproperties of quantity by means of letters and other symbols. It isapplicable to those relations that are true of every kind ofmagnitude.
Poisoning caused by a virus that originates and develops in theorganism itself.
A division of passerine birds in which the vocal muscles arebut little developed, so that they lack the power of singing.
To determine the homologies or structural relations of.

Destructive to germs; -- applied to any agent which has adestructive action upon living germs, particularly bacteria, orbacterial germs, which are considered the cause of many infectiousdiseases.-- n.
The act of overseeing; inspection; superintendence; oversight.
A species of clay; meerschaum. [Also written keffekil.]
The state of being an accomplice. [R.] Sir H. Taylor.
Pertaining to, or applied to, the language of the Tuscaroras,Iroquois, Wyandots, Winnebagoes, and a part of the Sioux Indians.Schoolcraft.
The knowledge of a sciolist; superficial knowledge.

A monkey of the upper Nile and Abyssinia (Cercopithecusgriseoviridis), having the upper parts dull green, the lower partswhite, the hands, ears, and face black. It was known to the ancientEgyptians. Called also tota.
A male cat, especially when full grown or of large size.

A mineral occuring in silky fibers of a lavender blue color. Itis related to hornblende and is essentially a silicate of iron andsoda; -- called also blue asbestus. A silicified form, in which thefibers penetrating quartz are changed to oxide of iron, is the yellowbrown tiger-eye of the jewelers.
The act of setting apart to an office in the Christianministry; the conferring of holy orders.
A utensil for popping corn, usually a wire basket with a longhandle.
Having many heads or many stems from one crown or root. Gray.
A certain Oriental system of theosophy. A. P. Sinnett.
A heron (Ardea comata) found in Asia, Northern Africa, andSouthern Europe.
A genus of freeswimming oceanic tunicates, allied to Salpa, andhaving alternate generations.

A small musical imstrument on the principle of the accordion.It is a small elastic box, or bellows, having free reeds on theinside, and keys and handles on the outside of each of the twohexagonal heads.
Any agent detrimental to, or destructive of, the life ofmicrobes or bacterial organisms.
Butylene; -- so called from the four carbon atoms in themolecule.
A waiting for; ambush; watch; watching; heed. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Having a pistil or pistils; -- usually said of flowers havingpistils but no stamens.
To transfer from one ship or conveyance to another. [Writtenalso tranship.]
The peculiar language or phraseology of seamen; sailor's cant.
To differ from an established church in regard to doctrines,rites, or government.
The quality or state of being in peril; absence of safety;insecurity. Bacon.
A field worker, esp. a woman who works in the field. [Scot.]
The manager or acting partner of a company, joint-stockassociation, etc.
To produce young; -- said of eggs; to come forth from the egg;-- said of the young of birds, fishes, insects, etc.
To accuse of crime; to inform against. [Obs.] Foxe.
A measure of surface in the metric system containing tenthousand ares, or one million square meters. It is equal to about247.1 acres.
A flattened stem or branch which more or less resembles a leaf,and performs the function of a leaf as regards respiration andassimilation.
A short club with a knobbed end used as a missile weapon byKafir and other native tribes of South Africa.
The troops who march in front of an army; the advance guard;the van.
A double reading, or twofold interpretation, as of a Scripturetext. [R.]
The wife or widow of an elector in the old German empire.Burke.
In a grounded or firmly established manner. Glanvill.
That which is a month old, or which lives for a month. [R.]Wordsworth.
Strong of wing; strong on the wing. [Poetic] Davies (HolyRoode).
An instrument for measuring the force or amount of endosmoticaction.
An instrument for gauging or testing a plane surface. SeeSurface gauge, under Surface.
A hydrocarbon extracted from gutta-percha, as a yellow,resinous substance; -- called also fluanil.
The act of magnifying; enlargement; exaggeration. [R.]

Drawn out from a heated solid bar, as by a process of spiralrolling which first hollows the bar and then expands the cavity byforcing the bar over a pointed mandrel fixed in front of the rolls; -- said of a weldless tube.
The prominence at the posterior extremity of a bird's body,which supports the feathers of the tail; the rump; -- sometimescalled pope's nose.
Absence of virility or manhood; effeminacy. Prynne.
The quality or state of being unseemly; unbecomingness. Udall.
An acid obtained by sybjecting another acid to the action ofheat. Cf. Pyro-.

An explosive substance consisting of nitroglycerin absorbed bysome inert, porous solid, as infusorial earth, sawdust, etc. It issafer than nitroglycerin, being less liable to explosion frommoderate shocks, or from spontaneous decomposition.
The semisolid external layer of protoplasm in some unicellularorganisms, as the amoeba; ectoplasm; exoplasm.
The science of spiritual being or phenomena of any description.
To fix firmly, as in cube; to secure or place firmly. [Obs.]Milton.
An inflammantion of the cellular or areolar tissue, esp. ofthat lying immediately beneath the skin.
Having violent contrasts of color, or of light and shade;lacking in harmony.
A low stool to keep the goods from touching the floor. Knight.
A biography written by the subject of it; memoirs of one's lifewritten by one's self.
A sort of cotton so short and fine thet it can not be spun,used in the East Indies to line palanquins, to make mattresses, etc.
Having three ports; specif.: Designating a type of two-cycleinternal-combustion engine in which the mixture enters the crank casethrough a port uncovered by the piston near the end of its stroke.
One of the cells or tubes which inclose the feeling zooids ofBryozoa. See Illust. of Sea Moss.
The common chamber into which the intestinal, urinary, andgenerative canals discharge in birds, reptiles, amphibians, and manyfishes.
The quality of being incoincident; want of coincidence. [R.]

A black, fibrous substance resembling horsehair, obtained fromthe leafstalks of two kinds of palms, Metroxylon Sagu, and Arengasaccharifera, of the Indian islands. It is used for making cordage.Called also ejoo.
A struggling out of any difficulty. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Dexterous in taking and conveying away; thievish; pilfering;addicted to petty thefts. Fuller.
A genus of shrubs or small trees, often having handsomeevergreen leaves, and remarkable for the beauty of their flowers;rosebay.
One who, or that which, confirms, establishes, or ratifies; onewho corroborates. Shak.
A set of four feet; a measure or distance of four feet.
To handle; to wear or soil by handling; as books. Poe.
A fleshy spike of flowers, usually inclosed in a leaf called aspathe.
Intoxicated, or partially so; intoxicating. [R.] T. Brown.
A polymeric modification of cyanogen, obtained as a brown orblack amorphous residue by heating mercuric cyanide.
Of or pertaining to possession; arising from possession.
A kind of erratic melancholy, in which the patient imagineshimself a wolf, and imitates the actions of that animal.
A compound of the binary type, in which hydrogen is united withsome other element.
Any animal that sucks blood; esp., the leech (Hirudomedicinalis), and related species.
A candidate for honors or degrees who is near the time of hisexamination.
According to the order or series of causes; by tracing effectsto causes.
A hot sweetened drink of rum and water spiced with cinnamon,cloves, etc., and beaten up with eggs.
To annul or reverse by an act of the will. Longfellow.
To refuse to consider as pope; to depose from the popedom.One whom they disposed. Tennyson.
The act of immortalizing, or state of being immortalized.
An officer, particularly one in the civil service; a placeman.
To disarrange; to derange; to put in disorder. [R.] Drummond.
In a deliberative manner; circumspectly; considerately.
Belonging to, or designating, a region of the earth's surfacewhich comprises most of South America, the Antilles, and tropicalNorth America.
The quality of being acceptable, or suitable to be favorablyreceived; acceptability.
A pointed wooden tool used in glazing leaden lattice.
A genus of parasitic or saprophytic plants including the Indianpipe and pine sap. The name alludes to the dropping end of the stem.
Any one of a series of metameric, unsaturated hydrocarbonsC9H18 of the ethylene series.
An integrating wattmeter for measuring the energy in joulesexpended in an electric circuit or developed by a machine.
A place where persons under arrest are temporarily locked up; awatchhouse.
A combination of two hooks which close upon each other, bymeans of a spring, as soon as the fish bites. [U. S.]
Laid or placed underneath; also, having something laid or lyingunderneath.
Any one of the bony plates which support the gill covers offishes; an opercular bone.
A group of passerine birds, including the creepers andnuthatches.
A garland or fillet; a chaplet or wreath. Drayton. Tennyson.
An instrument for ascertaining the velocity of the blood in avessel.
A small gold coin formerly current in England; a half angel.Eng. Cyc.
A model of a town or country, in relief, executed in wood,cork, pasteboard, or the like. Brande & C.
A passage, usually vertical, for admitting fresh air into amine or a tunnel.
The cell of a pericarp in which the seed is lodged.
Serving to designate; designative; indicating. [R.]
A veil; a thin covering; also, material for making veils.

Of, pertaining to, or designating, a complex ketonic acid,C5H6O3, obtained as a white crystalline substance; -- so calledbecause once supposed to contain a peculiar radical of four carbonatoms. Called also acetyl-acrylic acid.

In an internal-combustion engine with two or more cylinders, aninduction coil and vibrator placed in the circuit between the batteryor magneto and the coils for the different cylinders, which are usedwithout vibrators of their own.
Manganese dioxide, occurring in tetragonal crystals nearly ashard as quartz.

Spurge, or bastard spurge, a genus of plants of many species,mostly shrubby, herbaceous succulents, affording an acrid, milkyjuice. Some of them are armed with thorns. Most of them yieldpowerful emetic and cathartic products.
An absorption of one estate, or one contract, in another, or ofa minor offense in a greater.
An order of fishes having an incomplete or reduced branchialapparatus. It includes the sticklebacks, the flutemouths, andFistularia.
Previous intimation; a suggestion beforehand. T. Scott.
Manganese carbonate, a rose-red mineral sometimes occuringcrystallized, but generally massive with rhombohedral cleavage likecalcite; -- called also dialogite.
Toward a distal part; on the distal side of; distally.
The act of lubricating; the act of making slippery.

A beautiful crystalline compound, SiC, consisting of carbon andsilicon in combination; carbon silicide. It is made by heating carbonand sand together in an electric furnace. The commercial article isdark-colored and iridescent. It is harder than emery, and is used asan abrasive.
A white crystalline nitrogenous substance (C2H4N4); -- calledalso dicyandiamide.
Tissue-producing; connected with the formation and developmentof the organic tissues.
A rounded organ between the eyes of the frog; the interoculargland.
The state of being sole, or alone; singleness. [R.]Chesterfield.
The influence of a word in regard to construction, requiringthat another word should be in a particular case.
A European fish (Centriscus scolopax), distinguished by a longtubular snout, like the pipe of a bellows; -- called also trumpetfish, and snipe fish.
Of, pertaining to, or containing, palladium; -- usedspecifically to designate those compounds in which palladium has alower valence as compared with palladic compounds.
The circumference of a circle, ellipse, or other figure.
A retailer of vegetables or fruits in their fresh or greenstate.

A white or yellowish crystalline substance, C6H4.(SO2.CO).NH,produced artificially by the oxidation of a sulphamic derivative oftoluene. It is the sweetest substance known, having over two hundredtimes the sweetening power of sugar, and is known in commerce underthe name of saccharine. It has acid properties and forms salts (whichare inaccurately called saccharinates). I. Remsen.
Want or neglect of observance; inobservance. Whitlock.
A bag made of thin glazed muslin, used as a wrapper for dressgoods. McElrath.
The uniform worn by the officers and soldiers of a regiment;military dress; -- formerly used in the singular in the same sense.Colman.
Affected with palsy; palsied; paralytic. [R.] Johnson.
