In the manner of a convalescent; with increasing strength orvigor.
A kind of large. thin muffin or cake, light and spongy, andcooked on a griddle or spider.
Pertaining to that which is out of doors. "Extr occupations."Cowper.
A machine tool for drilling slots, in which the work or toolhas a lateral motion back and forth; also, a drilling machine inwhich the spindle holder can be adjusted laterally.
Any Asiatic pheasant of the genus Lophophorus, as the Impeyanpheasant.
A discourse or treatise on the heavens and the heavenly bodies;the study of the heavens; uranography.
A transparent pyx, in which the consecrated host is exposed toview.
A chair with adjustable back, for the sick, to support themwhile sitting up in bed.
In passing; in the course of any procedure; -- said specif.(Chess),
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of vanadium, analogousto pyrophosphoric acid.
Pertaining to or engaged in the hunting of foxes; fond ofhunting foxes.
A small inclosed pond used for gathering and greening oysters.
A house or hospital for persons who are infected with anypestilential disease.

An invisible power in a body by which it draws anything toitself; the power in nature acting mutually between bodies orultimate particles, tending to draw them together, or to producetheir cohesion or combination, and conversely resisting separation.
Capture of fishes, as by angling. [R.] W. H. Russell.
Any species of small marine fishes of the genera Onos andRhinonemus (formerly Motella), allied to the cod. They have three orfour barbels.
To contradict, meet, or oppose by argument, plea, orcountervailing proof. Abbott.
The part of a dwelling appropriated to women. [India]
One of a series of substances C10H16, resembling camphor,regarded as modified terpenes.
A five-pointed star, resembling five alphas joined at theirbases; -- used as a symbol.
A semicircular projection made at the shoulder of a bastion forthe purpose of covering the retired flank, -- found in oldfortresses.

The morsel of execration; a species of ordeal consisting in theeating of a piece of bread consecrated by imprecation. If thesuspected person ate it freely, he was pronounced innocent; but if itstuck in his throat, it was considered as a proof of his guilt.Burril.
One who is versed in the science of fossils; a paleontologist.Joseph Black.
In a favored or a favorable manner; favorably. [Obs.] Deut.xvii. 1. Arscham.
A commission giving an officer higher rank than that for whichhe receives pay; an honorary promotion of an officer.
A kettle in which water is boiled for making tea, coffee, etc.
Forming again; having the quality of renewing form;reformatory. Good.
One who envies; one who desires inordinately what anotherpossesses.
One who held the real presence of Christ's body in theeucharist, but not by transubstantiation.
The long silky hair or wool of the Angora goat of Asia Minor;also, a fabric made from this material, or an imitation of suchfabric.
An old Spanish silver coin of the value of about twenty cents.
That part of a bridle or halter which encompasses the head.Shak.
A military government; government by military chiefs and anarmy.
One who voyages; one who sails or passes by sea or water.
One who bridles; one who restrains and governs, as with abridle. Milton.
A small fish of the Mediterranean; a gilthead. See Gilthead(a).
Importance; significance; consequence; that which is important.[Obs.] Shak. "Careful to conceal importancies." Fuller.
To break off with an abrupt, sharp noise; to bite; to nibble.[Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
Inversion and prolapse of the mucous coat of the rectum, fromrelaxation of the sphincter, with more or less swelling; prolapsusani. Dunglison.
The quality or state of being spiritual or spiritual-minded;spirituality.
Of or pertaining to Jove, or Jupiter (either the deity or theplanet).
A variable quantity, considered as increasing or diminishing; -- called, in the modern calculus, the function or integral.
An unsect which feeds on mucus, or the sap of plants, ascertain Diptera, of the tribe Mucivora.
Speaking smoothly; plausible; flattering; smooth-tongued.
Any humming bird of the genus Heliomaster. The feathers of thethroat have a brilliant metallic luster.
An instrument combining a cinematograph and a phonograph sothat the moving figures on the screen are accompanied by theappropriate sounds.
Secreting water; -- applied to certain glands. Dunglison.
The state of being demoniac, or the practices of demoniacs.
The crime of destroying one's offspring, either in the womb orafter birth. Bouvier.
A perpendicular arrangement of flat, single plaits, each plaitbeing folded so as to cover half the breadth of the preceding one.
Resembling a cord in toughness and flexibility, as the roots ofsome endogenous trees.
To stew or broil in a covered kettle or pan.A braising kettle has a deep cover which holds coals; consequentlythe cooking is done from above, as well as below. Mrs. Henderson.
Inflammation of a capsule, as that of the crystalline lens.

An order of herbivorous dinosaurs with birdlike characteristicsin the skeleton, esp. in the pelvis and hind legs, which in somegenera had only three functional toes, and supported the body inwalking as in Iguanodon. See Illust. in Appendix.
A meal made from hulled cotton seeds after the oil has beenexpressed.

A morbid condition of any part of the body, consisting incongestion of the blood vessels, with obstruction of the bloodcurrent, and growth of morbid tissue. It is manifested outwardly byredness and swelling, attended with heat and pain.
Of pertaining to crinoids; consisting of, or containing,crinoids.

A powerful and very poisonous vegetable alkaloid found in thehemlock (Conium maculatum) and extracted as a colorless oil, C8H17N,of strong repulsive odor and acrid taste. It is regarded as aderivative of piperidine and likewise of one of the collidines. Itoccasions a gradual paralysis of the motor nerves. Called alsoconiine, coneine, conia, etc. See Conium, 2.
A distemper incident to cattle, in which their livers areaffected. Crabb.
A genus of plants, some species of which produce beautiful andfragrant flowers; Cape jasmine; -- so called in honor of Dr.Alexander Garden.
Anything used for healing diseases or wounds; a medicine; ahealing application.
Plaintive; -- a term applied to a mournful or pathetic movementor style. Moore.

(Bot.) A cherry tree (Prunus Mahaleb) of Southern Europe. Thewood is prized by cabinetmakers, the twigs are used for pipe stems,the flowers and leaves yield a perfume, and from the fruit a violetdye and a fermented liquor (like kirschwasser) are prepared.
A term applied to the lowest deposits of the Cretaceous orchalk formation of Europe, being the lower greensand.
Swimming on the surface; buoyant; light. Sir W. Raleigh.
A censer of metal, for burning incense, having various forms,held in the hand or suspended by chains; -- used especially at mass,vespers, and other solemn services. Fairholt.

Native sulphate of barium, a mineral occurring in transparent,colorless, white to yellow crystals (generally tabular), also ingranular form, and in compact massive forms resembling marble. It hasa high specific gravity, and hence is often called heavy spar. It isa common mineral in metallic veins.
An orange-yellow variety of the mineral thorite, found inNorway.
A hoisting apparatus; an elevator; a crane; a lift. [Prov.Eng.]
Motion excited by reflex nerves. See Excito-motory.
One of the canine teeth; -- so called from having but one pointor cusp on the crown. See Tooth.
The red goosefoot (Chenopodium rubrum), -- said to be fatal toswine.
Native barium sulphate or barite, -- so called because of itshigh specific gravity as compared with other non-metallic minerals.
A field where grass for hay has been cut; a meadow. Cowper.
Any merely ornamental adjunct of a woman's dress, as a bunch ofribbon, lace, etc.
Fit to be deputed; suitable to act as a deputy. Carlyle.
To surpass in speed of riding; to ride beyond or faster than.Shak.

The doctrine of those who deny a supernatural agency in themiracles and revelations recorded in the Bible, and in spiritualinfluences; also, any system of philosophy which refers the phenomenaof nature to a blind force or forces acting necessarily or accordingto fixed laws, excluding origination or direction by one intelligentwill.
A cowhide, or coarse riding whip, made of untanned (or raw)hide twisted.
The system of Malthusian doctrines relating to population.
A product of gastric digestion, a mixture of hemipeptone andantipeptone.
Any of the players who meet in the final round of a tournamentin which the losers in any round do not play again.
A third somewhat; something mediating, or regarded as being,between two diverse or incompatible substances, natures, orpositions.
The principles of dynamics in their application to the blood;that part of science which treats of the motion of the blood.
Capable of being done or achieved; practicable; feasible. SirT. Browne.
Resembling, or approximating to, a hemisphere in form.
The act or process of curling the hair. [Obs.] burton.
A section or part of a cylinder, cone, or other solid ofrevolution, cut off by a plane oblique to the base; -- so called fromits resemblance to the hoof of a horse.
The quality of being admirable; wonderful excellence.
A second growth or crop, or (metaphorically) development. J. S.Mill.
Wavy or undulating like camlet; veined. Sir T. Herbert.
The science which treats of climates and investigates theirphenomena and causes. Brande & C.
A kind of pasture grass (Cynodon Dactylon). See Bermuda grass:also Illustration in Appendix.
An instrument for measuring the intensity of heat radiatingfrom a fire, or the cooling influence of bodies. It is a differentialthermometer, having one bulb coated with gold or silver leaf. [R.]
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a hypothetical sulphacid(called also thioarsenic acid) analogous to arsenic acid, and knownonly in its salts.
A mineral of pale steel-gray color and metallic luster,occurring in isometric crystals, and also massive. It is a sulphideof cobalt containing some nickel or copper.
The state or quality of being centric; centricalness.
A child or baby; esp., a representation in art of the infantChrist wrapped in swaddling clothes.
Producing yolk, or vitelline substance; -- applied to certaincells (also called nutritive, or yolk, cells) formed in the ovariesof many insects, and supposed to supply nutriment to the developingova.
A pole or a frame raised as a sea beacon or a landmark.
A wooden blade with a cross handle, used for mi Tomlinson.
The state, quality, or character of being stealthy; stealth.
One of the sets of parallel doubled threads which, withmounting, compose the harness employed to guide the warp threads tothe lathe or batten in a loom.
A genus of fossil trees of the Devonian and Carboniferous ages,having the exterior marked with scars, mostly in quincunx order,produced by the separation of the leafstalks.
To render wrongly; to translate or recite wrongly. Boyle.
The state of being a king; the attributes of a king; kingship.Gower.
A box for holding instruments or materials for work.
Exhibiting the prismatic colors; irised; iridescent. W.Phillips.
A straight piece of timber, or an iron bar or beam, erected onthe extremity of the keel to support the rudder, and receive the endsof the planks or plates of the vessel.
double rhymes, or rhymes (called in French feminine rhymesbecause they end in e weak, or feminine) in which two syllables, anaccented and an unaccented one, correspond at the end of each line.
Having two acid hydrogen atoms capable of replacement by basicatoms or radicals, in forming salts; bibasic; -- said of acids, asoxalic or sulphuric acids. Cf. Diacid, Bibasic.

A name applied to various species of edible fishes of the genusSerranus, and related genera, inhabiting the Meditarranean, the coastof California, etc. In California, some of them are also called rockbass and kelp salmon.
To strip or lay bare, as land of wood, houses, etc.; to commitwaste.
The process of becoming, or the state of being, acclimated, orhabituated to a new climate; acclimatization.
Not tractile; incapable of being drawn out or extended. Bacon.
One of tree men united in public office or authority.
A stick to ram down the charge of a musket, etc.; a rammer orramrod. [R.]
An official report of proceedings in the British Parliament; --so called from the name of the publishers.
To transfer to the wrong place in printing; to print out ofplace. [R.] Coleridge.
One who withstands, or opposes; an opponent; a resisting power.
Stiff in opinion; firmly or unduly adhering to one's ownopinion or to preconceived notions; obstinate in opinion. Sir W.Scott.
A fabulous cow of enormous size, whose food was patient wives,and which was therefore in very lean condition.
A kind of color prepared from calcined lapis lazuli;ultramarine; also, a blue prepared from carbonate of copper. [Writtenalso sanders-blue.]
That quality of a law which concerns the condition, state, andcapacity of persons. Burrill.
The act of suborning; the crime of procuring a person to takesuch a false oath as constitutes perjury. Blackstone.
Pertaining to dower, or a woman's marriage portion;constituting dower, or comprised in it. Garth.
A primitive, from which spring other words; a radical; a root;an etymon.
A large mass or avalanche of snow which slips down the side ofa mountain, etc.
The act of disgorging; a vomiting; that which is disgorged. Bp.Hall.
Following, or more recent than, the Tertiary; Quaternary.
The act of embedding, or the state of being embedded.
A young, flexible shoot of a plant; esp., the long trailingbranch of a vine, or a slender branch in certain mosses.
In pale, with the head in chief; -- said of the figure of afish, as if rising for air.
A chart or catalogue of fixed stars, especially of starsvisible to the naked eye.
Indigence.New indigencies founded upon new desires. South.
The quality of being inexcitable; insusceptibility toexcitement.
An order of Echini, including the irregular sea urchins, as thespatangoids. See Spatangoid.
A black submetallic mineral consisting of oxide of chromium andiron; -- called also chromic iron.
Designating certain compounds of titanium in which that elementhas a lower valence as contrasted with titanic compounds.
Pertaining to hypogeic acid; -- applied to an acid obtainedfrom hypogeic acid.

A unit of measurement of the freight transportation performedby a railroad during a given period, usually a year, the total ofwhich consists of the sum of the products obtained by multiplying theaggregate weight of each shipment in tons during the given period bythe number of miles for which it is carried.

A sectarian; a member or adherent of a sect; a follower ordisciple of some particular teacher in philosophy or religion; onewho separates from an established church; a dissenter.I never knew that time in England when men of truest religion werenot counted sectaries. Milton.
Behind the stomach; -- said of two lobes of the carapace ofcertain crustaceans.
The act of preconceiving; conception or opinion previouslyformed.
A short cylinder connecting a trunnion with the body of acannon. See Illust. of Cannon.
Among tailors, cloth suitable for making entire suits ofclothes.
An apparatus designed for collecting spores, germs, bacteria,etc., suspended in the air.
To surpass in jesting; to drive out, or away, by jesting. [R.]Shak.
A small black spot or mark remaining in the cavity of thecorner tooth of a horse after the large spot or mark has becomeobliterated.
The doctrine or system of those who deduce their religiousopinions from reason or the understanding, as distinct from, oropposed to, revelation.
A piece of pork, consisting or ribs with little flesh on them.
A bone which usually connects the clavicle with the post-temporal in the pectorial arch of fishes.
An instrument for reproducing sounds, especially articulatespeech, at a distance.
Any fish of the genus Distichodus. Several large speciesinhabit the Nile.
The fireplace at the side of an annealing oven. Knight.
A condiment formed of small fishes or shrimps, pounded up withsalt and spices, and then dried. It is much esteemed in China.
A kind of warm cap winter wear, made from a knit bag withclosed tapered ends by pushing one end within the other, thus makinga conical cap of double thickness.
Like a bed; -- applied to several processes on the inner sideof the sphenoid bone.
The first bud, or gemmule, of a young plant; the bud, orgrowing point, of the embryo, above the cotyledons. See Illust. ofRadicle. Gray.
A trifle; trifling talk; nonsense. [Colloq.] Spectator.
One side of an echinoderm, including a pair of ambulacra, indistinction from the opposite side (trivium), which includes threeambulacra.
` phrase applied to an appeal or argument addressed to theprinciples, interests, or passions of a man.
Turning to the left (of the spectator) in the ascending line; -- the opposite of dextrorse. See Dextrorse.
Stuffing, or mixture of viands, like that used on dressing afowl; forcemeat.
Written in, or pertaining to, hierograms; expressive of sacredwriting. Bp. Warburton.
Belonging to, or affecting, a single organ, or set of organs.

The ornament of woodwork upon the gable of a house, usedextensively in the 15th century. It was generally suspended from theedge of the projecting roof (see Verge, n., 4), and in positionparallel to the gable wall. Called also bargeboard.
One who falsifies, or gives to a thing a deceptive appearance;a liar.
Of or pertaining to the nasal septum and the maxilla; situatedin the region of these parts.-- n.
An official of the Eastern Church, resembling a sacrist in theWestern Church.
Having a single purpose; hence, artless; guileless; single-hearted.

To run or flow in a broken, irregular, noisy current, as waterfrom a bottle, or a small stream among pebbles or stones.Pure gurgling rills the lonely desert trace, And waste their music onthe savage race. Young.
A kind of intercolumniation in an entablature, in which onlyone triglyph and two metopes are introduced.
A kind of rue (Ruta sylvestris) growing in India. At Lahore theseeds are used medicinally and for fumigation.
Fitted for trail or test; experimental; tentative; treating ofattempts.
Capable of being baptized; fit to be baptized. Baxter.
That branch of the science of geodesy which has to do with themeasurement of heights, either absolutely with reference to the sealevel, or relatively.
A day (December 28) observed by mass or festival incommemoration of the children slain by Herod at Bethlehem; -- calledalso Holy Innocent's Day.
The management of land; rural economy; agriculture.
Belonging to exchanges in commerce; of exchange. [R.]
A game much like hockey, played in an open field; also, the,bent stick for playing the game. [Local, Eng.] Halliwell.
An animal which imitates something else, in form or habits.
Hydrogen; -- called also in view of its supposed metallicnature. Graham.
A steel-gray mineral of metallic luster. It is a sulphide ofsilver and copper.
The acceptance of articles, or other tests tending to promoteuniformity; esp. (Ch. of Eng.), formal assent to the Thirty-nineArticles and the Book of Common Prayer, required before ordination.
One who maintains that all things happen by inevitablenecessity.
One believed to be supernaturally impressed with the marks ofChrist's wounds. See Stigma, 8.
The want of the quality of coloring or tingeing other bodies.Kirwan.
Of or pertaining to bole or clay; partaking of the nature andqualities of bole; clayey.
A shot made with the object balls in an anchor space.
The quality or state of being pertinacious; obstinacy;perseverance; persistency. Macaulay.
Surroundings; specif., collectively, one's attendants orassociates.
One who favors or supports the theory of a pantisocracy.Macaulay.
One who transcribes, or writes from a copy; a copier; acopyist.
The quality of being clever; skill; dexterity; adroitness.
A divergence of lines of color sculpture, or of fibers atdifferent angles.
The state of being definite; determinateness; precision;certainty.
A short fly that falls too far out to be handled by aninfielder and too close in to be caught by an outfielder. [Cant]

The recess, seat, or inclosed place, where a priest sits tohear confessions; often a small structure furnished with a seat forthe priest and with a window or aperture so that the penitent who isoutside may whisper into the priest's ear without being seen by himor heard by others.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, thiophene; specifically,designating a certain acid analogous to benzoic acid.
To ride hard; to jounce. [Obs.]Spurr'd, galled and tired by jauncing Bolingbroke. Shak.
To write one's name, alone or with other words, upon the backof (a paper), for the purpose of transferring it, or to secure thepayment of a
The act or process of turning to flesh, or to a substanceresembling flesh.
Deposal from a throne; deposition from regal power.
That which is cast or brought forth prematurely; an abortion.Sir T. Browne.
The state of being a mother; the character or relation of amother.
Conveyed in a vehicle; furnished with a vehicle. M. Green.
The marking of the clothes with stripes or horizontal bands.[Obs.] Chaucer.
Of, pertaining to, or containing, lead; -- used specifically todesignate those compounds in which it has a lower valence ascontrasted with plumbic compounds.
Inclined to drink to excess; intoxicated; tipsy. [R.] M.Collins.
A light cloth covering for the head and neck, used by soldiersas a protection from sunstroke.
Pertaining to the art of making sweetmeats. [Obs.] Beaumont.
Trousers or overalls of thick cloth or leather, buttoned on theoutside of each leg, and generally worn to protect other trouserswhen riding on horseback. [Local, U.S.] Bartlett.
The party to a contract who receives, or agrees to receive, theproperty sold. Blackstone.
Represented with jagged and uneven edges, as is torn off; --used esp. of the head or limb of a beast. Cf. Couped.
The faculty of multiplying in two ways; -- by ova fecundated byspermatic fluid, and asexually, as by buds. See Parthenogenesis.
One to whom a thing is dedicated; -- correlative to dedicator.
A division of the Caucasian races, comprising the lighter-colored members.
To apply astrology to; to study or practice astrology.
Of or pertaining to Boeotia; hence, stupid; dull; obtuse.-- n.
A post-office clerk whose duty is to decipher obscureaddresses.
The part of a theater behind the scenes; the back part of thestage of a theater.
A high explosive consisting principally of picric acid, used asa shell explosive in the British service; -- so named from theproving grounds at Lydd, England.
A kind of twilled linen cloth for lining. Simmonds.
Opposition; impediment; obstruction. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A lashing binding a thing tightly or binding things together.
Farthest from the middle or interior; farthest outward;outermost.
The last, and usually the longest, division of the smallintestine; the part between the jejunum and large intestine. [Writtenalso ileon, and ilium.]
To make clean by wiping; to wipe away; to cleanse; hence, topurge. [R.] Quincy.
A substance of variable composition, but resembling a soft,dark-colored metal, used in the bearings of machines for obviatingfriction, and as a substitute for lubricants.
One who reads or performs music readily at first sight. [R.]Busby.
A group of spiders having only two lunglike organs. [Writtenalso Dipneumones.]

Act or process of attempting to give an arbitrary market valueor price to a commodity by governmental interference, as bymaintaining a purchasing fund, making loans to producers to enablethem to hold their products, etc.; -- used chiefly of such action byBrazil.
An alkaloid found in the Calabar bean, and the seed ofPhysostigma venenosum; physostigmine. It is used in ophthalmicsurgery for its effect in contracting the pupil.
Suffocating with heat; oppressively hot; sultry. [R.] Evelyn.
One who believes in the contagious character of certaindiseases, as of yellow fever.
A horizontal bar on a stake, used for supporting the yarnswhich are kept apart by pins in the bar.

A remedial treatment, by drawing the pointed extremities of tworods, each of a different metal, over the affected part;tractoration, -- first employed by Dr. Elisha Perkins of Norwich,Conn. See Metallotherapy.
A stone laid before a door as a stair to rise on in enteringthe house.
Of the color of ashes; a whitish gray or brownish gray.
One of the patches of villi found in some forms of placenta.
A rope passing through a block, used in managing or dragging atrawlnet.
By the act of nature; originally; from birth. Sir M. Hale.
It is not clear; -- a verdict given by a jury when a matter isto be deferred to another day of trial.
A hound that pursues by the sight rather than by the scent. SirW. Scott.

A volatile liquid consisting of three parts of carbon, six ofhydrogen, and one of oxygen; pyroacetic spirit, -- obtained by thedistillation of certain acetates, or by the destructive distillationof citric acid, starch, sugar, or gum, with quicklime.
Book worship, esp. of the Bible; -- applied by Roman Catholicdivine Coleridge. F. W. Newman.
The sail set next above the royal. See Illust. under Sail.
A flying squirrel (Sciuropterus volans) native of NorthernEurope and Siberia; -- called also minene.
An oil obtained by distillation of peat, and containing variousmembers of the pyridine series.
A bird belonging to Cuculus, Coccyzus, and several alliedgenera, of many species.
A whitlow running around the finger nail, but not affecting thebone. [Colloq.]
Leather tanned from a hog's skin. Also used adjectively.
An extinct group of marine reptiles, embracing both theIchthyosauria and the Plesiosauria, now regarded as distinct orders.
A small British marine fish (Callionymuslyra); -- called alsoyellow sculpin, fox, and gowdie.
A large, slender, harmless snake of the southern United States(Masticophis flagelliformis).
A colloquial expression, not employed in formal discourse orwriting.
A house in which nuns reside; a cloister or convent in whichwomen reside for life, under religious vows. See Cloister, andConvent.
Belonging to, or resembling, a suborder of composite plants ofwhich the chicory (Cichorium) is the type.
The pulpy, edible seed vessels of certain plants, especiallythose grown on branches above ground, as apples, oranges, grapes,melons, berries, etc. See 3.

A subdivision in the upper part of the Devonian system inAmerica, so named from the Chemung River, along which the rocks arewell developed. It includes the Portage and Chemung groups or epochs.See the Diagram under Geology.

Dimness or abolition of sight, with a diminution oftransparency, a bluish or greenish tinge of the refracting media ofthe eye, and a hard inelastic condition of the eyeball, with markedincrease of tension within the eyeball.
Having horns with three angles, like those of some species ofgoats.
Having a flush deck, or with only a moderate depressionamidships; -- said of a vessel.

One of a large sect of Russian dissenters founded, about 1860,in the village of Osnova, near Odessa, by a peasant, Onishchenko, whohad apparently been influenced by a German sect settled near there.They zealously practice Bible reading and reject priestly dominionand all external rites of worship. -- Stun"dism (#), n.
The quality of being incessant; unintermitted continuance;unceasingness. Dr. T. Dwight.
Serving or tending to divert; also, distinguishing. [Obs.]
Repetition of one's self or of one's acts; the saying or doingwhat one has already said or done.

One of the segments of the transverse axis, or the so calledhomonymous parts; as, for example, one of the several segments of theextremities in vertebrates, or one of the similar segments in plants,such as the segments of a segmented leaf. Syd. Soc. Lex.
A measure of land mentioned in Domesday Book. It is supposed tohave consisted of a few acres only. [Obs.]
Having a clear physical or mental vision; having a clearunderstanding.
A tremolo effect, such as that produced on the piano byvibratory repetition of a note with sustained use of the pedal.
Having the form of, or resembling, a style, pin, or pen;styloid.
Not furnished with shields or beds for the spores, as thethallus of certain lichens.

A supposed new element, a radioactive substance discovered byM. and MMe. Curie in pitchblende. It is closely related chemically tobismuth. It emits only alpha rays and is perhaps identical withradium F.
Seven times as much; multiplied by seven; sevenfold.
Faith personified as a goddess; the goddess of faith.
The current through one branch of the star arrangement of athree-phase circuit.
One who pins or impounds cattle. See Pin, v. t. [Obs.]
a small fascine or fagot, steeped in wax, pitch, and glue, usedin various ways, as for igniting buildings or works, or to lightditches and ramparts. Farrow.
A species of gause, or very silk.The smoke of sulphur . . . is commonly used by women to whitentiffanies. Sir T. Browne.
Of the nature of a holograph; pertaining to holographs.
A chart or graphic representation of the average distributionof rain over the surface of the earth.
One who makes dissections for anatomical illustration; usually,the assistant of a professional anatomist.
A rich, white sauce, prepared with butter and cream.
One who arrays. In some early English statutes, applied to anofficer who had care of the soldiers' armor, and who saw them dulyaccoutered.
A device consisting of a short rope with flat hooks at eachend, for hoisting casks or barrels by the ends of the staves.
The act of puffing; bestowment of extravagant commendation.
That which is written with one's own hand; an originalmanuscript; a person's own signature or handwriting.
A book in which a person keeps an account of his notes, bills,bills of exchange, etc., thus showing all that he issues andreceives.
A butyrate of glycerin; a fat contained in small quantity inmilk, which helps to give to butter its peculiar flavor.
A genus of small dipterous files, including several veryinjurious species, as the Hessian fly. See Hessian fly.
Incongruity; disagreement; unsuitableness. Sir M. Hale.
A registar or clerk; -- used originally in courts of civil lawjurisdiction, but in Europe used for a clerk or registar generally.
Of, or relating to, expression; phraseological; also, vividlyrepresenting or suggesting an idea sentiment. Fized. Hall. Ruskin.

Curved toward the same side in all directions; -- said ofsurfaces which in all directions around any point bend away from atangent plane toward the same side, as the surface of a sphere; --opposed to anticlastic. Sir W. Thomson.
A payment of money; a toll or duty; also, the rendering of aservice. Burrill.
Pining for home; in a nostalgic condition.-- Home"sick`ness, n.
A nymph of paradise; -- so called by the Mohammedans.
A native garment or rug of skin sewed together in the form of asquare. [South Africa]
Of or pertaining to rain; descriptive of the distribution ofrain, or of rainy regions.
Of or pertaining to the Acrita.-- n. An individual of the Acrita.
One who undertakes anything; specifically, a godfather; asponsor; a guardian. Puller. Shipley.
The French middle class, particularly such as are concerned in,or dependent on, trade.
The theory that living organisms can be produced only by thedevelopment of living germs. Cf. Biogenesis, Abiogenesis.
Formed of wood pulp by molds; relating to casts made of woodpulp in molds.
Clumsy; awkward. [Obs.]Rough-hewn, cloutery verses. E. Phillips.
Not comprehended within a rule or rules. Jer. Taylor.
A kind of pessary of medicated wool or cotton, formerly used.
One of the dowels joining the ends of the fellies which formthe circle of the wheel of a gun carriage. Wilhelm.
One who, or that which, burrows; an animal that makes a holeunder ground and lives in it.

An ancient mode of punishing criminals among the Persians, byconfining the victim in a trough, with his head and limbs smearedwith honey or the like, and exposed to the sun and to insects untilhe died.
An old stringed instrument played upon with a wheel; a hurdy-gurdy.
Appearing as if seen from the center of the planet Saturn;relating or referred to Saturn as a center.
A leaf converted into a fruit or a constituent portion of afruit; a carpel.
To spin out to too great length; to protract unduly. W.Cartwright.
Any one of a series of complex basic sulphur compoundsanalogous to the sulphines.
The state of needing, or of suffering a natural want. [R.] J.Grote.
The state or quality of not being deficient. [Obs.] Strype.
A paved yard or floor where ores are cleaned and sorted, orwhere ore, salt, mercury, etc., are trampled by horses, to effectintermixture and amalgamation.
To receive hospitality; to be a guest. [Obs.] Grew.
A direction to violinists to pluck the string with the finger,instead of using the bow. (Abrev. pizz.)

A release, by a sovereign, or officer having jurisdiction, fromthe penalties of an offense, being distinguished from amenesty, whichis a general obliteration and canceling of a particular line of pastoffenses.
The second day of February, on which is celebrated the feast ofthe Purification of the Virgin Mary; -- so called because the candlesfor the altar or other sacred uses are blessed on that day.
A beam, into which are framed the ends of headers in floorframing, as when a hole is to be left for stairs, or to avoidbringing joists near chimneys, and the like. See Illust. of Header.
One of the lateral appendages of an annelid; -- called alsofoot tubercle.
An instrument for measuring the bleaching power of chloride oflime and potash; a chlorometer. Ure.
That part of a speech, usually the exordium, in which theorator sets forth the subject matter to be discussed.
The quality or state of being inimitable; inimitableness.Norris.
The act of burning, or the state of being burned. [R.] Johnson.
A cooling periodical wind in the Isle of Cyprus, blowing fromthe northwest from eight o'clock, A. M., to the middle of the day orlater.
A short candle end used for igniting a fuse. Raymond.
The result of eliminating n variables between n homogeneousequations of any degree; -- called also resultant.
A puppet; a doll; originally, an idol, because in the MiddleAges it was generally believed that the Mohammedans worshiped imagesrepresenting Mohammed. [Obs.] Wyclif. Beau. & Fl.
Terminated with crescent; -- said of a cross the ends of whichare so terminated.
To form like pearls; to decorate with, or as with, pearls; toimpearl.
Having, consisting of, or pertaining to, half tones; specif.(Photo-engraving),
One skilled in ornithology; a student of ornithology; one whodescribes birds.
An instrument for accurately determining the ductility ofmetals.
The membrane of fibrous connective tissue which closely investscartilage, except where covering articular surfaces.
An oxide of a nonmetallic body or an organic radical, capableof forming an acid by uniting with the elements of water; -- socalled because it may be formed from an acid by the abstraction ofwater.
A speaking or conversing together; conference; mutualdiscourse. Bailey.
A table or other means for calculating the periodical functionsof women. Dunglison.

An East Indian carnivore (Mydaus meliceps) allied to thebadger, and noted for the very offensive odor that it emits, somewhatresembling that of a skunk. It is a native of the high mountains ofJava and Sumatra, and has long, silky fur. Called also stinkingbadger, and stinkard.
The shell of a nut; the stone of a drupe fruit. See Endocarp.
Extreme meanness, affectation, conceit, or impudence. A.Chalmers.
A post (generally a pillar of iron) supporting a lamp orlantern for lighting a street, park, etc.
To origination of living matter from non-living. SeeAbiogenesis. Bastian.
A stone designating a limit or boundary; a landmark. Bacon.
A rawhide whip plaited with two thongs of buffalo hide T.Roosevelt.
The act or practice of drining the surface of land.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, a former glacial formation.
To commit fornication; to have unlawful sexual intercourse.
A product of gastric and pancreatic digestion, differing fromhemipeptone in not being decomposed by the continued action ofpancreatic juice.
Inflammation of the dura mater or outer membrane of the brain.
Not capable of being done or accomplished; impracticable.Glanvill.
A figure in which the orator treats of things according totheir events consequences.
An extensive division of fishes including the ordinary fishes(Teleostei) and the ganoids.
A kind of speedwell (Veronica hederifolia) which spreadschiefly in winter. Dr. Prior.
The iron hook fixed to a casement to pull it shut, or to holdit party open at a fixed point.
A large stone set upright in olden times as a memorial ormonument. Many, of unknown date, are found in Brittany and throughoutNorthern Europe.
A figure in which successive clauses end with the same word oraffirmation; e. g., "Are they Hebrews so am I. Are they Israelites soam I." 2 Cor. xi. 22.
To disunite; to undo or repeal the annexation of. State Trials(1608).
The larva of the cheese fly. See Cheese fly, under Cheese.
A region of country having covers; a hunting country.
A tropical South American tree (Nectandra Rodioi), the bark ofwhich yields the alkaloid bebeerine, and the wood of which is knownas green heart.
The state of being gentlemanly; gentlemanly conduct or manners.
A support for the back, attached to the seat of a carriage.[Colloq.]
A fossil plant which is found in the lowest beds of theSilurian age.
The innermost of the ossicles of the ear; the stirrup, orstirrup bone; -- so called from its form. See Illust. of Ear.
Diminution; a species of hyperbole, representing a thing asbeing less than it really is.
The quality or state of being washy, watery, or weak.
A keeping of the hearer in doubt and in attentive expectationof what is to follow, or of what is to be the inference or conclusionfrom the arguments or observations employed.

A room combining a very small kitchen and a pantry, with thekitchen conveniences compactly arranged, sometimes so that they foldup out of sight and allow the kitchen to be made a part of theadjoining room by opening folding doors.
Emanative; of the nature of an emanation. Dr. H. More.
A white mark in the forehead of a horse, descending almost tothe nose; -- called also white-blaze.
A lubricant or salve for sores, burns, or the like; anointment. Cowper.

A Chinese toy made by cutting a square of thin wood, or othersuitable material, into seven pieces, as shown in the cut, thesepieces being capable of combination in various ways, so as to form agreat number of different figures. It is now often used in primaryschools as a means of instruction.
A mean or inferior poet, perhaps from his habit of wanderingaround as a stroller; an itinerant poet. Also, a name given to thecyclic poets. See under Cyclic, a. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
Mica containing iron and magnesia, generally of a black or darkgreen color; -- a common constituent of crystalline rocks. See Mica.
Washed by the waves or tide; -- said of a rock or strip ofshore, or (Naut.) of an anchor, etc., when flush with the surface ofthe water, so that the waves break over it.

A clergyman or layman who promotes revivals of religion; anadvocate for religious revivals; sometimes, specifically, aclergyman, without a particular charge, who goes about to promoterevivals. Also used adjectively.
The milk that remains after the butter is separated from thecream.
In accordance with the principles of dynamics or moving forces.J. Peile.
Of or relating to Voltaire, the French author. J. Morley.
A religious sect noted for warlike traits, founded in thePunjab at the end of the 15th century.
Checkmate given when movement of the king is completelyobstructed by his own men.

A colorless nonmetallic element, tasteless and odorless,comprising four fifths of the atmosphere by volume. It is chemicallyvery inert in the free state, and as such is incapable of supportinglife (hence the name azote still used by French chemists); but itforms many important compounds, as ammonia, nitric acid, thecyanides, etc, and is a constituent of all organized living tissues,animal or vegetable. Symbol N. Atomic weight 14. It was formerlyregarded as a permanent noncondensible gas, but was liquefied in 1877by Cailletet of Paris, and Pictet of Geneva.
Of or pertaining to selenium; derived from, or containing,selenium; specifically, designating those compounds in which theelement has a higher valence as contrasted with selenious compounds.
Control of one's self; restraint exercised over one's self;self-command.

St. Anthony's fire; a febrile disease accompanied with adiffused inflammation of the skin, which, starting usually from asingle point, spreads gradually over its surface. It is usuallyregarded as contagious, and often occurs epidemically.
Turning sour; readily becoming tart or acid; slightly sour.Faraday.
One of the precursors of the Reformation; -- a nicknamecorresponding to Lollard, etc.
To weigh, estimate, or rate below desert; to undervalue. [R.]Marston.
Capable or worthy of being wished for; desirable. Udall.
A curly-haired breed of spaniels, naturally very fond of thewater.
A grass with leaves having edges furnished with very minutehooked prickles, which form a cutting edge; one or more species ofLeersia.
The quality or property of being in fragnebts, or brokenpieces, incompleteness; want of continuity. G. Eliot.

One of a large series of amorphous or crystalline substances,occurring very widely distributed in plants, rarely in animals, andregarded as influental agents in the formation and disposition of thesugars. They are frequently of a bitter taste, but, by the action offerments, or of dilute acids and alkalies, always break down intosome characteristic substance (acid, aldehyde, alcohol, phenole, oralkaloid) and glucose (or some other sugar); hence the name. They areof the nature of complex and compound ethers, and ethereal salts ofthe sugar carbohydrates.

To give an origin or beginning to; to cause to be; to bringinto existence; to produce as new.A decomposition of the whole civill and political mass, for thepurpose of originating a new civil order. Burke.
A man learned in the civil law; an expert in juridical science;a professor of jurisprudence; a jurist.
Craniotomy; -- usually applied to bisection of the fetal headwith a saw.
One of the retractor muscles of the proboscis of certain worms.
A mineral usually occurring in fibrous masses, of a brick-redcolor, being tinged with iron, and consisting chiefly of thesulphates of lime, magnesia, and soda.
Act of making gestures; gesturing. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Pertaining to disquisition; of the nature of disquisition.
Having no race or kindred; childless. [Obs. & R.] Shak.
Dividing into double or treble ramifications; -- said of a leafor stem. [R.] Loudon.
The upper stomach of a cow, or other ruminant animal; therumen.
Characterized by, or pertaining to, debility; weak;debilitating.
Quality or state of being occasional; occasional occurrence.[R.]
One with itself; separate from others. [Obs.] Sylvester.
Quality of being first; primitiveness. [Obs.] Bp. Pearson.
The reduction of facts or principles to a system. Dunglison.
A statue whose extremities are of stone, the trunk beinggenerally of wood. Elmes.
One who, or that which, subverts; an overthrower. Sir T. More.
A plant (Herniaria glabra) supposed to be valuable for the cureof hernia or rupture.
Any South American monkey of the genus Mycetes. Many speciesare known. They are arboreal in their habits, and are noted for theloud, discordant howling in which they indulge at night.
A chair with arms to support the elbows; an armchair. Addison.
Not according to law; being or done in violation of law;unlawful. Milton.
Ignorance of one's own character, powers, and limitations.

A name of several maritime grasses, as the sea sand-reed(Ammophila arundinacea) which is used in Holland to bind the sand ofthe seacoast dikes (see Beach grass, under Beach); also, the LygeumSpartum, a Mediterranean grass of similar habit.
Having short breath or disordered respiration, as a horse.
More recent than the Eocene, that is, including both theMiocene and Pliocene divisions of the Tertiary.
The second part of the Talmud, or the commentary on the Mishna(which forms the first part or text).
One of the terminal hooks on the foot of an insect.
One who, or that which, interposes or intervenes; an obstacleor interruption; a mediator or agent between parties. Shak.
The master or superintendent of a mint. Also used figuratively.

An element obtained by reduction of its oxide, as a hard,grayish white metal, fusible with difficulty, but easily oxidized.Its ores occur abundantly in nature as the minerals pyrolusite,manganite, etc. Symbol Mn. Atomic weight 54.8.
The name by which a person is addressed; an appellative.
Having a pearly speck in the eye; afflicted with the cataract.
A heinous offense which requires expiation. [R.] Howell.
A variety of cellulose, occuring as a fine transparent membranecovering the aerial organs of plants, and forming an essentialingredient of cork; by oxidation it passes to suberic acid.
A college or corporation in Turkey composed of the hierarchy,namely, the imams, or ministers of religion, the muftis, or doctorsof law, and the cadis, or administrators of justice.
Of or pertaining to the region beyond the North wind, or to itsinhabitants.
Awry; askance; asquint; oblique or obliquely; -- sometimesindicating scorn, or contempt, or entry. Spenser.

One who, or that which, separates. Specifically:(a) (Steam Boilers) A device for depriving steam of particles ofwater mixed with it.(b) (Mining) An apparatus for sorting pulverized ores into grades, orseparating them from gangue. (c) (Weaving)
A plant of the genus Zingiber, of the East and West Indies. Thespecies most known is Z. officinale.

An extensive order of rhizopods which generally have achambered calcareous shell formed by several united zooids. Many ofthem have perforated walls, whence the name. Some species are coveredwith sand. See Rhizophoda.
Winding; twisted; warped; -- applied to curves and surfaces.
A large, highly esteemed, edible fish of India (Latescalcarifer); -- also called begti.
One who has gift and disposition of a benefice. [Eng.]
Having a general resemblance to lilies or to liliaceous plants.

The act or process of daubing a vessel's bottom near thesurface of the water with a mixture of tallow, sulphur, and resin, asa temporary protection against worms, after the slime, shells, etc.,have been scraped off.
Public moneys expended at Athens on festivals, sacrifices, andpublic entertainments (especially theatrical performances), and ingifts to the people; -- also called theoric fund.
A glucoside extracted from squill (Scilla) as a light poroussubstance.
The quality of being direct; straightness; straightforwardness;immediateness.
Detached; separated; -- a term indicating that every note is tobe performed in a distinct and pointed manner.
To make English; to English; to anglify; render conformable tothe English idiom, or to English analogies.
The lowest groups of animals, in which no nervous system hasbeen observed.
A popular name for any society or club which meets for thepractice of male part songs.
Capable of being published; suitable for publication.
Capable of miscarrying; liable to fail. [R.] Bp. Hall.
To impregnate with aroma; to render aromatic; to give a spicyscent or taste to; to perfume. Bacon.
A jury, for the trial of a fore foreigner, composed equally ofcitizens and aliens.
Mercury telluride, an iron-black metallic mineral, found inColorado.
Scarcely; hardly. [Obs. or Colloq.] Robynson (More's Utopia)
The apartment appropriated for the males. This was in the lowerpart of the house.
To bevel the end of a timber to fit against an inclinedsurface.
A tribe of lophobranch fishes having a tubular snout. Thefemale carries the eggs in a ventral pouch.
Pertaining to, or in the style of, Demosthenes, the Grecianorator.
Work or devices suitable to be concealed; a secret stratagem.[Obs.]

A colorless liquid, CHBr3, having an agreeable odor andsweetish taste. It is produced by the simultaneous action of bromineand caustic potash upon wood spirit, alcohol, or acetone, as also bycertain other reactions. In composition it is the same as chloroform,with the substitution of bromine for chlorine. It is somewhat similarto chloroform in its effects. Watts.
The change of one mineral species to another, so as to involvea change in physical characters without alteration of chemicalcomposition.
A simple fieldwork, consisting of two faces forming a salientangle pointing outward and open at the gorge.
The act of diluting, or the state of being diluted. Arbuthnot.
That which grows under trees; specifically, shrubs or smalltrees growing among large trees. Milton.
The smallest part of any substance which possesses thecharacteristic properties and qualities of that substance, and whichcan exist alone in a free state.
Chips made by one who whittles; shavings cut from a stick witha knife.
The act of swelling beyond the surrounding surface. Cooke(1615).
Under the tongue; -- applied esp., in the higher vertebrates,to the twelfth or last pair of cranial nerves, which are distributedto the base of the tongue.-- n.
Any one of numerous species of pseudoneoropterous insectsbelonging to Termes and allied genera; -- called also white ant. SeeIllust. of White ant.
The twenty-fourth part of a grain; -- a weight used bygoldsmiths. Crabb.
An efflorescence or discoloration of the skin; an eruption orbreaking out, as in measles, smallpox, scarlatina, and the likediseases; -- sometimes limited to eruptions attended with fever.Dunglison.
The dephasing of the two parts of a single alternating currentin two dissimilar branches of a given circuit.
The eliminant of the n partial differentials of any homogenousfunction of n variables. See Eliminant.
A brown, nitrogenous pigment contained in the retinalepithelium; a variety of melanin.
The inspissated juice of the common lettuce, sometimes used asa substitute for opium.
Sharing; participating; having a share of part. Bacon.
One who makes dresses, cloaks, etc., for women; a dressmaker.
One who makes merriment or indulges in conviviality; a jovialcomrade.
The quality of being diffuse; especially, in writing, the useof a great or excessive number of word to express the meaning;copiousness; verbosity; prolixity.
A juror's taking of money from the both parties for a verdict.
One of the seven confederated tribes of Indians belonging tothe Sioux, or Dakotas.
A large edible river fish (Erythrinus macrodon) of Guiana.
The median, convex lobe of the head of a trilobite. SeeTrilobite.
State of being a rascal; rascality; domain of rascals; rascals,collectively. Emerson.
Disguised by dress so as to be ridiculous; travestied; --applied to a book or shorter composition. [R.]
Of or pertaining to a meatus; resembling a meatus. Owen.
Pertaining to, or set with, briers or bushes; brambly. [R.]
Of or pertaining to the sternum and the mastoid process.
An eruptive rock allied to trachyte, consisting essentially ofa triclinic feldspar, with pyroxene, hornblende, or hypersthene.
Flowing tendency or quality; fluency. [R.] W. Nichols.

On a painting, and sometimes in a bas-relief, mosaic picture,or the like, that part of the scene represented, which is nearest tothe spectator, and therefore occupies the lowest part of the work ofart itself. Cf. Distance, n., 6.
An order of large aquatic herbivorous mammals, including themanatee, dugong, rytina, and several fossil genera.
A shoe that is worn over another for protection from wet or forextra warmth; esp., an India-rubber shoe; a galoche.
The state of being sole, or alone; soleness. [R.] Sir E.Dering.
To rise upward in a whirl; to raise upward with a whirlingmotion.

A genus of plants of the Spurge family, containing but onespecies (R. communis), the castor-oil plant. The fruit is three-celled, and contains three large seeds from which castor oil issexpressed. See Palma Christi.
A water hole in the bed of an intermittent stream, esp. thebowl at the foot of a cliff over which the stream leaps when in theflood stage. [Western U. S.]
An instrument for taking azimuths and altitudes simultaneously.
The Unicorn, a constellation situated to the east Orion.
Resembling, or analogous to, the cerebrum or brain.
A product of metabolism; a substance produced by metabolicaction, as urea.
A very fine wavy crosswise color marking, or a patch of suchmarkings, as on the feathers of birds.
Having a caudal fin extending around the end of the vertebralcolumn, like that which is first formed in the embryo of fishes;diphycercal.
One of a sect of Christian in the primitive church who usedwater instead of wine in the Lord's Supper.
Having parts, as leaves, arranged in many vertical rows.
Little flowers of ornament introduced into a melody by a singeror player.
A writ given by statute to recover lands when the tenant hasfor two years failed to perform the conditions of his tenure.
Fleeting; lasting but a short time; -- applied particularly toorgans or parts which are short-lived as compared with the life ofthe individual.
A kind of light bridge, used in sieges, for surprising a postor outwork which has but a narrow moat; a flying bridge.
A collective name for the Indians of Nicaragua and Honduras.
The act of running about; also, rambling language. [Obs.]Barrow.
Pertaining to the time of equal day and night; -- applied tothe equinoctial line. Whewell.

Any one of a series of isomeric hydrocarbons of pleasantaromatic odor, occurring especially in coniferous plants andrepresented by oil of turpentine, but including also certainhydrocarbons found in some essential oils.

A substance composed essentially of gun cotton and camphor, andwhen pure resembling ivory in texture and color, but variouslycolored to imitate coral, tortoise shell, amber, malachite, etc. Itis used in the manufacture of jewelry and many small articles, ascombs, brushes, collars, and cuffs; -- originaly called xylonite.
The cattle of the Hebrides, or of the Highlands. [Scot.] Sir W.Scott.

One of the changes of assimilation, in which proteid matterwhich has been transformed, and made a part of the tissue or tissuecells, is endowed with life, and thus enabled to manifest thephenomena of irritability, contractility, etc. McKendrick.
A colored photographic picture taken upon paper made sensitivewith potassium bichromate or some other salt of chromium.
One who swears or is sworn with others; one bound by oath withothers; a compurgator. Burrill.
The business of a huckster; small dealing; peddling.Ignoble huckster age of piddling tithes. Milton.
In the East Indies, an inclosure containing a house,outbuildings, etc.
The act of vouchsafing, or that which is vouchsafed; a gift orgrant in condescension. Glanvill.
A friend to colonization, esp. (U. S. Hist) to the colonizationof Africa by emigrants from the colored population of the UnitedStates.
A division of fishes in which the lower pharyngeal bones areunited. It includes the scaroid, labroid, and embioticoid fishes.
Broken and detached fragments, taken collectively; especially,fragments detached from a rock or mountain, and piled up at the base.
A short stick, with one end loaded, or thicker and heavier thatthe other, used as an offensive weapon.
The act of disconcerting, or state of being disconcerted;discomposure; perturbation. [R.] State Trials (1794).

The tenets or doctrines of Faustus Socinus, an Italiantheologian of the sixteenth century, who denied the Trinity, thedeity of Christ, the personality of the Devil, the native and totaldepravity of man, the vicarious atonement, and the eternity of futurepunishment. His theory was, that Christ was a man divinelycommissioned, who had no existence before he was conceived by theVirgin Mary; that human sin was the imitation of Adam's sin, and thathuman salvation was the imitation and adoption of Christ's virtue;that the Bible was to be interpreted by human reason; and that itslanguage was metaphorical, and not to be taken literally.
One who guards the entrance of a house or apartment; a porter;a janitor.
The commission or compensation allowed to a ship's husband.
Having mild and salubrious qualities. [Obs.] Bacon.
Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the intestine.

A very large marine fish (Megapolis Atlanticus) of the SouthernUnited States and the West Indies. It often becomes six or more feetin length, and has large silvery scales. The scales are a staplearticle of trade, and are used in fancywork. Called also tarpon,sabalo, savanilla, silverfish, and jewfish.
Of or pertaining to revocation; tending to, or involving, arevocation; revoking; recalling.
The space from within which the ball must be struck inbeginning the play for each hole.
A drinking bout in which every one pays an equal share. [Obs.]
Something intricately contrived; a contrived; a puzzle. [Cant &Obs.] Arbuthnot.
A wood nymph; a nymph whose life was bound up with that of hertree.
Not to be expected or anticipated. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Characterized by asseveration; asserting positively.
A stalk which bears the fructification in some lichens, as inthe so-called reindeer moss.
The condition of a bond servant; sevice without wages; slavery.Their children . . . upon those did Solomon levy a tribute of bondservice. 1 Kings ix. 21.
Belonging to Apicius, a notorious Roman epicure; hence appliedto whatever is peculiarly refined or dainty and expensive in cookery.H. Rogers.
Act or recreation of riding in or driving a motor car orautomobile.
A group of butterflies including those known as virgins, orgossamer-winged butterflies.
A natural covered opening in the earth; a cave; also, anartificial recess, cave, or cavernlike apartment.
Any fossil foraminifer of the genus Rotalia, abundant in thechalk formation. See Illust. under Rhizopod.
To practice ventriloquism; to speak like a ventriloquist.
The feeding of the body upon itself, as in fasting; nutritionby consumption of one's own tissues.
A petty or inferior Whig; -- used in contempt. Spectator.
Conveyance by boat; also, a charge for such conveyance.
A monster capable of assuming a woman's form, who was said todevour human beings or suck their blood; a vampire; a sorceress; awith.

One of a secret society, organized in the north of Ireland in1795, the professed objects of which are the defense of the regningsovereign of Great Britain, the support of the Protestant religion,the maintenance of the laws of the kingdom, etc.; -- so called inhonor of William, Prince of Orange, who became William III. ofEngland.
An old wind instrument of the double bassoon kind, havingventages but not keys.
The philosophical theory which attributes the origin of all ourknowledge to experience.
A name of several annual weeds. See Goosefoot, and Lamb's-quarters.
Hypnotism of one's self by concentration of the attention onsome object or idea.
A genus of herbs of the Barberry family, having large palmatelylobed peltate leaves and solitary flower. There are two species, theAmerican Podohyllum peltatum, or May apple, the Himalayan P. Emodi.
A white crystalline nitrogenous substance, C2H4.(CO)2.NH,obtained by treating succinic anhydride with ammonia gas. It is atypical imido acid, and forms a series of salts. See Imido acid,under Imido.
In company with others; unitedly; concurrently. Bp. pearson.
An extinct animal of large size, known from its three-toedfootprints in Mesozoic sandstone.
Not exact; not precisely correct or true; inaccurate.
Converging to a center; -- applied to lines drawn so as to meetin a point or center.
Pertaining to contexture or arrangement of parts; producingcontexture; interwoven. Dr. John Smith (1666).
Fit to be praised; praise-worthy; laudable; commendable. Wyclif(2 Tim. ii. 15).
Of or pertaining to pronunciation; that pronounces.

Ceremonially clean, according to Jewish law; --applied to food,esp. to meat of animals slaughtered according to the requirements ofJewish law. Opposed to tref. Hence, designating a shop, store, house,etc., where such food is sold or used.
Growing upward, as distinguished from a laterral growth; --applied to the growth of corals. Dana.
The presence of peptone, or a peptonelike body, in the urine.
A notification by a candidate for orders of his intention toinquire whether any impediment may be alleged against him.
Pertaining to starch; of the nature of starch; starchy.
Having the form of a fiber or fibers; resembling a fiber.
The top end of a timber, rising above the gunwale, and servingfor belaying ropes, etc.; -- called also kevel head.
In a marked emphatic manner; -- used adverbially as adirection.
A kind of gate or portcullis, having iron bars, like a harrow,studded with iron spikes. It is hung above gateways so that it may bequickly lowered, to impede the advance of an enemy. Farrow.
The seed of a Brazilian lauraceous tree (Nectandra Puchury) ofa taste and smell between those of nutmeg and of sassafras, --sometimes used medicinally. Called also sassafras nut.

A plant (Menyanthes trifoliata) which grows in moist and boggyplaces, having racems of white or reddish flowers and intenselybitter leaves, sometimes used in medicine; marsh trefoil; -- calledalso bog bean.
A peculiar larval form of Phoronis, a genus of marine worms,having a circle of ciliated tentacles.
A belted waist resembling a shirt in plainness of cut andstyle, worn by women or children; -- in England called a blouse.
To play a low card when holding a high one, in the hope of afuture advantage.

Will not prosecute; -- an entry on the record, denoting that aplaintiff discontinues his suit, or the attorney for the public aprosecution; either wholly, or as to some count, or as to some ofseveral defendants.

The act of communicating or ejecting; esp., an ecclesiasticalcensure whereby the person against whom it is pronounced is, for thetime, cast out of the communication of the church; exclusion fromfellowship in things spiritual.
A salt having two equivalents of arsenic acid to one of thebase. Graham.
A punt made from the goal line by a player of the side whichhas made a touchdown to one of his own side for a fair catch, fromwhich an attempt to kick a goal may be made.
The person who has a right to present to a benefice; thepatron; an advowee. See Advowson.
Maine; -- a nickname alluding to the pine tree in its coat ofarms.
A kind of pantograph which produces copies microscopicallyminute.
A woven band of cotton or flax, used for reins, girths, bedbottoms, etc.

One who prepares a play for production. He arranges the detailsof the stage settings, the business to be used, all stage effects,and instructs the actors, excepting usually the star, in the generalinterpretation of their parts.
A red crystalline nitrogenous substance or artificialproduction, which by reduction passes directly to indigo.
The doctrine or belief that all men will be saved, or madehappy, in the future state.
Minced meat; meat chopped very fine; a mixture of boiled meat,suet, apples, etc., chopped very fine, to which spices and raisinsare added; -- used in making mince pie.
A funeral rite (usually in the plural); the ceremonies ofburial; obsequies; funeral procession.But see his exequies fulfilled in Rouen. Shak.
An order of pelagic Gastropoda, having the foot developed intoa median fin. Some of the species are naked; others, as Carinaria andAtlanta, have thin glassy shells.
The quality or state of being half barbarous or uncivilized.
Like paper; having the thinness or consistence of paper. Gray.
An instrument for measuring minute intervals of time; used indetermining the velocity of projectiles, the duration of short-livedluminous phenomena, etc.
The dagger held in the left hand, while the rapier is held inthe right; -- used to parry thrusts of the adversary's rapier.
That may be assimilated; that may be likened, or appropriatedand incorporated.
A genus of eight-armed cephalopods, including numerous species,some of them of large size. See Devilfish,
A theory which explains inheritance by the transmission of thetype of growth force possessed by one generation to another.
A female pupil; especially, a graduate of a school or college.
A large species of African baboon (Cynocephalus porcarius); --called also ursine baboon.
The act or process of lapidifying; fossilization; petrifaction.
One who, or that which, fells, knocks or cuts down; a machinefor felling trees.
One who disturbs the public peace.-- Peace"break`ing, n.
A person of congenitally abnormal mind bordering on insanity ordegeneracy.
The act of rivaling, or the state of being a rival; acompetition. "Keen contention and eager rivalries." Jeffrey.
A writing back; the answering of a letter. Loveday.
To make empty; to render of no effect; to humble. [Obs.] Bp.Pearson.
An apparatus for raising a liquid by pressure of air or steamin a reservoir containing the liquid.
The act of assassinating; a killing by treacherous violence.
To make or form amiss; to spoil in making. "Limpingpossibilities of mismade human nature." Mrs. Browning.
Relating to any disease characterized by tonic spasms.
A small kind of hound with a long body and short legs, used asan earth dog.
An active principle of Arnica montana. It is a bitter resin.
Honeycomb; having cavities or cells, somewhat resembling thoseof a honeycomb; alveolate; favose.
The domain or sphere of scoundrels; scoundrels, collectively;the state, ideas, or practices of scoundrels. Carlyle.
An instrument for cleansing the ear, consisting of a smallpiece of sponge on an ivory or bone handle.
The art of forming or of cultivating forests; the management ofgrowing timber.
A tension spoke of a bicycle or similar wheel, securedtangentially to the hub.
A composition of wax and lampblack, used by shoemakers forpolishing, and by antiquaries in copying inscriptions.
A hydrostatic press of immense power, invented by Joseph Bramahof London. See under Hydrostatic.
The quality or state of being mucous or slimy; mucousness.
Two metrical feet taken together, or included in one measure.Hadley.Trochaic, iambic, and anapestic verses . . . are measured bydipodies. W. W. Goodwin.
A kind of plant with acrid leaves. See under 2d Plantain.
One of an ancient sect of physicians who went by generalprinciples; -- opposed to the Empiric.
A small room, esp. if pleasant, or elegantly furnished, towhich a lady may retire to be alone, or to receive intimate friends;a lady's (or sometimes a gentleman's) private room. Cowper.
The act of permitting; allowance; permission; leave. Milton.
To divide into separate parts; to cut in pieces; to separateand expose the parts of, as an animal or a plant, for examination andto show their structure and relations; to anatomize.
Shriveled or shrunken; -- said especially of grain which haslost its juices from the ravages of insects, such as the wheat midge,or Trips (Thrips cerealium).
Immorality; also, the nectar conferring immortality.-- a. Ambrosial; immortal.
An order of ganoid fishes of which the bichir of Africa is aliving example. See Crossopterygii.
A white, fatty, crystalline substance, tasteless and odorless,found in animal and plant products and tissue, and especially innerve tissue, in the bile, and in gallstones.
The condition of not having reached puberty, or the age ofability to reproduce one's species; want of age at which the marriagecontract can be legally entered into.
In the manner of a gerund; as, or in place of, a gerund.

A follower of Marcion, a Gnostic of the second century, whoadopted the Oriental notion of the two conflicting principles, andimagined that between them there existed a third power, neitherwholly good nor evil, the Creator of the world and of man, and theGod of the Jewish dispensation. Brande & C.

One of a warlike, pastoral people, skillful as horsemen,inhabiting different parts of the Russian empire and furnishingvaluable contingents of irregular cavalry to its armies, those ofLittle Russia and those of the Don forming the principal divisions.
A derivative of xylene obtained as a white crystallinesubstance which on exposure in the air becomes red; -- called alsobetaorcin.
The gathering and examination of sheets preparatory to binding.
To smoke; to blacken with smoke; to rub with soot. [Obs.]
A gigantic African tree (Adansonia digitata), also naturalizedin India. See Adansonia.
The third part of the corn or grain growing on the ground atthe tenant's death, due to the lord for a heriot, as within the manorof Turfat in Herefordshire.
A group of Coelenterata, comprising the Anthozoa Ctenophora.The sea anemone, or actinia, is a familiar example.
One who labors in a toilsome occupation; a person who does workthat requires strength rather than skill, as distinguished from thatof an artisan.
To absterge; to cleanse; to purge away. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A genus of cactaceous plants having flattened, jointed stems,and petals united in a tube. The flowers are very showy, and severalspecies are in cultivation.
Quality of being brusque; roughness joined with promptness;blutness. Brit. Quar.
One of a body of devoted Jews who opposed the Hellenistic Jews,and supported the Asmoneans.
Corrupt or guilty assent to wrongdoing, not involving actualparticipation in, but knowledge of, and failure to prevent or opposeit.
Of or pertaining to constables; consisting of constables.
An ornament resembling a ball placed in a circular flower, thepetals of which form a cup round it, -- usually inserted in a hollowmolding.
One who believes that Christ was a mere man. Smart.
A small outwork of a fortification; a fortilage; -- called alsofortelace.
Act of wasting away; a consuming; extinction. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
A genus of reodents comprising the common squirrels.
The pin grass (Erodium cicutarium), a weed in California.
One who treats; one who handles, or discourses on, a subject;also, one who entertains.
A customary deduction from the gross weight of goods, differentin different countries, such as tare and tret.
A genus of coarse herbs having small flowers in panicled cymes;figwort.
A ravenous appetite caused by disease; excessive and morbidhunger.

Any of eight isomeric liquid compounds, C5H11OH; ordinarily, amixture of two of these forming a colorless liquid with a peculiarcough-exciting odor and burning taste, the chief constituent of fuseloil. It is used as a source of amyl compounds, such as amyl acetate,amyl nitrite, etc.
Ulceration of bone; a process in which bone disintegrates andis carried away piecemeal, as distinguished from necrosis, in whichit dies in masses.
An aquatic plant of the genus Sagittaria, esp. S. sagittifolia,-- named from the shape of the leaves.

A common mineral of the zeolite family, a hydrous silicate ofalumina and lime, usually occurring in sheaflike aggregations ofcrystals, also in radiated masses. It is of a white or yellowishcolor, with pearly luster on the cleavage surface. Called alsodesmine.
Any one of several species of humming birds of the genusSteganura, having two of the tail feathers very long and racket-shaped.
A palmitate derived from three molecules of palmitic acid.
An artificial alkaloid of complex composition, resemblingthalline and used as an antipyretic, -- whence its name.
A morbid swelling of the scrotum due to extravasation of urineinto it.
A white or gray tasteless powder, the oxide of the elementglucinum; -- formerly called glucine.
Of or pertaining to Poland or its inhabitants.-- n.
The art or process of weaving; texture. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A modal relation or quality; a mode or point of view underwhich an object presents itself to the mind. According to Kant, thequality of propositions, as assertory, problematical, or apodeictic.
The act of announcing or proclaiming beforehand. [Obs.]
The material of which belts for machinery are made; also,belts, taken collectively.
In the enharmonic style or system; in just intonation.
A slab of stone used as a veneer for coarse masonry. Knight.
Of or pertaining to the Chinese and allied races; Chinese.
A depriving of bone or of fruit stones. [Obs.] Bacon.
Inhabiting the seashore, esp. the zone between high-water andlow-water mark.
The particular place, or kind of situation, in which a speciesnaturally occurs; a habitat. (e) (Naut.)
The ketone of propionic acid, obtained as a colorless fragrantliquid.
A contract by which two parties or more agree that a certainsum of money, or other thing, shall be paid or delivered to one ofthem, on the happening or not happening of an uncertain event.Bouvier.
Want of success; failure; misfortune. Prof. Wilson.
One of the small sesamoid bones situated behind the condyles ofthe femur, in some mammals.
The governor of a province of the Ottoman empire, next indignity to the grand vizier.
A half gable, as at the end of a penthouse or of the aisle of achurch.
A genus of shrubs, natives of Australia, New Zealand, etc.,having pretty white, red, or purple blossoms, and much resemblingheaths.
An instrument for marking or laying off the outlines of teethof gear wheels.
To warn; to admonish; to advise. [Obs.] Wyclif (2 Cor. v. 20).
That part of the upper deck abaft the mainmast, including thepoop deck when there is one.
Native zinc carbonate. It generally occurs in stalactitic,reniform, or botryoidal shapes, of a white to gray, green, or browncolor. See Note under Calamine.
Applied to the down of newly hatched or unfledged birds.
The small arch or bar at right angles to the strings of aviolin, guitar, etc., serving of raise them and transmit theirvibrations to the body of the instrument.
A kind of novation by which a debtor, to be liberated from hiscreditor, gives him a third person, who becomes obliged in his steadto the creditor, or to the person appointed by him. Pothier.
Of or pertaining to the state of a widow; widowed. [R.] Jer.Taylor.
One who consecrates; one who performs the rites by which aperson or thing is devoted or dedicated to sacred purposes. [Writtenalso consecrater.]
A European amarylidaceous plant (Pancratium maritimum).
A summoner; an apparitor; a sompnour. [Obs.] Piers Plowman.
A supposed rare element, said to be associated with cerium,yttrium, etc., in the mineral samarskite, and more recently calledsamarium. Symbol Dp. See Samarium.
A genus of plants found in the fresh-water ponds or lakes ofEurope, Asia, and North America; the yellow water lily. Cf. Nymphaea.
A broad stern without overhang, flattened on the bottom, usedin some torpedo and fast power boats. It prevents settling in thewater at high speed.
Fit to be walked on; capable of being walked on or over. [R.]Swift.
An automobile designed for touring; specif., a roomy car, not alimousine, for five or more passengers.

Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C4H7N3O2, obtained,by the action of the vapor of cyanic acid on cold aldehyde, as awhite crystalline substance having a slightly acid taste and faintsmell; -- called also ethidene- or ethylidene-biuret.
To give scant measure; to squeeze or pinch in order to effect asaving. [Prev. Eng. & Colloq. U.S.]
A bully; a bravo; a ruffian; an assassin. [Obs.] Milton.
One who holds to the atomic philosophy or theory. Locke.
Composed of bone; resembling bone; capable of forming bone;bony; ossific.
A crystalline globulin, contained in oat kernels, very similarin composition to excelsin, but different in reactions andcrystalline form.
A genus of marsipobranchs, including the hagfish. See Hag, 4.
A colorless substance isomeric with chlorophyll, contained inparts of plants capable of becoming green. Watts.
A metal-hubbed wheel of great strength and elasticity, esp.adapted for artillery carriages and motor cars.
A narrow stripe of purple worn by the equites on each side ofthe tunic as a sign of rank.
An ornament or a fetter for the ankle; an ankle ring.
Any fern of the genus Asplenium, some species of which wereanciently used as remedies for disorders of the spleen.
The act of setting in a flame or blaze. [Obs.] Sir. T. Browne.
Evil or corrupt usage; abuse; wrong; reproach; deception;cheat. Chaucer.
An extinct order of ganoid fishes. They had a compressed body,covered with dermal ribs (pleurolepida) and with enameled rhomboidalscales.
Of or pertaining to a division of the Silurian formation,corresponding in general to the Lower Silurian of most authors,exclusive of the Cambrian.-- n.
A stringed instrument of music resembling the lute or theviolin, but larger, and having six strings, three of silk coveredwith silver wire, and three of catgut, -- played upon with thefingers.
As by right or title; arrogantly; presumptuously. Collier.
The science which treats of the nose, and its diseases.
A pisonous resin extracted from hemp (Cannabis sativa, varietyIndica). The narcotic effects of hasheesh are due to this resin.

A special structure found in the mouth of most mollusks, exceptbivalves. It consists of several muscles and a cartilage whichsupports a chitinous radula, or lingual ribbon, armed with teeth.Also applied to the radula alone. See Radula.
An extinct Quaternary marsupial from Australia, about as largeas the hippopotamus; -- so named because of its two large frontteeth. See Illustration in Appendix.

A motion to and fro, up and down, or from side to side, in anyfluid or elastic medium, propagated continuously among its particles,but with no translation of the particles themselves in the directionof the propagation of the wave; a wave motion; a vibration.
A short, straight, horizontal mark [-], placed over vowels todenote that they are to be pronounced with a long sound; as, a, indame; e, in seam, etc.
The birds, or all the kinds of birds, inhabiting a region.

An officer in Christian churches appointed to perform certainsubordinate duties varying in different communions. In the RomanCatholic and Episcopal churches, a person admitted to the lowestorder in the ministry, subordinate to the bishops and priests. InPresbyterian churches, he is subordinate to the minister and elders,and has charge of certain duties connected with the communion serviceand the care of the poor. In Congregational churches, he issubordinate to the pastor, and has duties as in the Presbyterianchurch.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, lichens; abounding inlichens; covered with lichens. G. Eliot.
A Brazilian name for the lofty myrtaceous tree (Bertholetiaexcelsa) which produces the large seeds known as Brazil nuts.
A word formerly used (as finis is now) at the conclusion of abook to indicate the end.
Act of making hollow; also, a hollow; an exvation; adepression.
The quality or state of being tenebrous; tenebrousness. Burton.
Indefatigableness; unweariedness. [Obs.] J. Gregory.
The European greater weever fish (Trachinus draco), which iscapable of inflicting severe wounds with the spinous rays of itsdorsal fin. See Weever.
Influenced in its contraction by heat or cold; -- said of amuscle.
One versed in statistics; one who collects and classifies factsfor statistics.
Capable of uniting with five molecules of a monacid base;having five acid hydrogen atoms capable of substitution by a basicradical; -- said of certain acids.
A small lemuroid mammal (Arctocebus Calabarensis) of Africa. Ithas only a rudimentary tail.

A contract or obligation under seal; a contract by deed; awriting, under seal, given as security for a debt particularlyspecified. Chitty. Bouvier. Wharton (Law Dict.).Let specialties be therefore drawn between us. Shak.

Secondary and less distinct tones which accompany anyprincipal, and apparently simple, tone, as the octave, the twelfth,the fifteenth, and the seventeenth. The name is also applied to theartificial tones produced by a string or column of air, when theimpulse given to it suffices only to make a part of the string orcolumn vibrate; overtones.
A low, narrowleaved evergreen shrub (Cneorum tricoccon) foundin Southern Europe.
