Yellowish white; having a faint tint of dingy yellow. Gray.
Transportation, as of petroleum oil, by means of a pipeconduit; also, the charge for such transportation.
An unorganized ferment which causes cane sugar to take up amolecule of water and be converted into invert sugar.
An instrument from tetanizing a muscle by irritating its nerveby successive mechanical shocks.
A small cooper coin formerly current in the Roman States, worthabout a cent and a half.
Pertaining to adjection; that is, or may be, annexed. [R.]Earle.
The act of eventuating or happening as a result; the outcome.R. W. Hamilton.
A theory of the origin of ideas which derives them exclusivelyfrom sensation.
Having power to enact or establish as a law. Abp. Bramhall.
A flowing round on all sides; an inclosing with a fluid.
Remaining closed at maturity, or not opening along regularlines, as the acorn, or a cocoanut.
To prefigure; to exhibit previously in a type. Bp. Pearson.
Assuming man as the center or ultimate end; -- applied totheories of the universe or of any part of it, as the solar system.Draper.
An alcoholic tincture prepared with fresh plants. New Eng.Dict.
A kind of round dance in march or polka time; also, a piece ofmusic for this dance. [U. S.]

An extensive order of parasitic worms. They are found in theinternal cavities of animals belonging to all classes. Many speciesare found, also, on the gills and skin of fishes. A few species areparasitic on man, and some, of which the fluke is the most important,are injurious parasites of domestic animals. The trematodes usuallyhave a flattened body covered with a chitinous skin, and arefurnished with two or more suckers for adhesion. Most of the speciesare hermaphrodite. Called also Trematoda, and Trematoidea. See Fluke,Tristoma, and Cercaria.
A large mass of ice, generally floating in the ocean.
Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, sandalwood (Santalum); --used specifically to designate an acid obtained as a resinous or redcrystalline dyestuff, which is called also santalin.

A house for the reception of strangers.(b) In the Middle Ages, a room in a monastery for the reception andentertainment of strangers and pilgrims, and for the relief ofpaupers. [Called also Xenodocheion.]
A contrivance for hatching eggs by artificial heat.
A fancied perception of flashes of light, a symptom ofepilepsy; hence, epilepsy itself; convulsions.

A small opening; a small depression or cavity; a space, as avacant space between the cells of plants, or one of the spaces leftamong the tissues of the lower animals, which serve in place ofvessels for the circulation of the body fluids, or the cavity or sac,usually of very small size, in a mucous membrane.
One who frequents; one who often visits, or resorts tocustomarily.
A complaint to a court. See Audita Querela. [Obs.] Ayliffe.
Having a bill shaped like the colter of a plow, or like aknife, as the heron, stork, etc.
Act or process of expelling the exhaust gases from the cylinderby some special means, as, in many four-cycle engines, by utilizingthe momentum of the exhaust gases in a long exhaust pipe.
An African sheeplike quadruped (the Ammotragus tragelaphus)having a long mane on the breast and fore legs. It is, perhaps, thechamois of the Old Testament.

The doctrine of the Mystics, who professed a pure, sublime, andwholly disinterested devotion, and maintained that they had directintercourse with the divine Spirit, and aquired a knowledge of Godand of spiritual things unattainable by the natural intellect, andsuch as can not be analyzed or explained.
The state or quality of being romantic; widness; fancifulness.Richardson.
Partaking of the nature and character of schorl; resemblingschorl.
The armpit, or the cavity beneath the junction of the arm andshoulder.

Having the power of breathing impaired by the rupture,dilatation, or running together of air cells of the lungs, so thatwhile the inspiration is by one effort, the expiration is by two;affected with pulmonary emphysema or with heaves; -- said of a horse.Youatt.
Having the form of a sword, but very long and narrow.
Having one oblique intersection; -- said of that system ofcrystallization in which the vertical axis is inclined to one, but atright angles to the other, lateral axis. See Crystallization.

One of the grand divisions of the animal kingdom, including theclasses Cephalopoda, Gastropoda, PteropodaScaphopoda, andLamellibranchiata, or Conchifera. These animals have an unsegmentedbilateral body, with most of the organs and parts paired, but notrepeated longitudinally. Most of them develop a mantle, whichincloses either a branchial or a pulmonary cavity. They are generallymore or less covered and protected by a calcareous shell, which maybe univalve, bivalve, or multivalve.
The practice or theory of using hellebore as a medicine.
Used in only one person, especially only in the third person,as some verbs; impersonal.
A plan proposed; a draft of a proposed measure; a project.
Of or pertaining to building or construction; architectural.
Incapable of being effaced; indelible; ineradicable.
Floating in water, as the leaves of water lilies, or submersed,as those of many aquatic plants.
Not having organic structure; devoid of organs; inorganic.
The pelvic arch, or the pelvic arch together with the sacrum.See Pelvic arch, under Pelvic, and Sacrum.
A slender, nearly leafless, American herb (Polygonumarticulatum), with jointed spikes of small flowers.
The art of writing in cipher, or in characters which are notintelligible except to persons who have the key; cryptography.
Forming or producing an oil; specifically, designating acolorless gaseous hydrocarbon called ethylene. [Archaic]
The drupaceous fruit of two South African shrubs of the genusArduina (A. bispinosa and A. grandiflora).
A massive variety of talc, of a grayish green or brown color.It forms extensive beds, and is quarried for fireplaces and forcoarse utensils. Called also potstone, lard stone, and soapstone.
The faculty or propensity which impels to reserve, secrecy, orconcealment.
To be careless, negligent, or aswkward, esp. with regard todress and neatness; to be wasteful. Ray.
An oblong rectangular piece of cloth, worn by Roman ladies, andfastened with brooches.
An insect that turns about nimbly; the mole cricket; -- calledalso fan cricket. Johnson.
The herb wolfsbane, or monkshood; -- applied to any plant ofthe genus Aconitum (tribe Hellebore), all the species of which arepoisonous.
a position in which an army finds itself with no way of exitbut to the front.
A country or region, more or less remote from the city of Rome,brought under the Roman government; a conquered country beyond thelimits of Italy. Wyclif (Acts xiii. 34). Milton.
A pneumatic reproducer for a phonograph, controlled by therecording stylus on the principle of the relay. It produces muchclearer and louder tones than does the ordinary vibrating diskreproducer.
An inhabitant, or, collectively, inhabitants, of the Faroeislands.
A branching perennial plant (Cichorium Intybus) with brightblue flowers, growing wild in Europe, Asia, and America; alsocultivated for its roots and as a salad plant; succory; wild endive.See Endive.
An American genus of plants, containing but a single species(E. repens), the trailing arbutus.
A bar of iron sharpened at one end, and used as a lever.
A naval vessel having the parts above water covered andprotected by iron or steel usually in large plates closely joined andmade sufficiently thick and strong to resist heavy shot.
To cease to hold; to unhand; to release. [Obs.] Otway.
The act of inveigling, or the state of being inveigled; thatwhich inveigles; enticement; seduction. South.
The first coat in plastering; -- called also scratchwork. SeePricking-up.
A European flounder (Hippoglossoides limandoides); -- calledalso rough dab, long fluke, sand fluke, and sand sucker.
The peculiar fruit of fennel, carrott, parsnip, and the like,consisting of a pair of carpels pendent from a supporting axis.

A lagging or retardation of the effect, when the forces actingupon a body are changed, as if from velocity or internal friction; atemporary resistance to change from a condition previously invuced,observed in magnetism, thermoelectricity, etc., on reversal ofpolarity.
One who furthers. or helps to advance; a promoter. Shak.
Covered with hairs or pubescence so platted together andinterwoven as to form a mass easily removed.
The Cornish chough. See under Chough. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
A stick three feet, or a yard, in length, used as a measure ofcloth, etc.
A loop or eye formed on the head rope of a bonnet, by which itis attached to the foot of a sail; -- called also latch and lasket.[Usually in pl.]
A member of the sanhedrin. Schaeffer (Lange's Com. ).
A sum paid to a lord as a pecuniary compensation for killinghis man (that is, his vassal, servant, or tenant). Spelman.
One who produces or creates original works of art ordecoration.
The sense by which the impressions made on the olfactory organsby the odorous particles in the atmosphere are perceived.

The matins and lauds for the last three days of Holy Week,commemorating the sufferings and death of Christ, -- usually sung onthe afternoon or evening of Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday, insteadof on the following days.
A ditch on the outside of the counterscarp, usually full ofwater.
Strengthening; supporting; corroborating. Bacon.-- n.
Neglect or omission to use an easement or franchise or toassert a right. Kent.
The faculty supposed to influence sexual desire; propensity tolove. Combe.
The envelope or coat of certain fungi, such as the puffballsand earthstars.
A person of a dull, grave, gloomy temperament. W. browne.
The art or process of making electrical measurements.
The union of three persons (the Father, the Son, and the HolyGhost) in one Godhead, so that all the three are one God as tosubstance, but three persons as to individuality.
In a mincing manner; not fully; with affected nicety.
One to whom something is presented; also, one who is presented;specifically (Eccl.), one presented to benefice. Ayliffe.
To deprive of material or physical qualities orcharacteristics.Dematerializing matter by stripping if of everything which . . . hasdistinguished matter. Milman.
A piece for one or more solo instruments with orchestra; --more concise than the concerto.
Immaterial; incorporeal; spiritual. [Obs.] Sir W. Raleigh.
Any species of Tardigrada, 2. See Illust. of Tardigrada.
An ornament much used in Egyptian architecture, generallyasserted to have been suggested by the Egyptian water lily.
Government by a patriarch, or the head of a family.
A sliding, as down a snow slope in the Alps. Tyndall.
Loaded dice so contrived as to turn up high numbers. [Obs] SirJ. Harrington.
Having a motley coat, or coat of divers colors. Shak.

The standard adopted by the Emperor Constantine after hisconversion to Christianity. It is described as a pike bearing a silkbanner hanging from a crosspiece, and surmounted by a golden crown.It bore a monogram of the first two letters (CHR) of the name ofChrist in its Greek form. Later, the name was given to variousmodifications of this standard.
An instrument formerly used for taking the altitude of theheavenly bodies, but now superseded by the quadrant and sextant; --so called because the observer turned his back to the body observed.
A bitter principle obtained from the root of the bryony(Bryonia alba and B. dioica). It is a white, or slightly colored,substance, and is emetic and cathartic.
To edify anew; to build again after destruction. [R.] Milton.
Want of confidence or trust; suspicion; distrust. Milton.
One of the rings on the top of the saddle of a harness, throughwhich the reins pass.
The act or result of balancing or adjusting; equipoise; evenadjustment of forces. [R.] Darwin.
A dwelling for a number of paupers maintained at publicexpense; an almshouse; a workhouse.
A bolt which a looped head, or an opening in the head.
Pertaining to, having the nature of, or resembling, an insect.Howell.
The song of Zacharias at the birth of John the Baptist (Luke i.68); -- so named from the first word of the Latin version.
A long-continued or excessive dilatation of the pupil of theeye.
An unmarried person; also, one opposed to marriage. Foxe.
To cover or saturate with albumen; to coat or treat with analbuminous solution; as, to albuminize paper.
Deprived or destitute of natural feelings; unnatural. [Obs.]Shak.
A theoretical aggregation of molecules constituting astructural particle of protoplasm, capable of increase or diminutionwithout change in chemical nature.
To face, as an embankment, with masonry, wood, or othermaterial.
A divalent, compound radical, CO.CH2, regarded as the essentialradical of glycolic acid, and a large series of related compounds.
in laundry work, to dry without smoothing or ironing.
A green or blue pigment produced by Peziza in certain kinds ofdecayed wood, as the beech, oak, birch, etc., and extracted as anamorphous powder resembling indigo.
A sort of pear, called also the red butter pear, from itssmooth, delicious, soft pulp.
An effusion of blood into the cavity of the pleura.
One who cultivates or keeps a nursery, or place for rearingtrees, etc.
The wiew or doctrins of the ultramontane party in the LatinChurch. Gladstone.
A dwarf tree, one in size between a shrub and a tree; atreelike shrub. Bradley.
A stone laid over, or erected near, a grave, usually with aninscription, to preserve the memory of the dead; a tombstone.
Rising spirally from right to left (of the spectator);sinistrorse.
One of the starch group (C6H10O5)n of the carbohydrates; as,starch, arabin, dextrin, cellulose, etc.
Of or pertaining to Mars, the Roman god of war, or to theplanet bearing his name; martial.
One who pretends to be wise; a wiseacre; a witling. Donne.
A horizontal graduated bar mounted on a staff, used as astadium, or telemeter, for measuring distances.
A man who violates his religious covenant. Jer. ix. 2.
To make drafts upon or against, in excess of the proper amountor limit.
Of or pertaining to prosthesis; prefixed, as a letter orletters to a word.
A contrivance, turning on a vertical axis by a handle or winch,and giving a circular motion to the ore to be washed; a stirrer.
Having the form of a shallow bowl; -- said of a corolla.
A patch; an addition; a piece put on. [Obs.] John Lewis (1731).
Pertaining to a dunghill; hence, mean; dirty; paltry. [Obs.]Howell.
A carved ornament on the stern of a vessel, containing a windowor the representation of one.
Of, pertaining to, or representing the pterygoid and quadratebones or cartilages.
Situated in front of the nose, or in front of the nasalchambers.
To deprive (a bencher) of his privileges. Mozley & W.
To bend or bow over; to bend in a contrary direction. [Obs.]Fuller.
That which goes out, or is paid out; outlay; expenditure; --the opposite of Ant: income. Lowell.
The act of disembodying, or the state of being disembodied.
To act more than is necessary; to go to excess in action. B.Jonson.
Something serving to tie or secure. [Obs.] Latimer.
Chinese conduct, art, decoration, or the like; also, a specimenof Chinese manners, art, decoration, etc.
A yellow powder, C6H3N9, obtained from certain sulphocyanates.It has acid properties and forms compounds called mellonides.
A little or insignificant dandy; a contemptible fop.
A colonnade or covered ambulatory, especially in classicalstyles of architecture; usually, a colonnade at the entrance of abuilding.

An apparatus for producing artificial respiration by pumpingoxygen or air or a mixture of the two into and out of the lungs, asof a person who has been asphyxiated by drowning, breathing poisonousgases, or the like, or of one who has been stunned by an electricalshock.
To imitate the manner of the Laconians, especially in brief,pithy speech, or in frugality and austerity.
An upholder of kingly authority; a royalist. [Obs.] Fuller.
A Mohammedan saint; especially, one who claims to work curessupernaturally.
One whose occupation is to make cabinets or other choicearticles of household furniture, as tables, bedsteads, bureaus, etc.
A morbid condition of the system resulting from excessive useof chloral.
Derived from epithelial cells and destined to become a part ofthe muscular system; -- applied to structural elements in certainembryonic forms.
The fruit of the Corylus Avellana or hazel. It is an oval nut,containing a kernel that has a mild, farinaceous, oily taste,agreeable to the palate.
A grayish white mineral occuring in tetragonal crystals and incleavable masses. It is esentially a silicate of aluminia and soda.
A goatsucker; -- so called from the peculiar noise it makeswhen darting through the air.
A lower conduit; a subterranean conduit. [Obs.] Sir H. Wotton.
The reduction of a metal from a state of combination to itsmetallic state.
Course of life; means of support; livelihood. [Obs.]
A cover; a shelter; a protection. [Archaic] Carew. C. Kingsley.
The state of being effeminate; unmanly softness. Fuller.
A plant which keeps its leaves green through the winter.
To forage for booty; to plunder. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
A Jacobite who favored the restoration of James II, oncondition of a general amnesty and of guarantees for the security ofthe civil and ecclesiastical constitution of the realm.
A medicine serving to mitigate or remove fever.-- a.

One of the stages in the life history of certain rusts(Uredinales), regarded at one time as a distinct genus. It is asummer stage preceding the teleutospore, or winter stage. SeeUredinales, in the Supplement.
The cultivation of trees and shrubs, chiefly for timber or forornamental purposes.
Covered; -- applied to seeds which have the usual integumentarycovering.
A salt of a diamino phenol, C6H3(OH)(NH2)2, used as adeveloper.
The production of stigmata upon the body. See Stigma, 8.
The act of whispering into something. [Obs.] Johnson.
A small European shrub (Daphne Mezereum), whose acrid bark isused in medicine.
An alloy of copper and zinc, resembling brass, but of a goldencolor. Ure.
The science which treats of the bones of the vertebrateskeleton.
To deprive of an endowment, as a church. Gladstone.
A form of micrococcus in which cocci are united in a binarymanner. See Micrococcus.
A genus of large malacopterygious fishes of the orderSiluroidei. They inhabit the inland waters of Europe and Asia.
The quality or relations of being immediate in manner, place,or time; exemption from second or interventing causes. Bp. Hall.
One who performs or carries into effect. See Executor.

A summer or girder extending across a building flush with, andsupporting, the upper part of a front or external wall; a longlintel; a girder; -- used principally above shop windows. [Writtenalso brestsummer and bressummer.]
An amorphous mineral of apple-green color; a hydrous silicateof nickel and magnesia. It is an important ore of nickel.
A process which, among some of the lower forms of life,precedes reproduction by budding, fission, spore formation, etc.
Undergoing the process of becoming stone; having the capacityof being converted into stone; having the quality of petrifyingbodies.
A distance lime brawn across the rink or course between themiddle line and the tee. [Scot.]
Originally, one appointed to the command of a burg (fortress orcastle); but the title afterward became hereditary, with a domainattached.
Having the quality of preserving from loss, decay, or injury.
Snobs, collectively. [Hybrid & Recent] C. Kingsley.

Any one of several species of long-legged sandpipers of thegenus Totanus, in which the legs are bright yellow; -- called alsostone snipe, tattler, telltale, yellowshanks; and yellowshins. SeeTattler, 2.
Having the nerves radiating from the base; -- said of leaves.
A slight gleam or glimmer; a glimpse. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acid,obtained by the action of acetic acid and potassium nitrite on uricacid, as a yellow crystalline substance, with a bitter, astringenttaste.
To convey by a pipe line; to furnish with a pipe line or pipelines.
A perforated steel die through which wires or tubes are drawnto form them.
Three metrical feet taken together, or included in one measure.
In a chary manner; carefully; cautiously; frugally.

A radiotelegraphic station serving solely for determining theposition of ships. The radius of operation of such stations wasrestricted by the International Radiotelegraphic Convention (1912) to30 nautical miles.

A philosophic movement of the 18th century characterized by alively questioning of authority, keen interest in matters of politicsand general culture, and an emphasis on empirical method in science.It received its impetus from the unsystematic but vigorous skepticismof Pierre Bayle, the physical doctrines of Newton, and theepistemological theories of Locke, in the preceding century. Itschief center was in France, where it gave rise to the skepticism ofVoltaire , the naturalism of Rousseau, the sensationalism ofCondillac, and the publication of the "Encyclopedia" by D'Alembertand Diderot. In Germany, Lessing, Mendelssohn, and Herder wererepresentative thinkers, while the political doctrines of the leadersof the American Revolution and the speculations of Benjamin Franklinand Thomas Paine represented the movement in America.
A kind of pseudomorph, in which there has been a change ofphysical characters without alteration of chemical composition, asthe change of aragonite to calcite.
A green poisonous substance used as a pigment and drug,obtained by the action of acetic acid on copper, and consistingessentially of a complex mixture of several basic copper acetates.
The application of a knowledge of bacteria for their detectionand identification, as in the examination of polluted water.
Ready to obey; reverent; differential; also, servilelysubmissive.
A group of birds including the common fowl and the pheasants.
One of the specially large spores of certain flowerless plants,as Selaginella, etc.
A trope, by which a speaker assumes that his hearer is apartner in his sentiments, and says we, instead of I or you. Beattie.
The act or process of producing schiller in a mineral mass.
A solid unctuous material, of which candles are made.
Any animal which eats flesh, especially any carnivorousmarsupial.
The state or practice of an athlete; the characteristics of anathlete.
Consisting of, or resembling, fat or oil; oily; unctuous;oleaginous.

Any one of several fungus diseases, caused by parasitic speciesof the series Melanconiales, attacking the bean, grape, melon,cotton, and other plants. In the case of the grape, brown concavespots are formed on the stem and fruit, and the disease is calledbird's-eye rot.
A captain, leader, or commander; a chief; the head of a troop,army, or clan.

A complex nitrogenous substance obtained from murexide,alloxantin, and other ureids, as a white, or yellowish, crystallinewhich turns red on exposure to the air; -- called also uramil,dialuramide, and formerly purpuric acid.
Situated in front of the bronchus; -- applied especially to anair sac on either side of the esophagus of birds.
A festival commemorative of the founding of a city or theconsecration of a church; also, the ceremonies (as at Oxford andCambridge, England) commemorative of founders or benefactors.
A plant from which layers are propagated by bending itsbranches into the soil. P. Henderson.
A disease in hawks, characterized by the presence of smallthreadlike worms, also of filaments of coagulated blood, from therupture of a vein; -- called also backworm. Sir T. Browne.
A Mexican shrub (Euphorbia pulcherrima) with very large andconspicuous vermilion bracts below the yellowish flowers.
An instrument for ascertaining the amount of rainfall at anyplace in a given time; a rain gauge.
An apparatus for determining the amount of nitrogen or some ofits compounds in any substance subjected to analysis; an azotometer.
Combined, or impregnated, with nitric acid, or some of itscompounds.
Having a hard albumen penetrated by irregular channels filledwith softer matter, as the nutmeg and the seeds of the North Americanpapaw.
A division of birds including the geese, ducks, and closelyallied forms.
Produced by the conversion of the stamens into petals, asdouble flowers, like the garden ranunculus. Brande.
A walking abroad; a promenading. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
Having stamens joined by filaments into three bundles. SeeIllust. under Adelphous.
The fore part of the night last past; the previous evening.[R.] Shak.
A stitch in which the looping of the thread or threads forms achain on the under side of the work; the loop stitch, asdistinguished from the lock stitch. See Stitch.
An extinct genus of brachiopods, very characteristic of theCarboniferous rocks.

The figure inclosed by lines through the points contact of thewheels of a vehicle, etc., with the surface or rails on which theyrun; more esp., the length of this figure between the points ofcontact of the two extreme wheels on either side.
The act of consigning or sending property to an agent orcorrespondent in another place, as for care, sale, etc.
The quality or state of being precious; costliness; dearness.
A district from which a Zaim draws his revenue. Smart.
Crystallized cawk, in which the crystals are small.
Any bat of the genus Phyllostoma, or allied genera, havinglarge membranes around the mouth and nose; a nose-leaf bat.
The conversion of a fruit juice or other saccharine solutioninto alcohol by fermentation.
A processive wasting or melting away of the solid parts of theanimal system with copious excretions of liquids by one or morepassages. [Obs.]
A making thick or viscous; thickness; inspissation. [R.] Dr. H.More.
A word letter; a phonogram, that, for the sake of brevity,represents a word; as, |, i. e., t, for it. Cf. Grammalogue.
A textile fabric with a nap or shag on one side, longer andsofter than the nap of velvet. Cowper.
State of being aseptic; the methods or processes ofasepticizing.
A division of amphipod Crustacea, in which the abdomen is smallor rudimentary and the legs are often reduced to five pairs. Thewhale louse, or Cyamus, and Caprella are examples.
Professional cant; the chatter of conjurers to divert attentionfrom their tricks; hence, jugglery. [Colloq.]
Similar and probably related motion of the stars of anasterism, as distinguished from apparent change of place due to solarmotion.-- ## = star streaming --
One who deals in flesh; hence, a pimp; a procurer; a pander.[R.] Shak.
Any plant of the labiate genus Scutellaria, the calyx of whoseflower appears, when inverted, like a helmet with the visor raised.
The act of disenchanting, or state of being disenchanted.Shelton.
Compression, especially constriction of vessels by an externalcause.
One who dives under water in search of something, as forpearls; a diver. [R.] Ray.
Honored for a long time; venerable, and worthy of honor, byreason of antiquity, or long continuance.
To expel from the bar, or the legal profession; to deprive (anattorney, barrister, or counselor) of his status and privileges assuch. Abbott.
The quality of being changeable; fickleness; inconstancy;mutability.
A vinegar cup; socket of the hip bone; a measure of about oneeighth of a pint, etc.
Property given, usually by a parent to a child, in advance of afuture distribution.
Full of humps or bunches; covered with protuberances; humped.
Pertaining to, or designating, a monobasic acid, HPO3,analogous to nitric acid, and, by heating phosphoric acid, obtainedas a crystalline substance, commonly called glacial phosphoric acid.
The taking of a lesser number or quantity from a greater of thesame kind or denomination; an operation for finding the differencebetween two numbers or quantities.
The act of bending the knee, particularly in worship. Bp.Stillingfleet.
The work of the painter; also, any work of art in which objectsare represented in color on a flat surface; a colored representationof any object or scene; a picture.
Of or pertaining to Thalia; hence, of or pertaining to comedy;comic.
Same as Correspondence, 3.The correspondencies of types and antitypes . . . may be veryreasonable confirmations. S. Clarke.
A genus of shrubs or perennial herbs including the meadowsweetand the hardhack.
The diagonal or lateral axis in a monoclinic crystal which isat right angles with the vertical axis.
The structure which unites together the ascidiozooids in acompound ascidian.
The pagan lands; pagans, collectively; paganism. [R.]
One versed in the niceties of academical disputation or ofschool divinity.
In a nominal manner; by name; in name only; not in reality.Burke.
One who appraises; esp., a person appointed and sworn toestimate and fix the value of goods or estates.
A minute particular; a small or minor detail; -- used chieflyin the plural.
A green foliated kind of amphibole, observed in eclogite andsome varietis of gabbro.
Tending to pull asunder, tear, or rend; distracting.
A prickly, climbing shrub of the genus Pisonia. The fruit is akind of berry.
A kind of boat of various forms, used in the IndianArchipelago.
The first university examination; -- called also little go. Seeunder Little, a.
The typical pentadactyloid limb of the higher vertebrates.
The act of betrothing, or the state of being betrothed;betrothal.
Lint; esp., lint made into a tent for insertion into wounds orulcers.

An adjustable diaphragm, suggesting the iris of the eye in itsaction, for regulating the aperture of a lens, consisting of a numberof thin pieces fastened to a ring. It is used in cameras andmicroscopes.
A contraction of two syllables into one; synizesis.
Corn of grain of which bread is made, as wheat, rye, etc.
A colorless oil obtained from hemp dy distillation, andpossessing its intoxicating properties.
A nephoscope registering by photography, commonly consisting ofa pair of cameras used simultaneously.
A carpentry obstruction, stockade, or other obstacle made in apassage in order to stop an enemy.
A silver coin of Portugal, worth about sixpence sterling, orabout eleven cents. Homans.
Diminished in value; dishonored; degraded. [R.] Shak.
A genus of climbing orchidaceous plants natives of tropicalAmerica.
A jet of steam issuing from a fissure in the earth.
Calcium oxalate, occurring in colorless or white monocliniccrystals.
The stoker or fireman of a furnace, as in glass works.Tomlinson.
To cover, as a corpse, with a mound or tomb; to bury. [Obs.]
One who overlays; that with which anything is overlaid.
Pertaining to the circumference; encompassing; encircling;circuitous. Parkhurst.
To mingle; to mix; to unite; to blend. [R.] Thomson.
A kind of buttress of masonry to strengthen a revetment wall.
Capable of being cut smoothly; scissible. [R.] Arbuthnot.
A sulphide of antimony and silver of an iron-black color andmetallic luster; called also black silver, and brittle silver ore.
A pupil; especially, a graduate of a college or other seminaryof learning.
The act of refashioning, or the state of being refashioned.[R.] Leigh Hunt.
The person to whom another is bound, or the person to whom abond is given. Blackstone.
An African sapotaceous tree (Bassia, or Butyrospermum, Parkii),from the seeds of which a substance resembling butter is obtained;the African butter tree.
A bract on the stalk of a single flower, which is itself on amain stalk that support several flowers. Gray.
A California fish (Hemilepidotus spinosus), allied to thesculpin.
Tending to cause perturbation; disturbing. Sir J. Herschel.
Having fine supported by spinous fin rays; -- said of certainfishes.
A method or practice of the administration of the sacrament bydipping the bread or wafer in the wine and administering bothtogether.
An orthographic projection of the sphere on the plane of themeridian, the eye being supposed at an infinite distance, and in theeast or west point of the horizon.
The act or art of dealing in stocks; the business of astockjobber.
An armed constable; also, a government servant or courier.[Turkey]

A large genus of evergreen coniferous trees, mostly found inthe northern hemisphere. The genus formerly included the firs,spruces, larches, and hemlocks, but is now limited to those treeswhich have the primary leaves of the branchlets reduced to merescales, and the secondary ones (pine needles) acicular, and usuallyin fascicles of two to seven. See Pine.
One who stands near; one who is present; a bystander.
A group of nudibranch mollusks without special gills.
Composed of solitary parts, as a flower with one sepal, onepetal, one stamen, and one pistil.
The position of a candidate; state of being a candidate;candidateship.
To cause to become like the Europeans in manners or character;to habituate or accustom to European usages.A state of society . . . changed and Europenized. Lubbock.
Working smoothly, or without splitting; -- said of timber.
An alloy resembling silver, and consisting chiefly of copper,zinc, and nickel, with small proportions of tin, aluminium, andbismuth. Ure.
Relating to, or made by means of, the electroscope.
An image or representation; a form; a phantom; an apparition.Sir W. Scott.
A kind of catchfly (Silene inflata) which is sometimes frothyfrom the action of captured insects.
A name given by miners to George Stephenson's safety lamp.Raymond.
The property of radiant energy (found chiefly in solar orelectric light) by which chemical changes are produced, as inphotography.
Of, pertaining to, or denoting, those rays of light whichproduce chemical effects; actinic. [R.]
A supposed element, afterward found to be a mixture of severalmetals, as copper, iron, lead, nickel, etc.
The operation of puncturing the chest wall so as to let outliquids contained in the cavity of the chest.
A wheel-like joint of the stem of a fossil crinoid.
One who carries the armor or arms of another; an armiger. Judg.ix. 54.
An instrument for exhibiting the repulsive action produced bylight or heat in an exhausted vessel; a modification of theradoimeter. W. Crookes.
A shilling sterling, being about twenty-four cents.
Having all the flowers of a plant alike in respect to thestamens and pistils.
The division of mankind which embraces the smooth-haired races.
Having a roof, or top, shaped like an inverted U; wagon-headed.
One who examines the sheets of a book that has just beenprinted, to ascertain whether they are correctly printed, paged, etc.[Eng.]
A sea view; -- distinguished from landscape. [Jocose] Fairholt.

A system of characters invented by Prof. Alexander MelvilleBell to represent all sounds that may be uttered by the speechorgans, and intended to be suggestive of the position of the organsof speech in uttering them.
To consider by a separate act of attention or analysis. Sir W.Hamilton.
The doctrine that the universe, taken or conceived of as awhole, is God; the doctrine that there is no God but the combinedforce and laws which are manifested in the existing universe;cosmotheism.
People of rank and fashion; the class of swells, collectively.[Jocose]
A variety of enstatite, often having a bronzelike luster. It isa silicate of magnesia and iron, of the pyroxene family.
To exceed in duration; to survive; to endure longer than.Milton.
One who skulks, or keeps out of sight; hence, a truant; anidler; a thief, etc. [Obs.] Shak.
A Turkish official; one of the dominant tribe of Turks;loosely, any Turk.
The state of being enravished or enraptured; ecstasy; rapture.Glanvill.
In being; actually existing; -- distinguished from in posse, orin potentia, which denote that a thing is not, but may be.
The title of an incarnation of self-abnegation, virtue, andwisdom, or a deified religious teacher of the Buddhists, esp. GautamaSiddartha or Sakya Sinha (or Muni), the founder of Buddhism.
The adaptation or adjustment of parts to each other, as of abroken bone or dislocated joint.
Something requiring much care and expense and yielding littleprofit; any burdensome possession. [Slang]
Of or pertaining to the setting sun; falling; descending;western.
A flowing; also, a hostile incursion. [Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
A little Greek, or one of small esteem or pretensions. B.Jonson.
Unarmed; destitute of prickles or thorns, as a leaf. Gray.
An enlargement or protrusion of the mucous membrane of thelachrymal passages, or dropsy of the lachrymal sac, dependent uponcatarrhal inflammation of the latter. Dunglison.

A poisonous alkaloid obtained from the root hellebore(Veratrum) and from sabadilla seeds as a white crystalline powder,having an acrid, burning taste. It is sometimes used externally, asin ointments, in the local treatment of neuralgia and rheumatism.Called also veratria, and veratrina.
A livid, or black and blue, mark; a blow; a bruise.
A bully or braggadocio; a swaggering, boastful fellow; aswaggerer. Milton.
A small tube, usually curved, applied to a trumpet, horn, etc.,to change its pitch or key.
To give by will; -- used of real estate; formerly, also, ofchattels.
The act, process, or result of salifying; the state of beingsalified.
A short, upright piece of timber in framing; a short post; anintermediate stud. Oxf. Gloss.
One who believes in the law of universal causation.
A viverrine mammal of Madagascar (Eupleres Goudotii), allied tothe civet; -- called also Falanouc.
To wander in a wrong path; to stray; to go astray. [Obs.]Chaucer.
The arrangement of a body of troops, as in a square, column,etc. Farrow.

To invest or clothe again with some right, authority, ordignity; to restore to a former capacity; to reinstate; to qualifyagain; to restore, as a delinquent, to a former right, rank, orprivilege lost or forfeited; -- a term of civil and canon law.Restoring and rehabilitating the party. Burke.

Characterizing that kind of reasoning which deducesconsequences from definitions formed, or principles assumed, or whichinfers effects from causes previously known; deductive ordeductively. The reverse of a posteriori.

The quality or state of being seedy, shabby, or worn out; astate of wretchedness or exhaustion. [Colloq.] G. Eliot.What is called seedness, after a debauch, is a plain proof thatnature has been outraged. J. S. Blackie.
Having the difference marked; distinguished by certain tokens.Bacon.
A light oily hydrocarbon, C14H30, of the marsh-gas series; --so called from the fourteen carbon atoms in the molecule.
An alkaloid obtained from the leaves of an Australian tree(Duboisia myoporoides), and regarded as identical with hyoscyamine.It produces dilation of the pupil of the eye.
One who, or that which, heartens, animates, or stirs up. W.Browne.
The transmission of a disease from one person to another, bydirect or indirect contact.
The navigable part of a river, bay, etc., through which vesselsenter or depart; the part of a harbor or channel ehich is kept openand unobstructed for the passage of vessels. Totten. the rough.
One of the French Protestant insurgents who rebelled againstLouis XIV, after the revocation of the edict of Nates; -- so calledfrom the peasant's smock (camise) which they wore.
A marine univalve shell of the genus Bulla and allied genera,belonging to the Tectibranchiata.
A nitrogenous organic base from coal tar, and identical withquinoline. Cf. Quinoline.
The matter composing the nucleus of a cell; the protoplasm ofthe nucleus; karyoplasma.
An opinionated person; one given to conjecture. [Obs.] South.
Having the margin dentate and also ciliate or fringed withhairs.
The amount of illumination produced by a standard candle at adistance of one foot.
To render insecure; to put in danger. [Obs.] Fanshawe.
The state of being a boy; the time during which one is a boy.Hood.
Of or pertaining to the Necrophaga; eating carrion. SeeNecrophagan.
To induce hypnotism in; to place in a state of hypnotism.
Giving a name; naming; designating; -- said of that case orform of a noun which stands as the subject of a finite verb.-- n.
One who is rigorous; -- sometimes applied to an extremeJansenist.
The act of analyzing, or separating into constituent parts;analysis.
To ween amiss; to misjudge; to distrust; to be mistaken. [Obs.]Spenser.
Inserted below the pistil or pistils; -- said of sepals,petals, and stamens; having the sepals, petals, and stamens insertedbelow the pistil; -- said of a flower or a plant. Gray.
Yielding gelatin on boiling with water; capable ofgelatination.
An itinerant licensed dealer in commodities used for food; ahawker; a huckster; -- formerly applied especially to one who boughtgrain in one place and sold it in another. [Now dialectic, Eng.]
Act of enlightening, or the state of being enlightened orinstructed.
Fixed position; stable condition; firmness. [Obs.] Shak.
Of or pertaining to lentigo; freckly; scurfy; furfuraceous.

A formal allegation or charge against a party made or presentedto the appropriate court or officer, as for a wrong done or a crimecommitted (in the latter case, generally under oath); an information;accusation; the initial bill in proceedings in equity.
A strong or sweet scent. [Obs. & Illegitimate.] Sir T. Herbert.
An intermediate agent; a broker; a procurer; -- usually in adisparaging sense. Shak.
Inferior ore, separated from the better by cobbing. Raymond.
To go into or reside in the country; to ruralize. Pope.
To card coarsely; to run through the scribling machine.
The act of focalizing or bringing to a focus, or the state ofbeing focalized.
A genus of plant-eating beetles, including the potato beetle.See Potato beetle.
One of the radial segments composing the body of one of theCoelenterata.
The substance which, added to the material of a cell wall,makes it waterproof, as in cork.
The complex, nitrogenous, organic base and dyestuff called alsoaniline black.
The association of a number of persons for their benefit.
Situated below the eyes, as the antenna of certain insects.
The act of eloping; secret departure; -- said of a woman and aman, one or both, who run away from their homes for marriage or forcohabitation.
That with which one dabs; hence, a pad or other device used byprinters, engravers, etc., as for dabbing type or engraved plateswith ink.
Anything alleged in pleading which is impertinent, and isreproachful to any person, or which derogates from the dignity of thecourt, or is contrary to good manners. Daniell.
Something to preserve memory; a reminder; a monument; hence, amark; an image; a superscription; a record. [Obs.] Spenser.
An instrument for examining the capillary vessels of animalsand plants. Morin.
A house appropriated for the use of the poor; a poorhouse.
Want of retaining power; forgetfulness. De Quincey.
The celebration of the hundredth anniversary of any event; acentenary. [U. S.]
Any bird that frequents the water, or lives about rivers,lakes, etc., or on or near the sea; an aquatic fowl; -- used alsocollectively.
A scallion; a leek or small onion. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Having but one set of teeth; -- opposed to diphyodont.
Wattles, or hurdles, made with stakes interwoven with osiers,to cover lodgments. [Obs.]
The quality or condition of one who thrives; prosperity;growth; increase.
Received into some other thing or part, as a sword into asheath; invaginated.
A rich variety of new cheese, resembling butter, but white.Halliwell.
Grass and sprigs beaten or trampled down by a stag passingthrough them. Crabb.
A disease characterized by livid spots on the skin fromextravasated blood, with loss of muscular strength, pain in thelimbs, and mental dejection; the purples. Dunglison.
Of or pertaining to fratricide; of the nature of fratricide.
The instrument or medium used to effect chemical dialysis.
One who patters, or talks glibly; specifically, a streetpeddler. [Cant, Eng.]
Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid obtainedfrom a lichen (Cetraria vulpina) as a yellow or red crystallinesubstance which on decomposition yields pulvinic acid.
The quality of being religious; religious feeling or sentiment;religiousness. [R.] M. Arnold.
A dynamite composed of nitroglycerin (30 parts), sodium nitrate(52.5), charcoal (10.5), and sulphur (7), used in mining andblasting.
The malicious burning of a dwelling house or outhouse ofanother man, which by the common law is felony; the malicious andvoluntary firing of a building or ship. Wharton.
Of or pertaining to the odometer, or to measurements made withit.

A straight line in space with which a definite linear magnitudetermed the pitch is associated (cf. 5th Pitch, 10 (b)). It is used toexpress the displacement of a rigid body, which may always be made toconsist of a rotation about an axis combined with a translationparallel to that axis.
A tropical plant (Cajanus indicus) and its edible seed, a kindof pulse; -- so called from Angola in Western Africa. Called alsopigeon pea and Congo pea.
Polite or elegant literature; the humanities; -- used somewhatvaguely for literary works in which imagination and taste arepredominant.
An avoiding or escaping; also, a warning. [Obs.] Bailey.
A genus of tropical corals, usually branched, and having a veryvolid texture.
Consisting in, or accompanied by, undulations; undulatory.
The cry of cats; a harsh, disagreeable noise or cry like thecry of cats. Shak.
Representing the whole figure; -- said of a picture or statue.-- n.
A rope or halter made of flexible twigs, or withes, as ofbirch. [Scot.]
The quality or state of being poor (in any of the senses of theadjective). Bacon.
The art or operation of carving figures or inscriptions on rockor stone.
The basal substance of the cell nucleus; a hyaline or granularsubstance, more or less fluid during life, in which the other partsof the nucleus are imbedded.
Failure or omission of duty; a fault; a misdeed; an offense; amisdemeanor; a crime.The delinquencies of the little commonwealth would be represented inthe most glaring colors. Motley.
The expression of spoken sounds by an alphabet. Encyc. Brit.

A genus of very large marine bivalve shells found on the coralreefs of the Indian and Pacific Oceans. One species (T. gigas) oftenweighs four or five hundred pounds, and is sometimes used forbaptismal fonts. Called also paw shell, and fountain shell.
One who deliberately puts an end to his own existence, or loseshis life while engaged in the commission of an unlawful or maliciousact; a suicide. Burrill.
The point on the side of the skull where the temporal line, orupper edge of the temporal fossa, crosses the coronal suture.
A modification of the kaleidophon, for showing composition ofacoustic vibrations. It consists of two thin slips of steel weldedtogether, their length being adjystable by a screw socket.
The common beam tree of England (Pyrus Aria); -- so called fromthe white, woolly under surface of the leaves.
The state of being bereaved; deprivation; esp., the loss of arelative by death.
To place one's self; to take up one's residence; to settle.[Colloq.]
The state of being pagan; pagan characteristics; esp., theworship of idols or false gods, or the system of religious opinionsand worship maintained by pagans; heathenism.
Any one of a group of maioid crabs remarkable for the length oftheir legs; -- called also spider crab.
A performer on a musical instrument; an instrumentalist.
A thick, heavy knife with a hooked point, used in pruninghedges, etc. When it has a short handle, it is sometimes called ahand bill; when the handle is long, a hedge bill or scimiter.
The act of stripping, or depriving; the state of beingdivested; the deprivation, or surrender, of possession of property,rights, etc.
A description or plan of the heavens and the heavenly bodies;the construction of celestial maps, globes, etc.; uranology.
The room occupied by the guard during its term of duty; also, aroom where prisoners are confined.
The time of remaining in the nest. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Having an imperfect or interrupted columnar structure.
To affirm something of another thing; to make an affirmation.Sir M. Hale.
The part of the framing of a railway car or truck, by which anaxle box is held laterally, and in which it may move vertically; --also called a jaw in the United States, and a housing in England.
The act of indoctrinating, or the condition of beingindoctrinated; instruction in the rudiments and principles of anyscience or system of belief; information. Sir T. Browne.
The character, personality, or office of a hostess. Shak.
The state or condition of a cousin; also, the collective bodyof cousins; kinsfolk.
An animal, probably the hippopotamus, described in Job xl. 15-24.
Comprised in, or like, a point; exact. [Obs. & R.] Sir T.Browne.
A kind of soft French cream cheese; -- so called from thedistrict in France where it is made; --called also fromage de Brie.
(Physiol.) A substance formed by a katabolic process; --opposed to anastate. See Katabolic.
Of or pertaining to a heptarchy; constituting or consisting ofa heptarchy. T. Warton.
Admitting an atonement; capable of being atoned for; expiable.
One who accepts the astronomical system of Ptolemy.
Those insects which have a complete metamorphosis; metabola.
The condition of increased irritability of a nerve in theregion of the cathode or negative electrode, on the passage of acurrent of electricity through it.
The god of the great outer sea, or the river which was believedto flow around the whole earth.
A mark (!) used to indicate an exclamation. G. Brown.
To subject to such reactions or processes that diazo compounds,or their derivatives, shall be produced by chemical exchange orsubstitution.
A red resin forming the essential basis of dragon's blood; --called also dracin.
A genus of bacteria, characterized by having their filamentsvery long, slender, and indistinctly articulated.
A place where things are preserved; a repository. [R.] Sir M.Hale.
Capable of being formed into glass; tending to become glass.
One who practices or advocates polygyny. H. Spenser.
The great flexor muscle of the hip joint, divisible into twoparts, the iliac and great psoas, -- often regarded as distinctmuscles.
The quality of being courtly; elegance or dignity of manners.
A festival celebrated annually by the Romans on February 23 inhonor of Terminus, the god of boundaries.
To sink from a swollen state; to subside. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A poisonous glucoside accompanying helleborin in severalspecies of hellebore, and extracted as a white crystalline substancewith a bittersweet taste. It has a strong action on the heart,resembling digitalin.
Having a straight shaft with whorls of spines; -- said ofcertain sponge spicules. See Illust. under Spicule.
One who does business in the way of barter or exchange.
A writer of memoirs of religious persona, as examples ofChristian excellence.
The state of being domestic; domestic character; householdlife.
The act or process of intensifying; intensification; climax.[R.] Carlyle.
One who talks in the same strain or on the same subject untilweariness is produced. Richardson.
A rent of the full annual value of the tenement, or near it; anexcessive or unreasonably high rent. Blackstone.
A plant found growing in salt marshes, or in the sea.
A substance resembling inulin, found in the unripe bulbs of thedahila.
The struggle in the rush lines after the ball is put in play.
Armor for the arm; -- generally used for the whole arm from theshoulder to the wrist, and consisting, in the 15th and 16thcenturies, of many parts.
Smooth; having a surface without hairs or any unevenness.
The act of transmeating; a passing through or beyond. [Obs.]
Endowed with grace; beautiful; full of graces; honorable. Shak.
A woman who betrays her country or any trust; a traitoress.Dryden.

An Indian of a linguistic stock of tribes of the Peruvian coastwho had a developed agricultural civilization at the advent of theSpaniards, before which they had been conquered by the Incas. Theyconstructed irrigation canals which are still in use, adorned theirbuildings with bas-reliefs and frescoes, and were skilled goldsmithsand silversmiths. -- Yun"can (#), a.
The office, or the term of office, of a dictator; hence,absolute power.

Lit., world view; a conception of the course of events in, andof the purpose of, the world as a whole, forming a philosophical viewor apprehension of the universe; the general idea embodied in acosmology.
A soft white alloy of variable composition (as a nine parts oftin to one of copper, or of fifty parts of tin to five of antimonyand one of copper) used in bearings to diminish friction.
Yielding free gold or silver; -- said of certain ores which canbe reduced by crushing and amalgamation, without roasting or otherchemical treatment. Raymond.

Overlapping; contorted; convolute; -- applied primarily, inbotany, to two opposite leaves, each of which has one edgeoverlapping the nearest edge of the other, and secondarily to acircle of several leaves or petals which thus overlap.
One of the chiefs or pontiffs of the Roman province of Asia,who had the superintendence of the public games and religious rites.Milner.
Involving, or pertaining to, routine; ordinary; customary. [R.]Emerson.
One who treats sacred things with irreverence, or defiles whatis holy; one who uses profane language. Hooker.
A long carriage, with a calash top, so constructed as to givespace for reclining at night, when used on a journey.
The quality or state of being scurvy; vileness; meanness.
To throw sticls at cocks; to throw anything about awkwardly orirregularly. [Prov. Eng.] Southey.
A kind of oil cake prepared from the cocoanut. See Oil cake,under Cake.
A vessel with thirty banks of oars, or, as some say, thirtyranks of rowers.
To fall off from the wind; to edge away to leeward; -- saidonly of inferior craft.

Antimony hydride, or hydrogen antimonide, a colorless gasproduced by the action of nascent hydrogen on antimony. It has acharacteristic odor and burns with a characteristic greenish flame.Formerly called also antimoniureted hydrogen.
That part of a landscape which recedes from the spectator intodistance. [R.] Fairholt.
Having the orb or disk complete or fully illuminated; like thefull moon.
A glucoside found in the flowers of a plant (Murraya exotica)of South Asia, and extracted as a white amorphous slightly bittersubstance.
A chair with arms to support the elbows or forearms. Tennyson.
A modern term applied to animals (as a boar) when borne asraging, or with furious aspect.
An offering or oblation heaved up or elevated before the altar,as the shoulder of the peace offering. See Wave offering. Ex. xxix.27.
A loose hydrated form of silica, a variety of opal, depositedin concretionary cauliflowerlike masses, around some hot springs andgeysers.
A collection of particles or bodies into one mass; a heap; anaggregation.
An order of knights holding a middle place between the senateand the commonalty; members of the Roman equestrian order.
A kind of breechloading, center-fire rifle, or improved needlegun.
A bromide having a higher proportion of bromine than any otherbromide of the same substance or series.
Of or pertaining to the epoch, or the deposits, following theTertiary, and immediately preceding man.-- n.
A collection of small projectiles, inclosed in a case orcanister.

To prevent from centralizing; to cause to withdraw from thecenter or place of concentration; to divide and distribute (what hasbeen united or concentrated); -- esp. said of authority, or theadministration of public affairs.
A resinous substance formed in the decomposition of cholic acidof bile; -- so called because it is difficult to solve.

An instrument for recording and reproducing sound by localmagnetization of a steel wire, disk, or ribbon, moved against thepole of a magnet connected electrically with a telephone receiver, orthe like.
A white crystalline substance obtained by dehydration ofsalicylic acid.
Of or pertaining to divination by means of the stars;astrologic. [R.] Dr. H. More.
A friar of a mendicant order (the Order of Our Lady of MountCarmel) established on Mount Carmel, in Syria, in the twelfthcentury; a White Friar.
An instrument for measuring the magnifying power of a lens orsystem of lenses.
Having a round back or shoulders; round-shouldered.

A disease which is very destructive to silkworms, and whichsometimes extends to other insects. It is attended by the developmentof a fungus (provisionally called Botrytis bassiana). Also, thefungus itself.
That art or operation of measuring the inclination of strata.
The territory without the walls, but within the legal limits,of a town or city. Brande & C.
A ceremonial treatise related to Puranic and magic literature;esp., one of the sacred works of the worshipers of Sakti. -- Tan"tric(-trik), a.
One born within hearing distance of Bow-bells; a cockney.Halliwell.
Having short intervals between the joints; -- said of a plantor an animal, especially of a horse whose pastern is too short.
The operation of supersaturating, or the state of beingsupersaturated.
To ordain again, as when the first ordination is considereddefective. Bp. Burnet.
Not warranted; being without warrant, authority, or guaranty;unwarrantable.
In echinoderms, one of the areas or zones intervening betweentwo ambulacra. See Illust. of Ambulacrum.
The science or art of comparing or measuring degrees ofmoisture. Evelyn.
In a polary manner; with polarity. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
The examination of coins, and the separation of the good fromthe debased. [East Indies]
The quality or condition of being impassible; insusceptibilityof injury from external things.
Prevention of sepsis by excluding or destroying microorganisms.
Capable of being inquired into; subject or liable toinquisition or inquest. Bacon.
A secret name; a name by which a person is known only to theinitiated.
To make supposition; to think; to be of opinion. Acts ii. 15.
The endmost plank of a strake which stops short of the stem orstern.

A kind of short cannon, formerly in use, designed to throw alarge projectile with small velocity, used for the purpose ofbreaking or smashing in, rather than piercing, the object aimed at,as the side of a ship. It has no trunnions, but is supported on itscarriage by a bolt passing through a loop on its under side.
The state or quality of a goody or goodwife [Jocose] Hudibraus.
A genus of dipterous insects, including the gnat and mosquito.
A glow of refulgence in the western sky after sunset.
The rust of any metal, esp. of brass or copper; verdigris.
Having power to resolve; causing solution; solvent.
One pretending to perfection; esp., one pretending to moralperfection; one who believes that persons may and do attain to moralperfection and sinlessness in this life. South.
The assimilation by one body or organism of the elements ofanother.
To interpret erroneously; to understand or to explain in awrong sense.
The large lobe of the hind brain in front of and above themedulla; the little brain. It controls combined muscular action. SeeBrain.
One who, or that which, ravages or lays waste; spoiler.
A couple of verses or poetic lines making complete sense; anepigram of two verses.
One who is versed in or treats of ontology. Edin. Rev.
One who, or that which, neutralizes; that which destroys,disguises, or renders inert the peculiar properties of a body.
An order of Infusoria, having one or two long, whiplike cilia,at the anterior end. It includes monads. See Infusoria, and Monad.
Barren land having only a thin coat of grass. [Prov. Eng.]
One who prospects; especially, one who explores a region forminerals and precious metals.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a large family of plants ofwhich the sedge is the type.
A jerk or kick produced by a blow or sudden strain upon thepatellar tendon of the knee, which causes a sudden contraction of thequadriceps muscle.
The quality or state of being inscrutable; inscrutability.
Of or pertaining to an idealogue, or to idealization.
Serving of tending to evacuate; cathartic; purgative.
A wading bird of the genus Numenius, remarkable for its long,slender, curved bill.
A side work, made of gabions, fascines, or bags, filled withearth, or of earth heaped up, to afford cover from the flanking fireof an enemy.
In a state of slimness; in a slim manner; slenderly.
A bird of Europe (Fringilla coelebs), having a variety of verysweet songs, and highly valued as a cage bird; -- called also copperfinch.

Filled or saturated with water so as to be heavy, unmanageable,or loglike; -- said of a vessel, when, by receiving a great quantityof water into her hold, she has become so heavy as not to bemanageable by the helm.
The resistance of a horse, that interrupts his cadence and themeasure of his manege, occasioned by a bad horseman, or the badtemper of the horse.
A stiff cotton fabric used by milliners for lining bonnets.
Bearing or producing berries; bacciferous; as, cocciferroustrees or plants.
The state or quality of being incorporeal or bodiless;immateriality; incorporealism. G. Eliot.
One who edits or writes for a magazine. [R.] Goldsmith.
The more transparent cells, which finally become external, inmany segmenting ova, as those of mammals.
The state or quality of being inclinable; inclination.
A signal call on a trumpet or cornet for entrance or exit onthe stage. [Obs.]
A friar who acted as porter at the gate of a monastery. Sir W.Scott.
A complex derivative of cyanogen, regarded as an acid, andknown chiefly in its salts; -- called also hydromellonic acid.
The art of selecting and combining the stops or registers of anorgan.
Having the quality of recrimination; retorting accusation;recriminating.

The vassal or tenant of a baron; one who held under a baron,and who also had tenants under him; one in dignity next to a baron; atitle of dignity next to a baron. Burrill. "A worthy vavasour."Chaucer. [Also written vavasour, vavassor, valvasor, etc.]Vavasours subdivide again to vassals, exchanging land and cattle,human or otherwise, against fealty. Motley.

Any one of numerous species of small fishes of the genusGasterosteus and allied genera. The back is armed with two or moresharp spines. They inhabit both salt and brackish water, andconstruct curious nests. Called also sticklebag, sharpling, andprickleback.
To make a judicial decision; to decide; to determine. [R.]Hales.
The head or chief of a tithing, or borough (see 2d Borough);the headborough; a parish constable. Spelman.
A kind of fungus of the genus Phallus, which emits a fetidodor.
A body formed from albumin by pancreatic and gastric digestion.It is convertible into antipeptone.
Want or failure of importation; a not importing of commodities.
A weak base identical with betaine; -- so called because foundin the boxthorn (Lycium barbarum). See Betaine.
To retract, as what has been spoken; to recant; to unsay. [R.]Shak.
A sulcus parallel to, but some distance below, the horizontallimb of the fissure of Sylvius.
The act of budding again; the state of having budded again.
The faculty supposed to impel to the commission of acts ofdestruction; propensity to destroy.
A California market fish (Pomancentrus rubicundus) of a deepscarlet color.
To pour from one vessel into another; to transfuse. [Obs.]Barrow.
Having one the same appearance; having a mutual resemblance.
A kind of figured stone, rugged and beset with eminences,anciently used in divination. [Obs.] Encyc. Brit.
Resembling, or pertaining to, the Crotalidae, or Rattlesnakefamily.
Hoisted as high as the tackle will admit; brought closetogether, as the two blocks of a tackle in hoisting.
A translucent mineral of a green color and pearly or vitreousluster. It is a hydrous arseniate of copper.
Act of disporting; diversion; play. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
To interrogate again; to question repeatedly. Cotgrave.
A product of human workmanship; -- applied esp. to the simplerproducts of aboriginal art as distinguished from natural objects.

A bow or arch exhibiting, in concentric bands, the severalcolors of the spectrum, and formed in the part of the hemisphereopposite to the sun by the refraction and reflection of the sun'srays in drops of falling rain.

One of the orders of myriapods, including the centipeds. Theyhave a single pair of elongated legs attached laterally to eachsegment; well developed jaws; and a pair of thoracic legs convertedinto poison fangs. They are insectivorous, very active, and somespecies grow to the length of a foot.

A violent storm, often of vast extent, characterized by highwinds rotating about a calm center of low atmospheric pressure. Thiscenter moves onward, often with a velocity of twenty or thirty milesan hour.
The act of deploring or lamenting; lamentation. Speed.
An aneroid barometer having a second scale that gives theapproximate elevation above sea level of the place where theobservation is made.
Of or pertaining to clothing; wearing clothes. Ld. Lytton.
An extinct order of Mesozoic marine reptiles including thegenera Plesiosaurus, and allied forms; -- called also Sauropterygia.
The act of unsettling, or the state of being unsettled.Marvell.
Of or pertaining to a septum or septa, as of a coral or ashell.
An instrument for measuring the height of objects. Knight.
A silly, pert girl; -- corresponding to jackanapes. Massinger.
To collect, and reduce to order, as troops dispersed or throwninto confusion; to gather again; to reunite.
A general fire; a conflagration. [Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
An inflammation and swelling of the soft parts of the roof ofthe mouth immediately behind the fore teeth in the horse; -- calledalso lampers.
The branch of dendrology treating of the gross and minutestructure of wood.
A material used for grinding, as emery, sand, powdered glass,etc.
That tie of consanguinity which exists between personsdescended from the same mother; -- used in distinction from agnation.
A heavier-than-air flying machine in which the motive power isfurnished solely by the aviator.
A compound radical, C6H5.CH2, related to toluene and benzoicacid; -- commonly used adjectively.
Harborage; lodging; shelter; harbor. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A troublesome grass, growing as a weed in grain fields; --called also chess. See Chess.
An instrument to guid the hands and fingers of pupils inplaying on the piano, etc.
Capable of being relished; agreeable to the taste; gratifying.
Having the power or quality of preserving; tending to preserve,or to keep from injury, decay, etc.
Revolving around the planet Jupiter; appearing as viewed fromJupiter. [R.] J. R. Hind.
The quality or state of being earthy, or of containing earth;hence, grossness.

Any one of numerous species of ducks which frequent theseacoasts and feed mainly on fishes and mollusks. The scoters,eiders, old squaw, and ruddy duck are examples. They may bedistinguished by the lobate hind toe.
Pertaining to an acid first obtained from benzoic aldehyde (oilof better almonds), as a white crystalline substance; -- called alsophenyl glycolic acid.
A fencer; a gladiator; one who exhibits his skill in the use ofthe sword.
Necessary; indispensable; -- said of those tones whichconstitute a chord, in distinction from ornamental or passing tones.
. Bissextile; a year containing 366 days; every fourth yearwhich leaps over a day more than a common year, giving to Februarytwenty-nine days. See Bissextile.
A genus of large univalve mollusks abundant in the arctic seas.It includes the common whelk (B. undatum).
An instrument for measuring the tension of the aqueous vapor inthe atmosphere, being essentially a wet and dry bulb hygrometer.
Of or pertaining to thorium; designating the compounds ofthorium.
An explosive consisting of ammonium nitrate, a derivative ofnitrobenzene, chlorated napthalene, and wood meal.
One who has served in an army in several campaigns; an oldsoldier; a veteran.
Vanadate of bismuth, occurring in minute reddish browncrystals.
The process of chasing on metals; also, the work thus chased.Weale.
A styliform process forming the posterior extremity of thevertebral column in some fishes and amphibians.
The quality of being adorable, or worthy of adoration. Johnson.
The theory founded on the influence which the humors weresupposed to have in the production of disease; Galenism. Dunglison.
A contrivance for recording the speed of a railway train.Knight.
A semivitrified clay or shale, somewhat resembling jasper; --called also porcelain jasper.
A circle of two or more leaves, flowers, or other organs, aboutthe same part or joint of a stem.
An innovation or novelty; a neoteric word or phrase.
The taking again into the king's hands of such lands ortenements as he had granted to any man on false suggestions or othererror.
Of or pertaining to a tenement; capable of being held bytenants. Blackstone.

A device for producing a current of air; as: (a) A metal platetemporarily placed before the upper part of a grate or open fire. (b)A machine for producing an artificial blast or current of air bypressure, as for increasing the draft of a furnace, ventilating abuilding or shaft, cleansing gram, etc.
The distance traversed by an arrow shot from a bow.
An instrument for measuring the acuteness of the sense ofhearing. Itard.
The act of murdering a son or a daughter; also, parent whocommits such a murder.
The system of doctrines and  rites taught in the tantras. --Tan"trist (#), n.
The science of, or a treatise on, first principles. Fleming.
Of or pertaining to Tringa, or the Sandpiper family.
To quality. [R.]The benefice he is capacified and designed for. Barrow.
A retiring of the sea, occasioning a change of high-water mark,whereby land is gained.
The common soft tissue which unites the polyps of a compoundhydroid. See Hydroidea.
On this side of the mountains. See under Ultramontane.
To mitigate; to moderate; to appease; to abate; to diminish.[Archaic] Chaucer.
To subject to the action of smoke. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
The art or process of measuring the polarization of light.
Pertaining to, or consisting of, a sheaf or sheaves; resemblinga sheaf.
Having alternate curvatures in opposite directions; bent in azigzag manner.
The quality of being anxious; great solicitude; anxiety.
One who holds the doctrine of ditheism; a dualist. Cudworth.
A diseased condition produced by the excessive use of bromineor one of its compounds. It is characterized by mental dullness andmuscular weakness.
A disseizin by one who once before was adjudged to havedassezed the same person of the same lands, etc.; also, a writ whichlay in such a case. Blackstone.

One of that class of Calvinists who consider the decree ofelection as contemplating the apostasy as past and the elect as beingat the time of election in a fallen and guilty state; -- opposed toSupralapsarian. The former considered the election of grace as aremedy for an existing evil; the latter regarded the fall as a partof God's original purpose in regard to men.
To disperse; to scatter; -- opposite of congregate. [Obs.]
A term applied to that phase of vegetable growth in which anorgan grows more rapidly on its upper than on its under surface. SeeHyponastic.
An order of Bryozoa of which Rhabdopleura is the type. SeeRhabdopleura.
Any tectibranchiate mollusk of the genus Aplysia. See Aplysia.
A leaf inserted between other leaves; a blank leaf inserted, asin a book.
An assemblage or arrangement of ribs, as the timberwork for thesupport of an arch or coved ceiling, the veins in the leaves of someplants, ridges in the fabric of cloth, or the like.
A group of cells resembling a stoma, but without any trueaperture among them.

A dark blue, edible berry with a white bloom, and its shrub(Gaylussacia frondosa) closely allied to the common huckleberry. Thebush is also called blue tangle, and is found from New England toKentucky, and southward.
A species of mint (Mentha viridis) growing in moist soil. Itvields an aromatic oil. See Mint, and Mentha.
Capable of being crystallized; that may be formed intocrystals.
Dried dung of cattle used as fuel. [Prov. Eng.] Waterland.
A genus of American gallinaceous birds, including the commonand the wild turkeys.
Neglect of using; failure to use. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
A fire kindled in a public place in token of joy; a bonfire; afiring of guns in token of joy.
A mixture of two parts of the oil of roses with one of thevinegar of roses. Floyer.
A discourse or treatise on trees; the natural history of trees.
Having a hissing sound; hissing; sibilant. [R.] Pennant.
One for whom a person becomes sponsor at baptism, and whom hepromises to see educated as a Christian; a godson or goddaughter. SeeGodfather.
Pertaining to, or designating, a supposed acid obtained frompectin.
A built-up, rifled, rapid-fire gun of oil-tempered steel,having a rectangular breechblock which moves horizontally orvertically in a mortise cut completely through the jacket. It is madein France.
An idiom of the Saxon or Anglo-Saxon language. T. Warton.
A colorless gas, CH3Cl, of a sweet odor, easily condensed to aliquid; -- called also methyl chloride.
One of a body of officers charged with the government ofSpanish municipalities, corresponding to the English alderman.
The use of the microscope; investigation with the microscope.

A follower of (Joannes) Duns Scotus, the Franciscan scholastic(d. 1308), who maintained certain doctrines in philosophy andtheology, in opposition to the Thomists, or followers of ThomasAquinas, the Dominican scholastic.
One of the varieties of calcite, barite, and feldspar, whichemit a fetid odor on being struck; -- called also swinestone.
Neglect of duty; idleness; indolence. [Obs.] Massinger.
One who prepares beforehand, as subjects for dissection,specimens for preservation in collections, etc. Agassiz.
A species of Ranunculus (R. bulbosus); -- called alsobutterflower, buttercup, kingcup, goldcup. Shak.
Any detergent plant, or the part of it used as a detergent, asthe roots of Agave Americana, Chlorogalum pomeridianum, etc. [Sp.Amer. & Mex.]
Calcium tungstate, a mineral of a white or pale yellowish colorand of the tetragonal system of crystallization.
A foul-smelling weed, the stinking goosefoot (ChenopodiumVulvaria).
A kettledrum; a kind of tabor, used by the Moors. Croly.
A trader in law; one who practices law as if it were a trade.Milton.
A name that precedes the family name or surname; a first name.Selden.
The quality of being laudable; praiseworthiness;commendableness.

A misplacing or error in the order of time; an error inchronology by which events are misplaced in regard to each other,esp. one by which an event is placed too early; falsification ofchronological relation.
A proposition or device for securing peace, especially in thechurch. South.
A board used on the lap as a substitute for a table, as bytailors.
A Dravidian of a group of tribes of Orissa, India, a section ofwhom were formerly noted for their cruel human sacrifices to theearth goddess, murder of female infants, and marriage by capture.
Of or pertaining to the rod or punishment with the rod.
The doctrine or practice of consorting with the opposite sex,at pleasure, without marriage.
A tribe of North American Inedians, inhabiting the northernpart of Mexico. They belong to the Tinneh stock, and are closelyrelated to the Apaches.
To clear or strip of wood (by cutting down trees). [R.]Fuller.
The state or quality of being famous. [Obs.] Johnson.
A doing well; right performance of duties. Also usedadjectively.
A boiler in which clay is beaten by a wheel to a creamyconsistence. Knight.
The state or quality of being absorbable. Graham (Chemistry).
The yellow, waxlike secretion from the glands of the externalear; the earwax.
A kind of very pungent sauce made from red peppers.
An herb (Linaria vulgaris) of the Figwort family, having narrowleaves and showy orange and yellow flowers; -- called also butter andeggs, flaxweed, and ramsted.
The extant copies of the first or earliest printed books, or ofsuch as were printed in the 15th century.

A game played with rackets and a ball suspended by a stringfrom an upright pole, the object of each side being to wrap thestring around the pole by striking the ball in a direction oppositeto the other.
A steel containing a small amount of tungsten, noted fortenacity and hardness, even under a considerable degree of heat.Magnets made of it are said to be highly permanent. It often containsmanganese.
The carp; -- so called on account of its cunning. Walton.

Lydian stone, or black jasper, a variety of siliceous or flintyslate, of a grayish or bluish black color. It is employed to test thepurity of gold, the amount of alloy being indicated by the color lefton the stone when rubbed by the metal.
A club usually located in the suburbs or vicinity of a city ortown and devoted mainly to outdoor sports.
Relating to, or characteristic of, Boswell, the biographer ofDr. Johnson.
A small bit of anything, of indefinite size or quantity; ashort distance. [Scot.] Sir W. Scott.
A bitter white crystalline substance found in the cocculusindicus. It is a peculiar poisonous neurotic and intoxicant, andconsists of a mixture of several neutral substances.
A neatling of a pigeon or other similar bird, esp. when veryfat and not fully fledged.
Having, or surrounded by, long, narrow depressions or furrows.
The act or process of deepening worn lines in an etched plateby submitting it again to the action if acid. Fairholt.
A young salmon two or three years old, when it has acquired itssilvery color.
Development of cells in animal and vegetable organisms. SeeGemmation, Budding, Karyokinesis; also Cell development, under Cell.
A small European fern (Asplenium Ceterach) formerly used inmedicine.
The process of laminating, or the state of being laminated.
A man who has authority to act, within certain limits, asmaster of the house; a steward; also, a chief minister or officer.
One who possesses, or occupies, previously. R. Brady.
A mountain or hill, usually more or less conical in form, fromwhich lava, cinders, steam, sulphur gases, and the like, are ejected;-- often popularly called a burning mountain.
The act of freeing from an illusion, or the state of beingfreed therefrom.
Imperfect fetation in some organ exterior to the uterus; extra-uterine fetation. Hoblyn.
The quality or state of being protuberant; protuberance;prominence.
Having no motion or activity; incapable of motion; benumbed;torpid. [Obs.] Evelyn.
A blue, fluorescent, oily base (regarded as a derivative ofpyridine), obtained from conine.
To inure or habituate to a climate different from that which isnatural; to adapt to the peculiarities of a foreign or strangeclimate; said of man, the inferior animals, or plants.
A board, or other woodwork, carried round the walls of a roomand touching the floor, to form a base and protect the plastering; --also called washboard (in England), mopboard, and scrubboard.
The handkerchief upon which the Savior is said to haveimpressed his own portrait miraculously, when wiping his face withit, as he passed to the crucifixion.
Any one of numerous species of butterflies of the genusArgynnis and allied genera, having silvery spots on the under side ofthe wings. See Illust. under Aphrodite.
The interval between the diastole and systole of the heart. Itis perceptible only in the dying.
A genus of insects including the earwigs. See Earwig, 1.

A white robe with a purple border, worn by a Roman boy beforehe was entitled to wear the toga virilis, or until about thecompletion of his fourteenth year, and by girls until their marriage.It was also worn by magistrates and priests.
A genus of bitter aromatic plants, sometimes used in medicine;hoarhound.
Having the ovules and seeds so curved, or bent down uponthemselves, that the ends of the embryo are brought close together.
One of a series of substances formed, in secreting cells, byconstructive or anabolic processes, in the production of protoplasm;-- opposed to katastate. Foster.
Divided into, or consisting of, five parts; also, arranged insets, with five parts in each set, as a flower with five sepals, fivepetals, five, or twice five, stamens, and five pistils.
The act of anglicizing, or making English in character.
