To loose from a truss, or as from a truss; to untie orunfasten; to let out; to undress. [R.] Dryden.
A snare; a stratagem; a trepan. See 3d Trepan. South.

An ancient Spanish land tenure similar to the English knight'sfee; hence, in Spain and countries settled by the Spanish, a landmeasure of varying size. In Cuba it is about 33 acres; in Porto Rico,about 194 acres; in the Southwestern United States, about 108 acres.
A trumpet call for rousing soldiers; a reveille. [Obs.]Hudibras.
One who depends for salvation on faith, without works; anAntinomian. Hammond.
To adopt the principles of the Sadducees. Atterbury.
The principle or practice of entire abstinence, esp. fromintoxicating drinks.
Having leaves of more than one shape on the same plant.
The closing subdivision of the Hamilton period in the AmericanDevonian system; -- so called because the formations of this periodcrop out in Genesee, New York.
In hair dressing, a loose, low coil at the back of the head,like the knot on the head of the bust of Clytie by G. F. Watts.
A kind of type, in size between small pica and bourgeois.
An Italian four-wheeled carriage, esp. one let for hire; ahackney coach.
In an ardent manner; eagerly; with warmth; affectionately;passionately.
A genus of land snails, often large, common in the warm partsof America and Africa.
Lines of white or black paint drawn along a mortar joint in abrick wall. Knight.
A book-shaped needlecase, having leaves of cloth into which theneedles are stuck.
To ingraft, as a tree or plant, by the insertion of a bud oreye; to inoculate.The arts of grafting and ineying. J. Philips.
A West Indian fruit like the mango in taste, sometimes pickled;also, the tree (Grias cauliflora) bearing this fruit.
One who, or that which, contributes aid or additional supplies;an assistant; an auxiliary. Hammond.
The act or mode of adding; also, the thing added. [R.] B.Jonson.
A voltaic battery in which the exciting fluid is water.
Exercising its highest influence; -- said of a planet. [Obs.]Chaucer.
Relating to a church; unduly fond of church forms. [Colloq.]
To let blood from by opening a vein; to bleed. [R.] Howell.
That division of elasmobranch fishes which includes the sharks.
A hydrous sulphate of copper and lead, found in some parts ofCaledonia or Scotland.
To render difficult; to difficilitate. [Obs.] Cotgrave.
Having legs of a different tincture from that of the body; --said of a bird in heraldic representations.
A cell annexed to an abbey, for the use of a hermit. Howell.
A saddle girth made of leather, canvas, woven horsehair, orwoven grass. [Western U.S.]
Of or pertaining to ashes. [Obs.]Light and favollous particles. Sir T. Browne.
Having a typically large size; belonging to the megasthenes.
Of or relating to the relating to the adjective; of the natureof an adjective; adjective. W. Taylor (1797)
A substance which is similar to another in crystalline form andcomposition.
Reddish; of a yellowish red or brownish red color; tawny.
Lying on the bottom of a river or other water; sunk.
A withered person; one who is decrepit. [Obs.] Chapman.
Ethyl oxamate, obtained as a white scaly crystalline powder.
A light covering of reeds, over which the main covering islaid, in thatching houses. [Prov. Eng.] Wright.
A half god, or an inferior deity; a fabulous hero, theoffspring of a deity and a mortal.
The cover of the eye; that portion of movable skin with whichan animal covers or uncovers the eyeball at pleasure.
To grumble or mutter like a froward child. [Obs.] E. Phillips.
In a tropical manner; figuratively; metaphorically.
One of a physiological group of globular bacteria whichproduces fermentations of diverse nature; -- distinguished frompathogene.
To grow cordial; to feel or express cordiality. [R.]
Curtain or covering; -- applied to various membranouspartitions, especially to the soft palate. See under Palate.
Pertaining to an acid produced by treating oleic with nitricacid. [R.]
Three sided, the sides being plane or concave; having threesalient angles or edges; trigonal.
A mineral closely related to dolomite, but containing iron.
The packet of vellum leaves in which the gold is first beateninto thin sheets.
A salt of osmic acid. [Formerly written also osmiate.]
Rounded stones containing tin ore, lying at the surface of theground, and indicating a vein. Raymond.
One who gets a living by picking up rags and refuse things inthe streets.
Inclined or hanging downwards, as a flower on a recurved stalk,or an ovule which hangs from the upper part of the ovary.
In a supple manner; softly; pliantly; mildly. Cotgrave.
A game of cards derived from conquian, played by two or moreplayers with one or two full packs of cards.
A series of strata in the lower Silurian formations of GreatBritain; -- so named from Llandeilo in Southern Wales. See Chart ofGeology.
A genus of marine bivalves, having a pearly interior, allied tothe pearl oyster; -- so called from a supposed resemblance of thetypical species to a bird.
A system of theology embracing all religions; a complete systemof theology.
Of or pertaining to starched or starch; stiffness of manner;preciseness.
The act of evolving, or the state of being evolved; evolution.
The side of the way; the edge or border of a road or path.
A discourse or treatise upon the tides; that part of sciencewhich treats of tides. J. S. Mill.
The nettle rash, a disease characterized by a transienteruption of red pimples and of wheals, accompanied with a burning orstinging sensation and with itching; uredo.
The uppermost member of the cornice of an entablature.
A guard in the front part of vehicle, to prevent splashing by amud or water from the horse's heels; -- in the United States commonlycalled dashboard.
Cream; -- a term used esp. in cookery, names of liqueurs, etc.
A small wrenlike Australian bird (Stipiturus malachurus),having the tail feathers long and loosely barbed, like emu feathers.
A material found in the cell walls of cork. It is amodification of lignin.
The goddess of law and order; the patroness of existing rights.
The state of being orbate, or deprived of parents or children;privation, in general; bereavement. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
A variety of jade. It is used by some savages, particularly thenatives of the South Sea Islands, for making axes or hatchets.
Correction or government of one's self for the sake ofimprovement.
A disease of horses, characterized by difficult breathing, withheaving of the flank, wheezing, flatulency, and a peculiar cough;broken wind.
A phenol alcohol obtained, by the decomposition of salicin, asa white crystalline substance; -- called also hydroxy-benzyl alcohol.
A pointed instrument of the dagger kind fitted on the muzzle ofa musket or rifle, so as to give the soldier increased means ofoffense and defense.
Not shent; not disgraced; blameless. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
The parasitic worm that causes the gapes in birds. SeeIllustration in Appendix.
To dig under or beneath; to undermine. [Obs.] Wyclif.
A breech-loading machine gun consisting of a number of barrelsfitted together, so arranged that the barrels can be firedsimultaneously, or successively, and rapidly.
A genus of fossil univalve shells, believed to belong to theHeteropoda, peculiar to the Paleozoic age.
The act or state of being bound as surety for another;suretyship.
A piece of oak bolted perpendicularly on the side of a vessel,to aid in drawing down and securing the clew of the mainsail.
An extensive group of rodents which includes the rats, mice,jerboas, and many allied forms.
Moving like waves; undulatory. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A state of being released from coverture; freedom of a womanfrom the coverture of a husband.
Making Christ the center, about whom all things are grouped, asin religion or history; tending toward Christ, as the central objectof thought or emotion. J. W. Chadwick.
To study by candlelight or a lamp; to study by night.

A species of hexameter verse so constructed as to be divisibleinto two portions of three feet each, having generally a trochee inthe first and the fourth foot, and an amphimacer in the third; --applied also to a regular hexameter verse when so constructed as tobe divisible into two portions of three feet each. Andrews.
The office of a chancellor; the time during which one ischancellor.

A fusible white cast iron containing a large amount of carbon(from three and a half to six per cent) and some manganese. When themanganese reaches twenty-five per cent and upwards it has a granularstructure, and constitutes the alloy ferro manganese, largely used inthe manufacture of Bessemer steel. Called also specular pig iron,spiegel, and spiegeleisen.
A native or inhabitant of Switzerland; a Switzer; the people ofSwitzerland.
A paste of clay used in decorating coarse pottery in relief.
A kind of blackish seaweed (Himanthalia lorea) found on thenorthern coasts of the Atlantic. It has a thonglike forking processrising from a top-shaped base.
A movement or phase of post-impressionism (which see, below).
Resembling a lentil in size or form; having the form of adouble-convex lens.
A variety of feldspar, having a verdigris-green color.
Hollow-seeded; having the ventral face of the seedlike carpelsincurved at the ends, as in coriander seed.
A plank fixed beneath an object, as beneath the rudder of avessel, to protect it from injury; a plank on the ground under theend of a shore or the like.
Cleft to the middle or slightly beyond the middle; opening witha cleft; divided by a linear sinus, with straight margins.
In a solitary manner; in solitude; alone. Mic. vii. 14.
Similarity of origin; affinity. [Obs.]  Dr. H. More.
An East Indian coin, of about one tenth of the weight of arupee.
Any plant of the aquatic umbelliferous genus Sium, poisonousherbs with pinnate or dissected leaves and small white flowers.

A vocabulary, or book containing an alphabetical arrangement ofthe words in a language or of a considerable number of them, with thedefinition of each; a dictionary; especially, a dictionary of theGreek, Hebrew, or Latin language.
The adhesion or cohesion of different floral verticils or setsof organs.
The department of musical science which treats of the pitch oftones, and of the laws of melody.
The third joint of the typical appendages of Crustacea.
One of the minute apertures between the cells in many serousmembranes.
A genus of brachiopods of which many species are found in thefossil state. A few still exist in the deep sea.
One who recaptures; one who takes a prize which had beenpreviously taken.
In a dim or obscure manner; not brightly or clearly; withimperfect sight.
A native or natives of Ceylon descended from its primitiveinhabitants; also (sing.),

The third division, or that between the reticulum, or honeycombstomach, and the abomasum, or rennet stomach, in the stomach ofruminants; the omasum; the psalterium. So called from the numerousfolds in its mucous membrane. See Illust of Ruminant.

A West African buffalo (Bubalus brachyceros) having short hornsdepressed at the base, and large ears fringed internally with threerows of long hairs. It is destitute of a dewlap. Called also short-horned buffalo, and bush cow.
Any of a class of toxic substances of protein nature; a toxin.
A printed programme of a play, with the parts assigned to theactors.
To withdraw from concentration; to decentralize. [R.]
An extensive order of Porifera, which includes those that havethe skeleton composed mainly of siliceous fibers or spicules.
In an heraldic manner; according to the rules of heraldry.

One of the largest species of sharks (Cetorhinus maximus), socalled from its habit of basking in the sun; the liver shark, or boneshark. It inhabits the northern seas of Europe and America, and growsto a length of more than forty feet. It is a harmless species.
The stem or stalk that supports the flower or fruit of a plant,or a cluster of flowers or fruits.
The papal chamberlain; the cardinal who presides over thepope's household. He has at times possessed great power. [Writtenalso camerlengo and camarlengo.]
Light land; rosland. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Mortimer.
Having a blunt or button-shaped extremity; -- said of cuttinginstruments.
The act or process of freezing anew, or together,as two piecesof ice.
One who marks with points. specifically, one who writes Hebrewwith points; -- applied to a Masorite. E. Robinson.
Quality of being customable; conformity to custom. [Obs.]
One who does not belong, or refuses to belong, to a tradesunion.
To give a rural appearance to; to cause to appear rustic. Lamb.
A person invested with full power to transact any business;especially, an ambassador or envoy to a foreign court, with fullpower to negotiate a treaty, or to transact other business.
Of or pertaining to Burmah, or its inhabitants.-- n. sing. & pl.

The tendency of certain plant organs, as leaves, to assumespecial "sleeping" positions or make curvatures under the influenceof darkness. It is well illustrated in the leaflets of clover andother leguminous plants.
One who, or that which, transforms. Specif. (Elec.), anapparatus for producing from a given electrical current anothercurrent of different voltage.
A broad-leaved plant (Petasites vulgaris) of the Compositefamily, said to have been used in England for wrapping up pats ofbutter.
Of the nature of, or constituting, doctrine. [Obs.] Sir P.Sidney.
A house appropriated for the use of a school or schools, or forinstruction.
One of the fine granules contained in the protoplasm of apollen grain.
To cry up. as if for sale; to blazon. [Obs.] Holland.
The integument of the under surface of the bell, or disk-shapedbody, of a jellyfish.
Not covert; not within the bonds of matrimony; unmarried; --applied either to a woman who has never married or to a widow.
A group of extinct carnivorous whales. Their teeth hadcompressed and serrated crowns. It includes Squalodon and alliedgenera.
A bony prominence; particularly, an eminence at the end of abone bearing a rounded articular surface; -- sometimes applied alsoto a concave articular surface.
A skipping or leaping about in frolic; a hop; a sportive prank.Dryden.
To withhold praise from; to deprive of praise. [R.]

One of the dwellers in the Cistercian convent of Port Royal desChamps, near Paris, when it was the home of the Jansenists in the17th century, among them being Arnauld, Pascal, and other famousscholars. Cf. Jansenist.
A white mark on the foot of a horse, between the fetlock andthe coffin.
A bag for holding implements or materials for work; especially,a reticule, or bag for holding needlework, and the like.
Capable of boring or cutting wood; -- said of many insects.
A musical instrument in which the tones are produced by flamesof hydrogen, or illuminating gas, burning in tubes of different sizesand lengths.
An aquatic mite of the genus Hydrachna. The hydrachids, whileyoung, are parasitic on fresh-water mussels.

A fern of the genus Adiantum (A. pedatum), having very slendergraceful stalks. It is common in the United States, and is sometimesused in medicine. The name is also applied to other species of thesame genus, as to the Venus-hair. Maiden grass, the smaller quakinggrass.-- Maiden tree. See Ginkgo.
The act of prejudging; decision before sufficient examination.
An open space within a monastery or adjoining a church, as thespace within a cloister, the open court before a basilica, etc.
Sirs; gentlemen; -- abbreviated to Messrs., which is used asthe plural of Mr.
A colorless crystalline alkaloid obtained in small quantitiesfrom opium.
The property or jurisdiction of a thane; thanage. Sir W. Scott.
One of the small galleries run out in front of the glacis. Theyserve to annoy the enemy's miners.
A congenital malformation in which the spinal column is cleftat its lower portion, and the membranes of the spinal cord project asan elastic swelling from the gap thus formed.
The range within which the fire of small arms is verydestructive. With the magazine rifle, this is six hundred yards.
The pied wagtail; -- so called because it frequents ponds.

An edifice or structure of heavy timbers or logs for militarydefense, having its sides loopholed for musketry, and often an upperstory projecting over the lower, or so placed upon it as to have itssides make an angle wit the sides of the lower story, thus enablingthe defenders to fire downward, and in all directions; -- formerlymuch used in America and Germany.
The quality or state of being malevolent; evil dispositiontoward another; inclination to injure others; ill will. See Synonymof Malice.
The doctrine of belief that matter is God, or that there is noGod except matter and the universe; pantheism. See Materialism.
One of the leaves of the corolla, or the colored leaves of aflower. See Corolla, and Illust. of Flower.
Outside of the branchial arches; -- said of the cartilages thusplaced in some fishes.
The act of scanning; distinguishing the metrical feet of averse by emphasis, pauses, or otherwise.
Producing or promoting the growth of flesh. [R.] -- n.
Furnished with, protected by, or built like, a casemate.Campbell.
Having so marked an appearance as easily to be recognized.[Scot.]
A hydrocarbon, C23H48, of the methane series, resemblingparaffin; -- so called because it has twenty-three atoms of carbon inthe molecule.
The surface formed by cutting away the arris, or angle, formedby two faces of a piece of timber, stone, etc.
To bestow horns upon; to make a cuckold of; to cuckold. [Obs.]Burton.
An instrument for measuring the extension of a body, especiallyfor measuring the elongation of bars of iron, steel, or othermaterial, when subjected to a tensile force.
Inoculation with the syphilitic virus, especially when employedas a preventive measure, like vaccination.
Any one of several species of large hawks of the genusArchibuteo, having the legs feathered to the toes. Called also rough-legged hawk, and rough-legged buzzard.
The state of being, or the personality of, a beadle. A. Wood.
Ascending and descending fresh streams from and to the sea, asthe salmon; anadromous. [R.]
The state of being closely surrounded, crowded, or pressed, asby ice. [R.] Kane.
A division of Pectostraca including saclike parasites ofCrustacea. They adhere by rootlike extensions of the head. SeeIllusration in Appendix.
A banderole; esp. a banner displayed at a funeral processionand set over the tomb. See Banderole.

A genus of plants having a beaklike tours or receptacle, aroundwhich the seed capsules are arranged, and membranous projections, orstipules, at the joints. Most of the species have showy flowers and apungent odor. Called sometimes crane's-bill.
A title borne by every one of the daughters of the kings ofSpain and Portugal, except the eldest.
Of or pertaining to a mandible; like a mandible.-- n.
Customary; ordinary; -- applied to the usual English spelling,in distinction from strictly phonetic methods. H Sweet.-- n.
A complex, oily, nitrogenous base, isomeric with nicotine, andobtained by the reduction of certain derivatives of the pyridinegroup.
An ancient military engine, in the form of a crossbow, used forhurling large missiles.
One who plays at bowls, or who rolls the ball in cricket or anyother game.
Redundancy of language in speaking or writing; the use of morewords than are necessary to express the idea; as, I saw it with myown eyes.
The fruit of the Adansonia digitata; also, the tree. SeeAdansonia.
The cleaning of the flues of a boiler from scale, etc., by ablast of steam.
One of a succession of niches or platforms, one above another,to hold ore which is thrown successively from platform to platform,and thus raised to a higher level.
Having a delicately crackled surface; --applied to porcelian,etc.
Vascular tissue of plants, consisting of spiral vessels,dotted, barred, and pitted ducts, and laticiferous vessels.
An ornamental cutting of the edges of garments, introducedabout a. d. 1346, according to the Chronicles of St Albans. [Obs.]Halliwell.
A man who has charge of railroad points or switches. [Eng.]
One of a breed of large-bodied domestic fowls, having fivetoes, or the hind toe double. There are several strains, as thewhite, gray, and silver-gray. They are highly esteemed for the table.
A dose which is less than required; a small or insufficientdose.
The quality of being insusceptible of feeling, pain, orsuffering; impassiveness.
Distillation; the substance obtained by distillation. [Obs.]Shak.
To conform or make conformable to the language, customs, etc.,of Attica.
A barometer in which the changes of atmospheric pressure areindicated by the motion of a column of water instead of mercury. Itrequires a column of water about thirty-three feet in height.

A self-evident and necessary truth, or a proposition whosetruth is so evident as first sight that no reasoning or demonstrationcan make it plainer; a proposition which it is necessary to take forgranted; as, "The whole is greater than a part;" "A thing can not, atthe same time, be and not be."
A woman belonging to one of the religious and charitableassociations or communities in the Netherlands, and elsewhere, whosemembers live in beguinages and are not bound by perpetual vows.
Having a large, protuberant belly, or one shaped like a tun;pot-bellied.
A fee or rent paid by a tenant for the privilege of faldage onhis own ground. Blount.
A cotton stuff showing a fine cord on one side and a satinysurface on the other.
Having the sporangium destitute of a ring; -- said of certaingenera of ferns.
A fluid vaccine obtained by growing a bacterium (Bacteriumanthracis) in beef broth. It is used to immunize animals, esp.cattle.
The method or process of measuring volumes by means of thevolumenometer.
A supply of water; specifically, water collected, as inreservoirs, and conveyed, as by pipes, for use in a city, mill, orthe like.
A box containing lighted tinder, formerly carried by soldierswho used matchlocks, to kindle the match.
The person who employs another to perform a mandate. Bouvier.
An instrument for constructing triangles in marine surveying,etc.
The ring of the fruit of several East Indian species of acacia;neb-neb. It contains gallic acid and tannin, and is used for dyeingdrab.
To exile by ostracism; to banish by a popular vote, as atAthens. Grote.
Partaking of, made of, or pertaining to, iron; like iron.[Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A gun, pistol, or any weapon from a shot is discharged by theforce of an explosive substance, as gunpowder.
A gavel or rent paid for a privilege, as of fishing, in someriver or water.
A climbing plant (Ipomoea purpurea) having handsome, funnel-shaped flowers, usually red, pink, purple, white, or variegated,sometimes pale blue. See Dextrorsal.
A shrike or butcher bird; -- called also mattages. [Prov. Eng.]
An officious person who courts favor servilely; a pickthank.[Obs.] Shak.
A division of Cheiroptera, including the bloodsucking bats. SeeVampire.

Remission of the temporal punishment due to sins, after theguilt of sin has been remitted by sincere repentance; absolution fromthe censures and public penances of the church. It is a payment ofthe debt of justice to God by the application of the merits of Christand his saints to the contrite soul through the church. It istherefore believed to diminish or destroy for sins the punishment ofpurgatory.
The common European grosbeak (Coccothraustes vulgaris); --called also cherry finch, and coble.
Producing flowers from a rootstock, or apparently from a root.
The council held under Pope Pius IX. in Vatican at Rome, in1870, which promulgated the dogma of papal infallibility.
A rope with a hook and a toggle, sometimes used to drag a guncarriage or to lash it to the limber, and for various other purposes.
A fatty substance contained in the oil of the dolphin and theporpoise; -- called also phocenin.
A man sphinx; a sphinx having the head of a man and the body ofa lion.
A superficial, inflammatory tumor, suppurating with a centralcore; a boil.
a neglect of a tenant to perform services, or make payment, fortwo years.
One who assumes, arrogates, pretends, or supposes. W. D.Whitney.
An instrument, devised by Professor Helmholtz, for testing thecolor perception of the eye, or for comparing different lights, as totheir constituent color or their relative whiteness.
A sect of Jews who adhere closely to the letter of theScriptures, rejecting the oral law, and allowing the Talmud nobinding authority; -- opposed to the Rabbinists.
A mode of harrowing crosswise, or transversely to the ridges.Crabb.

An officer of state in England who marshals and orders allgreat ceremonials, takes cognizance of matters relating to honor,arms, and pedigree, and directs the proclamation of peace and war.The court of chivalry was formerly under his jurisdiction, and he isstill the head of the herald's office or college of arms.
A name of the Hesychasts, from their habit of gazing upon thenavel.
A European yellow-flowered, gentianaceous (Chlora perfoliata).The whole plant is intensely bitter, and is sometimes used as atonic, and also in dyeing yellow.
The placenta and membranes with which the fetus is connected,and which come away after delivery.
A foot consisting of three long syllables and one shortsyllable.
A shallow wooden vessel for holding milk or cream. [Prov. Eng.& Scot.] Grose.
The offense committed by an officer who corruptly claims andtakes, as his fee, money, or other thing of value, that is not due,or more than is due, or before it is due. Abbott.
A variety of spinel ruby, of a pale rose red, or inclining toorange. See Spinel.
A kind of bass, an edible fresh-water fish (Pomoxys annularis)of the southern United States.
The possession by a woman of more than one husband at the sametime; -- contrasted with Ant: monandry.
To blind by a red-hot metal plate held before the eyes. [R.]
To render volatile; to cause to exhale or evaporate; to causeto pass off in vapor.The water . . . dissolving the oil, and volatilizing it by theaction. Sir I. Newton.
An American perennial herb (Chelone glabra) having whiteflowers shaped like the head of a turtle. Called also snakehead,shell flower, and balmony.
A message transmitted and recorded by a teleautograph.
An induced electric current circulating wholly within a mass ofmetal; -- called also Foucault current.
One who disorganizes or causes disorder and confusion.
A coarse, gross person; a person void of sensibility orsinsitiveness; a dullard.
A piece of plate armor for the head of a war horse; a tester.
A colorless mobile liquid, C6H5.SH, of an offensive odor, andanalogous to phenol; -- called also phenyl sulphydrate.
The doctrine or creed of a deist; the belief or system of thosewho acknowledge the existence of one God, but deny revelation.
A plant of the Cabbage species (Brassica oleracea) of manyvarieties, resembling the cauliflower. The "curd," or flowering head,is the part used for food.
The act or art of heraldic decoration; delineation of armorialbearings.
One of several species of armadillos of the genera Dasypus andEuphractus, having five toes both on the fore and hind feet.
Treatment of severe nervous disorder, as neurasthenia, by restand isolation with systematic feeding and the use of massage andelectricity.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid extracted from madderroot. It is a yellow crystalline substance from which alizarin isobtained.
The posterior of the three principal divisions of the brain,including the epencephalon and metencephalon. Sometimes restricted tothe epencephalon only.
The first vertebra of the neck, articulating immediately withthe skull, thus sustaining the globe of the head, whence the name.
Uniformity of physical properties in all directions in a body;absence of all kinds of polarity; specifically, equal elasticity inall directions.
The art of judging of a person's character, disposition, andaptitude from his handwriting.
Circular motion in a direction contrary to some other circularmotion.
To happen or come to pass unfortunately; also, to suffer evilfortune. [Obs.]

Having the properties exhibited by gases under very lowpressures (one millionth of an atmosphere or less). Matter under thiscondition, which has been termed the fourth state of matter, issometimes called radiant matter.
Containing counsel or warning; hortatory; advisory. [Obs.]Potter.
The throne or seat of a bishop within the chancel. [Obs.]
A genus of ruminants comprising the common domestic cattle.
Iron ore in coarse powder, prepared for reduction by theCatalan process.
Of or pertaining to the open air; being under the open sky.[R.] N. Bacon.
A rope or hawser by which a vessel is towed or warped along; --so called because it is necessary to guess at the length to becarried in the boat making the attachment to a distant object.
A nonplane curve formed by the intersection of the surface ofan oblique cone with the surface of a sphere whose center is at thevertex of the cone.
Indicating, or pertaining to, some mode of conceivingexistence, or of expressing thought.
The opposite pole; anything diametrically opposed. Geo. Eliot.
A man who makes a practice of amusing others by low tricks,antic gestures, etc.; a droll; a mimic; a harlequin; a clown; amerry-andrew.
A glucoside extracted from the leaves of a certain plant(Urechitis suberecta) as a bitter white crystalline substance.
An umbelliferous plant of the genus Sison (S.Amomum); -- socalled because used to cure a swelling called a hone.
Slow; in slow time; slowly; -- rarely written lente.
A white crystallized mineral resin from the Fichtelgebirge,Bavaria.
One of an extinct family of trees allied to the modern clubmosses, and including Lepidodendron and its allies.
The quantity or sum that is left after subtraction, or afterany deduction.
An ulcer in the eye, upon the cornea, which causes the loss ofthe humors. Dunglison.
A treatise on the regulation of the diet; dietetics. [Writtenalso sitiology.]
A perennial composite herb (Chrysanthemum Leucanthemum) withconspicuous white rays and a yellow disk, a common weed in grasslands and pastures; -- called also oxeye daisy.
Conducting influences from the spinal cord outward; -- said ofthe motor or efferent nerves. Opposed to esodic.
Of, pertaining to, or connected with, plasma; plasmatic.

An instrument consisting of a mirror moved by clockwork, bywhich a sunbeam is made apparently stationary, by being steadilydirected to one spot during the whole of its diurnal period; also, ageodetic heliotrope.
A throw of dice after the game in ended; hence, anything donetoo late. Gower.
Affected with atrophy, as a tissue or organ; arrested indevelopment at a very early stage; rudimentary.
A storm characterized by high wind with little or no rain.

A Jew bound by a vow to lave the hair uncut, to abstain fromwine and strong drink, and to practice extraordinary purity of lifeand devotion, the obligation being for life, or for a certain time.The word is also used adjectively.
The act of feminizing, or the state of being feminized.
Having the lower part of the body like a fish. Crabb.
A mountain tribe of Mexican Indians living near Acapulco. Theyare remarkable for having the dark skin of the face irregularlyspotted with white. Called also speckled Indians.

A crystalline, nitrogenous substance, with a sweet taste,formed from hippuric acid by boiling with hydrochloric acid, andpresent in bile united with cholic acid. It is also formed fromgelatin by decomposition with acids. Chemically, it is amido-aceticacid. Called also glycin, and glycocin.
One of the corneas of a compound eye in the invertebrates.Carpenter.
Paper impregnated with saltpeter. The fumes from the burningpaper are often inhaled as an alleviative by asthmatics.
An open internal courtyard inclosed by the walls of a largedwelling house or other large and stately building.
Iron sesquioxide in isometric form, probably a pseudomorphafter magnetite.
Any protuberance of a bone which is not natural; an excrescenceor morbid enlargement of a bone. Coxe.
The practice of seeking after, and hanging on, noblemen, orpersons of quality, especially in English universities. [Cant, Eng.]
One opposed to the doctrines and practices of socialists orsocialism.
Tubular with one end dilated, as the flower of the trumpetcreeper.

A curious South American bird (Anhima, or Palamedea, cornuta),often domesticated by the natives and kept with poultry, which itdefends against birds of prey. It has a long, slender, hornlikeornament on its head, and two sharp spurs on each wing. Although itsbeak, feet, and legs resemble those of gallinaceous birds, it isrelated in anatomical characters to the ducks and geese (Anseres).Called also horned screamer. The name is sometimes applied also tothe chaja. See Chaja, and Screamer.
The quality of being abstruse; difficulty of apprehension.Boyle.
Massive quartz occurring as a rock; a metamorphosed sandstone;-- called also quartz rock.
A utensil for melting glue, consisting of an inner pot holdingthe glue, immersed in an outer one containing water which is heatedto soften the glue.
To disorganize, or disband and send home, as troops which havebeen mobilized.
The curve which a body describes in space, as a planet or cometin its orbit, or stone thrown upward obliquely in the air.
The doctrine of uniformity in the geological history of theearth; -- in part equivalent to uniformitarianism, but also used,more broadly, as opposed to catastrophism.
To vindicate again; to reclaim; to demand and take back.Mitford.
A vessel carrying at the masthead a brilliant light, and mooredoff a shoal or place of dangerous navigation as a guide for mariners.
The act of rehabilitating, or the state of being rehabilitated.Bouvier. Walsh.
A salt of valeric acid with glycerin, occurring in butter,dolphin oil., and forming an forming an oily liquid with a slightlyunpleasant odor.
To return an argument or a charge; to make a severe reply.Pope.
A fixed point or station; a basis or fundamental principle; aposition from which objects or principles are viewed, and accordingto which they are compared and judged.
The quality of being warlike; exercises suitable for war.[Obs.]
Covered with minute cracks in the glaze; -- said of some kindsof porcelain and fine earthenware.
Having the form of a tooth or of teeth; tooth-shaped.
A genus of Pseudoneuroptera including the white ants, ortermites. See Termite.
A genus of low perennial or biennial plants, the leaves ofwhich are beset with gland-tipped bristles. See Sundew. Gray.
, 1st & 3d pers. sing. of Forewite. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The science or art of cutting solids into certain figures orsections, as arches, and the like; especially, the art ofstonecutting.
Any plant of the genus Geissois, having seeds overlapping liketiles on a roof.
To import again; to import what has been exported; to bringback. Young.
A hand containing three of a kind and a pair, as three kingsand two tens. It ranks above a flush and below four of a kind.
One of certain minute coiled threads in the coating of someseeds. When moistened these threads protrude in great numbers. Gray.
Having the stigma visible at the throad of a gamopetalouscorolla, while the stamens are concealed in the tube; -- said ofdimorphous flowers. The opposite of Ant: thrum-eyed.
To untwist; to unravel, as the end of a rope. Johnson.
The bear's-foot (Helleborus foetidus); -- so called because theroot was used in settering, or inserting setons into the dewlaps ofcattle. Called also pegroots. Dr. Prior.
The class of skin disease developed by the dartrous diathesis.See under Dartrous.
Feeding on fruit, as birds and other animals. Pennant.
A white, crystalline, sugarlike substance, obtained by thedecomposition of certain glucosides, and intermediate in naturebetween the hexacid alcohols (ductile, mannite, etc.) and theglucoses.
A double slip of leather by which bells are fastened to ahawk's legs.
A hydrous silicate of magnesia and aluminia. It occurs in soft,soapy, amorphous masses, filling veins in serpentine and cavities intrap rock.
Entrance or place of a door. [Obs. or Local] Bp. Warburton.
One of the two principal orders of myriapods. They havenumerous segments, each bearing two pairs of small, slender legs,which are attached ventrallly, near together.
Deprivation of rank or office; degradation. [R.] Milton.
The quality of being original; originality. [R.] Johnson.
One of the three liberal arts forming the trivium. [Obs.]Skelton. Wood.
The land-locked variety of the common salmon. [Canada]
Having the right of electing one's self, or, as a body, ofelecting its own members.
Belonging, or relating, to Latium, a country of ancient Italy.See Latin.

A usage, among diplomats, of rotation in precedence amongrepresentatives of equal rank, sometimes determined by lot and atother times in regular order. The practice obtains in the signing oftreaties and conventions between nations.
A term applied to the action of nerve force in the spinalcenter. Marshall Hall.
The art or profession of a dentist; dental surgery.

Any one of several species of carnivorous animals inhabitingAfrica and Asia, related to the dog and wolf. They are cowardly,nocturnal, and gregarious. They feed largely on carrion, and arenoted for their piercing and dismal howling.
In a shrill manner; acutely; with a sharp sound or voice.
The doctrine or science of the origin of the minerals composingthe globe.
In the first place; before anything else; -- sometimesimproperly used for first.
In hotels, aplan upon which guests pay for both room and boardby the day, week, or other convenient period; -- contrasted withEuropean plan.
The condition or quality of being fortunate; good luck;success; happiness.
Not connectedly; without connection. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A process of reasoning in which each conclusion applies to justsuch an object as each of the premises applies to. Jevons.
The son of Erebus and Nox, whose office it was to ferry thesouls of the dead over the Styx, a river of the infernal regions.Shak.
To expound; to explain; also, to expose; to imperil. [Old Eng.& Scotch] Drummond.
A race run by young men with lighted torches in their hands. Hewho reached the goal first, with his torch unextinguished, gained theprize.
A soft silk, heavier than a foulard and not glossy.
A stable; a shippen. [Obs.]The shepne brenning with the blacke smoke. Chaucer.
A series of muscular contractions due to sudden stretching ofthe muscle, -- a sign of certain neuropathies.
Coincidence, as that of lines or figures laid over one another.
A colorless crystalline slightly sweet substance obtained fromthe molasses of the sugar beet.
The process of chenge into a stony or calcareous substance bythe deposition of lime salt; -- normally, as in the formation of boneand teeth; abnormally, as in calcareous degeneration of tissue.
Having a red color and oily appearance; -- applied to a purplesemifluid substance said to be obtained from archil.
A wasting away from want of nourishment; diminution in bulk orslow emaciation of the body or of any part. Milton.
A large transverse commissure in the third ventricle of thebrain; the middle or soft commissure. B. G. Wildex.
Shaped like one half of a bivalve shell; shell-shaped.
The perforation of a cavity of the body with a trocar,aspirator, or other suitable instrument, for the evacuation ofeffused fluid, pus, or gas; tapping.
In singing, or in the use of the bow, a gradual carrying orlifting of the voice or sound very smoothly from one note to another;a gliding from tone to tone.
To reverse or annul by vote, as a former vote. [R.] Bp, Burnet.
Expelling wind from the body; warning; antispasmodic."Carmenative hot seeds." Dunglison.
One who, or that which, crawls; a creeper; a reptile.
The fighting of two or more persons, in a public place, to theterror of others. Blackstone.
The conversion of a cell wall into a material of a stonynature.
A Philistine; -- a cant name given to townsmen by students inGerman universities.
Tending to the properties of an alkali; slightly alkaline.
Lying outside the visible spectrum at its red end; -- said ofrays less refrangible than the extreme red rays.

The formation belonging to the middle of the three subdivisionsof the Corniferous period in the American Devonian system; -- socalled from Schoharie, in New York, where it occurs. See the Chart ofGeology.
One skilled in shooting at an object with exactness; a goodmarksman.
The emission of semen, or sperm, at other times than in sexualintercourse. Dunglison.
The act of separating a body from others by nonconductors, soas to prevent the transfer of electricity or of heat; also, the stateof a body so separated.
The posture, action, or disposition of a figure or a statue.
A projection, formed by a separate ossification, at thescapular end of the clavicle of many birds.
Pertaining to, consisting of, or resembling, flame. [Obs.] SirT. Browne.
The act of taking by storm and pillaging; sack. [R.] H. Roscoe.
One who, or that which, prepares, fits, or makes ready. Wood.
The flowing of different streams into one. [Obs.] Burton.
Having a tooth or teeth like those of a saw; serrate.
One who interpolates; esp., one who inserts foreign or spuriousmatter in genuine writings.
The skin of a newborn seal; also, the seal itself. [Sealers'Cant]
To bleach by excluding the light, as the stalks or leaves ofplants, by earthing them up or tying them together.
Pertaining to Hybla, an ancient town of Sicily, famous for itsbees.
A radioactive substance apparently formed as a product fromthorium.
Linen goods collectively; linen underwear, esp. of women; theclothing of linen and cotton with its lace, etc., worn by a women.
A scoop or ring with either a blunt or a cutting edge, forremoving substances from the walls of a cavity, as from the eye, ear,or womb.
A place for hiding or preserving articles of value. Cowell.
Sourness or severity of countenance; sterness. [Obs.]
Without; outside' outwardly. Cf. Withinforth. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Botchery; covering of defects; bungling; hypocrisy. [R.] Shak.
An appendage; that which depends on something else, or isdistinct from the main dependence; an accessory. Shak.
A preservative against contagious and infectious diseases, andthe effects of poison in general. Brande & C.

The State of Delaware; -- a popular sobriquet. It is said,though the story lacks proof, to have taken its origin from theinsistence of a Delaware Revolutionary captain, named Caldwell, thatno cock could be truly game unless the mother was a blue hen, whenceBlue Hen's Chickens came to be a nickname for the people of Delaware.
A plant of the genus Arum (A. maculatum); the European wake-robin.
Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, the highest oxygenacid (HIO
The practice of gang robbery in India; robbery committed bydacoits.
A genus of living Brachiopoda; -- so called from its fanciedresemblance to the cranium or skull.
Leaving the neck and shoulders uncovered; cut low in the neck,or low-necked, as a dress.
To throw, as a muscle, into a state of permanent contraction;to cause tetanus in. See Tetanus, n., 2.
A kind of pottery, with opaque glazing and showy, which reachedits greatest perfection in Italy in the 16th century.
One who speaks through the teeth, that is, with the teethclosed.
One who describes the phenomena of galvanism; a writer ongalvanism.
Showing want of respect; disrespectful. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
All; -- a direction for all the singers or players to performtogether. Moore (Encyc. of Music).
In a tender manner; with tenderness; mildly; gently; softly; ina manner not to injure or give pain; with pity or affection; kindly.Chaucer.
The doctrine of atoms. See Atomic philosophy, under Atomic.
Of or pertaining to Cantabria on the Bay of Biscay in Spain.
Divination by means of a child's navel, to learn how manychildren the mother may have. Crabb.
A division of Hymenoptera including those which have anovipositor adapted for perforating plants. It includes the sawflies.
A person so far out of the protection of the law, that if hewere murdered, no geld, or fine, should be paid, or composition madeby him that killed him. Cowell. Burrill.
A pot or vessel in which flesh is cooked; hence (pl.),
State of being ultimate; that which is ultimate, or final;ultimatum. [R.] Swift.
One of the peculiar stinging, cells found in Coelenterata; anematocyst; a lasso cell.
One of the larger divisions of the animal kingdom; a branch; agrand division.
The brush turkey (Talegallus Lathami) of Australia. See Brushturkey.
A peculiar mucilaginous substance extracted from the seeds ofthe quince (Cydonia vulgaris), and regarded as a variety of amylose.
A low, fleshy perennial herb (Glaux maritima) found alongnorthern seashores.

The act of laying down one's testimony in writing; also,testimony laid or taken down in writting, under oath or affirmation,befor some competent officer, and in reply to interrogatories andcross-interrogatories.
To deprive of power; to divest of strength. H. Bushnell.
Without penal restraint; not punishable. [R.] Swift.
The act of resping or breathing; the act of taking in andgiving out air; the aggregate of those processes bu which oxygen isintroduced into the system, and carbon dioxide, or carbonic acid,removed.

To fall or dash against; to touch upon; to strike; to hit; tociash with; -- with on or upon.The cause of reflection is not the impinging of light on the solid orimpervious parts of bodies. Sir I. Newton.But, in the present order of things, not to be employed withoutimpinging on God's justice. Bp. Warburton.

Money paid back or remitted; especially, a certain amount ofduties or customs, sometimes the whole, and sometimes only a part,remitted or paid back by the government, on the exportation of thecommodities on which they were levied. M
A European sting ray of the genus Trygon (T. pastinaca); --called also fireflare and fiery flaw.
A figure by which the ordinary course of thought is inverted inexpression, and the last put first; -- called also hysteron proteron.
Exchange; replacement; substitution; metathesis. [R.]
To come out to the surface of the ground; -- said of strata.
Small steel plates combined together so as to slide one uponthe form a piece of armor.
Having the quality of cementating or uniting firmly.
A half vault; one of the seven artificial motions of a horse,in which he raises his fore legs in a particular manner.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, the studies pursued aftergraduation, esp., after receiving the bachelor's degree at a college;graduate. -- n.

A black pigment found in the pigment-bearing cells of the skin(particularly in the skin of the negro), in the epithelial cells ofthe external layer of the retina (then called fuscin), in the outerlayer of the choroid, and elsewhere. It is supposed to be derivedfrom the decomposition of hemoglobin.
A plant which aids, shelters, or protects another plant in itsgrowth, as those which are used for nurse crops.
The soft celluar substance of the tissues of plants andanimals, like the pulp of leaves, to soft tissue of glands, and thelike.
To move or turn toward the east; to veer from the north orsouth toward the east.
A soft Tertiary sandstone; -- applied to a rock occurring inSwitzerland. See Chart of Geology.
A house of correction for the confinement of disorderlypersons; -- so called from a hospital built in 1553 near St. Bride's(or Bridget's) well, in London, which was subsequently a penalworkhouse.
Having two toes in front and two behind, as the trogons andwoodpeckers.

One of a class of auxiliary numbers, devised by John Napier, ofMerchiston, Scotland (1550-1617), to abridge arithmeticalcalculations, by the use of addition and subtraction in place ofmultiplication and division.

To instruct in the rudiments or principles of learning, or of abranch of learning; to imbue with learning; to instruct in, or imbuewith, principles or doctrines; to teach; -- often followed by in.A master that . . . took much delight in indoctrinating his young,unexperienced favorite. Clarendon.
The state of being saturated; fullness of supply. [Obs.]Warner.
(Mus.) Gradually diminishing in rapidity and loudness.
Resembling, or partaking of the nature of, sulphur; having thequalities of sulphur.
The third day of the week, following Monday and precedingWednesday.
One of the twists, or strings, as of fibers, wires, etc., ofwhich a rope is composed.
A small, flat, wind instrument of music, in which the notes areproduced by the vibration of free metallic reeds.
Applied to that class of literature in which the principalpersonage is the Spanish picaro, meaning a rascal, a knave, a rogue,an adventurer.
Assured by or of one's self; self-reliant; complacent.
Independency; the church system of Independents. Bp. Gauden.
Of both sexes; hermaphrodite; as a flower with stamens andpistil, or an animal having ovaries and testes.
The thick-celled winter or resting spore of the rusts (orderUredinales), produced in late summer. See Illust. of Uredospore.
A stanza or division in lyric poetry, consisting of four versesor lines. Crabb.
The terminal joint or movable piece at the end of the abdomenof Crustacea and other articulates. See Thoracostraca.
To make into a verb; to use as a verb; to verbalize. [R.]Earle.
A large rope made of three strands each containing many yarns.
A deep blue variety of iolite, sometimes used as a gem; --called also saphir d'eau.

An unctuous preparation for external application, of aconsistence intermediate between that of an ointment and a plaster,so that it can be spread upon cloth without the use of heat, but doesnot melt when applied to the skin.
The filling or covering with water or other fluid; overflow;inundation; the filling anything to excess.
An ancient term for embroidery, esp. applied to the earliestform of lace, or to that early embroidery on linen and the like, fromwhich the manufacture of lace was developed.
Trembling; -- used as a direction to perform a passage with ageneral shaking of the whole chord.

The sphere or globular mass of cells (blastomeres), formed bythe clevage of the ovum or egg in the first stages of itsdevelopment; -- called also mulberry mass, segmentation sphere, andblastosphere. See Segmentation.
One who gives publicity, proclaims, or blazons; esp., one whoblazons coats of arms; a herald. Burke.
The Ten Commandments or precepts given by God to Moses on MountSinai, and originally written on two tables of stone.
A cloth woven so as to imitate the appearance of marble; --much used in the 15th and 16th centuries. Beck (Draper's Dict.).
Capable of being defended, or of making or affording defense.[Obs.]No fort so fencible, nor walls so strong. Spenser.
A workman whose business it is to shape boots or shoes, orplace leather smoothly, on lasts; a tool for stretching leather on alast.
A kind of wood common in Demerara, durable in salt water,because not subject to the depredations of the sea worm and barnacle.

The spiritual head of the Armenian church, who resides atEtchmiadzin, Russia, and has ecclesiastical jurisdiction over, andconsecrates the holy oil for, the Armenians of Russia, Turkey, andPersia, including the Patriarchs of Constantinople, Jerusalem, andSis.

That order of the Crinoidea which includes most of the livingand many fossil forms, having jointed arms around the margin of theoral disk; -- also called Brachiata and Articulata. See Illusts.under Comatula and Crinoidea.
A member of an exceeding austere religious order, founded atChartreuse in France by St. Bruno, in the year 1086.
An error in chronology, consisting in an event being datedbefore the actual time.
Act of dispanding, or state of being dispanded. [Obs.]
Lit., may it do (you) good; -- a salutation used in wellwishing, esp. among Germans, as in drinking healths.
A tough, compact mineral, of a white, greenish, or grayishcolor. It is near zoisite in composition, and in part, at least, hasbeen produced by the alteration of feldspar.
The excessive discharge of phosphates in the urine.
A unit of energy, or work, being equal to the work done inraising one pound avoirdupois against the force of gravity the heightof one foot.
Under the tail; -- applied to the bones which support thecaudal fin rays in most fishes.
The agile gibbon; -- called also ungka-pati, and ungka-etam.See Gibbon.
Want of celebrity or distinction; obscurity. [R.] Coleridge.
A band round the crown of a hat; sometimes, a band of blackcloth, crape, etc., worn as a badge of mourning.
The great artery which carries the blood from the heart to allparts of the body except the lungs; the main trunk of the arterialsystem.
A kind of divination by means of figures or lines, formed bylittle dots or points, originally on the earth, and latterly onpaper.
A block, or ring, serving as a guide for the running rigging orfor any rope.
An apparatus, consisting of a number of cells whose sides areof parchment paper, for conducting the process of osmosis. It is usedesp. in sugar refining to remove potassium salts from the molasses.
To render American; to assimilate to the Americans in customs,ideas, etc.; to stamp with American characteristics.
Belonging, or relating, to the secondary or reptilian age, orthe era between the Paleozoic and Cenozoic. See Chart of Geology.
An alkaloid which is the active principle of tobacco. It is acolorless, transparent, oily liquid, having an acrid odor, and anacrid burning taste. It is intensely poisonous. Ure.
A polymeric form of pyridine, C10H10N2, obtained as a colorlessoil by the action of sodium on pyridine.
A morbid condition of the foot in which the toe is depressedand the heel elevated.
That part of the rampart and parapet which is between twobastions or two gates. See Illustrations of Ravelin and Bastion.
A sort of pneumonia occuring in iron workers, produced by theinhalation of particles of iron.
A duck used to lure wild ducks into a decoy; hence, a personemployed to lure others into danger. Beau. & Fl.
The rounded or pointed top of a grinding mill spindle, forminga pivot on which the stone is balanced.
Barriers with loopholes, formerly erected on the deck of avessel to shelter the men in a close engagement with an enemy'sboarders; -- called also close quarters. [Obs.]
Any worm belonging to the Plathelminthes; also, sometimesapplied to the planarians.
The state or office of a coadjutor; joint assistance. Pope.
Cloth treated with oil or paint, and used for marking garments,covering flooors, etc.
One who works in metals, or prepares them for use; one who isskilled in metallurgy.
Having a cheerful spirit and demeanor; good-tempered. See Good-natured.
A disease incident to trees, causing the bark to rot and falloff.
A genus of brachiopods of which some species are still living,while many are found fossil.
One who leads a pack horse; a miller's servant. [Obs. or Local]
A combination of aceric acid with a salifiable base.
The last troop; the rear of an army; a rear guard. Also usedfiguratively. Shak.
To graze cattle promiscuously in the commons of each other, asthe inhabitants of adjoining townships, manors, etc.
An instrument or machine for showing when the sun arrived atthe tropics and equinoctial line.
The fourteenth century, when applied to Italian art,literature, etc. It marks the period of Dante, Petrarch, andboccaccio in literature, and of Giotto in painting.
A person given to idle observation of everything, with wonderor astonishment; a credulous or gossipy idler.
A person whose intellectual development proceeds normally up toabout the eighth year of age and is then arrested so that there islittle or no further development.
Characterized by a glume, or having the nature of a glume.
One of the solid parts of a battlemented parapet; a battlement.See Illust. of Battlement.
A building which is occupied by the guard, and in whichsoldiers are confined for misconduct; hence, a lock-up.
A rough, coarse fellow; collectively, the lowest class of thepeople; the rabble; the riffraff. [Colloq. U.S.]
The doctrine of arts in general; such branches of learning asrespect the arts.
A condition in which the knees are bent in so as to touch eachother in walking; inknee.
The passing off from the sun's disk of an inferior planet, in atransit.
Slight; thin; lean; poor. HavingGrate on their scranned pipes of wretched straw. Milton.
The yellow pigment present in the inner segments of the retinain animals.  See Chromophane.

A method adopted in etching, to keep the acid from those partswhich are already sufficiently corroded, by applying varnish or othercovering matter with a brush, but allowing the acid to act on theother parts.
A circular letter, written or printed for the purpose ofdisseminating news. This was the name given to the earliest Englishnewspapers.
A peplos. Hence: An overskirt hanging like an ancient peplos;also, a short fitted skirt attached to a waist or coat.
A shrub of the blueberry group (Vaccinium stamineum); also, itsbitter, greenish white berry; -- called also squaw huckleberry.
Full of spirit or natural fire; haughty; courageous; impetuous;not brooking restraint or opposition.
To disencumber of a clog, or of difficulties and obstructions;to free from encumbrances; to set at liberty. Shak.
An iron bar made at a single heat from a puddle-ball hammeringand rolling.
All the ground between the ordinary highwater and low-watermarks.
Consisting of starch; resembling starch; stiff; precise.
A genus of papilionaceous herbaceous plants, one species ofwhich (G. glabra), is the licorice plant, the roots of which have abittersweet mucilaginous taste.
A style of interweaving giving to fabrics a channeled or flutedeffect; also, a fabric woven so as to have this effect; a rep.
Divided into two parts, somewhat after the manner of a fork;dichotomous.
A place where the nourishment and care of babies are offeredfor hire.
A genus of highly ornate and brilliantly colored birds ofAustralia, allied to the birds of Paradise.
A hinge having one strap perpendicular and the other straphorizontal giving it the form of an Egyptian or T cross.
Hanging down like gyves or fetters. [Poetic & Rare] Shak.
An order of birds, including the swans, ducks, geese,flamingoes and screamers.
Having the quality of contracting, binding, or compressing.Thomson.
Satisfied with one's self or one's actions; self-complacent.
Arranged in five vertical rows; pentastichous. Gray.
Previous ordination or appointment; predetermination;predestination.
One who would exclude another from some right or privilege;esp., one of the anti-popish politicians of the time of Charles
Home-returning; -- used specifically of carrier pigeons.
Wicked in the extreme; abominable; iniquitous; atrociouslyvillainous; execrable; detestably vile.
One who hangs another; esp., one who makes a business ofhanging; a public executioner; -- sometimes used as a term ofreproach, without reference to office. Shak.
Indefiniteness; vagueness; also, number or quantity not limitedby our understanding, though yet finite. [Obs.] Sir M . Hale.
An impassable road or way; a  blind alley; cul-de-sac; fig., aposition or predicament affording no escape.
One who announces; a messenger; a nuncio. [Obs.] Hoole.
One who makes a practice of giving or selling tips, or privatehints or information, esp. for use in gambling upon the probableoutcome of events, as horse races.
A mineral of a white to yellowish, purplish, or emerald-greencolor, occuring in prismatic crystals, often of great size. It is asilicate of aluminia and lithia. See Hiddenite.
Pertaining to the cuticle, or external coat of the skin;epidermal.
Applied to coarse cloth made of undyed wool, formerly worn byScotch peasants. [Scot.]
Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid compoundof platinous cyanide and hydrocyanic acid. It is obtained as acinnaber-red crystalline substance.
A division of Ctenophora including those which have two longtentacles.
The breaking out of pimples, or an efflorescence, as inmeasles, scarlatina, etc.
The act of furnishing, or of supplying furniture; also,furniture. [Obs.] Daniel.
In a rabbinical manner; after the manner of the rabbins.
Relating to a type or types; belonging to types; serving as atype; typical. Owen.
A place where roses are cultivated; a nursery of roses. SeeRosary, 1.
Marked with spots and patches of white and some color otherthan black; -- usually distinguished from piebald, in which thecolors are properly white and black. Said of horses.
A compound decomposable, or subjected to decomposition, by anelectric current.
An ordinary with its ends cut off, borne sinister as a mark ofbastardy, and containing one fourth in breadth of the bend sinister;-- called also bastard bar. See Bend sinister.
A certificate given to one who prosecutes a felon toconviction, exempting him from certain parish and ward offices.
Of or pertaining to typhus; of the nature of typhus.
A cereal grass (Triticum vulgare) and its grain, whichfurnishes a white flour for bread, and, next to rice, is the grainmost largely used by the human race.
A mobile liquid, CO.N.C6H5, of pungent odor. It is the phenylsalt of isocyanic acid.
The state or quality of being irregular; that which isirregular.
A genus of very large lizards native of Asia and Africa. Itincludes the monitors. See Monitor, 3.

To speak through the nose; to breathe through the nose when itis obstructed, so as to make a broken sound.One clad in purple Eats, and recites some lamentable rhyme . . .Snuffling at nose, and croaking in his throat. Dryden.
A distilled liquor prepared in Mexico from a species of agave.See Agave.

A composite plant (Artemisia Absinthium), having a bitter andslightly aromatic taste, formerly used as a tonic and a vermifuge,and to protect woolen garments from moths. It gives the peculiarflavor to the cordial called absinthe. The volatile oil is a narcoticpoison. The term is often extended to other species of the samegenus.
The act of throwing up froth or scum; separation of the scum orimpurities from liquids; scumming; clarification.
A steamboat having a stern wheel instead of side wheels.[Colloq. U.S.]
The round hole in the furnace of a glass manufactory throughwhich the fused glass is taken out. Craig.
The state or quality of being irresoluble; insolubility.
Existence from eternity equally with another eternal being;equal eternity.
Calculated to arrest attention; ostentatiously fashionable;showy. [Colloq.]
A genus of composite herbs, several of which are cultivated foesalad; lettuce.
To imbue with the principles of abolitionism. [R.] Bartlett.
A sucking whale less than one year old; -- so called bysailors.
So named; called by such a name (but perhaps called thus withdoubtful propriety).

The nut of an Australian tree (Macadamia ternifolia). It isabout an inch in diameter, and contains a single round edible seed,or sometimes two hemispherical seeds. So called from Queensland inAustralia.
The process by which feldspar is changed into kaolin.
A small kind of whale, of the genus Globicephalus, of severalspecies. The most common is G. melas. Also sometimes applied to otherwhales of larger size.
A bag in which feed for a horse, ox, or the like, may befastened under the nose by a string passing over the head.
An expansion at the base of the style, as in umbelliferousplants.
a simple thread lace worked upon a pillow with coarse thread;also, a similar lace made by machinery.
A trammel, or hook to support a pot over a fire. Knight.
The act of blocking up; the state of being blocked up.
One skilled in geometry; a geometer; a mathematician.
Inverted in position; appearing to be upside down or reversed,as the flowers of the orchis and the leaves of some plants.
Culture, training, or education of one's self by one's ownefforts.

A right formerly claimed by the states of the German Empire ofjoining their own ministers with those of the emperor in publictreaties and negotiations to the common interest of the empire.Encyc. Brit.
Liable to be accused or censured; chargeable with a crime orfault; blamable; -- with of.
Having, or characterized by, four digits to the foot or hand.
A weakening or cessation of the contractile power of the heart.
A lasso cell, or thread cell. See Lasso cell, under Lasso.
To stand up; to be erected; to rise. Spenser. Milton.At once upstood the monarch, and upstood The wise Ulysses. Cowper.
In the old Norse mythology, the gods Odin, Thor, Loki, Balder,Frigg, and the others. Their home was called Asgard.
A large family of dicotyledonous plants, having their flowersarranged in dense heads of many small florets and their anthersunited in a tube. The daisy, dandelion, and asters, are examples.
A cantata relating to rural life; a composition for instrumentscharacterized by simplicity and sweetness; a lyrical composition thesubject of which is taken from rural life. Moore (Encyc. of Music).
A toy which imitates the sound of tearing cloth, -- used bydrawing it across the back of unsuspecting persons. [Eng.]
The median plate of the plastron of turtles; -- called alsoentosternum.
To boil or cook again; hence, to make over; to vamp up; toreconstruct. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
To lead a military life; to carry on continual wars. Camden.
A compound or twin crystal consisting of four individuals.
An evergeen seashore plant (Eryngium maritimum). See Eryngium.
A white crystalline substance, C27H55.OH, obtained from Chinesewax, and regarded as an alcohol of the marsh gas series; -- calledalso cerotic alcohol, ceryl alcohol.
The small hollow curvature given to the top or bottom of theshaft of a column where it expands to meet the edge of the fillet; --called also the scape. Parker.
A clerk, precentor, singer, or leader of music, in the church.
One who owns; a rightful proprietor; one who has the legal orrightful title, whether he is the possessor or not. Shak.
A fortune teller; one who pretends to reveal mysteries. [Obs.]Hudibras.
A piece of timber which terminates the keel at the fore end,connecting it with the lower end of the stem.

The art of inducing an extraordinary or abnormal state of thenervous system, in which the actor claims to control the actions, andcommunicate directly with the mind, of the recipient. See Animalmagnetism, under Magnetism.
A twisted cord; also, a molded or worked ornament of similarform.
One of a sacerdotal college of fifteen men whose chief duty wasto take care of the Sibylline books.
The state or quality of being inadmissible, or not to bereceived.
A leaf-cutting bee of the genus Megachilus. See Leaf cutter,under Leaf.
An iron with a flat, smooth surface for ironing clothes.
One who instructs by question and answer, especially inreligions matters.
One who plots or schemes; a contriver; a conspirator; aschemer. Dryden.

The mutual influence, under certain conditions, of two streamsof light, or series of pulsations of sound, or, generally, two wavesor vibrations of any kind, producing certain characteristicphenomena, as colored fringes, dark bands, or darkness, in the caseof light, silence or increased intensity in sounds; neutralization orsuperposition of waves generally.
The inosculation of vessels, or intercommunication between twoor more vessels or nerves, as the cross communication betweenarteries or veins.
To make incapable of harmony, or of harmonious action; to putout of tune. Shak.
Of or pertaining to Moschus, a genus including the musk deer.
Capable of rooting out, or tending to root out. Cheyne.
A tribe of North American Indians who occupied Western New Yorkand part of Ohio, but were driven away and widely dispersed by theIroquois.
One who is skilled in zymology, or in the fermentation ofliquors.
The process of breaking up the flat masses into which wroughtiron is first hammered, in order that the pieces may be reheated andwrought into bar iron.
The quality of being arduous; difficulty of execution.
One whose voice appears to proceed from the stomach; aventriloquist. [Obs.]
The Lord's day or Sunday; also, the Lord's prayer. [Obs.]
The name popularly given to the rich man in our Lord's parableof the "Rich Man and Lazarus" (Luke xvi. 19-31). Hence, a name for arich worldling.
Pertaining to, or designating, a force producing magnetic flux,analogous to electromotive force, and equal to the magnetic fluxmultiplied by the magnetic reluctance.
A greenish chloritic mineral common in certain igneous rocks,as diabase, as a result of alternation.
A sore on the back or hips caused by lying for a long time inbed.
One who employs synthesis, or who follows synthetic methods.
Judgment; discrimination. See Dijudication. [Obs.] Boyle.

An affection of the kidneys, usually inflammatory in character,and distinguished by the occurrence of albumin and renal casts in theurine. Several varieties of Bright's disease are now recognized,differing in the part of the kidney involved, and in the intensityand course of the morbid process.
Pertaining to annunciation; announcing. [R.] Dr. H. More.
Not simultaneous; not concurrent in time; --opposed tosynchronous.
The act of individuating or state of being individuated;individualization. H. Spencer.

The viscid and more or less granular material of vegetable andanimal cells, possessed of vital properties by which the processes ofnutrition, secretion, and growth go forward; the so-called " physicalbasis of life;" the original cell substance, cytoplasm, cytoblastema,bioplasm sarcode, etc.
A salt formed by the union of hydrotelluric acid and the base.
The belly and its contents; the abdomen; also, the firststomach, or rumen, of ruminants. See Rumen.
The art or process of measuring the amount of salt in asubstance.
A condition in which glucose is discharged in the urine;diabetes mellitus.
The unoin or articulation of bones to form a joint.
A cancer. By some medical writers, the term is applied to anindolent tumor. See Cancer. Dunglison.
Material for strouds; a kind of coarse cloth used in trade withthe North American Indians.
(Mus.) A Turkish instrument of music, with a hollow bodycovered with skin, over which five strings are stretched. [Writtenalso kussir.]

A small bar of gold and silver, either pure, or alloyed in someknown proportion with copper, for trying the purity of articles ofgold or silver by comparison of the streaks made by the article andthe bar on a touchstone.
A genus of North American shrubs with poisonous evergreenfoliage and corymbs of showy flowers. Called also mountain laurel,ivy bush, lamb kill, calico bush, etc.
A South African antelope (Oryx Capensis), having long, sharp,nearly straight horns.
A primary by which direct nominations of candidates for officeare made.
An animal of the barnacle tribe, of the genus Lepas, having afleshy stem or peduncle; a goose barnacle. See Cirripedia.
Any leglike appendage of a crustacean, when modified wholly, orin part, to serve as a jaw, esp. one of the maxillipeds.
A coarse fish of India, used in making a breakfast relishcalled burtah.
Pertaining to whetstones; like or suitable for whetstones.
A genus of herbs, mostly with yellow flowers, includingcrowfoot, buttercups, and the cultivated ranunculi (R. Asiaticus, R.aconitifolius, etc.) in which the flowers are double and of variouscolors.
A great collection of ore without any vein coming into it orgoing out from it.
An instrument or machine for measuring work done, especiallyfor ascertaining the number of rotations made by a machine or wheelin manufacturing cloth; a counter. Ure.
Having the nature or appearance of a radix or root.
To take leave with the customary civilities; to bow orcourtesy.
In Gothic vaulting, any rib which does not spring from theimpost and is not a ridge rib, but passes from one boss orintersection of the principal ribs to another.
Having a cramp or square piece at the end; -- said of a crossso furnished.
An Indo-European people, allied to the Lithuanians and OldPrussians, and inhabiting a part of the Baltic provinces of Russia.
A fault in a casting, produced by a bubble of air; a blowhole.
Having the quality of mitigating or curing fever. Boyle.
A mark or signature peculiar to an individual; a trade-mark.
One of the two most experienced barristers in the Court ofExchequer, who have precedence in motions; -- so called from theplace where he sits. The other of the two is called the tubman.Whishaw.
Displeasure; discontent; annoyance. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A curve from which another curve, called the involute orevolvent, is described by the end of a thread gradually wound uponthe former, or unwound from it. See Involute. It is the locus of thecenters of all the circles which are osculatory to the given curve orevolvent.
Of an excitable or irritable temperament; irascible. Milton.
Derived from, or dependent upon, vital processes; -- said ofcertain electric currents supposed by some physiologists to circulatein the nerves of animals.
In plastering, a particularly good troweled surface. Knight.
Quality or state of being weasy; full feeding; sensualindulgence. [Obs.] Joye.
The third or middle finger; the third digit, or that whichcorresponds to it.
A wind instrument of the double reed kind, furnished withholes, which are stopped by the fingers, and by keys, as in flutes.It forms the natural bass to the oboe, clarinet, etc.
The possession of dovelike qualities, harmlessness andinnocence. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Pertaining to, or consisting of, minutes. [Obs.] Fuller.
Helmet-shaped; -- applied to a corolla having a broad, helmet-shaped upper petal, as in aconite.
Spread over the surface of the ground; procumbent. Gray.
Nitrate of calcium, a substance having a grayish white color,occuring in efforescences on old walls, and in limestone caves,especially where there exists decaying animal matter.
A bowl or vessel made from a gourd. [Local, New York] Bartlett.
A genus of exogenous polypetalous plants, embracing about onehundred and eighty species. See Saxifrage.
The act of gathering the vintage, or crop of grapes.
To agitate or discuss beyond what is expedient. Bp. Hall.
One who misobserves; one who fails to observe properly.
To fold and sew down the edge of with a coarse zigzag stitch.
A boy; fellow; esp., a serving boy or man; a waiter; -- in Eng.chiefly applied to French waiters.
Full of kernels; resembling kernels; of the nature of kernels.Holland.
A trough used by miners to receive the powdered ore from thebox where it is beaten, or for carrying water to the stamps, or otherapparatus, for comminuting, or sorting, the ore.
A word used as a shout of joy, exultation, approbation, orencouragement.
The operation of sewing up a laceration of the neck of theuterus.
The doctrines or principles of the Novatians. Milner.
A line connecting the points on the surface of the earth wherea certain temperature is found at the same depth.
One who converses much, or who excels in conversation. Byron.

An elementary substance; a metal which combined with oxygenforms lime. It is of a pale yellow color, tenacious, and malleable.It is a member of the alkaline earth group of elements. Atomic weight40. Symbol Ca.
A worsted yarn or cord of peculiar smoothness, used in themanufacture of braid, fringe, etc. Simmonds.
The snuff, or burnt wick, of a candle. [Obs.] Bacon.
Virtually involved or included; involved in substance;inferential; tacitly conceded; -- the correlative of express, orexpressed. See Imply.
A sloping plain, esp. one with the upper end at the crest of acliff; a hill or ridge with one face steep and the opposite facegently sloping. [Southwestern U. S.]
That erodes or gradually eats away; tending to erode;corrosive. Humble.
A powerful vegetable alkaloid, C17H19NO5, extracted from theColchicum autumnale, or meadow saffron, as a white or yellowishamorphous powder, with a harsh, bitter taste; -- called alsocolchicia.
A mineral, found in crystals, of a yellow to green or browncolor, and consisting of aluminia and glucina. It is very hard, andis often used as a gem.
An aboriginal tribe inhabiting the southern part ofKamtschatka.
The period intervening between one celebration of the Pythiangames and the next.
A former French money of account worth 20 sous, or a franc. Itwas thus called in distinction from the Paris livre, which contained25 sous.
A soft solid made by incorporating a medicinal substance orsubstances with sugar, sirup, or honey.
Shaped like a plipper, as one petal of the lady's-slipper;calceolate.
Destitute of pores; very close or compact in texture; solid.Sir T. Browne.
the taking away from a clergyman his benefice, or otherspiritual promotion or dignity.
Same as Carl, 3. Carling Sunday, a Sunday in Lent when carlsare eaten. In some parts of England, Passion Sunday. See Carl, 4.

An apparatus in which the image of an external object orobjects is, by means of lenses. thrown upon a sensitized plate orsurface placed at the back or an extensible darkened box or chambervariously modifled; -- commonly called simply the camera.
A person attached to a particular pursuit, study, or science asto music or painting; esp. one who cultivates any study or art, fromtaste or attachment, without pursuing it professionally.
A silicate of iron and lime occurring in black prismaticcrystals; -- also called ilvaite. [Spelt also jenite.]
To convert into vapor, as by the application of heat, whethernaturally or artificially. Vaporizing surface. (Steam Boilers) SeeEvaporating surface, under Evaporate, v. t.
A mud volcano, the water of which is often impregnated withsalts, whence the name.
In an affecting manner; is a manner to excite emotions.
The act of unraveling, or the state of being unraveled.
A slave who led his master's children to school, and had thecharge of them generally.
The act or operation of cutting, to relieve the structure instrangulated hernia. [Frequently written kelotomy.]
A yellow or greenish yellow gas, first prepared by Davy,evolved from potassium chlorate and hydrochloric acid. It is supposedto consist of chlorine tetroxide with some free chlorine.
Opening during the day, and closing at night; -- said offlowers or leaves.
The act of bothering, or state of being bothered; cause oftrouble; perplexity; annoyance; vexation. [Colloq.]
A bickern; a bench anvil with a long beak, adapted to reach theinterior surface of sheet metal ware; the horn of an anvil.
The science which treats of the complex relations of livingcreatures to other organisms, and to their surrounding conditionsgenerally. St. George Mivart.
Situated near or beside the occipital condyle or the occipitalbone; paramastoid; -- applied especially to a process of the skull insome animals.
Infllammation of the nose; esp., inflammation of the mucousmembrane of the nostrils.
To deprive of blessings; to make wretched. [Obs.] Shak.
A colorless liquid hydrocarbon resembling oil of turpentine,obtained by dehydrating menthol. It has an agreeable odor and acooling taste.
A Bohemian dance of two kinds, one in triple time, like awaltz, the other in two-four time, like a polka. The former is mostin use.
An East Indian insectivore (Tupaia ferruginea). It is arborealin its habits, and has a bushy tail. The fur is soft, and varies fromrusty red to maroon and to brownish black.
Western; being in the west; occidental. [Poetic] Milton.
One versed in the science of exegesis or interpretation; --also called exegete.

A white crystalline aldehyde having a burning taste andcharacteristic odor of vanilla. It is extracted from vanilla pods,and is also obtained by the decomposition of coniferin, and by theoxidation of eugenol.
A place where rags are bought and kept for sale. [Eng.]
The condition, pursuits, or occupation of a virtuoso. Bp. Hurd.
Applied to those days when the holy sacrifice is not offered.Shipley.
A number of hermitages or cells in the same neighborhoodoccupied by anchorites who were under the same superior. C. Kingsley.
The act of deranging or putting out of order, or the state ofbeing deranged; disarrangement; disorder; confusion; especially,mental disorder; insanity.

A rare element of the chromium group, occurring in nature inthe minerals molybdenite and wulfenite, and when reduced obtained asa hard, silver-white, difficulty fusible metal. Symbol Mo. Atomicweight 95.9.
