A substance which sheathes a part, or blunts irritation,usually some bland, oily, or mucilaginous matter; -- nearly the sameas demulcent. Forsyth.
Of or pertaining to stichs, or lines; consisting of stichs, orlines. [R.]
To make prolific; to fertilize; to impregnate. Sir T. Browne.
The act of rearranging, or the state of being rearranged.
The gigantic sugar pine of California and Oregon (PinusLambertiana). It has the leaves in fives, and cones a foot long. Thetimber is soft, and like that of the white pine of the EasternStates.
Situated around the vitellus, or between the vitellus and zonapellucida of an ovum.
A soldier in a body of cavalry; a cavalryman; also, the horseof a cavalryman.
Made by transposing; consisting in transposition; transposable.
A kind of small onion (Allium Ascalonicum), native ofPalestine; the eschalot, or shallot.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, debility of the vitalpowers; weak.
A method of surveying or map making by photography, used alsoin determining the height and motions of clouds, sea waves, and thelike.
Not having, or not governed by, reins; hence, not checked orrestrained.
A liquor, generally spirituous in which a bitter herb, leaf, orroot is steeped.
A plant of the genus Campanula; -- so named from its bell-shaped flowers.
An eye, bud, or shoot, as of a plant; an oilet. [Obs.] Holland.
A small European lamprey (Petromyzon branchialis); -- calledalso prid, and sandpiper.
To trepan. [Obs.] "By trepanizing the skull." Jer. Taylor.
A fold of the wall which projects into the cavity of theintestine in bivalve mollusks, certain annelids, starfishes, and someother animals.
Invocation of evil spirits; witchcraft. [Obs.] Hallywell.
A style of painting, sculpture, or other imitative art, whichillustrates everyday life and manners.
A name applied to various skin diseases, but especially toringworm. See Ringworm, and Sycosis.
An extensive division of ganoids, including the gar pike,bowfin, etc.; the bony ganoids. See Illustration in Appendix.
A division of Coleoptera having, apparently, only four tarsaljoints, one joint being rudimentary.
A stiff wire brush for cleaning iron castings and other metal.
A constituent part of a species of gum from Bassora, as also ofgum tragacanth and some gum resins. It is one of the amyloses. Ure.
A powerfully narcotic and intoxicating gum resin which exudesfrom the flower heads, seeds, etc., of Indian hemp.
In a regular manner; in uniform order; methodically; in dueorder or time.
The quality or condition of being reciprocal; reciprocalness.[R.]
A slender knife for use in the operation of tenotomy.
Having a typically small size; of or pertaining to themicrosthenes.
The one who wields the bat in cricket, baseball, etc.
A short line used in drawing and engraving, especially inshading and denoting different surfaces, as in map drawing. SeeHatching.
A name given by English miners to sphalerite, or zinc blende; -- called also false galena. See Blende.
The board used in the game of chess, having eight rows ofalternate light and dark squares, eight in each row. SeeCheckerboard.
The breastplate of the armor of a horse. See Peytrel. [Obs.]Chaucer.
One of a tribe of beetles which feed upon dacaying animal andvegetable substances; a carrion beetle.
An oval figure on monuments, and in papyri, containing the nameof a sovereign.
The quality of resembling a brush; brushlike condition;shagginess. Dr. H. More.
Three letters united in pronunciation so as to have but onesound, or to form but one syllable, as -ieu in adieu; a triphthong.
A viaduct, pier, scaffold, or the like, resting on trestlesconnected together.
One who holds a prior to purchase certain public land. Abbott.
A introductory portion; an introduction or preface, as to abook, document, etc.; specifically, the introductory part of astatute, which states the reasons and intent of the law.
One of the less volatile hydrocarbons of coal tar, obtained asa white crystalline substance, C16H10.
One who holds the doctrine of the real objective presence ofChrist;s body and blood in the holy eucharist. Shipley.
The manners of a courtier; courtliness. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
The act of prefiguring; prefiguration; also, that which isprefigured. Carlyle.
A follower of Eutyches [5th century], who held that the divineand the human in the person of Christ were blended together as toconstitute but one nature; a monophysite; -- opposed to Nestorian.
An honorary payment, usually in recognition of services forwhich it is not usual or not lawful to assign a fixed business price.Heumann.
A complex nitrogenous substance, produced as a yellowcrystalline substance, and regarded as a complex derivative ofbarbituric acid.
A cavern or cavity, esp. an anatomical cavity or sinus. Huxley.
The close linen or muslin cap of an old woman. [Prov. Eng. &Scot.]
Straight forward; in a straight direction. [Archaic] Sir P.Sidney.
A genus of oceanic nudibranchiate mollusks having the smallbranched gills situated on the upper side of four fleshy laterallobes, and on the median caudal crest.
Having two units of combining power; bivalent. Cf. Valence.
A concretion, or kind of bezoar, from the intestines of thehorse.
Madam; Mrs; -- a title of address or respect among theItalians.
The act of vitriolizing, or the state of being vitriolized;vitriolation.
One who offers in sacrifice; specifically, one of a sect ofRussian fanatics who practice self-mutilatio and sacrifice.
A disease in horses and swine, in which the upper part of thethroat, or groups of lymphatic glands elsewhere, swells.
To divide, as the heavens, into twelve houses. See House, inastrological sense. [Obs.]
One who alienates or transfers property to another. Blackstone.
To start up; to befall; to escape; to shun. [Obs.] Spenser.
An instrument for determining and recording the differentphases, as the intensity, velocity, etc., of a muscular contraction.
The South American hairy armadillo (Dasypus villosus).

The mutual pleas and replies of the plaintiff and defendant, orwritten statements of the parties in support of their claims,proceeding from the declaration of the plaintiff, until issue isjoined, and the question made to rest on some single point.Blackstone.
The act of expilating or stripping off; plunder; pillage.[Obs.]This ravenous expiation of the state. Daniel.
To rend in pieces. [Obs.]The wolf hath many a sheep and lamb to-rent. Chaucer.
A blasting powder or dynamite composed of nitroglycerin, woodfiber, sodium nitrate, and magnesium carbonate.
A sterile plain, containing an excess of alkali, at the bottomof an undrained basin in an arid region; a playa.
Pertaining to, consisting of or resembling, ice; icy. Sir T.Browne.
The mildest form of epilepsy, with momentary faintness orunconsciousness, but without convulsions; -- opposed to grand mal.
The penis or clitoris, or the embryonic or primitive organ fromwhich either may be derived.
A small decorative object without practical utility.
The American white-fronted goose (Anser albifrons).
In the middle of a ship, with regard to her length, andsometimes also her breadth. Totten.
A woman who violates her religious engagements. James iv. 4.
The act of flustering, or the state of being flustered;fluster. [Colloq.]
To weed, or clear of weeds, with a hoe. [Obs.] Ainsworth.
One who, or that which, sweetens; one who palliates; that whichmoderates acrimony.
An old cry in throwing water, slops, etc., from the windows inEdingburgh. Sir. W. Scott.
A conductor; an officer in the ancient church who gave thesignal for the choir to sing, and who beat time with the hand, andregulated the music. Moore (Encyc. of Music.)
The quality or state of being shoddy. [Colloq.] See the Noteunder Shoddy, n.
A device attached to a mowing machine for raising the uncutfallen grain and marking the limit of the swath.
Not isomeric; not made of the same components in the sameproportions.
A leguminous plant of the genus Ervum (Ervum Lens), of smallsize, common in the fields in Europe. Also, its seed, which is usedfor food on the continent.
Confirmation or ratification (as of something otherwise nulland void), by a court or a grantor.
A universal remedy; -- name formerly to a purgative electuary.
The quality or state of being marvelous; wonderfulness;strangeness.

A school for young children, conducted on the theory thateducation should be begun by gratifying and cultivating the normalaptitude for exercise, play, observation, imitation, andconstruction; -- a name given by Friedrich Froebel, a Germaneducator, who introduced this method of training, in rooms opening ona garden.
One who makes an unlawful rescue; a rescuer. Burril.
A fleshy plant (Arenaria peploides) growing in large tufts inthe sands of the northern Atlantic seacoast; -- called also seasandwort, and sea purslane.
A principle of grammar; a grammatical rule. [Obs.] Dalgarno.
One who hypothecates or pledges anything as security for therepayment of money borrowed.

One who, or that which, extracts; as:(a) (Surg.) A forceps or instrument for extracting substances.(b) (Breech-loading Firearms) A device for withdrawing a cartridge orspent cartridge shell from the chamber of the barrel.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a vanadic acid analogous tometaphosphoric acid.
A weight, consisting of two spheres or spheroids, connected bya short bar for a handle; used (often in pairs) for gymnasticexercise.
A colorless, crystalline, aromatic hydrocarbon, C6H2(CH3)4, offartificial production, with an odor like camphor.
One of the smooth areas surrounding the tubercles of a seaurchin.
Either of the feasts of the Holy Cross, occuring on May 3 andSeptember 14, annually.
A double sulphide of antimony and iron, of a dark steel-graycolor.
The white indris of Madagascar. It is regarded by the nativesas sacred.
An extinct genus of cyathophylloid corals common in thePaleozoic formations. It is cup-shaped with numerous septa, and witha deep pit in one side of the cup.
The science of languages, or of the origin, signification, andapplication of words; glossology.
Pertaining to, or designating, certain days allowed to thepretor for hearing causes, when be might speak the threecharacteristic words of his office, do, dico, addico. They werecalled dies fasti.

The quality of being magnanimous; greatness of mind; elevationor dignity of soul; that quality or combination of qualities, incharacter, which enables one to encounter danger and trouble withtranquility and firmness, to disdain injustice, meanness and revenge,and to act and sacrifice for noble objects.
The operation of making a permanent opening into the stomach,for the introduction of food.
A metrical foot composed of a short syllable and two long ones;according to some, two long and a short.
One who conceals himself board of a vessel about to leave port,or on a railway train, in order to obtain a free passage.
A court of justice; judgment hall. [R.] J. S. Mill.
One of an order of nuns established on the principles of theJesuits, but suppressed by Pope Urban in 1633.
Plumbago; graphite.It leaves a blackish mark somewhat likelead. See Graphite.
To adjust wrongly of unsuitably; to throw of adjustment. I.Taylor.
An instrument, intended to represent the revolution of a cometround the sun. Hutton.
To arrange (types) in a composing stick in order for printing;to set (type).
A public room where coffee and other refreshments may beobtained.
A splinter or fragment, as of wood or stone. See Spall.
A white waxy solid, C16H33.OH; -- called also cetylic alcohol.See Cetylic alcohol, under Cetylic.
A sweet cake or cooky containing aromatic seeds, as caraway.Tusser.
An instrument for measuring shells, or the angle of theirspire.
A two-masted Arab or Indian trading vessel, used in IndianOcean.
Firewood cut into billets of a certain length. [Obs.] [Eng.]
One who describes lichens; one versed in lichenography.
A kind of minuet, in triple time, of French origin, popular inthe reign of Queen Elizabeth and for some time after; -- called alsopassing measure, and passymeasure. Percy Smith.
Partaking of the nature both of vegetable and animal matter; --a term sometimes applied to vegetable albumen and gluten, from theirresemblance to similar animal products.
One who uses abusive slang; a ranting partisan. [Colloq. orHumorous] W. Irving.
A false or erroneous trial; a trial which has no result.
The group of Thysanura which includes Lepisma and allied forms;the bristletails. See Bristletail, and Lepisma.
Having the marginal florets enlarged and radiating but notligulate, as in the capitula or heads of the cornflower, Gray.
The quality of being unacceptable; unacceptableness.
The goddess of rural leisure, to whom the husbandmen sacrificedat the close of the harvest. She was especially honored by theSabines.
A degraded tribe of California Indians; -- so called from theirpractice of digging roots for food.

A telephonic instrument for office or other similar use, havinga sound-magnifying device enabling the ordinary mouthpiece to bedispensed with. Much use has been made of it for overhearing, or forrecording, conversations for the purpose of obtaining evidence foruse in litigation.
A double chloride of platinum and some other metal or radical;a salt of platinochloric acid.
Of or pertaining to rachitis; affected by rachitis; rickety.
The quality or state of being suitable; suitableness.
That which is undergoing putrefaction; the products ofputrefaction.
The art or practice of measuring distances or lengths. Cheyne.
A pipe for leading combustible gases downward from the top ofthe blast furnace to the hot-blast stoves, boilers, etc., where theyare burned.
The showing in court of a sufficient lawful reason why a partycharged or accused did that for which he is called to answer.
Having a throat which produces a shrill note. [R.] Shak.
An oblique-angled parallelogram like a rhomb, but having onlythe opposite sides equal, the length and with being different.
Good as a remedy against disease of the spleen.-- n.
To induct, as a bishop, into the powers and privileges of avacant see.

Disconnected; separated; distinct; -- a direction to performthe notes of a passage in a short, distinct, and pointed manner. Itis opposed to legato, and often indicated by heavy accents writtenover or under the notes, or by dots when the performance is to beless distinct and emphatic.
One of the claque employed to applaud at a theater.
A common herb of the Mint family (Brunela vulgaris), destituteof active properties, but anciently thought a panacea.
An instrument for measuring angles for determining elevations,distances, etc.
The representation of a mantle, or the drapery behind andaround a coat of arms: -- called also lambrequin.
A caldron of boiling water into which an accused person plungedhis forearm as a test of innocence or guilt.
A goose-neck apparatus for supplying water from an elevatedtank, as to the tender of a locomotive.
The act of making rich; enrichment. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
A tribe of Indians which formerly occupied the region ofNorthern Illinois, allied in language to the Sacs and Foxes.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, the poppy or opium; specif.(Chem.), designating an acid related to aconitic acid, found in opiumand extracted as a white crystalline substance.
A machine in which four pulleys act together. Brande & C.
The state, activity, or enjoyment of animals; mere animal lifewithout intellectual or moral qualities; sensuality.
A gab at the end of an eccentric rod, with long jaws, shapedlike the letter V.
The philosophy of modern thinkers who follow Kant in hisgeneral theory of knowledge, esp. of a group of German philosophersincluding F. A. Lange, H. Cohen, Paul Natorp, and others.
Pairing with several males; -- said of certain fishes of whichseveral males accompany each female during spawning.
In a balloon, the braced wooden ring attached to the suspensionropes at the bottom, functionally analogous to the keel of a ship.

A very large and important genus of grasses, found in nearlyall parts of the world. It includes the lemon grass of Ceylon and thebeard grass, or broom sedge, of the United States. The principalsubgenus is Sorghum, including  A. sorghum and A. halepensis, fromwhich have been derived the Chinese sugar cane, the Johnson grass,the Aleppo grass, the broom corn, and the durra, or Indian millet.Several East Indian species, as A. nardus and A. schonanthus, yieldfragrant oils, used in perfumery.

A pie made of apples (usually sliced or stewed) with spice andsugar. Apple-pie bed, a bed in which, as a joke, the sheets are sodoubled (like the cover of an apple turnover) as to prevent any onefrom getting at his length between them. Halliwell, Conybeare.-- Apple-pie order, perfect order or arrangement. [Colloq.]Halliwell.
A loan upon goods laden on board a ship. It differs frombottomry, which is a loan on the ship itself. Bouvier.
As much as an urn will hold; enough to fill an urn.
Of or pertaining to Malta or to its inhabitants.-- n. sing. & pl.
The state of being widowed or bereaved; loss; bereavement. [R.]
Chief ruler; monarch; sovereign; -- a title of the Sultan ofTurkey, and of the Shah of Persia.
An earth of a deep brown color, containing more vegetable thanmineral matter; an earthy variety of lignite, or brown coal.
A genus of American jurassic dinosaurs. A length of sixty feetis believed to have been attained by these reptiles.
A raised part of the floor of a large room; a platform for araised table or throne. See Dais.
One who commutes; especially, one who commutes in traveling.
Lit., my lord; hence (as used on the Continent), an Englishnobleman or gentleman.

Plants having distinct flowers and true seeds. { 1.Dicotyledons (called also Exogens).-- Seeds with two or more cotyledons. Stems with the pith, woodyfiber, and bark concentrically arranged. Divided into two subclasses:Angiosperms, having the woody fiber interspersed with dotted orannular ducts, and the seed contained in a true ovary; Gymnosperms,having few or no ducts in the woody fiber, and the seeds naked. 2.Monocotyledons (called also Endogens).-- Seeds with single cotyledon. Stems with slender bundles of woodyfiber not concentrically arranged, and with no true bark.} II.Cryptogamia.
Any small moth of the genus Aspidisca, whose larva makes ashieldlike covering for itself out of bits of leaves.
Privation or destitution of blood; -- opposed to plethora.Dunglison.
Having a charge in each of the four corners; -- said of a crosson a shield, and also of the shield itself.
A compound containing a relatively large amount of carbon. [R.]
One who watches; one who sits up or continues; a diligentobserver; specifically, one who attends upon the sick during thenight.

A yellow pigment imported from India and China. It has a strongodor, and is said to be obtained from the urine of herbivorousanimals when fed on the mango. It consists if a magnesium salt ofeuxanthic acid. Called also puri, purree, and Indian yellow.
According to the rule of obedience. [R.]An obediental subjection to the Lord of Nature. Sir M. Hale.

A high priest. Especially:(a) One of the sacred college, in ancient Rome, which had the supremejurisdiction over all matters of religion, at the head of which wasthe Pontifex Maximus. Dr. W. Smith.(b) (Jewish Antiq.) The chief priest.(c) (R. C. Ch.) The pope.
A yellow, crystalline, organic base, C13H12N2O, obtainedartificially.
To graft by uniting, as a scion, to a stock, without separatingeither from its root before the union is complete; -- also called tograft by approach. P. Miler.
To cause (a vessel) to lean over so that she floats on oneside, leaving the other side out of water and accessible for repairsbelow the water line; to case to be off the keel.
To loosen or separate by dissolving the glue which unties; tounglue.
To wait or watch for; to be on guard against. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A bird of prey of the Hawk family, belonging to the genus Buteoand related genera.
An association, including both Japanese and Europeans, havingfor its object the changing of the Japanese method of writing bysubstituting Roman letters for Japanese characters.
Any atom, group, or radical substituted for another, orentering a molecule in place of some other part which is removed.
An extensive artificial group of gastropods comprising allthose which have a spiral shell and the foot attached to the base ofthe neck.
Fawning or obsequious behavior; servility. [R.] Bailey.
Pertaining to, or resembling, the devil Mephistopheles, "acrafty, scoffing, relentless fiend;" devilish; crafty.
The hypothesis, or doctrine, that living beings have originatedby the modification of some other previously existing forms of livingmatter; -- opposed to abiogenesis. Huxley.
Giving life or spirit; having power to give life; inspiriting;invigorating.

The first Sunday after Easter Sunday, properly Albless Sunday,because in the early church those who had been baptized on Easter evelaid aside on the following Saturday their white albs which had beenput on after baptism.

The habit of lurking about dwelling houses, and other placeswhere persons meet fro private intercourse, secretly listening towhat is said, and then tattling it abroad. The offense is indictableat common law. Wharton.
The quality or state of being irascible; irritability oftemper; irascibleness.
Expressing the agreement of the two terms of a proposition.
Having many names or titles; polyonymous. Sir W. Jones.
The science of water, its properties, phenomena, anddistribution over the earth's surface.
Containing, pertaining to, or of the nature of, coprolites.
In a manner to excite horror; dreadfully; terribly.
A white crystalline base, C3H7NO2, derived from aldehydeammonia.
A sweet and juicy variety of European grape, of a dark purplishblack color, much grown under glass in northern latitudes.
In a small quantity or degree; with minuteness. [R.] Ascham.
Pertaining to, or used for, the determination of the amount ofozone; of or relating to ozonometry.
A recording or registering tachometer; also, its autographicrecord.
Capable of being, or liable to be, overturned or subverted.
An explosive consisting essentially of nitroglycerin, woodmeal, and some nitrate, as that of sodium.
An appearance as of a halo of light, surround the edges of darkobject
A morbid an uncontrollable craving (often periodic) for drink,esp. for alcoholic liquors; also improperly used to denote acute andchronic alcoholism.
dealing with (a person or problem) directly; taking the bull bythe horns.Syn. -- braving, coping with, grappling, tackling.[WordNet 1.5 +PJC]
Of or pertaining to strontium; containing, or designating thecompounds of, strontium.
The constellation Charles's Wain, or Ursa Major. See Ursamajor, under Ursa.
An epic poem attributed to Homer, which describes the return ofUlysses to Ithaca after the siege of Troy.
A warbler of the United States (Dendroica striata).
A composition in three voice parts; a vocal (rarely aninstrumental) trio.
Retention or suppression of the menstrual discharge.

Anciently, one to whom lands were given; in later use, one towhom lands and tenements are given in tail; in modern use, one onwhom a power is conferred for execution; -- sometimes called theappointor.
A little elevation of earth made by a mole; a molehill.Mortimer.
A toll for passage through a forest. [Obs.] Cowell.
A preacher; -- so called in contempt. [Obs.] Howell.
A vagrant; an idle, sturdy beggar; a vagabond; a tramp.
One who, or that which, lodges; one who occupies a hired roomin another's house.
A small portion; a pittance; a little bit. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
Spray blown from the tops waves during a gale at sea; also,snow driven in the wind at sea; -- written also spindrift.
Transcending, or reaching beyond, the limits of humanknowledge; -- applied to affirmations and speculations concerningwhat lies beyond the reach of the human intellect.
The process of making blooms from the ore or from cast iron.
The quality or state of being weighty; weight; force;importance; impressiveness.
Jumping, or inducing to jump; characterized by jumps; hence,extremely nervous.
A division of Mammalia in which the placenta is zonelike.
A soft, compact stone, of a grayish, greenish, or yellowishcolor, carved into images by the Chinese, and hence called figurestone, and pagodite. It is probably a variety of pinite.
The giving of evidence on the part of a plaintiff to destroythe effect of evidence introduced by the defendant in the same suit.
A starch or arrow-root made from the tubes of an East Indianzinziberaceous plant (Curcuma angustifolia); also, the plant itself.
Excessive use of the pronoun we; -- called also weism. [Colloq.or Cant]
To strew with verbena, or vervain, as in ancient sacrifices andrites.
Capable of being exhausted, drained off, or expended. Johnson.
Forming or resembling a sheath or case. Sir T. Browne.
Any American marsupial of the genera Didelphys and Chironectes.The common species of the United States is Didelphys Virginiana.
Inclined to worry or fret; also, causing worry or annoyance.
The catamenial or menstrual discharge, a periodic flow of bloodor bloody fluid from the uterus or female generative organs.
Increasing; on the increase; -- said of the moon represented asthe new moon, with the points turned toward the dexter side.
The American elk (Cervus Canadensis). It is closely related tothe European red deer, which it somewhat exceeds in size.
A government by many chiefs, princes, or rules. [Obs.]Cudworth.
The gilthead (Crenilabrus melops), a fish of the Britishcoasts.
Relating to the chair or office of a teacher. [Obs.]
A genus of bitter herbs or shrubs having eight stamens and atwo-celled ovary (as the Seneca snakeroot, the flowering wintergreen,etc.); milkwort.
A term sometimes applied to the effects (tetanus) produced inthe muscles of the limbs, when a current of electricity is passedalong the spinal cord or nerves.
A morgue; a place for the temporary reception and exposure ofdead bodies.
The act or process of reducing from the state of an oxide.
Of or pertaining to a repast, especially to dinner.
A form of madness in which the patient conceives himselfpossessed of devils.
Any organ or part of the body (as the kidneys, skin, etc.,)which serves to carry off excrementitious or waste matter.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex acid related tomesitylenic acid, obtained as a white crystalline substance by theaction of sodium and carbon dioxide on crude xylenol.
An instrument for ascertaining the specific gravity of liquids.
An old wife; an old woman; -- correlative of gaffer, an oldman.
One of certain small prominences on the hind part of the faceof an elephant's tooth.
That portion of the real estate of a man which his widow enjoysduring her life, or to which a woman is entitled after the death ofher husband. Blackstone.
To coat or impregnate with rubber or a rubber solution orpreparation, as silk.
One of a family of beetles having the maxillary palpiterminating in a hatchet-shaped joint.
A movable furrowed piece of steel struck by the flint, to throwsparks into the pan, in an early form of flintlock. Knight.
A contagious disease of horses, associated with painfululcerating enlargements, esp. upon the head and limbs. It is of thesame nature as glanders, and is often fatal. Called also farcin, andfarcimen.
The hypothetical hydrocarbon radical CH, regarded as anessential residue of certain organic compounds.
That part of a discourse which recites the time, manner, orconsequences of an action, or simply states the facts connected withthe subject.
One who, or that which, interposes; an interloper, an opponent.[R.] Heywood.

A rare metallic element of the platinum group, found native asan alloy in platinum ore, and in iridosmine. It is a hard, infusible,bluish or grayish white metal, and the heaviest substance known. Itstetroxide is used in histological experiments to stain tissues.Symbol Os. Atomic weight 191.1. Specific gravity 22.477.
One of a group of carabid beetles having slender palpi.

An instrument used by various savage races for throwing aspear; -- called also throw stick and spear thrower. One end of thestick receives the butt of the spear, as upon a hook or thong, andthe other end is grasped with the hand, which also holds the spear,toward the middle, above it with the finger and thumb, the effectbeing to bring the place of support nearer the center of the spear,and practically lengthen the arm in the act of throwing.
An intermediate product formed in the gastric digestion ofalbuminous matter.
An ode in honor of a victor in the Olympic games. [R.] Johnson.
Half a poetic verse or line, or a verse or line not completed.
Of or pertaining to the interval of the octave and the fourth.
The black and white standard of the Knights Templars.
One of the sinuous tracks on the surfaces of many stones, andpopularly considered as worm trails.
An edible marine fish of California (Rhacochilus toxotes).
A condition of excessive fever; an elevation of temperature ina disease, in excess of the limit usually observed in that disease.
That part of the reserve force in Germany which is called outlast.
Having a short and thick neck like that of a bull. Sir W.Scott.
One who compiles; esp., one who makes books by compilation.
With affection; lovingly; fondly; tenderly; kindly.
One who believes in a sibyl or the sibylline prophecies.Cudworth.
A leguminous plant (Genista tinctoria) of Europe and RussianAsia, and adventitious in America; -- called also greenwood,greenweed, dyer's greenweed, and whin, wood-wash, wood-wax, and wood-waxen.
Long-toed boots or shoes formerly worn in many parts of Europe;-- so called from Cracow, in Poland, where they were first worn inthe fourteenth century. Fairholt.
The quality or habit of being lenient; lenity. [Obs.] Blount.
Of or pertaining to Rhodes, an island of the Mediterranean.-- n.

According to the French method of numeration (which method isfollowed also in the United States) the number expressed by a unitwith twenty-seven ciphers annexed. According to the English method,the number expressed by a unit with forty-eight ciphers annexed. SeeNumeration.
A list of servants in a household; -- called also chequer roll.

The wood of any one of several different kinds of trees; also,any one of the trees themselves. Among the trees so called are theCladrastis tinctoria, an American leguminous tree; the severalspecies of prickly ash (Xanthoxylum); the Australian FlindersiaOxleyana, a tree related to the mahogany; certain South Africanspecies of Podocarpus, trees related to the yew; the East IndianPodocarpus latifolia; and the true satinwood (Chloroxylon Swietenia).All these Old World trees furnish valuable timber.
A turkish fabric of silk and cotton, with gold threadinterwoven.
Goggles intended to rectify strabismus by permitting visiononly directly in front. Knight.
The quality or state of being triple, or threefold; trebleness.In their trinal triplicities on high. Spenser.
Incapable of doing either harm or good, as some medicines.Dunglison.
The estimation of the specific gravity of urine by theurinometer.
One of two corresponding copies of an instrument; a duplicate.
An ignorant and degraded Turanian tribe which occupies aportion of Northern Russia and a part of Siberia.Samoyeds.
One who sanctifies, or makes holy; specifically, the HolySpirit.
An apparatus for bringing artificial light down from achandelier nearer to a table or desk; a pendant.
A gaseous compound of hydrogen and nitrogen, NH3, with apungent smell and taste: -- often called volatile alkali, and spiritsof hartshorn.
A game like California Jack, except that the pack drawn from isturned face down.
The state or manner of a barbarian; lack of civilization.
The Dragon, a northern constellation within which is the northpole of the ecliptic.
To collect specimens in the study of entomology. C. Kingsley.
Alternately disposed on exactly opposite sides of the stem soas to from two ranks; distichous.
The soft woolly hair which covers most parts of the mammalfetus, and in man is shed before or soon after birth.
Shouting together for joy; rejoicing together. [R.] Neale.
The act of tantalizing, or state of being tantalized. Gayton.
Toward the outside or surface; -- opposed to entad. B. G.Wilder.
The quality or state of being whimsical; freakishness;whimsical disposition.

A proceeding in the nature of a prosecution for some offensagainst the government, instituted and prosecuted, really ornominally, by some authorized public officer on behalt of thegovernment. It differs from an indictment in criminal cases chieflyin not being based on the finding of a grand juri. See Indictment.
The quality of being incorporeal; immateriality. Berkeley.
The act of polishing, or the state of being polished. [R.]
The art of operation of restoring lost parts or the normalshape by the use of healthy tissue.
Having a great belly, bigbellied; pregnant; teeming. Shak.
To deprive of the entrails; to disembowel. Dr. H. More.
The act of cutting away the knots of trees. [R.] Crabb.
A pointed instument for clearing the teeth of substances lodgedbetween them.
To give an Egyptian character or appearance to. Fairbairn.
That which is egested or thrown off from the body by thevarious excretory channels; excrements; -- opposed to ingesta.
Deprived of the foreskin; circumcised. [R.] Milton.
A morbid growth or deposit of bony matter between or on thesmall pastern and the great pastern bones. J. H. Walsh.
One who hands over or transmits; a conveyer in succession.Dryden.
A metallic mineral, a selenide of copper and silver; -- socalled by Berzelius on account of its being found soon after thediscovery of the metal selenium.
A jar or bottle, as of porous earthenware, in which water iscooled by evaporation.
The act of dashing or striking against. Sir T. Browne.

The old name, in Scotland, for the last day of the year, onwhich children go about singing, and receive a dole of bread orcakes; also, the entertainment given on that day to a visitor, or thegift given to an applicant. [Scot.]
An ornamental bordering or framelike decoration around thesides and top of a door, window, or fireplace. The top piece iscalled the traverse and the side pieces the ascendants.
A hydrous carbonate of copper and zinc, found in pale green orblue crystalline aggregations. It yields a kind of brass onreduction.
A species of seaweed. [Spelled also slowcawn.] See 3d Laver.
The mouth to the grate of a furnace; also, the space in frontof the furnace, where the stokers stand.
That may be sailed over, as water or air; navigable.
A curved sheath or breasting for a revolving cylinder or roll.
The Egyptian sycamore (Ficus Sycamorus). See Sycamore.
Of or pertaining to the sacrum; in the region of the sacrum.
A mild kind caustic used to reduce warts and otherexcrescences. Dunglison.
The second crust formed in port and some other wines after longkeeping. It consists of pure, shining scales of tartar, supposed toresemble the wing of a bee.
A treatise upon fish or the art of fishing; ichthyology.
The doctrine concerning those things of which we arenecessarily ignorant.
A curve generated by a point in the plane of a circle when thecircle is rolled along a straight line, keeping always in the sameplane.
Containing mammalian remains; -- said of certain strata.
That doctrine which refers all phenomena to a single ultimateconstituent or agent; -- the opposite of dualism.
Not neighborly; distant; reserved; solitary; exclusive.-- adv.
Succession by turns; alternation. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Animal cellulose; a substance present in the mantle, or tunic,of the Tunicates, which resembles, or is identical with, thecellulose of the vegetable kingdom.
Having the quality of reverberation; reverberating.
The general appearance and manner of life of a living organism.
The act or process of titrating; a substance obtained bytitrating.
An alkaloid obtained as a yellow amorphous substance by thedecomposition of veratrine.
To indue or imbue (a body) with soul. [R.] Emerson.
Having the teeth inserted in sockets in the alveoli of thejaws.
To place or fix firmly or permanently. [Obs.] Shak.
Not to stimulate; to soothe; to quiet. [Obs.] Cheyne.
A painful spasmodic contraction of the vagina, often renderingcopulation impossible.
To burn with a sudden and sparkling combustion, as niter; also,to snap and crackle with slight explosions when heated, as salt.
The expressing of the sounds of a language by syllables, ratherthan by an alphabet or by signs for words. I. Taylor (The Alphabet).
Condition of being circumjacent, or of bordering ou every side.
In an organic manner; by means of organs or with reference toorganic functions; hence, fundamentally. Gladstone.
Admitting of being performed, done, or executed; practicable.
In an apprehensive manner; with apprehension of danger.
A miracle worker; -- a title given by the Roman Catholics tosome saints.
The pouch in which incubation takes place in some Tunicata.
A salt well known as a catharic under the name of Glauber'ssalt, which term is properly applied to the hydrate, Na2SO4.10H2O.

A yellowish red, crystalline substance, C20H12O5, produced byheating together phthalic anhydride and resorcin; -- so called, fromthe very brilliant yellowish green fluorescence of its alkalinesolutions. It has acid properties, and its salts of the alkalies areknown to the trade under the name of uranin.
Having a natural contrariety; adverse; antipathetic. [Obs.]Beau. & Fl.

A symbolical acknowledgment made by a feudal tenant to, and inthe presence of, his lord, on receiving investiture of fee, or comingto it by succession, that he was his man, or vassal; profession offealty to a sovereign.
A plant of several species of the Mint family, cultivated forits bright-colored or variegated leaves.

Eating or feeding on flesh. The term is applied: (a) to animalswhich naturally seek flesh for food, as the tiger, dog, etc.; (b) toplants which are supposed to absorb animal food; (c) to substanceswhich destroy animal tissue, as caustics.
An ambiguous speech; a figure in which a word is used anequivocal sense. [R.]
One who sells anything; one whose occupation is to sell goodsor merchandise.
An Egyptian deity, at first a symbol of the Nile, and so offertility; later, one of the divinities of the lower world. Hisworship was introduced into Greece and Rome.
One who wears a red coat; specifically, a red-coated Britishsoldier.
In an arduous manner; with difficulty or laboriousness.
One who defrauds; a cheat; an embezzler; a peculator.
The formation of ova or eggs in the ovary, and the discharge ofthe same. In the mammalian female the discharge occurs duringmenstruation.
The interval embracing six diatonic degrees of the scale.
A neutral organic substance found in the root of the elecampane(Inula helenium), and extracted as a white crystalline or oilymaterial, with a slightly bitter taste.
One who, or that which, plies; specifically: (a) pl.
Belonging to Belgravia (a fashionable quarter of London, aroundPimlico), or to fashionable life; aristocratic.
Of or pertaining to union or unionists; tending to promote orpreserve union.

A white crystalline substance having a bitter taste, extractedfrom the buds of levant wormseed and used as an anthelmintic. Itoccassions a peculiar temporary color blindness, causing objects toappear as if seen through a yellow glass.
A line connecting or marking points on the earth's surface,which have the same mean summer rainfall.
An annual variety of Brassica oleracea, or cabbage of which thecluster of young flower stalks and buds is eaten as a vegetable.
Appearing as if overlaid with a thin layer of different color;-- said of the colors of certain birds and insects.
A treatise on amphibious animals; the department of naturalhistory which treats of the Amphibia.
The caudal plate of trilobites, crustacean, and certaininsects. See Illust. of Limulus and Trilobite.
A cessation of arms for a short time, by convention; atemporary suspension of hostilities by agreement; a truce.
Compatible; suitable; consistent. [Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
In a manner to please nice taste; with elegance; with duesymmetry; richly.
The act of passing over a strait or narrow sea. [Obs.] Sir J.Davies.
The quality of being amenable; amenableness. Coleridge.
An articular surface on the ilium of birds against which thegreat trochanter of the femur plays.
A division of Crinoidea including numerous fossil species inwhich the body is covered with tessellated plates.
Pertaining to, or designed for, the measurement of endosmoticaction.
A person born in India, of mixed Indian and British blood; ahalf-caste. Malcom.
A species of Spanish grass (Macrochloa tenacissima), of whichcordage, shoes, baskets, etc., are made. It is also used for makingpaper.
Any marine saurian; esp. (Paleon.) the large extinct species ofMosasaurus, Icthyosaurus, Plesiosaurus, and related genera.
An aquatic bird, the glaucous gull (Larus glaucus), common inarctic regions.
The dark coloring matter of the liquid of the cuttlefish.
Of or pertaining to the sea; -- sometimes applied to rocksformed from sediments deposited upon the sea bottom.
A genus of small glassy heteropod mollusks found swimming atthe surface in mid ocean. See Heteropod.
Specifically, a grandfather; more generally, any ancestor.
Having only one petal, or the corolla in one piece, or composedof petals cohering so as to form a tube or bowl; gamopetalous.
To corrupt; to defile; to contaminate. [Obs.] Blount.

Any person connected with an army, or within the lines of anarmy, who does not make it his business to fight, as any one of themedical officers and their assistants, chaplains, and others; also,any of the citizens of a place occupied by an army; also, any oneholding a similar position with respect to the navy.
Turnip-shaped; large and round in the upper part, and veryslender below.
Half or imperfectly vitrified; partially converted into glass.
To move uneasily one way and the other; to move irregularly, orby fits and starts. Moore.
Any one of several species of small American minnows of thegenus Fundulus, as F. catenatus.
A convex molding of rounded surface, generally from half tothree quarters of a circle.

A species of Smilax (S. Pseudo-China) growing from New Jerseyto the Gulf of Mexico, which has very large tuberous and farinaceousrootstocks, formerly used by the Indians for a sort of bread, and bythe negroes as an ingredient in making beer; -- called also bamboobrier and China brier.
A kind of sandal worn by Indians and the lower classesgenerally; --usually used in pl. [Southern U. S. & Mex.]
A hard, black variety of vulcanite. It may be cut and polished,and is used for many small articles, as combs and buttons, and forinsulating material in electric apparatus.
One of the two orders of Nemerteans. See Nemertina.
The membrane of fibrous connective tissue which closely investsall bones except at the articular surfaces.
A light, liquid food, made by boiling meal of maize, oatmeal,or fiour in water or milk; thin porridge.
A granule of chlorophyll; -- also called chloroleucite.

A certain quantity of fur skins, as of martens, ermines,sables, etc., packed between boards; being in some cases forty skins,in others one hundred and twenty; -- called also timmer. [Writtenalso timbre.]
Reproduction without the union of parents of distinct sexes:asexual reproduction.
One who furbishes; esp., a sword cutler, who finishes swordblades and similar weapons.
Of or pertaining to the monandria; having but one stamen.
The offense of transporting wool or sheep out of Englandcontrary to the statute formerly existing. Blackstone.
The act or process of making ether; specifically, the processby which a large quantity of alcohol is transformed into ether by theagency of a small amount of sulphuric, or ethyl sulphuric, acid.
A form of rifled cannon and small arms invented by Sir JosephWhitworth, of Manchester, England.
A follower of Donatus, the leader of a body of North Africanschismatics and purists, who greatly disturbed the church in the 4thcentury. They claimed to be the true church.
Having a single floral envelope, that is, a calyx without acorolla, or, possibly, in rare cases, a corolla without a calyx.
The game of cards called also all fours, and old sledge. [U.S.]
The third estate, or commonalty, in France, answering to thecommons in Great Britain; -- so called in distinction from, and asinferior to, the nobles and clergy.
In union; conjointly; unitedly; together. Sir W. Hamilton.
Any compound containing two amido groups united with one ormore acid or negative radicals, -- as distinguished from a diamine.Cf. Amido acid, under Amido, and Acid amide, under Amide.
A young larval form of many annelids, mollusks, and bryozoans,in which a circle of cilia is developed around the anterior end.
The state of being everlasting; endless duration; indefiniteduration.
Having the filaments of the stamens divided into two parts.
To dwell in; to abide within; to remain in possession.The Holy Ghost became a dove, not as a symbol, but as a constantlyindwelt form. Milman.
Failure to alienate; also, the state of not being alienated.
Of or pertaining to the class Diandria; having two stamens.
A term used for the Powder of Algaroth, a white powder which isa compound of trichloride and trioxide of antimony. It was formerlyused in medicine as an emetic, purgative, and diaphoretic.
Any one of the colored substances found in animal and vegetabletissues and fluids, as bilirubin, urobilin, chlorophyll, etc.
A disease attended with inflammation and ulceration of thecolon and rectum, and characterized by griping pains, constant desireto evacuate the bowels, and the discharge of mucus and blood.
The quality or state of being tortile, twisted, or wreathed.
Having a single heart, as fishes and amphibians.-- n.
An affection of the windpipe of a horse, causing a loud,peculiar noise in breathing under exertion; the making of the noiseso caused. See Roar, v. i., 5.

A concrete juice produced by various trees found in the Malayanarchipelago, especially by the Isonandra, or Dichopsis, Gutta. Itbecomes soft, and unpressible at the tamperature of boiling water,and, on cooling, retains its new shape. It dissolves in oils andethers, but not in water. In many of its properties it resemblescaoutchouc, and it is extensively used for many economical purposes.The Mimusops globosa of Guiana also yields this material.

A telegraphic alphabet in very general use, inventing by SamuelF.B.Morse, the inventor of Morse's telegraph. The letters arerepresented by dots and dashes impressed or printed on paper, as, .-(A), -... (B), -.. (D), . (E), .. (O), ... (R), -- (T), etc., or bysounds, flashes of light, etc., with greater or less intervalsbetween them.
The state of being curvilinear or of being bounded by curvedlines.
Originally, a nickname for a member of the conservative sectionof the Democratic party in New York; hence, one opposed to progressin general; a fogy. [Political Cant, U.S.]
A mixture of ore, cinders, etc., used to line the hearth of apuddling furnace. [Eng.] [It is commonly called fix in the UnitedStates.]
A garment resembling a long frock coat worn by the clergy ofcertain churches when officiating, and by others as the usually outergarment.
To go back; to return to a former place or state. Sir T.Browne.
A skin disease marked by the development or irregular yellowishpatches upon the skin, especially upon the eyelids; -- called alsoxanthelasma.
One who undoes anything; especially, one who ruins another.
The state of being a swordsman; skill in the use of the sword.Cowper.
The doctrine or science of light, explaining its nature andphenomena; optics.
To struggle in extreme pain; to be in agony; to agonize.
An impure earthy or coaly bitumen, which emits a highly fetidodor when burning.
A private memorial tendered to a court, in which a person setsforth his cause of action; the exhibiting of an action in writing.Blackstone.
A band of gray matter bordering the fimbria in the brain; thedentate convolution. Wilder.
A bitter principle found in the bark of the privet (Ligustrumvulgare), and extracted as a white crystalline substance with a warm,bitter taste; -- called also ligustron.
One who discusses; one who sifts or examines. Wood.
A glass vessel or bottle, especially a small bottle formedicines; a vial.
The covering of a seed; -- sometimes limited to the outer coator testa. Lindley.
The bell or vase of the Corinthian capital. [Improperly soused.] Gwilt.
Anything employed for the observation of light or luminouseffects.
Things gotten by a man's own industry, or purchased with hisown money, as opposed to things which come to him by descent. Mozley& W.
Pertaining to the development of electricity, especiallyelectrical currents, by power; producing electricity or electricalcurrents by mechanical power.
One who, or that which, drives away smoke or fumes.
Not capable of being passed over; insuperable; insurmountable.
A size of type between great primer and double pica. See theNote under Type.
A place where the business of canning fruit, meat, etc., iscarried on. [U. S.]
The quality of being maidenly; the behavior that becomes amaid; modesty; gentleness.
The act of synchronizing; concurrence of events in respect totime.
One of the ordinary zooids of the Bryozoa. [Spellt alsopolypid.]
To pardon; to overlook the offense of; esp., to forgive for aviolation of the marriage law; -- said of either the husband or thewife.
In the manner of alternatives, or that admits the choice of oneout of two things.
A flask in which gunpowder is carried, having a charging tubeat the end.
Highly actinic light, derived from sunlight or from some formof electric lamp, used in the treatment of lupus and other cutaneousaffections.
A command to a horse, probably meaning "stand still." [Obs.]Chaucer.
Pertaining to, or resembling, garum. Sir T. Browne.
To spray (tobacco) with a liquid intended to produce flavor oraroma.
An instrument for measuring currents, especially the force orintensity of electrical currents; a galvanometer.
The science which treats of the structure, functions, anddiseases of the eye.
That part of the lower floor of a theater with seats at therear of the parquet and beneath the galleries; -- called also, esp.in U. S., orchestra circle or parterre.
Producing, or relating to, epipolism or fluorescence. [R.]
One who crams; esp., one who prepares a pupil hastily for anexxamination, or a pupil who is thus prepared. Dickens.
A portion of the mesoblast (of peripheral origin) of thedeveloping embryo, the cells of which are especially concerned informing the first blood and blood vessels. C. S. Minot.
The quality or state of being voluble (in any of the senses ofthe adjective).
An order of marine Crustacea, mostly of small size.
Pertaining to or resembling Dr. Johnson or his style; pompous;inflated.
The process of forming an artificial tip or part of a lip, byusing for the purpose a piece of healthy tissue taken from someneighboring part.
Of or pertaining to the first Frankish dynasty in Gaul orFrance.-- n.
A glucoside extracted from the bark of the oak (Quercus) as abitter citron-yellow crystalline substance, used as a pigment andcalled quercitron.
A kind of bindweed (Convolvulus arvensis).He bare a burden ybound with a broad list, In a withewyndes wiseybounden about. Piers Plowman.
Of or pertaining to Vesta, the virgin goddess of the hearth;hence, pure; chaste.
The character or dignity of a thane; also, thanes,collectively. J. R. Green.
The power of exciting the organs of the brain by magnetic ormesmeric influence.
One who practices allopathy; one who professes allopathy.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid of titaniumanalogous to metasilicic acid.
The quality or condition of being navigable; navigableness.
Haughty manner or spirit; haughtiness; pride; arrogance.
An oilskin hat or southwester; -- a fisherman's name. [U. S.]
A genus of acanthopterygious fishes which includes the commonmackerel.
One who resolves religion into prayer. [Obs.] Gauden.
Dissimilar; incongruous; unsuitable. [Obs.] Cudworth.
The custom, or tribal law, which prohibits marriage betweenmembers of the same tribe; marriage outside of the tribe; -- opposedto endogamy. Lubbock.
The assumption of several structural forms without acorresponding difference in function; -- said of sponges, etc.
A sexual zooid, or medusoid bud of a hydroid; a gonophore. SeeHydroidea, and Illust. of Campanularian.
The dried tubers of various species of Orchis, and Eulophia. Itis used to make a nutritious beverage by treating the powderedpreparation with hot water. U. S. Disp.

A small water bird (Podilymbus podiceps), allied to the grebes,remarkable for its quickness in diving; -- called also dapchick,dobchick, dipchick, didapper, dobber, devil-diver, hell-diver, andpied-billed grebe.
A silver coin of Japan, worth about thirty-four cents. [Writtenalso itzebu, ichebu, itcheboo, etc.]
A colorless gaseous hydrocarbon (C3H6) of the ethylene series,having a garlic odor. It occurs in coal gas, and is producedartificially in various ways. Called also propene.
A collection of, or a treatise on, maxims, grave sentences, orreflections. [Obs.] Milton.
A person who is especially devoted to the cultivation oftulips. Sir T. Browne.
An alkaloid produced by the action of hydrochloric acid onsolanidine, as a tasteless yellow crystalline substance.
Intellectual powers; possession of intellect; quality of beingintellectual.
A genus of trees growing naturally on the Andes in Peru andadjacent countries, but now cultivated in the East Indies, producinga medicinal bark of great value.
To investigate, or relate the history of, descents.
Liability to be removed or dismissed from office. [R.] T.Jefferson.
One who has been married three times; also, one who has threehusbands or three wives at the same time.
Any signal giving information about the weather. The systemused by the United States Weather Bureau includes temperature, coldor hot wave, rain or snow, wind direction, storm, and hurricanesignals.
Having power to inform, animate, or vivify. Dr. H. More.
A wind associated with a volcanic outburst and due to theeruption or to convection currents over hot lava.
Self-conceited; forward; pushing. [Colloq.] Halliwell.
A curtain or screen; also, a cotton fabric in blue and whitestripes, used for curtains. McElrath.
A substance extracted from the rootstock of the Polygala Senega(Seneca root), and probably identical with polygalic acid.
The condition of the Helots or slaves in Sparta; slavery.
A beam acting as a tie, as at the bottom of a pair of principalrafters, to prevent them from thrusting out the wall. See Illust. ofTimbers, under Roof. Gwilt.
False or imaginary feeling or sense perception such as occursin hypochondriasis, or such as is referred to an organ that has beenremoved, as an amputated foot.
A northern gull (Rissa tridactyla), inhabiting the coasts ofEurope and America. It is white, with black tips to the wings, andhas but three toes.
A dealer in furs; one who makes or sells fur goods.

With a constantly increasing volume of voice; with graduallyincreasing strength and fullness of tone; -- a direction for theperformance of music, indicated by the mark, or by writing the wordon the score.
Not prejuged; unprejudiced; impartial. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A person of a perverse understanding or obstinate character.[R.]
One who entices; one who incites or allures to evil. Burton.
Abatement of a morbid process, as a fever and return to anormal condition. [Obs.]
A certain portion of lands, tithes, and offerings, for themaintenance of the parson of a parish.

A tussock moth (Ocneria dispar) native of the Old World, butaccidentally introduced into eastern Massachusetts about 1869, whereits caterpillars have done great damage to fruit, shade, and foresttrees of many kinds. The male gypsy moth is yellowish brown, thefemale white, and larger than the male. In both sexes the wings aremarked by dark lines and a dark lunule. The caterpillars, when full-grown, have a grayish mottled appearance, with blue tubercles on theanterior and red tubercles on the posterior part of the body, allgiving rise to long yellow and black hairs. They usually pupate inJuly and the moth appears in August. The eggs are laid on treetrunks, rocks, etc., and hatch in the spring.
One whose business is to draw up conveyances of property, asdeeds, mortgages, leases, etc. Burrill.
The disorganization or disarming of troops which havepreviously been mobilized or called into active service; the changefrom a war footing to a peace footing.
A white wax, made by bleaching and purifying ozocerite, andused as a substitute for beeswax.
A king who has sovereignty over inferior kings or rulingprinces. J. R. Green.
Curved so that the apex hangs down; having the top bentdownward.

A gold coin, first made in the reign of Edward IV., having astar on the reverse resembling the rowel of a spur. In the reigns ofElizabeth and of James I., its value was fifteen shillings. [Writtenalso spur-rial, and spur-ryal.]
Filled with white flakes; mothery; -- said vinegar whencontaining mother. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
A piece of parchment, or paper, containing a recognizance orbail bond.
A member of the king's council; a king's councilor. Burrill.
Of or relating to the city or the university of Oxford,England. Macaulay.
Inflammation of the cellular tissue in the vicinity of theuterus.
The state or quality of being fitted; adaptation. [Obs.] Dr. H.More.

A method of phonetic printing of the English language, asdevised by Mr. Pitman, in which nearly all the ordinary letters andmany new forms are employed in order to indicate each elementarysound by a separate character.
A small plate covering the armpit in armor of the 14th centuryand later.
One who thrusts in the banderillas in bullfighting.  W. D.Howells.
Contradictory; inconsistent; opposing. [R.] Milton.
The legalized use of one metal only, as gold, or silver, in thestandard currency of a country, or as a standard of money values. SeeBimetallism.
A zinc-carbon cell in which the zinc (amalgamated) issurrounded by dilute sulphuric acid, and the carbon by nitric acid ora chromic acid mixture, the two plates being separated by a porouscup.
The quality or state of being rectilinear. Coleridge.
Applied to boiled potatoes cut into small pieces and heated inoil or butter. They are usually flavored with onion and parsley.
The act or manner of feeding. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A horse that moves with a high step or proud gait; hence, aperson having a proud bearing. [Colloq.]
Of or pertaining to islands; full of islands. Cotgrave.

A light canoe, made of skins stretched over a frame, andusually capable of carrying but one person, who sits amidships anduses a double-bladed paddle. It is peculiar to the Eskimos and otherArctic tribes.
To change into another shape or form; to transform. [Writtenalso transhape.] Shak.
A recapitulation, in the peroration, of the heads of anargument.
A variety of tourmaline varying in color from a pale rose to adeep ruby, and containing lithium.

A colorless crystalline substance, C6H3.CH3.(OH)2, which isobtained from certain lichens (Roccella, Lecanora, etc.), also fromextract of aloes, and artificially from certain derivatives oftoluene. It changes readily into orcein.
A partition in a vessel, to separate apartments on the samedeck.
A bony tube which, in some birds, connects the tympanium withthe air chambers of the articular piece of the mandible.
Lit., King of Heaven; -- a title of the emperor of Japan as thehead of the Shinto religion.
One who inoculates; one who propagates plants or diseases byinoculation.
A writ of command to suspend the powers of an officer incertain cases, or to stay proceedings under another writ. Blackstone.
Not to be influenced or moved by prayers; obdurate. [R.]Wyclif.
Abounding in sap; resembling, or consisting lagerly of,sapwood.
The production of two or more embryos in one seed, due eitherto the existence and fertilization of more than one embryonic sac orto the origination of embryos outside of the embryonic sac.
A necklace of diamonds or other precious stones, esp. one ofseveral strings.
One of the hard, bony appendages which are borne on the jaws,or on other bones in the walls of the mouth or pharynx of mostvertebrates, and which usually aid in the prehension and masticationof food.
The Abyssinian or Arabian ibex (Capra Nubiana). It is probablythe wild goat of the Bible.

A small nematode worm (Anguillula tritici) which attacks thegrains of wheat in the ear. It is found in wheat affected with smut,each of the diseased grains containing a large number of the minuteyoung of the worm.
Resting on supposition; hypothetical; conjectural; supposed.South.
To place fitly together; to adapt; to clear. [Obs.] Holland.
One who adheres to what he thinks the classical canons of art.Ruskin.
A mucilagenous secretion of certain birds found as thecharacteristic ingredient of edible bird's-nests.
A circular opening to recive a hook, cord, ring, or rope; aneyelet.
An artificial bed of animal matter for the manufacture of niterby nitrification. See Nitrification, 2.
One who espouses; one who embraces the cause of another ormakes it his own.

Belonging to, or in the manner of, Sappho; -- said of a certainkind of verse reputed to have been invented by Sappho, consisting offive feet, of which the first, fourth, and fifth are trochees, thesecond is a spondee, and the third a dactyl.
The largest of the three orders into which the Fungi Imperfectiare divided, including various forms.
The act of making fourfold; a taking four times the simple sumor amount.
To place under the domination of Africans or negroes. [Amer.]Bartlett.
The deep-seated parts of the vertebrate skeleton which arerelation with the nervous axis and locomation. Owen.
Containing three letters or characters, or three sets ofletters or characters.
A change produced in the blood by exposure to the air inrespiration; oxygenation of the blood in respiration;arterialization.
Walking; -- said of any animal on an escutcheon, which isrepresented as walking with the dexter paw raised.
A genus of evergreen plants growing along the shores of theMediterranean, and breading a fruit resembling that of the olive.
To be brittle when red-hot; to be red-short. Moxon.
The science which treats of the liver; a treatise on the liver.
Pertaining to, or designating, a variety of tannic acidextracted from fustic (Maclura, formerly Morus, tinctoria) as ayellow crystalline substance; -- called also maclurin.
In a wooing manner; enticingly; with persuasiveness. Shak.
Artificial and ornamental rockwork in imitation of a grotto.Cowper.
A turban ornamented with an imitation of gold or silverembroidery.
One of the semi-Arians of the 4th century, who held that theSon was of like, but not the same, essence or substance with theFather; -- opposed to homoousian.
The state of being supernatural; belief in supernatural agencyor revelation; supernaturalism.

Those animals in which the protoplasmic mass, constituting theegg, is converted into a multitude of cells, which are metamorphosedinto the tissues of the body. A central cavity is commonly developed,and the cells around it are at first arranged in two layers, -- theectoderm and endoderm. The group comprises nearly all animals exceptthe Protozoa.
A practitioner who tries to prevent or cure baldness.
Having the skeleton in the state of cartilage, the bonescontaining little or no calcareous matter; said of certain fishes, asthe sturgeon and the sharks.
A religious or either sex devoted to prayer and meditation,rather than to active works of charity.
A process resembling "nature printing," by which drawingsexecuted on gelatin are impressed into a soft metal plate, from whichthe printing is done as from copperplate.
An agent that destroys offensive smells; a deodorizer.
The bar of a carriage to which the traces are fastened; thewhiffletree.
A sea robin having large, winglike pectoral fins. See Searobin, under Robin.
Falsely or imperfectly metallic; -- said of a kind of luster,as in minerals.
One born in Africa, the offspring of a white father and a"colored" mother. Also, and now commonly in Southern Africa, a nativeborn of European settlers.
To treat or preserve, as wood, by a process resemblingkyanizing.
A substance capable of crystallizing in several distinct forms;also, any one of these forms. Cf. Allomorph.
One who animadverts; a censurer; also [Obs.], a chastiser.
Filled to excess with blood or other liquid; congested.
Lean meat cut into strips and sun-dried. H. R. Haggard.
Applied to sexual zooids of hydroids, that have a saclike formand do not become free; -- opposed to phanerocodonic.

A contrivance for producing manifold copies of writing ordrawing. The writing or drawing is done with a style carrying a smallwheel at the end which makes minute punctures in the paper, thusconverting it into a stencil. Copies are transferred with an inkedroller.
Resembling a fungus of the genus Peziza; having a cuplike form.
To appropriate to one's own use the property of the public; tosteal public moneys intrusted to one's care; to embezzle.An oppressive, . . . rapacious, and peculating despotism. Burke.
One skilled in treating and curing disorders of the ear.
A four-sided figure having only right angles; a right-angledparallelogram.
A very small arctic sea bird (Mergulus alle, or Alle alle)common on both coasts of the Atlantic in winter; -- called alsolittle auk, dovekie, rotch, rotchie, and sea dove.
A philosopher who treats chiefly of matter; one who adopts orteaches hylism.
Pertaining equally to the right-hand side and the left-handside. Earle.
A fresh-water tortoise (Chelopus marmoratus) of California; --used as food.
The last monitory, published after three admonitions and beforethe last excommunication.
A member of a council, especially of the common council of acity; a councilor.
A turning into a circle; round figures. [Obs.] Donne.
One engaged with others at a banquet or merrymaking. SydneySmith.
Attendance of a chaperon on a lady in public; protectionafforded by a chaperon.
Denoting a tribe of Franks who established themselves early inthe fourth century on the river Sala [now Yssel]; Salic.-- n.
Desirable; capable or worthy of being the object of desire.Bramhall.
An instrument for viewing pictures by means of a lens, so as topresent them in their natural proportions and relations.
All together; hence, in costume, the fine arts, etc., thegeneral effect of a work as a whole, without regard to the executionof the separate perts.
Lacking in matter or substance; visionary; chimerical.
Belonging or relating to the period, and also to the formation,next following the Carboniferous, and regarded as closing theCarboniferous age and Paleozoic era.-- n.
Characterized by dehiscence; opening in some definite way, asthe capsule of a plant.
State of being disquieted; uneasiness; harassment. [R.]Hopkins.
The doctrine or policy of secession; the tenets of secession;the tenets of secessionists.
One who admires the moderns, or their ways and fashions.

That which belongs to the church, or to a person as anecclesiastic, or to religion, as distinct from temporalities.During the vacancy of a see, the archbishop is guardian of thespiritualities thereof. Blackstone.
A tobacco pipe, so arranged that the smoke passes throughwater, making a bubbling noise, whence its name. In India, the bulbcontaining the water is often a cocoanut shell.
A hydrous carbonate of nickel occurring as an emerald-greenincrustation on chromite; -- called also emerald nickel.
To deprive of polarity; to reduce to an unpolarized condition.
Waste silk formed in winding off the threads from a cocoon.
A kind of adoption in ancient Rome. See Arrogation.
A switch consisting of one or more knifelike pieces hinged atone end and making contact near the other with flat gripping springs.
The quality or state of being gentle, well-born, mild,benevolent, docile, etc.; gentility; softness of manners,disposition, etc.; mildness.
Having weak knees; hence, easily yielding; wanting resolution.H. James.
The doctrine that the members of the human race have all acommon origin.

A large division of Anthozoa, including those which have simpletentacles and do not form stony corals. Sometimes, in a wider sense,applied to all the Anthozoa, expert the Alcyonaria, whether formingcorals or not.
A small ornamental leguminous tree of the American species ofthe genus Cercis. See Judas tree, under Judas.
A linget or ingot; also, a mold for casting metals. See Linget.
The quality of being frank; candor; openess; ingenuousness;fairness; liberality.
A kind of small and very acid French plum; -- appliedespecially to the stoned and dried fruit.
A picture representing a scene at sea. [Jocose] Thackeray.
A genus of rubiaceous trees and shrubs, mostly East Indian,many species of which yield valuable red and yellow dyes. The wood ishard and beautiful, and used for gunstocks.
An instrument to measure angles, esp. one used by geologists tomeasure the dip of strata.
A mineral consisting chiefly of uranium oxide with some lead,thorium, etc., occurring in black octahedrons, also in masses with apitchlike luster; pitchblende.
Having coarse, unattractive or stern features. Smollett.
The loosely woven substance which lines the chambers within thegleba in certain Gasteromycetes.
Dycrasia.Sin is a cause of dycrasies and distempers. Jer. Taylor.
One who, or that which, knits, joins, or unites; a knittingmachine. Shak.
The disposition or endeavor to level all distinctions of rankin society.
The division of a design or draught into squares, in order themore easily to reproduce it in larger or smaller dimensions.
Capable of, or fit for, being cultivated; capable or becomingcultured. London Spectator.
An optical toy for producing amusing figures or pictures bymeans of two revolving disks, on one of which distorted figures arepainted.
The first martyr; the first who suffers, or is sacrificed, inany cause; -- applied esp. to Stephen, the first Christian martyr.
The writing of glossaries, glosses, or comments forillustrating an author.
A follower; a disciple; an adherent to a sect. [Obs.] Sir W.Raleigh.
One who scatters; esp., one who scatters money; an improvidentperson. [Obs.]
To reckon; to compute; to suppose; to impute. [Obs.] Drayton.
The spirit or practices of a malingerer; malingering.
A class of Molluscoidea, including minute animals which bybudding form compound colonies; -- called also Polyzoa.
Suffering or enduring together. [Obs.] Sir G. Buck.
A number, letter, or any quantity written on the right hand ofand above another quantity, and denoting how many times the latter isrepeated as a factor to produce the power indicated;
A building devoted to the public used of a town; a townhall.
A lichen (Lecanora tartarea), from which the powder isobtained.
Pertaining to, or containing, ruthenium; specifically,designating those compounds in which it has a higher valence ascontrasted with ruthenious compounds.
A ruminant having solid horns or antlers, as the deer. Brande &C.

Any one of numerous species of echinoderms belonging to theclass Asterioidea, in which the body is star-shaped and usually hasfive rays, though the number of rays varies from five to forty ormore. The rays are often long, but are sometimes so short as toappear only as angles to the disklike body. Called also sea star,five-finger, and stellerid.
The black centaury (Centaurea nigra); -- so called from theknoblike heads of flowers. Called also bullweed.

Calcium fluoride, a mineral of many different colors, white,yellow, purple, green, red, etc., often very beautiful, crystallizingcommonly in cubes with perfect octahedral cleavage; also massive. Itis used as a flux. Some varieties are used for ornamental vessels.Also called fluor spar, or simply fluor.
To wit; namely; videlicet; -- often abbreviated to sc., or ss.

(Arch.) In classical architecture, a vertically faced memberimmediately below the circular base of a column; also, the lowestmember of a pedestal; hence, in general, the lowest member of a base;a sub-base; a block upon which the moldings of an architrave or trimare stopped at the bottom. See Illust. of Column.
Having wheels of the same size or diameter; having equalrotation. [R.]
To move or change from one state into another; to transform.[Obs.] Spenser.
The penis; -- so called in some animals, as the bull. Shak.
Rolled in a spiral; scroll-like; turbinate; -- applied to thethin, plicated, bony or cartilaginous plates which support theolfactory and mucous membranes of the nasal chambers.
A weight of the metric system, being one million grams; ametric ton.
One who does not tempt, or is not a tempter. [Obs.] Wyclif.
A kind of milkweed (Asclepias Curassavica) with red flowers. Itis used in medicine.

A member of a Scottish sect, founded in the 18th century byJohn Glass, a minister of the Established Church of Scotland, whotaught that justifying faith is "no more than a simple assent to thedivine testimone passively recived by the understanding." The Englishand American adherents of this faith are called Sandemanians, afterRobert Sandeman, the son-in-law and disciple of Glass.
One pledged to entire abstinence from all intoxicating drinks.

Quality or state of being not employed; -- used esp. ineconomics, of the condition of various social classes whentemporarily thrown out of employment, as those engaged for shortperiods, those whose trade is decaying, and those least competent.
Having a brown color tonged with red, as of flame seen throughsmoke.
In the manner of one transacting business wisely and by rightmethods.
A genus of fishes including the gray mullets. See Mullet.
To get more astern or parallel with the vessel's course; todraw aft; -- said of the wind.
A peculiar substance obtained from the thyroid gland,containing from nine to ten per cent of iodine.
The quality or state of being welcome; gratefulness;agreeableness; kind reception.
The hindermost dorsal piece of a thoracic somite of an insect;the plate behind the scutellum.

Ladle-shaped; -- applied to two small cartilages of the larynx,and also to the glands, muscles, etc., connected with them. Thecartilages are attached to the cricoid cartilage and connected withthe vocal cords.

An extinct order of herbivorous dinosaurs having the feet of asaurian type, instead of birdlike, as they are in many dinosaurs. Itincludes the Largest Known land animals, belonging to Brontosaurus,Camarasaurus, and alied genera. See Illustration in Appendix.
A drowning of many persons at once, -- a method of executionpracticed at Nantes in France during the Reign of Terror, by JeanBaptiste Carrier.

The science of the connection between nerve action andconsciousness; the science which treats of the relations of thepsychical and physical in their conjoint operation in man; thedoctrine of the relation of function or dependence between body andsoul.
A genus of aromatic plants. It includes species which bearcardamoms, and grains of paradise.
In a scambling manner; with turbulence and noise; with boldintrusiveness.

A tribe of Indians (called also Loups) who formerly occupiedthe region of the Platte river, but now live mostly in the IndianTerritory. The term is often used in a wider sense to include alsothe related tribes of Rickarees and Wichitas. Called also Pani.
The interior curve of an arch; esp., the inner or lower curvedface of the whole body of voussoirs taken together. See Extrados.
A hydrous phosphate of alumina and manganese. It is generallyof a rose-pink color, -- whence the name.
A field where corn is or has been growing; -- in England, afield of wheat, rye, barley, or oats; in America, a field of Indiancorn.
A figure in which a harts or indelicate word or expression issoftened; a way of describing an offensive thing by an inoffensiveexpression; a mild name for something disagreeable.
Just drawn out of the ground, and hanging perpendicularly;atrip; -- said of the anchor. Totten.
The act of obliterating, or the state of being obliterated;extinction. Sir. M. Hale.
One of a degraded and savage race of South Africa, withyellowish brown complexion, high cheek bones, and wooly hair growingin tufts.
The growth or development of an animal or a zooid from anonsexual germ.
A roll or bag, filled with dust, borne by Byzantine emperors,as a memento of mortality. It is represented on medals.
Having the seeds straight, as in the fruits of someumbelliferous plants; -- opposed to coelospermous. Darwin.

Designating, or pert. to, a linguistic stock of South AmericanIndians comprising the most important Brazilian tribes. Agriculture,pottery, and stone working were practiced by them at the time of theconquest. The Tupi and the Guarani were originally the most powerfulof the stock, which is hence also called Tupi-Guaranian.

A very intense light, produced by turning two streams of gas,one oxygen and the other hydrogen, or coal gas, in a state ofignition, upon a ball of lime; or a stream of oxygen gas through aflame of alcohol upon a ball or disk of lime; -- called alsooxycalcium light, or lime light.
One who follows the business of navigating ships or othervessels; one who understands the practical management of ships; oneof the crew of a vessel; a mariner; a common seaman.
A fresh-water fish of the United States (Semotilus bullaris); -- called also silver chub, and Shiner. The name is also applied toother allied species.
A genus of African lemurs, including numerous species.
Six and ten; consisting of six and ten; fifteen and one more.
A genus of cryptogamous plants resembling Lycopodia, butproducing two kinds of spores; also, any plant of this genus. Manyspecies are cultivated in conservatories.
The base or servile tenure by which a bordar held his cottage.
The division of a tendon, or the act of dividing a tendon.
An apron for a child to protect the front part of dress; atier.
The act or process of systematizing; systematization.
In an arrogant manner; with undue pride or self-importance.

An order of pelagic Hydrozoa including species which formcomplex free-swimming communities composed of numerous zooids ofvarious kinds, some of which act as floats or as swimming organs,others as feeding or nutritive zooids, and others as reproductivezooids. See Illust. under Physallia, and Porpita.
Bearing three flowers together, or only three flowers.
A fossil plant from the coal formations of Europe and America,now regarded as the branchlets and foliage of calamites.
The time of the new moon; the beginning of the month in thelunar calendar.
Something that is inferior and of little worth. [Obs.] Beau. &Fl.
A layer of cells forming a kind of cuticle inside of the propercortical layer, or surrounding an individual fibrovascular bundle.
The act or process of methodizing, or the state of beingmethodized.
The extreme end of the chancel or choir; properly the round orpolygonal part.
One who makes a request or demand; hence, a candidate.
Superabundance; superfluity; an overflowing. [R.] Shak.
A barrister, considered a learner of law till of sixteen years'standing, when he might be called to the rank of serjeant. [Obs.]Blackstone.

The irregular triangular space between the curve of an arch andthe inclosing right angle; or the space between the outer moldings oftwo contiguous arches and a horizontal line above them, or anotherarch above and inclosing them.
An impure resin of turpentine, hardened on the outside of pinetrees by the spontaneous evaporation of its essential oil. Whenpurified, it is called yellow pitch, white pitch, or Burgundy pitch.
A species of tinamou (Calopezus elegans), having a long slendercrest.
The state of being globular; globosity; sphericity.
The act of ushering, or the state of being ushered in. [Obs.]Shaftesbury.
prevented from sailing, by a contrary wind. See Weatherbound.
