Hollow relief; sculpture in relief within a sinking made forthe purpose, so no part of it projects beyond the plain surfacearound.
The state or quality of being manageable; manageableness.
A compound or twin crystal made up of eight individuals.
Doubly serrate, or having the serratures serrate, as in someleaves.
Any bryozoan of the genus Flustra or allied genera which formfrondlike corals.
Wanting the power of procreation; unable to copulate; also,sometimes, sterile; barren.
A money of account in Goa, India, equivalent to about 2s. 6d.sterling. or 60 cts.
An instrument for estimating the amount of acetic acid invinegar or in any liquid containing acetic acid.
The state of being streamy; a trailing. R. A. Proctor.
The state of being an angel; angelic nature. Mrs. Browning.
A name given to the first power spinning machine, becausedriven by water power.
At what time soever; at whatever time; whenever. Mark xiv. 7.
One who, or that which, disquiets, or makes uneasy; adisturber.
The hypothetical radical SbH4, analogous to ammonium; -- calledalso antimonium.
To take a swathe from; to relieve from a bandage; to unswaddle.Addison.
An old instrument of the lute or cittern kind. [Spelt alsoorpheoreon.]
A die, cut in intaglio, for stamping an ornament in relief, asupon metal.
A mixture of salt, coarse meal lime, etc., attractive topigeons.
Pieces of timber at a masthead, to which are attached the uppershrouds. At the head of lower masts in large vessels, they support asemicircular platform called the "top."
One who makes a contract of marriage between two persons.
To roll or turn round; to cause to perform a rotary or circularmotion. Ray.
A madness, craze, or strong fancy, for ferns. [R.] C. Kingsley.
The portion of a graduated instrument, as a quadrant orastrolabe, carrying the sights or telescope, and showing the degreescut off on the arc of the instrument Whewell.
To cover with, or as with, a shroud; to shroud. Churchill.
One given to fanciful ideas or theories; a theorist; aspectator. [R.] Mrs. Browning.
A conical rifle bullet, with a cavity in its base plugged witha piece of iron, which, by the explosion of the charge, is drivenfarther in, expanding the sides to fit closely the grooves of thebarrel.
A singing bird of northern Europe and Asia (Cyanecula Suecica),related to the nightingales; -- called also blue-throated robin andblue-throated warbler.
The act of aiding one's self, without depending on the aid ofothers.

One of a religious denomination whose tenets and practices aremainly those of the Baptists, but partly those of the Quakers; --called also Tunkers, Dunkards, Dippers, and, by themselves, Brethren,and German Baptists.
A dyeing matter extracted from the roots of Alkanna tinctoria,which gives a fine deep red color.
Produced by applying the tongue to the teeth or to the gums; orrepresenting a sound so formed.-- n.
Healthy nutrition; soundless as regards the nutritivefunctions.
To make a monk (or wearer of a cowl) of. [R.] Drayton.
An order of wormlike, degraded, parasitic arachnids. They havetwo pairs of retractile hooks, near the mouth. Called alsoPentastomida.
The act of luxating, or the state of being luxated; adislocation.

Situated between the petiole and the stem; -- said of the pairof stipules at the base of a petiole when united by those marginsnext the petiole, thus seeming to form a single stipule between thepetiole and the stem or branch; -- often confounded withinterpetiolar, from which it differs essentially in meaning.
A Roman coin or denomination of money, in value the fourth partof a denarius, and originally containing two asses and a half,afterward four asses, -- equal to about two pence sterling, or fourcents.
A falconer who keeps a goschawk. [Obs.] Shak. Cowell. [Writtenalso austringer.]
An attack upon a fortress or fortified town, with shells, hotshot, rockets, etc.; the act of throwing bombs and shot into a townor fortified place.
Discriminating marks; signs; tokens; indications; appearances.Burrill.
A man whose business is to manage or display signals;especially, one employed in setting the signals by which railroadtrains are run or warned.
A mineral of a nearly black color and vitreous luster, andconsisting principally of the silicates of yttrium, cerium, and iron.
A person devoted to fleshly things. [Obs.] Spenser.
To make part in schism; to make a breach of communion in thechurch.
To deprive of glasslike character; to take away vitreous lusterand transparency from.
A plant of the genus Hypericum (H. Androsoemum), from which ahealing ointment is prepared in Spain; -- called also parkleaves.
A hole made by a mouse, for passage or abode, as in a wall;hence, a very small hole like that gnawed by a mouse.
Capacity for receiving; susceptibility. [R.] Wollaston.
One who subscribed and defended the "Solemn League andCovenant." See Covenant.
Variegated; spotted; speckled; piebald. [Prov. Eng.]
A colorless buttery substance obtained from the fruit ofMyristica otoba, a species of nutmeg tree.

A proclamation, as of the French kings, calling not only theirimmediate feudatories, but the vassals of these feudatories, to takethe field for war; also, the body of vassals called or liable to becalled to arms, as in ancient France.
An imaginary animal borne as a charge, having wings, an eagle'shead, and a short tail; -- sometimes represented without wings.
One who compliments; one given to complimenting; a flatterer.
One of a class of paupers or pensioners, or licensed beggars,in Scotland, to whim annually on the king's birthday were distributedcertain alms, including a blue gown; a beadsman.
A member of a corporation, esp. one of the original members.
The act or process of dislodging, or the state of beingdislodged.
A Mass for a deceased person or for some special object, saiddaily for a year or on the anniversary day.
Having a variously cut or incised margin; -- said of leaves.
Containing less alcohol than proof spirit. See Proof spirit,under Spirit.
The active medicinal principle of colocynth; a bitter, yellow,crystalline substance, regarded as a glucoside.
Maize or Indian corn; -- the common name in South Africa.
To deprive of superabundant water, as by evaporation ordistillation; to clear of aqueous matter; to rectify; -- used ofspirits and acids.
The quality of being penetrable; susceptibility of beingpenetrated, entered, or pierced. Cheyne.
Hatred of women; repugnance to the society of women. Holmes.
Of or pertaining to straw; made of, or resembling, straw. Shak.
Bags, usually of leather, united by straps or a band, formerlymuch used by horseback riders to carry small articles, one baghanging on each side.
A light covered carriage, having four wheels and seats for fouror more persons, usually drawn by one horse.
Paper steeped in saltpeter, which burns slowly, and is used asa match for firing gunpowder, and the like.
Jutlanders; one of the Low German tribes, a portion of whichsettled in Kent, England, in the 5th century.
Resembling a fox in his characteristic qualities; cunning;artful; foxy.
A deerlike, or thin, ill-formed neck, as of a horse.
The quality of being active; nimbleness; quickness of motion;activity.
A genus of freshwater leeches, furnished with a proboscis. Theyfeed upon mollusks and worms.
A massive, somewhat impure variety of quartz, in color usuallyof a gray to brown or nearly black, breaking with a conchoidalfracture and sharp edge. It is very hard, and strikes fire withsteel.
Of or pertaining to the Pharaohs, or kings of ancient Egypt.
A funnel-shaped sleeve arranged to show the sleeve lining andan inner sleeve.

Any large webfooted bird of the genus of Pelecanus, of whichabout a dozen species are known. They have an enormous bill, to thelower edge of which is attached a pouch in which captured fishes aretemporarily stored.
An instrument for measuring or registering the amount ofcloudiness.
The death of a part by molecular disintegration and withoutloss of continuity, as in the processes of degeneration and atrophy.Virchow.
Having a form like that of the new moon; shaped like acrescent.
A row of balusters topped by a rail, serving as an openparapet, as along the edge of a balcony, terrace, bridge, staircase,or the eaves of a building.
That department of physics which treats of the atmosphere.
A brother by both the father's and mother's side, incontradistinction to a uterine brother, one by the mother only.Bouvier.
To produce or render extemporaneous compositions, especially inverse or in music, without previous preparation; hence, to doanything offhand.
Connected; tied; -- a term used when successive tones are to beproduced in a closely connected, smoothly gliding manner. It is oftenindicated by a tie, thus staccato.
Emitting, or appearing to emit, blood or sap, etc.; also,expressing anguish or compassion.
The middle space or region between heaven and hell; the abodeof human beings; the earth.
That point in which the three perpendiculars let fall from theangles of a triangle upon the opposite sides, or the sides produced,mutually intersect.
A straight, horizontal mark placed over two or more members ofa compound quantity, which are to be subjected to the same operation,as in the expression x2 + y2 - x + y.
The feudal system; a system by which the holding of estates inland is made dependent upon an obligation to render military serviceto the kind or feudal superior; feudal principles and usages.
Of or pertaining to a spherulite; characterized by the presenceof spherulites.
A small hole or gap through which a wild animal passes; a muse.Shak.
That part of the axis of a curved line which is interceptedbetween the ordinate and the normal.
Metaphorical; tralatitious; also, foreign; exotic. [Obs.]Evelyn.
The art or science of descriptive drawing; especially, the artor science of drawing by mechanical appliances and mathematical rule.
The act of violently forcing air out through the nasal passageswhile the cavity of the mouth is shut off from the pharynx by theapproximation of the soft palate and the base of the tongue.
Forcible manipulation of a dislocated, stiff, or painful joint.
A tilted hammer; a heavy hammer, used in iron works, which islifted or tilted by projections or wipers on a revolving shaft; atrip hammer.
A modified kind of telescope adapted to taking photographs ofthe sun.
A mineral occurring in white rounded crystalline masses. It isa hydrous borate of lime and soda.
A volatile, pungent, liquid hydrocarbon, C6H10, consisting oftwo allyl radicals, and belonging to the acetylene series.
A sea nymph, one of the daughters of Nereus, who wereattendants upon Neptune, and were represented as riding on seahorses, sometimes with the human form entire, and sometimes with thetail of a fish.
An electric generator or dynamo which is combined on one framewith a turbomotor, by which it is driven.
The act or the process of freeing from silver; also, thecondition resulting from the removal of silver.
Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, yttrium.

An instrument of extreme sensibility, used to determine slightdifferences and degrees of heat. It is composed of alternate bars ofantimony and bismuth, or any two metals having different capacitiesfor the conduction of heat, connected with an astatic galvanometer,which is very sensibly affected by the electric current induced inthe system of bars when exposed even to the feeblest degrees of heat.
A stanchion or post of wood or iron, with two arms forsupporting a boom, spare yards, etc.; -- called also crane andcrutch. Totten.
An instrument consisting of a short pendulum with a slidingweight. It is set in motion by clockwork, and serves to measure timein music.
The process of applying additional colors, by applications ofprinting blocks, to patterns already partly colored.
A merry frolic; especially, a drinking frolic; a carousal.[Colloq.]
To represent by a portrait, or as by a portrait; to portray.[R.] Shaftesbury.
Of, pertaining to, or like, an index; having the form of anindex.
A so-called variety of bacterium, consisting in reality ofseveral bacteria linked together in the form of a chain.
Composed of three three-stranded ropes, or hawsers, twistedtogether to form a cable.
A second or new appearance; the act or state of appearingagain.
The act of buying the whole quantity of any commodity. [R.]Bacon.
To record or narrate in the manner of a history; to chronicle.[R.]
A breeze, gale, or mist from the sea. Ham. Nav. Encyc.
Something put into a liquid or mass to make it thicker.
A pipe for carrying off waste water, etc., from a sink orcesspool. Knight.
One who demands; the plaintiff in a real action; any plaintiff.
Any one of several species of South American birds belonging toTinamus and allied genera.
One of a sect of Christian dualists originating in Armenia inthe seventh century. They rejected the Old Testament and the part ofthe New.
The distance, reckoned toward the west, between the twomeridians passing through the extremities of a course, or portion ofa ship's path; the departure of a course which lies to the west ofnorth.
Vegetable coloring matter other than green; chromule.
The scent of the game, as far as it can be traced. [Obs.] Shak.

The era in use in all Christian countries, which was intendedto commence with the birth of Christ. The era as now established wasfirst used by Dionysius Exiguus (died about 540), who placed thebirth of Christ on the 25th of December in the year of Rome 754,which year he counted as 1 a. d. This date for Christ's birth is nowgenerally thought to be about four years too late.
To take into, or as into, the stomach or alimentary canal. SirT. Browne.
Having or designating conspicuous or warning colors orstructures indicative of special means of defense against enemies, asin the skunk.

Of or pertaining to calling; used in calling; specifically(Gram.), used in address; appellative; -- said of that case or formof the noun, pronoun, or adjective, in which a person or thing isaddressed; as, Domine, O Lord.
The territorial disrict legally assigned to a chapel.
A dry white wine, of a tart flavor, produced in Teneriffe; --called also Teneriffe.

The original sense seems to have been a lane cut through trees.See Grave, v., and cf. Groove.] A smaller group of trees than aforest, and without underwood, planted, or growing naturally as ifarranged by art; a wood of small extent.
The state of being related by kindred, affinity, or otheralliance. Mason.
To move quickly up and down; to bob up and down, as a cork onrough water; also, to bubble. Cotton.
Of or pertaining to a ratio when the excess of the greater termover the less is more than a unit, as that of 3 to 5, or 7 to 10.[Obs.] Hutton.
To affix one's signature to, a second time; to sign again.
The mast erected at the head of the foremast, and at the headof which stands the fore-topgallant mast. See Ship.
The act of floating on the water; swimming. Sir T. Browne.
The absence or suppression of the essential organs (stamens andpistil) in a flower.
A mineral of the scapolite group; -- so called from the doubleeffect of fire upon it, in fusing it, and rendering itphosphorescent.
A black variety of diamond, found in Brazil, and used fordiamond drills. It occurs in irregular or rounded fragments, rarelydistinctly crystallized, with a texture varying from compact toporous.
In a proximate manner, position, or degree; immediately.
The current that sets seaward near the bottom when waves arebreaking upon the shore.
The act of shaking, or the state of being shaken. Gayton.
To strip or wear off the skin of; to abrade; to gall; to breakand remove the cuticle of, in any manner, as by rubbing, beating, orby the action of acrid substances.
Having a tendency to form ulcers; rendering ulcerous.
The first or anterior segment of the thorax in insects. SeeIllusts. of Butterfly and Coleoptera.

A state in which the thoughts, expressions, and actions arewild, irregular, and incoherent; mental aberration; a roving orwandering of the mind, -- usually dependent on a fever or some otherdisease, and so distinguished from mania, or madness.
The certificate of admission given in some American colleges.
The art or practice of divining the destiny of persons by theletters which form their names.
To infix, as in a globe; to fix or secure firmly. [Obs.]Milton.
A pin worn on the breast for a fastening, or for ornament; abrooch.
The quality of being inexorable, or unyielding to entreaty.Paley.
A genus of trees, intermediate in character between the palmsand the pines. The pith of the trunk of some species furnishes avaluable kind of sago.
One of the classes of the arthropods, including lobsters andcrabs; -- so called from the crustlike shell with which they arecovered.
A meal taken at the close of the day; the evening meal.
An instrument for recording automatically the variations ofatmospheric pressure.
Capable of yielding, or being converted into, peptone.
A little tower, frequently a merely ornamental structure at oneof the angles of a larger structure.
Any Australian bat of the genus Nyctophilus, having a verysimple nasal appendage.
In promorphology, pertaining to or exhibiting that kind oforganic form, in which the stereometric ground form is a pyramid,with similar poles. See Promorphology.
A siliceous stone, a variety of quartz, closely resemblingflint, but more brittle; -- called also chert.
Made at home; of domestic manufacture; made either in a privatefamily or in one's own country. Locke.
A state of restlessness and agitation, often with generalindisposition and a distressing sense of oppression at theepigastrium. Dunglison.
Of or pertaining to an outline; being in, or forming, anoutline. Trench.
Opposite to the sun; -- said of the point in the heavens 180distant from the sun.
To groove in; to join in or with a groove. Tennyson.
A dam or mound to obstruct a water course, and raise the waterto a height sufficient to turn a mill wheel.
Of or relating to Brittany, or Bretagne, in France.-- n.
Incapable of being burnt; incombustibe. Sir T. Browne.
The hearing and determination of a cause between parties incontroversy, by a person or persons chosen by the parties.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, saccharone; specifically,designating an unstable acid which is obtained from saccharone (a) byhydration, and forms a well-known series of salts.

One who carries a verge, or emblem of office. Specifically: --(a) An attendant upon a dignitary, as on a bishop, a dean, a justice,etc. [Eng.] Strype.(b) The official who takes care of the interior of a church building.

An order of carnivorous dinosaurs in which the feet are lessbirdlike, and hence more like those of an ordinary quadruped, than inthe Ornithopoda. It includes the repacious genera Megalosaurus,Creosaurus, and their allies.
One who creates a product on his own account; whoeverundertakes on his own account an industrial enterprise in whichworkmen are employed. F. A. Walker.
A constellation represented as a serpent held by Serpentarius.

That branch of anthropology which treats of the actualdistribution of the human race in its different divisions, asdistinguished by physical character, language, institutions, andcustoms, in contradistinction to ethnography, which treatshistorically of the origin and filiation of races and nations. P.Cyc.

The reedbuck, a South African antelope (Cervicapraarundinacea); -- so called from its frequenting dry places coveredwith high grass or reeds. Its color is yellowish brown. Called alsoinghalla, and rietbok.
The state or quality of being lax; want of tenseness,strictness, or exactness.
A short grace note, one semitone below the note to which it isprefixed; -- used especially in organ music. Now used as equivalentto the short appoggiatura.
The third of the four great original castes among the Hindoos,now either extinct or partially represented by the mercantile classof Banyas. See the Note under Caste, 1.
The berry or fruit of any tree of the genus Morus; also, thetree itself. See Morus.
The act of Judaizing; a conforming to the Jewish religion orritual. [R.]
The standard weight or coin by which others are adjusted.
of Number. The fourth book of the Pentateuch, containing thecensus of the Hebrews.
The quality or state of being umbrose; shadiness. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
Capable of being constrained; liable to constraint, or torestraint. Hooker.
In racing, the going over a course by a horse which has nocompetitor for the prize; hence, colloquially, a one-sided contest;an uncontested, or an easy, victory.
An order of Annelida which includes the earthworms and relatedspecies.
The state of being mortified; humiliation; subjection of thepassions. [R.]
To carry or transport over a river, strait, or other narrowwater, in a boat.
The liquid storax of the East Indian Liquidambar orientalis.

A burrowing crab of the genus Gelasimus, of many species. Themale has one claw very much enlarged, and often holds it in aposition similar to that in which a musician holds a fiddle, hencethe name; -- called also calling crab, soldier crab, and fightingcrab.
A French partisan soldier, or one belonging to a corps ofdetached light troops engaged in forays, skirmishes, scouting, etc.
One of the four pursuivants of the English college of arms.
The act of transfixing, or the state of being transfixed, orpierced. Bp. Hall.
Capable of being pictured, or represented by a picture.
A white crystalline substance consisting of phenol salicylate.
Toward a proximal part; on the proximal side of; proximally.
Intolerance; want of toleration; refusal to tolerate adifference of opinion.
A fine grade of woolen yarn twisted somewhat harder andsmoother than zephyr yarn.
Of, pertaining to, or containing, terbium; also, designatingcertain of its compounds.
Valuable additions or betterments, as buildings, clearings,drains, fences, etc., on premises.
The science of exchanges, a branch of political economy.
A modification of the bassoon, much deeper in tone.
The part of the day which follows noon, between noon andevening.
An american bird (Pipilo erythrophthalmus) of the Finch family,so called from its note; -- called also towhee bunting and groundrobin.
The act of praising unduly; excessive praise. Milton.
Wrinkled; full of wrinkles; specifically (Bot.), having theveinlets sunken and the spaces between them elevated, as the leavesof the sage and horehound.
A disease of brute animals, especially of horses, seated in theglands under the ear, where a tumor is formed which sometimes ends insuppuration.
In England, the persons appointed, under a commission ofbankruptcy, to manage the estate of a bankrupt for the benefit of hiscreditors.

Service of the shield, a species of knight service by which atenant was bound to follow his lord to war, at his own charge. It wasafterward exchanged for a pecuniary satisfaction. Called alsoscutage. Blackstone.
A treatise on the art of testing, as in assaying metals, etc.
A taking sides, as with a party, sect, or faction. Bp. Hall.
The treatment of disease by the injection of blood serum fromimmune animals.
Paralysis of the motor nerves; loss of movement. Foster.
A cutting off; a division; a schism; a faction. South.
Wrought in a rough, unfinished way; worked over coarsely.
Discoidal by derivation; -- applied especially to the placentaof man and apes, because it is supposed to have been derived from adiffused placenta.
The science of the derivation and signification of words; thatbranch of learning which treats of the signification and applicationof words.

An oily, volatile hydrocarbon, obtained by the distillation ofcaoutchouc or guttaipercha.C5H8 -- unsaturated, and used to makesynthetic rubber by polymerization. In organic chemistry, viewedconceptually as the building block of the terpene series ofhydrocarbons
Any free-swimming gonophore of a hydroid; a hydroid medusa.
Composed of long and narrow plates, shaped like the blade of aknife.
To range about in an irregular manner. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
producing coral; coraligerous; coralliferous. Humble.
A picrate compound, used as an explosive in blasting.
A person not a Mohammedan, who pays the capitation tax.[Turkey.]
The act, process, or time of flowering; florescence.
Vesture. [Obs.]Richrevesture of cloth of gold. E. Hall.
A figure of speech in which an inanimate object or abstractidea is represented as animated, or endowed with personality;prosopopas, the floods clap their hands. "Confusion heards hisvoice." Milton.
Having a face left as it comes from the quarry and not smoothedwith the chisel or point; -- said of stones.
The quality or state of being judicious; sagacity; s
Having the upper jaw projecting beyond the lower, with theupper incisors in advance of the lower; -- said of dogs.
A lip, commonly the upper one, having a fissure ofperpendicular division like that of a hare.-- Hare"lipped`, a.
A figure which consists in answering the charge of anadversary, by a counter charge.
A division of fresh-water rhizopods including those that have asoft body and delicate branched pseudopodia. The genus Gromia is oneof the best-known.
To heat and ferment in the mow, as hay when housed too green.
A mineral occuring in octahedral crystals, also massive, of areddish color. It is a silicate of iron, zinc manganese, andglicinum, containing sulphur.
To awake; to arouse; to stir or start up; also, to shout out.[Obs.] Chaucer.
Having a tendency to flow in; having influence; influential.[R.] Holdsworth.
A tiny mass of bioplasm, in itself a living unit and havingformative power, as a living white blood corpuscle; bioblast.
A suborder of fishes including Gobiesox and allied genera.These fishes have soft-rayed fins, and a ventral sucker supported infront by the pectoral fins. They are destitute of scales.
To bear witness; to testify under oath; to make deposition.Then, seeing't was he that made you to despose, Your oath, my lord,is vain and frivolous. Shak.
Pertaining to, or containing, gonidia or gonimia, as that partof a lichen which contains the green or chlorophyll-bearing cells.
Resembling a series of dovetails; -- said of a line ofdivision, such as the border of an ordinary.
The quality that gives an affront or offense. [R.] Bailey.
Excess of excitement; the state of being overexcited.
Government in accordance with a system of law. Milman.
Among leather dealers, the thickest and stoutest tanned hides.
A small standard weight used in assaying bullion, etc.,sometimes equaling 0.5 gram, but varying with the assayer.
Resembling, or becoming to, a shepherd; pastoral; rustic. [R.]Jer. Taylor.
A defense for the front of the thigh, consisting of one or moreiron plates hanging from the belt on the lower edge of the corselet.
A substance resembling, and isomeric with, ordinary camphor,and extracted from the essential oil of feverfew; -- called alsoPyrethrum camphor.
The quality or state of being respirable; respirableness.
Pertaining to insurrection; consisting in insurrection.
An under servant for the kitchen; a scullion; a cook's errandboy. [Obs.] Halliwell.
A machine for measuring at any moment velocity of rotation, asof a wheel of a steam engine. Knight.
One of the spores contained in the asci of lichens and fungi.[See Illust. of Ascus.]

One who, or that which, searhes or examines; a seeker; aninquirer; an examiner; a trier. Specifically:(a) Formerly, an officer in London appointed to examine the bodies ofthe dead, and report the cause of death. Graunt.(b) An officer of the customs whose business it is to search ships,merchandise, luggage, etc.(c) An inspector of leather. [Prov. Eng.](d) (Gun.) An instrument for examining the bore of a cannon, todetect cavities.(e) An implement for sampling butter; a butter trier.(j) (Med.) An instrument for feeling after calculi in the bladder,etc.
A bush or lining; -- sometimes called . See 4th Bush.
A reddish yellow pigment present in human bile, and in thatfrom carnivorous and herbivorous animals; the normal biliary pigment.
Concealed by the intervention of some other heavenly body, as astar by the moon.
Chemistry in its relation to vegetable bodies; vegetablechemistry. R. Hunt.
A kind of metallic ware made in India. The material is acomposition of zinc, tin, and lead, in which ornaments of gold andsilver are inlaid or damascened. [Spelt also bidry, bidree, bedery,beder.]
The quality or state of being sententious. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
A division of the Carnivora, including the dogs, cats, andbears, in which the feet are not webbed; -- opposed to Pinnipedia.
Birds which are able to run about and obtain their own food assoon as hatched.
Not susceptible of excitement; dull; lifeless; torpid.
A bonnet, generally made of some thin or light fabric,projecting beyond the face, and commonly having a cape, -- worn bywomen as a protection against the sun.
Contention; strife; scolding; specif., a kind of metricalcontest between two persons, popular in Scotland in the 16th century.[Obs. or Scot.]
A small room from which the magazine of a naval vessel islighted, being separated from the magazine by heavy glass windows.
Anything used as a protection from the sun's rays.Specifically:(a) A small parasol.(b) An awning.
A somewhat heart-shaped cherry with a whitish skin.
A West African long-tailed monkey (Cercopithecus ruber); thered monkey.
One versed in many sciences; a person of various learning.
A mineral of a light indigo-blue color, occurring in smallmasses, or in monoclinic crystals; blue spar. It is a hydrousphosphate of alumina and magnesia.
A small singing bird, as the nightingale and warblers.
Of or pertaining to emerald; resembling emerald; of an emeraldgreen.
The thin epithelium lining the blood vessels, lymphatics, andserous cavities. See Epithelium.
Belonging to, or resembling, oats or the oat grasses.
A Dutch coin, and money of account, of the value of two cents,or about one penny sterling; hence, figuratively, anything of littleworth.
A vessel for water for washing the hands; also, one to holdwine or water.
The process of filling in or finishing with grout; also, thegrout thus filled in. Gwilt.
A continual falling or succession of drops; rain water fallingfrom the eaves. Bacon.
A group of large, extinct, herbivorous mammals, common in theTertiary formation of the United States.
Bearing a tuft of soft hairs or down, as the seeds of milkweed.Gray.
Loose hose or breeches; leather leg quards. The word is usedloosely and often in a jocose sense.
To free the breech of, as a cannon, from its fastenings orcoverings. Pennant.
To take up for renewed consideration, as a motion or a votewhich has been previously acted upon.
An organ in certain fungi and lichens, surrounding andenveloping the masses of fructification. Henslow.
One who practices philanthropy; one who loves mankind, andseeks to promote the good of others.
The act of planting again; a replanting. [R.] Hallywell.
One who, or that which, limits; a boundary. Sir T. Herbert.
Developing from below towards the apex, or from thecircumference towards the center; centripetal; -- said of certaininflorescence.
An obtuse-angled figure, esp. and obtuse-angled triangle.[Obs.]
One who invades; an assailant; an encroacher; an intruder.

A piece of metal bent in the form of an oxbow, with the twoends perforated to receive a pin, used on the end of the tongue of aplow, wagen, etc., to attach it to a draft chain, whiffletree, etc.;-- called also clavel, clevy.
Periodical; annual; -- applied to winds which annually blowfrom the north over the Mediterranean, esp. the eastern part, for anirregular period during July and August.

A genus of small pectinibranch mollusks, having thick spiralshells, abundant between tides on nearly all rocky seacoasts. Theyfeed on seaweeds. The common periwinkle is a well-known example. SeePeriwinkle.
A master subordinate to the principal master; an assistantmaster.
The handle of a rake.That tale is not worth a rakestele. Chaucer.
Having the qualities or characteristics of a snake; snaky.
The holder of a stake; one with whom the bets are depositedwhen a wager is laid.

A rare element of the chromium group found in certain minerals,as wolfram and scheelite, and isolated as a heavy steel-gray metalwhich is very hard and infusible. It has both acid and basicproperties. When alloyed in small quantities with steel, it greatlyincreases its hardness. Symbol W (Wolframium). Atomic weight, 183.6.Specific gravity, 18.
Paste used by weavers to dress their webs. Buchanan.
Deviating somewhat from the type of a species, genus, or othergroup; slightly aberrant.
An instrument employed for replacing a displaced organ or part.
A particular leap of a horse, when he raises both his fore legsat once, equally advanced, and, as his fore legs are falling, raiseshis hind legs, so that all his legs are in the air at once.
To suffer to go at large, on his finding sureties, ormainpernors, for his appearance at a day; -- said of a prisoner.
Having the wings covered with small scalelike structures, asthe lepidoptera; scaly-winged.
The quality of being genial; sympathetic cheerfulness; warmthof disposition and manners.
Cut off smoothly, as distinguished from erased; -- usedespecially for the head or limb of an animal. See Erased.

A genus of plants (herbs, shrubs, or trees), some species ofwhich have large, showy flowers. Some species are cultivated in Indiafor their fiber, which is used as a substitute for hemp. See Althea,Hollyhock, and Manoe.
A name given in the Sandwich Islands to lava having arelatively smooth surface, in distinction from the rough-surfacedlava, called a-a.
Thin brownish chaffy scales upon the leaves or young shoots ofsome plants, especially upon the petioles and leaves of ferns. Gray.
A variety of barite emitting a fetid odor when rubbed orheated.
The spiral tubular proboscis of lepidopterous insects. SeeLepidoptera.
One of a body of light troops, cavalry or infantry, trained forrapid movements.
In an extravagant manner; wildly; excessively; profusely.
The art or process of reproducing colors by photography.
A tumor, sometimes found in newborn children, which is made upof a heterigenous mixture of tissues, as of bone, cartilage andmuscle.
A mythical monster of the early Anglo-Saxon literature; adragon. W. Spalding.
One who, or that which, augments or increases anything.
One who, or that which, discharges. Specifically, inelectricity, an instrument for discharging a Leyden jar, orelectrical battery, by making a connection between the two surfaces;a discharging rod.
The act of bedewing; the state of being moistened with de[Obs.] Chambers.
Being without warmth; not communicating warmth; cold. [R.]Coleridge.
One who holds or owns a share or shares in a joint fund orproperty.
The art or process of calculating the atomic proportions,combining weights, and other numerical relations of chemical elementsand their compounds.
A kind of gall produced by a gallfly on the cup of an acorn, --used in tanning and dyeing.
An extinct genus of large slothlike American edentates, alliedto Megatherium.
The quality of being accidental; accidentalness. [R.]Coleridge.
The office or employment of a surgeon, as in the naval ormilitary service.
Not condensing; discharging the steam from the cylinder at apressure nearly equal to or above that of the atmosphere and not intoa condenser.
An instrument for determining the weight or pressure of theatmosphere, and hence for judging of the probable changes of weather,or for ascertaining the height of any ascent.
Gray; a gray color; a mixture of white and black. Shak.
The chaffinch; -- so named from its call note. [Prov. Eng.]
A rope carried taut between or over obstacles likely to engageor foul the running rigging in working a ship.
One of a family of clavicorn beetles, including those whichhave very long maxillary palpi.
Pertaining to Brabant, an ancient province of the Netherlands.
A work thrown up at the end of a bridge nearest the enemy, forcovering the communications across a river; a bridgehead.
A state of not being committed or pledged; forbearance orrefusal to commit one's self. Also used adjectively.
One of those who went to California in the rush for gold in1849; an argonaut. [Colloq., U. S.]
The quality of being coagulable; capacity of being coagulated.Ure.
A nontoxic diamine, C4H12N2, formed in the putrefaction of theflesh of mammals and some other animals.

One born of European parents in the American colonies of Franceor Spain or in the States which were once such colonies, esp. aperson of French or Spanish descent, who is a native inhabitant ofLouisiana, or one of the States adjoining, bordering on the Gulf ofof Mexico.
An oxidation product of uric acid. It is of a pale reddishcolor, readily soluble in water or alcohol.
Being within the material world; -- opposed to extramundane.
A large music box imitating a variety of orchestralinstruments.
Not leviable; incapable of being imposed, or collected. [R.]Sir M. Hale.
A show or spectacle representing a sea fight; also, a place forsuch exhibitions.
To defend, as with a shield; to shield. [Archaic] Shak.
To underlet; to lease, as when a lessee leases to anotherperson.
An obscure ecclesiastical council; a conciliable. Milman.
To enter in a list, or on a piece of parchment, called a panel;to form or enroll, as a list of jurors in a court of justice.Blackstone.
A mysterious part or decoration of the breastplate of theJewish high priest. See the note under Urim.
The black vulture (Catharista atrata). It ranges from theSouthern United States to South America. See Vulture.
Artificial digestion of food for use in illness or impaireddigestion.
A bitter principle extracted from the bulbs of the squill(Scilla), and probably consisting of a complex mixture of severalsubstances.
An examiner; one whose business is to put questions. Formerly,in the English Court of Exchequer, an officer who audited thesheriffs' accounts.
Decorated or furnished with olive trees. [R.] T. Warton.
One after another; -- said especially of horses harnessed anddriven one before another, instead of abreast.
Characterized by flatness of head, especially that produced byartificial means, as a certain tribe of American Indians.
A mineral of a green color and pearly luster; a hydrousphosphate of copper.
To alienate in mortmain, that is, to convey to a corporation.See Mortmain.
Having pigeonlike feet; -- said of those gallinaceous birdsthat rest on all four toes, as the curassows and megapods.
A yellowish-white calcareous freestone from the Isle ofPortland in England, much used in building.
Divided, shared, or participated in, in common with others.[R.] Milton.
Any heavy substance, as stone, iron, etc., put into the hold tosink a vessel in the water to such a depth as to prevent capsizing.
A dress of strong materials for restraining maniacs or thosewho are violently delirious. It has long sleeves, which are closed atthe ends, confining the hands, and may be tied behind the back.
Of or pertaining to the ancient Celtiberia (a district in Spainlying between the Ebro and the Tagus) or its inhabitants theCeltiberi (Celts of the river Iberus).-- n.
To remove the glaze from, as pottery or porcelain, so as togive a dull finish.
Having a monopodium or a single and continuous axis, as abirchen twig or a cornstalk.
Of or pertaining to the genus Stenoderma, which includesseveral West Indian and South American nose-leaf bats.
One who makes recensions; specifically, a critical editor.
A single stone, especially one of large size, shaped into apillar, statue, or monument.
Having a cruel, ferocious disposition; bloodthirsty. Dryden.
A large African antelope (Alcejaphus tora). It has widelydivergent, strongly ringed horns.
Situated in the axis of anything; as an embryo which lies inthe axis of a seed. Gray.

The seventh Sunday, and the fiftieth day, after Easter; afestival of the church in commemoration of the descent of the HolySpirit on the day of Pentecost; Pentecost; -- so called, it is said,because, in the primitive church, those who had been newly baptizedappeared at church between Easter and Pentecost in white garments.
A Roman copper coin, equal to one third of the as. See 3d As,2.
A method of etching in which the design upon the plate isproduced in relief.
Equal law or right; equal distribution of rights andprivileges; similarity.
The state or quality of being ungainly; awkwardness.
A climbing plant of the genus Cardiospermum, having round seedswhich are marked with a spot like a heart. Loudon.
To sell the same articles at a lower price than; to sellcheaper than.
A coin of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, of the value of abouttwenty-eight cents. See Crown, n., 9.
A South American bird (Psophia crepitans), allied to thecranes, and easily domesticated; -- called also the gold-breastedtrumpeter. Its body is about the size of the pheasant. See Trumpeter.
The act of tessellating; also, the mosaic work so formed. J.Forsyth.
A solid bounded by twelve quadrilateral faces. It is ahemihedral form of the isometric system, allied to the tetrahedron.
In a radiate manner; with radiation or divergence from acenter.
An apothecium in certain lichens, having a spherical surfacemarked with spiral or concentric ridges and furrows.
At or toward the caudal extremity; caudal; -- in human anatomyoften used for dorsal.
That condition of the pulse in which the pulse curve orsphygmogram shows but a single crest, the dicrotic elevation entirelydisappearing.
A plane used for cutting out grooves and inlaying strings andbands in straight and circular work.
A genus of shrubs including gooseberries and currants of manykinds.

A believer in the doctrine, formerly current, of encasement inthe male (see Encasement), in which the seminal thread, orspermatozoid, was considered as the real animal germ, the head beingthe true animal head and the tail the body.

A day which is a term (as for payment of rent), or is a day ina term, as of the sitting of a court; esp., one of a series ofspecial days, designated by scientists of different nations orstations, for making synoptic magnetic, meteorological, or otherphysical observations.
A shoe for oxen, consisting of a flat piece of iron nailed tothe hoof.
A deity recognized as real but conceived as not acting in humanaffairs, hence not worshiped.
One who abuses [in the various senses of the verb].
A genus of small marine Crustacea, considered the type of adistinct order (Nebaloidea, or Phyllocarida.)
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid (distinct fromsantoninic acid) obtained from santonin as a white crystallinesubstance.
The  tendency of fluids to run together. [R.] Boyle.
One who, or that which, causes to be remembered. [Obs.]
Sheets of tin or other plate which run below the gauge. Knight.
Advice; counsel; suggestion; also, a dispatch or advice boat.[Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Characterized by blots or heavy touches; coarsely depicted;wanting in delineation. Ruskin.
A contrivance or maneuvering to catch game illegally.
One of a Mohammedan sect founded in the ninth century byKarmat.
Full af daring or of defiance; adveturous. [R.] Shak.
In the form of a pentagon; with five angles. Sir T. Browne.
Causing secretion; -- said of nerves which go to glands andinfluence secretion.
To free from obstructions; to clear a passage through. [Obs.]Boyle.
The operation of finding the primitive function which has agiven function for its differential coefficient. See Integral.
The creation of an artifical flood by the sudden letting in ofa body of water; -- called also flushing.
Borne lower than usual, as a fess; also, having the ends of thewings turned downward towards the point of the shield.
Imparting flavor; pleasant to the taste or smell; sapid.Dryden.
A monastic superior, who, under the general of his order, hasthe direction of all the religious houses of the same fraternity in agiven district, called a province of the order.
One of the descendants of Esau or Edom, the brother of Jacob;an Idumean.
An instrument for measuring angles, in surveying, etc. Itresembles
The picarian birds, as distinguished from the singing birds.
A direct or indirect passing from one key to another; amodulation.
One who treats diseases of the hands and feet; especially, onewho removes corns and bunions.

A disease which affects children, and which is characterized bya bulky head, crooked spine and limbs, depressed ribs, enlarged andspongy articular epiphyses, tumid abdomen, and short stature,together with clear and often premature mental faculties. Theessential cause of the disease appears to be the nondeposition ofearthy salts in the osteoid tissues. Children afflicted with thismalady stand and walk unsteadily. Called also rachitis.
An upward curve or very obtuse angle in the upper surface ofany member, as of a timber laid horizontally; -- the opposite ofcamber.
Cementing together; uniting closely; causing to adhere;promoting healing, as of a wound or a broken bone, by adhesion of theparts.
One belonging to an order in the Roman Catholic Church, nextinterior to the order of deacons; also, a member of a minor order inthe Greek Church.
Partly one and partly the other; neither acid nor alkaline;neutral. [R.] Smart.
A sharpened flint for the lock of a gun, to ignite the charge.It was in common use before the introduction of percussion caps.
A narrow dale; a small dell; a small, secluded, and emboweredvalley.
Pertaining to a part of the columella of the ear, which, inmany animals, projects beyond the connection with the stapes.-- n.
That method of spelling in which the same letters representdifferent sounds in different words, as in the ordinary Englishorthography; e. g., g in get and in ginger.
To break upwards; to force away or passage to the surface.
The genus to which belongs the single species D. Camphora, alofty resinous tree of Borneo and Sumatra, yielding Borneo camphorand camphor oil.
The state of being bedeviled; bewildering confusion; vexatioustrouble. [Colloq.]
A solid figure contained by a plane rectilineal figure as baseand several triangles which have a common vertex and whose bases aresides of the base.
An instrument of such focal length that it may be used as anobserving telescope for objects close at hand or as a long-focusedmicroscope.
The act of fastending the gige or leather strap to the shield.[Obs.] "Gigging of shields." Chaucer.
A Scotch game resembling hockey; also, the club used in thegame. Jamieson.
Of nature of a presentiment; foreboding. [R.] Coleridge.
The salmon of the Columbia River or California. See Quinnat.
A tool for smoothing the solder joints of lead pipe. Knight.
One who is turned against another or others with a design tooppose

A plant of the genus Cuscuta. It is a leafless parasitical vinewith yellowish threadlike stems. It attaches itself to some otherplant, as to flax, goldenrod, etc., and decaying at the root. isnourished by the plant that supports it.
a genus of poisonous umbelliferous plants, of which the waterhemlock or cowbane is best known.
One who receives or conceals, as stolen goods or criminal.

The very large ovoid or roundish fruit of a cucurbitaceousplant (Citrullus vulgaris) of many varieties; also, the plant itself.The fruit sometimes weighs many pounds; its pulp is usually pink incolor, and full of a sweet watery juice. It is a native of tropicalAfrica, but is now cultivated in many countries. See Illust. ofMelon.
The person who takes charge of a locomotive when it is left bythe engineer after a trip.
One who maintains that the human races are all of one species;-- opposed to polygenist.
At that time; then; in those days; -- correlative to nowadays.[R.]
The quality or state of not being defensible. Walsh.
To remove a peg or pegs from; to unfasten; to open. Shak.
Subsisting on alms or charitable contributions. [Obs.] Bp.Hall.
One skilled in the diseases of cattle or domestic animals; aveterinary surgeon.
Minute acicular or dendritic crystalline forms sometimesobserved in glassy volcanic rocks.
The branch of meteorology treating of the automaticregistration of the precipitation of rain, snow, etc.; also, thegraphic presentation of precipitation data.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid, obtainedindirectly from mucic acid, and somewhat resembling itaconic acid.

A staff corps in the United States navy, consisting of paydirectors, pay inspectors, paymasters, passed assistant paymasters,and assistant paymasters, having relative rank from captain toensign, respectively.
A stand of wood or iron, with hooks or pegs upon which to hanghats, etc.
A genus of bivalve shells of which one species (D. polymorpha)is often so abundant as to be very troublesome in the fresh waters ofEurope.
A manganese phosphate near triplite, but containing hydroxylinstead of fluorine.
Any sight or reading of the leveling staff, except thebacksight; any sight or bearing taken by a compass or theodolite in aforward direction.
Difference of quality or property in different directions.
A foot in which the arch of the instep is flattened so that theentire sole of the foot rests upon the ground; also, the deformity,usually congential, exhibited by such a foot; splayfoot.
Relating to the measurement of the amount of hematin orhemoglobin contained in blood, or other fluids.
Formed like a rope; -- applied especially to several ropelikebundles or masses of fibers on the dorsal side of the medullaoblongata.
A magnificent species of palm (Mauritia flexuosa), growing nearthe Orinoco. The natives eat its fruit and buds, drink its sap, andmake thread and cord from its fiber.
Not Episcopal; not pertaining to the Episcopal church orsystem.
A reddish resinous substance, obtained from indican.
The process of removing a cause from an inferior court to thesupreme court. Bell.
A delicate pastry made of powdered sugar and the whites of eggswhipped up, -- with jam or cream added.
A division of Protozoa in which a mouthlike opening exists.

The process of removing moisture from the blast of an ironblast furnace by reducing its temperature so far that it will notremain suspended as vapor in the blast current, but will be depositedas snow in the cooling apparatus. The resultant uniformly dehydratedblast effects great economy in fuel consumption, and promotesregularity of furnace operation, and certainty of furnace control.
A genus of liliaceous plants with woody stems and funnel-shapedflowers.
Having, or consisting of, a single chamber; -- said of alegislative assembly. [R.] F. Lieber.
That part of a torsion balance from which the wire or filamentis suspended.

Hereditary transmission of the physical and psychical qualitiesof parents to their offspring; the biological law by which livingbeings tend to repeat their characteristics in their descendants. SeePangenesis.
A name given to several plants, from the shape and roughness oftheir leaves; as, Anchusa officinalis, a kind of bugloss, andHelminthia echioides, both European herbs.
A large size of paper for drawings. See under Paper.
A cavalry raid; hence, a military expedition. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A variety of translucent quartz, spangled throughout withscales of yellow mica. ~= feldspar, a variety of oligoclase withinternal firelike reflections due to the presence of minute crystals,probably of hematite; sunstone.
The act of reapplying, or the state of being reapplied.
Any larva of a beetle or moth, which is injurious to books.Many species are known.
A proposition collected from the agreement of other previouspropositions; any conclusion which results from reason or argument;inference.
To make national; to make a nation of; to endow with thecharacter and habits of a nation, or the peculiar sentiments andattachment of citizens of a nation.
A young lady of superior beauty and attractions; a handsomelady, or one who attracts notice in society; a fair lady.
A New Zealand plover (Anarhynchus frontalis), remarkable forhaving the end of the beak abruptly bent to the right.
A fossil echinus of the genus Cannulus; -- so called from itssupposed resemblance to a cap.
The deportment or conduct of a gentleman. [Obs.] Ascham.
Deliberate consideration; prudent procedure; caution.

Any one of the abdominal appendages of a crustacean, especiallyone of the posterior ones, which are often larger than the rest, anddifferent in structure, and are used chiefly in locomotion. SeeIllust. of Crustacea, and Stomapoda.
The torpedo, which numbs by the electric shocks which it gives.
The state of being unconcerned, or of having no share orconcern; unconcernedness. [Obs.] South.
An officer who formerly supplied the place of the count, orearl; the sheriff of the county.
The state or quality of being legitimate; lawfulness;genuineness.
The act of upheaving, or the state of being upheaved; esp., anelevation of a portion of the earth's crust. Lubbock.
A group of wingless insects, of which the flea in the type. SeeFlea.
Not capable of being healed; incurable; irremediable.
One of the higher alcohols of the paraffine series obtainedfrom spermaceti as a white crystalline solid. It is so called becauseit occurs in the ethereal salt of lauric acid.
Capable of being denominated or named. Sir T. Browne.
A description of, or a treatise on, antiquity or antiquities.
A weaver's cutting instrument; for severing the loops of thepile threads of velvet.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a complex tribasic organicacid, C3H5.(CO2H)3 occurring naturally in unripe beet roots, andproduced artificially from glycerin as a white crystalline substance.
A gown or frock with short sleeves, formerly worn by mariners.Shak.

A generalization with regard to systems of chemicalequilibrium, discovered by Prof. J. Willard Gibbs. It may be statedthus: The degree of variableness (number of degrees of freedom) of asystem is equal to the number of components minus the number ofphases, plus two. Thus, if the components be salt and water, and thephases salt, ice, saturated solution, and vapor, the system isinvariant, that is, there is only one set of conditions under whichthese four phases can exist in equilibrium. If only three phases beconsidered, the system is univariant, that is, the fixing of onecondition, as temperature, determines the others.
Between peduncles; esp., between the peduncles, or crura, ofthe cerebrum.
That part of a legal instrument, as a commission, indictment,etc., which shows where, when, and by what authority, it taken,found, or executed. Bouvier. Wharton.

A genus of halcyonoids in which the skeleton, or coral (calledorgan-pipe coral), consists of a mass of parallel cylindrical tubesunited at intervals by transverse plates. These corals are usuallyred or purple and form large masses. They are natives of the tropicalparts of the Indian and Pacific Oceans.
Any large seaweed of the genus Laminaria; tangle; kelp.  SeeKelp.
A genus of parasitic insects including the fleas. See Flea.
To come before; to anticipate; hence, to hinder; to prevent.[Obs.] Philips.
The end of a ship's keelson, to which the sternpost is bolted;-- called also stern knee.
Full of or marked with freckles; sprinkled with spots;freckled.
The passage of gases, vapors, or liquids thought membranes orporous media from within outward, in the phenomena of osmose; --opposed to endosmose. See Osmose.
To foretell. [Obs.]Her danger nigh that sudden change foresaid. Fairfax.
One who believes that eternal punishment consists inannihilation or extinction of being; a destructionist.
The quality of being innate in the mind, or prior toexperience; a priori reasoning.
An instrument to measure the height and diameter of trees.
One who takes exceptions or makes objections. [Obs.] Milton.
With an even, level, or smooth surface; without roughness,elevations, or depression; uniformly; equally; comfortably;impartially; serenely.
An instrument for examining the dichroism of crystals.
The state or quality of being seaworthy, or able to resist theordinary violence of wind and weather. Kent.
To handle or manage awkwardly; to crowd or tumble together.Shak.

the month in which female deer are fawning, when hunting isprohibited. Bullokar.-- Fence roof, a covering for defense. "They fitted their shieldsclose to one another in manner of a fence roof." Holland. Fence time,the breeding time of fish or game, when they should not be killed.-- Rail fence, a fence made of rails, sometimes supported by posts.-- Ring fence, a fence which encircles a large area, or a wholeestate, within one inclosure.-- Worm fence, a zigzag fence composed of rails crossing one anotherat their ends; -- called also snake fence, or Virginia rail fence.-- To be on the fence, to be undecided or uncommitted in respect totwo opposing parties or policies. [Colloq.]

The fruit of a cucubritaceous plant (Cicumis Melo), having apeculiar aromatic flavor, and cultivated in many varieties, theprincipal sorts being the cantaloupe, of oval form and yellowishflesh, and the smaller nutmeg melon with greenish flesh. See Illust.of Melon.
Ferruginous quartz, of a blood-red or brownish red color,sometimes with a tinge of yellow.
Pertaining to ulmin; designating an acid obtained from ulmin.
A genus of Bryozoa which produce delicate corals, oftenincrusting like lichens, but sometimes branched.
To make a parenthesis of; to include within parentheticalmarks. Lowell.
The science of Mollusca, and of the shells which they form;malacology.
The quality or state of being incompatible; inconsistency;irreconcilableness.
The state of being made up of branchiate segments. R.Wiedersheim.
To influence in an excessive degree; to have undue influenceover.
The act of nationalizing, or the state of being nationalized.
One who holds land in a parish, but lives elsewhere. [Eng.]
A division of vermiform gastropod mollusks, without a shell,belonging to the Isopleura.
A kind of handwriting in which the downward slope of theletters is from left to right.
The act of postillating; exposition of Scripture in preaching.
Wine flavored with spice or honey. See Pigment, 3. [Obs.]
A fermented liquor made in Cayenne from the grated root of themanioc, and resembling perry. Dunglison.
A poor person; especially, one development on private or publiccharity. Also used adjectively; as, pouper immigrants, pouper labor.
The disease caused by the tsetse fly. [South Africa]
The state of being deeply interested; earnestness; zeal.
The quality of being audacious; impudence; audacity.
A kind of script in which the heavy strokes are nearly upright,giving the characters when taken together a round look.
The descent of a deity to earth, and his incarnation as a manor an animal; -- chiefly associated with the incarnations of Vishnu.
A mineral of the feldspar group, like orthoclase or commonfeldspar in composition, but triclinic in form.
A glucoside found in the seeds of black mustard (Brassicanigra, formerly Sinapis nigra) It resembles sinalbin, and consists ofa potassium salt of myronic acid.
A mixture of buttermilk and boiling whey; curds. [prov. Eng.]Wright.
An alkaloid found in opium in small quantities, and extractedas a white crystalline substance.
A genus of motile bacteria characterized by short, slightlysinuous filaments and an undulatory motion; also, an individual ofthis genus.
A figure or drawing made to illustrate a statement, orfacilitate a demonstration; a plan.
A camp permanently intrenched, attached to Turkish frontierfortresses.
Becoming an understrapper; subservient. [R.] Sterne.
The act of imperiling, or the state of being imperiled.
A short, round iron bar or lever used in naval gunnery. Totten.
A class of Molluscoidea having a symmetrical bivalve shell,often attached by a fleshy peduncle.
The breastplate of a horse's armor or harness. [Spelt alsopeitrel.] See Poitrel. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who takes a portion of a contract, as for work, from theprincipal contractor.
Having the texture and color of new wax; like wax; waxy.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the castor-oil plant(Ricinus communis, or Palma Christi); -- formerly used to designatean acid now called ricinoleic acid. [Obsoles.]
To chew loudly and greedily; to champ. [Prov. Eng. & Colloq. U.S.] Halliwell.
The European sapphirine gurnard (Trigla hirundo). It has largepectoral fins.
A white arc or circle in the sky attending frosty weather andformed by reflection of sunlight from ice crystals floating in theair; the parhelic circle whose center is at the zenith.
Relating to, or obtained from, borax; containing borax.
Formed by, or resulting from, consultation; advisory. Bancroft.
A male for whom one has stood sponsor in baptism. SeeGodfather.
A gauzelike fabric for ladies' dresses, veils, etc. of worsted,silk and worsted, or cotton and worsted.
Opposed to the office or authority of magistrates. [Obs.]South.
Silica, SiO2 as found in nature, constituting quarz, and mostsands and sandstones. See Silica, and Silicic.
To talk a weak and silly manner, like one whose faculties aredecayed; to prate; to prattle. Stanyhurst.
Being out of the common course or limits; extravagant; bizarre.
To seal; to confirm, as by a seal or stamp. [Obs.] Bradford.
A hydrocarbon radical formerly supposed to exist in oenanthicacid, now known to be identical with heptyl.
A brass wind instrument, like the trumpet, furnished withvalves moved by small pistons or sliding rods; a cornopean; a cornet.
The divine energy, personified as the wife of a deity (Brahma,Vishnu, Siva, etc.); the female principle.
A disproportionate regard for the interests peculiar to asection of the country; local patriotism, as distinguished fromnational. [U. S.]
Criminal; wicked; contrary to law, right, or dury. [Obs.] Shak.
A South American monkey, the ursine howler (Mycetes ursinus).See Howler, n., 2.
Relating to, becoming to, or like, an alderman; characteristicof an alderman.
In an overthwart manner;across; also, perversely. [Obs.]Peacham.
A kind of gum; -- called also gum tragacanth, or tragacanth.See Tragacanth.
Having the structure of the palate like that of the ostrich andemu.
A long, low war galley used by the Neapolitans and Sicilians inthe early part of the nineteenth century.
A shrubby euphorbiaceous plant of the genus Manihot, withfleshy rootstocks yielding an edible starch; -- called also manioc.

One of a sect of philosophers, said to have been found in Indiaby Alexander the Great, who went almost naked, denied themselves theuse of flesh, renounced bodily pleasures, and employed themselves inthe contemplation of nature.
The art or process of depositing a coating (commonly) ofsilver, gold, or nickel on an inferior metal, by means ofelectricity.
A bifurcated garment for a man, covering the body from thewaist downwards, and consisting of breeches and stockings in one.
The movement of a ship backward, or with her stern foremost.
Being beyond the mountains; specifically, being beyond theAlps, in respect to the one who speaks.
A white waxy substance, found in small quantities in spermacetias an ethereal salt of several fatty acids, and regarded as analcohol of the methane series.
The Anointed; an appellation given to Jesus, the Savior. It issynonymous with the Hebrew Messiah.
The edge of a cask, etc; a chine. See Chine, n., 3. [Writtenalso hime.]
A stage intermediate between the larva and pupa of bees andcertain other hymenopterous insects.
The ninth part of movable goods, formerly payable to the clergyon the death of persons in their parishes. Mozley & W.
To express by a euphemism, or in delicate language; to make useof euphemistic expressions.

Classified facts respecting the condition of the people in astate, their health, their longevity, domestic economy, arts,property, and political strength, their resources, the state of thecountry, etc., or respecting any particular class or interest;especially, those facts which can be stated in numbers, or in tablesof numbers, or in any tabular and classified arrangement.
Imbued with nectar; mingled with nectar; abounding with nectar.Milton.
The middle of the posterior, or dorsal, margin of the greatforamen of the skull.
Serving to show or make known; showing; indicative; signifying;implying.
The act of closing the doors of a schoolroom against aschoolmaster; -- a boyish mode of rebellion in schools. Swift.
A hedge or fence formed of branches of trees interlaced, orplashed. [Obs.] Carew.
A sugar of the composition C5H10O5, obtained from cherry gum byboiling it with dilute sulphuric acid.
To represent incorrectly (almost always, unfacorably); to givea false erroneous representation of, either maliciously, ignirantly,or carelessly. Swift.
To throw out with force from a narrow orifice; to eject; tospurt out. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A double fluoride of silicon and some other (usually basic)element or radical, regarded as a salt of fluosilicic acid; -- calledalso silicofluoride.
The condition or quality of being interesting. A. Smith.
To move or loosen from a settled position or state; to unfix;to displace; to disorder; to confuse.

Having, or being in, a contrary order; -- said of a section ofan oblique cone having a circular base made by a plane not parallelto the base, but so inclined to the axis that the section is acircle; applied also to two similar triangles when so placed as tohave a common angle at the vertex, the opposite sides not beingparallel. Brande & C.
A dish formed of oatmeal boiled in water to a certainconsistency and frequently stirred, or of oatmeal and dripping mixedtogether and stirred about in a pan; a hasty pudding.
Consisting of, or covered with, hair; hairy; pilose.
One who strongly adheres to the papal authority; anultramontanist.
Vegetable glue or gelatin; glutin. It is one of theconstituents of wheat gluten, and is a tough, amorphous substance,which resembles animal glue or gelatin.
The deposit of slime at the mouth of a river; slime.
Of or pertaining to an acid more generally called pepsin-hydrochloric acid.
That which is superadded; augmentation. [Obs.] Baxter.
The business of cutting or getting timber or logs from theforest for lumber. [U.S.]
To adjust or form to a line; to range or form in line; to bringinto line; to aline.
A soldier of light cavalry of the 16th century, who carried ademilance.
Causing intense grief; overpowering with anguish; verydistressing.
Opinion, especially high opinion, of one's self; an overweeningestimate of one's self or of one's own opinion. Collier.
A small South American bird (Anumbius anumbii) allied to theovenbirds of the genus Furnarius). It builds a very large and complexnest of twigs and thorns in a bush or tree.
A place where copper is wrought or manufactured. Woodward.
A poetic foot of two long syllables, as in the Latin wordleges.
Concealed within the base of the petiole, as the leaf buds ofthe plane tree.
One who inserts in a category or list; one who classifies.Emerson.

The step, or raised secondary part, of an altar; a superaltar;hence, in Italian painting, a band or frieze of several picturesrunning along the front of a superaltar, or forming a border or frameat the foot of an altarpiece.
One who believes in the theory of spontaneous generation, orheterogenesis. Bastian.
The crab plover (Dromas ardeola), a peculiar North Africanbird, allied to the oyster catcher.

The fruit of two South American trees (Lecythis Ollaria, and L.Zabucajo), which have for their fruit large, pot-shaped, woodycapsules containing delicious nuts, and opening almost explosively bya circular lid at the top. Vases and pots are made of this capsule.
The albuminous material composing the body of a cytode.
A precipitation of silver, in a beautiful arborescent form.
The dorsal portion of an arthromere or somite of an articulateanimal. See Illust. under Coleoptera.

A short piece of instrumental music played between the parts ofa song or cantata, or the acts of a drama; especially, in churchmusic, a short passage played by the organist between the stanzas ofa hymn, or in German chorals after each line.

A shell longer than a deck-piercing shell, with thinner wallsand a larger cavity for the bursting charge, which consists of about130 pounds of high explosive. It has no soft cap, and is intended toeffect its damage by the powerful explosion which follows on slightresistance. It is used chiefly in 12-inch mortars.
A kind of cress, a pungent cruciferous plant, including severalspecies of the genus Nasturtium.
A hydrocarbon oil obtained by the distillation of resin, --used in printer's ink.
Viscid mucus secreted in abnormal quantity in the respiratoryand digestive passages.
A mild, eruptive disease, generally attacking children only;varicella.
Resembling nettles; -- said of several natural orders allied tourticaceous plants.
Special activity excited in any part of the nervous system orin any organ of sense or motion; the nervous influence necessary forthe maintenance of life,and the functions of the various organs.
The privilege granted to lords of certain manors to judgethieves taken within the seigniory of such lords. Cowell.
A scientific study of children, undertaken for the purpose ofdiscovering the laws of development of the body and the mind frombirth to manhood.
The public lectures or published writings of Aristotle. SeeEsoterics.
A genus of nudibranchiate mollusks, found in the warmerlatitudes, swimming in the open sea. These mollusks are beautifullycolored with blue and silvery white.
Of a blood-red color; crimson; (Bot.) brownish red.
A genus of trees with perigynous rosaceous flowers, and asingle two-ovuled carpel which usually becomes a drupe in ripening.
One who lets or permits; one who lets anything for hire.
Having a pike or spine on the back; -- said of certain fishes.
The act or art of alloying metals; also, the combination oralloy.
Having the principal veins radiating, or diverging, from theapex of the petiole; -- said of such leaves as those of thegrapevine, most maples, and the castor-oil plant.
Instrument for determining the amount of starch in a substance.
Properly the citron, a variety of Citrus medica, with largefruits, not acid, and having a high perfume.
Of, pertaining to, or seated in, one eye; monocular.
A house of lewdness or ill fame; a house frequented byprostitutes; a bawdyhouse.
A claim made by a person as an offset to a claim made on him.
A form of vessel, often with steam power, having sharp ends anda very convex upper deck, much used on the Great Lakes, esp. forcarrying grain.
Lying loose in pulp or cotton within a berry or pericarp, as ina nest.
Adapted to excite wonder or admiration; surprising; strange;astonishing.

A shark of the genus Cestracion, and of related genera. Theposterior teeth form a pavement of bony plates for crushingshellfish. Most of the species are extinct. The Port Jackson sharkand a similar one found in California are living examples.
One of the distinct parts of a compound leaf; a leaflet.
That one of a series of sulphides of any element which has thelowest proportion of sulphur; a sulphide with but one atom of sulphurin the molecule.
A compound formed from the hydrate of aluminium by thesubstitution of a metal for the hydrogen.

That portion of the cell protoplasm which is the seat of allactive changes, and which carries on the function of hereditarytransmission; -- distinguished from the other portion, which istermed nutritive plasma. See Hygroplasm.
Of or pertaining to the two posterior gastric lobes of thecarapace of crabs.

A charge in addition to the freight; originally, a gratuity tothe captain for his particular care of the goods (sometimes calledhat money), but now belonging to the owners or freighters of thevessel, unless by special agreement the whole or part is assigned tothe captain. Homans.
A white amorphous substance, regarded as a polymericmodification of isocyanic acid.
A large East Indian nocturnal tree snake (Dipsas dendrophila).It is not venomous.
A fabled marine creature, typically represented as having theupper part like that of a woman, and the lower like a fish; a seanymph, sea woman, or woman fish.
A tune or air to regulate the movements of the dance so called;a movement in suites, sonatas, symphonies, etc., having the danceform, and commonly in 3-4, sometimes 3-8, measure.

The shadow cast, in an eclipse, where the light is partly, butnot wholly, cut off by the intervening body; the space of partialillumination between the umbra, or perfect shadow, on all sides, andthe full light. Sir I. Newton.
A plant or weed that grows in rivers; a species of ofEquisetum; also, the yellow frog lily (Nuphar luteum).
To cause to lose heart; to dishearten. [Obs.] Shak.
Closely resembling; being a counterpart.-- Twin"like`ness, n.
Having four leaves; consisting of four distinct leaves orleaflets.
Having or exhibiting resemblance; resembling. [R.] Gower.
Having the sinews under the belly shrunk by excessive fatigue.
A stone, or metallic mass, which has fallen to the earth fromdistant space; a meteorite; a meteoric stone.
That branch of algebra which treats of quadratic equations.
A genus of Hydrocorallia, which includes the millipores.
An American bird (Galeoscoptes Carolinensis), allied to themocking bird, and like it capable of imitating the notes of otherbirds, but less perfectly. Its note resembles at times the mewing ofa cat.

A disease frequently induced by remaining for some time in anatmosphere of high pressure, as in caissons, diving bells, etc. It ischaracterized by neuralgic pains and paralytic symptoms. It isvariously explained, most probably as due to congestion of internalorgans with subsequent stasis of the blood.
A building for the shelter of neat cattle. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]Massinger.
Something done in the meantime; interlude. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A small, herbaceous, trailing plant, of the genus Illecebrum(I. verticillatum.)
A stringed instrument of music played with a bow; a violin; akit.
The act of distinguishing or describing a thing, by giving itsdifferent, or specific difference; exact definition or determination.
The passage of a door; entrance way into a house or a room.
A donee of the crown; one the whom, upon certain condition,escheated property is made over.
Engaging in a plot to commit a crime; conspiring. [Obs.] Shak.
The name of several evergreen trees. The wood is remarkable forits durability and fragrant odor.
The act, or art, of causing animals to produce tallow; also,the property in animals of producing tallow.
The English bilberry; -- so called because it grows on moorsamong the whins, or furze. Dr. Prior.
Worthy of vituperation; shameful; disgraceful. [Obs.]
A disposition to turn or incline towards the earth; theinfluence of gravity in determining the direction of growth of anorgan.
A soft, white or colored silk fabric, of a gauzy texture andwavy appearance, used for ladies' scarfs, shawls, bonnet trimmings,etc.; -- called also Oriental crape. De Colange.
The department of physiology which deals with the principles ofmuscular contraction; the exercise of muscular force or contraction.
Any one of several large, thick, spiral marine shells belongingto Rapa and allied genera, somewhat turnip-shaped.
The quality of being essential; the essential part. Jer.Taylor.
One who is extravagant in pretensions, opinions, or manners.Swift.
Short of, or lacking the regular number of, servants orhelpers.
A poison which occasions a persistent delirium, or mentalaberration (as belladonna).
The slender styles of the pistillate flowers of maize; alsocalled silk.
The roughest and cheapest sort of rubblework, in masonry.

A tree (Guaiacum officinale) found in the warm latitudes ofAmerica, from which the guaiacum of medicine is procured. Its wood isvery hard and heavy, and is used for various mechanical purposes, asfor the wheels of ships' blocks, cogs, bearings, and the like. SeeGuaiacum.
Compounded of chlorine and iodine; containing chlorine andiodine.

A bridge of which either the whole or a part is made to beraised up, let down, or drawn or turned aside, to admit or hindercommunication at pleasure, as before the gate of a town or castle, orover a navigable river or canal.
To distribute according to, or to imbue with, the principles ofagrarianism.
Producing milk or a milklike juice or fluid, as the milkweed.See Latex.
A wild horse found in the region of the Caspian Sea.
The act or process by which a substance in solidifying assumesthe form and sructure of a crystal, or becomes crystallized.
The charge, office, court, or jurisdiction of an official.Ayliffe.
The process of washing ore, or of uncovering mineral veins, bya heavy discharge of water from a reservoir; flushing; -- also calledbooming.
A Peruvian plant (Piper, or Artanthe, elongatum), allied to thepepper, the leaves of which are used as a styptic and astringent.
The operation of sewing up wounds of the abdomen. Quincy.
An agent, as mercury, iodine, etc., which promotes theliquefying processes of the system, and increases the secretions.
Adapted for digging; -- said of the legs of certain insects.
The art or science of cultivating the ground, including theharvesting of crops, and the rearing and management of live stock;tillage; husbandry; farming.
A person employed by an agent to transact the whole, or a part,of the business intrusted to the latter. Bouvier. Chitty.
A slender marine fish of the genus Ammodytes, especiallyAmmodytes tobianus of the English coast; -- called also sand lance.
A thermometer specially constructed for measuring tempereturesat a depth below the surface of the ground.
A name formerly given to cellulose found in certain fungi andmushrooms.
A figure in which an epithet of a contrary signification isadded to a word; e. g., cruel kindness; laborious idleness.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, cacography; badly writtenor spelled.
A race of people of uncertain origin, who inhabited Scotland inearly times.
Inborn mettle or courage; one's own temper. [Obs.] Shak.
Tissue which is not stained by fluid dyes. W. Flemming.
A lord; a landholder, esp. one who holds land directly of thecrown. [Scot.]
Erroneous construction; wrong interpretation. Bp.Stillingfleet.

Of, pertaining to, or designating, a sulphonic acid obtained,as a blue solution, by dissolving indigo in sulphuric acid; --formerly called also cerulic sulphuric acid, but properly calledindigo-disulphonic acid.
The art of employing perfumes in medicine. [R.] Dunglison.
Any one of a group of lizards of the Gecko tribe, having thetoes broad, and furnished with a groove in which the claws can beconcealed.
The office or function of an internuncio. Richardson.
Winding or coiled round; curved into a circle; taking acircular course.
The quality or state of being semiliquid; partial liquidity.
To free from the barriers or restrictions of a park. [R.]Spectator.
A burrowing rodent (Spalax typhlus), native of Russia and AsiaMinor. It has the general appearance of a mole, and is destitute ofeyes. Called also mole rat.
To embalm and dry as a mummy; to make into, or like, a mummy.Hall (1646).
Of or pertaining to Socotra, an island in the Indian Ocean, onthe east coast of Africa.-- n.
To cause to make a sharp twanging sound; to twang, or twangle.Addison.
One of the dark particles forming the doubly refracting disksof muscle fibers.
To dig out of the ground; to take out of a place of burial; todisinter. Mantell.
The basking or liver shark; -- called also homer. See Livershark, under Liver.
In a wood, mad, or raving manner; madly; furiously. [Obs.]Chaucer.
The ninth month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year, answering toa part of November with a part of December.
The scutum or dorsal plate of the middle thoracic segment of aninsect. See Illust. of Butterfly.

Of, pertaining to, or designating, a sulphacid, H2CSO2 (calledalso thiocarbonic acid), or an acid, H2CS3, analogous to carbonicacid, obtained as a yellow oily liquid of a pungent odor, and formingsalts.
An alloy of gold and silver with a large proportion of copperor other base metal, used in coinage.
The refuse from a grain distillery, used to fatten swine.
A coloring principle, C14H6O2(OH)2, found in madder, and nowproduced artificially from anthracene. It produces the Turkish reds.
