To sniggle, or fish with a brog. [Prov. Eng.] Wright.

A collection of glosses or explanations of words and passagesof a work or author; a partial dictionary of a work, an author, adialect, art, or science, explaining archaic, technical, or otheruncommon words.
Of or pertaining to the desires; hence, impelling togratification; appetitive.
The office, rank, or station of a rector; rectorship.
One who deposes or testifies under oath; one who givesevidence; usually, one who testifies in writing.
Losing freshness, color, brightness, or vigor.-- n.

A sulphate in which but half the hydrogen of the acid isreplaced by a positive element or radical, thus making the proportionof the acid to the positive or basic portion twice what it is in thenormal sulphates; an acid sulphate.
Having a movable joint or finger closing againts a precedingjoint or a projecting part of it, so that the whole may be ised forgrasping, as the claw of a crab; pincherlike.
A genus of marine bivalves which bore holes in wood. They areallied to Pholas.
A stone used by seamen for scrubbing the decks of ships.Totten.
The doctrines or tenets of Sabellius. See Sabellian, n.
In golden terms or a golden manner; splendidly; delightfully.[Obs.] Shak.
To convert or recover from the state of a proselyte. Fuller.
Any one of several species of large-footed, gallinaceous birdsof the genera Megapodius and Leipoa, inhabiting Australia and otherPacific islands. See Jungle fowl (b) under Jungle, and Leipoa.
To center again; to restore to the center. Coleridge.
A movement in tactics by which the order of companies in lineis inverted, the right being on the left, the left on the right, andso on.
A small vessel having two or three masts, and a runningbowsprit, and carrying lugsails. See Illustration in Appendix.Totten.

Produced by the friction or rustling of the breath, intonatedor unintonated, through a narrow opening between two of the mouthorgans; uttered through a close approach, but not with a completeclosure, of the organs of articulation, and hence capable of beingcontinued or prolonged; -- said of certain consonantal sounds, as f,v, s, z, etc.-- n.
Not sensitive; wanting sensation, or wanting acute sensibility.Tillotson. Ruskin.
An order of sponges having a fibrous skeleton, including thecommercial sponges.
Liability to lapse, err, or apostatize. [Archaic] Coleridge.
Having all the planes required by complete symmetry, -- inopposition to hemihedral.
A young fellow; a younker. [Obs. or Colloq.] Sir W. Scott.
Progressive emaciation of the body, accompanied with hecticfever, with no well-marked local symptoms.
An annual composite plant (Senecio vulgaris) one of the mostcommon, and widely distributed weeds on the globe.
Dehiscing or opening by a transverse fissure extending around(a capsule or pod). See Illust. of Pyxidium.
The state of being twice folded; reduplication. [R.] Bailey.

A northern duck (Dafila acuta), native of both continents. Theadult male has a long, tapering tail. Called also gray duck,piketail, piket-tail, spike-tail, split-tail, springtail, seapheasant, and gray widgeon.
That which characterizes a blockhead; stupidity. Carlyle.
Overlapping each other; -- said of leaves whose bases arefolded so as to overlap and bestride the leaves within or above them,as in the iris.
Diluting; making thinner or weaker by admixture, esp. of water.Arbuthnot.
A previous or antecedent condition; a preliminary condition.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a hypothetical sulphacid(called also thioarsenious acid) analogous to arsenious acid, andknown only in its salts.
Supplying need; profitable; advantageous. [Obs.] Udall.
A name of several English gold coins struck in different reignsand having having different values; a rose noble.
One who shares; a participator; a partaker; also, a divider; adistributer.
One of the iron hooks to which the port hinges are attached. J.Knowles.
The crab-eating raccoon (Procyon cancrivorus), found in thetropical parts of America.
The act or the policy of obstructing progress. Lond. Lit.World.
One who gives a negative vote; -- sometimes abridged intononcon. or non con.
A small rounded body contained in the nucleus of a cell or aprotozoan.
A genus scrophulariaceous plants; the speedwell. See Speedwell.
Born or bred in, of, or near a river. [Obs.] Bailey.
Affected by "dope"; esp., sluggish or dull as though under theinfluence of a narcotic. [Slang]
A land surface reduced by erosion to the general condition of aplain, but not wholly devoid of hills; a base-level plain.
The quality of being arbitrary; despoticalness; tyranny. Bp.Hall.
A kind of implement used for tearing up weeds esp. on summerfallows. [Prov. Eng.]
Growing in, or full of, clusters; like clusters. Johnson.
An iron-black mineral of metallic luster, occurring in smallorthorhombic crystals, also massive. It contains sulphur, arsenic,copper, and often silver.
The addition of a syllable or particle to the end of a pronoun,verb, or adverb.

Belonging to a certain order which is composed of the Ionicorder grafted upon the Corinthian. It is called also the Roman or theItalic order, and is one of the five orders recognized by the Italianwriters of the sixteenth century. See Capital.

A part that transmits motion to another part by contact withit, or through an intermediate relatively movable part, as a gearwhich drives another, or a lever which moves another through a link,etc. Specifically:(a) The driving wheel of a locomotive.(b) An attachment to a lathe, spindle, or face plate to turn acarrier.(c) A crossbar on a grinding mill spindle to drive the upper stone.
A genus of plants, generally with dotted leaves and yellowflowers; -- called also St. John's-wort.
One who abstains; esp., one who abstains from the use ofintoxicating liquors.
Any solid concretion, formed in any part of the body, but mostfrequent in the organs that act as reservoirs, and in the passagesconnected with them; as, biliary calculi; urinary calculi, etc.
Having a broad patch of color across the back, like a saddle;saddle-backed.
To doom beforehand; to predestinate.Thou art foredomed to view the Stygian state. Dryden.
A projecting bonnet or shade to protect the complexion; also, awide-brimmed hat. [Obs.]
The quality or appearance of being artificial; that which isartificial.
A freckle on the skin, resembling the seed of fern. [Prov.Eng.]
Of, pertaining to, or designating, the fifth pair of cranialnerves, which divide on each side of the head into three mainbranches distributed to the orbits, jaws, and parts of the mouth;trifacial.
The temple or temporal fossa. Also used adjectively.
In an intentional manner; with intention; by design; ofpurpose.
A thin leafike appendage (the exopodite) of the second maxillaof decapod crustaceans. It serves as a pumping organ to draw thewater through the gill cavity.
Having knops or knobs; fastened as with buttons. [Obs.] Rom. ofR.
A genus of polypetalous plants; also, any plant of the genus.
A conceptacle of certain lichens, which contains spermatia.
A form of albumin found in ascitic and certain serous fluids.It is sometimes regarded as a mixture of albumin and mucin.
Causing no loss of light; -- applied to reflectors which throwback the rays of light without perceptible loss.

A person appointed, ordinarily by a court, to receive, and holdin trust, money or other property which is the subject of litigation,pending the suit; a person appointed to take charge of the estate andeffects of a corporation, and to do other acts necessary to windingup its affairs, in certain cases. Bouvier.
Changeable in form; resembling a Proteus, or an amoeba.
One who holds to the principles of supernaturalism.
Partaking of divinity; divine in a partial or lower degree. Bp.Hall.
A composer or compiler of hymns; one versed in hymnology.Busby.
A copper coin of Italy and Spain equivalent to a centime.
A neuropterous insect of the genus Hemerobius, and alliedgenera.
A lizard (Stellio vulgaris), common about the EasternMediterranean among ruins. In color it is olive-green, shaded withblack, with small stellate spots. Called also hardim, and starlizard.
To convert or reduce into a condition like that of the earth;to make earthy. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Full of drifts; tending to form drifts, as snow, and the like.
To regulate the fortune of; to make happy. [Obs.] Spenser.
One eminently studious of symmetry of parts. [R.] Sir P.Sidney.
Consisting of, or having, several embryos; polyembryonic.
The act of asserting one's self, or one's own rights or claims;the quality of being self-asserting.
Any disease of the tonsils, throat, or windpipe, attended withinflammation, swelling, and difficulty of breathing and swallowing.
The act of drawing the attention and force of an enemy from thepoint where the principal attack is to be made; the attack, alarm, orfeint which diverts.
Containing copses of trees or shrubs; covered with shrubs.Bartram.
A cactaceous shrub (Cereus Pitajaya) of tropical America, whichyields a delicious fruit.
The quality of being princely; the state, manner, or dignity ofa prince.
The art or practice of foretelling events, or of telling thefortunes or the disposition of persons by inspecting the hand;palmistry.
Having pure blood, or a large admixture or pure blood; ofapproved breed; of the best stock.
A concession made for the purpose of retorting with greaterforce.
The European redstart; -- so called from the red color of itstail.
Producing prosperity or happiness; blessed. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Capable of being, or deserving to be, hated; odious;detestable.
The forests or partly cleared grounds on the frontiers.

One who guards, protects, watches over, or has the care of,some person or thing. Specifically: --(a) A treasurer; a keeper. "Tutour of your treasure." Piers Plowman.(b) (Civ. Law) One who has the charge of a child or pupil and hisestate; a guardian.(c) A private or public teacher.(d) (Eng. Universities) An officer or member of some hall, whoinstructs students, and is responsible for their discipline.(e) (Am. Colleges) An instructor of a lower rank than a professor.
To dress or adorn to excess; to dress too much. Pope.
One who possesses exalted rank or holds a position of dignityor honor; especially, one who holds an ecclesiastical rank above thatof a parochial priest or clergyman.
To move or affect strongly with passion. [Archaic] Chapman.
An oration or eulogy in praise of some person or achievement; aformal or elaborate encomium; a laudatory discourse; laudation. SeeSynonym of Eulogy.

A marine fish. The name is applied to two species:(a) The Pagrus, or Chrysophrys, auratus, a valuable food fish commonin the Mediterranean (so named from its golden-colored head); --called also giltpoll.(b) The Crenilabrus melops, of the British coasts; -- called alsogolden maid, conner, sea partridge.
Of or pertaining to a turret, or tower; resembling a tower.

A map or chart showing the principal meteorological elements ata given hour and over an extended region. Such maps usually show theheight of the barometer, the temperature of the air, the relativehumidity, the state of the weather, and the direction and velocity ofthe wind. Isobars and isotherms outline the general distribution oftemperature and pressure, while shaded areas indicate the sectionsover which rain has just fallen. Other lines inclose areas where thetemperature has fallen or risen markedly. In tabular form are shownchanges of pressure and of temperature, maximum and minimumtemperatures, and total rain for each weather station since the lastissue, usually 12 hours.
Having few or imperfect syringeal muscles; -- said of somepasserine birds (Oligomyodi).
A priest hearing, or sitting to hear, confession. [R.] Boucher
The upper division of the European Triassic. See Chart ofGeology.
Cover with, or as with, a hood. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A genus of marine gastropods, mostly natives of warm climates.
A semitranslucent variety of opal that becomes translucent ortransparent on immersion in water.
To divest of vulgarity; to make to be not vulgar. Lamb.
A spurner or contemner; a despiser; a scoffer. [Obs.] Joye.
The art of printing colored pictures on canvas from oilpaintings on stone.
Being beyond the world, or beyond the limits of our system.Boyle.
The act or process of uniting by chemical affinity, by whichsubstances unite with each other in definite proportions by weight toform distinct compounds.
A climbing plant of the genus Menispermum; -- so called fromthe crescentlike form of the seeds.
To strip of burgeons or buds; to disbud. [R.] Holland.
Impure dark-colored sulphuric acid that has been used in therefining of petroleum.
Government by the state, or by political power, in distinctionfrom government by ecclesiastical power. [R.] O. A. Brownson.
To make proportional in its parts; to reduce to symmetry.Burke.
The imaginary great circle on the earth's surface, everywhereequally distant from the two poles, and dividing the earth's surfaceinto two hemispheres.
A molding generally placed under the echinus or quarter roundof capitals in the Doric, Ionic, and Corinthian orders ofarchitecture.

One legally empowered to make quest of certain matters, esp. ofabuses of weights and measures. Specifically:(a) A churchwarden's assistant; a sidesman. Blount. [Obs.](b) A collector of parish rents. Blount. [Obs.]
The rhythmical expansion or dilatation of the heart andarteries; -- correlative to systole, or contraction.

Having or consisting of three coats; -- applied to plasteringwhich consists of pricking-up, floating, and a finishing coat; or, ascalled in the United States, a scratch coat, browning, and finishingcoat.
Any statue of the goddess Pallas; esp., the famous statue onthe preservation of which depended the safety of ancient Troy.
The act of notching or indenting the margin, or the state ofbeing so notched; also, a notch or shallow sinus in a margin.
The act of releasing, as from confinement or obligation.Milton.

An electric glow lamp having filaments of metallic tungsten.Such lamps, owing to the refractory nature of the metal, may bemaintained at a very high temperature and require an expenditure ofonly about 1.25 watts per candle power.
To act backward, or in return; to act in opposition; to beretrospective.
The smaller two-horned rhinoceros of South Africa (Atelodusbicornis).
Curled; spiral; helicoid; -- applied esp. to certain arteriesof the penis.
An antiquary; a collector of antiques. [R.] Pinkerton.
A fine plaited hat, made in Central America of the young leavesof a plant (Carludovica palmata).
A tree having the wood or the sap of the color of blood.
A state of being alone, or without company; solitariness. [R.]Bp. Montagu.
A fast of eight days before a great festival. Shipley.
An Australian tree (Pittosporum bicolor); also, its wood, usedin making waddies.
One who throws. Specifically: (a) One who throws or twistssilk; a throwster. (b) One who shapes vessels on a throwing engine.
Having a changeable, varying luster, or color, like that of achangeable silk, or oa a cat's eye in the dark.
Of extensive reading; deeply versed; -- often followed by in.
The quality of being debonair; good humor; gentleness;courtesy. Sterne.
The act of triturating, or reducing to a fine or impalpablepowder by grinding, rubbing, bruising, etc. Paley.
A rudimentary form of crystallite, spherical in shape.

The visible majesty of the Divine Presence, especially whenresting or dwelling between the cherubim on the mercy seat, in theTabernacle, or in the Temple of Solomon; -- a term used in theTargums and by the later Jews, and adopted by Christians. [Writtenalso Shechinah.] Dr. W. Smith (Bib. Dict.)
A wheel which imparts regularity to the movements of any engineor machine; a fly wheel.
An Old World finch of the genus Minia, as the M. Malabarica ofIndia, and M. cantans of Africa.
A holder, owner, or proprietor of land.-- Land"hold`ing, n. & a.
To go wrong; to go astray. [Obs.] "The world is miswent."Gower.
Common salt, obtained from sea water by evaporation.
A treatise on, or description of, coins and medals.
A slight trespass or offense; a petty crime or fault. Sir W.Scott.
A stone found at Rosetta, in Egypt, bearing a trilingualinscription, by aid of which, with other inscriptions, a key wasobtained to the hieroglyphics of ancient Egypt. Brande & C.
A millepid, or galleyworm; -- called also thousand-legged worm.
An officer of the peace having power as a conservator of thepublic peace, and bound to exeute the warrants of judicial offiers.Bouvier.
To annul indirectly by enacting a new and contrary law, insteadof by expressly abrogating or repealing the old one. [Obs.] Bailey.
Formerly, in the British service, a gunner or a gunner's mate;one of the soldiers in a train of artillery, who assisted the gunnersin loading, firing, and sponging the guns. [Obs.]
The opening and crying of hounds at first finding the scent oftheir game.
The external case of thin material used to bring any member toa required form.
One of several species of large, crested, Asiatic pheasants,belonging to the genus Euplocamus, and allied to the firebacks.
An apparatus for observing the phosphorescence produced indifferent bodies by the action of light, and for measuring itsduration.
Situated above the acromial process of the scapula.
A mixture of oleomargarine with lard or other fattyingredients. It is used as a substitute for butter. See Butterine.
One whose opinions are ungrounded notions. [R.] Bp. Hopkins.

A rare mineral, containing chiefly niobium, titanium, thorium,and cerium. It was so called by Berzelius on account of the inabilityof chemical science, at the time of its discovery, to separate someof its constituents.
Of or pertaining to the styloid and mastoid processes of thetemporal bone.
The melting or dissolving of one thing into another.
A plea, by the defendant, in a criminal prosecution, which,without admitting guilt, subjects him to all the consequences of aplea of quilty.
The division of Vertebrata in which the embryo develops anallantois. It includes reptiles, birds, and mammals.
A narrow passage between two buildings, as between the transeptand chapter house of a monastery. [Eng.]
Divided into many similar segments; -- said of an insect ormyriapod.

A one-celled, dry, indehiscent fruit, with a thin membranouspericarp, adhering closely to the seed, so that fruit and seed areincorporated in one body, forming a single grain, as of wheat,barley, etc.
A roof or ceiling covering a semicircular room or recess, orone of nearly that shape, as the apse of a church, a niche, or thelike. It is approximately the quarter of a hollow sphere.
That which deflects, as a diaphragm in a furnace, or a come ina lamp (to deflect and mingle air and gases and help combustion).
A slattern who suffers her gown to trail in the mire; adrabble-tail.
One who hawks about fruit, green vegetables, fish, etc.
The American black-throated bunting (Spiza Americana).
An opaque or milk-white chalcedony, a variety of quartz; also,a similar variety of opal.
To weave, as cloth, so as to produce the appearance of diagonallines or ribs on the surface.

A very large seal (Macrorhinus proboscideus) of the Antarcticseas, much hunted for its oil. It sometimes attains a length ofthirty feet, and is remarkable for the prolongation of the nose ofthe adult male into an erectile elastic proboscis, about a foot inlength. Another species of smaller size (M. angustirostris) occurs onthe coast of Lower California, but is now nearly extinct.
Of, pertaining to, or of the nature of, colic. Swift.
To listen or listen to; to hearken to. [Obs.] P. Plowman.
Stone-producing; -- said of polyps which form coral.
Weakening; annulling, or tending to make void. [Obs.]

A rare disease of the skin, characterized by the development ofvery hard, more or less flattened, prominences, appearing first uponthe nose and subsequently upon the neighboring parts, esp. the lips,palate, and throat. J. V. Shoemaker.
The branch of physical science which treats of the geographicaldistribution of rain.
An instrument for measuring small movements, distances, ordisplacements by means of the interference of two beams of light; --called also refractometer.
Previous esteem or estimation. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
One who gathered news for, and wrote, news-letters. Macaulay.
One who, or that which, narrows or contracts. Hannah More.
Feeding on serpents; -- said of certain birds and reptiles.
To freeze; to congeal. [Obs.]Thou hast enfrozened her disdainful breast. Spenser.
Not producing fruit; unfruitful; unprofitable. [R.] T. Adams.
To be too trustful or confident; to trust too much. [Obs.]Wyclif
A small round tower erected at the foot of a bastion. [Obs.]
Of six; belonging to six; containing six. Dr. H. More.
A circle of feathers surrounding the opening of the ear ofbirds.
A genus of woodpeckers, including some of the common Americanand European species.
An aroid herb (Calla palustris) having a white spathe. It is aninhabitant of the north temperate zone.
Producing females only; -- said of certain female insects.
A lover or friend of women; one who esteems woman as the highertype of humanity; -- opposed to Ant: misogynist.
The shank bone, or great bone above the fetlock, in the foreand hind legs of the horse and allied animals, corresponding to themiddle metacarpal or metatarsal bone of most mammals. See Horse.
A remodeling or reshaping of the thorax; especially, theoperation of removing the ribs, so as to obliterate the pleuralcavity in cases of empyema.
The act of transferring; conveyance; passage; transfer.
The vascular body which forms the apex of the penis, and theextremity of the clitoris.
Food and drink ordered from the buttery by a student.
Overthrowing; defeating; -- applied to Plato's refutativedialogues. Enfield.
The African white two-horned rhinoceros (Atelodus simus).
Not interesting of affecting; insignificant; not belonging toone. [Obs.] Addison.

A mineral consisting of the carbonate of lime and magnesia invarying proportions. It occurs in distinct crystals, and in extensivebeds as a compact limestone, often crystalline granular, either whiteor clouded. It includes much of the common white marble. Also calledbitter spar.
Any one of a series of compounds of mercaptans with aldehydes.
A mineral of a color between white and steel-gray, with ametallic luster, and consisting chiefly of arsenic and iron.
A history or description of books and manuscripts, with noticesof the different editions, the times when they were printed, etc.
Any small windowlike opening or recess, esp. one to show therelics within an altar, or the like.
Capable of being conceived; conceivable. Sir M. Hale.
An extinct genus of Paleozoic Cephalopoda, having a long,straight, conical shell. The interior is divided into numerouschambers by transverse septa.
The fourth tone above, or fifth below, the tonic; -- so calledas being under the dominant.
Having a pointed, beardlike process, as the glumes of wheat;awned. Gray.
General composition or structure; manner in which the parts ofa thing are combined; make-up; style of dress, etc. [Colloq.] H.Kingsley.

A mock sun appearing in the form of a bright light, sometimesnear the sun, and tinged with colors like the rainbow, and sometimesopposite to the sun. The latter is usually called an anthelion. Oftenseveral mock suns appear at the same time. Cf. Paraselene.
The quality or state of being knavish; knavery; dishonesty.
Furnished or covered with little scales; squamulose.
Having the nose narrow; -- said esp. of the skull. Opposed toplatyrhine.
To cause to shrink or draw together; to contract; to curl. [R.]Wiseman.
A genus of elegant, glassy sponges, consisting of interwovensiliceous fibers, and growing in the form of a cornucopia; -- calledalso Venus's flower-basket.
The book of forms for making, ordaining, and consecratingbishops, priests, and deacons.
A tribe of North American Indians belonging to the Creekconfederation.
Any ground squirrel of the genus Spermophilus; gopher. SeeIllust. under Gopher.
The state of being incomplete; imperfectness; defectiveness.Boyle.
A gathering or forming of a storm or squall, indicated bythick, dark clouds.
A derivative of urea, C3H4N2O2, obtained from allantion, as awhite, crystalline substance, with a sweetish taste; -- called alsoglycolyl urea.
A copier; a transcriber; an imitator; a plagiarist.
In a a corresponding manner; conformably; suitably.
Consistent with one's self or with itself; not deviation fromthe ordinary standard by which the conduct is guided; logicallyconsistent throughout; having each part consistent with the rest.
The act or right of alienating lands to a corporation, whichwas considered formerly as transferring them to dead hands, or inmortmain.
The block or strip of wood or similar material which stops, atthe right place, the shutting of a door.
The forked bone in front of the breastbone in birds; -- calledalso merrythought, and wishing bone. See Merrythought, and Furculum.
A salt of thiosulphuric acid; -- formerly called hyposulphite.
Of or pertaining to a chloride; containing a chloride.
The process of converting, or of being converted, into afossil.
A device to magnify sound, or direct it in a given direction ina greater volume, as a very large funnel used as an ear trumpet or asa speaking trumpet.
In a treble manner; with a threefold number or quantity;triply. Swift.
The act of bequeathing; bequeathment; bequest. Fuller.
One who, or that which, reams; specifically, an instrument withcutting or scraping edges, used, with a twisting motion, forenlarging a round hole, as a bore of a cannon, etc.
One of a numerous body of Presbyterians in Scotland who secededfrom the communion of the Established Church, about the year 1733,and formed the Secession Church, so called.
Worship of the Olympian gods, esp. as a dominant cult orreligion.
The quality or state of being insuperable; insuperableness.
A light cape or short cloak of silk or lace worn by women insummer.
To cause to pass through fine interstices, as a liquor; tofilter; to strain. Sir M. Hale.
A plane figure of a thousand angles and sides. Barlow.

The abnormal reception or slipping of a part of a tube, byinversion and descent, within a contiguous part of it; specifically,the reception or slipping of the upper part of the small intestineinto the lower; introsusception; invagination. Dunglison.
A glucoside extracted from Phillyrea as a bitter whitecrystalline substance. It is sometimes used as a febrifuge.
One who practices or advocates vivisection; a vivisector.
To place in the sky or in heaven. [R.] "A thing enskied andsainted." Shak.
A kind of inn, in the East, where caravans rest at night, beinga large, rude, unfurnished building, surrounding a court. [Writtenalso caravanserai and caravansera.]
Having no answer, or impossible to be answered. Byron.
Not isometric; having unsymmetrical parts; -- said of crystalswith three unequal axes. Dana.
To assert positively; to teach magisterially or with bold andundue confidence; to advance with arrogance.The pride of dogmatizing schools. Blackmore.
A kind of amaranth (Amarantus caudatus). Dr. Prior.
Extra pay; esp. an extra allowance to an English officerserving in India. Whitworth.
Not disposed to affection; unfriendly; disaffected. [R.]Blount.
Designating an organic acid obtained from oil of ben. SeeMoringa.
An instrument with long iron teeth set in a board, forcleansing flax or hemp from the tow, hards, or coarse part; a kind oflarge comb; -- called also hackle and heckle.

To laugh with short catches of the breath or voice; to laugh ina light, affected, or silly manner; to titter with childish levity.Giggling and laughing with all their might At the piteous hap of thefairy wight. J. R. Drake.
An air-filled gap in a magnetic or electric circuit; specif.,in a dynamo or motor, the space between the field-magnet poles andthe armature; clearance.
One who believes wrongly; one who holds a false religion. Shak.
A condition in the wood of some trees in which the rings areseparated, as some suppose, by the action of high winds upon thetrunk; wind shake.
A form of air pump in which exhaustion is produced by a streamof mercury running down a narrow tube, in the manner of an aspirator;-- named from the inventor.
A loss or decay of sight, from loss of power in the opticnerve, without any perceptible external change in the eye; -- calledalso gutta serena, the "drop serene" of Milton.
Adapted to persuade; hortatory; persuasive. [Obs.] Bp. Ward.
The act by which a third person, to protect his own interest,interposes and becomes a party to a suit pending between otherparties.
Any sac or saclike cavity; especially, one of the synovialsacs, or small spaces, often lined with synovial membrane, interposedbetween tendons and bony prominences.
An aspect of the planets when distant from each other half ofthe quintile, or thirty-six degrees.

The moral condition, or the condition in other respects, so faras it is affected by, or dependent upon, moral considerations, suchas zeal, spirit, hope, and confidence; mental state, as of a body ofmen, an army, and the like.
A mark or depression in the middle of the abdomen; theumbilicus. See Umbilicus.belly button in humans
One who makes experiments; one skilled in experiments. Faraday.
A guillemot (Uria grylle), of the arctic regions. Also appliedto the little auk or sea dove. See under Dove.
Settled pay or compensation for services, whether paid daily,monthly, or annually.
A bargelike vessel with steel hull, large hatchways, and coaltransporters, for coaling war vessels from its own hold or from othercolliers.
Of or pertaining to a sea so named, the northwestern part ofwhich is known as the Gulf of Venice.
Of or pertaining to Miletus, a city of Asia Minor, or to itsinhabitants.
The state of being dozy; drowsiness; inclination to sleep.
The science which treats of Christian doctrinal theology.
The act or practice of maliciously setting fires; arson.
Divided into lozenge-shaped compartments, as the field or abearing, by lines drawn in the direction of the bend sinister.
Admitting, as a curve, of the construction of a straight l
The redshank; -- so called from its note. [Prov. Eng.]
In a desultory manner; without method; loosely; immethodically.
A division of shrimplike Thoracostraca in which each of thethoracic legs has a long fringed upper branch (exopodite) forswimming.
The denuded stems or stalks of such crops as buckwheat and thecereal grains, beans, etc.; straw.
One who, or that which, primes; specifically, an instrument ordevice for priming; esp., a cap, tube, or water containing percussionpowder or other capable for igniting a charge of gunpowder.
A genus of leguminous plants; the Kentucky coffee tree. Theleaves are cathartic, and the seeds a substitute for coffee.
To retire into a den, or hole, and lie dormant in winter; toretreat and lie hid. [R.] G. Shaw.
The action of a horse in rearing repeatedly and dangerously.
Relating to, or resembling, a cup; also improperly used forcalycular, calyculate.
An instrument which registers meteorologic phases orconditions.
The act of confronting; the state of being face to face.
A kind of posset made of eggs, brandy, sugar, and ale. Lamb.
An old name for those Anthozoa which, like the actinias, havenumerous simple tentacles.
Freedom from disturbance; calmness; repose; apathy;indifference.
Pertaining to a symbology; versed in, or characterized by,symbology.
Issuing or coming up; -- a term used to express a charge orbearing rising or coming out of another.
The act of disfiguring, or the state of being disfigured;defacement; deformity; disfigurement. Gauden.
A plant (Campanula Rapunculus) of the Bellflower family, with atuberous esculent root; -- also called ramps.
A delicate fiber, produced in the Philippine Islands from anunidentified plant, of which dresses, etc., are made.
One of an extinct family of cryptagamous trees, including thegenus Sigillaria and its allies.
Energy wasted by hysteresis or eddy currents in the core of anarmature, transformer, etc.
An ocher-yellow mineral occurring on minute rhombohedralcrystals. It is a hydrous sulphate of iron and potash.
Pertaining to, or designating, either one of two distinct acidswhich are derived from xylic acid and related compounds, and aremetameric with uvitic acid.
A joint in which the edges or ends of the pieces united comesquarely together instead of overlapping. See 1st Butt, 8.
Making an incursion; invasive; aggressive; hostile.
The quality or state of being addicted; attachment.
A firework which, while burning, is caused to revolve on anaxis by the reaction of the escaping gases.(f) (Poetry) The burden or refrain of a song.
The doctrine that the ideas of right and wrong are intuitive.J. Grote.
Bleached yarn in making the linen tape called inkle; unwroughtinkle. Knight.
The science of describing plants in a systematic manner; also,a description of plants.
Of or pertaining to monandry; practicing monandry as a systemof marriage.
A kind of movable dam, in one form consisting of two leavesresting against each other at the top when raised and folding downone over the other when lowered, for deepening shallow parts in ariver.
A game of cards in which the suits are played in sequence,beginning with a 5 or 9, the player who gets rid of his cards firstbeing the winner.
A utensil with a bottom perforated with little holes forstraining liquids, mashed vegetable pulp, etc.; a strainer ofwickerwork, perfprated metal, or the like.
The upper lip or helmet-shaped part of a labiate flower.
Convicted by one's own consciousness, knowledge, avowal, oracts.
Retained in service on half or full pay after the disbandmentof the company or troop; -- said of an officer. [Eng.]
The quality of being catholic; universality; catholicity.
A violent, irascible, or passionate person. [Colloq.] Grose.
A needless repetition of words in speaking or writing. Milton.
The act or phenomenon of spontaneously dividing transversely,as do certain species of annelids and helminths; transverse fission.See Illust. under Syllidian.
A second or a new impression or edition of any printed work;specifically, the publication in one country of a work previouslypublished in another.
Having flowers appearing before the leaves; -- said of certainplants. Gray.
The duty of keeping watch and ward (see the Note under Watch,n., 1) with a horn to be blown upon any occasion of surprise.Burrill.
of or pertaining to the universe in its present state;specifically, pertaining to the races of men known to history.
The doctrine that the soul is preexistent to the body, and isinfused into it at conception or birth; -- opposed to tradicianismand creationism.
The quality or state of being taper; tapering form; taper.Shenstone.
A kind of thin, transparent muslin, used for dresses.
A mineral substance or petrifaction, in the form of coral.
Of or pertaining to a subdeacon, or to the office or rank of asubdeacon.
Act of assoiling, or state of being assoiled; absolution;acquittal.
The operation of breaking a bone in order to correct deformity.
A roundabout or indirect course; indirectness. [Obs.] S.Richardson.
An irregular, narrow, projecting part of a field. [Prov. Eng.]
The front part of an edifice or lot; extent of front.
To relinquish or deny having a claim; to disavow another'sclaim; to decline accepting, as an estate, interest, or office.Burrill.
Of or pertaining to the pine; obtained from the pine; formerly,designating an acid which is the chief constituent of common resin, -- now called abietic, or sylvic, acid.
A body formed from bilirubin, identical with urobilin.

An alkaloid distinct from picrotoxin and obtained from thecocculus indicus (the fruit of Anamirta Cocculus, formerlyMenispermum Cocculus) as a white, crystalline, tasteless powder; --called also menispermina.
A sort of cupboard, or case, to contain bows and otherimplements of archery.
A white crystalline substance, C3H7NSO2, containing sulphur,occuring as a constituent of certain rare urinary calculi, andoccasionally found as a sediment in urine.
A colored photograph produced by superimposing a translucentcolored positive over a strong uncolored one.
A state of being not divided; oneness. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
An instrument for recording simultaneously the pressure andtemperature of a gas; a combined thermograph and barograph.
Capable of being enjoyed or of giving joy; yielding enjoyment.Milton.
To exceed in noise; to surpass in noisiness. [R.] Fuller.
A condition of the blood, characterized by an abnormally largeamount of fibrin, as in many inflammatory diseases.
A plant (Pistia stratiotes) which floats on tropical waters,and forms a rosette of spongy, wedge-shaped leaves. J. Smith (Dict.Econ. Plants).
Pertaining to a gulf; full of gulfs; hence, devouring. [R.]Mallet.
Not ductile; incapable of being drawn into threads, as a metal;inelastic; tough.
Something hanging straight down; a plumb line. [Obs.]
The art of measuring the distance of objects afar off. [Obs. orR.]
The mendole; a small worthless Mediterranean fish consideredpoisonous by the ancients. See Mendole.
Act of injuring another's reputation by any slanderouscommunication, written or oral; the wrong of maliciously injuring thegood name of another; slander; detraction; calumny; aspersion.
Of or pertaining to the region between the rectum and ishialtuberosity.
A measure of weight, containing a hundred grams, or about 3.527ounces avoirdupois.
One of series of long, heavy waves which roll in upon a coast,sometimes in calm weather.
An official administering a prefecture of China; a prefect,supervising the civil business of the hsiens or districts comprisedin his fu (which see).
To form into bone; to change from a soft animal substance intobone, as by the deposition of lime salts.

A gaseous hydrocarbon, C2H6, forming a constituent of ordinaryilluminating gas. It is the second member of the paraffin series, andits most important derivatives are common alcohol, aldehyde, ether,and acetic acid. Called also dimethyl.
A place of defense; a fortress; a garrison; a fortress; agarrison or guardhouse.
A fluoride of the cerium metals occurring in hexagonal crystalsof a pale yellow color. Cf. Fluocerite.
An order of fishes generally having the maxillary bone unitedwith the premaxillary, and the articular united with the dentary.
A native or inhabitant of Slavonia; ethnologically, a Slav.
A rent reserved in grants of land, by the payment of which thetenant is quit from other service. Blackstone.
An ancient wind instrument, resembling the bassoon in tone.
A violent wind from the west or southwest, which sweeps overthe pampas of South America and the adjacent seas, often doing greatdamage. Sir W. Parish.
The process of temporarily raising the value of a stock, as byfictitious sales. [U.S.]
A four-wheeled vehicle, having a long elastic board or frameresting on the bolsters or axletrees, and a seat or seats placedtransversely upon it; -- called also buck wagon.
A supposed compound of hydrofluoris acid and a base; afluoride. [Archaic]
The quality of state of being profligate; a profligate or veryvicious course of life; a state of being abandoned in moral principleand in vice; dissoluteness.
Composed of dactyls and trochees so arranged as to produce amovement like that of ordinary speech.
A follower of Damian, patriarch of Alexandria in the 6thcentury, who held heretical opinions on the doctrine of the HolyTrinity.
The state of being on the right-hand side; also, the quality ofbeing right-handed; right-handedness. Sir T. Browne.
A laborer, especially a deck hand, on a river steamboat, whomoves the cargo, loads and unloads wood, and the like; in anopprobrious sense, a shiftless vagrant who lives by chance jobs.[Western U.S.]

A capsule developed on certain hydroids (Thecaphora), inclosingthe blastostyle upon which the medusoid buds or gonophores aredeveloped; -- called also gonangium, and teleophore. See Hydroidea,and Illust. of Campanularian.
Water impregnated with lime; esp., an artificial solution oflime for medicinal purposes.
Pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, erythrin.
A frame, generally vertical, for holding small arms.
Of or pertaining to an extensive forest in Germany, of whichthere are still portions in Swabia and the Hartz mountains.
Dull of apprehension; not possessing quick intelligence.
The East Indian name for grass oil. See under Grass.
Having bipinnate leaflets arranged on each side of a rhachis.
A kind of sauce much used in India, containing garlic, pepper,ginger, and other strong spices.
A variety of the mineral domeykite, or copper arsenide, fromthe Condurra mine in Cornwall, England.
A deputy ruler or viceroy in India; also, a title given bycourtesy to other persons of high rank in the East.
The ideas, views, aims, etc., of a Utopian; impracticableschemes of human perfection; optimism.
To pass from one note to another with no perceptible cassationof sound.
Furnished with, or as with, dower or a marriage portion. Shak.
A kind of carpet woven with loops like the Brussels, butdiffering from it in having the loops cut so as to form an elasticvelvet pile; -- so called because made originally at Wilton, England.
Neglect of disuse of familiarity, or familiar acquaintance.[Obs.] South.
A law or ruling prohibiting proper or free debate, as inclosure. [Colloq. or Cant]
A flower-shaped ornament, esp. one terminating an object orforming one of a series, as a knob of a cover to a dish, or a flower-shaped part in a necklace.
A spider monkey (Ateles belzebuth) of Central and SouthAmerica.
Of or pertaining to Leon, in Spain.-- n. sing. & pl.
A heavy conducting wire on which the trolley car runs and fromwhich it receives the current.
A hydrocarbon of the paraffin series, a white waxy substance,C19H40; -- so called from the number of carbon atoms in the molecule.
Of or pertaining to a feast or banquet. [Obs.] Smart.
Vessels and other utensils, ornaments, or the like, made ofbaked clay. See Crockery, Pottery, Stoneware, and Porcelain.
A thin, washable material of silk, or silk and cotton,originally imported from India, but now also made elsewhere.
A Spanish title of courtesy given to a lady; Mrs.; Madam; also,a lady.
An officer of the forest who had the care of vert and venisonby night. [Obs.]
To convert into agate; to make resemble agate. Dana.
To heat, as steam, apart from contact with water, until itresembles a perfect gas.
One engaged in warfare; a military man; a soldier; a warrior.
The formation of stony concretions or calculi in any part ofthe body, especially in the bladder and urinary passages. Dunglison.
One who holds that the atonement was made only for a part ofmankind, that is, for the elect.
To reduce toa feudal tenure; to conform to feudalism.

A light road carriage propelled by the feet of the rider.Originally it was propelled by striking the tips of the toes on theroadway, but commonly now by the action of the feet on a pedal orpedals connected with the axle of one or more of the wheels, andcausing their revolution. They are made in many forms, with two,three, or four wheels. See Bicycle, and Tricycle.
Making or secreting a hard substance; becoming hard.
Any large tumor developed in the abdomen, and neitherfluctuating nor sonorous. Dunglison.
Cleft to the middle, or slightly beyond the middle, into threeparts; three-cleft.
Extremely rash; foolhardy. See under March, the month. Sir W.Scott.
Stridulous; able to stridulate; used in stridulating; adaptedfor stridulation. Darwin.
A rhombohedral zeolitic mineral, related in form andcomposition to chabazite.
One who hangs on, or sticks to, a person, place, or service; adependent; one who adheres to others' society longer than he iswanted. Goldsmith.
The act of appeasing, or the state of being appeased;pacification. Hayward.
In Spain and Portugal, one who supports the constitution.

A combined rotary type-setting and printing machine for officeuse. The type is transferred semi-automatically by means of keys froma type-supply drum to a printing drum. The printing may be done bymeans of an inked ribbon to print "typewritten" letters, or directlyfrom inked type or a stereotype plate, as in a printing press.
A clause, as in a blanket mortgage or policy, that includes agroup or class of things, rather than a number mentioned individuallyand having the burden, loss, or the like, apportioned among them.
The quality or state of being signal or remarkable. [Obs.] SirT. Browne.
Going out of use; becoming obsolete; passing into desuetude.
Steel cast in ingots from the Bessemer converter or open-hearthfurnace.

A street towards the southern end of the borough of Manhattan,New York City, extending from Broadway to the East River; -- socalled from the old wall which extended along it when the citybelonged to the Dutch. It is the chief financial center of the UnitedStates, hence the name is often used for the money market and thefinancial interests of the country.
One who deals in wonders, or believes in them; a wonder worker.Carlyle.
Not apprehensible; unintelligible; inconceivable. Milton.
Pertaining to the sending of two messages in oppositedirections at the same time.
One of a series of compounds containing iodine, and analogousto the chlorhydrins.
Of or pertaining to the patriarch Noah, or to his time.
Having flanches; -- said of an escutcheon with those bearings.
A detachment or separation from a former connection. [R.]
A machine for cleansing wool of burs, seeds, and othersubstances.
One among the Jews who adhered to the Talmud and the traditionsof the rabbins, in opposition to the Karaites, who rejected thetraditions.
The bone of either the upper arm or the thing, the propodialiabeing the humerus and femur.
A division of the Arachnida, having the abdomen annulated,including the scorpions, harvestmen, etc.; pedipalpi.
To associate or hold fellowship as brothers, or as men of likeoccupation or character; to have brotherly feelings.
A game played by volleying a large inflated ball with the handsover a net 7 ft. 6 in. high.

In Ireland, a national school which has been built by the aidof grants from the board of Commissioners of National Education andis secured for educational purposes by leases to the commissionersthemselves, or to the commissioners and the trustees.
A chorus leader; esp. one who provided at his own expense andunder his own supervision one of the choruses for the musicalcontents at Athens.
The hut used by the nomadic Indian tribes of the arid regionsof the west and southwest United States, typically elliptical inform, with a rough frame covered with reed mats or grass orbrushwood.
In the Eucharist, the versicles immediately before the preface,inviting the people to join in the service by "lifting up the heart"to God.
The principle or advocacy of a political alliance or union ofall the states of America.
Affected by, or produced by, gangrene; of the nature ofgangrene.
One who receives, or its entitled to receive, an annuity. Lamb.

The irritating action of various agents (stimuli) on muscles,nerves, or a sensory end organ, by which activity is evoked;especially, the nervous impulse produced by various agents on nerves,or a sensory end organ, by which the part connected with the nerve isthrown into a state of activity; irritation.
. A peculiar sort of stitch formed by the locking of twothreads together, as in the work done by some sewing machines. SeeStitch.
The hypothetical radical C3H5O, regarded as the essentialresidue of propionic acid and certain related compounds.
An old dance with swords and bucklers; a sword dance.
A performer upon the viola di gamba. See under Viola.
An American fresh-water mussel (Quadrula pustulosa). Its shellis used in making buttons.
Gathered, or having the map gathered, into little tufts, knots,or protuberances. Cf. Frieze, v. t., and Friz, v. t.,
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an anilene sulphonic acidwhich is obtained as a white crystalline substance.
A place or ground set apart for the burial of the dead; agraveyard; a churchyard; a necropolis.
Genesis through an internal force, as opposed to naturalselection.
A student of Chinese; one versed in the Chinese language,literature, and history.
A iodide having more than one atom of iodine in the molecule.
A texture of osiers, twigs, or rods; articles made of such atexture.
A kind of food used by the natives of Western Africa, made ofmillet flour with flesh, and leaves of the baobab; -- called alsolalo.
Glassmaker's ashes; a kind of potash or pearlash, brought fromthe Levant and Syria, -- used in the manufacture of fine glass.
The blue coloring matter of certain flowers. Same as Cyanin.
A tall pole erected in an open place and wreathed with flowers,about which the rustic May-day sports were had.
A place or room for the stowage of cargo in a ship; also, theact of stowing cargo; the pulling and moving about of packagesincident to close stowage; -- formerly written romage. [Obs.]
Consisting of two iambic dimeters catalectic, the last of whichlacks the final syllable; -- said of a kind of verse.
To swell, or be prominent, beyond the adjacent surface; tobulge out. S. Sharp.

A high and narrow tank, with a central cylinder for theintroduction of compressed air, used in the agitation and settling ofpulp (pulverized ore and water) during treatment by the cyanideprocess; -- so named because, though originally devised in NewZealand, it was first practically introduced in Pachuca, Mexico.

The seat of sensation; the nervous center or centers to whichimpressions from the external world must be conveyed before they canbe perceived; the place where external impressions are localized, andtransformed into sensations, prior to being reflected to other partsof the organism; hence, the whole nervous system, when animated, sofar as it is susceptible of common or special sensations.
A person whose employment is to write what another dictates, orto copy what another has written.
The state of existing in tribes; also, tribal feeling; tribalprejudice or exclusiveness; tribal peculiarities or characteristics.
A litter on which a person may be carried. [Obs.] Coigrave.
A medicinal confection made of freshly gathered vegetablesubstances mixed with finely powdered refined sugar. See Confection.
A French lyceum, or secondary school supported by the Frenchgovernment, for preparing students for the university.
A spoon of the largest size commonly used at the table; --distinguished from teaspoon, dessert spoon, etc.
Having half as many (three) carboxyl radicals as mellitic acid;-- said of an organic acid.
Not stable; not standing fast or firm; unstable; prone tochange or recede from a purpose; mutable; inconstant.
Any one of several species of fishes belonging to Polynemus andallied genera. They have numerous long pectoral filaments.

Formerly, one of the four terms of the courts of common law inEngland, beginning on the eleventh of January and ending on thethirty-first of the same month, in each year; -- so called from thefestival of St. Hilary, January 13th.
Somewhat cinereous; of a color somewhat resembling that of woodashes.
The quality of being irresolvable; irresolvableness.

One of a order of nuns founded in 1812 at Loretto, in Kentucky.The members of the order (called also Sisters of Loretto, or Friendsof Mary at the Foot of the Cross) devote themselves to the cause ofeducation and the care of destitute orphans, their labors beingchiefly confined to the Western United States.
Tending or adapted to remind; careful to remind. Southey.
A metrical composition consisting of a single strophe.
A worm or grub that makes for itself a case. See Caddice.
An alkaloid said to be contained in the bark of Geoffroyainermis, a leguminous tree growing in Jamaica and Surinam; -- calledalso jamacina. Watts.
The four-colored flag of the South African Republic, orTransvaal, -- red, white, blue, and green.
One who, or that which, beautifies or makes beautiful.
To act with force in opposition to force impressed; to exerciserepulsion.
One who estimates or sets the value of a thing; an appraiser.Shak.
A variety of wheat from which starch is produced; -- calledalso French rice.
The European sedge warbler (Acrocephalus phragmitis).
A young chicken before it is fully fledged. [Prov. Eng.]
The quality of being of particular value or worth; nicely;excellence.
A white opacity in the cornea of the eye; -- called alsoalbugo.
To excel, or to leave behind, in sailing; to sail faster than.Beau. & Fl.
That point in the orbit of the moon which is at the greatestdistance from the earth.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, great fear, or funking.[Colloq. Eng.]
To waste away; to pine; to languish. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]Gower.
After the manner of the Hebrews or of the Hebrew language.
To move heavily; to lounge or idle; to loll. [Law.] CharlesReade.
Proper to be examined in a court of justice. Bailey.
Speaking in a quick or short manner; hence, gruff; curt.[Colloq.]
A European species of Iris (Iris Pseudacorus) having brightyellow flowers.
The symbol, quantity, or thing upon which a mathematicaloperation is performed; -- called also faciend.
To converge to one point or focus, as light or rays.
A parsonage; -- so called in some Baptist churches. [SouthernU. S.]
A tasteless white crystalline substance, extracted from theroots of the sulphurwort (Peucedanum), masterwort (Imperatoria), andother related plants; -- called also imperatorin.

A rare element of the carbon-silicon group, intermediatebetween the metals and nonmetals, obtained from the mineral zircon asa dark sooty powder, or as a gray metallic crystalline substance.Symbol Zr. Atomic weight, 90.4.
One who makes experiments; an experimenter. Whaterly.
The act or practice of communicating a disease to a person inhealth, by inserting contagious matter in his skin or flesh.
The art or office of a herald; the art, practice, or science ofrecording genealogies, and blazoning arms or ensigns armorial; also,of marshaling cavalcades, processions, and public ceremonies.
In the smooth and melodious style of an air; ariose.
A dugout canoe; by extension, any small boat. [Writtenvariously periauger, perogue, piragua, periagua, etc.]
To destroy the aggregation of; to separate into componentparts, as an aggregate mass.
Of or pertaining to Pomerania, a province of Prussia on theBaltic Sea.-- n.
The sine of the complement of an arc or angle. See Illust. ofFunctions.
To make as pliable as kid leather. [Obs.] Br. Montagu.
To strive or struggle against; to withstand. [Obs.] Spenser.
The state or condition of being nonresident, Swift.
A genus of orchidaceous plants including the lady's slipper.
A salt of selenic acid; -- formerly called also seleniate.
One who carries a wallet; a foot traveler; a tramping beggar.[Colloq.] Wright.
A closely fitting knit sleeve; also, a legging of knittedmaterial. [Scot.]
Likelihood of the occurrence of any event in the doctrine ofchances, or the ratio of the number of favorable chances to the wholenumber of chances, favorable and unfavorable. See 1st Chance, n., 5.
One who makes, imitates, collects, or deals in, bronzes.
The act iif immuring, or the state of being immured;imprsonment.
One who joins or promotes a coalition; one who advocatescoalition.
The collection of postage stamps of various issues.
An officer who directs and lays out the meres or boundaries forthe workmen; -- called also bailiff, and barmaster. [Eng.]
The husband of one's daughter; a man in his relationship to hiswife's parents.To take me as for thy son in lawe. Chaucer.
A flat stone used in paving, or any rock which will split intosuch stones. See Flag, a stone.
A goatlike antelope (Haplocerus montanus) which inhabits theRocky Mountains, frequenting the highest parts; -- called alsomountain goat.
One of numerous small calcareous structures forming theskeleton of certain echinoderms, as the starfishes.
A genus of minute living Foraminifera having a globular shell.
A substance which is formed in mucous epithelial cells, andgives rise to mucin.
Peevishness; malignity; frowardness; crabbedness; surliness.[Obs.] Shak.
A winding or zigzag trench forming a path or communication fromone siegework to another, to a magazine, etc.
To take off the hat of; to remove one's hat, especially as amark of respect. H. Spenser.
Blood formative; -- applied to a substance in early fetal life,which breaks up gradually into blood vessels.
The colored ring around the nipple, or around a vesicle orpustule.
To snuffle, as one does with a catarrh. [Prov. Eng.]
One who carries about a small load; a peddler. See 2d Jag.[Scot.] Sir W. Scott.
A genus of cruciferous plants, having white or yellowishflowers, including several species of cress. They are found chieflyin wet or damp grounds, and have a pungent biting taste.
An orthopterus insect of the genus Blatta, and allied genera.
One who kills, or attempts to kill, by surprise or secretassault; one who treacherously murders any one unprepared fordefense.
Complete overthrow; disorder; a turning upside down.
The song of Simeon (Luke ii. 29-32), used in the ritual of manychurches. It begins with these words in the Vulgate.
The granule within the nucleolus or entoblast of a nucleatedcell. Agassiz.
Any unusual outgrowth from the surface of a thing, as of apetal; also, the capacity or act of producing such an outgrowth.
A book in which rough entries of transactions are made,previous to their being carried into the journal.
A suborder of Arachnoidea, including the European tarantula andthe wolf spiders (Lycosidae) and their allies, which capture theirprey by rapidly running and jumping. See Wolf spider.
The Australian gray crow shrile (Strepera anaphonesis); -- socalled from its note.
To treat as if righteous and just; to pardon; to exculpate; toabsolve.By him all that believe are justified from all things, from which yecould not be justified by the law of Moses. Acts xiii. 39.
Bordering on the sea; situated beside the sea. Drayton.
A germ in that stage of development in which its form is simplythat of a non-nucleated mass of protoplasm. It precedes the one-celled germ. So called from its likeness to a moner. Haeckel.
The sound of a drum when continuously beaten; hence, aclamorous, repeated sound; a clatter.The rubadub of the abolition presses. D. Webster.
One of the two most experienced barristers in the Court ofExchequer. Cf. Postman, 2.
A traveling tinker; also a tramp or sturdy beggar. [Prov. Eng.]
The tendency to associate in cliques; the spirit of cliques.
Capable of being insulted or affronted. [R.] Emerson.
A catch made by a player on side who makes a prescribed signalthat he will not attempt to advance the ball when caught. He must notthen be interfered with.

The doctrine, in opposition to the materialists, that all whichexists is spirit, or soul -- that what is called the external worldis either a succession of notions impressed on the mind by the Deity,as maintained by Berkeley, or else the mere educt of the mind itself,as taught by Fichte.
Shaped like a helmet; galeate. See Illust. of Galeate.
An instrument for determining the depth of the sea water by itspressure.
To wince; to shrink; to kick with impatience or uneasiness.
A large grackle or blackbird (Quiscalus major), found in theSouthern United States.
A falling back or descending a second time; a relapse. W.Montagu.
A reader of lections; formerly, a person designated to readlessons to the illiterate.
An unleavened cake, as of maize flour, baked on a heated ironor stone.
A sleeve covering the arm from the elbow to the hand. Crabb.
An oxgang, or as much land as an ox can plow in a year; anancient measure of land, of indefinite quantity, but usuallyestimated at fifteen acres.
Lace, gimp, braid etc., sewed on a garment. Sir W. Scott.
The quality or fact of being attractable. Sir W. Jones.
One who habitually intoxicates himself with a narcotic obtainedfrom mandrake.
To balance two scales, sides, or ends; to keep even with equalweight on each side; to keep in equipoise. H. Spenser.
Somewhat prehensile; prehensile in an inferior degree.
A figure of speech in which opposite things or persons arecompared. Crabb.
The nonpayment or nonacceptance of commercial paper by theparty on whom it is drawn.
The venereal disease; -- often used as a mild oath. [Obs.]Shak.
The outlet from a dam or reservoir; also, a cut to divert theflow of water.
In Turkey and other Oriental countries, a porter or burdenbearer; specif., in Western India, a palanquin bearer.
An act or a bill conferring upon a chief executive, as agovernor or mayor, large powers of appointment and removal of headsof departments or other subordinate officials. [Polit. Cant, U. S.]
A yellow crystalline glucoside obtained from the pansy (Violatricolor), and decomposing into glucose and quercitrin.
That part of a crustacean behind the cephalothorax; -- morecommonly called abdomen.
In a reverse manner; on the other hand; on the opposite. Bp.Pearson.
A tumor made up of a gelatinous tissue resembling that found inthe umbilical cord.
The protecting of a joint, as between roof and parapet wall,with mortar, or cement, where flashing is employed in better work.
Not teachable; indisposed to be taught, trained, ordisciplined; not easily instructed or governed; dull; intractable.
Growing in sets of five; -- said especially of leaves composedof five leaflets set at the end of a common petiole.
To eject from the trachea or lungs; to discharge, as phlegm orother matter, by coughing, hawking, and spitting; to spit forth.
The act of realizing, or the state of being realized.
A genus of shrubs or small trees, having the foliage coveredwith small silvery scales; oleaster.
A subordinate or local assembly; a diet of inferior rank.
A house for children to play in or to play with; a playhouse.
The river lamprey (Ammocoetes, or Lampetra, fluviatilis).

That quality or condition of a body in virtue of which itexhibits opposite, or contrasted, properties or powers, in opposite,or contrasted, parts or directions; or a condition giving rise to acontrast of properties corresponding to a contrast of positions, as,for example, attraction and repulsion in the opposite parts of amagnet, the dissimilar phenomena corresponding to the different sidesof a polarized ray of light, etc.
Act of disclosing or uncovering something concealed. [Obs.]Boyle.
As much as a wineglass will hold; enough to fill a wineglass.It is usually reckoned at two fluid ounces, or four tablespoonfuls.
To calculate or determine beforehand; to prearrange. Masson.
Liability to be sued; the state of being subjected by law tocivil process.
A commendation; eulogy. [R.] "Commendatories to our affection."Sharp.
The farthest point of the moon's northing and southing, in itsmonthly revolution. [Obs.]
Vegetable tissue composed of short cells with thickened orhardened walls, as in nutshells and the gritty parts of a pear. SeeSclerotic.
A lubber; an idle fellow; a loiterer. [Old Slang] Dr. Favour.
A horizontal dislocation in a metallic lode, taking place at anintersection with another lode.
An albuminous body formed in small quantity by the pepticdigestion of proteids. It can be converted into peptone by pancreaticjuice, but not by gastric juice.
One of the partitions which divide a compound ovary into cells.
A necklace of a rural fashion, bought at St. Audrey's fair;hence, a necklace in general. [Obs.]Of which the Naiads and the blue Nereids make Them tawdries for theirnecks. Drayton.
The theory or doctrines put forth by Darwin. See above. Huxley.
To put off; to lay aside, as a garment. [Obs.] Spenser.
A gratuity given to tenants after they had reaped their lord'scorn. [Obs.]

One who, or that which, revolves; specifically, a firearm (commonly a pistol) with several chambers or barrels so arranged as torevolve on an axis, and be discharged in succession by the same lock;a repeater.
To bring under the influence of religion. [R.] Mallock.
One who blatters; a babbler; a noisy, blustering boaster.
The part of each apodeme derived from the intersternal membranein Crustacea and insects.
To hold more than one benefice at the same time. [Eng.]
Of or pertaining to prostitutes or prostitution; meretricious.[Obs.] Bale.
Restoration of a mixed body or matter to its former nature andstate. [Achaic.] Coxe.
Having a very small knoblike termination, or collected intominute capitula.
Having one's thoughts directed toward mean or insignificantsubjects.
A physician who applies the rules of dietetics to the cure ofdiseases. Dunglison.
Adieu; farewell; good-by; -- chiefly used among Spanish-speaking people.
A private lane, or one opening out of the usual road.
Foul matter; dirt, rubbed in; sullying blackness, deeplyingrained.

In Roman dwellings, a cistern or tank, set in the atrium orperistyle to recieve the water from the roof, by means of thecompluvium; generally made ornamental with flowers and works of artaround its birm.
Chromate of copper and lead, of various shades of green.
Partly crystalline; -- said of rock which consists of crystalsimbedded in a glassy ground mass.
The division of Thysanura which includes Podura, and alliedforms.
The outer, nonsensitive layer of the skin; cuticle; scarfskin.See Dermis.
A goddess supposed to live in or reign over the sea, or somepart of the sea.
Pertaining to the Muse Erato who presided over amatory poetry.Stormonth.
Of or pertaining to the last syllable but two.-- n.
A species of informal state paper, much used in negotiation.
By constraint or compulsion; in a constrained manner. Hooker.
Low relief; sculpture, the figures of which project less thanhalf of their true proportions; -- called also bassrelief and basso-rilievo. See Alto-rilievo.
Jerked beef; beef cut into long strips and dried in the windand sun. Darwin.
A machine for setting type or for casting lines of type andsetting them.

A kind of starch with very large, oval, flattened grains, oftensold as arrowroot, and extensively used for adulterating cocoa. It ismade from the rootstocks of a species of Canna, probably C. edulis,the tubers of which are edible every month in the year.
Wrought with severe labor; elaborate; studied. Swift.
Having the foot united with the neck; of or pertainingto theTrachelipoda.
An appelation applied after the manner of a proper name to thefox. Same as Renard.
An internal dorsal chitinous process between the first twodivisions of the thorax of insects.
The use of words in a sense opposite to their proper meaning;as when a court of justice is called a court of vengeance.
A very large siluroid fish (Leptops olivaris) of theMississippi valley; -- also called goujon, mud cat, and yellow cat.
A binary compound containing hydrogen; a hydride. [R.] SeeHydride.
Opposed to pictures or images as objects of worship. [R.] SirT. Browne.
Ornamental work, mostly carved in olivewood, decorated withinlay, made at or near Sorrento, Italy. Hence, more rarely, jig-sawwork and the like done anywhere.
A very sensitive modification or application of the thermopile,used for indicating minute changes of radiant heat, or temperature.
One who accepts rationalism as a theory or system; also,disparagingly, a false reasoner. See Citation under Reasonist.
Half proof; evidence from the testimony of a single witness.[Obs.] Bailey.
Quality or state of being ubiquitary, or ubiquitous. [R.]Fuller.

Any bee of the genus Apis, which lives in communities andcollects honey, esp. the common domesticated hive bee (Apismellifica), the Italian bee (A. ligustica), and the Arabiab bee (A.fasciata). The two latter are by many entomologists considered onlyvarieties of the common hive bee. Each swarm of bees consists of alarge number of workers (barren females), with, ordinarily, one queenor fertile female, but in the swarming season several young queens,and a number of males or drones, are produced.
The quality of being alterable; variableness; alterability.
An unfermentable sugar, obtained as an uncrystallizable sirupby the decomposition of melitose; also obtained from a Tasmanianeucalyptus, -- whence its name.
A glucoside found in licorice root (Glycyrrhiza), in monesiabark (Chrysophyllum), in the root of the walnut, etc., and extractedas a yellow, amorphous powder, of a bittersweet taste.
Low, worthless people; the rabble. [Scot.] Jamieson.
A parisan of Charles X. Of France, or of Dod Carlos of Spain.
The land within the boundaries of a farm; a farmstead or farm.[Archaic.] Longfellow.
A cement used in making joints, filling cracks, etc.  For iron,the principal constituents are iron borings and sal ammoniac; forwood, white lead or litharge, whiting, and linseed oil.
The period or state of full expansion in a flower. Gray.
The projection in rear of the breech of a cannon, usually aknob or breeching loop connected with the gun by a neck. In oldwriters it included all in rear of the base ring.
A division of Tunicata comprising the free-swimming species,such as Salpa and Doliolum.
The lungs of an animal or bird; -- sometimes coarsely appliedto the lungs of a human being.
Having the power of excreting, or promoting excretion. Harvey.
Having the power or purpose to revise; revising. Story.
The quality of being invendible; invendibleness; unsalableness.
To diversify aggain what is already diversified. [R.] Sir M.Hale.
Siliceous earth; specifically, porous infusorial earth, used asan absorbent of nitroglycerin in the manufacture of dynamite.
A white, crystallizable, bitter substance extracted from oil ofcascarilla.
A native or inhabitant of Lucca, in Tuscany; in the plural, thepeople of Lucca.
the state of being copartners in any undertaking. [R.]
Incomplete paralysis, affecting motion but not sensation.
. A shutting out from communion; excommunication. [Obs.]Excommunication is the utmost of ecclesiastical judicature. Milton.
One of the serial segments, or metameres, of which the bodiesof vertebrate and articulate animals are composed.
A fusty state or quality; moldiness; mustiness; an ill smellfrom moldiness.
To habituate to a climate not native; to acclimatize. J. H.Newman.
A coarse American composite weed (Polymnia Uvedalia).
A Swedish coin worth about twenty-seven cents. It was formerlythe unit of value in Sweden.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the ethylene series,metameric with fumaric acid and obtained by heating malic acid.
A South American bird (Guira guira) allied to the cuckoos.
That part of moral philosophy which treats of virtue, itsnature, and the means of attaining to it.
A Chilian burrowing rodent of the genus Spalacopus.

Lit., culture war; -- a name, originating with Virchow (1821 --1902), given to a struggle between the the Roman Catholic Church andthe German government, chiefly over the latter's efforts to controleducational and ecclesiastical appointments in the interest of thepolitical policy of centralization. The struggle began with thepassage by the Prussian Diet in May, 1873, of the so-called May laws,or Falk laws, aiming at the regulation of the clergy. Oppositioneventually compelled the government to change its policy, and from1880 to 1887 laws virtually nullifying the May laws were enacted.
One of a pair of small appendages of the lingua or labium ofcertain insects. See Illust. under Hymenoptera.
Pertaining to regalia; pertaining to the royal insignia orprerogatives. Hallam.
A variety of gesso which when dried becomes hard and durable,often used in making bas-relief casts, which are colored and mountedin elaborate frames.

An American feline quadruped (Felis concolor), resembling theAfrican panther in size and habits. Its color is tawny, withoutspots; hence writers often called it the American lion. Called alsopuma, panther, mountain lion, and catamount. See Puma.
The quality or state of being unique; uniqueness. [R.] Walpole.
of or pertaining to gravel, or renal calculi. Dunglison.
Of or pertaining to Aracan, a province of British Burmah.-- n. sing. & pl.
One who dogmatizes; a bold asserter; a magisterial teacher.Hammond.
A term applied to a lachrymal gland on the inner side of theorbit of many animals which have a third eyelid, or nictitatingmembrane. See Nictitating membrane, under Nictitate.
A genus of plants (Uvularia) with yellowish bell-shapedflowers.
A rare element supposed by Bahr to have been extracted fromwasite, but now identified with thorium.
A variety of allanite occurring in slender prismatic crystals.
An intensely poisonous alkaloid, extracted from aconite.
In a newfangled manner; with eagerness for novelty. [Obs.] SirT. More.
A peculiar transparent worm of the genus Sagitta, living at thesurface of the sea. See Sagitta.
A kind of short-barreled pocket pistol, of very large caliber,often carrying a half-ounce ball.
The act of naturalizing; endenization. [R.] Evelyn.
A spear bearer; a statue of a man holding a spear or in theattitude of a spear bearer. Several important sculptures of thissubject existed in antiquity, copies of which remain to us.
The fire god of the Ammonites, to whom human sacrifices wereoffered; Moloch. Lev. xviii. 21.
A rounded apothecium having an elevated rim formed of theproper thallus, the fructification of certain lichens.
Uncertain; inconstant; slippery. [Obs. & R.] Beau. & Fl.
The sudden issuing of a body of troops, usually small, from abesieged place to attack or harass the besiegers; a sally.
The jamb, or cheek, of an opening in a wall, as of door orwindow.
The withdrawing, or open renunciation, of a suit in court bythe plaintiff, by which he forever lost his right of action.Blackstone.
The act of exalting one's self, or the state of being soexalted.
Fagots, boughs, or loose materials of any kind, laid on thebottom of the hold for the cargo to rest upon to prevent injury bywater, or stowed among casks and other cargo to prevent their motion.

A mineral occurring in rhombic prisms, generally yellowish andpellucid, also colorless, and of greenesh, bluish, or brownishshades. It sometimes occurs massive and opaque. It is a fluosilicateof alumina, and is used as a gem.
To make a raid for booty; to maraud; also, to skirmish inadvance of an army. See Picaroon. [Obs.] Bp. Burnet.
Unlawful use of a right; use in excess of, or varying from,one's right. Bouvier.
The act of dimidiating or halving; the state of beingdimidiate.
An extinct genus of reptiles of the Permian period. Called alsoProtosaurus.
A genus of composite plants in which the scales of theinvolucre are united so as to form a kind of bur; cocklebur; clotbur.
A twist or bend; a turn; a whimsey. [Colloq.] Hudibras.
A chief chancellor; -- an officer in the old German empire, whopresided over the secretaries of the court.
The place or the works where the fulling of cloth is carriedon.

A more or less solid article of confectionery made by boilingsugar or molasses to the desired consistency, and than crystallizing,molding, or working in the required shape. It is often flavored orcolored, and sometimes contains fruit, nuts, etc.
Relating to the Eastern Islands; East Indian. [R.] Ogilvie.
A thing of the same genus, species, or kind; a thing allied innature, character, or action.
A portion of the southern equatorial current flowing westwardfrom the Fiji Islands to New Guinea.
The quality or state of being spirituous; spirituousness. [R.]
Shining with a phosphoric light; luminous without sensibleheat.-- n.
A cart carrying water; esp., one carrying water for sale, orfor sprinkling streets, gardens, etc.
A rare mineral occurring in tetragonal crystals of a white,yellow, or grayish color and adamantine luster. It is achlorocarbonate of lead.
A great circle of the sphere passing through the poles of theheavens and the zenith of a given place. It is crossed by the sun atmidday.
The trade of mercers; the goods in which a mercer deals.
Growing above the axil; inserted above the axil, as a peduncle.See Suprafoliaceous.
A spherical magnet so placed that its poles, equator, etc.,correspond to those of the earth. [Obs.] Chambers.
One of several color-producing glycosides found in madder root.
Respect of persons; especially, a premature opinion orprejudice against a person, formed from his external appearance. [R.]Addison.
Anything peculiar to the Chinese; esp., a Chinese peculiarityin manners or customs.
A spectroscope fitted for measurements of the luminious spectraobserved with it.
Settlement of claims; an equitable arrangement of conflictingclaims, as in set-off, contribution, exoneration, subrogation, andmarshaling. Bispham.

A numerous group of fourteen -- footed Crustacea, inhabitingboth fresh and salt water. The body is usually compressed laterally,and the anterior pairs or legs are directed downward and forward, butthe posterior legs are usually turned upward and backward. The beachflea is an example. See Tetradecapoda and Arthrostraca.
A fish that makes a sound when caught; as:(a) The squeteague.(b) A California sculpin.
A skin disease, common in India, in which there is perpetualitching and eruption, esp. of the groin, breast, armpits, and face.
An alkaloid found in jaborandi leaves, from which it isextracted as a white amorphous substance. In its action it resemblesatropine.
Not very distinct; obscure; rudimental; imperfectly developed;abortive.
Furnished with panicles; arranged in, or like, panicles;paniculate.
A variety or macaroni made in tubes of small diameter.
A small red fish of the genus Cepola; the ribbon fish.
Intoxicated; inebriated; tipsy; drunk. [R.] Dryden.
A unit employed by oculists in numbering glasses according tothe metric system; a refractive power equal to that of a glass whoseprincipal focal distance is one meter.
A game played with nine pins, or pieces of wood, set on end, atwhich a wooden ball is bowled to knock them down; bowling.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Grind, Etym: contr. from grindeth.[Obs.] Chaucer.
An oxychloride of copper, usually in emerald-green prismaticcrystals.
An instrument for reckoning the distances or velocities ofclouds.
To deal in dissertation; to write dissertations; to discourse.[R.] J. Foster.
One of a pair of broad plates, developed from the outermaxillipeds of crabs, and forming a cover for the other mouth organs.
The writer or maker of a vocabulary; a lexicographer.
A group of beetles having short elytra, as the rove beetles.
An orange-yellow substance found in pigment spots of certaincrabs.
One of certain vagrant or heretical Oriental monks in the earlychurch.
Beneath the axis of the skeleton; subvertebral; hyposkeletal.
A port on the seashore, or one accessible for seagoing vessels.Also used adjectively; as, a seaport town.
A variety of pyroxene, from the valley of Fassa, in the Tyrol.
The composition of a cento; the act or practice of composing acento or centos.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a nitro derivative ofsalicylic acid, called also anilic acid.
The thickness of the layer or body of pigment applied by thepainter to his canvas with especial reference to the juxtaposition ofdifferent colors and tints in forming a harmonious whole. Fairholt.
To bend; to cause to become curved; to make crooked; todeflect. J. Philips.
Foreign; unnatural; unusual; -- said of forms of crystals notnatural to the substances in which they are found.
The process of repairing broken feathers or a deficient wing.
That part of a bit which is put in a horse's mouth.
The act or process of cutting out a portion of the iris inorder to form an artificial pupil.
The first game after the set is deuce. See Set, n., 9.
A name given to any one of several yellow or scarlet dyestuffsof artificial production and complex structure. In general they arediazo and sulphonic acid derivatives of benzene and naphthol.
A coarse kind of thick woolen cloth, worn by the poor in theMiddle Ages; also, a woolen cap or hood worn over the shoulders orover the head.
A zooid of the third generation in asexual reproduction.
A chanting; recitation or reading with musical modulations.
A thin, serous fluid commonly discharged from ulcers or foulwounds.
To go beyond in reigning; to reign through the whole of, orlonger than. [R.] Spenser.
