A girl; esp., a great, awkward girl; a wench. [Prov. Eng.]
To operate on as, or by means of, a cathartic medicine, or in asimilar manner.

A repetition of the last word or any prominent word in asentence or clause, at the beginning of the next, with an adjunctidea; as, "He retained his virtues amidst all his misfortunes --misfortunes which no prudence could foresee or prevent."
The act of boiling up or effervescing. [R.] Sir H. Wotton.
A headdress of false hair, usually covering the whole head, andrepresenting the natural hair; a wig. Shak.
The small aperture or foremen in the outer coat of the ovule ofa plant.
The inner layer of the wall of the uterus, which envelops theembryo, forms a part of the placenta, and is discharged with it.
As seen or estimated from the center of the moon; with the mooncentral.
The act of exploring; exploration. [R.] Sir T. Browne.

An electro-negative element or radical, which, by combinationwith a metal, forms a haloid salt; especially, chlorine, bromine, andiodine; sometimes, also, fluorine and cyanogen. See Chlorine family,under Chlorine.
The act of pulling to pieces, or of separating the parts. Bp.Hall.

A clause sometimes inserted in contracts or specifications,requiring that a material of construction, as cement, must be of abrand that has stood the test of a specified number of years' use inan important public work. [Cant, U. S.]
A wandering; vagrancy. [Obs.]A thousand vagancies of glory and desight. Milton.
An exclamation denoting surprise, or contempt, doubt, etc.

One who lives either north or south of the tropics, ascontrasted with one who lives on the other side of them; -- so calledbecause at noon the shadows always fall in opposite directions (theone northward, the other southward).
A piece of pork cut lower down than the sparerib, and destituteof fat. [Eng.] Southey.
To study, as another actor's part, in order to be hissubstitute in an emergency; to study another actor's part.
To cause to be no longer a vessel; to empty. [Obs.] Ford.
Subjected to equal pressure from every side; being inhydrostatic equilibrium, as a body submerged in a liquid at rest;pertaining to, or characterized by, isostasy.
After the manner of the Levites; in accordance with thelevitical law.
A bully; a hector; a swaggerer; an empty boaster. [R.] Dryden.
Having deep and sharp notches, as a leaf or a petal.

One of the lessons from the Nebiim (or Prophets) read in theJewish synagogue on Sabbaths, feast days, fasts, and the ninth of Ab,at the end of the service, after the parashoth, or lessons from theLaw. Such a practice is evidenced in Luke iv.17 and Acts xiii.15.
The state of being debauched; intemperance. Bp. Hall.
The astringent fruit of a species of wild cherry (PrunusVirginiana); also, the bush or tree which bears such fruit.
Fitted or designed to dehort or dissuade. Bp. Hall.
Something, as a symptom, indicating that the usual mode oftreatment is not to be followed. Burke.
A irrevocable Turkish decree countersigned by the sultan.
A boy who carries pots of ale, beer, etc.; a menial in a publichouse.
The mensuration of plane surfaces; -- distinguished fromstereometry, or the mensuration of volumes.
One who disobeys the law; a criminal.-- Law"break`ing, n. & a.
Of or pertaining to the Rasores, or gallinaceous birds, as thepeacock, domestic fowl, patridge, and the like.
Bestowing praise; eulogistic; laudatory. [Obs.] E. Phillips.
Having a leaflike membrane on the nose; -- said of certainbats, esp. of the genera Phyllostoma and Rhinonycteris. See Vampire.
Not sexual; not proper or peculiar to one of the sexes. DeQuincey.
Paper chewed, and rolled into a ball, to be thrown as amissile.

Such a mental condition, as, either from the existence ofdelusions, or from incapacity to distinguish between right and wrong,with regard to any matter under action, does away with individualresponsibility.

An instrument, consisting essentially of a magic lantern inwhich photographic pictures are used, by which the image of alandscape, or any object, may be thrown upon a screen in such amanner as to seem to stand out in relief, so as to form a strikingand accurate representation of the object itself; also, a pair ofmagic lanterns for producing the effect of dissolving views.
To ascertain by diagnosis; to diagnosticate. See Diagnosticate.
To throw out, as smoke, dust, etc., in puffs. [Scot.]
A vegetable alkaloid found with conine in the poison hemlock(Conium maculatum). It is a white crystalline substance, C8H17NO,easily convertible into conine.
A large leather flap which covers the saddletree. [WesternU.S.]
Cyanite or kyanite; -- so called in allusion to its unequalhardness in two different directions. See Cyanite.
A glucoside extracted from bitter almonds as a white,crystalline substance.
A large and powerful serpent of tropical America, sometimestwenty or thirty feet long. See Illustration in Appendix.
An Athenian military officer commanding a certain division ofan army. Milford.
The small cranberry (Vaccinium oxycoccus), which grows in boggyplaces.
A species of grebe (Podiceps crisratus); the crested grebe.
Having sword-shaped leaves, or appendages; ensiform.
The part of a sugarhouse where the molasses is drained off fromthe sugar.
To cause to become or appear vulgar. [Obs.] Daniel.
Placed irregularly and distantly; scattered; -- applied tobranches, leaves, peduncles, and the like.
An English gold coin, of the value of twenty-five shillingssterling, struck in the reign of James I.
The order of Annulata which includes the leeches. SeeHirudinea.
Twice crenated, as in the case of leaves whose crenatures arethemselves crenate.
A glucoside extracted from the root of a South African plant ofthe genus Vernonia, as a deliquescent powder, and used as a mildheart tonic.
The central chapel of the three forming the sanctuary of aCoptic church. It contains the high altar, and is usually closed byan embroidered curtain.
Toward the dorsum or back; on the dorsal side; dorsally.
A poisonous bulbous plant (Buphane toxicaria) of the Cape ofGood Hope.
One guilty of champerty; one who purchases a suit, or the rightof suing, and carries it on at his own expense, in order to obtain ashare of the gain.
The male of any pheasant of the genus Pavo, of which at leasttwo species are known, native of Southern Asia and the East Indies.
A dark blue scombroid food fish (Acanthocibium solandri orpetus) of Florida and the West Indies.
A building; a structure; an architectural fabric; -- chieflyapplied to elegant houses, and other large buildings; as, a palace, achurch, a statehouse.
A stricture or narrowing, as of a canal, cavity, or orifice.
A gelatinous nitrogenous material extracted from crude silk andother similar fiber by boiling water; -- called also silk gelatin.
To make a lady of; to make ladylike. [Obs.] Massinger.
A formal question or inquiry; esp. (Law), a question asked inwriting. Macaulay.
One who assembles a number of individuals; also, one of anumber assembled.
A person who is not of noble birth; specif., a freeman whoduring the prevalence of feudalism held allodial land.
A division of arachnids having large, powerful fangs and asegmented abdomen; -- called also Solpugidea, and Solpugides.
A small oval porcelain or glass cup, having a rim curved to fitthe orbit of the eye. it is used in the application of liquidremedies to eyes; -- called also eyeglass.
A dark brown substance of vegetable origin, allied to curare,and used by the natives of New Granada as an arrow poison.

Coal brought by sea; -- a name by which mineral coal wasformerly designated in the south of England, in distinction fromcharcoal, which was brought by land. Sea-coal facing (Founding),facing consisting of pulverized bituminous coal.
a. & n. from Wean, v.The weaning of the whelp is the great test of the skill of the kennelman. J. H. Walsh.Weaning brash. (Med.) See under Brash.
Pertaining to administration, or to the executive part ofgovernment.
That which (as a drug, or some kinds of food) excites tovenery.
One who attempts to unite principles or parties which areirreconcilably at variance; specifically (Eccl. Hist.),
To endow with the qualities of a woman. [R.] Daniel.
The marking out of the boundaries, or identifying the place orsite of, a piece of land, according to the description given in anentry, plan, map, etc. Burrill. Bouvier.
A compound of arsenic with a metal, or positive element orradical; -- formerly called arseniuret.
Any one of several species of bryozoans of the genus Retepora.They form delicate calcareous corals, usually composed of thinfenestrated fronds.
A court held in Derbyshire, in England, for decidingcontroversies between miners. Blount.
The squamous part of the temporal bone, or a bonecorrespondending to it, under Temporal.
A great Brazilian palm (Maximiliana regia), having immensespathes which are used for baskets and tubs.
An underchanter; a precentor's deputy in a cathedral; asuccentor.
A person required to make answer in an action or suit; --opposed to plaintiff. Abbott.
The foot of an insect or a crustacean. It usually consists ofform two to five joints.
One who debauches or corrupts others; especially, a seducer tolewdness.
A disease due to inhaling the poisonous fumes present in themanufacture of aniline.

An extensive division of birds which includes the woodpeckers,toucans, trogons, hornbills, kingfishers, motmots, rollers, andgoatsuckers. By some writers it is made to include also the cuckoos,swifts, and humming birds.
To throw up a bank so as to confine or to defend; to protect bya bank of earth or stone.

A diseased condition, produced by the absorption of lead,common among workers in this metal or in its compounds, as amongpainters, typesetters, etc. It is characterized by various symptoms,as lead colic, lead line, and wrist drop. See under Colic, Lead, andWrist.
The people or the people's party, in ancient Rome, as opposedto the optimates.
An obsolete phrase of disputed meaning, -- perhaps, smooth orpolished bone.His saddle was of rewel boon. Chaucer.
Illuminating power, as of a lamp, or gas flame, reckoned interms of the light of a standard candle.

Backward development; a passing from a higher to a lower stateof organization or structure, as when an animal, approachingmaturity, becomes less highly organized than would be expected fromits earlier stages or known relationship. Called also retrogradedevelopment, and regressive metamorphism.
A representation of the outlines of an object filled in with ablack color; a profile portrait in black, such as a shadow appears tobe.
One of the half-breed descendants of whites and Indians; amestizo; -- so called throughout Central America. They are usually ofa yellowish orange tinge. Am. Cyc.
A friend; -- a Spanish term applied in the Philippine Islandsto friendly natives.
Having a broad hem separated from the body of the article by aline of open work; as, a hemistitched handkerchief.
A contrivance for producing manifold copies of a writing ordrawing.
One of the first pair of lateral plates in the plastron ofturtles.
A stone, or cast-iron plate, or former, on which hot glass isrolled to give it shape.
The serum of blood rendered antitoxic to a venom by repeatedinjections of small doses of the venom.
An instrument for regulating the electro-motive force in analternating-current circuit; -- so called because used to "boost", orraise, the pressure in the circuit.
Restitution for cattle; a penalty for taking away cattle.Cowell.
The artifices, intrigues, and plottings, at courts.
A metallic mineral having a grayish tin-white color, andcontaining cobalt and iron, with sulphur and arsenic.
Gratuitous discharge; a release from debt or obligation withoutpayment; free remission.
A horizontal row of corbels, with the panels or filling betweenthem; also, less properly used to include the stringcourse on them.
One who practices sleight of hand; a prestidigitator.

Any worm of the genus Lumbricus and allied genera, found indamp soil. One of the largest and most abundant species in Europe andAmerica is L. terrestris; many others are known; -- called alsoangleworm and dewworm.
To walk or run about in a slatternly, careless, or thoughtlessmanner. [Colloq.] Pope.
A long, light, open vehicle, with benches or seats runninglengthwise.
My lady; -- a French title formerly given to ladies of quality;now, in France, given to all married women. Chaucer.
A kind of cast steel containing nickel, which greatly increasesits strength. It is used for armor plate, bicycle tubing, propellershafts, etc.
To follow with violence and trampling. [R.] The Puritan (1607).
The act of filling up, or the state of being filled up;fullness. [Obs.]
The English name for a catboat; -- so called because Una wasthe name of the first boat of this kind taken to England. D. Kemp.

The complex mixture of volatile, liquid, inflammablehydrocarbons, occurring naturally, and usually called crudepetroleum, mineral oil, or rock oil. Specifically: That portion ofthe distillate obtained in the refinement of petroleum which isintermediate between the lighter gasoline and the heavier benzine,and has a specific gravity of about 0.7, -- used as a solvent forvarnishes, as a carburetant, illuminant, etc.
An amorphous antimonate of lead, produced from the alterationof other ores, as from jamesonite.
One who engages in a conspiracy; a plotter. 2 Sam. xv. 31.
Related to, derived from, or containing, undecyl; specifically,designating that member of the fatty acids which corresponds toundecane, and is obtained as a white crystalline substance, C11H22O2.
A set of fire irons, including, commonly, tongs, shovel, andpoker.
To combine wtih carbon or a carbon compound; -- said esp. of aprocess for conferring a higher degree of illuminating power oncombustible gases by mingling them with a vapor of valatilehydrocarbons.
In England, an ecclesiastical dignitary, next in rank below abishop, whom he assists, and by whom he is appointed, though withindependent authority. Blackstone.
A cavity in a rock, having its interior surface studded withcrystals and sometimes filled with water; a geode.
A condition of overgrowth or excessive development of an organor part; -- the opposite of atrophy.

In internal-combustion engines with electric ignition, a plug,screwed into the cylinder head, having through it an insulated wirewhich is connected with the induction coil or magneto circuit on theoutside, and forms, with another terminal on the base of the plug, aspark gap inside the cylinder.
An equal sounding; the consonance of the unison and itsoctaves.
Infected with the itch, or with an itching sensation. Cowper.
The order or mode of development of an organ or part.
An oceanic fish of large size (Elacate canada); the crabeater;-- called also bonito, cubbyyew, coalfish, and sergeant fish.
To soak water; to fill the interstices of with water.
A form of union or immovable articulation where a hard part isreceived into the cavity of a bone, as the teeth into the jaws.
The closing of a factory or workshop by an employer, usually inorder to bring the workmen to satisfactory terms by a suspension ofwages.
Sameness of signification of two or more propositions whichdiffer in language.
The act of signaling, or of signalizing; hence, description bypeculiar, appropriate, or characteristic marks. Mrs. Browning.
A small square shield, formerly worn on the shoulders ofknights, -- being the prototype of the modern epaulet. Fairholt.
A steep descent or declivity; steep face or edge of a ridge;ground about a fortified place, cut away nearly vertically to preventhostile approach. See Scarp.
A native attorney or agent; also, an ambassador. [India]
To shake over or away; to drive away; to disperse. [Obs.]Chaucer.
Having the property of preventing any other substance fromoccupying the same space at the same time.
The state of being constrained, bound, or obliged; that whichconstrains or obliges; obligation; bond. [R.] Milton.
A kind of tree (Osmanthus Americanus), allied to the Europeanolive.
A kind of highly sized rag paper or board, sometimes containinga small admixture of wood pulp; -- so called because used originally,as now, in presses for pressing and finishing knit underwear.
Full of grains; abounding with granular substances; granular.
A complex nitrogenous compound obtained by heating togetherpyruvic acid and urea.
Having the quill feathers of the tail somewhat rigid.
A figure by which a word is repeated with vehemence oremphasis, as in the following lines: -Alone, alone, all all alone, Alone on a wide wide sea. Coleridge.
A species of Turnix (Turnix sylvatica) native of Spain andNorthen Africa.
The scientific study or knowledge of spiritual beings and theirrelations to God, angels, and men.

To take (one or more) from the next higher denomination inorder to add it to the next lower; -- a term of subtraction when thefigure of the subtrahend is larger than the corresponding one of theminuend.
One of the chief military officers of a government or country;the commander of an army, of a body of men not less than a brigade.In European armies, the highest military rank next below fieldmarshal.
Having feet or legs that are used as oars; -- said of certaincrustaceans and insects.
A crystalline mineral found in guano. It is a hydrous phosphateof magnesia and ammonia.
A poem written in tercets with but two rhymes, the first andthird verse of the first stanza alternating as the third verse ineach successive stanza and forming a couplet at the close. E. W.Gosse.
A firing in the direction of the length of a trench, or a lineof parapet or troops, etc.; a raking fire.
An artist who, by mechanical means, multiplies copies of worksof art.
The skill of a good seaman; the art, or skill in the art, ofworking a ship.
The holding by the fourth hand of the best and third best cardsof a suit led; also, sometimes, the combination of best with thirdbest card of a suit in any hand.

A large South American snake of the Boa family (Eunectesmurinus), which lives near rivers, and preys on birds and smallmammals. The name is also applied to a similar large serpent (Pythontigris) of Ceylon.
Made up like a dandy; having the dress or manners of a dandy;buckish.

A suborder of serpents including those that have permanentlyerect grooved poison fangs, with ordinary teeth behind them in thejaws. It includes the cobras, the asps, and the sea snakes. Calledalso Proteroglyphia.
The third month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year; -- supposedto correspond nearly with our month of June.
The right which the owner of a mill possesses, by contract orlaw, to compel the tenants of a certain district, or of his sucken,to bring all their grain to his mill for grinding. Erskine.
The act of imbruting, or the state of being imbruted. [R.]Brydges.
The European woodpecker, or yaffle; -- called also nickerpecker.
Inability to perceive or distinguish certain colors, esp. red;color blindness. It has various forms and degrees. So called from thechemist Dalton, who had this infirmity. Nichol.
Homesickness; esp., a severe and sometimes fatal form ofmelancholia, due to homesickness.
One who ackowledged the right of the plaintiff or cognizee in afine; the defendant. Blackstone.
The science which treats of the skin, its structure, functions,and diseases.
Sacrifices offered to the souls of deceased heroes or friends.
An obligation to perform certain services, as the repair ofroads, for the lord or sovereign.
A substance, analogous to benzil, obtained from oil of caraway.
Having the gout in the hand, or subject to that disease. Sir.T. Browne.

A wire basket on the end of a rod to carry glass bottles, etc.,to the annealing furnace; also, an iron rod to be thrust into themouths of bottles, and used for the same purpose; -- calles alsopontee and punty.
The act of flattering to gain favor; servile approbation.[Obs.] Bp. Hall.
An assembly of the clergy, by their representatives, to consulton ecclesiastical affairs.
A species of tenure in fee simple, being the opposite ofancient demesne, or copyhold. Burrill.
Having but one optic axis, or line of no double refraction.
A young man living as an apprentice on a sheep station, orotherwise engaged in acquainting himself with colonial life.[Colloq., Australia]

A tumor of fleshy consistence; -- formerly applied to manyvarieties of tumor, now restricted to a variety of malignant growthmade up of cells resembling those of fetal development without anyproper intercellular substance.
To convert into gelatin, or into a substance resembling jelly.
Disposed to fly away; flighty; unrestrained; light and free; --used of both persons and things. -- n.
A kind of demigod attendant on Kuvera, the god of wealth.
The act of interceding; intercession; intervention. [R.] Bp.Reynolds.
Relating to, or connected with, the hypoblast; as, the hypoicsac.
An emulsion of glycerin and the yolk of eggs, used as anointment, as a vehicle for medicines, etc.
A combination of alloxanic acid and a base or base or positiveradical.
One who has an irrepressible desire for alcoholic drinks.
The quality or state of being temperate; moderateness;temperance.
That branch of physical science which treats of the phenomenaof electricity and its properties.
Having, or abounding in, fins, as fishes; pertaining to fishes.
The tenant of a tenant; one who holds lands or tenements of atenant or lessee.
The act or process of reducing, by depression of temperature orincrease of pressure, etc., to another and denser form, as gas to thecondition of a liquid or steam to water.
Any one of a series of artificial blue dyes, in appearanceresembling indigo, for which they are often used as substitutes.
Hot-short; brittle when red-hot; -- said of certain kinds ofiron.-- Red"-short`ness, n.
One who, or that which, desolates or lays waste. Mede.
Pertaining to, or resembling, gauze; thin and slight as gauze.
Loss by use, decay, evaporation, leakage, or the like; waste.
Recovery, as of anything lost, especially of the health orstrength.

A nickname for a native of citizen of New England, especiallyone descended from old New England stock; by extension, an inhabitantof the Northern States as distinguished from a Southerner; also,applied sometimes by foreigners to any inhabitant of the UnitedStates.From meanness first this Portsmouth Yankey rose, And still tomeanness all his conduct flows. Oppression, A poem by an American(Boston, 1765).
One skilled in magic; one who practices the black art; anenchanter; a necromancer; a sorcerer or sorceress; a conjurer.
The act of rendering modern in style; the act or process ofcausing to conform to modern of thinking or acting.
Imperfectly baked; hence, not brought to perfection;unfinished; also, of weak or dull understanding. [Colloq.] Halliwell.
A calculous concretion, especially one in the kidneys orbladder; the disease arising from a calculus.
Half a tone; -- the name commonly applied to the smallerintervals of the diatonic scale.

A thorny tree or shrub of the genus Lawsonia (L. alba). Thefragrant white blossoms are used by the Buddhists in religiousceremonies. The powdered leaves furnish a red coloring matter used inthe East to stain the hails and fingers, the manes of horses, etc.
The state or quality of being crustaceous or having a crustlikeshell.
One of the lateral lobes of the foot in certain gastropods.
A student who is advanced beyond the first year of hisresidence.
Having little or no knowledge; ignorant; stupid; silly. [R.] N.Bacon.
To report erroneously; to give an incorrect account of. Locke.

A peculiar East Indian mammal (Galleopithecus volans), havingalong the sides, connecting the fore and hind limbs, a parachutelikemembrane, by means of which it is able to make long leaps, like theflying squirrel; -- called also flying lemur.
A medicine having, or supposed to have, the power of expellingcalculous matter with the urine. Hooper.
A hold in which an arm of one contestant is held twisted andbent behind his back by his opponent.
Struck with horror; horrified.Blank and horror-stricken faces. C. Kingsley.
The notch, fork, or other device on the gunwale of a boat, inwhich the oar rests in rowing.  See Rowlock.
One of a tribe of tortoises, including the terrapins, etc., inwhich the head and neck can be withdrawn.
A suit of light armor covering less than the whole body, ashaving no protection for the legs below the things, no vizor to thehelmet, and the like.
An apparatus for examining the interior of the mouth.
Warfare; war; hence, contention; opposition. [Obs.]
One of the chief administrative divisions or provinces of theOttoman Empire; -- formerly called eyalet.
An involuntary and unnatural contraction of one or more musclesor muscular fibers.
A kind of candy, mainly composed of sugar and butter. [Colloq.]Dickens.
An order of Entomastraca, including many minute Crustacea, bothfreshwater and marine.
The act of suffixing, or the state of being suffixed.
One who guesses; one who forms or gives an opinion withoutmeans of knowing.
One of the stems or shoots of sugar cane of the second year'sgrowth from the root, or later. See Plant-cane.
Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid calledpyrogallol. See Pyrogallol.
Serving or intended to explore; searching; examining;explorative. Sir H. Wotton.
One who entreats; one who asks earnestly; a beseecher.
A slender, lofty tower attached to a mosque and surrounded byone or more projecting balconies, from which the summon to prayer iscried by the muezzin.
Not deeper than the skin; hence, superficial. Lowell.
A work of twelve volumes, each containing the offices in theGreek Church for a month; also, each volume of the same. Shipley.
Tincture of opium, used for various medical purposes.
In a rough manner; unevenly; harshly; rudely; severely;austerely.
To cause to linger; to detain too long. [Obs.] Fuller.
A sort of ancient trimming of tinsel and thread for women'sgowns; -- called also bobbinwork. [Obs.] Piers Plowman.
Restored to wholeness or a perfect state; renewed. Bacon.
Anything made of iron; -- a general name of such parts orpieces of a building, vessel, carriage, etc., as consist of iron.
To insert in a category or list; to class; to catalogue.
The muscular system of an animal, or of any of its parts.
A collection of specimens of plants, dried and preserved, andarranged systematically; an herbarium.
A Japanese covered litter, carried by men. B. Taylor.
The science of light; -- a general term sometimes employed whenoptics is restricted to light as a producing vision. Knight.
A canine tooth of the upper jaw. See Teeth. To cut one'seyeteeth, to become acute or knowing. [Colloq.]
The act of disjoining, or state of being disjoined; separation.Fuller.
To have corrosive action; to be subject to corrosion. Corrodinglead, lead sufficiently pure to be used in making white lead by aprocess of corroding.
To set in order; to array; to attire; to deck, to dress. [Obs.]
Inflammation of the brain, or of the meninges of the brain,attended with acute fever and delirium; -- called also cephalitis.
The interbrain or thalamencephalon; -- sometimes abbreviated todien. See Thalamencephalon.
One who seeks only his own interest, advantage, or pleasure.
A genus of Australian birds which includes the brush turkey.See Brush turkey.
A mineral consisting of the hydrous sulphate of lime (calcium).When calcined, it forms plaster of Paris. Selenite is a transparent,crystalline variety; alabaster, a fine, white, massive variety.
The act or process of measuring the chest capacity by means ofa spirometer.
Of or pertaining to thirty years; consisting of thirty years;occurring once in every thirty years.
A tribute which tenants paid to their lord, in lieu of bran,which they were obliged to furnish for his hounds.
A work having two parapets whose faces unite so as to form asalient angle toward the enemy.
A small marline spike having generally a wooden handle, -- usedin sailmaking. R. H. Dana, Ir.
A figure of speech in which the speaker breaks off suddenly, asif unwilling or unable to state what was in his mind; as, "I declareto you that his conduct -- but I can not speak of that, here."
Crowned; having the head encircled as with a diadem. Shak.
The common name of the kerria Japonica or Japan globeflower, ayellow-flowered, perennial, rosaceous plant, seen in old-fashionedgardens.

Highly carbonized iron, the direct product of the blastfurnace; -- used for making castings, and for conversion into wroughtiron and steel. It can not be welded or forged, is brittle, andsometimes very hard. Besides carbon, it contains sulphur, phosphorus,silica, etc.
The quality of being divine; superhuman or supreme excellence.Shak.
A cartilaginous lidlike appendage which closes the glottiswhile food or drink is passing while food or drink is passing throughthe pharynx.

The act or art of punctuating or pointing a writing ordiscourse; the art or mode of dividing literary composition intosentences, and members of a sentence, by means of points, so as toelucidate the author's meaning.
A rapid inspiratory act, in which the mouth is kept shut andthe air drawn in through the nose.
Not fully compressed; partially or somewhat compressed.
An order of fishes remarkable for their long and compressedform. The ribbon fishes are examples. See Ribbon fish, under Ribbon.
Freedom from doubt; assurance; certainty. J. H. Newman.
A white crystalline substance, C6H4(OH)2, of the phenol series,found in various plants; -- so called because first obtained bydistillation of gum catechu. Called also catechol, oxyphenol. etc.
A stick or club employed in the game of ball called cat ortipcat. Massinger.
A mill operated by the power of the wind, usually by the actionof the wind upon oblique vanes or sails which radiate from ahorizontal shaft. Chaucer.
Supposition; hypothesis; conjecture. [Obs.] Hudibras.
The entrance of the moon into the shadow of the earth ineclipses, the sun's entrance into a sign, etc.
The quality or state of being inscrutable; inscrutableness.
A game in which nine holes are made in the ground, into which aball is bowled.
A subsoil made up of small stones or finely-broken rock; brash.
Capable of being attached; esp., liable to be taken by writ orprecept.
A state of being bent or curved; incurvation; a bendinginwards. Sir T. Browne.
Resembling a slattern; sluttish; negligent; dirty.-- adv.
Any unicellular plant, or plant forming only a plasmodium,having reproduction only by fission, gemmation, or cell division.
To breathe hard, and with an audible piping or whistling sound,as persons affected with asthma. "Wheezing lungs." Shak.
A French gold coin of twenty francs, or about $3.86.
Of or pertaining to a portion of the horn of the hyoid bone.
The dominion, condition, or character of a queen. Mrs.Browning.
That branch of moral philosophy which treats of the relation ofduty to pleasure; the science of practical, positive enjoyment orpleasure. J. Grote.
Finely granulated; -- said of quicksilver which has beengranulated by agitation during the amalgamation process. Raymond.
An instrument for measuring the direction, duration, and forceof earthquakes and like concussions.
The leaves of an orchid (Angraecum fragrans), of the islands ofBourbon and Mauritius, used (in France) as a substitute for Chinesetea.
To conform to the Greek custom, especially in speech.
A yellowish crystalline substance, C6H5.CO.CO.C6H5, formed frombenzoin by the action of oxidizing agents, and consisting of adoubled benzoyl radical.
One of the great tendons situated in each side of the ham, orspace back of the knee, and connected with the muscles of the back ofthe thigh.
A telescope adapted for taking photographs of the heavenlybodies.

Of or pertaining to Thebes in Egypt; specifically, designatinga version of the Bible preserved by the Copts, and esteemed of greatvalue by biblical scholars. This version is also called the Sahidicversion.
An order of birds, including only the penguins, in which thewings are without quills, and not suited for flight.
A compound of tellurium with a more positive element orradical; -- formerly called telluret.
The 95th Psalm, which is said or sung regularly in the publicworship of many churches. Also, a musical composition adapted to thisPsalm.
Having the gills around the margin of the body, as certainlimpets.
An apparatus by which a number of copies of written matter,maps, plans, etc., can be made; -- called also hectograph.
A body of legions; legions, collectively. [R.] Pollok.
A large pear, shaped like a flattened top, used chiefly forcooking. Johnson.
A nucleated cell having an envelope or cell wall, as a redblood corpuscle or an epithelial cell; a cell concerned in growth.
Of or pertaining to an order of plants, of which the genus Arumis the type.
The head; also, a knoblike protuberance or capitulum.
The act or process of making mathematical computations or ofestimating results.
The quality or state of being styptic; astringency.
To utter foolishly or excessively; to surpass in babbling. [R.]Milton.
One who transacts, performs, or conducts any business. Derham.
The act of making sublime, or state of being made sublime.

A widow endowed, or having a jointure; a widow who eitherenjoys a dower from her deceased husband, or has property of her ownbrought by her to her husband on marriage, and settled on her afterhis decease. Blount. Burrill.
One who, or that which resuscitates. Also used adjectively.
An effusion of watery liquid into the cavity of a joint.
Of or pertaining to trial by ordeal. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.

A genus of spinose, plectognath fishes, having the teeth ofeach jaw united into a single beaklike plate. They are able toinflate the body by taking in air or water, and, hence, are calledglobefishes, swellfishes, etc. fishes, and sea hedgehogs.
A white crystalline substance regarded as a hydrate of oil ofturpentine.
One of several pieces fayed across the apron and lapped in theknightheads, or inside planking above the upper deck. Ham. Nav.Encyc.

A religious dance of the North American Indians, participatedin by both sexes, and looked upon as a rite of invocation the purposeof which is, through trance and vision, to bring the dancer intocommunion with the unseen world and the spirits of departed friends.The dance is the chief rite of the Ghost-dance, or Messiah, religion,which originated about 1890 in the doctrines of the Piute Wovoka, theIndian Messiah, who taught that the time was drawing near when thewhole Indian race, the dead with the living, should be reunited tolive a life of millennial happiness upon a regenerated earth. Thereligion inculcates peace, righteousness, and work, and holds that ingood time, without warlike intervention, the oppressive white rulewill be removed by the higher powers. The religion spread through amajority of the western tribes of the United States, only in the caseof the Sioux, owing to local causes, leading to an outbreak.
An obligation to have the grain growing on certain lands groundat a certain mill, the owner paying a toll. Bell.
An aversion to the company of men; a love of solitude.
A European species of wormwood (Artemisia maritima) growing bythe sea.

A malicious publication expressed either in print or inwriting, or by pictures, effigies, or other signs, tending to exposeanother to public hatred, contempt, or ridicule. Such publication isindictable at common law.
Apperaing in distinct crystals; -- said of the mineralconstituents of a rock.
A depression in the sphenoid bone; the pituitary fossa.
The cougar. Applied also, in some parts of the United States,to the lynx.

Designating, or pert. to, a mixed racial type including theAfghans, and characterized chiefly by stature above mean, faircomplexion, dark, or sometimes gray, eyes, brachycephaly, and verylong, prominent, and moderately narrow nose.
The possession by a woman of only one husband at the same time;-- contrasted with polyandry.
A bishop, who, during a vacancy of the see, administers thebishopric till a successor is installed.
The uppermost zone of the sea, which receives the most light.
The fruit of the Japanese medlar (Photinia Japonica). It is aslarge as a small plum, but grows in clusters, and contains four orfive large seeds. Also, the tree itself.
A view of many objects; also, a sort of panorama withdissolving views.
A solid, all plane sections of which are ellipses or circles.See Conoid, n., 2 (a).
Noting a flight of stairs, consisting of two or more straightportions connected by a platform (landing) or platforms, and runningin opposite directions without an intervening wellhole.
The pedicel on which the ovary of certain flowers, as thepassion flower, is seated; a carpophore or thecaphore.
A white man; -- a term used by negroes of the African coast,West Indies, etc.
One who encounters; an opponent; an antagonist. Atterbury.
The backing or steaming of clams on heated stones, betweenlayers of seaweed; hence, a picnic party, gathered on such anoccasion.
Of or pertaining to Hanover or its people, or to the House ofHanover in England.
The land bordering on, or adjacent to, the sea; the seashore.Also used adjectively.
Situated between hills; -- applied especially to valleys lyingbetween volcanic cones.
A tasteless and odorless crystalline substance, extracted fromcloves, polymeric with common camphor.

A personal action which lies to recover possession of goods andchattle wrongfully taken or detained. Originally, it was a remedypeculiar to cases for wrongful distress, but it may generally now bebrought in all cases of wrongful taking or detention. Bouvier.
Act of involving, or state of being involved; involution.

A carnivore (Viverricula Mallaccensis) allied to the civet butsmaller, native of China and the East Indies. It furnishes a perfumeresembling that of the civet, which is highly prized by the Javanese.Called also Malacca weasel, and lesser civet.
One who emigrates, or quits one country or region to settle inanother.
A hood-shaped bandage for the head, the shoulder, or the stumpof an amputated limb.
The demand, by the consuls or tribunes, of a law to be passedby the people; a proposed law or decree.
The quality or state of being porous; -- opposed to density.
Acting or moving automatically by means of compressed air.
The peculiar free swimming larva of Balanoglossus. See Illust.in Append.
Of or pertaining to Servia, a kingdom of Southern Europe.-- n.
Not susceptible of corruption or decay; incorruptible. Dryden.
The act of speechifying. [Used humorously or in contempt.]
The nickname of a crackbrained Italian who fancied himself anemperor. [Obs.] Shak.
Implying an admission; tending to admit. [R.] Lamb.
The quality of being corruptible; the possibility or liabilityof being corrupted; corruptibleness. Burke.
Broadway, in New York City, in the neighborhood chieflyoccupied by theaters, as from about 30th Street about 50th Street; --so called from its brilliant illumination at night.
Expensiveness; costliness; sumptuousness. [R.] Sir W. Raleigh.
One of the higher hydrocarbons, C10H20, of the ethylene series.
A binary compound of carbon with some other element or radical,in which the carbon plays the part of a negative; -- formerly termedcarburet.
Overstocked, or overgrown, or covered, with grass. [Obs.]Spenser.
To exceed in measure or extent; to measure more than. Sir T.Browne.

An order of Mammallia including the lion, tiger, wolf bear,seal, etc. They are adapted by their structure to feed upon flesh,though some of them, as the bears, also eat vegetable food. The teethare large and sharp, suitable for cutting flesh, and the jawspowerful.
To make or place an arch over; to hang over like an arch."Brown with o'erarching shades." Pope.
The act or process of foreclosing; a proceeding which bars orextinguishes a mortgager's right of redeeming a mortgaged estate.
A rubber of hard wood used in smoothing marble to be polished.Knight.
Equality; -- sometimes written ovelty and ovealty. Burrill.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by theoxidation of convolvulin (obtained from jalap, the tubers of Ipomoeapurga), and identical in most of its properties with sebacic acid.
Of the delicate purplish pink color likened to that of peachblooms; -- applied esp. to a Chinese porcelain, small specimens ofwhich bring great prices in the Western countries.
A cutaneous disease occurring under two distinct forms.
A Mexican prickly poppy (Argemone platyceras), which hasmigrated into California.
A purchaser who buys from a purchaser; one who buys at secondhand.
The state of being a pauper; the state of indigent personsrequiring support from the community. Whatly.
A term of reproach, implying that one is fit to be hanged.[Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
Possession of lands or tenements in, or conveyance to, deadhands, or hands that cannot alienate.
A piece of wood or sheet metal fitted into a ditch to dam upthe water so as to overflow a field. [U. S.]
A mouse (Arvicala agrestis), called also meadow mouse, whichoften does great damage in fields and gardens, by feeding on rootsand seeds.

A figure or trope by which a part of a thing is put for thewhole (as, fifty sail for fifty ships), or the whole for a part (as,the smiling year for spring), the species for the genus (as,cutthroat for assassin), the genus for the species (as, a creaturefor a man), the name of the material for the thing made, etc. Bain.

A division of annelids including those which construct, andhabitually live in, tubes. The head or anterior segments usually beargills and cirri. Called also Sedentaria, and Capitibranchiata. SeeSerpula, and Sabella.
Of or pertaining to the kitchen, or the servants' quarters;hence, subordinate; menial. [Obs.]
One of the small bones in the tympanum of the ear; the anvilbone. See Ear.
A daughter of Cadmus, and by Zeus mother of Bacchus.
An African genus of ganoid fishes including the bichir.
A genus of corals with meandering grooves and ridges, includingthe brain corals.
Being the last one of a million of units or objects counted inregular order from the first of a series or succession; being one ofa million.
A stretching and stiffening of the trunk and extremities, aswhen fatigued and drowsy.
The natural abode, locality or region of an animal or plant.
To make an ambitious display of; to show or exhibit boastingly.[R.] Jer. Taylor.

The only existing genus of tetrabranchiate cephalopods. Aboutfour species are found living in the tropical Pacific, but many otherspecies are found fossil. The shell is spiral, symmetrical, andchambered, or divided into several cavities by simple curvedpartitions, which are traversed and connected together by acontinuous and nearly central tube or siphuncle. See Tetrabranchiata.

An ornamental tree of the genus Maclura (M. aurantiaca),closely allied to the mulberry (Morus); also, its fruit. The tree wasfirst found in the country of the Osage Indians, and bears a hard andinedible fruit of an orangelike appearance. See Bois d'arc.
Confusing; having a tendency to confusion.  Bp. Hall.
That which saponifies; any reagent used to causesaponification.
The doctrine of mutual dependence as the condition ofindividual and social welfare. F. Harrison. H. Spencer. Mallock.
Producing or bearing a great number; bringing forth many.
Matter in pleading which is not necessary or relevant to thecase, and which may be rejected.
To sley, or prepare for use in the weaver's sley, or slaie.Shak.
A short narrative or tale, esp. one dealing with surprising ormarvelous events.
New Hampshire; -- a nickname alluding to its mountains, whichare chiefly of granite.
The act, process, or result of saturating a substance, or ofcombining it to its fullest extent.
Before that time; beforehand. [Obs.]Many a winter therebiforn. Chaucer.
A Japanese musical instrument with three strings, resembling aguitar or banjo.
Those fortuitous effects produced by luminous rays falling oncertain objects so that some parts stand forth in abnormal brightnessand other parts are cast into a deep shadow.
Pertaining to arthrodynia, or pain in the joints; rheumatic.
One who makes or writes comments; a commentator; an annotator.
The goddess of beauty and love, that is, beauty or lovedeified.
A division of Invertebrata which includes the classesBrachiopoda and Bryozoa; -- called also Anthoid Mollusca.
Strict adherence to the forms or principles of some churchorganization; sectarianism.
Having all the florets in the same flower head of the samecolor.
The horizontal bracing of a bridge, which prevents its swaying.
Violation of chastity by force; rape. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
The act or operation of crushing the head of a fetus in thewomb in order to effect delivery.
A disease of the bones, in which they lose their earthymaterial, and become soft, flexible, and distorted. Also calledmalacia.
One of the movable peduncles which, in the decapod Crustacea,bear the eyes at the tip.
A colorless stone of high luster, made of paste. It is muchused as an inexpensive ornament.
A stiff compact pasteboard of various qualities, for makingcards, etc., often having a polished surface.
A fine smooth-faced woolen cloth for men's garments, usually ofdouble width (i.e., a yard and a half); -- so called in distinctionfrom woolens three quarters of a yard wide.
A place for raising oranges; a plantation of orange trees.
Relating to Draco, the Athenian lawgiver; or to theconstellation Draco; or to dragon's blood.
A coarse, composite weed, having a rough or prickly fruit; oneof several species of the genus Xanthium; -- called also clotbur.
Feudal tenure; the feudal system. See Feudality. Burke.
A province or territorial division of a kingdom, under the ruleof a nomarch, as in modern Greece; a nome.
The sixth day of the week, following Thursday and precedingSaturday.
The doctrine of papal supremacy; extreme views in support ofthe authority of the pope; ultramontanism; -- a term used only bypersons who are not Roman Catholics.
Increase of irritation or violence, particularly the increaseof a fever or disease.
Pertaining to anthropotomy, or the dissection of human bodies.

A custom, formerly practiced by the scholars at Eton school,England, of giing every third year, on Whittuesday, to a hillock nearthe Bath road, and exacting money from all passers-by, to support atthe university the senior scholar of the school.
An instrument for obtaining, and transferring to a picture, thepoints and outlines of objects, so as to represent them in theirproper geometrical relations as viewed from some one point.

An appendage to the shield, placed above it, and supporting thecrest (see Illust. of Crest). It generally represents a twist of twocords of silk, one tinctured like the principal metal, the other likethe principal color in the arms.
To bring together again; to compose or form anew. Spenser.
One of a class of compounds formed from certain polybasicalcohols (and especially glycerin) by the substitution of chlorinefor one or more hydroxyl groups.
Not exceptive; not including, admitting, or being, anexception.
A disease of the eyelids, attended with loss of the eyelashes.Thomas.
A Mohammedan rosary, consisting of ninety-nine beads. Byron.
A secretary or notary under the Roman empire; also, a similarofficer in France during the old monarchy.
Abstruseness; that which is abstruse. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
To shoot forth, as rays of light; to beam; to radiate. Dr. H.More.
To combine with hydrogen; to treat with, or subject to theaction of, hydrogen; to reduce; -- contrasted with oxidize.

A device used in connection with hot-air engines, gas-burningfurnaces, etc., in which the incoming air or gas is heated by beingbrought into contact with masses of iron, brick, etc., which havebeen previously heated by the outgoing, or escaping, hot air or gas.
Too frequent use of the letter m, or of the sound representedby it.

Connected with, or having its origin upon, the external surfaceof the body; -- especially applied to the feelings which originate atthe extremities of nerves distributed on the outer surface, as thesensation produced by touching an object with the finger; -- opposedto entoperipheral. H. Spenser.
The terminal part of the oviduct in insects and various otherinvertebrates. See Illust., of Spermatheca.
To steal or purloin from the writings of another; toappropriate without due acknowledgement (the ideas or expressions ofanother).
A nitro derivative of methane, analogous to chloroform,obtained as a colorless oily or crystalline substance, CH.(NO2)3,quite explosive, and having well-defined acid properties.
A tool used by turners in metal, having a bend forming a heelnear the cutting end.
A kind of bur marigold (Bidens tripartita) found in wet placesin Europe.
One of many textile fabrics having a pile like that of velvet.
A messenger or officer who serves the process of anecclesiastical court. Bouvier.
To prophesy; to foretell; to practice prediction; to utterprophecies.
A person in disguise; a masker; a mummer. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
A Venetian coin, worth about three English farthings, or oneand a half cents. [Obs.]
A compound radical, C6H13, regarded as the essential residue ofhexane, and a related series of compounds.
The morbid condition produced by the excessive use of tobacco.
A genus of fishes, remarkable for their power of living longout of water, and of making their way on land for considerabledistances, and for climbing trees; the climbing fishes.
An electro-negative element, or the element which, in electro-chemical decompositions, is evolved at the anode; -- opposed tocation. Faraday.
The quality or state of being simple; simplicity. Shak.
A double iambus; a foot consisting of two iambuses (
A species of civet (Viverra fossa) resembling the genet.
The wryneck; -- so called from its note. [Prov. Eng.]

The faculty of seeing; sight; one of the five senses, by whichcolors and the physical qualities of external objects are appreciatedas a result of the stimulating action of light on the sensitiveretina, an expansion of the optic nerve.
One who dwells in the same house with another. R. Browning.
Having small pits or depression, as the receptacle in somecomposite flowers.
A toll duty formerly exacted of merchant strangers by mayors,sheriffs, etc., for goods shown or offered for sale within theirprecincts. Cowell.
A beverage consisting of lemon juice mixed with water andsweetened.
A portion of land nearly surrounded by water, and connectedwith a larger body by a neck, or isthmus.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the formic acidseries, found in the tar, wax, or paraffine obtained by distillingcertain kinds of wood, as the beech.
The number three; three things together; a ternary. Bp. Hall.
A cord; specifically, the umbilical cord or navel string.

A name given by Prof. Huxley to a gelatinous substance found inmud dredged from the Atlantic and preserved in alcohol. He supposedthat it was free living protoplasm, covering a large part of theocean bed. It is now known that the substance is of chemical, not oforganic, origin.
The act or art of riding, and of training and managing horses;manege.
A sweetheart, of either sex; a gallant, or a mistress; --usually in a bad sense. [Archaic] Chaucer. Spenser. Shak.
The office, disposition, or act of a pedant; pedantry. [Obs.]
Growing upon flowers; -- said of certain species of fungi.
Bow-compasses carrying a drawing pen. See Bow-compass.
The act of breaking open and entering, with a feloniouspurpose, the dwelling house of another, whether done by day or night.See Burglary, and To break a house, under Break.
To fasten or bind, as with a knot; to knot together. Fuller.
In the greater part of Russia, a division for local governmentconsisting of a group of mirs, or village communities; a canton.
A permitted choice; a rhetorical figure in which a thing iscommitted to the decision of one's opponent. [Obs.] Milton.
A solemn or formal observance; proceeding according to dueform; the formality which is necessary to render a thing done valid.
Shifting the sword from one side of an adversary's sword to theother.
A genus of composite plants, with shining, commonly white oryellow, or sometimes reddish, radiated involucres, which are oftencalled "everlasting flowers."
the material of which wicks are made; esp., a loosely braidedor twisted cord or tape of cotton.
Relating to the use of galvanic heat as a caustic, especiallyin medicine.
Having elevations or depressions in form like one half of abivalve shell; -- applied principally to a surface produced byfracture.
Belonging to the Gephyrea.-- n. One of the Gerphyrea.
Two in a year; semiannual.-- adv. Twice in a year; semiannually.
Pertaining to, or having the nature of, insects. Bacon.
The true, or six-legged, insects; insects other than myriapodsand arachnids.
Resembling silver plate; -- said of certain architecturalornaments.
The mineral or earthy substance associated with metallic ore.
A mania for, or an inordinate attachment to, foreign customs,institutions, manners, fashions, etc. [R.] Saintsbury.
Furnished with, or having the form of, a steeple; adorned withsteeples. Fairfax.
A large rope to fasten the midship part of a ship to a wharf,or to another vessel.
A kind of mantilla worn by women over the head and shoulders,and sometimes over part of the face. [Mexico & Sp. Amer.]
A group of suctorial Infusoria, which in the adult stage arestationary. See Suctoria.
A yellow crystalline substance produced artificially. It isisomeric with alizarin.
Consisting of hail; abounding in hail. [R.] Bailey.
To clear of outlawry or attainder; to place under theprotection of the law. Burrill.
A genus of marine fishes, including the wrasses of Europe. SeeWrasse.

Pertaining to, or resembling, a family of endogenous and mostlyepiphytic or saxicolous plants of which the genera Tillandsia andBillbergia are examples. The pineapple, though terrestrial, is alsoof this family.
Any one of a group of thick oily hydrocarbons, C12H26, of theparaffin series.
Agreement of words with one another, in gender, number, person,or case.
One who obtrudes himself on another for bed and board. [Scot.]De Quncey.
In a linguistic manner; from the point of view of a linguist.Tylor.
A grooved director for a probe or knife.(c) (Printing) A strip or device to direct the compositor's eye tothe line of copy he is setting.
Ability; aptitude. [Obs.] Robynson. (More's Utopia).
A simple gland, glandular cavity, or tube; a follicle; as, thecryps of Lieberk.
A swaggering; vain boasting; ostentation; a bluster. Swift.
A blending of one color into another; the spreading of onecolor over another, as on the feathers of birds.
A bituminous mineral resembling asphaltum, found in the countyof A.
To make stony or calcareous by the deposit or secretion ofsalts of lime.
A rope or chain to confine the bowsprit of a ship downward tothe stem or cutwater; -- usually in the pl.
A rare metallic element found in platinum ore. It is a whitemalleable substance. Symbol Da. Atomic weight 154.
In a comprehensive manner; with great extent of scope.
A pretty or dear little bird; -- a pet name. Tennyson.
A light, with a powerful reflector, placed at the head of alocomotive, or in front of it, to throw light on the track at night,or in going through a dark tunnel.
The acid amide derivative of valeric acid, obtained as a whitecrystalline substance.
The state of being a father; the character or authority of afather; paternity.
A name given to several resinous-glandular composite plants ofCalifornia, esp. to the species of Grindelia, Hemizonia, and Madia.
An arsenide of platinum occuring in grains and minute isometriccrystals of tin-white color. It is found near Sudbury, OntarioCanada, and is the only known compound of platinum occuring innature.
A picture produced by a process in which development afterexposure may be deferred indefinitely, so as to permit transportationof exposed plates; also, the process itself.

Any liquid preparation of a color and consistency resemblingmilk; as: (a) In pharmacy, an extract of seeds, or a mixture of oiland water united by a mucilaginous substance. (b) In photography, aliquid preparation of collodion holding salt of silver, used in thephotographic process.
An American sole (Achirus lineatus, or A. achirus), related tothe European sole, but of no market value.
A genus including the long-tailed, or diadem, indris. SeeIndris.
A silver coin of several countries of Europe, and of differentvalues.
Living or having their nests in common, as certain birds.
Having no stem or caulis, or only a very short one concealed inthe ground. Gray.
Not erratic or wandering; fixed; settled; established.
To carry improperly; to carry (one's self) wrongly; tomisbehave. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The quality of being multiform; diversity of forms; variety ofappearances in the same thing. Purchas.
One who is skilled; a master of his business; a proficient; anadept. [Colloq.]
Formic aldehyde, regarded as a methylene derivative.
An extinct marine reptile from the coal measures of NovaScotia; -- so named because supposed to be of the earliest knownreptiles.
A rover in quest of booty or plunder; a plunderer; one whopillages. De Quincey.
To excite; to irritate; especially, to excite the activity of(a nerve or an irritable muscle), as by electricity.
Having the form of a funnel, or tunnel; that is, expandinggradually from the bottom upward, as the corolla of some flowers;infundibuliform.
The state of one mesmerized, or in a partial and morbid sleep.
Boiled or stewed meat; beef boiled with vegetables in waterfrom which its gravy is to be made; beef from which bouillon or souphas been made.
The buds or branches produced from underground stems.
An oval or pearshaped diamond having its entire surface cut intriangular facets.
The blade of a leaf; the broad, expanded portion of a petal orsepal of a flower. Gray.
An animal of the seal tribe, moving by short feet that serve aspaddles.
Relating to homodermy; originating from the same germ layer.
A variety of sugar, found in certain plants. It is opticallyinactive.
The art or occupation of working upon wooden furniturerequiring nice workmanship; also, such furniture.
A hook fastened to pole, by which shepherds lay hold on thelegs or necks of their sheep; a shepherd's crook. Dryden.
One who administered the Eucharist with unleavened bread; -- aname of reproach given by those of the Greek church to the Latins.
The track or tread a horseman makes upon the ground he goesover. Johnson.
The principles and rules of the art of poetry. J. Warton.
The cowslip (Primula veris); -- so called from its supposedremedial powers. Dr. Prior.

Applied to the case (as the fourth case of Latin and Greeknouns) which expresses the immediate object on which the action orinfluence of a transitive verb terminates, or the immediate object ofmotion or tendency to, expressed by a preposition. It corresponds tothe objective case in English.

In gasoline-engine motor vehicles, the cooling of the cylinderby increasing its radiating surface by means of ribs or radiators,and placing it so that it is exposed to a current of air. Cf. Watercooling. -- Air"-cooled`, a.
One of an important religious sect in India which regards Sivawith peculiar veneration.
A division of annelids including the common earthworms andallied species.

Chemistry applied to, or used in, medicine; -- used especiallywith reference to the doctrines in the school of physicians inFlanders, in the 17th century, who held that health depends upon theproper chemical relations of the fluids of the body, and whoendeavored to explain the conditions of health or disease by chemicalprinciples.
An intermediate act or decree before final decision. Ayliffe.
Containing the combustible principle of coal. Kirwan.
A genus of plants related to the banana, found at the Cape ofGood Hope. They have rigid glaucous distichous leaves, and peculiarrichly colored flowers.
A person in whose favor a power of appointment is executed.Kent. Wharton.
The stingfish, or lesser weever (Tranchinus vipera).
A brief written acknowledgment of a debt, not made payable toorder, like a promissory note. Burrill.
An apparatus for measuring the external movements of a givenpoint of the chest wall, during respiration; -- also calledthoracometer.
A tract of land or a territory inclosed within anotherterritory of which it is independent. See Exclave. [Recent]
Relating to, or connected with, hydrocephalus, or dropsy of thebrain.
According to custom; ordinarily; customarily. Latimer.
The state or quality of being null and void; invalidity;forfeiture. Burrill.
To jolt; to shake, especially by rough riding or by drivingover obstructions.
Something taught; precepts; schooling. [Obs.] penser.
A short rope grafted on a harpoon, to which a longer linTotten.
Relating to dissertations; resembling a dissertation.
To be intewoven or entwined; to twine together; as, a bower ofwreathing trees. Dryden.
One whose occupation is to tan hides, or convert them intoleather by the use of tan.
The act, art, or process of representing sounds by phoneticsigns.
Of or pertaining to Pegasus, or, figuratively, to poetry.
A robber; a pirate; hence, loosely, a rogue or rascal.
Quiet; peaceable; harmless; innocent. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
One who, or that which, roots; one that tears up by the roots.
A student of biology; one versed in the science of biology.
A massive mineral, greenish in color, and opal-like inappearance. It is essentially a hydrous silicate of iron.
The lower group of the Wealden formation; -- so called from itsdevelopment around Hastings, in Sussex, England.

A West African anthropoid ape allied to the gorilla andchimpanzee, and by some considered only a variety of the chimpanzee.It is noted for building large, umbrella-shaped nests in trees.Called also tscheigo, tschiego, nschego, nscheigo.
A division of Arachnida, including the whip scorpions(Thelyphonus) and allied forms. Sometimes used in a wider sense toinclude also the true scorpions.

Any one of several species of actinians belonging to the genusCerianthus. These animals have a long, smooth body tapering to thebase, and two separate circles of tentacles around the mouth. Theyform a tough, flexible, feltlike tube with a smooth internal lining,in which they dwell, whence the name.
A beast that has died of disease or by mischance. [Obs.] Bp.Hall.
The glowing effect which arises from the use of warm colors;hence, any similar appearance or effect in a painting, or work ofcolor.
The fragrant gum resin of various species of Boswellia;Oriental frankincense.
The material of the outside or front side, as of a wall orbuilding; facing.
The crested curassow; -- called also royal pheasant. SeeCurassow.
Capable of being understood; intelligible. Chillingworth.
A genus of Devonian fossil fishes with winglike appendages. Thehead and most of the body were covered with large bony plates. SeePlacodermi.
Of or pertaining to the Osci, a primitive people of Campania, aprovince of ancient Italy.-- n.
The theory or practice of Marconi's wireless telegraph system.
That which prevents, hinders, or obstructs; that whichintercepts access; in medicine, something to prevent disease; aprophylactic.
Having three ribs or nerves extending unbranched from the baseto the apex; -- said of a leaf. Gray.
Of or pertaining to Trent, or the general church council heldin that city.

The use of some epithet or the name of some office, dignity, orthe like, instead of the proper name of the person; as when hismajesty is used for a king, or when, instead of Aristotle, we say,the philosopher; or, conversely, the use of a proper name instead ofan appellative, as when a wise man is called a Solomon, or an eminentorator a Cicero.
Pertaining to, or having, a hobby or whim; eccentric;whimsical.[Colloq.] Sterne.
A register or roll showing the order in which officers,enlisted men, companies, or regiments are called on to serve.
A sudden, violent check of a horse by drawing or twitching thereins on a sudden and with one pull.
A petrifaction of the human body, or of any portion of it.
Characterized by, or causing, a morbid redness of the skin;relating to erythema.
.The act of drawing or laying over, as a covering. [Obs.]
A bracket to support a balcony, a cornice, or the like.
A close-fitting cap represented in Greek art as worn byOrientals, assumed to have been conical in shape. It has been adoptedin modern art as the so-called liberty cap, or cap of liberty.
Having no granules, as chlorophyll in certain conditions. R.Brown.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, copper; containing copper;-- said of those compounds of copper in which this element is presentin its highest proportion.
One skilled in the hydrography; one who surveys, or draws mapsor charts of, the sea, lakes, or other waters, with the adjacentshores; one who describes the sea or other waters. Boyle.
The principles or practice of a nonresistant; passiveobedience; submission to authority, power, oppression, or violencewithout opposition.
To call together; to summon to meet; to assemble by summons.There remained no resource but the dreadful one of convoking aparliament. palfrey.
Serving or tending to provoke, excite, or stimulate; exciting.
A red clay from the Upper Missouri region, used by the Indiansfor their pipes.
One who gathers and hoards money in trifling sums; a miser.
Butyl; -- so called from the four carbon atoms in the molecule.
The mother and ruler of a family or of her descendants; a rulerby maternal right.
Dependent on one's self; self-depending; self-reliant.
A curved plank, placed edgewise, to work in the bows of avessel. R. H. Dana, Jr.
To drive from a house or habitation; to dislodge; hence, todeprive of shelter.
In palmistry, applied to the line which marks the separationbetween the hand and the arm.
The quality of being inheritable or descendible to heirs.Jefferson.
Having the ganglia of the nervous system symmetricallyarranged, as in certain invertebrates; -- opposed to heterogangliate.
A copious vomiting of dark-colored matter; or the substance sodischarged; -- one of the most fatal symptoms in yellow fever.
A framework moving on casters, designed to support childrenwhile learning to walk.
One whose possession of an estate is broken off, ordiscontinued; one whose estate is subject to discontinuance.
A small bar, rod, bundle of fibers, or septal membrane, in theframework of an organ part.
Having an oblique spiral arrangement of planes, as levogyrateand dextrogyrate crystals.
To produce inanition in; to exhaust for want of nourishment.[R.]
Description or definition by denial, exclusion, or exception;statement of what a thing is not, or has not, from which may beinferred what it is or has.
A lage molding used in the bases of columns. Its profile issemicircular. See Illust. of Molding. Brande&C.
The common qua(Colinus, or Ortyx, Virginianus); -- so calledfrom its note.
A round gall produced on the leaves and shoots of variousspecies of the oak tree. See Gall, and Nutgall.
Righteousness. [Obs.]In doom and eke in rightwisnesse. Chaucer.
To prevent or hinder oxidation, rust, or decay; as, inoxidizingoils or varnishes.
To designate with an obelus; to mark as doubtful or spirituous.[R.]
A basin, or bowl, to hold water for washing one's hands, face,etc.
One who favors the practice of fallowing land. [R.] Sinclair.
The quality of being diminutive; smallness; littleness;minuteness.
Exercise of authority; control; government; arrangement.Chaucer. J. H. Newman.
The flanged outer end of a drawbar; also, a name applied to thedrawgear.
The receiving or harboring a felon knowingly, after thecommission of a felony. Burrill.
Bearing globules; in geology, used of rocks, and denoting avariety of concretionary structure, where the concretions areisolated globules and evenly distributed through the texture of therock.
Pertaining to, or designating, certain compounds of oxygen andbromine.
One who has, or affects, sentiment or fine feeling.
The act of electrifying, or the state of being charged withelectricity.
A boast or boasting; a vaunt; a bravado; a bragging;braggodocio. Swift.
Capable of being inscribed, -- used specif. (Math.) of solidsor plane figures capable of being inscribed in other solids orfigures.
Pertaining to the art of binding books. [R.] Dibdin.
Of or pertaining to the machinery of a poem; acting or used asa machine.[Obs.] Dryden.
Not tamed; untamed; savage; wild. [Obs.] J. Salkeld.
A cork stuck with feathers, which is to be struck by abattledoor in play; also, the play itself.
Things belonging to the sheriff; especially, farms (called alsovicontiel rents) for which the sheriff used to pay rent to the king.
A small vessel of iron, copper, or other metal, with a handle,used for culinary purpose, as for stewing meat.
A gold coin of Zealand [Netherlands] equal to 14 florins, about$ 5.60.
A hybrid whose parents differ by three pairs of contrastingMendelian characters.
The second, or true, muscular stomach of birds, in which thefood is crushed and ground, after being softened in the glandularstomach (crop), or lower part of the esophagus; the gigerium.
A work raised in the middle of a wide ditch, to defend it.Crabb.
A short sleep taken about the middle of the day, or afterdinner; a midday nap.
A colorless, mobile, and very volatile liquid obtained fromalcohol by certain of oxidation.
Sung or addressed to one departing; valedictory; as, apoplecticsongs or hymns.
A small piece or silver of skin which hangs loose, near theroot of finger nail. Holloway.
Of or pertaining to a pluviometer; determined by a pluviometer.
Serving to moisten the eye; -- sometimes applied to thelachrymal ducts.
A genus of parrots with gray heads. of New Zeland and papua,allied to the cockatoos. See Kaka.
Having the toes united by a web for a considerable part oftheir length.
One of several that jointly sign a written instrument, as atreaty. Fallows.
A trible of North American Indians (Southern Appalachian)allied to the Choctaws. They formerly occupied the northern part ofAlabama and Mississippi, but now live in the Indian Territory.
Hard rubber produced by vulcanizing with a large proportion ofsulphur.
To germinate; to bud; to multiply abundantly. Warburton.

To use the hands in dexterous operations; to do hand work;specifically, to manage the apparatus or instruments used inscientific work, or in artistic or mechanical processes; also,specifically, to use the hand in mesmeric operations.
A passage for wind or air; a passage or pipe for ventilatingapartments. Gwilt.
The morbid phenomena produced by dwelling among marshes;malarial disease or disposition.
The postero-lateral ossification in the sternum of birds; also,the part resulting from such ossification.
One who tramps; a stroller; a vagrant or vagabond; a tramp.Dickens.
Water flavored, sweetened, and frozen, to be eaten as aconfection.
The quality or state of being intangible; intangibleness.
A sunken compartment with raised margins, molded or otherwise,as in ceilings, wainscotings, etc.
A name given to several species of crowfoot (Ranunculus) whichhave spear-shaped leaves.
An order of fishes, formerly proposed by Agassiz, for thosewith thin, smooth scales, destitute of marginal spines, as theherring and salmon. The group is now regarded as artificial.
A compound of two atoms of hydrogen with some other substance.[Obs.]
To enslave; to bind; to restrict. [Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
Divination by burning straws on red-hot iron, and noting themanner of their burning. Craig.
Making undue claims and pretension; prone to arrogance. [R.]Dr. H. More.
To remove from a class; to separate or degrade from one'sclass.  North Am. Rev.
Having six columns in front; -- said of a portico or temple.-- n.
Undue boldness of speculation; unbelief. Berkeley.-- a.
The horizontal line which measures the distance to which aprojectile is thrown; the range.
One of a series of flat, fringed, and usually bilobed,appendages, of which several pairs occur on the abdominal somites ofmany crustaceans. They are used as fins in swimming.

An instrument formed by combining prisms so as to correct thechromatic aberration of the light while linear dimensions of objectsseen through the prisms are increased or diminished; -- called alsoprism telescope. Sir D. Brewster.
To drive on rashly; to go to excess; hence, to exaggerate; toboast. [Obs.] Barrow.

An order that aims to limit losses by fixing a figure at whichpurchases shall be sold or sales bought in, as where stock is boughtat 100 and the broker is directed to sell if the market price dropsto 98.

An ament; a species of inflorescence, consisting of a slenderaxis with many unisexual apetalous flowers along its sides, as in thewillow and poplar, and (as to the staminate flowers) in the chestnut,oak, hickory, etc.-- so called from its resemblance to a cat's tail. See Illust. ofAment.
The intersection of two surface forming a salient angle,especially the angle at the top between the opposite slopes or sidesof a roof or a vault.
Liquefying by heat after having been frozen; thawing; melting.
A genus of extinct Tertiary Foraminifera, having a thin, flat,round shell, containing a large number of small chambers arrangedspirally.
A flattened concretionary nodule, usually of limestone,intersected within by cracks which are often filled with calcite,barite, or other minerals.
A piece of furniture having a number of uninclosed shelves orstages, one above another, for receiving articles of elegance or use.Fairholt.
The true meaning, understanding, or intention of a law, or ofany legal instrument.
One of the larger measures of electrical resistance, amountingto one million ohms.
A surplice, in England and America usually one shorter and lessfull than the ordinary surplice and with short sleeves, or sometimesnone.
The advantage of using water as a mechanical power; also, theplace where water is, or may be, so used. See under Privilege.
A foot consisting of four syllables, of which the first andlast are long, and the other short (- ~ ~ -); that is, a choreus, ortrochee, and an iambus united.
A division of swimming birds including those that havetotipalmate feet.
Stirring; in a state of activity or motion; out of bed.
The contact of one curve with another, when the number ofconsecutive points of the latter through which the former passessuffices for the complete determination of the former curve. Brande &C.
Affecting a whole people or a number of countries; everywhereepidemic.-- n.
One of the royalist insurgents in western France (Brittany,etc.), during and after the French revolution.
Vigorous; energetic; with energy; -- a direction to perform apassage with energy and force.
A kind of canoe used in Central and South America; also, a kindof boat used in the Southern United States. Bartlett.
A word coined by Lewis Carroll (Charles L. Dodgson), andusually explained as a combination of chuckle and snort. [Humorous]
One who assesses, or sets a value on, anything; an appraiser.Swift.
A local tax paid by a ship for the ground or space it occupieswhile in port. Bouvier.
the entire covering, or mode of arrangement, of scales, as onthe legs and feet of a bird.
Causing dilation; tending to dilate, on enlarge; expansive.Coleridge.
The quality or state of being rancid; a rancid scent or flavor,as of old oil. Ure.
The act of disheriting, or debarring from inheritance;disinhersion. Bp. Hall.
Covered with gyrons, or divided so as to form several gyrons; -- said of an escutcheon.
Any plant of the genus Pilularia; minute aquatic cryptograms,with small pill-shaped fruit; -- sometimes called peppergrass.
A circular hole formed in the rocky beds of rivers by thegrinding action of stones or gravel whirled round by the water inwhat was at first a natural depression of the rock.
A variety of steatite sometimes manufactured into culinaryvessels.
An iron-potash mica, of a raven-black color, usually found ingranitic rocks in small six-sided tables, or as an aggregation ofminute opaque scales. See Mica.
Work performed, or results obtained, by guess; conjecture.
A line connecting places on the earth having the same meanwinter temperature. Cf. Isothere.
A West African antelope (Damalis Senegalensis), allied to thesassaby. It is reddish gray, with a black face, and a black stripe onthe outside of the legs above the knees.
A species of Capsicum, or Guinea pepper (C. annuum). It is thered pepper of the gardens.
To make resemble. [Obs.]If I was a philosopher, says Montaigne, I would naturalize artinstead of artilizing nature. Bolingbroke.
Not subjected to the principles or usages of the Roman CatholicChurch.
Of a wild nature; -- applied to animals, as foxes, wild ducks,etc., in which no one can claim property.
A time that will never come, as the Greeks had no calends.
A musician who plays on the harp or lyre; a composer of lyricalpoetry. Shelley.
Rubbish; refuse; dirt. [Obs.]All this mullok [was] in a sieve ythrowe. Chaucer.
That part of the eye of an invertebrate which corresponds infunction with the retina of a vertebrate.
A general term used of any triclinic feldspar. See the Noteunder Feldspar.

Divination by the assistance, or supposed assistance, of evilspirits, or the power of commanding evil spirits; magic; necromancy;witchcraft; enchantment.Adder's wisdom I have learned, To fence my ear against thy sorceries.Milton.
An itinerant theatrical player who plays in barns when atheatre is lacking; hence, an inferior actor, or one who plays in thecountry away from the larger cities. --Barn"storm`ing, n. [TheatricalCant]
Misgovernment; misconduct; misbehavior. [Obs.] Chaucer.Spenser.
Having relation to changes in currents that depend on themoon's phases. Bache.
Without dimensions; having no appreciable or noteworthy extent.Milton.
A short, light musket or rifle, esp. one used by mountedsoldiers or cavalry.
An apparatus for condensing vegetable juices, or for dryingfruit by heat.
An imagined space having more than three dimensions.
A cement or paste (as of plaster and freestone, or of sawdustand glue or lime) used by sculptors, builders, and workers in wood orstone, to fill holes, cover defects, or finish a surface.
A talmudic exposition of the Hebrew law, or of some part of it.
A genus of plants of the order Filices or ferns. Thefructifications are in uncovered roundish points, called sori,scattered over the inferior surface of the frond or leaf. There arenumerous species.
Relating to disquisition; fond discussion or investigation;examining; inquisitive.
Possessing in itself the property of emitting light. Sir D.Brewster.
A community in which many persons unite as in one family, andare regulated by certain communistic laws and customs.
A Russian measure of length equal to about seven English feet.
The operation of forming a new canthus, when one has beendestroyed by injury or disease.
Having the maxillo-palatine bones separate from each other andfrom the vomer, which is pointed in front, as in the gulls, snipes,grouse, and many other birds.
A capping or crowning molding in classic architecture.
The maiming of a person by depriving him of the use of any ofhis members which are necessary for defense or protection. See Maim.
Hollow and distended, as a perianth, corolla, nectary, orpericarp. Martyn.

Originally, in classical architecture, the triangular spaceforming the gable of a simple roof; hence, a similar form used as adecoration over porticoes, doors, windows, etc.; also, a rounded orbroken frontal having a similar position and use. See Temple.
To meet a wager on, as on the taking of a trick, with a higherwager. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
The quality of being worthy to be worshiped. [R.] Coleridge.
A hard, compact variety of serpentine found in Rhode Island. Itis of a light green color and resembles jade.
A metallic handle with a clasp for holding a crayon.
Laws relating to the equilibrium of the blood in the bloodvessels.
Spore formation. See Spore formation (b), under Spore.
A member of a reserve force of soldiers or militia. [Eng.]
The process of producing electrotype plates. See Note underElectrotype, n.
