It is a staple food plant of the tropics, beingprepared like potatoes, and has been introduced into the SouthernUnited States.
In relief; pertaining to sculpture in relief, especially ofmetal; also, pertaining to chasing such as surface ornamentation inmetal.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, pegmatite; as, the pegmaticstructure of certain rocks resembling graphic granite.
A small, strong carriage for conveying materials on a railroad.[Eng.]
A youth beloved by Venus for his beauty. He was killed in thechase by a wild boar.
To tread down; to trample upon. [Obs.]In hell shall they be all fortroden of devils. Chaucer.
The act or state of predominating; ascendency; predominance. W.Browne.
One who practices simony, or who buys or sells preferment inthe church. Ayliffe.
Made of silk; having a silky or flaxlike appearance. Coles.
A sycophant; a fawner; a toady. Cf. Bootlick. Shak.
Pertaining to, or resembling, orichalch; having a color orluster like that of brass. Maunder.
A dumb gymnastic apparatus for training the hands of pianistsand organists, as to a legato touch.
The number by which another number is multiplied; a multiplier.
Pertaining to the Franks, or their language; Frankish.
An African antelope (Hippotragus Bakeri). Its face is stripedwith black and white.
divination practiced with water in a basin, by throwing threestones into it, and invoking the demon whose aid was sought.
The active young larva of any oil beetle. It has feet armedwith three claws, and is parasitic on bees. See Illust. of Oilbeetle, under Oil.
Any one of several small German and Dutch coins, worth fromabout one and a half cents to about five cents.
The state of a cuckold; cuckolds, collectively. Addison.
The qualities and practices of a slut; sluttishness;slatternlines. Drayton.
A colorless oil (quickly becoming brown), with a pleasant odor,obtained by the decomposition of ericolin.
A salt of orthosilicic acid, H4SiO4; -- so called because theratio of the oxygen atoms united to the basic metals and siliconrespectively is 1:1; for example, Mg2SiO4 or 2MgO.SiO2.
A penalty or fine for neglect. [Local, New England]
A rounded mass or irregular shape; a little knot or lump.
An explosive consisting of a mixture of powdered aluminium andnitrate of ammonium.
A vacuum tube in which the exhaustion is carried to a very highdegree, with the production of a distinct class of effects; -- socalled from W. Crookes who introduced it.
Possessed of the supposed evil eye; also, looking with envy,jealousy, or bad design; malicious. Shak.
In a domestic manner; privately; with reference to domesticaffairs.
An instrument used for smoothing the surface of a core.
One of a peculiar kind of internal buds, or germs, produced inthe interior of certain Bryozoa and sponges, especially in the fresh-water species; -- also called winter buds.

Neuralgia of the sciatic nerve, an affection characterized byparoxysmal attacks of pain in the buttock, back of the thing, or inthe leg or foot, following the course of the branches of the sciaticnerve. The name is also popularly applied to various painfulaffections of the hip and the parts adjoininhg. See Ischiadicpassion, under Ischiadic.
Any one of several species of handsome gastropod shells of thegenus Trochus, or Imperator. The shell is conical, with the margintoothed somewhat like the rowel of a spur.
That may be plucked off, cropped, or torn away. [Obs.] Bailey.
A summary, plan, or scheme of something proposed, affording aprospect of its nature; especially, an exposition of the scheme of anunpublished literary work.
A sulphide of antimony, lead, and silver, occuring inmonoclinic crystals.
A beetle of the genus Melolontha, and allied genera. See Maybeetle, under May.
The quality or state of being potential; possibility, notactuality; inherent capability or disposition, not actuallyexhibited.
To vote in opposition ti; to balance or overcome by viting; tooutvote. Dr. J. Scott.
The state of being extensive; wideness; largeness; extent;diffusiveness.
Incapable of being explored, searched out, or discovered. SirG. Buck.
An animal one year old, or in the second year of its age; --applied chiefly to cattle, sheep, and horses.
The change of pyroxene to amphibole by paramorphism.
Capable of being designated or distinctly marked out;distinguishable. Boyle.
The outer boundary of a body or figure, or the sum of all thesides.
A large South American bird (Dicholophus, or Cariama cristata)related to the cranes. It is often domesticated. Called also cariama.
A sack or matters inflated with air, and used as a bed.
A long, flat-bottomed canoe, used for the navigation of riversand lagoons in Central America. Squier.
A cake made of the meal of Indian corn, wrapped in a coveringof husks or paper, and baked under the embers. [U.S.] Bartlett.
A kind of large ship formerly used by the Spaniards andPortuguese in the East India trade; a galleon. [Spelt also carrack.]The bigger whale like some huge carrack law. Waller.
To bring to a certain degree of consistency, by evaporation, asa fluid. Graduating engine, a dividing engine. See Dividing engine,under Dividing.
The process or act of baffling, or of being baffled;frustration; check.
Instinct; incitement; inspiration. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
A grayish or greenish compact rock, composed of feldspar andaugite, and allied to basalt.
A game at cards, played by two or more persons. The fortune ofeach player depends upon obtaining from the dealer such cards thatthe sum of their pips, or spots, is twenty-one, or a number near toit.
The acts, arts, or boastful pretensions of a quack; falsepretensions to any art; empiricism. Carlyle.
A kind of dress goods made of cotton or woolen, with a glossysurface resembling satin.
A plant in new Zealand (Phormium tenax), allied to the liliesand aloes. The leaves are two inches wide and several feet long, andfurnish a fiber which is used for making ropes, mats, and coarsecloth.
The officer in a religious house who had the care of theinfirmary. [Obs.]

A mollusk having a shell consisting of two lateral plates orvalves joined together by an elastic ligament at the hinge, which isusually strengthened by prominences called teeth. The shell is closedby the contraction of two transverse muscles attached to the innersurface, as in the clam, -- or by one, as in the oyster. SeeMollusca.

A class of objects divided into several subordinate species; aclass more extensive than a species; a precisely defined and exactlydivided class; one of the five predicable conceptions, or sorts ofterms.
In an atomic manner; in accordance with the atomic philosophy.
To oppose or check by some obstacle; to check by a returncheck.
Work done by a team, as distinguished from that done bypersonal labor.
The state or quality of being slick; smoothness; sleekness.
A poisonous alkaloid extracted from corroval, and characterizedby its immediate action in paralyzing the heart.
A part of mechanics which treats of the motion, range, time offlight, etc., of bodies thrown or driven through the air by animpelling force.
Any large marine mammal, as a seal, walrus, or cetacean.
To conform, or cause to conform, to the religion of Islam.

Any parrot of the genus Sittace, or Macrocercus. About eighteenspecies are known, all of them American. They are large and have avery long tail, a strong hooked bill, and a naked space around theeyes. The voice is harsh, and the colors are brilliant and stronglycontrasted.
Having the veins (of a leaf) diverging from the two sides of amidrib.
Said before, or in a preceding part; already described oridentified.
An imperfection on the inside of the hind leg in horses,different from a curb, but at the same height, and frequentlyinjuring the sale of the animal by growing to an unsightly size.Craig.
One of the nine honorable ordinaries, consisting of two broadbands of the width of the bar, issuing, respectively from the dexterand sinister bases of the field and conjoined at its center.
Work aside from regular work; subordinate or secondarybusiness.
Pertaining to, or situated near, the calcar of the brain.
Elevated, -- as a toe, when raised so high that the tip doesnot touch the ground.
A classic idiom or expression; a classicalism. C. Kingsley.
The quality or tenure of the fee held by a vavasor; also, thelands held by a vavasor.
Gentle heat; moderate warmth; tepidness. Arbuthnot.
The modern dialects spoken in the north of Germany, takencollectively; modern Low German. See Low German, under German.
According to desert (whether good or evil); justly.
Sitting, as a lion or other beast. Sejant rampant, sitting withthe forefeet lifted up. Wright.
An object of ridicule or scorn; a laughingstock. Shak.
A South American bird of the flycatcher family. (Tityrainquisetor).
A rope applied to the fore yardarm, to change the position ofthe foresail.
The highest or utmost degree; the best of anything. [Colloq.]
The theory that the heathen divinities originated in thepersonification of elemental powers.
Any written or other legal evidence of the conveyance ofproperty; a conveyance; a deed.
A hound that tracks animals by the scent; specifically, abloodhound. [Spelt variously slouthhound, sluthhound, etc.]
A perennial herb (Phryma Leptostachya), having slender seedlikefruits.
The state of abounding, or being covered, with hair. Johnson.
In the universities of Germany and some other Europeancountries, a licensed teacher or lecturer having no share in theuniversity government and dependent upon fees for remuneration.
One who is engaged in lumbering as a business or employment.[U.S.]

A double star; -- applied to the nucleus of a cell, when,during cell division, the loops of the nuclear network separate intotwo groups, preparatory to the formation of two daughter nuclei. SeeKaryokinesis.
One who violates; an infringer; a profaner; a ravisher.
Purulent inflammation of the cellular or areolar tissue.
A subclass of fishes including all the ordinary bony fishes asdistinguished from the ganoids.
A narrow circle of persons associated by common interests orfor the accomplishment of a common purpose; -- generally used in abad sense.
The exhibition and explanation of a dissection or otheranatomical preparation.

A proceeding devised to enable a person, of whom the same debt,duty, or thing is claimed adversely by two or more parties, to compelthem to litigate the right or title between themselves, and therebyto relieve himself from the suits which they might otherwise bringagainst him.
The state of an heir; succession by inheritance. Burke.
Capable of being obtained or moved by petition. [Obs.] Bailey.
An herb (Pilea pumila) of the Nettle family, having a smooth,juicy, pellucid stem; -- called also clearweed.
A directive influence exercised by a mass of matter upongrowing organs. Encyc. Brit.

The act or right of purchasing before others. Specifically:(a) The privilege or prerogative formerly enjoyed by the king ofbuying provisions for his household in preference to others. [Eng.](b) The right of an actual settler upon public lands (particularlythose of the United States) to purchase a certain portion at a fixedprice in preference to all other applicants. Abbott.
A formative letter at the beginning of a word. M. Stuart.
Pertaining to, or designating, any one of three acids obtainedby the distillation of citric acid, and called respectivelycitraconic, itaconic, and mesaconic acid.
A minute spherical or rounded structure; as blood, lymph, andpus corpuscles, minute fungi, spores, etc.
Partaking of the qualities of a bear; resembling a bear intemper or manners. Harris.
To stand apart from; top leave off; to desist. [Obs.] Raleigh.
One who supports or frequents conventicles. Dryden.
One who toots; one who plays upon a pipe or horn. B. Jonson.
A genus of intestinal worms which includes the common tapewormsof man. See Tapeworm.
A European species of deer (Cervus dama), much smaller than thered deer. In summer both sexes are spotted with white. It is commonin England, where it is often domesticated in the parks.
A brother by the marriage of one's father with the mother ofanother, or of one's mother with the father of another.
Bred from the best blood through a long line; pure-blooded; --said of stock, as horses. Hence, having the characteristics of suchbreeding; mettlesome; courageous; of elegant form, or the like.-- n.
Two-nerved; -- applied to leaves which have two longitudinalribs or nerves.
One who, or that which, contributes; specifically, one whowrites articles for a newspaper or magazine.
A medicine adapted to relieve or cure disease of the kidneys.
One of the subdivisions of the trachea or windpipe; esp. one ofthe two primary divisions.
A woman versed in magical arts; a sorceress; also, a woman whofascinates. Shak.
Situated behind the tympanum, or in the skull, behind theauditory meatus.
Pertaining to, or having, convulsions; convulsionary. [R.]Lamb.
To split into scales, especially to become converted intoscales at the result of heat or decomposition.
A combination of wheels, and their connection, in a machine ormechanism.
The act of borrowing or exchanging. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Characterized by waving or flamelike curves, as in the traceryof windows, etc.; -- said of the later (15th century) French Gothicstyle.
A Turkish saint; a kind of dervish, regarded by the people as asaint: also, a hermit.
To practice an exercise or exercises; to train one's self.
A salmon returning from the sea the second time. [Prov. Eng.]
Straight in form or upright in position; erect. [Obs.] Shak.
Divination by means of the ascent or motion of smoke.
The red oxide of copper; red copper; an important ore ofcopper, occurring massive and in isometric crystals.
A glass used in subliming camphor. [Spelled also bombolo andbumbolo.]
An insoluble albuminous body formed from casein and otherproteid substances by the action of gastric juice. Meissner.
Suitable to be written upon; capable of being written upon, asa slate; -- said especially of a certain kind of globe. Scudamore.

Pertaining to, or derived from, linoleum, or linseed oil;specifically (Chem.), designating an organic acid, a thin yellow oil,found combined as a salt of glycerin in oils of linseed, poppy, hemp,and certain nuts.
By deduction; by way of inference; by consequence. Sir T.Browne.
The quality or condition of being bunchy; knobbiness.
State of being acquainted; degree of acquaintance. [R.] Boyle.
Pertaining to the catamenia, or menstrual discharges.
Of or pertaining to the external organs of generation.
A formulary or prescription for making some combination,mixture, or preparation of materials; a receipt; especially, aprescription for medicine.
A pneumatic or hydraulic cushion for a falling weight, as inthe valve gear of a steam engine, to prevent shock.
An old name for the judges of the higher English courts.
To draw towards a common center or a middle line. Huxley.
Pecuniarily embarrassed through owning much unprofitable land.[Colloq.]
Brightness or strength of color. [R.] E. Waterhouse.
The state of having, or the property of taking, a crystallineform unlike that which belongs to the species.
Opposition of action; counteraction or contrariety of things orprinciples.
A state of difficulty or perplexity; doubt; uncertainty.
Amphibole resulting from the alternation of pyroxene byparamorphism. It is not uncommon in massive eruptive rocks.
The act of setting the value; valuation by an appraiser;estimation of worth.
A lens convex on one side and concave on the other.
A medicine supposed to expel black bile or choler. [Obs.]
A weight of 1,000 kilograms, or 2,204.6 pounds avoirdupois.
The hipped part of a roof which is hipped only for a part ofits height, leaving a truncated gable.
The two hundredth year or anniversary, or its celebration.
To sit badly or imperfectly upon; to misbecome. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A liquid hydrocarbon, C10H20, of the ethylene series, regardedas a polymeric form of amylene.
A powerful instrument of brass, curved somewhat like the Romanbuccina, or tuba.
A sort of salt, finely granulated, formed out of the bittern orleach brine.
Overalls of sheepskin or leather, usually open at the back,worn, esp. by cowboys, to protect the legs from thorny bushes, as inthe chaparral; -- called also chapareras or colloq. chaps. [Sp.Amer.]
Devotion to the pursuit of wealth; worldliness. Carlyle.
The state of being in disorder; derangement; confusion. [Obs.]Bacon.
One skilled in the art or science of music; esp., a skilledsinger, or performer on a musical instrument.
Reduced to ashes by burning; thoroughly consumed. [Obs.] Bacon.
A bed of earth heated by fermenting manure or other substances,and covered with glass, intended for raising early plants, or fornourishing exotics.
To insure; to covenant to indemnify for loss, or to pay aspecified sum at death. See Insure.
An epidemic disease of the silkworm, characterized by thepresence of minute vibratory corpuscles in the blood.
The horizontal thrust or pressure of an arch or vault upon theabutments. [R.] Knight.
One who, or that which, inclines; specifically, an inclineddial.
The vessel which carries the commanding officer of a fleet orsquadron and flies his distinctive flag or pennant.
The art or practice of disputation or controversy, especiallyon religious subjects; that branch of theological science whichpertains to the history or conduct of ecclesiastical controversy.

A four-stroke cycle for internal-combustion engines consistingof the following operations: First stroke, suction into cylinder ofexplosive charge, as of gas and air; second stroke, compression,ignition, and explosion of this charge; third stroke (the workingstroke), expansion of the gases; fourth stroke, expulsion of theproducts of combustion from the cylinder. This is the cycle inventedby Beau de Rochas in 1862 and applied by Dr. Otto in 1877 in theOtto-Crossley gas engine, the first commercially successful internal-combustion engine made.
Pure silica, like quartz, but crystallizing in hexagonaltables. It is found in trachyte and similar rocks.
An adventurer; -- a term of contempt for a Northern man seekingprivate gain or political advancement in the southern part of theUnited States after the Civil War (1865). [U. S.]
A vessel with a spout, in which tea is made, and from which itis poured into teacups.
A boxlike structure with funnel-shaped traps for catching eels;an eelbuck.
Of or pertaining to nucleoplasm; -- esp. applied to a bodyformed in the developing ovum from the plasma of the nucleus of thegerminal vesicle.
One instructed in the mysteries of a secret system. Carlyle.
Plainness to the eye or the mind; visibleness; obviousness.[R.] Sherwood.
A tavern; a house where liquors are retailed. [Obs. as anEnglish word.]

A warning or citation to appear in court; a writtennotification signed by the proper officer, to be served on a person,warning him to appear in court at a day specified, to answer to theplaintiff, testify as a witness, or the like.

A disease, the chief symptom of which is a very acute pain,exacerbating or intermitting, which follows the course of a nervousbranch, extends to its ramifications, and seems therefore to beseated in the nerve. It seems to be independent of any structurallesion. Dunglison.
A thin stuff made of the finest wool or silk, or of wool andsilk.
In a dry manner; not succulently; without interest; withoutsympathy; coldly.

A telescope with a diagonal eyepiece, suspended vertically ingimbals by the object end beneath a fixed diagonal plane mirror. Itis used for delineating landscapes, by means of a pencil at the eyeend which leaves the delineation on paper.
A piece of metal in the form of a coin, struck with a device,and intended to preserve the remembrance of a notable event or anillustrious person, or to serve as a reward.

A large brass wind instrument, formerly used in the orchestraand in military bands, having a loud tone, deep pitch, and a compassof three octaves; -- now generally supplanted by bass and contrabasstubas. Moore (Encyc. of Music).
The food supplied to the Israelites in their journey throughthe wilderness of Arabia; hence, divinely supplied food. Ex. xvi. 15.
Having the ends terminating in rounded protuberances or singleballs; -- said of a cross.
The quality or state of being transparent; transparency.
A town or village, or part of a town or village, assigned to abody of troops for quarters; temporary shelter or place of rest foran army; quarters.
The crime of buying or selling ecclesiastical preferment; thecorrupt presentation of any one to an ecclesiastical benefice formoney or reward. Piers Plowman.
Of or pertaining to Libya, the ancient name of that part ofAfrica between Egypt and the Atlantic Ocean, or of Africa as a whole.

Characterizing that kind of reasoning which derivespropositions from the observation of facts, or by generalizationsfrom facts arrives at principles and definitions, or infers causesfrom effects. This is the reverse of a priori reasoning.
The arrangement of flowers in a cluster; the science of therelative position of flowers; inflorescence.
An assumed name; a fanciful epithet or appellation; a nickname.[Sometimes less correctly written soubriquet.]
Masonry constructed of unsquared stones that are irregular insize and shape.
A watchman; an officer of customs or police. [India]
One who sets right; one who does justice or redresses wrong.Shelton.

A diminution or softening of statement for the sake of avoidingcensure or increasing the effect by contrast with the moderationshown in the form of expression; as, " a citizen of no mean city,"that is, of an illustrious city.
Cap or bonnet strings made long to tie under the chin.

Sound of the kind or quality heard in speech or song in theconsonants b, v, d, etc., and in the vowels; sonant, or intonated,utterance; tone; -- distinguished from mere breath sound as heard inf, s, sh, etc., and also whisper.

One who pays; one who compensates, rewards, or requites;specifically, an officer or agent of a government, a corporation, oran employer, whose duty it is to pay salaries, wages, etc., and keepaccount of the same.
The tops or heads of stream-work which lie over the stream oftin.
A privy, or water-closet, esp. in a camp, hospital, etc.

A musical instrument, of unknown character, supposed by some tohave been used by the people of Gath, and thence obtained by David.It is mentioned in the title of Psalms viii., lxxxi., and lxxxiv. Dr.W. Smith.
That part of grammar which treats of the quantity of syllables,of accent, and of the laws of versification or metrical composition.
A yellow acid substance formed by the action of hot nitric acidon albuminous or proteid matter. It is changed to a deep orange-yellow color by the addition of ammonia.
The quality of being artless, or void of art or guile;simplicity; sincerity.
A variety of jade or nephrite, -- used in New Zealand for themanufacture of axes and weapons.
Lamentation; threnody; a dirge. Shak.The threns . . . of the prophet Jeremiah. Jer. Taylor.
Pertaining to endosmose; of the nature endosmose; osmotic.Carpenter.
The ankle bone, or hock bone; the bone of the tarsus whicharticulates with the tibia at the ankle.
The act or habit of eating earth. See Dirt eating, under Dirt.Dunglison.
The large white lily (Lilium longiflorum eximium, syn. L.Harrisii) which is extensively cultivated in Bermuda.
A genus of large sea birds, including the albatross. SeeAlbatross.
Appropriate to, or like, a parson; -- used in disparagement.[Colloq.]
Money paid for the maintenance of a beacon; also, beacons,collectively.
The track of man or beast as followed by the scent. [Scot.]Halliwell.
To rise, or cause to rise, in a swarm or swarms. [R.] Shak.Cowper.
A remedy which has an action similar to that of another remedy,and hence increases the efficiency of that remedy when combined withit.
A piece of malleable iron, wrought into the shape of a bar inthe middle, but unwrought at the ends.
Sameness 9kind or nature; uniformity of structure or material.
The wheel which, together with the axle, forms the axis inperitrochio, which see under Axis.
One who makes his mark, instead of writing his name, in signingdocuments. Burrill.
That may be accommodated, fitted, or made to agree. [R.] I.Watts.
The large process at the proximal end of the ulna whichprojects behind the articulation with the humerus and forms the bonyprominence of the elbow.
A kind of diorite or diabase containing imbedded whitishspherules, which give the rock a spotted appearance.
A compound of the so-called margaric acid with a base.
To remain sitting, or in session, longer than, or beyond thetime of; to outstay.
To set in, or punish with, the pillory; to pillory. [R.]
An instrument for measuring the volume of a body, especially asolid, by means of the difference in tension caused by its presenceand absence in a confined portion of air.
A small column or pillar, used as a monument, milestone, etc.

A small fish, about three inches in length, of the Herringfamily (Engraulis encrasicholus), caught in vast numbers in theMediterranean, and pickled for exportation. The name is also appliedto several allied species.
To baptize; -- used in contempt by the Reformers. [Obs.]Tyndale.
Pertaining to, or of the nature of, a falcon or hawk; hawklike.Lowell.
One who treks before or first; a pioneer. [South Africa]
A block of wood, usually fastened to some spar, and shaped toreceive the end of another spar.
A genus of shrubs growing in Australia, having beautiful, hard,dry, evergreen leaves.
A word which is joined to another so closely as to lose itsproper accent, as the pronoun thee in prithee (pray thee).
The Australian white-quilled honey eater (Entomyza albipennis).
A white crystalline solid, from ammonia by replacement of anequivalent of hydrogen by acetyl.
To reduce to a lower rating or rank; to degrade. Marryat.
Gout in the joints of the foot; -- applied also to gout inother parts of body.
To become putrid; to decay offensively; to rot. Isa. 1. 6.
Of or pertaining to the palm of the hand or the sole of thefoot.
The act or process of volatilizing, or rendering volatile; thestate of being volatilized.
Having the nose bottleshaped, or large at the end. Dickens.
Good faith; honesty; freedom from fraud or deception.
The dorsal lobe or branch of a parapodium. See Parapodium.
A division of fishes including the mackerels, tunnies, andallied fishes.
A small blunt-pointed bistoury, -- used in syringotomy.
The upper and outer element of periotic bone, -- in man forminga part of the temporal bone.
The radical UO2, conveniently regarded as a residue of manyuranium compounds.

Any affection produced by the action of the sun on some part ofthe body; especially, a sudden prostration of the physical powers,with symptoms resembling those of apoplexy, occasioned by exposure toexcessive heat, and often terminating fatally; coup de soleil.
In an obligatory manner; by reason of obligation. Foxe.
As much as will fill a book; a book full. Shak.-- a.
A genus of terrestrial gastropods, having transparent, verythin, and delicate shells, -- whence the name.
The portion of movable estate to which the children areentitled upon the death of the father.
The enacting or passing of a law a second time; the renewal ofa law.
A pitch-black mineral consisting chiefly of the oxide ofuranium; uraninite. See Uraninite.
Of or pertaining to pectin; specifically, designating an acidobtained from ordinary vegetable jelly (pectin) as an amorphoussubstance, tough and horny when dry, but gelatinous when moist.
The quality or state of being peculiar; peculiarity. Mede.
To make hostile; to cause to become an enemy. [Obs.] A. Seward.
Done (as bowling) with the arm not raised above the elbow, thatis, not swung far out from the body; underhand. Cf. Over-arm andRound-Arm.

A judicial writ, founded upon some record, and requiring theparty proceeded against to show cause why the party bringing itshould not have advantage of such record, or (as in the case of scirefacias to repeal letters patent) why the record should not beannulled or vacated. Wharton. Bouvier.
A white metallic alloy; which is made into spoons, forks,teapots, etc. British plate or German silver. See German silver,under German.
A system of apparatus for electric signals providing forautomatic transmission of a definite number of different signals orcalls, as in connection with hotel annunciators.
Of or pertaining to the Avesta or the language of the Avesta. --n.
A form of mental alienation in which the patient has grandiosedelusions.
Having, or characterized by, three unequal axes intersecting atoblique angles. See the Note under crystallization.
A heap or pile of hay, usually covered with thatch forpreservation in the open air.
The process of forming an ulcer, or of becoming ulcerous; thestate of being ulcerated; also, an ulcer.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid amide derivative ofsuccinic acid, obtained as a white crystalline substance, and forminga series of salts.
A small, two-wheeled, hooded vehicle drawn by one more men.[Japan]
The state or dignity of a thane; thanehood; also, theseignioralty of a thane.
An assistant editor, as of a periodical or journal.
A cup or bowl; especially, the cup used in the sacrament of theLord's Supper.
A leader of the rabble; one who attempts to control themultitude by specious or deceitful arts; an unprincipled and factiousmob orator or political leader.
The person to whom a note or bill is indorsed, or assigned byindorsement.
A genus of singing birds including the true thrushes.
One who nurses; a nurse; one who cherishes or encouragesgrowth.
Ornamentation by means of lacquer painted or carved, or simplycolored, sprinkled with gold or the like; -- said especially ofOriental work of this kind.
A small, African, foxlike animal (Vulpes zerda) of a pale fawncolor, remarkable for the large size of its ears.

An instrument for indicating changes of temperature withoutindicating the degree of heat by which it is affected; especially, aninstrument contrived by Count Rumford which, as modified by ProfessorLeslie, was afterward called the differential thermometer.
A kind of palsy affecting the jaw of a horse. Crabb.
Swarming and devastating like locusts. [R.] Tennyson.
To overwhelm with water; to drench; to drown. [Obs.] Shak.
The act or process of carding coarsely. Scribbing machine, themachine used for the first carding of wool or other fiber; -- calledalso scribbler.
Pertaining to, or designating, a tannic acid found in oak barkand extracted as a yellowish brown amorphous substance.
This previously known, or which should be known in order tounderstand something else.
A personification, in German and Scandinavian mythology, of aspirit natural power supposed to work mischief and ruin, esp. tochildren.
In accordance or agreement; agreeably; conformably; -- followedby with or to.
A chinese reed instrument, with tubes, blown by the mouth.
A blossoming anew of a plant after it has apparently ceasedblossoming for the season.
A kind of masonry in which the outer faces of the wall areashlar, the space between being filled with broken stone and mortar.Cross layers of stone are interlaid as binders. [R.] Weale.
Olefiant gas, or ethylene; hence, by extension, any one of theseries of unsaturated hydrocarbons of which ethylene is a type. SeeEthylene.
One who is versed in ethics, or has written on ethics.
A division of Artiodactyla having four stomachs. This divisionincludes the camels, deer, antelopes, goats, sheep, neat cattle, andallies.
A metameric segment of the cerebro-spinal nervous system.
Having the quality of cementing; tenacious; viscous; glutinous.
A beverage of molasses and water, seasoned with vinegar andginger. [U. S.]
Rising to a point or head; conical; pointed; crested. Wiseman.
A swivel at one end of a ropewalk, used in laying the strands.
A wastebook, in which entries of transactions are made as theytake place.

The second month in the year, said to have been introduced intothe Roman calendar by Numa. In common years this month containstwenty-eight days; in the bissextile, or leap year, it has twenty-nine days.
A radical, of the aromatic series, regarded as an essentialingredient of certain compounds found in the waxy resin of anAustralian species of fig.
In a telescopical manner; by or with the telescope.
A tailor's assistant for repairing garments; -- called alsobusheler. [Local, U.S.]
In a manner conformable to allopathy; by allopathic methods.
To concert or arrange beforehand; to settle by previousagreement.
Eatable growth of grass for horses and cattle, esp. that ofaftermath.
Carried; conveyed; supported; defrayed. See Bear, v. t.
The state or quality of being irredeemable; irredeemableness.
The edible nut of a forest tree (Castanea vesce) of Europe andAmerica. Commonly two or more of the nuts grow in a prickly bur.
A soft, effeminate person; a voluptuary. [R.] Bp. Woolton. .
The expectoration of blood, due usually to hemorrhage from themucous membrane of the lungs.
The union of the second person of the Godhead with manhood inChrist.
From head to foot; at all points. "He was armed cap-a-pie."Prescott.
A small piece of inclosed ground. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
In a perfunctory manner; formally; carelessly. Boyle.
The quality or state of being impregnable; invincibility.
Flowering, or state of flowering; the blooming of flowers;blowth.
A tendency in the end of a magnetic needle to point to thenorth. Faraday.
Causing the ejection of matter from the stomach; emetic.
By consequence; by natural or logical sequence or connection.
A body of troops, whether cavalry, artillery, infantry, ormixed, consisting of two or more regiments, under the command of abrigadier general.
A wheel with cogs or teeth; a gear wheel. See Illust. ofGearing.
The office and dignity of president; presidency. Hooker.
A tribe of spiders including those which lie in wait and leapupon their prey; the leaping spiders.
To become loose; to become less tight, firm, or compact. S.Sharp.
Having the form of tussocks; full of, or covered with,tussocks, or tufts.
A stone composed of sand or grit; -- so called because it iseasily cut or wrought.

A chronic nervous affection of cattle, horses, and sheep,caused by eating the loco weed and characterized by a slow, measuredgait, high step, glassy eyes with defective vision, delirium, andgradual emaciation.
A Spanish dance, or the lively music which accompanies it.
The equivalent of an additional circuit or wire, in reality notexisting, obtained by certain arrangements of real circuits, as insome multiplex telegraph systems.
That class of Mollusca which includes the bivalve shells; theLamellibranchiata. See Mollusca.
Obsequiously complying with the spirit of the times, or thehumors of those in power.

A form of sentence among the ancient Syracusans by which theybanished for five years a citizen suspected of having dangerousinfluence or ambition. It was similar to the ostracism in Athens; butolive leaves were used instead of shells for ballots.
Having a feminine countenance or complexion; smooth-faced;girlish. Fenton.
A poisonous alkaloid resembling veratrine, and found with it inwhite hellebore (Veratrum album); -- called also jervina.
A genus of small rubiaceous herbs, having tetramerous salveformblue or white flower. There are about twenty species, natives ofNorth America. Also, a plant of this genus.
A surety, under the old writ of mainprise, for a prisoner'sappearance in court at a day.
A one-horse carriage with two seats and a calash top.
The period of natural cessation of menstruation. See Change oflife, under Change.
Of or pertaining to accent; characterized or formed by accent.
The state of a part which, from having been soft, has becomehard and swollen by the accumulation of blood in the erectile tissue.
A lighthouse, or the apparatus placed in it for giving light.
A tool employed by blacksmiths for punching or enlarging thenail holes in a horseshoe.

Pertaining to, derived from, or consisting of, fluorine andboron. Fluoridic acid (Chem.), a double fluoride, consistingessentially of a solution of boron fluoride, in hydrofluoric acid. Ithas strong acid properties, and is the type of the borofluorides.Called also borofluoric acid.

A contradiction or incompatibility of thought or language; --in the Kantian philosophy, such a contradiction as arises from theattempt to apply to the ideas of the reason, relations or attributeswhich are appropriate only to the facts or the concepts ofexperience.
An acid elevator, as a tube through which acid is forced tosome height in a sulphuric acid manufactory.
A grove of shrubs or low trees under taller ones. Wordsworth.
One who believes in a temporary future punishment and a finalrestoration of all to the favor and presence of God; a Universalist.
A strip of tender flesh on either side of the vertebral columnunder the short ribs, in the hind quarter of beef and pork. Itconsists of the psoas muscles.
A woman's light scarflike head covering, usually knit orcrocheted of wool.
To convey by means of a vehicle; to ride in a vehicle. Carlyle.
The state of being uncurable; irremediableness. Harvey.

A slackening or arrest of the blood current in the vessels, duenot to a lessening of the heart's beat, but presumably to someabnormal resistance of the capillary walls. It is one of thephenomena observed in the capillaries in inflammation.

One who dances at the opera, not singly, but in groups orfigures; an accessory character on the stage, who figures in itsscenes, but has nothing to say; hence, one who figures in any scene,without taking a prominent part.
In a saucy manner; impudently; with impertinent boldness.Addison.

An inversion of the order of words or phrases, when repeated orsubsequently referred to in a sentence; thus,If e'er to bless thy sons My voice or hands deny, These hands letuseful skill forsake, This voice in silence die. Dwight.
The art or practice of defining words; definition of words.
A female slave, or one bound to service without wages, asdistinguished from a hired servant.
One who enacts a law; one who decrees or establishes as a law.Atterbury.
The doctrine and ceremonies of the Church of Rome; popery. [R.]Whitgift.
The practice or faculty of subsisting on many kinds of food.
A species of capsicum (Capsicum baccatum), whose small,conical, coral-red fruit is among the most piquant of all redpeppers.
Like a carrot in color or in taste; -- an epithet given toreddish yellow hair, etc.
A steward or butler of a monastery or chapter; one who hascharge of procuring and keeping the provisions.
A book or other thing that a person carries with him as aconstant companion; a manual; a handbook.
A shrike or butcher bird; -- written also matagasse. [Prov.Eng.]
Any one of three metameric radicals which are characteristicrespectively of the three xylenes.
A hive for a swarm of bees. Also used figuratively.
In a whisper, or low voice; in a whispering manner; withwhispers. Tennyson.
Not conditioned; not limited; absolute. [Obs.] Boyle.
The science which relates to mammals or the Mammalia. SeeMammalia.
A dry, scaly eruption on the skin; especially, a ringworm.
The quality or state of being simultaneous; simultaneousness.
An alkaloid extracted from the root of the pellitory of Spain(Anacyclus pyrethrum).
The system and influences of a monastic life; monasticism.
One who makes it his business to marry beggars to each other.Swift.
Want of nutrition; failure of nourishment. E. Darwin.
So as to have motion or direction parallel to the equator.
The concurrence of two vowels in two successive words orsyllables. Pope.
. An ideal personification of the typical Russian or of theRussian people; -- used as "John Bull" is used for the typicalEnglishman.
At, or by reason of, this; as, he was offended hereat. Hooker.
The hollow beneath the junction of the arm and shoulder; theaxilla.
Pertaining to liberty, or to the doctrine of free will, asopposed to the doctrine of necessity.
The layer of vascular connective tissue lining the medullarycavities of bone.
A weapon resembling a hammer, often having one side of the headpointed; -- used by horsemen in the Middle Ages to break armor.Fairholt.
Painting in shades of one color; monochrome. Mollett.
Having, or existing in, many different forms or fashions;multiform.
A woman's skirt so scant at the bottom as to restrain freedomof movement after the fashion of a hobble. -- Hob"ble-skirt`ed, a.
The dysentery, a disease in which the flux or discharge fromthe bowels has a mixture of blood. Arbuthnot.
Large; strong; -- from the gigantic bones shown atRoncesvalles, and alleged to be those of old heroes. [Obs.]
Imperfectly digested, matured, or ripened. [Obs.] Bacon.
A North American rodent, so named because it is said to make abooming noise. See Sewellel.
A well known public school and charitable foundation in thebuilding once used as a Carthusian monastery (Chartreuse) in London.
A chicken; -- used as a diminutive or pet name, especially incalling fowls.
A kind of custard apple (Anona squamosa). See under Custard.
The faculty of perceiving; a percipient. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
A muscle of the cheek; -- so called from its use in blowingwind instruments.
The act of deifying; exaltation to divine honors; apotheosis;excessive praise.
The least quantity assignable, admissible, or possible, in agiven case; hence, a thing of small consequence; -- opposed to Ant:maximum.
A substance composed of ground bone, mineral matters, etc.,hardened by pressure, and used for making billiard balls, boxes, etc.
Capable of being inspired or drawn into the lungs; inhalable;respirable; admitting inspiration. Harvey.
The act of magnetizing, or the state of being magnetized.
One of the bones of either the metacarpus or metatarsus.
The bittersweet nightshade (Solanum Dulcamara). SeeBittersweet.
To reply, as a plaintiff to a defendant's rejoinder.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, any one of three isomericcrystalline acids, C9H10ON.CO2H, which are toluyl derivatives ofglycocoll.
To render urban, or urbane; to refine; to polish. Howell.
A surety; one who is bound, or who gives security, for another.
A projection on the inner side of the distal end of thenumerus; the internal condyle.
The part of a harness which passes over the saddle, andsupports the shafts of a cart; -- called also ridgerope, and ridger.Halliwell.

That branch of science, or of engineering, which treats offluids in motion, especially of water, its action in rivers andcanals, the works and machinery for conducting or raising it, its useas a prime mover, and the like.
The period of a synodic revolution of the moon, or the timefrom one new moon to the next; varying in length, at different times,from about 29
Relating to, or affected with, hiccough. Dunglison.
One who describes the fauna of country; a naturalist. GilbertWhite.
Attention; consideration; knowledge; understanding. [Obs.]Spenser.
That part of the headstall of a bridle which passes over ahorse's nose.
A mineral found usually in thin, wedge-shaped crystals of ayellow or green to black color. It is a silicate of titanium andcalcium; titanite.
A genus of fossil ganoid fishes found in the old red sandstoneor Devonian formation. The head is large, and protected by a broadshield-shaped helmet prolonged behind into two lateral points.
One who holds or occupies a place; one who has office undergovernment. Sir W. Scott.
To make froward, perverse, or ungovernable. [Obs.] Sir E.Sandys.
Migration back to the place from which one came. Sir M. Hale.
One of numerous species of birds that feed upon insects, whichthey take on the wing.
To delay; to hinder; to neglect; to put off. [Obs.] Bacon.
Sized by a machine, and not while in the pulp; -- said ofpaper. Knight.
A sentry who guards the entrance or approach to a place; anoutguard.
A disciple of Hermogenes, and heretical teacher who lived inAfrica near the close of the second century. He ha
The Mohammedan tribes of the southern Philippine Islands, saidto have formerly migrated from Borneo. Some of them are warlike andaddicted to piracy.
An invariable quantity; specifically, a function of thecoefficients of one or more forms, which remains unaltered, whenthese undergo suitable linear transformations. J. J. Sylvester.
The girdle of a cassock, by which it is fastened round thewaist.
A tubular structure found in Potsdam sandstone, and believed tobe the fossil burrow of a marine worm.
The name firat given in England to the red wines of M
To make lethargic.All bitters are poison, and act by stilling, and depressing, andlethargizing the irritability. Coleridge.
Of or pertaining to latitude; in the direction of latitude.
A word, verse, or sentence, that is the same when read backwardor forward; as, madam; Hannah; or Lewd did I live, & evil I did dwel.
To set forth as a model or example. [Obs.] Hammond.
A tall, coarse grass (Imperata arundinacea) of the PhilippineIslands and adjacent countries, used for thatching.
The American woodcock; -- so called from its feeding among thebogs.
The state of being a laird; an estate; landed property. [Scot.]Ramsay.

The doctrine of Quesne, that there is a fluid universallydiffused, end equally animating all living beings, the difference intheir actions being due to the difference of the individualorganizations. Fleming.

A very singular missile weapon used by the natives of Australiaand in some parts of India. It is usually a curved stick of hardwood, from twenty to thirty inches in length, from two to threeinches wide, and half or three quarters of an inch thick. When thrownfrom the hand with a quick rotary motion, it describes veryremarkable curves, according to the shape of the instrument and themanner of throwing it, often moving nearly horizontally a longdistance, then curving upward to a considerable height, and finallytaking a retrograde direction, so as to fall near the place fromwhich it was thrown, or even far in the rear of it.
Situated beneath, or on the ventral side of, the vertebralcolumn; situated beneath, or inside of, the endoskeleton; hypaxial;hyposkeletal.
The Gorgon; or one of the Gorgons whose hair was changed intoserpents, after which all who looked upon her were turned into stone.
A design or draught which has been divided into squares, inorder to reproduce it in other dimensions.
The quality or state of being viewy, or of having unpracticalviews.
An order of fishes in which the air bladder is provided with aduct, and the ventral fins, when present, are abdominal. It includesthe salmons, herrings, carps, catfishes, and others.
A chiton, or loose, ungirded tunic, falling in straight folds.
The tree (Dipteryx odorata) which bears the tonka bean; also,the bean itself.
An instrument for measuring the muscular strength of man or ofother animals; a dynamometer. Dunglison.
A beating or flogging; a whipping; a scourging. Garth.
A book in which is kept a register of money received or paidout.
A division of Pulmonata in which the eyes are situated at thetips of the tentacles. It includes the common land snails and slugs.See Illust. under Snail.

A substance found in great abundance on some coasts or islandsfrequented by sea fowls, and composed chiefly of their excrement. Itis rich in phosphates and ammonia, and is used as a powerfulfertilizer.

One of the mineral concretions about the joints, and in othersituations, occurring chiefly in gouty persons. They consist usuallyof urate of sodium; when occurring in the internal organs they arealso composed of phosphate of calcium.
A small rent paid to the lord paramount. [Obs.] Swift.
A tea cake slighty sweetened, and raised with yeast, baked inthe form of biscuits or in a thin loaf, and eaten hot with butter.
Of or pertaining to the first canon, or that which contains theauthorized collection of the books of Scripture; -- opposed todeutero-canonical.
A type or block containing a facsimile of an autograph. Knight.

A citrous fruit produced by a cross between the sweet orangeand the trifoliate orange (Citrus trifoliata). It is more acid andhas a more pronounced aroma than the orange; the tree is hardier.There are several varieties.
A yellow urinary pigment, considered by Thudichum as the onlypigment present in normal urine. It is regarded by Maly as identicalwith urobilin.

A white, semisolid, spermaceti-like hydrocarbon, C16H34, of theparaffin series, found dissolved as an important ingredient ofkerosene, and so called because each molecule has sixteen atoms ofcarbon; -- called also hexadecane.
Pertaining to the variation of tensile strength with thetemperature.
To make fine; to dress finically. [Obs.]Hath so pared and finified them [his feet.] B. Jonson.
To oppress by bulk; to overtower. [Obs. & R.] Shak.
An order of marine sponges, containing calcareous spicules. SeePorifera.
One of certain Bohemian reformers who suffered persecution inthe fifteenth century; -- so called from Tabor, a hill or fortresswhere they encamped during a part of their struggles.
The state or quality of being spinescent or spiny; also, aspiny growth or covering, as of certain animals.
One of the classes of Protozoa, including a large number ofspecies, all of minute size.
Of or pertaining to nard; having the qualities of nard.
The cutting a fetus into pieces within the womb, so as toeffect its removal.
To do injury to; to hurt. [Archaic]Other might be determined thereby. Fuller.
To deprive of sinfulness, as a sin; to make sinless. [Obs.]Feltham.
Want of exertion; want of effort; defect of action; indolence;laziness.
Being in unison; having the same degree of gravity oracuteness; sounded alike in pitch.
Smoky; hence, fond of smoking; addicted to smoking tobacco.

An apparattus for showing the position of the earth, at anygiven time, with respect to the fixed stars. It consist of a hollowglass globe, on which are depicted the stars and constellations, andwithin which is a terrestrial globe.
A building in which sugar is made or refined; a sugarmanufactory.
A red crystallizable tasteless substance, extracted from thecarrot.
The act of suffocating, or the state of being suffocated; deathcaused by smothering or choking.
A picture printed from two half-tone plates made with thescreen set at different angles, and usually printed in two shades ofthe same color or in black and one tint.

An organic base belonging to the phenylamines. It may beregarded as ammonia in which one hydrogen atom has been replaced bythe radical phenyl. It is a colorless, oily liquid, originallyobtained from indigo by distillation, but now largely manufacturedfrom coal tar or nitrobenzene as a base from which many brilliantdyes are made.
A genus of deciduous forest trees, found in the north temperatezone, and including the true ash trees.
A solid preparation obtained by evaporating a solution of adrug, etc., or the fresh juice of a plant; -- distinguished from anabstract. See Abstract, n., 4.
One of the small notes occur on the unaccented parts of themeasure, taking their time from the preceding note.
Half logical; partly logical; said of fallacies. Whately.
A plasterer's float, having two handles; -- used in smoothingceilings, etc.
The act of adverting to again, or of reviewing. [R.] Norris.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, an extinct genus of sharks(Hybodus), especially in the form of the teeth, which consist of aprincipal median cone with smaller lateral ones.
The part of the carapace of a crustacean situated behind thecervical groove.
A baker; originally, a female baker. [Old Eng. & Scotch]
To ascend in vapors; to take the form of a meteor. Evelyn.
The shearing of a pile of books which are as yet uncovered, orout of boards. Knight.
The water cure; a mode of treating diseases by the copious andfrequent use of pure water, both internally and externally.
A form of articulation in which the bones are connected byintervening substance admitting slight motion; symphysis.
A horizontal working forming one of a series, the working facesof which present the appearance of a flight of steps.
To utter in a shrill tone; to scream. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
Furnished with a virole or viroles; -- said of a horn or abugle when the rings are of different tincture from the rest of thehorn.
A tool used by coopers for smoothing and chamfering rheir work,especially the inside of casks.
One of the curved lines () which inclose a parenthetic word orphrase.
The characteristic conduct or methods of a Bohemian. [Modern]
Of or pert. to, or characterized by, mania, or excitement.
Simulated, or capable of being simulated. Bp. Hall.

The right possessed by an heir or legatee of transmitting tohis successor or successors any inheritance, legacy, right, orprivilege, to which he is entitled, even if he should die withoutenjoying or exercising it.
Weak, poor, or flat liquor; weak, profitless discourse orwriting.
A comprehensive group equivalent to the true Coelenterata,i.e., exclusive of the sponges. They are so named from presence ofstinging cells (cnidae) in the tissues. See Coelenterata.
A town officer who makes proclamations to the people; thepublic crier of a town.
A division of insects nearly equivalent to the true Orthoptera.

The part of the alimentary canal between the cavity of themouth and the esophagus. It has one or two external openings throughthe nose in the higher vertebrates, and lateral branchial openings infishes and some amphibias.
A yellow crystalline substance found in the root of yellow dock(Rumex crispus) and identical with chrysophanic acid.
A minute abrupt point, as of a leaf; any small, sharp point orprocess, terminating a larger part or organ.
One who, or that which, detects or brings to light; one whofinds out what another attempts to conceal; a detector.

A mystical word or collocation of letters written as in thefigure. Worn on an amulet it was supposed to ward off fever. Atpresent the word is used chiefly in jest to denote something withoutmeaning; jargon.
That by which a lever is sustained, or about which it turns inlifting or moving a body.
The quality or state of being luminous; luminousness.
The name for numerous simple, but very irregular, melodies ofthe Swiss mountaineers, blown on a long tube called the Alpine horn,and sometimes sung.
A keeper or a frequenter of a brothel. [Obs.] Gower.
A species of wild goat (Capra Nubiana) found in the mountainsof Abyssinia, Upper Egypt, and Arabia; -- called also beden, andjaela.
A stone that is placed on the top, or which forms the top.
A vicious habit of a horse, consisting in the swallowing ofair; -- usually associated with crib-biting, or cribbing. SeeCribbing, 4.
Futility; trifling talk or behavior; drollery. [R.] Dr. H.More.
Rare or subtile; tenuous; -- opposed to dense. [Obs.] Glanvill.
The doctrine or the practices of the Essenes. De Quincey.
Overlaid with quicksilver, or with an amalgam of quicksilverand tinfoil.
The act of making antiquated, or the state of being antiquated.Beaumont.
One who treats of the origin of the universe; one versed incosmogony.
Lack of sympathy; want of interest; indifference. [R.]
In a civil manner; as regards civil rights and privileges;politely; courteously; in a well bred manner.
The operation of making an opening into the windpipe.
A large, globular glass bottle, esp. one of green glass,inclosed in basket work or in a box, for protection; -- used commonlyfor carrying corrosive liquids; as sulphuric acid, etc.
Of or pertaining to Vesuvius, a volcano near Naples.
The act of enticing by soft words; enticement. [Obs.]
A latent, not an exhausted, state of the vital energies; greatoppression of natural strength and vigor.
That portion of the axis which bears the nectocalyces in theSiphonophora.
A division of Hydroidea including the hydra. See Hydra.
The quality of being nimble; lightness and quickness in motion;agility; swiftness.
The act of pulling the wires, as of a puppet; hence, secretinfluence or management, especially in politics; intrigue.
A stick or small wooden cylinder used for tightening a bandage,in order to compress the arteries of a limb.
An instrument for measuring the intensity of magnetic forces;also, less frequently, an instrument for determining any of theterrestrial magnetic elements, as the dip and declination.
A bright-colored European actinian (Anemonia, or Anthea,sulcata); -- so called because it does not retract its tentacles.
An instrument for intensifying sounds produced by percussion ofthe thorax. Knight.
The crest or line in which strata slope or dip in oppositedirections.
Risk of injury, destruction, or loss by the sea, or while atsea.
A book in which a tradesman keeps his accounts. Locke.
The name of several caryophyllaseous weeds, especiallyStellaria media, the seeds and flower buds of which are a favoritefood of small birds.
Having the nature or habit of a rhizome or rootstock.
To render immethodical; to destroy the method of; to confuse.[R.]
Double-bodied, as a lion having one head and two bodies.
A tool of which the hemp for lines and twines, used bysailmakers, is finished.
The physical phenomena of organized bodies, in opposition totheir organic or vital phenomena.
Under the board, or table; hence, secretly; unfairly;underhand. See the Note under Aboveboard.
Leave of abserice; especially, leave given to an offcer orsoldier to be absent from service for a certain time; also, thedocument granting leave of absence.
Attractive power; attractiveness. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Inflammation of the pia mater or of the arachnoid membrane.

Any one of three isometric bases (C6H7N) related to pyridine,and obtained from bone oil, acrolein ammonia, and coal-tar naphtha,as colorless mobile liquids of strong odor; -- called also methylpyridine.
Barreled salt beef, packed with about 80 pounds chuck and rump,two flanks, and the rest plates.
Left-handed on both sides; clumsy; -- opposed to ambidexter.[R.] Sir T. Browne.
The development of tubercles; the condition of one who isaffected with tubercles.
To sing the notes of the gamut, ascending or descending; as, door ut, re, mi, fa, sol, la, si, do, or the same in reverse order.Yet can I neither solfe ne sing. Piers Plowman.
A kind of coarse punch with a rasplike face, used for making arough surface on etching ground, or on the naked copper, the effectafter biting being very similar to stippled lines.
To stare or stand upward; hence, to be uplifted or conspicuous."Rearing fiercely their upstaring crests." Spenser.
To impregnate or combine with an excess of sulphur.
One from whom a race, tribe, city, or the like, took its name;an eponym.
That branch of physical science which treats of the nature andproperties of light, the laws of its modification by opaque andtransparent bodies, and the phenomena of vision.
A kind of candy or sweetneat made up in small balls or disks.
To ramble over in order to clear; to scour. [Archaic] Shak.
An upright piece of round timber, in a whaleboat, over which aturn of the line is taken when it is running out too fast. Ham. Nav.Encyc.
A nearly opaque white mineral, in part identical with titanite,observed in some igneous rocks as the result of the alteration oftitanic iron.
Of or pertaining to cork; of the nature of cork; suberose.
The quality or state of being wild; an uncultivated or untamedstate; disposition to rove or go unrestrained; rudeness; savageness;irregularity; distraction.
One half of a shutter made in two parts for closing a porthole.
A division of amphibians having suctorial disks on the toes, asthe tree frogs.
An instrument for measuring and recording the variations in theactinic or chemical force of rays of light. Nichol.
Pertaining to cryptography; cryptographical. Boyle.
To trail along; to saunter or be drawn along, carelessly,swaying in a kind of zigzag motion. [Colloq.] Thackeray.
Any one of numerous species of aquatic salamanders; a triton.
Wherever; -- a contracted and poetical form. Cowper.
White with heat; heated to whiteness, or incandescence.
To dye with excess of color; to put one color over (another).Shak.
An electric telegraph which prints the messages in letters andnot in signs.

Induction in a circuit due to the action of one portion of acurrent upon an adjacent portion during periods of varying currentstrength. The nature of the induction is such as to oppose the actionwhich produces it.
Of, pertaining to, or like, the Mussulmans, or their customs:Mohammedan.
The last stone in a horizontal course, if of a less size thanthe others, or a piece of brick finishing a course. Gwilt.
Giving light; affording light or means of discovery. Boyle.
The Numidian crane (Antropoides virgo); -- so called on accountof the grace and symmetry of its form and movements.
One of the pads on the under surface of the toes of birds.
To crow, exult, or boast, over; to overpower. Spenser. Shak.
Opposed to or against nature; unnatural. [R.] Bp. Rust.
An anglo-Saxon copper coin of the lowest value, being worthhalf a farthing. S. M. Leake.
A piece of armor formerly worn to guard the things; a tasse.
Mortification or gangrene of bone, or the death of a bone orportion of a bone in mass, as opposed to its death by moleculardisintegration. See Caries.
A slender tactile organ on the lips of certain fished.
A glucoside occurring in jalap (the root of a convolvulaceousplant), and extracted as a colorless, tasteless, gummy mass ofpowerful purgative properties.
The middle part of the main or sea. [Poetic] Chapman.
Of or pertaining to Thessalonica, a city of Macedonia.-- n.
A variety of orthoclase feldspar common in certain eruptiverocks, as trachyte; -- called also glassy feldspar.
An algebraic curve, so called from its resemblance to a heart.
A word which has the acute accent on the antepenult.
With conformity or in conformity; suitably; agreeably.
To transport with delight; to enrapture; to fascinate. Spenser.
Deputies from the confederated states of ancient Greece to acongress or council. They considered both political and religiousmatters.
A prop or support; a piece of timber in the form of a stake orpost, used for a support or stay.
A light, open, two-wheeled carriage for one horse; a kind ofgig. ("The term and vehicle common about 1825." Latham.)

The theory, advanced by Thomson (Lord Kelvin) on the basis ofinvestigation by Helmholtz, that the atoms are vortically movingring-shaped masses (or masses of other forms having a similarinternal motion) of a homogeneous, incompressible, frictionlessfluid. Various properties of such atoms (vortex atoms) can bemathematically deduced.
Furnished with hoofs. See the Note under Nail, n., 1.
In an ingenuous manner; openly; fairly; candidly; artlessly.Being required to explane himself, he ingeniously confessed. Ludlow.
To utter the ordinary call or cry of a horse; to neigh.

Freehold estate; land which is the absolute property of theowner; real estate held in absolute independence, without beingsubject to any rent, service, or acknowledgment to a superior. It isthus opposed to feud. Blackstone. Bouvier.
A trivial mechanism; a device; a toy; a pretty thing.Arbuthnot.
A form of melody in which a phrase or passage is successivelyrepeated, each time a step or half step higher; a melodic sequence.
A clergyman of a superior order, as an archbishop or a bishop,having authority over the lower clergy; a dignitary of the church.
A contrivance for removing the pits from peaches, plums, andother stone fruit.
Festival games celebrated once in three years. [R.] May.
One versed in orthography; one who spells words correctly.
A small opening; esp., one of the apertures, closed bymembranes, between the tympanum and internal ear.
An order of mammalia, including the bats, having four toes ofeach of the anterior limbs elongated and connected by a web, so thatthey can be used like wings in flying. See Bat.
Acting from mercenary considerations; stipendiary. A. Seward.
One who denies the existence of the universe, or of a universeas distinct from God. G. H. Lewes.
A slight sound such as that made by pressing the tongue againstthe roof of the mouth and explosively sucking out the air at oneside, as in urging on a horse. -- v. i.
The fibrin ferment which produces the formation of fibrin fromfibrinogen.

An inflammation of the fingers or toes, generally of the lastphalanx, terminating usually in suppuration. The inflammation mayoccupy any seat between the skin and the bone, but is usually appliedto a felon or inflammation of the periosteal structures of the bone.
A hard, highly polishable composition, made of fine sawdustfrom hard wood (as rosewood) mixed with blood, and pressed.
A small hydrometer for determining the specific gravity ofurine.
The art or process of ascertaining the strength of alkalies, orthe quantity present in alkaline mixtures.
The quality of being formed by the aid of the teeth.
A constellation of the southern hemisphere, near the southpole.

A tube, as of cane or reed, sometimes twelve feet long, throughwhich an arrow or other projectile may be impelled by the force ofthe breath. It is a weapon much used by certain Indians of Americaand the West Indies; -- called also blowpipe, and blowtube. SeeSumpitan.
One of forty equal parts into which one whole is divided; thequotient of a unit divided by forty; one next in order after thethirty-ninth.
Of or pertaining to Temple, a valley in Thessaly, celebrated byGreek poets on account of its beautiful scenery; resembling Temple;hence, beautiful; delightful; charming.
The central column in the osseous cochlea of the ear.
A genus of aquatic plants having showy flowers (white, blue,pink, or yellow, often fragrant), including the white water lily andthe Egyptia lotus.
In the Anglo-Indian army, a native commander of a ressala.

That phase of the doctrine of utilitarianism taught by JeremyBentham; the doctrine that the morality of actions is estimated anddetermined by their utility; also, the theory that the sensibility topleasure and the recoil from pain are the only motives whichinfluence human desires and actions, and that these are thesufficient explanation of ethical and jural conceptions.
The science of the useful arts, esp. agriculture, manufactures,and commerce. [R.]
The return of the judge before whom a cause was tried, after averdict, of what was done in the cause, which is indorsed on the nisiprius record. Wharton.
A yellow crystalline substance of acid properties extractedfrom fustic (Maclura tinctoria, formerly called Morus tinctoria); --called also moric acid.
The quality, state, or degree of being replaceable.
A genus of shrubby plants bearing opposite leaves and largeheads of showy flowers, white, or of various colors. H. hortensis,the common garden species, is a native of China or Japan.
A small pan with a handle, in which sauce is prepared over afire; a stewpan.
Domestic fowls reared for the table, or for their eggs orfeathers, such as cocks and hens, capons, turkeys, ducks, and geese.
The act of dismasting; the state of being dismasted. [R.]Marshall.
The science of midwifery; the art of assisting women inparturition, or in the trouble incident to childbirth.
A verse which has a redundant syllable or foot; ahypercatalectic verse.
Having the mandibles large and palmate, or branched somewhatlike the antlers of a stag; -- said of certain beetles.
A woman who feeds and cherishes; a nurse. B. Jonson.
A species of joinery or cabinet-work consisting of an inlay ofgeometric or other patterns, generally of different colors, -- usedespecially for floors.
A cured olive which has spoiled or is on the verge ofdecomposition; loosely, an olive defective because of bruises,wormholes, or the like.
To incline from the vertical; to hade; -- said of a vein,fault, or lode.
The quality or state of being perceptive; power of perception.Locke.
Room or space at sea for a vessel to maneuver, drive, or scud,without peril of running ashore or aground. Totten.
A toll or duty paid for weighing wool; also, the act ofweighing wool. [Obs.] Nares.
The quality of being canonical; canonicity. Bp. Burnet.
A plant of several species of the genus Chrysocoma; -- socalled from the tufts of yellow flowers which terminate the stems;also, the Ranunculus auricomus, a kind of buttercup.
A member of the trecento, or an imitator of itscharacteristics.
In a conscientious manner; as a matter of conscience; hence;faithfully; accurately; completely.
Uniting the chemical rays of light into one focus, as a certainkind of lens; amacratic.
An extra first toe, or rudiment of a toe, on the preaxial sideof the hallux.
A genus of poisonous African serpents, with a horny scale overeach eye; the horned viper.
A subdivision of Cetacea, including the sperm whale, dolphins,etc.; the toothed whales.
Any apparatus for making distant objects visible by the aid ofelectric transmission.
The terminal part of the cochlea in birds and most reptiles; anappendage of the sacculus, corresponding to the cochlea, in fishesand amphibians.
An apple-green mineral occurring in reniform masses. It is ahydrous phosphate of alumina.
A large and commodious, but generally cumbrous and sluggishboat, used for journeys on the Ganges.
A combination of a cube and octahedron, esp. one in which theoctahedral faces meet at the middle of the cubic edges.
Slackening; -- a direction to perform a passage with a gradualdecrease in time and force; ritardando.
To have or experience a back fire or back fires; -- said of aninternal-combustion engine.
Regard for others, both natural and moral; devotion to theinterests of others; brotherly kindness; -- opposed to egoism orselfishness. [Recent] J. S. Mill.
Having to do with inlaid work; -- especially used withreference to work of the ancient Greeks.
A fight in which centaurs take part, -- a common theme forrelief sculpture, as in the Parthenon metopes.
A rattling sound in the throat arising from difficulty ofbreathing; a rattle. [Obs.]
The Dutch equivalent of Mr. or Sir; hence, a Dutchman.
A small instrument of ivory, wood, metal, or quill, used inplaying upon the lyre and other stringed instruments.
The quality of being negotiable or transferable by indorsement.
A species of Cardamine (C. pratensis), or lady's smock. Itsleaves are used in salads. Also, the ragged robin (Lychnis Flos-cuculi).
A plant of the genus Mitella; miterwort. Longfellow.
The forked bone of a fowl's breast; -- called also wishbone.See Furculum.
A print made from two half-tone plates made from the samenegative, but etched differently.
The sacred writings of the ancient Persian religion, attributedto Zoroaster, but chiefly of a later date.
A species of large tupelo (Nyssa aquatica) growing in swamps inthe southern of the United States. See Ogeechee lime.
The state and government of the pope; the papacy. [R.] Bacon.
A shell of the genus Crepidula; a boat shell. See Boat shell.
A small plaque, esp., in modern medal engraving, a small anddelicate bas-relief, whether cast or struck from a die, or of formother than circular.
Below; beneath; under; after; -- often used as a prefix.
Pertaining to, or desingating, an acid (called also valericacid) derived from pentane.
That branch of systemized knowledge which treats of theChinese, their language, literature, etc.
A dog accustomed to the water, or trained to retrievewaterfowl. Retrievers, waters spaniels, and Newfoundland dogs are sotrained.
Wrinkled; crumpled; furrowed; contracted into ridges andfurrows.
The coarse-grained brownish yellow wood of a small tree(Pisonia obtusata) of Florida and the West Indies. Also called pigeonwood, beefwood, and corkwood.
A judicial process commanding a person to appear in court andbring with him some piece of evidence or other thing to be producedto the court.
Moving in the air with, or as with, wings; moving lightly orrapidly; intended for rapid movement.
One who serves on board of the same ship with another; a fellowsailor.
Producing myosis, or contraction of the pupil of the eye, asopium, calabar bean, etc.-- n.
The state of being demure; gravity; the show of gravity ormodesty.
The disposition and tendency to preserve what is established;opposition to change; the habit of mind; or conduct, of aconservative.
To emasculate; to dispossess of manhood. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Of or pertaining to the language or people of the of Man.-- n.
Profound sleep from which a person can be roused only withdifficulty.
One of the great division of fungi, containing those specieswhich have naked spores borne on free or only fasciculate threads. M.J. Berkley.
A fortified place; a large and permanent fortification,sometimes including a town; a fort; a castle; a stronghold; a placeof defense or security.

The liver of the common cod and allied species. Cod-liver oil,an oil obtained fron the liver of the codfish, and used extensivelyin medicine as a means of supplying the body with fat in cases ofmalnutrition.
A disease of the skin, in which it become enormously thickened,and is rough, hard, and fissured, like an elephant's hide.
The state or quality of being libidinous; libidinousness.Skelton.
Existence without a body or material form; immateriality.Cudworth.
A kind of scepter or spear with three prongs, -- the commonattribute of Neptune.
A flowing or entering in; -- opposed to emanation. [R.] Good.
Curling or tending to curl; having curls; full of ripples;crinkled.
The act of casting off the skin or shell, as do insects andcrustaceans; ecdysis.
A plant of various species, chiefly cruciferous. The leaveshave a moderately pungent taste, and are used as a salad andantiscorbutic.
The name for a style of short breeches; smallclothes.
A genus of perennial, composite herbs including hemp agrimony,boneset, throughwort, etc.
A covering of canvas or tarpaulin for the hammocks, stowed onthe nettings, between the quarterdeck and the forecastle.
Applied to one of the cases of the noun in Latin and some otherlanguages, -- the fundamental meaning of the case being removal,separation, or taking away.
An East Indian insectivorous mammal of the genus Tupaia.
An instrument for taking altitudes, as a quadrant, sextant,etc. Knight.
One who, or that which, feeds on or destroys wit. [Obs.] B.Jonson.
To bring to the same nature as something else; to adapt. [Obs.]Dr. J. Scott.
A word to be given before a person is allowed to pass; awatchword; a countersign. Macaulay.
A letter or writing, usually under seal, conferring someprivilege, honor, or power; a document bearing record of a degreeconferred by a literary society or educational institution.
The state or condition of a catechumen or the time during whichone is a catechumen.
A muscle which contracts the skin of the forehead intowrinkles.
Represented as enraged, as any wild creature depicted with fireissuing from mouth and eyes.
A charitable gift or contribution; a gift; an alms; a dole; alargess; a sportula. [Obs.] Ayliffe.
An implement for braying and spreading ink in hand printing.
An alkaloid obtained from the yellow jasmine (Gelsemiumsempervirens), as a bitter white semicrystalline substance; -- calledalso gelsemia.
Wrong or bad management; as, he failed through mismagement.
Capable of being, or liable to be, delineated. Feltham.
The illumination produced by a British standard candle at adistance of one foot; --used as a unit of illumination.
Having only one form of pistils; -- said of the flowers of someplants. Darwin.
One of the component segments of the body of an animal.
Soreness of eyes; the state of being blear-eyes; blearedness.
A chain in which the alternate links are broad blocks connectedby thin side links pivoted to the ends of the blocks, used withsprocket wheels to transmit power, as in a bicycle.
One who advocates romanticism in modern literature. J. R.Seeley.
The flag hoisted at the fore by a vessel desiring a pilot, inthe United States the union jack, in Great Britain the British unionjack with a white border.
Relating to the indulgences of the Roman Catholic Church.Brevint.
The jurisdiction or office of an alcalde; also, the building orchamber in which he conducts the business of his office.
A resinoid coloring matter obtained from alkanet root.
A sacrifice, or ceremony, by which cities, fields, armies, orpeople, defiled by crimes, pestilence, or other cause of uncleanness,were purified.
Decorative painting in gray monochrome; -- used in Englishespecially for painted glass.
A young eel; a young conger or sea eel; -- called also elvene.
That which is held of another by service; property which oneholds of a lord or proprietor in consideration of some military orpecuniary service; fief; fee.
A small farm; -- so called as requiring but one yoke of oxen totill it. [Prov. Eng.]
One who follows the dietetic system of Graham. [U. S.]
A crystalline substance said to be found in the root of acertain plant of the Leadwort (Plumbago) family.
To make or take auguries; to augur; to predict. [Obs.] C.Middleton.
To make mad; to drive to madness; to craze; to excite violentlywith passion; to make very angry; to enrage.
A post sunk in the ground to receive the bars closing a passageinto a field.

A fine white claylike mineral, soft, and light enough when indry masses to float in water. It is a hydrous silicate of magnesia,and is obtained chiefly in Asia Minor. It is manufacturd into tobaccopipes, cigar holders, etc. Also called sepiolite.
One of the class of diviners among the Etruscans and Romans,who foretold events by the inspection of the entrails of victimsoffered on the altars of the gods.
Situated immediately in front, or on the ventral side, of thevertebral column; prespinal.
A division of Mollusca remarkable for the bilateral symmetry ofthe organs and the arrangement of the nerves.
Made of cast iron. Hence, Fig.: like cast iron; hardy;unyielding.
The Richardson's skua (Stercorarius parasiticus);- so calledfrom its cry. [Prov. Eng.]
At a small price; at a low value; in a common or inferiormanner.
The operation of removing a cataract by thrusting a needlethrough the cornea of the eye, and breaking up the opaque mass.
In a lowering manner; with cloudiness or threatening gloom.
A provisional name for a plant which has not had its flowersbotanically examined, and therefore has not been referred to itsproper genus.
The rice bunting or bobolink; -- so called in the island ofJamaica.
Given to sensual indulgence; gluttonous. [Obs.] Joye.
A viverrine animal of Madagascar (Cryptoprocta ferox). Itresembles a cat in size and form, and has retractile claws.
A city of the dead; a name given by the ancients to theircemeteries, and sometimes applied to modern burial places; agraveyard.
A woman's under-garment; a smock. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Johnson.
In an ineffective manner; without effect; inefficiently;ineffectually.
A channel at the end of a deck to restrain the water.
One of the naked, inflatable air sacs on the neck of theprairie chicken and other species of grouse.
The production and working or manufacture of metals. [R.] R.Park.
The act or practice of opening a vein for letting blood, in thetreatment of disease; venesection; bloodletting.
Work formed of clay in whole or in part, and baked; as, vases,urns, etc. Knight.
Of or pertaining to, or of the nature of, the Sauria.-- n.

A process of hardening the face of steel, as armor plates,invented by Hayward A. Harvey of New Jersey, consisting in theadditional carburizing of the face of a piece of low carbon steel bysubjecting it to the action of carbon under long-continued pressureat a very high heat, and then to a violent chilling, as by a spray ofcold water. This process gives an armor plate a thick surface ofextreme hardness supported by material gradually decreasing inhardness to the unaltered soft steel at the back.
A genus of trees found in the East Indies, some species ofwhich produce a fragrant resin, other species wood oil. The fruit hastwo long wings.
One of several species of sea birds of the generaSynthliboramphus and Brachyramphus, inhabiting the North Pacific.They are closely related to the murres.
That which forms the foundation or support of anything; thebasis; the essential or fundamental part; first principle. Dryden.
