Painful vivisection; -- opposed to callisection. B. G. Wilder.
A mark of a line or lines under a word in a sentence, or underanother line; underlining.
A building behind the main building. Specifically: A privy; anecessary.
A storm, strong wind, or gale coming from the southeast.
Capable of being impeded or hindered. [R.] Jer. Taylor.

A system of compromises in the tuning of organs, pianofortes,and the like, whereby the tones generated with the vibrations of aground tone are mutually modified and in part canceled, until theirnumber reduced to the actual practicable scale of twelve tones to theoctave. This scale, although in so far artificial, is yet closelysuggestive of its origin in nature, and this system of tuning,although not mathematically true, yet satisfies the ear, while it hasthe convenience that the same twelve fixed tones answer for every keyor scale, C# becoming identical with D, and so on.
To convert into English; to anglicize. Franklin. Darwin.
The larva of any geometrid moth, which drops from trees bymeans of a thread of silk, as the cankerworm.
A charter or warrant; also, a deed of gift. [India]
Of or pertaining to truisms; consisting of truisms. [R.]
Serving or tending to form an eschar;; producing a scar;caustic.
A thin layer or fold of tissue, usually supported by a fibrousnetwork, serving to cover or line some part or organ, and oftensecreting or absorbing certain fluids.
To smooth over; to palliate.By glozing the evil that is in the world. I. Taylor.
Massachusetts, which had been called the Colony ofMassachusetts Bay; -- a nickname.
One who as has charge of the work of a companionship.
A small party of men assembled for drill, inspection, or otherpurposes.
The worship of saints or sacred things. [R.] Coleridge.
Incapable of being deprived, or of being taken away.
Having power to renew; tending to reproduce; regenerating. G.S. Faber.
The practice or principles of cavaliers. Sir. W. Scott.
To call forth or increase the vital activity of an organism, orany of its parts.
As much as a trowel will hold; enough to fill a trowel.
The state or quality of being laic; the state or condition of alayman.
The delicate connective tissue framework which supports thenervous matter and blood vessels of the brain and spinal cord.
Resembling a bladder; swollen like a bladder; inflated;utricular. Dana.
The style or pin, which by its shadow, shows the hour of theday. It is usually set parallel to the earth's axis.
A Jewish festival, called also the Feast of Lots, instituted tocommemorate the deliverance of the Jews from the machinations ofHaman. Esther ix. 26.
A plant of Sierra Leone which yields a wholesome, creamy juice.
Pain in the muscles; muscular rheumatism or neuralgia.
Springing up or emerging; -- said of a plant or animal.
A stroller; a loiterer; esp., an idle, untidy woman; aslattern; a slut; a whore.
One of the tiles or squares of a tessellated pavement; anabaculus.
A distention of the scrotum by air; also, hernia of the lungs.
Having a single series of large scutes on the posterior side ofthe tarsus; -- said of certain birds.
A box with holes in its lid; -- used for sprinkling flour, ason meat or a breadboard; -- called also dredging box, drudger, anddrudging box.
To crush; to quash; to squash. [Colloq. or Slang, Scot.] Sir W.Scott.
A spear with barbed prongs used for harpooning fish. Knight.
A view of death; a meditation on the subject of death. Bryant.
A fibrous and muscular band lying within the longitudinal axisof the tongue in many mammals, as the dog.
The bolt of the cap-square over the trunnion of a cannon.Knight.
Capable of being prosecuted; liable to prosecution.

The higher literary idiom of Chinese, that of the canonicalbooks and of all composition pretending to literary standing. Itemploys a classical or academic diction, and a more condensed andsententious style than Mandarin, and differs also in the doubling andarrangement of words.
A standing without moving forward or backward; a stop; a stateor rest.
To prize beyong value, or in excess; to exceed in value. [Obs.]Shak.
Moving rapidly round a center; vortical. [R.] Cowper.
A sea urchin when deprived of its spines; -- popularly socalled from a fancied resemblance to a turban.
Rough dressing by knocking off knobs or projections; knobbing.
With wings expanded; -- said of a bird of pray, esp. an eagle.
Having an impaired intellect; whimsical; crazy. Pope.
A quartet; -- applied chiefly to instrumental compositions.
A small bird, the blackcap titmouse (Parus atricapillus), ofNorth America; -- named from its note.
The name of a hypothetical element predicted and afterwardsdiscovered and named germanium; -- so called because it was a missinganalogue of the silicon group. See Germanium, and cf. Ekkabor.
The class of Vertebrata that includes the fishes. The principaldivisions are Elasmobranchii, Ganoidei, and Teleostei.
The bone, or principal bone, of the lower jaw; the inferiormaxilla; -- also applied to either the upper or the lower jaw in thebeak of birds.
Sick at the stomach; also, crestfallen; dejected. [Slang]
Admitting of repudiation; fit or proper to be put away.
An intervening period of time; interval. [Obs.] Gower.
Cheerful or mirthful, as after good eating or drinking; also,wanton. [Scot. & Prov. Eng.]
A mineral of an olive-green color, commonly in orthorhombiccrystals. It is a hydrous phosphate of copper.
Pertaining to, derived from, designating, certain amidocompounds obtained by reducing certain nitro derivatives of diphenyl.

To pay out; to expend; -- usually from a public fund ortreasury.The duty of collecting and disbursing his revenues. Macaulay.Disbursing officer, an officer in any department of the publicservice who is charged with the duty of paying out public money.
Having toes connected by a membrane; palmiped; palmated; also,lobate.
A taking by surprise; an unexpected onset or attack. Carew.
Having some portion of the floral envelopes attached to thepericarp to form the fruit, as in the checkerberry, the mulberry, andthe pineapple.

A peculiar bitter orange-brown substance, with strong,penetrating odor, found in two sacs between the anus and externalgenitals of the beaver; castor; -- used in medicine as anantispasmodic, and by perfumers.
A residence at a particular place accompanied with an intentionto remain there for an unlimited time; a residence accepted as afinal abode. Wharton.
, a. Having the head covered with a wig; wearing a wig.
A brownish substance sometimes found in the blood, in cases ofjaundice.
Time during which one is awake. [R.] Mrs. Browning.
A wolf (Canis pallipes), found in India, allied to the jackal.
A physician who uses much mercury, in any of its forms, in hispractice.
To spurt or shoot in a scattering manner. [Obs.] Drayton.
A broad stripe of purple on the fore part of the tunic, worn bysenators in ancient Rome as an emblem of office.
A yellow, crystalline, organic dyestuff, C16H14N2, of artificalproduction. It is a strong base, and is a complex derivative ofaniline and quinoline.
A formal approbation by the pope of a person nominated to anecclesiastical dignity. Addis & Arnold.
Constituting, or containing, the essence of a thing;quidditative.
Having eyes like those of the mole; having imperfect sight.
An instrument for testing the density of gases, consisting of athin glass globe, which is weighed in the gas or gases, and then inan atmosphere of known density.
A group of Turbellaria in which there is no anal aperture.
The upper petal of a papilionaceous flower; the standard.
Having no limits; unbounded; boundless. Davies (Wit's Pilgr.).
The quality or state of being capable; capability;adequateness; competency.
One belonging to the second of the four classes in an Americancollege, or one next above a freshman. [Formerly written alsosophimore.]
A yellowish oily volatile liquid, C5H11NO2, used in medicine asa heart stimulant and a vasodilator. The inhalation of its vaporinstantly produces flushing of the face.
The dominion of an ethnarch; principality and rule. Wright.

A substance, resembling keratin, present in nerve tissue, as inthe sheath of the axis cylinder of medullated nerve fibers. Likekeratin it resists the action of most chemical agents, and bydecomposition with sulphuric acid yields leucin and tyrosin.

A level having a short telescope (hence its name) rigidly fixedto a table capable only of rotatory movement in a horizontal plane.The telescope is usually an inverting one. It is sometimes called theTroughton level, from the name of the inventor, and a varietyimproved by one Gavatt is known as the Gavatt level.
Composed of leaves united by their edges (coalescent). Gray.
A canvas screen, formerly sometimes extended along the side ofa vessel in a naval engagement, to conceal from the enemy theoperations on board.

One of the very minute, disk-shaped bodies found in blood withthe ordinary red corpuscles and white corpuscles; a third kind ofblood corpuscle, supposed by some to be an early stage in thedevelopment of the red corpuscles; -- called also blood plaque, andblood plate.
Measurement of distance or altitude by a staff or staffs.
One whose business it is to extract teeth with instruments; adentist. Shak.
The treatment of deformities in the human body by mechanicalappliances.
The method or operation of finding from a few given terms of aseries, as of numbers or observations, other intermediate terms inconformity with the law of the series.
The quality or state of being viscid; also, that which isviscid; glutinous concretion; stickiness.
Of or pertaining to prose; prosaic. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
To proclaim; to publish; also, to summon; to call. [Obs.] Bp.Burnet.
The upper stratum of coal, as nearest the light or surface.
A turbulent surface of water, caused by strong currents settingover submerged ridges; also, a dangerous submerged ridge or shoal.
A species of divination by meteors, chiefly by thunder andlightning, which was held in high estimation by the Romans.
Having no mirth; not festive or merry; dull; cheerless; gloomy;forlorn. [R.]
Of or pertaining to an isobathytherm; possessing or indicatingthe same temperature at the same depth.
One who, or that which, folds; esp., a flat, knifelikeinstrument used for folding paper.
Inclined or tending to remonstrate; expostulatory; urgingreasons in opposition to something.
One who studies, or professes the knowledge of, the decretals.
The occupation or work of a carpenter; the act of workingintimber; carpentry.
To go beyond, or be superior to, on the flank; to pass aroundor turn the flank or flanks of.
Freedom from confusion; distinctness. [Obs.] Bacon.
Tendency to become diffused; tendency, as of heat, to becomeequalized by spreading through a conducting medium.
Comrade; boon companion; good fellow; -- a term of familiaraddress and fellowship among sailors. Dickens.
The coloring principle of logwood. It is obtained as a yellowcrystalline substance, C16H14O6, with a sweetish taste. Formerlycalled also hematin.
To convert again into the forest, as a region of country.
Presented, instituted, and inducted into a rectory, and in fullpossession.-- n.
The suborder of elasmobranch fishes which comprises the sharks.
Formed into a legion or legions; legionary. Shelley.
An acrid plant of the genus Polygonum (P. Hydropiper), whichproduces smarting if applied where the skin is tender.
Having numerous facets; -- said of the compound eyes of insectsand crustaceans.
Not appalled; not frightened; dauntless; undaunted. Milton.
One who overweens. [R.]The conceits of warmed or overweening brain. Locke.
A mile traveled by a single car, taken as a unit ofcomputation, as in computing the average travel of each car of asystem during a given period.
Disposed to embrace; fond of caressing. [R.] Thackeray.
One of the special defensive zooids of certain hydroids. Theyhave the form of long, slender tentacles, and bear lasso cells.
An extensive group of worms which have the body coveredexternally with vibrating cilia. It includes the Rhabdocoela andDendrocoela. Formerly, the nemerteans were also included in thisgroup.
A square or oblong opening in a deck or floor, affordingpassage from one deck or story to another; the entrance to a cellar.
A bar attached to the tiller, for convenience in steering.

A small European singing bird (Saxicola oenanthe). The male iswhite beneath, bluish gray above, with black wings and a black stripethrough each eye. The tail is black at the tip and in the middle, butwhite at the base and on each side. Called also checkbird, chickell,dykehopper, fallow chat, fallow finch, stonechat, and whitetail.
A series of six notes, with a semitone between the third andfourth, the other intervals being whole tones.
One of the jointed antenniform appendage of the posteriorsomites of cartain insects. Packard.
An instrument for ligating, or for placing and fastening aligature.
In the form of a cross; across; transversely. Longfellow.
An international, interdenominational organization of Bibleclasses of young women.
The act or method of ascertaining the strength of vinegar, orthe proportion of acetic acid contained in it. Ure.
The act of twinning, or the state of being intwined.
Hermaphrodite, or having both stamens and pistils in everyflower.
A tailor; -- so called in contempt. [Old slang] L'Estrange.
The quality or state of being public, or open to the knowledgeof a community; notoriety; publicness.

A small herbivorous mammal of the genus Hyrax. The speciesfound in Palestine and Syria is Hyrax Syriacus; that of NorthernAfrica is H. Brucei; -- called also ashkoko, dassy, and rock rabbit.See Cony, and Hyrax.
One who writers marginal notes; one who illustrates the text ofa book by notes in the margin. Sir T. Browne.
A gibbon (Hylobates syndactylus), native of Sumatra. It has thesecond and third toes partially united by a web.
A covering or incrusting with marble; a casing of marble; avariegating so as to resemble marble. [R.]
Not according to Moses; unlike Moses or his works.By this reckoning Moses should be most un Mosaic. Milton.
To speculate in physiology; to make physiologicalinvestigations. Cudworth.
, and Gray.] (Bot.) A genus of twining plants with showymonopetalous flowers, including the morning-glory, the sweet potato,and the cypress vine.

One who has immediate jurisdiction in matters ecclesiastical;an ecclesiastical judge; also, a deputy of the bishop, or a clergymanappointed to perform divine service for condemned criminals andassist in preparing them for death.(c) (Am. Law) A judicial officer, having generally the powers of ajudge of probate or a surrogate.
A one-seeded, one-called, indehiscent fruit; an achene with thecalyx tube adherent.
The act of fortifying or guarding against objections. [Obs.]
The act of lopping or cutting off, as the head from the body.

One of the notes, bills, or bonds, issued as currency by therevolutionary government of France (1790-1796), and based on thesecurity of the lands of the church and of nobles which had beenappropriated by the state.
A measure of capacity, containing four quarts; -- used, for themost part, in liquid measure, but sometimes in dry measure.
A hold in which one arm is thrust under the corresponding armof the opponent, generally behind, and the hand placed upon the backof his neck. In the full nelson both hands are so placed.
The sudden drop or depression of the strata of rocks on oneside of a fault. See Throw, n.
To demise back; to convey or transfer back, as an estate.
Uniting, as glue; causing, or tending to cause, adhesion.-- n.
A large genus of plants belonging to the Sedge family, andincluding the species called galingale, several bulrushes, and theEgyptian papyrus.
A genus of shrubs having opposite, petiolate leaves and cymoseflowers, several species of which are cultivated as ornamental, asthe laurestine and the guelder-rose.
Having two principal ribs running longitudinally, as a leaf.
A strap for tightening a saddle girth. [Western U. S. & Sp.Amer.]
Arranged in little roselike clusters; -- said of leaves andbracts.
A genus of fossil fishes, found in Devonian and carboniferousstrata; -- so named from their round, sculptured spines.
To judge beforehand, or before hearing the facts and proof; toprejudge.
The act of opening, disclosing, or manifesting; opendeclaration. Jer. Taylor.
A bench on which work is performed, as in a carpenter's shop.
A young buck in the third year. See the Note under Buck. Shak.
United in one body; formed into a corporation; made a legalentity.

An oil used for illuminating purposes, formerly obtained fromthe distillation of mineral wax, bituminous shale, etc., and hencecalled also coal oil. It is now produced in immense quantities,chiefly by the distillation and purification of petroleum. Itconsists chiefly of several hydrocarbons of the methane series.
An aromatic plant (Thymus Serphyllum); -- called also wildthyme.
The conduct of a truant; neglect of employment; idleness;truancy. Ascham.
A council; a convention; a tribunal; an assembly; esp., thegrand council of state in Spain.
Born in a low condition or rank; -- opposed to highborn.
A message sent by telegraph; a telegraphic dispatch.
A fibrous material obtained by deviling rags or the remnants ofwoolen goods.
To turn inside out, or with the leg part back over the foot, asa stocking in pulling off or for putting on. [Scot.]
A book printed from engraved wooden blocks instead of movabletypes.
A mountain range owing its origin to the progress of ageosynclinal, and ending in a catastrophe of displacement andupturning. Dana.
Any picture printed in two shades of the same color, asduotypes and duographs are usually printed.

The principles of a political party in England (1838-48), whichcontended for universal suffrage, the vote by ballot, annualparliaments, equal electoral districts, and other radical reforms, asset forth in a document called the People's Charter.
Used to denote a case where a set-off pleaded by the defendantis met by a set-off pleaded by the plaintiff.

One of a number of riotous persons in England, who for sixyears (1811-17) tried to prevent the use of labor-saving machinery bybreaking it, burning factories, etc.; -- so called from Ned Lud, ahalf-witted man who some years previously had broken stocking frames.J. & H. Smith. H. Martineau.
To involve in a quarrel or dispute; to embroil. [R.] Bp.Sanderson.
The system, style, spirit, or character, of a priesthood, orsacerdotal order; devotion to the interests of the sacerdotal order.
The price or fare to be paid for passage at a ferry.
Articles made of iron, as household utensils, tools, and thelike.
A vulgar person; one who has vulgar ideas. Used alsoadjectively.
One who receipts; specifically (Law), one who receipts forproperty which has been taken by the sheriff.
Pertaining to Sigault, a French physician. See Symphyseotomy.

An order of cephalopods which includes those with two gills, anapparatus for emitting an inky fluid, and either eight or tencephalic arms bearing suckers or hooks, as the octopi and squids. SeeCephalopoda.
One of the great military roads constructed by the Romans inEngland and other parts of Europe; -- so called from the fosse orditch on each side for keeping it dry.
The first public examinations for degrees at the University ofOxford; -- usually contracted to mods.
A crystal of one species inclosing one of another species. SeeEndomorph.

Of or pertaining to Manila or Manilla, the capital of thePhilippine Islands; made in, or exported from, that city. Manilacheroot or cigar, a cheroot or cigar made of tobacco grown in thePhilippine Islands.-- Manila hemp, a fibrous material obtained from the Musa textilis,a plant allied to the banana, growing in the Philippine and otherEast India islands; -- called also by the native name abaca. From itmatting, canvas, ropes, and cables are made.-- Manila paper, a durable brown or buff paper made of Manila hemp,used as a wrapping paper, and as a cheap printing and writing paper.The name is also given to inferior papers, made of other fiber.
A mineral of a blackish green color, commonly massive or innodules. It is a hydrous phosphate of iron.
Of or pertaining to the protasis of an ancient play;introductory.
The quality or condition of being sharp; keenness; acuteness.
The act or practice of writing psalms, or sacred songs.

A Central American orchid (Peristeria elata), having a flowerstem five or six feet high, with numerous globose white fragrantflowers. The column in the center of the flower resembles a dove; --called also Holy Spirit plant.
A charcoal hearth or furnace for the conversion of cast ironinto wrought iron, or into iron suitable for puddling.
The quality or state of being unamiable; moroseness.
Relating to trypsin or to its action; produced by trypsin; as,trypsin digestion.
Having a tendency to purify or to sweeten by removing orcorrecting acidity and acrimony.
A customhouse officer who goes on board of a merchant ship tosecure payment of the duties; a tidewaiter.
The act of drawing the warp threads through the heddle-eyes ofa weaver's harness; the harness itself. Knight.
A preparation from acorns used by the Arabs as a substitute forchocolate, and also as a beverage for invalids.
Pertaining to Catiline, the Roman conspirator; resemblingCatiline's conspiracy.
An American wild cat (Felis tigrina), ranging from Mexico toBrazil. It is spotted with black. Called also long-tailed cat.
One of certain corrupt persons in the early church at Ephesus,who are censured in rev. ii. 6, 15.
The eye of a bean or other seed; the mark or scar at the pointof attachment of an ovule or seed to its base or support; -- calledalso hile.
A winding so arranged as to divide the armature current andlead a portion of it around the field-magnet coils; -- opposed toseries winding. --Shunt"-wound` (#), a.
A form of capsule for inclosing a dose of medicine that isoffensive, caustic, or the like.
Situated over or above a trochlea or trochlear surface; --applied esp. to one of the subdivisions of the trigeminal nerve.
The act or process of testing, esp. of analyzing or examiningmetals and ores, to determine the proportion of pure metal.
The peptone formed by pancreatic digestion; -- so calledbecause it is formed through the agency of the ferment trypsin.
A government by many persons, of whatever order or class.Cudworth.
Consisting chiefly of aloes; of the nature of aloes.
A plantation of pine trees; esp., a collection of living pinetrees made for ornamental or scientific purposes.
Capable of being participated or shared. [R.] Norris.
That part of a bird, or the feathers, surrounding the cloacalopening; the under tail coverts.
A passage for water, such as was usually made in a sea wall, todrain water out of marshes. Burrill.
Lime in the lump after it is burned; quicklime. [Eng.]
Divided from the border to the base into two distinct parts;bipartite.
A large boom or spar, which projects over the stem of a ship orother vessel, to carry sail forward.
A nurse who attends and feeds a child by hand; -- indistinction from a wet nurse, who suckles it.
An artificial red dye from which the Congo group received itsname. It is also widely used either in aqueous solution or as testpaper (Congo paper) for the detection of free acid, which turns itblue.
A kind of muslin of a texture between nainsook and mull.
A monk who had reserved goods and effects to himself,notwithstanding his renunciation of all at the time of profession.
The science of the dianoetic faculties, and their operations.Sir W. Hamilton.
Having a human head (upon an animal's body), as the Egyptiansphinx.
Of or pertaining to stichometry; characterized by stichs, orlines.
The act of eternizing; the act of rendering immortal or famous.

One who, or that which, scorifies; specifically, a small flatbowl-shaped cup used in the first heating in assaying, to remove theearth and gangue, and to concentrate the gold and silver in a leadbutton.
A species of agate, sprinkled with spots of red jasper.
A genus of fresh-water Pulmonifera, having reversed spiralshells. See Pond snail, under Pond.

Any plant of the genus Carex, perennial, endogenous herbs,often growing in dense tufts in marshy places. They have triangularjointless stems, a spiked inflorescence, and long grasslike leaveswhich are usually rough on the margins and midrib. There are severalhundred species.
Without regular form; shapeless; ugly; deformed. Cotton.
A card game played with the full pack ranking as at whist, eachplayer declaring for which of seven different points he proposes toplay.
The line bisecting the angle between the optic axes of abiaxial crystal.
A coarse linen cloth made in the north of England and inScotland, now nearly replaced by calico. Shak.
Any one of the spaces in the Milky Way which are very black,owing to the nearly complete absence of stars; esp., the large spacenear the Southern Cross sometimes called the Black Magellanic Cloud.
An explosive compound of nitroglycerin. See Nitroglycerin.
The bones of the cranium; more especially, the bones of thedomelike upper portion.
A hydrocarbon, C14H12, produced artificially in large, finecrystals; -- called also diphenyl ethylene, toluylene, etc.
Disapprobation; dislike; censure; adverse judgment.
To vibrate as a balance does before resting in equilibrium;hence, to be poised.Their parts all liberate on too nice a beam. Clifton.
A blank paper, with a person's signature, etc., at the bottom,given to another person, with permission to superscribe whatconditions he pleases. Hence: Unconditional terms; unlimitedauthority.

An order of Crustacea including the squillas. The maxillipedsare leglike in form, and the large claws are comblike. They have alarge and elongated abdomen, which contains a part of the stomach andheart; the abdominal appendages are large, and bear the gills. Calledalso Gastrula, Stomatopoda, and Squilloidea.
Near the sphenoid bone; -- applied especially to a bonesituated immediately beneath the sphenoid in the base of the skull inmany animals.-- n.
A rare fluophosphate of glucina, in small white crystals.
Compressed or flattened antero-posteriorly, or in a wayopposite to the usual one.
An instrument of punishment or torture resembling the knout,used in Russia.
A mark, record, or tracing, made by the action of electricity.
The act of loricating; the protecting substance put on; acovering of scales or plates.
Full of rushes: resembling rushes; juncaceous. [R.] Johnson.
A cover for the back or arms of a chair or sofa, etc., toprevent them from being soiled by macassar or other oil from thehair.
Fit to seal; belonging to a seal; composed of wax. [R.]
Having protuberances resembling the teat of an animal.
One who wrestles; one who is skillful in wrestling.
A curve of the third order, consisting of two infinitebranches, which have a common asymptote. The curve has a doublepoint, and a leaf-shaped loop; whence the name. Its equation is x3 +y3 = axy.
Above, or on the dorsal side of, the ethmoid bone or cartilage.
A sort of bar or movable nut, attached to the finger board of aguitar or other  fretted instrument for the purpose of raisinguniformly the pitch of all the strings.
Either one of two asclepiadaceous shrubs (Calotropis gigantea,and C. procera), which furnish a strong and valuable fiber. The acridmilky juice is used medicinally.
A religious meeting held in the closing hours of the year.
A show or exhibition having a great number of scenes or views.
One of the spiny plates foundon the back and tail of certainskates.
Nice or keen appreciation or enjoyment; relish; taste; fancy.Dryden.
The goods and wares sold by a haberdasher; also (Fig.),trifles. Burke.
Capable of being translated, or rendered into another language.
The more liquid or volatile portion of certain oily substance,as distinguished from stearoptene, the more solid parts. [Writtenalso elaoptene.]
The quality of being apprehensible. [R.] De Quincey.
A wise man; a physician, esp. a Mohammedan. [India]
An officer in attendance upon a hospital, but not residing init; esp., one who cares for the out-patients.
Plastic surgery of the nose to correct deformity or to replacelost tissue. Tissue may be transplanted from the patient's cheek,forehead, arm, etc., or even from another person.
An instrument designed to show the condition of the superficialportions of the eye.
The continuation of a trope in one word through a succession ofsignifications, or the union of two or more tropes of a differentkind in one word.
In a dirty manner; foully; nastily; filthily; meanly; sordidly.
A sensation originated by some external object, but so modifiedas in any way to lead to an erroneous perception; as when the rollingof a wagon is mistaken for thunder.
A state of permanent rigidity or contraction of the muscles,generally of the flexor muscles.
A grotesque mask, representing a person chewing or grimacing,worn in processions and by comic actors on the stage.
The quality or state of being provincial; peculiarity oflanguage characteristic of a province. T. Warton.
The act of setting free the dynamic powers of a medicine, as byshaking the bottle containing it.
A portable bag for travelers; -- so called because originallymade of carpet.
The act of soaking, or the state of being soaked; also, thequantity that enters or issues by soaking.
A junction of two dissimilar conductors used to produce athermoelectric current, as in one form of pyrometer; a thermocouple.
A group of birds including the woodpeckers, toucans, barbets,colies, kingfishes, hornbills, and some other related groups.
A sugarlike body obtained by the decomposition of thenitrogenous non-phosphorized principles of the brain.
A fossil resin, so called from its strong, peculiar, pleasantodor.
The division of birds which includes the gulls and terns.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid known only in itssalts (the metatungstates) and properly called polytungstic, orpyrotungstic, acid.

A similarity of crystalline form between substances of similarcomposition, as between the sulphates of barium (BaSO4) and strontium(SrSO4). It is sometimes extended to include similarity of formbetween substances of unlike composition, which is more properlycalled homoeomorphism.
Any one of several species of blood-sucking, venomous Hemipterathat sometimes bite the lip or other parts of the human body, causingpainful sores, as the cone-nose (Conorhinus sanguisuga). [U. S.]
The act or method of grouping the notes so as to form distinctmusical phrases.
A fine genius, or man of wit. "A man of letters and a belesprit." W. Irving.
A kind of turnip commonly with a large and long or ovoidyellowish root; a Swedish turnip. See Turnip.
Having the wings of an eagle; swift, or soaring high, like aneagle. Shak.
A cloth for covering a table, especially one with which a tableis covered before the dishes, etc., are set on for meals.
A flat muscle on either side of the tongue, connecting it withthe hyoid bone.
That which jets out or projects from anything. [R.] H. Miller.
Faultless; blameless; innocent. South.An innocent and incupable piece of ignorance. Killingbeck.
The part of a church, theater, or other public building,assigned to the audience.

A highly contagious and very destructive disease of horses,asses, mules, etc., characterized by a constant discharge of stickymatter from the nose, and an enlargement and induration of the glandsbeneath and within the lower jaw. It may transmitted to dogs, goats,sheep, and to human beings.
A description of apparent spots on the disk of the sun, or onplanets.
A stick, cane, or cudgel, made of the wood of the carb tree.
A flake; also, a lock, as of wool. [Obs.] J. Martin.
A little, perennial, white, woolly plant (Leontopodiumalpinum), growing at high elevations in the Alps.
In a proportionate manner; with due proportion; proportionally.
The male of the European black grouse (Tetrao tetrix, Linn.); -- so called by sportsmen. The female is called gray hen. See Heathgrouse.
Furnished with fleshy cups for adhering to bodies, ascuttlefish, etc.
Not condensible; incapable of being liquefied; -- said ofgases.
One of a religious order founded by Ignatius Loyola, andapproved in 1540, under the title of The Society of Jesus.
One of the small chips or slices into which beets are cut insugar making.
The son of Saturn and Ops, the god of the waters, especially ofthe sea. He is represented as bearing a trident for a scepter.
Having a bad look; threatening; ugly. See Note under Ill, adv.

A rare metallic element. It occurs quite widely, but in smallquantities, and always combined. It is isolated as a soft yellowishwhite metal, analogous to potassium in most of its properties. SymbolRb. Atomic weight, 85.2.
The author of a dramatic composition; a writer of plays.
The act of interserting, or that which is interserted. [Obs.]Hammond.
The quality or state of being sanable; sanableness;curableness.
A layman authorized to read parts of the public service of thechurch.
Consisting of a spondee, a choriamb, and a pyrrhic; -- appliedto a kind of verse in Greek and Latin poetry.-- n. (Pros.)
Fidelity to nature or to real life; representation withoutidealization, and making no appeal to the imagination; adherence tothe actual fact.
The act of keeping holiday; cessation from work. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
To beat or flog soundly. [Prov. Eng. & Colloq. U.S.] Forby.
A preparation from the seeds of Paullinia sorbilis, a woodyclimber of Brazil, used in making an astringent drink, and also inthe cure of headache.
A system of signaling in which balls of red and green fire arefired from a pistol, the arrangement in groups denoting numbershaving a code significance.

An African freshwater fish (Protopterus annectens), belongingto the Dipnoi. It can breathe air by means of its lungs, and whenwaters dry up, it encases itself in a nest of hard mud, where itremains till the rainy season. It is used as food.
That which cleanses or purifies; esp., an apparatus forremoving the feculencies of juices and sirups. Knight.
A double spondee; a foot consisting of four long syllables.
A rare skin disease consisting in the development of smooth,milk-white spots upon various parts of the body.
Round, water-worn, and loose gravel and pebbles, or acollection of roundish stones, such as are common on the seashore andelsewhere.
A cunette. 3. (Spectrometry) (Analytical chemistry)
A seed vessel resembling a silique, but about as broad as it islong. See Silique.
Any one of several species of bombycid moths belonging toNotodonta, Nerice, and allied genera. The caterpillar of these mothshas a hump, or spine, on its back.
A plant (Sarracenia flava) with long, hollow leaves.
One of the symmetrical halves of any one of the radii, orspheromeres, of a radiate animal, as a starfish.
One of the adherents of Charles Stewart Parnell (1846-91) inhis advocacy of home rule for Ireland.
A tribe of perching birds, including those which have a strongconical bill, as the finches.
A short mortar used formerly for throwing stone shot. Hakluyt.
A medicine which preserves or defends against disease; apreventive.
One versed in tactics; hence, a skillful maneuverer; an adroitmanager.
The offspring of a quadroon and a white person; a mestee.
A substitute for whalebone, made from the quills of geese andturkeys.
Of or pertaining to Portugal; Portuguese. [Obs.] -- n.
A mineral of a red, or brownish or yellowish red color. It is achromate of lead; -- called also phoenicocroite.
A figure by which the conjunction is often repeated, as in thesentence, "We have ships and men and money and stores." Opposed toasyndeton.
An advocate of, or believer in, traditionalism; a traditionist.
One of numerous species of Heliconius, a genus of tropicalAmerican butterflies. The wings are usually black, marked with green,crimson, and white.
A common European wild rose, with single pink or white flowers.
The fruit of a West Indian palm (Manicaria Plukenetii), oftenfound floating in the sea. A. Grisebach.
A division of Mollusca having slender, cirriform appendagesnear the mouth; the Scaphopoda.
Any substance (but especially sodium hyposulphite) used inremoving the excess of chlorine left in paper pulp or stuffs afterbleaching.
Of or pertaining to St. Bernard of Clairvaux, or to theCistercian monks.-- n.
The belief or doctrine that attributes everything to nature asa sanative agent.
A condition of endemic or inherited idiocy, accompanied byphysical degeneracy and deformity (usually with goiter), frequent incertain mountain valleys, esp. of the Alps.
An aquatic plant (Hottonia palustris), having finely dividedleaves.
The refrain of a famous song of the French Revolution.
A gold coin of Portugal, valued at about 27s. sterling.
Clasping or embracing a stem, as the base of some leaves. Gray.
Containing or expressing approbation; commendatory. Sheldon.

A kind of gun in which the elastic force of condensed air isused to discharge the ball. The air is powerfully compressed into areservoir attached to the gun, by a condensing pump, and iscontrolled by a valve actuated by the trigger.
A kind of griddlecake of unleavened bread, used among thenatives of India. [Anglo-Indian]
The art of house-keeping, cookery, etc. [R.] R. Park.
Good against scrofulous disorders. Johnson. Wiseman.
A small European rodent (Eliomys nitela), allied to thedormouse.
Noting two small bones, forming the body of the inverted hyoidarch.

A nitrogenous base, C5H11NO2, produced artificially, and alsooccurring naturally in beetroot molasses and its residues, from whichit is extracted as a white crystalline substance; -- called alsolycine and oxyneurine. It has a sweetish taste.
Of a red color with a slight mixture of gray. Dana.
One who brings meat to the table; hence, in some countries, theofficial title of the grand master or steward of the king's or anobleman's household.
To unite again; to join after separation or variance. Shak.
In an answerable manner; in due proportion or correspondence;suitably.
Below the lower lip; -- said of certain scales of reptiles andfishes.
Between or among constellations or stars; interstellar.
The opposition of nutrition; the failure of nutrition causingthe breaking down of tissue.
One who accepts the doctrine of experientialism. Also usedadjectively.
The title of the ruling Prince of Baroda, in Gujarat, inBombay, India.
Of or pertaining to the real or to the mystical Babylon, or tothe ancient kingdom of Babylonia; Chaldean.
Of or pertaining to a penumbra; resembling a penumbra;partially illuminated.
A concealed hiding place; a burrow; a lair; a hole.
In an inexpressible manner or degree; unspeakably; unutterably.Spectator.
The act or habit of talking idly or rapidly, or of makinginarticulate sounds; the sounds so made; noise made by the collisionof the teeth; chatter.
A genus of rapacious birds; one of the Accipitres or Raptores.
Pertaining to, or derived from, ytterbium; containingytterbium.
Want or absence of divine power or of divinity. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
A chapel; hence, the choir or orchestra of a prince's chapel;now, a musical establishment, usually orchestral. Grove.
The margin of the head, behind the bill of birds, often bearingrigid bristles.
Dewrotting; the process of decomposing the gummy matter of flaxand hemp and setting the fibrous part, by exposure on a sward to dew,rain, and sunshine.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a family of plants of whichthe cucumber, melon, and gourd are common examples.
A confection of different kinds of preserved fruits. -- a.
To unite, embrace, communicate with, or flow into, one another;to be connected in one system; to lock into one another; to interlacefirmly.

The opinions of Origen of Alexandria, who lived in the 3dcentury, one of the most learned of the Greek Fathers. Prominent inhis teaching was the doctrine that all created beings, includingSatan, will ultimately be saved.
To cover with a screen, or as with a screen; to shelter; toconceal. Shak.
An association for promoting art (esp. the arts of design), andgiving encouragement to artists.
An instrument formerly used in extracting foreign or offensivematter from a wound.
A transformer in which part of the primary winding is used as asecondary winding, or vice versa; -- called also a compensator orbalancing coil.
The rite or ceremonial observed by one of the Masonic systems,deriving its name from the city of York, in England; also, the systemitself, which, in England, confers only the first three degrees.
A small round dish with a handle, usually of porcelain.
A rope or chain fitted around the masthead to hold hangingblocks for jibs and stays.
A list of drams, operas, pieces, parts, etc., which a companyor a person has rehearsed and is prepared to perform.
The quality or state of being thin (in any of the senses of theword).
One who will never cease to be; one exempt from death, decay,or annihilation. Bunyan.
In an intensive manner; by increase of degree. Abp. Bramhall.
The part of the scapula behind or below the spine, ormesoscapula.
Not plumed; without plumes or feathers; featherless. [R.]Drayton.
A silicate of lime of a white to gray, red, or yellow color,occurring generally in cleavable masses, rarely in tabular crystals;tabular spar.
Made convex; protuberant in a spherical form. Sir T. Browne.

A fitting out, or equipment, as of a ship for a voyage, or of aperson for an expedition in an unoccupied region or residence in aforeign land; things required for equipment; the expense of, orallowance made for, equipment, as by the government of the UnitedStates to a diplomatic agent going abroad.
An instrument for determining the specific gravities ofliquids, and thence the strength spirituous liquors, salinesolutions, etc.
A local name for the partridge berry; also, for the deerberry.[U. S.]
In a geographical manner or method; according to geography.

An order of reptiles which includes the turtles and tortoises.The body is covered by a shell consisting of an upper or dorsalshell, called the carapace, and a lower or ventral shell, called theplastron, each of which consists of several plates.
A thousand millions; -- called also billion. See Billion.
The state of being a pagan; paganism. [R.] Cudworth.
The constitution, or fundamental law, of the French monarchy,as established on the restoration of Louis XVIII., in 1814.
By stealing, or as by stealing, furtively, or by an invisiblemotion. Sir P. Sidney.
A translucent variety of serpentine, of a honey yellow orgreenish yellow color, having a waxy resinlike luster.

A kind of fine pottery, the most remarkable being what iscalled jasper, either white, or colored throughout the body, andcapable of being molded into the most delicate forms, so that fineand minute bas-reliefs like cameos were made of it, fit even forbeing set as jewels.
One whose occupation is to make or repair small firearms; anarmorer.
Pestering; vexatious; troublesome. Used also as an intensive.[Colloq. & Low, U.S.] Judd.
Steel made by the direct refining of cast iron in a finery, or,as wootz, by a direct process from the ore.
A line drawn through points of equal temperature in a verticalsection of the ocean.
A dog kept to watch and guard premises or property, and to givenotice of the approach of intruders.
A genus of vascular, cryptogamic, herbaceous plants; -- alsocalled horsetails.
A low, oven-shaped mound, common in volcanic regions, andemitting smoke and vapors from its sides and summit. Humboldt.
A circular or oval window; -- generally used of architecture ofthe 17th and 18th centuries. A famous room in the palace ofVersailles bears this name, from the oval window opening into it.

An instrument for transmission of auditory vibrations throughthe bones of the head, so as to be appreciated as sounds by personsdeaf from causes other than those affecting the nervous apparatus ofhearing.
A maker of catalogues; esp. one skilled in the making ofcatalogues.
A rocket that ascends high and burns as it flies; a species offireworks.
To stop or close, as an opening; specif., (Ordnance),
Having the form of, or resembling, sawdust or raspings.
Pricking with a needle; a needle prick. Specifically (Med.):
The first coat of plaster laid on brick; also, the process ofapplying it.
One of the moons or satellites of the planet Jupiter. [Obs.]Derham.
To shorten by omitting a letter or letters or by reducing twoor more vowels or syllables to one.
The tendency of an organism to respond, during its growth, tothe force of gravitation.
A variety of onyx consisting of sard and white chalcedony inalternate layers.
A small, shrill flute, the pitch of which is an octave higherthan the ordinary flute; an octave flute.
A colorless or white crystalline compound, (CH2)6N4C2H5Br, usedas a sedative in epilepsy.
To call by the wrong name; to give a wrong or inappropriatename to.

A subdivision or the American Upper Silurian system, embracingthe Medina, Clinton, and Niagara epoch. The rocks of the Niagaraepoch, mostly limestones, are extensively distributed, and at NiagaraFalls consist of about eighty feet of shale supporting a greaterthickness of limestone, which is gradually undermined by the removalof the shale. See Chart of Geology.
The quality or state of being irremovable; immovableness.
The performer in music who takes the accompanying part. Busby.
A division of boring Hymenoptera, including Tremex and alliedgenera. See Illust. of Horntail.
One who conforms; one who complies with established forms ordoctrines.
The sanderling; -- so called from its cry. [Prov. Eng.]
The pivoted or swinging bar to which the traces of a harnessedhorse are fixed; a whiffletree.
To become corporeal; to assume the qualities of a materialbody. See Embody.The soul grows clotted by contagion, Imbodies, and imbrutes. Milton.
The art, process, or occupation of making a lexicon ordictionary; the principles which are applied in making dictionaries.
Not hitherto described; novel; hence, odd; abnormal;unclassifiable.
To take long, loose stitches over (the raw edges of a seam) toprevent raveling.
A place where animals are slaughtered for their hides andtallow. [Western U. S.]
A small instrument with four strings, played with a bow; afiddle.
Any one of several umbelliferous plants, of the genera Myrrhis,Osmorrhiza, etc.

An instrument for measuring the tension or elastic force ofgases, steam, etc., constructed usually on the principle of allowingthe gas to exert its elastic force in raising a column of mercury inan open tube, or in compressing a portion of air or other gas in aclosed tube with mercury or other liquid intervening, or in bending ametallic or other spring so as to set in motion an index; a pressuregauge. See Pressure, and Illust. of Air pump.
A bill or halberd of the 16th and 17th centuries. See 4th Bill.Many time, but for a sallet, my brainpan had been cleft with a brownbill. Shak.
The child of a mulatto and a negro; also, the child of anIndian and a negro; colloquially or humorously, a negro; a sambo.
Examination or study with the naked eye, as distinguished frommicrography.
A gephyrean worm of the genus Thalassema, having a spoonlikeprobiscis.
Of, relating to, or produced by, the chemical action of rays oflight; photographic.
Constipation; also, constriction of the vessels or ducts.
The act or product of theorizing; the formation of a theory ortheories; speculation.
The grasscloth plant (Boehmeria nivea); also, its fiber, whichis very fine and exceedingly strong; -- called also China grass, andrhea. See Grass-cloth plant, under Grass.
Within the range of hpe; proper to be hoped for. [Obs.] Bacon.
The origin and development of organs in animals and plants.

Pertaining to, or designating, an acid found in many kinds ofgrapes. It is also obtained from tartaric acid, with which it isisomeric, and from sugar, gum, etc., by oxidation. It is a sour whitecrystalline substance, consisting of a combination of dextrorotatoryand levorotatory tartaric acids. Gregory.
The quality or characteristics of a gem or jewel. [Obs.]Bailey.
One who scrutinizes; a close examiner or inquirer. Ayliffe.
The symmetry of a metameric structure; serial symmetry; thestate of being made up of metameres.
To send on from an intermediate station by means of a repeater.
The ventral and anterior of the three principal bones composingeither half of the pelvis; sharebone; pubic bone.
To roll or wallow; to welter. [Obs. or Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
Shaped like a sword; ensiform, as the long, flat leaves of theIris, cattail, and the like.
Any slender, marine fish of the genus Hemirhamphus, having theupper jaw much shorter than the lower; -- called also balahoo.
A genus of bats including some of the common smallinsectivorous species of North America and Europe.
In Spanish countries, a court or trial held, sometimes as longas six months, by a newly elected official, as the governor of aprovince, to examine into the conduct of a predecessor.
One who ordains or establishes; a director. [R.] T. Adams.
A doctor of the Sorbonne, or theological college, in theUniversity of Paris, founded by Robert de Sorbon, a. d. 1252. It wassuppressed in the Revolution of 1789.
The third division of the stomach of ruminants. See Manyplies,and Illust. under Ruminant.
A Celtic divinity, regarded as the evil principle, butconfounded by the Romans with Jupiter.
A basic substance, C7H17NO2, formed from the growth of thetyphoid bacillus on meat pulp. It induces in small animals lethargicconditions with liquid dejecta.
One who explains; an expounder or expositor; a commentator; aninterpreter.
Of or pertaining to the Crustacea; crustaceous.-- n.
Having the power of vellicating, plucking, or twitching;causing vellication.
Divided into an even number of bends; -- said of a shield orits charge. Cussans.
A parent stock or race of people, not yet divided into separatebranches or tribes.
A salt derived from a sesquioxide base, or made up on theproportions of a sesqui compound.
To refuse to worship; to treat as unworthy. [Obs.] Sir T. More.
A member of the lowest class in the military academy at WestPoint. [Cant, U.S.]
An inhabitant or native of the south, esp. of the SouthernStates of North America; opposed to Northerner.
The practice of meanly fawning on another; base sycophancy;servile adulation.
A large, handsome squirrel (Sciurus Javensis), native of Javaand Southern Asia; -- called also Java squirrel.
An inflammable, volatile, oily, liquid hydrocarbon, obtained bythe destructive distillation of caoutchouc.
A study; an exercise; a piece for practice of some specialpoint of technical execution.
A kind of choice winter apple, having a subacid taste; --formerly called go-no-further.
Tending to prevent the formation of urinary calculi, or todestroy them when formed.-- n.
A piece of wood, shell, stone, or other substance, worn in aperforation of the lip or cheek by many savages.

The disposition of a column and its component parts, and of theentablature resting upon it, in classical architecture; hence (as thecolumn and entablature are the characteristic features of classicalarchitecture) a style or manner of architectural designing.
A bicycle with equal or nearly equal wheels, usually 28 inchesdiameter, driven by pedals connected to the rear (driving) wheel by amultiplying gear.
The class of flowering plants including all which have trueflowers with distinct floral organs; phanerogamia.
A regulus consisting essentially of nickel, obtained as aresidue in fusing cobalt and nickel ores with silica and sodiumcarbonate to make smalt.
Pertaining to, or formed by, concretion or aggregation;producing or containing concretions.
A genus of evergreen tropical shrubs; -- so called from theblack berries of some species, which stain the mouth.
One who, or that which, erases; esp., a sharp instrument or apiece of rubber used to erase writings, drawings, etc.
The state of being negligent; negligence. [Obs.] Shak.
To lash with stripes; to wale; to thrash; to drub. [Prov. Eng.& Colloq. U. S.] Halliwell. Bartlett.
The act of dividing into two parts, or of making twocorrespondent parts, or the state of being so divided.
A hornlike tuft of feathers on the head of some birds.
The science which treats of poisons, their effects, antidotes,and recignition; also, a discourse or treatise on the science.
A very vascular superficial opacity of the cornea, usuallycaused by granulation of the eyelids. Foster.
Of or pertaining to micrococci; caused by micrococci. Nature.
To go or come after; -- used in the various senses of thetransitive verb: To pursue; to attend; to accompany; to be a result;to imitate.
A mode of facing sea walls and embankments with planks drivenas piles and secured by ties. Knight.

Falsely or imperfectly dipteral, as a temple with the innerrange of columns surrounding the cella omitted, so that the spacebetween the cella wall and the columns is very great, being equal totwo intercolumns and one column.-- n.
An affection characterized by pain in or about a joint, notdependent upon structural disease.
One who adopts the geological theory of igneous fusion; aPlutonian. See Plutonism.
A pustular eruption upon the scalp, or the beared part of theface, whether due to ringworm, acne, or impetigo.
The state of being unavoidable; certainty to happen. Prideaux.
A verbal imitation of a musical sound, as of the note of a larkor a horn.The lark, that tirra lyra chants. Shak."Tirralira, " by the river, Sang Sir Lancelot. Tennyson.
The daughter of Saturn and Ops or Rhea, the goddess of corn andtillage.
Near or beside the ethmoid bone or cartilage; -- appliedespecially to a pair of bones in the nasal region of some fishes, andto the ethmoturbinals in some higher animals.-- n.
A compound radical, NH4, having the chemical relations of astrongly basic element like the alkali metals.
The replacement of an edge by two similar planes, equallyinclined to the including faces or adjacent planes.
Any coral of the genus Madrepora; formerly, often applied toany stony coral.
Making a promise; implying a promise; promising. [R.]
The lowest of the grand divisions of the animal kingdom.

The cohesion of the particles on the surface of a body,determined by its capacity to scratch another, or be itselfscratched;-measured among minerals on a scale of which diamond andtalc form the extremes.
A boat or raft used in the East Indies in the landing ofpassengers and goods.

The cutting off or suppression of a vowel or syllable, for thesake of meter or euphony; esp., in poetry, the dropping of a finalvowel standing before an initial vowel in the following word, whenthe two words are drawn together.
The quality, state, or phenomenon of being trichromatic.
The act or process of gathering into a mass; the state of beingthus collected; collection; accumulation; that which isconglomerated; a mixed mass. Bacon.
Resembling pearl or mother-of-pearl; pearly in quality orappearance.
A method of armature winding in which the wire is wound uponthe outer surface of a cylinder or drum from end to end of thecylinder; -- distinguished from ring winding, etc.
A special oblong or pyriform cell, with slender branches, whichbears the spores in that division of fungi called Basidiomycetes, ofwhich the common mushroom is an example.
Pertaining to, or furnishing, a diagnosis; indicating thenature of a disease.
The state of being solitary; solitariness. [Obs.] Cudworth.
A place where eggs are deposited (as by sea birds) or kept; anest of eggs. [R.]
A change in the character of a cell wall, by which it becomesharder. It is supposed to be due to an incrustation of lignin.
A water clock; a contrivance for measuring time by thegraduated flow of a liquid, as of water, through a small aperture.See Illust. in Appendix.
The art or science of sounding, or measuring depths in the sea.
A displacement of an organ, esp. of the uterus, in such mannerthat its whole axis is directed further forward than usual.

A plant (Mesembryanthemum crystallinum), sprinkled withpellucid, watery vesicles, which glisten like ice. It is native alongthe Mediterranean, in the Canaries, and in South Africa. Its juice issaid to be demulcent and diuretic; its ashes are used in Spain inmaking glass. Ice-skater = one who skates on ice wearing an iceskate; esp. an athlete who performs athletic or artistic movements ona sheet of ice, wearing ice skates; including speed skater and figureskater
Of or pertaining to the diameter of the cranium, from oneparietal fossa to the other.

One of a class of religious reformers in Germany in the 17thcentury who sought to revive declining piety in the Protestantchurches; -- often applied as a term of reproach to those who make adisplay of religious feeling. Also used adjectively.
Having the number of floral organs unequal, as four petals andsix stamens.
A young male of the ox kind; especially, a common ox; acastrated taurine male from two to four years old. See the Note underOx.
The Baltimore oriole (Icterus galbula); -- so called becauseits nest is suspended from the limb of a tree. See Baltimore oriole.
A small warbler (Pratincola rubetra) common in Europe; --called also whinchacker, whincheck, whin-clocharet.
Between the times of sleeping; in an interval of wakefulness.[R.]
A kind of seaweed (Chorda Filum) having blackish cordlikefronds, often many feet long.
The quality or state of being tetravalent; quadrivalence.
An order of fresh-water rhizopods having a more or lessglobular form, with slender radiating pseudopodia; the sunanimalcule.
To behave or move in a lively or restless manner, as animpatient horse; to caper; to prance; to frisk.  Kipling.
A common name of the yellowish green mineral chrysolite, esp.the variety found in eruptive rocks.
To divest of scales; to remove scales from.[An eagle] purging and unscaling her long-abused sight at thefountain itself of heavenly radiance. Milton.
A white, crystalline hydrocarbon, regarded as a polymericvariety of ethylene, obtained in heavy oil of wine, the residue leftafter making ether; -- formerly called also concrete oil of wine.
A composition sung to the sound of seven chords or tones. Moore(Encyc. of Music).
The putting out of possession, wrongfully or otherwise, of onewho is in possession of a freehold, no matter in what title; --called also ouster.
Making inquiry; inquiring; questioning. [Obs.] Shenstone.
A genus of land snails having an elongated spiral shell, oftenof large size. The species are numerous ingabundant in tropicalAmerica.
A sacrificer; one who offers a sacrifice. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
A point where one branch of a curve crosses another branch. SeeDouble point, under Double, a.
Capable of being admitted to give surety by mainpernors; ableto be mainprised.
The cavity or ventricle of the thalamencephalon; the thirdventricle.
To practice psalmody. " The psalmodizing art." J. G. Cooper.
One of the specialized or tactile hairs which grow about thenostrils, or on other parts of the face, in many animals, as the so-called whiskers of the cat, and the hairs of the nostrils of man.
The reading of the lines of a newspaper directly across thepage, instead of down the columns, thus producing a ludicrouscombination of ideas.
One who wavers; one who is unsettled in doctrine, faith,opinion, or the like. Shak.
A magazine or other publication which appears at stated orregular intervals.
A strap of a bridle, halter, or the like, passing under ahorse's throat.
A word used to define or limit the extent of the significationof a common noun, such as the definite article, and some pronouns.

Any small marine gastropod shell of the genus Littorina. Thecommon European species (Littorina littorea), in Europe extensivelyused as food, has recently become naturalized abundantly on theAmerican coast. See Littorina.
A figure of speech by which a word is used in a literal andmetaphorical sense at the same time.
Having a thick skin; hence, not sensitive; dull; obtuse.Holland.
A verse containing eight feet; as, --Deep'' in|to'' the | dark''ness | peer''ing, | long'' I | stood''there | wond'''ring, | fear''ing. Poe.

A substance obtained from the residues of the distillation ofpetroleum, essentially the same as vaseline, but of somewhat stifferconsistency, and consisting of a mixture of the higher paraffines; akind of petroleum jelly.

A joint in a stone pavement where the stones are left slightlyhigher than elsewhere, the rest of the surface being sunken ordished. The raised surface is intended to prevent the settling ofwater in the joints.
A rope used for tying or hobbling the legs of a horse or cow.[Prov. Eng. & Local, U.S.] Grose.
Paving or flooring made of small squares or lozenges setdiagonally. [Formerly written pointal.]

A beautiful Australian parrakeet (Platycercus eximius) oftenkept as a cage bird. The head and back of the neck are scarlet, thethroat is white, the back dark green varied with lighter green, andthe breast yellow.
One who prepares homilies; one who preaches to a congregation.

In American colleges and universities, a day of thecommencement season on which the senior class celebrates thecompletion of its course by exercises conducted by the members, suchas the reading of the class histories and poem, the delivery of theclass oration, the planting of the class ivy, etc.
A Portuguese money of account rated in the treasury departmentof the United States at one dollar and eight cents; also, a Brazilianmoney of account rated at fifty-four cents and six mills.
An umbelliferous plant (Pimpinella anisum) growing naturally inEgypt, and cultivated in Spain, Malta, etc., for its carminative andaromatic seeds.
More recent than the Paleozoic, -- that is, including theMesozoic and Cenozoic.
To derive or deduce; also, to transmit; to transfer. [Obs.]Fotherby.
A shell or tube formed by an annelid, as a serpula.
The quality or state of being supple; flexibility; pliableness;pliancy.
In the West Indies and Guiana, a fugitive slave, or a freenegro, living in the mountains.

A spinose, plectognath fish of the Allantic coast of the UnitedStates (esp. Chilo mycterus geometricus) having the power ofdistending its body with water or air, so as to resemble a chestnutbur; -- called also ball fish, balloon fish, and swellfish.
A tern applied to the twelve houses, or parts, of the zodiac ofthe primum mobile, to distinguish them from the twelve signs; also,any one of the twelve signs of the zodiac.
A hypothetical radical of glycerin. [Obs.] Berzelius.
Inclined to swag; sinking, hanging, or leaning by its weight.Sir T. Browne.
To free from wrangling or litigation. [Obs.] Berkeley.
A person skilled in artillery or gunnery; a gunner; anartilleryman.
The act or process of litigating; a suit at law; a judicialcontest.
To retract or falsify a previous prediction. Milton.
A violent and cold northwest wind experienced in theMediterranean provinces of France, etc.
To yield seed; to emit seed, or sperm. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
One who fights against the gods; one who resists God of thedivine will.
A centaur; a fabulous being, half man, half horse, armed with abow and quiver. Shak.
A measure of length; the distance from the elbow to the end ofthe middle finger; a cubit.
A narrow opening, often cruciform, through which arrows mightbe discharged.
A curve, traced by a point in the radius, or radius produced,of a circle which rolls upon the concave side of a fixed circle. SeeHypocycloid, Epicycloid, and Trochoid.
The addition of a letter or syllable to the end of a word, aswithouten for without.
A small war club, esp. of savages; -- so called because of itssupposed use in crushing the skull.
The part of a chimney between the gathering, or portion of thefunnel which contracts in ascending, and the flue. Gwilt.
Producing, or yielding, gelatin; gelatiniferous; as, thegelatigeneous tissues.
Pertaining to, or resembling, an order of plants like thepalms, but having exogenous wood. The sago palm is an example.
A principal enemy. Specifically, Satan, the grand adversary ofmankind. Milton.
A genus of trees or shrubs, one species of which (F. Carica)produces the figs of commerce; the fig tree.
The condition or quality of being sane; soundness of health ofbody or mind, especially of the mind; saneness.
Act of benumbing, or state of being benumbed; torpor. Kirby.
A species of sunfish (Lepomis pallidus), common in the UnitedStates; -- called also blue sunfish, and copper-nosed bream.

A genus of leguminous trees of tropical America, the differentspecies of which yield balsamic products, among which are balsam ofPeru, and balsam of Tolu. The species were formerly referred toMyrospermum.
A kind of gimlet for making vents in casks; -- called alsopiercer.
Small articles of virtu, as jewelry, trinkets, etc.
Bearing ships; capable of floating vessels. [R.] Blount.
The north or northern regions. Shak.Both East West, South and Septentrioun. Chaucer.
Sport or freak of nature; a deformed or unnatural production.
Having or containing bulbs, or a bulb; growing from bulbs;bulblike in shape or structure.
Of or pertaining to a matriarch; governed by a matriarch.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the mulberry; moric.
An instrument for measuring the depth of the color of anything,especially of a liquid, by comparison with a standard liquid.
The quality or state of being universal; universality.
An ancient Roman liquid and dry measure, about equal to anEnglish pint.
Uniting and blending together different systems, as ofphilosophy, morals, or religion. Smart.
The external angle of knee timber, the inside of which iscalled the throat.

It seems; -- chiefly used impersonally in reports and judgmentsto express an opinion in reference to the law on some point notnecessary to be decided, and not intended to be definitely settled inthe cause.
A large South American monkey (Lagothrix Humboldtii), withprehensile tail.
An instrument or apparatus for detecting the presence ofelectrical currents, especially such as are of feeble intensity.
A hypothetical radical, C5H4N, regarded as the essentialresidue of pyridine, and analogous to phenyl.
The song of the Virgin Mary, Luke i. 46; -- so called becauseit commences with this word in the Vulgate.
The discussion or description of portraiture or ofrepresentative images. Cf. Iconography.
A yellowish white, translucent mineral, consisting of thecarbonates of lime and soda, with water.
The highest kind of worship, or that paid to God; --distinguished by the Roman Catholics from dulia, or the inferiorworship paid to saints.
A steel-gray metallic mineral, a sulphide of antimony and lead.
To scrape (the club) on the ground, in a stroke, before hittingthe ball; also, to make (a stroke) in that way.
The horse which goes between the thills, or shafts, andsupports them; also, the last horse in a team; -- called also thillhorse.
In a feeling manner; pathetically; sympathetically.
A nitrogenous substance resembling vitellin, present in the eggyolk of cartilaginous fishes.
A pustular eruptive disease of the cow, which, whencommunicated to the human system, as by vaccination, protects fromthe smallpox; vaccinia; -- called also kinepox, cowpock, andkinepock. Dunglison.
A large American holothurian (Lophothuria Fabricii) having abright orange convex body covered with finely granulated scales. Itsexpanded tentacles are bright red.
A term sometimes applied to the decomposition of organicsubstance into more simple bodies, by the use of chemical agentsalone. Thudichum.
A quorum, or number necessary, for conducting public worship.
Of or pertaining to the lighter division of the Melanochroi, orthose races having an olive or yellow complexion and black hair.
A double-lens instrument for measuring slight variations of thesun's diameter by photography, utilizing the common chord of twooverlapping images.
In a winking manner; with the eye almost closed. Peacham.
Agency; influence; production of effects. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
The work of a coal miner who is paid by a share of his product.

A camera for obtaining a circular panoramic view of thehorizon. The photographic plate is placed horizontally with avertical lens above. A mirror of peculiar shape reflects light fromthe entire horizon to the lens, by means of which it is focused uponthe plate.
A writing composed of words not having a certain letters; -- asin the Odyssey of Tryphiodorus there was no A in the first book, no Bin the second, and so on.
Belonging to rivers or streams; fluviatile. Johnson.
To affect reformation; to pretend to correctness. [R.]
An engine driven by heated or by compressed air. Knight.
A native sailor, employed in European vessels; also, a menialemployed about arsenals, camps, camps, etc.; a camp follower. [EastIndies]
One who sells unguents or perfumery. [Obs.] Jonhson.
A little cable less than ten inches in circumference.
Inability or incapability of enduring, or of being endured.[Obs.] Wyclif.
The art of mangonizing, or setting off to advantage. [Obs.]
A book containing stories, or short narratives, either true orfalse.
A plant (Echinospermum Lappula) of the Borage family, withsmall blue flowers and prickly nutlets.
An alloy of nicked with copper and zinc; German silver.
A manure made from night soil, dried and mixed with charcoal,gypsum, etc.
A morbid condition produced by the excessive or prolonged useof morphine.
The act of disburdening, discharging, or freeing morally from acharge or imputation; also, the state of being disburdened or freedfrom a charge.
An individual of one of the races of aboriginal inhabitantswhich survive in Hindostan.-- a.
The achromatic figure, formed in mitotic cell-division,consisting of two asters connected by a spindle-shaped bundle ofrodlike fibers diverging from each aster, and called the spindle.
Unskillfully painted, so that the painter's method of work istoo obvious; also, having too much pigment applied to the surface.[Cant]
To feed with too little food; to supply with an insufficientquantity of food.
resembling a rose in smell or color. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
The act of excogitating; a devising in the thoughts; invention;contrivance.
Having the lower chop or jaw depressed; hence, crestfallen;dejected; dispirited;downcast. See Chapfallen.
A duty paid to the crown for the passage of vessels on certainrivers.

A kind of cotton lace which is wrought by machines, and not byhand. [Sometimes written bobbin net.]The English machine-made net isnow confined to point net, warp net, and bobbin net, so called fromthe peculiar construction of the machines by which they are produced.Tomlinsom.
A plane four-sided figure, having two sides parallel to eachother.
With plundering violence; by violent injustice. [R.] Strype.
A flat batter cake cooked on a griddle; a flapjack; agriddlecake. [Local, U.S.]
Quality or state of being transplendent. [R.] Dr. H. More.
Not to be depended on; weak; unstable. [Prov. Eng.] Grose.
The art or occupation of a smith; smithing. [R.] Sir W.Raleigh.
Freeing from a burden or obligation; tending to exonerate.
The two projecting feathered angles of the forehead of somebirds; the frontal points.
One of a celebrated breed of American trotting horses; -- socalled from the name of the stud from which the breed originated inVermont.
The indian cane, a plant of the Palm family. It furnishes thecommon rattan. See Rattan, and Dragon's blood.
One who, or that which, bewrays; a revealer. [Obs. or Archaic]Addison.

A Vickers-Maxim one-pounder automatic machine cannon usingmetallic ammunition fed from a lopped belt attached to the gun; --popularly so called from its peculiar drumming sound in action.Sometimes, any of other similar automatic cannons.
The vessel in which incense is burned and offered; a censer; athurible. [R.] Evelyn.
An exclamatory sentence, or striking reflection, which sums upor concludes a discourse.
Having a conspicious tongue; -- said of certain reptiles andinsects.
One of three hydroxy derivatives of toluene, called thecresols. See Cresol.
A minute inclosed crystal, often observed when minerals orrocks are examined in thin sections under the microscope.
A game for two, played with 40 cards, in which each playertries to form three or four of a kind or sequences.
A note of half the time or duration of the breve; -- nowusually called a whole note. It is the longest note in general use.
To inclose, as a body of troops, between hostile forces, so asto cut off means of communication or retreat; to invest, as a city.
A diseased condition produced by poisoning with hydrargyrum, ormercury; mercurialism.
Wisdom derived from severe experience; hence, repentance. [R.]Bp. Montagu.
That point in the orbit of a double star where the smaller staris farthest from its primary.
A contrivance for holding and turning a drill. Knight.
Published under the name of some one other than the author.

One who holds or possesses lands, or other real estate, by anykind of right, whether in fee simple, in common, in severalty, forlife, for years, or at will; also, one who has the occupation ortemporary possession of lands or tenements the title of which is inanother; -- correlative to landlord. See Citation from Blackstone,under Tenement, 2. Blount. Wharton.
The act of symbolizing; symbolical representation. Sir T.Browne.
A genus of coniferous trees, properly called Fir, as the balsamfir and the silver fir. The spruces are sometimes also referred tothis genus.
A house on deck, where the cooking is done; -- commonly calledthe galley.
An astringent and narcotic drug made from the dried leaves andseed capsules of wild hemp (Cannabis Indica), and chewed or smoked inthe East as a means of intoxication. See Hasheesh.
Of or pertaining to the three great splanchnic cavities,namely, that of the head, the chest, and the abdomen; -- applied tothe sympathetic nervous system.
A kind of hard artificial stone, used for pavements.
A process of printing, ornamenting, or carving, by burning withheated instruments.
A jocosely depreciative name for a vehicle. [Ireland]
The condition of being mazed; confusion; astonishment. [Obs.]Chaucer.
Want of strength; weakness; feebleness. [Obs.] Wyclif.
Electric by virtue of its own peculiar properties; capable ofbecoming electrified by friction; -- opposed to anelectric.-- n.
A right whereby one thing is subject to another thing or personfor use or convenience, contrary to the common right.
A figure by which synonymous words are used to amplify adiscourse.
A special branch, resembling a leaf, as in the apparent foliageof the broom (Ruscus) and of the common cultivated smilax(Myrsiphillum).
The process by which anything becomes of the color of a lemon;esp., in alchemy, the state of perfection in the philosopher's stoneindicated by its assuming a deep yellow color. Thynne.
The addition of a letter at the end of a word, without changingits sense; as, numb for num, whilst for whiles.
Figuratively [Obs.]; by way of allusion; by implication,suggestion, or insinuation.
A musical istrument of percussion, consisting of bars yieldingmusical tones when struck. Knight.

In cost accounting, expenditure which is involved in theprocess of manufacture or the performance of work and which cannot becharged directly to any particular article manufactured or work done(as where different kinds of goods are produced), but must beallocated so that each kind of goods or work shall bear its propershare. [Brit.]
A cylindrical pipe fitting, having a number of lateral outlets,for connecting one pipe with several others.
To recall something by means of memory; to remember. [Obs.]Bryskett.
Immovable articulation by close union, as in sutures. Itsometimes includes symphysial articulations also. See the Note underArticulation, n., 1.
A photographic picture obtained by the use of a cyanide.
A short, thick piece of anything. [Colloq. U. S. & Prov. Eng.]
One of several large wading birds of the genera Mycteria andXenorhynchus, allied to the storks in form and habits.
One of certain upright timbers on the bilge ways, used tosupport a vessel in launching. Totten.
A nonacid compound consisting of one equivalent of sulphur andmore than one equivalent of some other body, as a metal.
A memorandum of a sale, and time when payment is due, given tothe purchaser at a sale of goods.
The mucilaginous drupaceous fruit of two East Indian trees(Cordia Myxa, and C. latifolia), sometimes used medicinally inpectoral diseases.
The tendency of a mass of matter toward a center of attraction;esp., the tendency of a body toward the center of the earth;terrestrial gravitation.
To embarrass with difficulties; to make a bungle or botch of.[Local, U. S.]
An embryo or certain invertebrates in the stage when theprimitive band is first developed.
A metallic substance, resembling gold in color, but inferior invalue; a mixed metal of the ancients, resembling brass; -- calledalso aurichalcum, orichalcum, etc.

A genus of long, slender, nematoid worms, parasitic in insectsuntil near maturity, when they leave the insect, and live in water,in which they deposit their eggs; -- called also hair eel, hairworm,and hair snake, from the absurd, but common and widely diffused,notion that they are metamorphosed horsehairs.
A ship or vessel employed in the business of taking fish, as inthe cod fishery.
One who collects illustrations from various books for thedecoration of one book.
An acute infectious febrile disease, resembling typhoid fever,with muscular pains, disturbance of the digestive organs, jaundice,etc.
An instrument attached to the wheel of a vehicle, to measurethe distance traversed; also, a wheel used by surveyors, whichregisters the miles and rods traversed.
To strip of a mask or disguise; to lay open; to expose.
A white, amorphous, insoluble substance regarded as a polymericvariety of chloral.
A liqueur distilled from fermented cherry juice, and flavoredwith the pit of a variety of cherry which grows in Dalmatia.

A yellowish beetle (Doryphora decemlineata), with tenlongitudinal, black, dorsal stripes. It has migrated eastwards fromits original habitat in Colorado, and is very destructive to thepotato plant; -- called also potato beetle and potato bug. See Potatobeetle.
An animated picture machine for screen projection; acinematograph.
Not capable of being pierced; impenetrable. [Obs.] Spenser.
The Anglicized form of the French arpenteur, a land surveyor.[R.]

A group of acalephs of which Lucernaria is the type. The bodyis cup-shaped with eight marginal lobes bearing clavate tentacles. Anaboral sucker serves for attachment. The interior is divided intofour large compartments. See Lucernarida.
One who forges, makes, of forms; a fabricator; a falsifier.
A contractile striated layer found in the bodies and stems ofcertain Infusoria.
A mock moon; an image of the moon which sometimes appears atthe point of intersection of two lunar halos. Cf. Parhelion.
The larva of a small tortricid moth which eats the leaves ofthe cranberry, so that the vines look as if burned; -- called alsocranberry worm.
Relating to the correcting or straightening out of something;corrective.
Like a huswife; capable; economical; prudent.-- adv.
To deprive of synonymous character; to discriminate in use; --applied to words which have been employed as synonyms. Coleridge.Trench.
Having broad scutella on the front, and small scales on theposterior side, of the tarsus; -- said of certain birds.
A game arranged as a test of superiority; also, one of a seriesof such games.
A North American herb (Heuchera Americana) of the Saxifragefamily, whose root has astringent properties.
Quality or state of being ventose; windiness; hence, vainglory;pride. Bacon.
Pertaining to phosphorite; resembling, or of the nature of,phosphorite.
A genus of composite plants with white or colored dry andpersistent involucres; a kind of everlasting.
Fated or decreed with something else. [R.] A. Tucker.
One of a sect among the Jews in the time of our Savior,remarkable for their strictness and abstinence.
A waxlike mineral resin; -- sometimes called native paraffin,and mineral wax.

A plan proposed to the Pope in 1891 by P. P.
