Having the form or nature of air, or of an elastic fluid;gaseous. Hence fig.: Unreal.
Somewhat shrubby in character; imperfectly shrubby, as theAmerican species of Wistaria.
Antiq.) A military cloak worn by a general and his principalofficers.
A massive piece of stone or wood laid immediately on the abacusof the capital of a column or pillar; -- now called architrave.
The act of impoverishing, or the state of being impoverished;reduction to poverty. Sir W. Scott.
A contrivance to fasten logs together in rafting; -- used bylumbermen. [U.S.]
One who maintains that animals of the same species have sprungfrom more than one original pair; -- opposed to monogenist.
An aspect of the planets when they are distant from each otherthe twelfth part of a circle, or thirty degrees. Hutton.
An evergreen shrub of the genus Erica (E. passerina).
The corner where the upper and under eyelids meet on each sideof the eye.
An extinct genus of large Eocene ungulates allied to Dinoceras.This name is sometimes used for nearly all the known species of thegroup. See Dinoceras.
The state or quality of being clear or bright; brightness;conspicuosness. [R.] Chapman.
The principles, practices, or organization of the Carbonari.
A solid figure inclosed or bounded by four triangles.
Consisting of, or containing, gristle; like gristle;cartilaginous.
Reproved by one's own conscience or one's own sense of guilt.
Minute vesicles surrounded by an area of reddened skin,produced by excessive sweating.
A rupture or hernia in the scrotum; scrotal hernia.
An error in regard to the place of an event or a thing; areferring something to a wrong place. [R.]
Harsh and offensive, as a color; tawdry or in bad taste, as acombination of colors, or any design or work of art.
Trembling or vaccilating, as if about to fall; unsteady;shaking. Johnson.
One of a class of marauders or bandits that formerly infestedthe border country between England and Scotland; -- so called inallusion to the mossy or boggy character of much of the bordercountry.
Suspiciousness; cause for suspicion. [Obs. & R.] Ld. Berners.
Wood of the jack (Artocarpus integrifolia), used incabinetwork.
In the direction toward which stars appear to move. SeeFollowing, 2.

A strong, durable, and elastic wood of a purplish color,obtained from several tropical American leguminous trees of the genusCopaifera (C. pubiflora, bracteata, and officinalis). Used fordecorative veneering. See Copaiba.
A compound of a binary type containing two atoms of iodine; --called also biniodide.
Belonging to, or designating, the modern revival of classical,esp. Greco-Roman, taste and manner of work in architecture, etc.
The art or process of converting skins into leather. See Tan,v. t., 1.
To diminish the quantity of; to disquantity. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
To heal or induce the formation of a cicatrix in, as in woundedor ulcerated flesh. Wiseman.
A neglect or failure of delivery; omission of delivery.
Any proposition which is subject to the process of conversion;-- so called in its relation to itself as converted, after whichprocess it is termed the conversae. See Converse, n. (Logic).
The suborder of primates which includes the monkeys, apes, andman.
The state of a communty which permits promiseuous sexualintercourse among its members, as in certain societies practicingcommunism.
A species of hickory (Carya alba) whose outer bark is loose andpeeling; a shagbark; also, its nut.
A certain game at cards in which, if no player wins three ofthe five tricks possible on any deal, the game is said to be spoiled.
The sister of one's husband or wife; also, the wife of one'sbrother; sometimes, the wife of one's husband's or wife's brother.

A real right, susceptible of assignment and of descent, chargedon productive real estate, the right being coupled with the enjoymentof the property on condition of taking care of the estate and payingtaxes, and sometimes a small rent. Heumann.
That which is part fable and part truth; a mixture of truth andfable. De Quincey.
Of the nature of camphor; containing camphor. Dunglison.
Measured by sixty degrees; fixed or indicated by a distance ofsixty degrees. Glanvill.
Producing spines; bearing thorns or spines; thorny; spiny.
To modify or qualify with respect to quantity; to fix orexpress the quantity of; to rate.
Having a rough grain or fiber; hence, figuratively, havingcoarse traits of character; not polished; brisque.
An elephant that is furnished with a pad for carrying burdensinstead of with a howdah for carrying passengers.
One of a tribe of Amphibia, which have both lungs and gills atthe same time, as the proteus and siren.
To become publicly known. [R.] "To keep it from divulging."Shak.
An action at law; a suit in equity or admiralty; any legalproceeding before a court for the enforcement of a claim.
One who, or that which, matches; a matching machine. See under3d Match.
Having one of the two florets in the same spikelet neuter, andthe other unisexual, whether male or female; -- said of grasses.
Nonresistance; passive submission; irresistance. Bp. Hall.

The uniform prescribed in regulations for active or routineservice, in distinction from dress, full dress, etc. In the UnitedStates army it is of olive-drab woolen or khaki-colored cotton, withall metal attachments of dull-finish bronze, with the exceptional ofinsignia of rank, which are of gold or silver finish.
Of or pertaining to the Struthiones, or Ostrich tribe.
The windowpane (Pleuronectes maculatus). [Local, U. S.]
A sort of fricassee with white sauce, variously made of capon,fish, etc. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Flighty; passing rapidly from one subject to another; nothaving the faculty of attention. Bacon.
Oviparous, but hatching the egg while it is within the body, assome fishes and reptiles.
The division of fishes which includes the rays and skates.
The quality of being alternative, or of offering a choicebetween two.
A stereoscope adapted to view distant natural objects orlandscapes; a telescopic stereoscope.
Any one of several species of large, elongated, marine fishesof the genus Cryptacanthodes, especially C. maculatus of the Americancoast. A whitish variety is called ghostfish.
A continuous and, usually, structureless layer which coversmore or less of the exterior of many corals.
A gelatin dynamite in which the dope is composed largely ofsodium nitrate.
The famous mythic Thracian poet, son of the Muse Calliope, andhusband of Eurydice. He is reputed to have had power to entrancebeasts and inanimate objects by the music of his lyre.
A cloth, the weft of which is of woolen yarn, and the warp ofcotton and silk, -- used for w
A genus of climbing plants, native of Mexico and South America.C. scandens is a consrvatory climber with large bell-shaped flowers.
Relating to glyptography, or the art of engraving on preciousstones. [R.]
The state or position of being a painter. [R.] Br. Gardiner.
A building or apartment for silkworms, when feeding and formingcocoons.
A mode of propagating trees by bending branches to the ground,and covering the small shoots with earth; layering. Chambers.
Of or pertaining to Monophysites, or their doctrines.
Incapable of being parted; inseparable. [Obs.] Chaucer. Wyclif.
Characterized by dimorphism; occurring under two distinctforms, not dependent on sex; dimorphic.
An instrument for measuring time by the running of sand. SeeHourglass.
Having three furrows, forks, or prongs; having three grooves orsulci; three-grooved.
The bathing of the feet, a bath for the feet. [Obs.]
The book containing the service of the Mass for the entireyear; a Mass book.
The act or power of giving by testament, or will. [R.] Burke.
A mental disorder in which melancholy and gloomy views tormentthe affected person, particularly concerning his own health.
The state of being healthy or healthful; freedom from disease.
A pit in the form of an inverted cone or pyramid, constructedas an obstacle to the approach of an enemy, and having a pointedstake in the middle. The pits are called also trapholes.
A light in which high illuminating power is obtained byintroducing a jet of oxygen gas or of common air into the center of aflame fed with coal gas or with oil.

To reduce to scoria or slag; specifically, in assaying, to fuseso as to separate the gangue and earthy material, with borax, lead,soda, etc., thus leaving the gold and silver in a lead button; hence,to separate from, or by means of, a slag.
Borne in the escutcheon with his tail doubled between his legs;-- said of a lion.
One who describes the universe; one skilled in cosmology.
In general, any piece of a frame which resists thrust orpressure in the direction of its own length. See Brace, and Illust.of Frame, and Roof.
Incapable of being defined or described; inexplicable. Bp.Reynolds.
The literary style of Dr. Samuel Johnson, or one formed inimitation of it; an inflated, stilted, or pompous style, affectingclassical words. E. Everett.
To act as a bishop; to fill the office of a prelate. [Obs.]Feeding the flock episcopating. Milton.
The art of copying works in relief, or of engraving as to givethe subject an embossed or raised appearance; -- used in representingcoins, bas-reliefs, etc.
Short curls dangling over the temples; -- fashionable in thereign of Charles II. [Obs.] Farquhar.
The carrion crow; -- called also gercrow. [Prov. Eng.]
The doctrine of Jansen regarding free will and divine grace.
The state of being conventional; adherence to socialformalities or usages; that which is established by conventional use;one of the customary usages of social life.
A contrivance used to supply small quantities of sweetenedliquid, water, etc., to any mixture, or to test tubes, etc.; adropping bottle.
A curious American mole (Condylura cristata) having the noseexpanded at the end into a stellate disk; -- called also star-nosedmole.
Conforming to the principles of the Jesuits. Milton.
A rascal; a good-for-nothing fellow. [Colloq.] Howitt.
Between rami or branches; esp., between the mandibles, or ramiof the lower jaw; intermandibular.
A name applied by Dujardin in 1835 to the gelatinous materialforming the bodies of the lowest animals; protoplasm.
To cause to become like the Scotch; to make Scottish. [R.]
One who makes much use of proverbs in speech or writing; onewho composes, collects, or studies proverbs.
Inciting to motion; -- applied to that action which, in thecase of muscular motion, commences in the nerve centers, and excitesthe muscles to contraction. Opposed to excito-motor.
Of or pertaining to a tutor; belonging to, or exercised by, atutor.
Relating to a structure composed of a circular range ofcolumns, without a core or building within. Weale.
The state of torpidity induced by the heat and dryness ofsummer, as in certain snails; -- opposed to hibernation.
A fragrant substance which is the chief constituent ofambergris.
To bluster; to swagger; to bully; to be bold, noisy, vaunting,or turbulent.I have a roisting challenge sent amongst The dull and factious noblesof the Greeks. Shak.
Pertaining to doxology; giving praise to God. Howell.

A species of cassowary (Casuarius Bennetti) found in NewBritain, and noted for its agility in running and leaping. It issmaller and has stouter legs than the common cassowary. Its crest isbiloted; the neck and breast are black; the back, rufous mixed withblack; and the naked skin of the neck, blue.
The watery eye; a disease in which the tears accumulate in theeye, and trickle over the cheek.
An explosive mixture, consisting of sawdust, charcoal, niter,and ferrocyanide of potassium, used as a substitute for gunpowder.
To drive about; to drive here and there. [Obs.] Rom. of R.
Resting on a track at the bottom, instead of being suspended; -- said of a sliding door. Forney.
A hood over the end of a wagon wheel hub to keep dirt away fromthe axle.
A written account or description of a single thing, or class ofthings; a special treatise on a particular subject of limited range.

The infernal regions, described in the Iliad as situated as farbelow Hades as heaven is above the earth, and by later writers as theplace of punishment for the spirits of the wicked. By the laterpoets, also, the name is often used synonymously with Hades, or theLower World in general.
The office, province, or jurisdiction of a waywode.
A small sail sometimes set under a studding sail or under adriver boom, and reaching nearly to the water.
One of those who commenced the reformation of religion in thesixteenth century, as Luther, Melanchthon, Zwingli, and Calvin.
A form of dentine which shows sinuous lines of structure in atransverse section of the tooth.
An herbaceous plant (Trillium erectum), and its astringentrootstock, which is said to have medicinal properties.
A writing signed by both or all the parties to a contract orbond.
A popular name given to a few species of the genus Careopsis,especially to C. tinctoria of Arkansas.
A form of fruit in the cycle of development of the Rusts orBrands, an order of fungi, formerly considered independent plants.
Having a valence of five; -- said of certain atoms andradicals.
Capable of being disposed of in traffic; marketable. [Obs.] Bp.Hall.
The branch of science which treats of the formation of theearth.
Having ten columns in front; -- said of a portico, temple, etc.-- n.
One of no merit; one who is nor deserving or worthy. [Obs.]Shak.
A peculiar and complicated system of versification, borrowed bythe early Italian poets from the Troubadours.
Argumentative; discursive; reasoning. [R.] Bp. Hall.
Making or doing throughly; efficient; effectual. [R.]Blackstone.
One of the abdominal legs of a crustacean. See Illust. underCrustacea.
To play the politician; to dispute as politicians do. [Obs.]Milton.
A literary or a musical composition formed by selections fromdifferent authors disposed in a new order.
The science of fruits; a treatise on fruits; the cultivation offruits and fruit trees.
Suitable for association or companionship. [Obs.] Sir H.Wotton.
The period before puberty, or from birth to fourteen in males,and twelve in females.
A low fellow; a stinkard; a scoundrel. [Obs.] Shak.
A chief butler; -- an officer of the German empire.
Pertaining to, affected with, or of the nature of, epilepsy.
Having, or relating to the power of producing heat; -- appliedto foods which, being rich in carbon, as the fats, are supposed togive rise to heat in the animal body by oxidation.
Capable of being thought or conceived; cogitable. Sir W.Hamilton.
To underlet a proportion of, for a single crop; -- said of afarm. [Ireland]
Coated with icing; iced; glazed; -- said of fruits, sweetmeats,cake, etc.
Relating to, or containing, Jehovah, as a name of God; -- saidof certain parts of the Old Testament, especially of the Pentateuch,in which Jehovah appears as the name of the Deity. See Elohistic.
A fine white wine produced on the estate of Schloss (or Castle)Johannisberg, on the Rhine.
One of a sect of philosophers in the Middle Ages, who adoptedthe opinion of Roscelin, that general conceptions, or universals,exist in name only. Reid.
The act of enswathing, or the state of being enswathed.
An inferior kind of vanilla, the pods of Vanilla Pompona.
With reflection; also, with censure; reproachfully. Swift.
To throw or pour back, as from a deep or hollow place; to pouror throw back in great quantity.
Steel deriving its qualities from carbon chiefly, without thepresence of other alloying elements; --opposed to alloy steel.
Occurring or appearing once every two weeks; fortnightly.-- n.
One of the substances of which vegetable tissue is composed,differing from cellulose in its solubility in certain media.
Congenitally united with an organ of another kind, as calyxwith ovary, or stamens with petals.
Gold and silver paper burned by the Chinese, in the form ofcoins or ingots, in worship and at funerals.

The fruit of the tree Punica Granatum; also, the tree itself(see Balaustine), which is native in the Orient, but is successfullycultivated in many warm countries, and as a house plant in colderclimates. The fruit is as large as an orange, and has a hard rindcontaining many rather large seeds, each one separately covered withcrimson, acid pulp.
A sulphide of lead and antimony, of a blackish lead-gray colorand metallic luster.
A species of mixed action, which lies for the recovery ofpossession of real property, and damages and costs for the wrongfulwithholding of it. Wharton.
The state of being savage; the state of rude, uncivilized men,or of men in their native wildness and rudeness.

A univalve mollusk of the genus Haliotis. The shell is linedwith mother-of-pearl, and used for ornamental purposes; the sea-ear.Several large species are found on the coast of California, clingingclosely to the rocks.
Inflammation of the synovial sheath enveloping a tendon.
One attached to the policy or family of Bonaparte, or of theBonapartes.
In a disinterested manner; without bias or prejudice.
The science of method or arrangement; a treatise on method.Coleridge.
A short note, equal in time to the half of a semiquaver, or thethirty-second part of a whole note.
To represent by an image, form, model, or resemblance.Our Savior was typified, indeed, by the goat that was slain, and thescapegoat in the wilderness. Sir T. Browne.
The hooded crow; also, in Scotland, the hooded gull.
A conical valve, opening outward, to close the mouth of a pipewhich passes through the side of a vessel below the water line.
The chitinous ribbon bearing the teeth of mollusks; -- calledalso lingual ribbon, and tongue. See Odontophore.

A celebrated Latin hymn, beginning with these words,commemorating the sorrows of the mother of our Lord at the foot ofthe cross. It is read in the Mass of the Sorrows of the Virgin Mary,and is sung by Catholics when making "the way of the cross" (ViaCrucis). See Station, 7 (c).
The act of refunding; also, that which is refunded. [R.] Lamb.

One of the quinine group of alkaloids, found especially in redcinchona bark. It is a white crystalline substance, C19H22N2O, with abitter taste and qualities similar to, but weaker than, quinine; --sometimes called also cinchonidia.
A slope or declivity in a manege ground down which a horse ismade to gallop, to give suppleness to his haunches.
A tubelike marking, occuring in sandstone and other strata.

A piece of linen about 1 ft. 8 in. wide by 213 ft. long,covered with embroidery representing the incidents of William theConqueror's expedition to England, preserved in the town museum ofBayeux in Normandy. It is probably of the 11th century, and isattributed by tradition to Matilda, the Conqueror's wife.
An ornamental foliation consisting of more than five divisionsor foils. [R.] See Foil.
The state of being discontented; uneasiness; inquietude. Bacon.
meadow irrigated by water from a spring or rivulet on the sideof hill.
To weaken, as to the body or the mind; to enfeeble. [R.] A.Wilson.
Any inflammation of the joints, particularly the gout.
To retard; to repel; to do damage to. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Shot or bits of iron used sometimes in loading cannon.

An eruption of the skin, taking various names, according to itsform, or the part affected; especially, an eruption of vesicles insmall distinct clusters, accompanied with itching or tingling,including shingles, ringworm, and the like; -- so called from itstendency to creep or spread from one part of the skin to another.

Exciting motion; -- said of that portion of the nervous systemconcerned in reflex action, by which impressions are transmitted to anerve center and then reflected back so as to produce muscularcontraction without sensation or volition.
One who has a reversion, or who is entitled to lands ortenements, after a particular estate granted is terminated.Blackstone.
The art or practice of burning pictures on wood with a hotiron; -- called also poker painting. See Poker picture, under Poker.
The stay extending from the foot of the foremast to themaintop.
The act of kindling, or the state of being kindled or on fire.Bacon.
One who, or that which, hacks. Specifically: A cuttinginstrument for making notches; esp., one used for notching pine treesin collecting turpentine; a hack.
Of or pertaining to the north; toward the north, or from thenorth; northern.
Represented as running; -- said of a beast borne in a coat ofarms.
An intentional perversion of truth for the purpose of obtainingsome valuable thing or promise from another.
An officer who has charge of the boats, sails, rigging, colors,anchors, cables, cordage, etc., of a ship, and who also summons thecrew, and performs other duties.
Not admitting of being vitrified, or converted into glass.Kirwan.
Lit., for whose benefit; incorrectly understood, it came to beused in the sense, of what good or use; and hence, (what) purpose;object; specif., the ultimate object of life.
Of or pertaining to glanders; of the nature of glanders.Youatt.
An itinerant player on the musette, an instrument formerlycommon in Europe.
An Algonquin tribe of Indians who formerly inhabited a part ofIllinois.
Slightly increasing an insensible perspiration; mildlydiaphoretic.-- n.
An image or effigy; -- used rather in an abstract sense, andrarely for a work of art.

A common large North American marmot (Arctomys monax). It isusually reddish brown, more or less grizzled with gray. It makesextensive burrows, and is often injurious to growing crops. Calledalso ground hog.
A region infested by rebels; rebels, considered collectively;also, conduct o Thackeray.
Any one of several metameric unsaturated hydrocarbons (C9H14)of the valylene series.
To tend or care for, or to curry or clean, as a, horse.
Too odious to be expressed or mentioned. [Obs.] Howell.
A kind of water found in copper mines; water impregnated withcopper.
A Sicilian dance, resembling the pastorale, set to a ratherslow and graceful melody in 12-8 or 6-8 measure; also, the music tothe dance.
Of or pertaining to the motions of fluids, or the forces whichproduce or affect such motions; -- opposed to hydrostatic. Sir W.Thomson.
Attachment to the principles of the society of Orangemen; thetenets or practices of the Orangemen.
Pertaining to, made of, or resembling, floss; hence, light;downy.
A person who has the care of neat cattle; a cowherd. Dryden.
An interval comprising two octaves and a second. Moore (Encyc.of Music.)
A composition for eight parts, usually for eight soloinstruments or voices.
A stick, carved with lines and dots, used, esp. by Australianaborigines, to convey information.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a hypothetical sulphacid ofantimony (called also thioantimonic acid) analogous to sulpharsenicacid.
The doctrine of philosophical necessity; necessitarianism.Hixley.
A white, sugarlike substance, C6H8.(OH)2, occurring naturallyin a manna from Madagascar, and in certain plants, and producedartificially by the reduction of galactose and lactose or milk sugar.
The first or chief man; as:(a) The chief man of a jury, who acts as their speaker.(b) The chief of a set of hands employed in a shop, or on works ofany kind, who superintends the rest; an overseer.
Of or pertaining to Anam, to southeastern Asia.-- n.
Excessive criticism, or unjust severity or rigor of criticism;zoilism.
Any one of several plants yielding a red pigment which is usedby the North American Indians, as the bloodroot and two species ofLithospermum (L. hirtum, and L. canescens); also, the pigment itself.
A conspiracy or plot, esp. for a malicious or evil purpose, asto incriminate a person on false evidence. [Slang]
That part of anatomy which treats of blood vessels andlymphatics.
To remove grease or fatty matter from, as wool or silk.
Being or coming between; intercedent; interposed. [Obs.] Bacon.

The science or doctrine of the elementary sounds uttered by thehuman voice in speech, including the various distinctions,modifications, and combinations of tones; phonetics. Also, a treatiseon sounds.
Tending, or pertaining, to reproduction; employed inreproduction. Lyell.
To separate or undo, as links; to uncoil; to unfasten. Shak.
Any vessel or canal in which blood circulates in an animal, asan artery or vein.
The system of religion, philosophy, and instruction, receivedand taught by the Druids; the rites and ceremonies of the Druids.
Extending over all the zones, from the tropics to the polarzones inclusive.
A suborder of leeches including those that have a protractileproboscis, without jaws. Clepsine is the type.
A vessel employed to attend other vessels, to supply them withprovisions and other stores, to convey intelligence, or the like.
The class of the Coelenterata which includes the corals and seaanemones. The three principal groups or orders are Acyonaria,Actinaria, and Madreporaria.

A diagram or drawing; made to represent a magnitude or therelation of two or more magnitudes; a surface or space inclosed onall sides; -- called superficial when inclosed by lines, and solidwhen inclosed by surface; any arrangement made up of points, lines,angles, surfaces, etc.
Capable of being written, or of being written upon. [R.]
A beating or throbbing, especially of the heart or of anartery, or in an inflamed part; a beat of the pulse.
Payment of toll; also, the amount or quantity paid as toll.Drayton.
Of a coarse texture; -- applied to silk with a heavy threadrunning crosswise.
An Australian lorikeet (Trichoglossus multicolor) remarkablefor the variety and brilliancy of its colors; -- called also blue-bellied lorikeet, and blue-bellied parrot.
Having hollow teeth; -- said of a group lizards.-- n.
Cast steel containing a considerable percentage of manganese,which makes it very hard and tough. See Alloy steel, above.
Of or pertaining to Ahura-Mazda, or Ormuzd, the beneficentdeity in the Zoroastrian dualistic system; hence, Zoroastrian.
To steal in small quantities, or articles of small value; topractice petty theft.
Anything which brings misfortune upon one, or causes failure inan effort or enterprise; a reverse. [Scot.]
A warlike tribe of indians, related to the blackfeet, formerlyinhabiting the region of Wyoming, but now mostly on reservations inthe Indian Territory. They are noted for their horsemanship.
An oxide of zinc which collects on the sides of furnaces wherezinc is sublimed. Formerly applied to the mineral calamine.
A Dominican friar; -- so named because, before the FrenchRevolution, that order had a convent in the Rue St. Jacques, Paris.
Uttered by the aid of the palate; -- said of certain sounds, asthe sound of k in kirk.
Continuing for two years, and then perishing, as plants whichform roots and leaves the first year, and produce fruit the second.
Epithelial mesoderm; a layer of cuboidal epithelium cells,formed from a portion of the mesoderm during the differetiation ofthe germ layers. It constitutes the boundary of the coelum.
A cuirass, originally of leather, afterward of plates of metalor horn sewed on linen or the like.
Incommensurable; also, unsymmetrical. [Obs.] D. H. More.
The use of a word in a figurative or extended sense; ametaphor;a trope. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
To make a dwarf of; to stunt or hinder the growth of; to dwarf.Donne.
In a heady or rash manner; hastily; rashly; obstinately.
A cake of Indian meal, water, and salt, baked before the fireor in the ashes; -- so called because often cooked on a hoe.[Southern U.S.]
The act of one who weeps; lamentation with tears; shedding oftears.
Neglect or failure to prepare; want of preparation.
A reader of lectures or discourses; a lecturer. Sheldon.
An address or public prayer read from the steps of the pulpitin Mohammedan mosques, offering glory to God, praising Mohammed andhis descendants, and the ruling princes.
The American hop hornbeam (Ostrya Virginica), a small tree withvery tough wood.
To dethrone; to depose from sovereign authority. Milton.
The process of separation, or the condition of being separate,as of the molecules of a body.
The quality or state of being technical; technicality.
The entire lower surface of the foot;-said of birds, ect.
To call or set as a prisoner at the bar of a court to answer tothe matter charged in an indictment or complaint. Blackstone.
Notice of a proposed marriage, proclaimed in a church, or otherplace prescribed by law, in order that any person may object, if heknows of just cause why the marriage should not take place.
A sulphide of chromium observed in some meteoric irons.
White; -- applied to albinos, from the whiteness of their skinand hair.

An objection, oral or written, taken, in the course of anaction, as to bail or security; or as to the decision of a judge, inthe course of a trail, or in his charge to a jury; or as to lapse oftime, or scandal, impertinence, or insufficiency in a pleading; also,as in conveyancing, a clause by which the grantor excepts somethingbefore granted. Burrill.
Liability to be overset; -- said of a ship or other vessel.
One who capers, leaps, and skips about, or dances.The nimble capperer on the cord. Dryden.
A trailing branch which is disposed to take root at the end orat the joints; a stole.
The resolution of a compound into parts by heat; dissociationby heat.
A service book containing a selection of pieces for thefestival services.
The quality or state of being southerly; direction toward thesouth.
A deep pie or pudding made of baked apples, or of sliced breadand apples baked together, with no bottom crust.
A genus of fungi having the under surface full of minute pores;also, any fungus of this genus.
One who swears to another's credibility. W. Wotton.
An uncouth or disagreable sound of words, owing to theconcurrence of harsh letters or syllables. "Cacophonies of allkinds." Pope.

The platforms, consisting of two or more planks doweledtogether, for the flooring of a temporary military bridge. Wilhelm.A singular, chess, is sometimes used. "Each chess consists of threeplanks." Farrow.
One of a fabulous race of dwarfs who waged war with the cranes,and were destroyed.
In a manner, or to a degree, that precludes remedy, cure, orcorrection.
One who, or that which, hardens; specif., one who temperstools.
A glass of fishes having a suckerlike mouth, without jaws, asthe lamprey; the Marsipobranchii.
One of a class of poets which flourished in Nuremberg and someother cities of Germany in the 15th and 16th centuries. They boundthemselves to observe certain arbitrary laws of rhythm.
A blue coloring matter supposed by some to be one of thecomponent parts ofchlorophyll.
One of the contestants in interference before the PatentOffice. [U.S.]
Am Austrian silver coin equivalent to 20 kreutzers, or about 10cents.
To pour (something) over or on something else. [Obs.] Evelyn.

An adherent of Nestorius, patriarch of Constantinople to thefifth century, who has condemned as a heretic for maintaining thatthe divine and the human natures were not merged into one nature inChrist (who was God in man), and, hence, that it was improper to callMary the mother of Christ; also, one of the sect established by thefollowers of Nestorius in Persia, india, and other Orientalcountries, and still in existence. opposed to Ant: Eutychian.
A merman; the male of the mermaid. [R.] "Not to mentionmermaids or seamen." Locke.
Pyrography; also, a design or picture made by pyrography.
The top member of a pillar, pier, wall, etc., upon which theweight of an arch rests.
The distal segment of the fore limb, including the carpus andfore foot or hand.
Literally, a letter word; a word represented by a logogram; as,it, represented by |, that is, t. pitman.
A common gray European moth (Halia vauaria) having a V-shapedspot of dark brown on each of the fore wings.
A duty or toil paid for weighing merchandise. Bouvier.
One of tow equal parts of a line, or other magnitude.
The state or quality of being congenial; natural affinity;adaptation; suitableness.  Sir J. Reynolds.
The act or condition of holding chattels; the state of being achattel.
A white crystalline substance derived from urethane, used inmedicine as an antipyretic, etc.
An intimate union of the soul with God in contemplation, -- anideal of the Neoplatonists and of some Oriental mystics.
The long flower stems of the ribwort plantain (PlantagoLanceolata). Dr. Prior.
Of the nature of melody; relating to, containing, or made upof, melody; melodious.
The upper faceted portion of a brilliant-cut diamond, whichprojects from the setting and occupies the zone between the girdleand the table. See Brilliant, n.
Capable of being sued; subject by law to be called to answer incourt. Story.
One of a tribe of beetles, having long maxillary palpi.
Measurement of the height and other dimensions of human beings,especially at different ages, or in different races, occupations,etc. Dunglison.
The native name of a South American rutaceous shrub (Pilocarpuspennatifolius). The leaves are used in medicine as an diaphoretic andsialogogue.
or conj. Moreover; besides; in addition to what has been said.
A shelf behind the altar, for display of lights, vases ofwlowers, etc.
Of or pertaining to the placoderms; like the placoderms.
Solemnness.Some think he wanted solemnes. Sir H. Wotton.
The clouded tiger cat (Felis marmorata) of Southern Asia andthe East Indies.
A direct descending blow with the edge of a sword. [Obs.] B.Jonson.
Dividing the partitions; -- said of a method of dehiscence inwhich a pod splits through the partitions and is divided into itscomponent carpels.

That branch of science which treats of the laws governing thephysical or mechanical, in distinction from the vital, forces, andwhich comprehends the consideration and general investigation of thewhole range of the forces concerned in physical phenomena. [R.]
Oblong. with one end narrower than the other; ovato-oblong.
A small, graceful, and swift African antelope, allied to theklipspringer.
A white person; -- an appellation supposed to have been appliedto the whites by the American Indians. J. F. Cooper.
Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid (called alsononoic acid) found in the leaves of the geranium (Pelargonium) andallied plants.
Relating to that tribe of ruminant mammals of which the genusBos is the type.
One who is half squire and half farmer; -- used humorously.[Eng.] C. Kingsley.
A person called to make up a deficiency in the number of jurorswhen a tales is awarded. Wharton.
The wood of the Rhus Cptinus or Venice sumach, a shrub ofSouthern Europe, which yields a fine orange color, which, however, isnot durable without a mordant. Ure.
A treatise on teaching or education. [Obs.] Milton.
The dorsal plate of the prothorax in insects. See Illust. ofColeoptera.
A vacant space, or gap, esp. between teeth in a jaw.
Any vessel or boat plying on water; vessels and boats,collectively.
A system of bracing bars, not crossing each other in themiddle, connecting the channel bars of a compound strut. Waddell.
A device with fingers or jaws for seizing an object and holdingor conveying it; as, in a printing press, a clasp for catching asheet and conveying it to the form.
Flowing sevenfold; divided into seven streams or currents. [R.]Fuller.
The act or process of forming spores; spore formation. SeeIllust. of Bacillus, b.
The state of being busy; multitude of business. [Obs.]
A composition irregular in form, like an improvisation; as,Liszt's "Hungarian Rhapsodies."
Matter stated by way of explanatory preamble or introduction tothe main allegations of a pleading; a leading to.

Any plant or species of the genus Isoetes, cryptogamous plantswith a cluster of elongated four-tubed rushlike leaves, rising from acorm, and containing spores in their enlarged and excavated bases.There are about seventeen American species, usually growing in themud under still, shallow water. So called from the shape of the shapeof the leaves.
The branch of science which treats of the ear and its diseases.
A lateral half of the heart, either the right or left. B. G.Wilder.
One who affects excessive refinement and elegance of language;-- applied esp. to a class of writers, in the age of Elizabeth, whoseproductions are marked by affected conceits and high-flown diction.
To interpret (mythology) on the theory of euhemerism.
The posterior part of the brain, including the medulla; theafterbrain. Sometimes abbreviated to meten.
A weight by which lead and some other metals were formerlysold, in England, varying from 19 [Obs.]
Having the form of a cucumber; having the form of a cylindertapered and rounded at the ends, and either straight or curved.
A grayish green antiseptic powder, consisting of a basic iodideand gallate of bismuth, sometimes used in place of iodoform. [ATrademark]
Commonly used as an auxiliary verb, either in the past tense orin the conditional or optative present. See 2d & 3d Will.
The act of voiding urine; also, a morbidly frequent passing ofthe urine, in consequence of disease.
An explosive containing nitroglycerin. It is used in blasting.
An aromatic bark used as a tonic, obtained from a SouthAmerican of the rue family (Galipea cusparia, or officinalis). U. S.Disp.

An immense leguminous tree (Pithecolobium Saman) of Venezuela.Its branches form a hemispherical mass, often one hundred and eightyfeet across. The sweet pulpy pods are used commonly for feedingcattle. Also called rain tree. J. Smith (Dict. Econ. Plants).
A block of type metal lower than the letters, -- used inspacing and in blank lines. [Abbrev. quad.]
An optical property of some crystals which exhibit a star-shaped by reflected light, as star sapphire, or by transmitted light,as some mica.
A sulphide having two atoms of sulphur in the molecule; adisulphide, as in iron pyrites, FeS2; -- less frequently calledbisulphuret.
The science which treats of rays of light, especially of theactinic or chemical rays.
A minor subdivision at the base of the Cambrian system inWales.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a subdivision of the TrentonPeriod of the Lower Silurian, characterized in the State of New Yorkby beds of shale.
Of or pertaining to Horace, the Latin poet, or resembling hisstyle.
A local division of the people in ancient Athens; a clan; atribe.
Of or pertaining to a chain of mountains in the United States,commonly called the Allegheny mountains.
The act of honesting; grace; adornment. [Obs.] W. Montagu.
A variety of datolite, usually having a botryoidal structure.
A small wooden pail or tub with an upright stave for a handle,-- often used as a dipper.
The elevation of the hand, or that part of the bar at which itis raised, in beating time; the weak or unaccented part of the bar; -- opposed to thesis. Moore.
The front piece of a cap; -- now more commonly called visor.
An affectation of excessive elegance and refinement oflanguage; high-flown diction.
A large North American aquatic salamander (Protonopsis horridaor Menopoma Alleghaniensis). It is very voracious and very tenaciousof life. Also called alligator, and water dog.
The premium or interest paid by the buyer to the seller, to beallowed to defer paying for the stock purchased until the nextfortnightly settlement day. [Eng.]

A system by which the track is divided into short sections, asof three or four miles, and trains are so run by the guidance ofelectric, or combined electric and pneumatic, signals that no trainenters a section or block until the preceding train has left it, asin absolute blocking, or that a train may be allowed to followanother into a block as long as it proceeds with excessive caution,as in permissive blocking.
The quality of being determinable; determinableness. Coleridge.
Large lumps picked out of the sieve, in dressing ore.
The secant of the complement of an arc or angle. See Illust. ofFunctions.
Willfully disobedient to the summous or prders of a court.Blackstone.
The imaginary milk-white animal on which Mohammed was said tohave been carried up to heaven; a white mule.
The movement which separates a limb or other part from theaxis, or middle line, of the body.
In the Corinthian capital, one of the eight stalks rising outof the lower leafage and terminating in leaves which seem to suportthe volutes. See Illust. of Corinthian order, under Corinthian.
A sack to hold miscellaneous articles, as tools, supplies, orthe like.
The first of the four pieces composing the dorsal part, ortergum, of a thoracic segment of an insect. It is usually small andinconspicuous.
Constructed of a timber frame, having the spaces filled in withmasonry; -- said of buildings.
A whitish soluble powder used as a developer in photography.Chemically, it is the sulphate of methyl-p-amino-m-cresol.
A long patch, on a balloon, to be ripped off, by the rip cord,at landing, in order to allow the immediate escape of gas and instantdeflation of the bag.
Anhydrous sodium sulphate, a mineral of a white or brown colorand vitreous luster.
Toward the higher part of a stream; against the current.
To find fault with; to scold; to overwhelm with wordy abuse; tocensure severely or abusively; to rate.
One who writes shorthand; a stenographer; esp., an ancientGreek or Roman notary.
Leaning forward; -- said of certain monosyllabic words whichare so closely attached to the following word as not to have aseparate accent.
The female of the bullfinch; -- called also tonyhoop. [Prov.Eng.]
Damaged by accidental exposure to light; light-fogged; -- saidof plates or films.

One of the higher aromatic hydrocarbons of coal tar, allied tonapthalene and anthracene. It is a white crystalline substance,C18H12, of strong blue fluorescence, but generally colored yellow byimpurities.
Specifically, ill from menstruation; affected with, or having,catamenial; menstruant.
A deformity in which the urethra opens upon the top of thepenis, instead of at its extremity.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acidobtained by decomposition of melam, or of urea, as a whitecrystalline powder; -- called also melanurenic acid.
Virginia; -- a name of uncertain origin, perh. from the olddesignation of the colony as "the Colony and Dominion of Virginia."
A blue coloring matter found in the pus from old sores,supposed to be formed through the agency of a species of bacterium(Bacillus pyocyaneus).C13H10N2O
A composition for infernal purposes; a magical preparation.Shak.
Above, or on the dorsal side of, the axis of the skeleton;episkeletal.
Situated beneath the acromial process of the scapula.
One of the principal divisions of Alcyonaria, including thoseforms which have a firm and usually branched axis, covered with aporous crust, or c
An inferior kind of cheese made from skim milk with a fatty"filling," such as oleomargarine or lard, to replace the fat removedin the cream.
A door in the back part of a building; hence, an indirect way.Atterbury.
The person to whom property is mortgaged, or to whom a mortgageis made or given.
A yellow crystalline dyestuff, regarded as a glucoside,extracted from a species (Rhamnus Frangula) of the buckthorn; --called also rhamnoxanthin.
An agent of a corporation, or of any body of men engaged in abusiness enterprise; an advocate or patron; an assignee.
The act of flustrating; confusion; flurry. [Colloq.]Richardson.
Applied to a semipermanent contraction of a muscle, produced bya mechanical irritant.
A form of hydrometer, specially graduated, for finding thedensity of milk, and thus discovering whether it has been mixed withwater or some of the cream has been removed.

One who, or that which, hems with a needle. Specifically:(a) An attachment to a sewing machine, for turning under the edge ofa piece of fabric, preparatory to stitching it down.(b) A tool for turning over the edge of sheet metal to make a hem.
An iron club used in lofting the ball; -- called also loftingiron.
An instrument for exhibiting certain chromatic effects of light(depending upon the persistence of vision and mixture of colors) bymeans of rapidly rotating disks variously colored.
One of two Roman officers or magistrates united in the samepublic functions.
Earthenware; vessels formed of baked clay, especially thecoarser kinds.
Of or pertaining to King Arthur or his knights.  J. R. Symonds.
A volcanic area or vent which yields only sulphur vapors,steam, and the like. It represents the stages of the volcanicactivity.
A place where coal is dug, including the machinery for raisingthe coal.
A set or prescribed model; a formula. [Obs.] Johnson.
A special involucre formed of one leaf and inclosing a spadix,as in aroid plants and palms. See the Note under Bract, and Illust.of Spadix.
A kind of mixed dish, as of cooked vegetables with white sauce,sweet jelly with whole fruit, etc. Also, fig., a medley.
A goddess of any stream or other body of water, whether one ofthe Naiads, Nereids, or Oceanides.
One who leases; the person who lets to farm, or gives a lease.Blackstone.
The person who binds himself, or gives his bond to another.Blackstone.
The art, process, or occupation, of making dresses.
A bitter white crystalline glucoside extracted from the rootbark of the apple, pear, cherry, plum, etc. [Formerly also writtenphloridzin.]
A form of government by the multitude; a mobocracy. Hare.
A man whose employment is to drive, or to convey goods in, acar or car.
Introductory; prefatory; preliminary. [R.] Hammond.
The act of meditating or contriving beforehand; previousdeliberation; forethought.
A nutlet resembling a seed, or the kernel of a drupe. Gray.
The name given to a hypothetical element, -- later discoveredand called gallium. See Gallium, and cf. Ekabor.
The state of quality of being infeasible; infeasibility. W.Montagu.
To cheat by boasting and false pretenses; to gull. [R.] Shak.
Those who lived in former ages, as opposed to the moderns.
An instrument for measuring liquids. It consists of a pistonmoving in a tube in which is contained the liquid, the quantityexpelled being indicated by the graduation upon the piston rod.
Of or pertaining to Genoa, a city of Italy.-- n. sing. & pl.
Capable of being broken; brittle; fragile; easily broken.
A name given to several species of Sagina, low andinconspicuous herbs of the Chickweed family.
Of, pertaining to, resembling, or containing, a sulphate orsulphates.
Stylish; modish; elegant; showy; aristocratic; fashionable.[Slang]
A medicine supposed to promote the formation of callus.
A quality analogous to that of a viscous fluid, supposed to becaused by internal friction, especially in the case of gases.
A double cyanide of platinum and some other metal or radical; asalt of platinocyanic acid.
The morbid deposition of black matter, often of a malignantcharacter, causing pigmented tumors.
(Arch.) A draped female figure supporting an entablature, inthe place of a column or pilaster.
Costing or worth three pence; hence, worth but little; poor;mean.
Having an odor of musk, or somewhat the like. Milton.
A place to stand upon; a locus standi; hence, a foundation orbasis for operations.
Situated above the temporal bone or temporal fossa.-- n.
A process from the middle of the coracoid in some animals.
One who watches shoals of fish; a balker. See Balker.
To expel air, or obstructing or irritating matter, from thelungs or air passages, in a noisy and violent manner.
Pertaining to, produced by, or of the nature of, magistery. SeeMagistery, 2.
A fund for the support of a priest, without the title of abenefice. The patron in the collator.

An instrument made like large lute, but having two necks, withtwo sets of pegs, the lower set holding the strings governed byfrets, while to the upper set were attached the long bass stringsused as open notes.
Composed of several carpels consolidated into one ovary.

A water wheel, on which the stream of water strikes neither sohigh as in the overshot wheel, nor so low as in the undershot, butgenerally at about half the height of the wheel, being kept incontact with it by the breasting. The water acts on the float boardspartly by impulse, partly by its weight.
A title given to every one of sons of the kings of Spain andPortugal, except the eldest or heir apparent.
A name given to several species of plants of the genusPolygonum, having angular stems beset with minute reflexed prickles.
A genus of heart-shaped sea urchins belonging to theSpatangoidea.
Destitute of a tail, as the frogs and toads. [Also writtenanourous.]
Drooping of the upper eyelid, produced by paralysis of itslevator muscle.
An anthem or psalm sung before the Communion service.
The operation for the removal of squinting by the division ofsuch muscles as distort the eyeball.
A genus of exinct marine reptiles, allied to the Mosasaurus.See Illust. in Appendix.
A dependent; a hanger-on; -- so called in contempt. B. Jonson.
Capable of being dismounted; -- said of a form of rim, for anautomobile wheel, which can be removed with its tire from the wheel.

An established formula for public worship, or the entire ritualfor public worship in a church which uses prescribed forms; aformulary for public prayer or devotion. In the Roman Catholic Churchit includes all forms and services in any language, in any part ofthe world, for the celebration of Mass.
Making erect or upright; raising; tending to erect.
To wound by clandestine detraction; to censure meanly orspitefully (as absent person); to slander or speak evil of (oneabsent). Spenser.
One of the minute bodies into which the chromatin of thenucleus is resolved during mitotic cell division; the idant ofWeismann.
To cheat; to deceive.She has bubbled him out of his youth. Addison.The great Locke, who was seldom outwitted by false sounds, wasnevertheless bubbled here. Sterne.
A kind of injector for forcing water by steam. See Injector,n., 2.
The quality of being paronymous; also, the use of paronymouswords.
The part a chimney appropriated to the fire; a hearth; --usually an open recess in a wall, in which a fire may be built.
One who redacts; one who prepares matter for publication; aneditor. Carlyle.
The act of keeping fractured limbs cool by the use of a fan orsome other contrivance. Dunglison.
The act of imbittering; bitter feeling; embitterment.
, n. A picture or delineation of the moon's surface, or of anypart of it.
One who, or that which, enlivens, animates, or invigorates.
Having an entire aperture; -- said of many univalve shells.
Used in copulation; -- said of the external reproductive organsof the males of many animals, and sometimes of those of the females.
The parliament of Austria (exclusive of Hungary, which has itsown diet, or parliament). It consists of an Upper and a Lower House,or a House of Lords and a House of Representatives.
To combine with oxygen, as any elementary substance, in suchproportion as to form a protoxide.
Stairs in the back part of a house, as distinguished from thefront stairs; hence, a private or indirect way.
A extinct genus of Branchiopoda, very common in Silurianlimestones.
A slight hit or tip of the ball, often unintentional.
An exact copy of a writing, set forth in the words and figuresof it. It differs from purport, which is only the substance orgeneral import of the instrument. Bouvier.

The repetition of the same letter at the beginning of two ormore words immediately succeeding each other, or at short intervals;as in the following lines: -Behemoth, biggest born of earth, upheaved His vastness. Milton.Fly o'er waste fens and windy fields. Tennyson.
An ornamental and diversified arrangement of beds or plots, inwhich flowers are cultivated, with intervening spaces of gravel orturf for walking on.
A bird fabled to exist single, to be consumed by fire by itsown act, and to rise again from its ashes. Hence, an emblem ofimmortality.
The anterior region or head of insects and other arthropods.Packard.
A truss, framed with a king-post; -- used in roofs, bridges,etc.
A fabric woven like velvet, but with the loops of the warpthreads uncut.

A church festival celebrated on the 6th of January, the twelfthday after Christmas, in commemoration of the visit of the Magi of theEast to Bethlehem, to see and worship the child Jesus; or, as othersmaintain, to commemorate the appearance of the star to the Magi,symbolizing the manifestation of Christ to the Gentles; Twelfthtide.
Incapable of being executed or performed; impracticable;infeasible.
A vessel, vat, or cistern, in which things are steeped.
A Saxon; an Englishman; a Lowlander. [Celtic] Sir W. Scott.
One who prates much in his own favor, and makes unwarrantablepretensions; a quack; an impostor; an empiric; a mountebank.
A star of the first magnitude in the southern constellationArgo.
Originally, a melody of simpler form than the aria; a songwithout a second part and a da capo; -- a term now variously andvaguely used.
A perennial plant (Pyrethrum, or Chrysanthemum, Parthenium)allied to camomile, having finely divided leaves and white blossoms;-- so named from its supposed febrifugal qualities.

One who reports. Specifically: (a) An officer or person whomakees authorized statements of law proceedings and decisions, or oflegislative debates. (b) One who reports speeches, the proceedings ofpublic meetings, news, etc., for the newspapers.Of our tales judge and reportour. Chaucer.
A genus of California pitcher plants consisting of a singlespecies. The long tubular leaves are hooded at the top, andfrequently contain many insects drowned in the secretion of theleaves.
The intensity of a magnetic field expressed in C.G.S. units, orgausses.
A mineral having a glassy fracture, occurring in translucenttrapezohedral crystals. It is a silicate of alumina and potash. It isfound in the volcanic rocks of Italy, especially at Vesuvius.
A storm, strong wind, or gale, coming from the northeast.
A kind of nearly black cherry with dark red flesh and juice, --used chiefly for preserving.
A red consisting of silica, borax, and soda, fused with oxideof copper and iron, and used in enamels, mosaics, etc.
The state or quality of being conducible; conducibleness. Bp.Wilkins.
One who prohibits or forbids; a forbidder; an interdicter.
A woman who is the principal of a school; a female teacher.
A writer of verses; especially, a writer of commonplace poetry;a poetaster; a rhymer; -- used humorously or in contempt.

The theory that structural variations, characteristic ofspecies and genera, are produced in animals and plants by the directinfluence of physical environments, and esp., in the case of animals,by effort, or by use or disuse of certain organs.
Any one of several species of small, brilliantly coloredAmerican birds of the genus Rhamphomicron. They have a long, slender,sharp bill, and feed upon honey, insects, and the juice of the sugarcane.

In the Middle Ages, one of an order of men who subsisted by thearts of poetry and music, and sang verses to the accompaniment of aharp or other instrument; in modern times, a poet; a bard; a singerand harper; a musician. Chaucer.

A wind blowing part of the year from one direction, alternatingwith a wind from the opposite direction; -- a term appliedparticularly to periodical winds of the Indian Ocean, which blow fromthe southwest from the latter part of May to the middle of September,and from the northeast from about the middle of October to the middleof December.
With a low voice and indistinct articulation; in a mutteringmanner.

A contagious continued fever lasting from two to three weeks,attended with great prostration and cerebral disorder, and marked bya copious eruption of red spots upon the body. Also called jailfever, famine fever, putrid fever, spottled fever, etc. See Jailfever, under Jail.
A small marmoset (Midas rosalia); the silky tamarin.
Quality of being profluent; course. [R.] Sir H. Wotton.
A vessel for perfumes; esp. one in which incense is burned.
A lesser third, having its terms as 6 to 5; a hemiditone. [R.]
To loosen, unfix, or separate, as things mortised together.Tennyson.
Pertaining to, or resembling, the bracts of a calycle.
A kind of wash bottle with two or three necks; -- so calledafter the inventor, Peter Woulfe, an English chemist.
A defense for the shoulder, composed of flexible overlappingplates of metal, used in the 15th century; -- the origin of themodern epaulette. Fairholt.
A boiling spring which throws forth at frequent intervals jetsof water, mud, etc., driven up by the expansive power of steam.
Turned into, or reduced to, a village. [Obs.] W. Browne.
A kind of coarse, woolen cloth, usually ribbed, woven from woolof long staple.
Distinguishing mark; diagnostic. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
An apartment on the after end of the lower gun deck of a shipof war, usually occupied as a messroom by the commissioned officers,except the captain; -- called wardroom in the United States navy.
A form of barometer so constructed as to inscribe of itselfupon paper a record of the variations of atmospheric pressure.
A quarter; esp., a quarter of a pound, or a quarter of ahundred. Piers Plowman.
To cause (a ship taken aback in a light breeze) so to turn ormake a circuit as to recover, without bracing the yards, the sametack on which she had been sailing.
The act of postponing; a deferring, or putting off, to a futuretime; a temporary delay. Macaulay.
An interior corner; a nook; hence, an angular recess or hollowbend in a mountain, river, cliff, or the like. [Western & Southern U.S.] D. S. Jordan.
A water cooler or jug with a handle and spout; a gurglet.Mollett.
A feather not fully developed; esp., a rudimentary feather justemerging through the skin.
The East Indian name of the Cynodon Dactylon; dog's-grass.
The hypothetical radical characteristic of vanillic alcohol.
Of the nature of a polypus; having many feet or roots, like thepolypus; affected with polypus.
A short lyric tale set to music; a song or short instrumentalpiece in ballad style; a romanza.
Situated in front of the operculum; pertaining to thepreoperculum.-- n.
In the proper position of an altar, that is, at the east of achurch with its ends towards the north and south. Shipley.
The faith, doctrines, or religious system of the Mohammedans;Mohammedanism; Islam.
Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid obtained as adeliquescent white crystalline substance, and isomeric with itaconic,citraconic, and mesaconic acids.
A friend of Greece; one who supports the cause of the Greeks;particularly, one who supported them in their struggle forindependence against the Turks; a philhellene.
Life and practice of brigands; highway robbery; plunder.

A nervous affection, occurring almost exclusively in women, inwhich the emotional and reflex excitability is exaggerated, and thewill power correspondingly diminished, so that the patient losescontrol over the emotions, becomes the victim of imaginarysensations, and often falls into paroxism or fits.
Having twice as many stamens as petals, as the geranium. R.Brown.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C3H3.CO2H, of theacetylene series, homologous with propiolic acid, obtained as a whitecrystalline substance.
Articulation, usually that kind of articulation which admits offree motion in the joint; diarthrosis. Coxe.
A white crystalline substance having a sweet taste and ahyacinthlike odor, obtained by the decomposition of styracin; --properly called cinnamic, or styryl, alcohol.
The process of invagination, in embryonic development, by whicha gastrula is formed.
A morbid degree of excitement or irritation in an organ.Hoblyn.
The act of putting one in possession of an estate in fee. SirM. Hale.
Dioecious, but having some hermaphrodite or perfect flowers onan individual plant which bears mostly pistillate flowers.
Prostitution or fornication on the part of a woman.
One who appoints, or executes a power of appointment. Kent.
Wine with a mixture of honey and species. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A band, plate, or loop of metal for clasping and holdingtimbers or parts of a machine. (b) (Naut.)
A form of Ambry, a closet; but confused with Almonry, as if aplace for alms.
To part, as an alliance; to sunder. [R.] "Disallied theirnuptials." Milton.
One who makes, inscribes, or engraves, alphabetical letters.
Kicking back; recalcitrating; hence, showing repugnance oropposition; refractory.
The art or method of sailing on the loxodromic or rhumb line.
A white tablet on which anything was inscribed, as a list ofnames, etc.
In an international manner; from an international point ofview.
The figures of two heads on a medal or coin, either side byside or joined.

A marine gadoid fish (Pollachius carbonarius), native both ofthe European and American coasts. It is allied to the cod, and likeit is salted and dried. In England it is called coalfish, lob,podley, podling, pollack, etc.
In a primeval manner; in or from the earliest times;originally. Darwin.
One who, or that which, fumigates; an apparattus forfumigating.
A member of The Institute of the Missionary Priests of St. Paulthe Apostle, founded in 1858 by the Rev. I. T. Hecker of New York.The majority of the members were formerly Protestants.
Having equal, or almost equal, authority with the apostles oftheir teachings.
Not cyclic; not disposed in cycles or whorls; as: (a) (Bot.)
A thin board which propagates the sound in a piano, in aviolin, and in some other musical instruments.

An extensive division of marine Annelida, including those thatare without oral tentacles or cirri, and have the gills, whenpresent, mostly arranged along the sides of the body. They generallylive in burrows or tubes.
A plant (Agathotes Chirayta) found in Northern India, havingmedicinal properties to the gentian, and esteemed as a tonic andfebrifuge.
One of a series of isonitroso derivatives obtained by theaction of hydroxylamine on aldehydes or ketones.
A pullet from which the ovaries have been removed to producefattening; hence, a fat pullet.
The pointless sword carried before English monarchs at theircoronation, and emblematically considered as the sword of mercy; --also called the sword of Edward the Confessor.

The power possessed by living organisms, both animal andvegetable, of adapting themselves to modifications or changes intheir environment, thus possibly giving rise to ultimate variation ofstructure or function.
The state of being undigested; unripeness; immaturity. [Obs.]Bacon.
Incapable of being reformed; incorrigible. Joseph Cook.

The certificate issued to the purchaser of land at a tax salecertifying to the sale and the payment of the consideration thereof,and entitling the purchaser upon certain conditions and at a certaintime thereafter to a deed or instrument of conveyance (called a taxdeed) of the land, to be executed by the proper officer.
Fear of one's self; fear of being egotistical. [R.] Hare.
Dissection of a dead body, for the purpose of ascertaining thecause, seat, or nature of a disease; a post-mortem examination.

The regular logical form of every argument, consisting of threepropositions, of which the first two are called the premises, and thelast, the conclusion. The conclusion necessarily follows from thepremises; so that, if these are true, the conclusion must be true,and the argument amounts to demonstration;
The art, act, or occupation or catching birds or wild fowls.
Analysis into primary or elemental parts. [Archaic] Bacon.

A person transformed into a wolf in form and appetite, eithertemporarily or permanently, whether by supernatural influences, bywitchcraft, or voluntarily; a lycanthrope. Belief in werewolves,formerly general, is not now extinct.The werwolf went about his prey. William of Palerne.The brutes that wear our form and face, The werewolves of the humanrace. Longfellow.
Absence or lack of intelligence; unwisdom; ignorance. Bp. Hall.
In the quaternion analysis, a quantity that has magnitude, butnot direction; -- distinguished from a vector, which has bothmagnitude and direction.
A white heat, or the glowing or luminous whiteness of a bodycaused by intense heat.
A particular proposition, as opposed to a universal one. SeeSubaltern, 2.
The canal by which the urine is conducted from the bladder anddischarged.
A thread or threadlike object or appendage; a fiber; esp.(Bot.), the threadlike part of the stamen supporting the anther.
The inner layer of the coating of a seed, usually thin anddelicate; the endopleura.
The larva of a moth (Heliothis armigera) which devours thebolls or unripe pods of the cotton plant, often doing great damage tothe crops.
A public nursery, where the young children of poor women arecared for during the day, while their mothers are at work.
That form of reproduction which requires but one parent, as inreproduction by fission or in the formation of buds, etc., which dropoff and form new individuals; asexual reproduction. Haeckel.
The cold-blooded vertebrates, that is, all but the mammals andbirds; -- the antithesis to Hematotherma.
A very dangerous contagious disease in which the air passages,and especially the throat, become coated with a false membrane,produced by the solidification of an inflammatory exudation. Cf.Group.
Liable to melt, grow soft, or become fluid. [Obs.] Harvey.
A long-tailed, crested Javan monkey (Semnopithecus mitratus).The head, the crest, and the upper surface of the tail, are black.
One who supports or sustains; especially, at a funeral, one ofthose who bear the copse, as distinguished from a bearer, orpallbearer, who helps to hold up the pall.
A South American tinamou (Rhynchotus rufescens); -- called alsoperdiz grande, and rufous tinamou. See Illust. of Tinamou.
A white waxy substance having a hot, bitter taste, extractedfrom tobacco leaves and called also tobacco camphor.
A mineral usually of a reddish brown color, and brilliantmetallic adamantine luster, occurring in tetragonal crystals. Incomposition it is titanium dioxide, like octahedrite and brooklite.
To save; to be parsimonious or niggardly. [Prov. Eng. & Colloq.U.S.]
A token, mark, or explanation. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
Breathing with difficulty and with a wheeze; wheezing. Usedalso figuratively.
Having a small or narrow mouth; -- said of certain small groundsnakes (Opoterodonta), which are unable to dilate their jaws.
The act of felicitating; a wishing of joy or happiness;congratulation.
The whole of a system of machines, apparatus, and accessories,when set up and arranged for practical working, as in electriclighting, transmission of power, etc.
An order of holothurians in which the internal respiratoryorgans are wanting; -- called also Apoda or Apodes.

A kind of theater in ancient Greece, smaller than the dramatictheater and roofed over, in which poets and musicians submitted theirworks to the approval of the public, and contended for prizes; --hence, in modern usage, the name of a hall for musical or dramaticperformances.
The flicker; -- called also high-hole. [Local, U. S.]
Things which impede or hinder progress; incumbrances; baggage;specif. (Mil.),
A nervous disease in which the patient involuntarily imitatesthe words or action of another.
In a sovereign manner; in the highest degree; supremely.Chaucer.
A minute thread of fiber, as one of the fibrous elements of amuscular fiber; a fibril.
Having the form of a crown or coronet; resembling a crown.
An order of holothurians mostly found in the deep sea. They areremarkable for their bilateral symmetry and curious forms. [Writtenalso Elasmopoda.]
A jellylike mass of free protoplasm, without any union ofamoeboid cells, and endowed with life and power of motion.
The digestion or dissolving of proteid matter by proteolyticferments.
An American genus of sapotaceous trees bearing sweet and ediblefruits.
One who, or that which, endures or lasts; one who bears,suffers, or sustains.

Containing or expressing salutations; speaking a welcome;greeting; -- applied especially to the oration which introduces theexercises of the Commencements, or similar public exhibitions, inAmerican colleges.
One who truckles, or yields servilely to the will of another.
A tollbooth; also, a merchants' meeting place, or exchange.[Obs.] Halliwell.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a family of plants which havefour petals arranged like the arms of a cross, as the mustard,radish, turnip, etc.
A rake for scraping up muck or dung. See Muckrake, v. i.,below.
Marked with a slur; performed in a smooth, gliding style, likenotes marked with a slur.
A weed of the genus Melampyrum, with black seeds, found onEuropean wheatfields.
The ethical theory which excludes all relations between virtueand happiness; the science of virtue; -- contrasted with eudemonics.J. Grote.
Inclined to, or engaged in, rumination or meditation.
A feast of the Romans in honor of Lupercus, or Pan.
The quality of being dilatory; lateness; slowness; tardiness;sluggishness.
A small hole, as the stop in a flute; a vent. Shak.
Unprovided with a diocese; having no diocese. Milton.
The substitution of one root vowel for another, thus indicatinga corresponding modification of use or meaning; vowel permutation;as, get, gat, got; sing, song; hang, hung. Earle.
To carry, as a firearm, with the breech near the ground and theupper part inclined forward, the piece being held by the right handnear the middle.
An uneasy, burning sensation in the stomach, often attendedwith an inclination to vomit. It is sometimes idiopathic, but isoften a symptom of often complaints.
Incision of the intestines, especially in reducing certaincases of hernia.
The state or quality of being imaginary; unreality.

A succulent plant of the genus Sempervivum (S. tectorum),originally a native of subalpine Europe, but now found very generallyon old walls and roofs. It is very tenacious of life under droughtand heat; -- called also ayegreen.
The act or process of covering with laths; laths, collectively;a covering of laths.
A unit of work or energy equal to that done by one kilowattacting for one hour; --approx. = 1.34 horse-power hour.
Promoting circulation; circulating. [R.] Coleridge.
To deprive of the tongue. [Obs.] Davies (Holy Roode).
A name sometimes applied to the process of annealing metals.
One's native land; the native land of one's fathers orancestors.
That part of the fore limb between the brachium and the carpus;the forearm.
An herb of the Mint family (Sideritis), supposed to heal swordcuts; also, a species of Galeopsis.
Consisting in a heap; formed or being in a heap or hillock.Pinkerton.
One of two suspending posts in a roof truss, or other framedtruss of similar form. See King-post.
The act of softening or relaxing; relaxation. Bacon.
A kind of large steelyard for weighing merchandise; -- alsocalled weighmaster's beam.
The popular designation of the hereditary sovereign of Japan.
One who forms or divides words into syllables, or is skilled indoing this.
A genus of plants comprehending the potato (S. tuberosum), theeggplant (S. melongena, and several hundred other species;nightshade.
A large building in which tobacco is stemmed. [U. S.] Bartlett.
One who, or that which, blends; an instrument, as a brush, usedin blending.
The native black race of Papua or New Guinea, and the adjacentislands.
The branch of science which treats of the relation of magnetismto light.
A sum formerly levied to pay the expense of coinage; -- nowcalled seigniorage.
Resembling a ring; -- said esp. of the cartilage at the larynx,and the adjoining parts.
An exhibition of wax figures, or the place of exhibition.
A steward; a purveyor, particularly of a college or Inn ofCourt. Chaucer.
A licensed lighter employed in the transportation of goods toand from vessels. [China] S. W. Williams.
The quality of being abstractive; abstractive property.
A Linnean genus of mollusks having a conical shell. See Cone,n., 4.
Rather quicker than andante; between that allegretto.
To insinuate; to offer indirectly. [Obs.] Sir E. Dering.

The tassels of twisted cords or threads on the corners of theupper garment worn by strict Jews. The Hebrew for this word istranslated in both the Authorized and Revised Versions (Deut. xxii.12) by the word "fringes."
The piping frog (Hyla Pickeringii), a small American tree frog,which in early spring, while breeding in swamps and ditches, singswith high, shrill, but musical, notes.
The all-containing soul. [R.]That unity, that oversout, within which every man's particular beingis contained and made one with all other. Emerson.
An operation to diminish the size of the opening betweeneyelids when enlarged by surrounding cicatrices.
One who estimates or values; a valuer. Jer. Taylor.
A comprehensive division of the animal kingdom, including allexcept the Vertebrata.
To wind about; to encircle.In the circle of his arms Enwound us both. Tennyson.
The state or quality of being needy; want; poverty; indigence.
The chaffinch, whose cry is thought to foretell rain. [Prov.Eng.]
The quality or state of being musky; the scent of musk.
To prevent the transfer o Insulating stool (Elec.), a stoolwith legs of glass or some other nonconductor of electricity, usedfor insulating a person or any object placed upon it.
Of an even, composed frame of mind; of a steady temper; noteasily elated or depressed. Bp. Gauden.
A subdivision of the Niagara period in the American upperSilurian, characterized by the formations known as the Oneidaconglomerate, and the Medina sandstone. See the Chart of Geology.

A level oblong space surrounded on three sides by seats ofwood, earth, or stone, rising in tiers one above another, and dividedlengthwise through the middle by a barrier around which the track orcourse was laid out. It was used for chariot races, games, and publicshows.
A term applied derisively to any literary or artistic work, andesp. a painting, done simply for money and the means of living.[Cant]
An arrow without a barb, for shooting at butts; an arrow. [Alsobut shaft.] Shak.
A condition produced by the excessive or long-continued use ofquinine, and marked by deafness, roaring in the ears, vertigo, etc.
a mineral, consisting chiefly of the silicate of bismuth, foundat Freiberg; -- called also culytine.
The quality or state of being prudish; excessive or affectedscrupulousness in speech or conduct; stiffness; coyness. Cowper.
A kind of kelp (Laminaria digitata) with palmately cleftfronds; -- called also sea wand, seaware, and tangle.

A room formerly in the Czar's Summer Palace in Russia, whichwas richly decorated with walls and fixtures made from amber.  Theamber was removed by occupying German troops during the Second WorldWar and has, as of 1997, never been recovered.  The room is beingrecreated from old photographs by Russian artisans. PJC

An unsaturated hydrocarbon, C8H8, obtained by the distillationof storax, by the decomposition of cinnamic acid, and by thecondensation of acetylene, as a fragrant, aromatic, mobile liquid; --called also phenyl ethylene, vinyl benzene, styrol, styrene, andcinnamene.
To deprive of temper, or of the proper degree of temper; tomake soft.
One taken at random rather than by selection; anybody.
A house where glass is made; a commercial house that deals inglassware.
To climb up; to ascend.Upclomb the shadowy pine above the woven copse. Tennyson.
Capable of being worshiped; worthy of worship. [R.] Carlyle.
To carry too far; to carry beyond the proper point. Hayward.
A morbid condition characterized by automatic and purposelessrepetition of words or imitation of actions.
The science of tongues or languages; comparative philology;glossology.
Forming, or separating into, scales or thin layers.
In a sprunt manner; smartly; vigorously; youthfully. [Obs.] B.Jonson.
To cast or throw out; to void, as excrement; to excrete, as theindigestible matter of the food; in an extended sense, to excrete bythe lungs, skin, or kidneys.
A tribe of spiders, comprising some of those which take theirprey in a web, but which also frequently run with agility, and chaseand seize their prey.
To free from a dam, mound, or other obstruction. Dryden.
Having a peculiar pouch developed near the front edge of thewing; -- said of certain bats of the genus Saccopteryx.

A genus of very large extinct ruminants found in the Tertiaryformation of India. The snout was prolonged in the form of aproboscis. The male had four horns, the posterior pair being largeand branched. It was allied to the antelopes, but very much largerthan any exsisting species.
Actuated or prompted by a devotion to money getting or theservice of Mammon. Carlyle.
To raise little bladders or blisters upon; to inflame andseparate the cuticle of; to blister. Wiseman.
A group of birds embracing the Anseres and flamingoes, in whichthe bill is lamellate.
A small fishing vessel met with in the Persian Gulf.
A degraded Papuan race, inhabiting Luzon and some of the othereast Indian Islands. They resemble negroes, but are smaller in size.They are mostly nomads.
To doubt. [R.]If he . . . were to loiter dubitating, and not come. Carlyle.
One who lives by shifts and tricks; one who avoids theperformance of duty or labor.
In an authentic manner; with the requisite or genuineauthority.
Sufficiency; plenty; abundance; contentment. [Obs.]He could in little thing have suffisaunce. Chaucer.
A disease in wheat, in which the blackened and contractedgrain, or ear, is filled with minute worms.
Tobacco which has been stripped of its stalks before packing.
The humbling of a person by act or words, especially by aretort or a reproof; the retort or the reproof which has such effect.
The quality of being impartible; communicability. Blackstone.
A liquid, C3H7.C6H4.CHO, obtained from oil of caraway; --called also cuminic aldehyde.
A red coloring matter obtained from the safflower, or Carthamustinctorius.
A very large genus of composite plants including the groundseland the golden ragwort.
Pertaining to an annotator; containing annotations. [R.]
Embodied in bread, esp. in the bread of the eucharist. [Obs.]Cranmer.
Restraint over one's self; self-control; self-command.
Consisting of the pulverized or fragmentary material of rock,as conglomerate, shale, etc.
Breaking in directions at right angles to each other; -- saidof the monoclinic feldspars.
An East India herring (Clupea toli) which is extensively caughtfor the sake of its roe and for its flesh.
An instrument for measuring the degree of viscosity of liquids,as solutions of gum.
An onyx, part or all of whose layers consist of jasper.
A plain cap or headdress for women or girls; especially, onetying under the chin by a very broad band, generally of the samematerial as the cap itself. Thackeray.
The state or condition of being an albino; albinism.
To adorn by illuminating or ornamenting with colored anddecorated letters and figures, as a book or manuscript. [R.]Palsgrave.

An instrument which shows the direction of the wind; a windvane; a weathercock; -- usually applied to a contrivance consistingof a vane above, connected in the building with a dial or index withpointers to show the changes of the wind.
Decomposed rock, usually reddish or ferruginous (owing tooxidized pyrites), forming the upper part of a metallic vein.
Argumentation; ratiocination; discursive reasoning.
The art of discovering or judging of a man's character,passions. and inclinations from a study of his visible features. [R.]
Gumminess; a viscous or adhesive quality or nature. [R.]Floyer.
One who, or that which, stupefies; a stupefying agent.
Property, landed or funded, so attached to a title of honor asto descend with it.

The art or act of determining the directions and heights of thelines of rampart with reference to the protection of the interiorfrom exposure to an enemy's fire from any point within range, or fromany works which may be erected. Farrow.

A pantheistic eclectic school of philosophy, of which Plotinuswas the chief (A. D. 205-270), and which sought to reconcile thePlatonic and Aristotelian systems with Oriental theosophy. It tendedto mysticism and theurgy, and was the last product of Greekphilosophy.

A pump consisting of an endless chain, running over a drum orwheel by which it is moved, and dipping below the water to be raised.The chain has at intervals disks or lifts which fit the tube throughwhich the ascending part passes and carry the water to the point ofdischarge.
A basket for holding materials for needlework, or the like.
