A chief magistrate of a free imperial city or canton ofSwitzerland. [Obs.]
A plane figure with fifteen angles, and consequently fifteensides.
The horney covering of the lower mandible of a bird.
A short act or piece between others, as in a play; aninterlude; hence, intermediate employment or time. Chesterfield.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, hydrogen telluride, which isregarded as an acid, especially when in solution.
Capable of being drawn out in length; ductile. Bacon.
Not torn, split, or parted; not torn to pieces. [Obs.] Bp.Hall.
An extinct genus of Devonian ganoid fishes, having the broadplates about the head studded with berrylike tubercles.
In an adverse manner; inimically; unfortunately; contrariwise.
A composite stone (quartz, schorl, and hornlende) in the wallsof tin and copper lodes.
The bearded tortoise (Chelys fimbriata) of South Americanrivers.
One who adjusts things to a line or lines or brings them intoline. Evelyn.
Not articulated; not jointed or connected by a joint.
That may produce discord; disagreeing; discordant. [R.]Halliwell.
A hawk resembling the buzzard, but with legs relatively longer.
A yellow-flowered composite plant (Helenium autumnale) the odorof which is said to cause sneezing.
Relating to the common wormwood or to an acid obtained from it.
A hoop suspended by an elastic strap, in which a young childmay be held secure while amusing itself by jumping on the floor.
One skilled in phytology; a writer on plants; a botanist.Evelyn.
The act of undervaluing; a rate or value not equal to the realworth.
The most posterior of the three pairs of embryonic renal organsdeveloped in many vertebrates.
A contraction of the muscles of the jaw by which its motion issuspended; a variety of tetanus.

A gaping or bursting open along a definite line of attachmentor suture, without tearing, as in the opening of pods, or thebursting of capsules at maturity so as to emit seeds, etc.; also, thebursting open of follicles, as in the ovaries of animals, for theexpulsion of their contents.
Mud or slime, such as that at the bottom of rivers. [Scot.]
One of the smaller cells, or blastomeres, resulting from thecomplete segmentation of a telolecithal ovum.
A treatise on, or the science of, the preservation of health.[R.]
A carangoid oceanic fish (Trachurops crumenophthalmus), havingvery large and prominent eyes; -- called also goggle-eye, big-eyedscad, and cicharra.
One who speaks in public; an haranguer; a preacher. Addison.
To avoid or defeat; to prove false, as a judgment. Blackstone.
Formed or pronounced by the cooperation of the lips and teeth,as f and v.-- n.
Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of, Pompeii, an ancientcity of Italy, buried by an eruption of Vesuvius in 79 a. d., andpartly uncovered by modern excavations.

A beautiful gem of a deep red color (with a mixture of scarlet)called by the Greeks anthrax; found in the East Indies. When held upto the sun, it loses its deep tinge, and becomes of the color ofburning coal. The name belongs for the most part to ruby sapphire,though it has been also given to red spinel and garnet.
A square of white linen worn at first on the head, but nowabout the neck and shoulders, by priests of the Roman Catholic Churchwhile saying Mass.
Having both sashes hung with weights and cords; -- said of awindow.
With confidence; with strong assurance; positively.
A triacid alcohol, related to glycerin, and obtained fromcertain styryl derivatives as a yellow, gummy, amorphous substance; -- called also phenyl glycerin.
A kind of cigar, originally brought from Mania, in thePhilippine Islands; now often made of inferior or adulteratedtabacco.
Conclusive; decisive; definitive; final. [Obs.] Greene (1593).
Not near; not close to; at a distance from. [Obs.] Davies(Muse's Sacrifice).

To saw (a log) into quarters; specif., to saw into quarters andthen into boards, as by cutting alternately from each face of aquarter, to secure lumber that will warp relatively little or showthe grain advantageously.
Like a polyp; having the nature of a polyp, but lacking thetentacles or other parts.
A substitute or deputy; one filling an office for a time.

One in control of the stage during the production of a play. Hedirects the stage hands, property man, etc., has charge of alldetails behind the curtain, except the acting, and has a generaloversight of the actors. Sometimes he is also the stage director.
To work in, as lace; to embellish with work resembling lace;also, to lace or enlace. P. Fletcher.
A red Madeira wine, wanting the high aroma of the white sorts,and, when old, resembling tawny port.
To relinquish all claim to; -- used when an insured persongives up to underwriters all claim to the property covered by apolicy, which may remain after loss or damage by a peril insuredagainst.
Distinct markings resembling the variegations of marble, as onbirds and insects.
Distance north or south of the equator, measured on a meridian.
The act of pleading for or supporting; work of advocating;intercession.
A loose outer garment worn the 16th and 17th centuries.
The system of drains and their operation, by which superfluouswater is removed from towns, railway beds, mines, and other works.
A composition resembling ivory in appearance and used as asubstitute for it.
A name given to the old Parthenon at Athens, because measuring100 Greek feet, probably in the width across the stylobate.
A material article of an agreement; an undertaking in thenature of bail taken in the admiralty courts; a bargain. Bouvier.Wharton.
A chair, litter, or other contrivance fitted to the back orpack saddle of a mule for carrying travelers in mountainousdistricts, or for the transportation of the sick and wounded of anarmy.
Two cats fabled, in an Irish story, to have fought till nothingwas left but their tails. It is probably a parable of a local contestbetween Kilkenny and Irishtown, which impoverished both towns.

An American orchidaceous plant (Aplectrum hyemale) whichflowers in early summer. Its slender naked rootstock produces eachyear a solid corm, filled with exceedingly glutinous matter, whichsends up later a single large oval evergreen plaited leaf. Calledalso Adam-and-Eve.
A dome parallel to the longer lateral axis of an orthorhombiccrystal. See Dome, n., 4.
To break into bends, turns, or angles; to crinkle.Old Veg's stream . . . drew her humid train aslope, Crankling herbanks. J. Philips.
A hydrous sulphate of lead and copper occurring in bright bluemonoclinic crystals.
A genus of American Eocene mammals allied to the horse, buthaving four toes in front and three behind.
A half wolf; a mongrel dog, between a dog and a wolf.
A bond or pledge for appearance before a judge on a certainday. [Obs.]
A case for trial which can not be tried during the term; apostponed case. [Eng.]
To divest of garniture; to disfurnish; to dismantle. Bp. Hall.
A kind of pillar; a cylindrical or polygonal support for aroof, ceiling, statue, etc., somewhat ornamented, and usuallycomposed of base, shaft, and capital. See Order.
A substance resembling pyroxylin, obtained by the action ofnitric acid on starch; -- called also nitramidin.
The pricking of a horse's foot in nailing on a shoe.
A diseased condition of the system, brought about by thecontinued use of alcoholic liquors.
A fabulous winged animal, half horse and half griffin. Milton.
A word which has the circumflex accent on the penult.
Close-fitting garments, especially for the lower part of thebody and the legs.
Of or pertaining to Saint Vincent de Paul, or founded by him.[R.]
The inspissated juice of the Papaver somniferum, or whitepoppy.
A salt formed by the combination of ambreic acid with a base orpositive radical.
In a ropy manner; in a viscous or glutinous manner.
The American quail or bobwhite. The name is also applied toother related species. See Bobwhite.
A blur, or an appearance of a double impression, as when thepaper slips a little; a mackle.
A short, distorted hand; also, the deformity of having such ahand.
In a converse manner; with change of order or relation;reciprocally. J. S. Mill.
A sensitive kind of barometer, in which the pressure of theatmosphere, acting upon a liquid, as oil, in the lower portion of theinstrument, compresses an elastic gas in the upper part.
Over the rest in authority; above all others; highest. [Obs.]Fabyan.
The doctrine that the perception or recognition of primarytruth is intuitive, or direct and immediate; -- opposed tosensationalism, and experientialism.
The fruit of the Viburnum obovatum, a shrub which grows fromVirginia to Florida.
The Sunday next before Easter; -- so called in commemoration ofour Savior's triumphal entry into Jerusalem, when the multitudestrewed palm branches in the way.
With decreasing volume of sound; -- a direction to performers,either written upon the staff (abbreviated Dec., or Decresc.), orindicated by the sign.
A covering; -- applied especially to the bundles oflongitudinal fibers in the upper part of the crura of the cerebrum.
A liquid measure equal to four gills, or an imperial pint.[Scot.]
Anything added to raise the sides of a ship. Bailey.
Fixedness of purpose; firmness; resolution. Dr. H. More.
The investing portion, or spherical envelope, surrounding theeccentric germinal spot of the germinal vesicle.
One who receives baptism on a sick bed. [Obs.] Hook.
A recalling by the faculty of memory; remembrance. [Obs. & R.]Bp. Montagu.
The simultaneous maturity of the anthers and stigmas of ablossom. Gray.
Giddiness; a whirling sensation in the head; vertigo.
The South American lapwing (Vanellus Cayennensis). Its wingsare furnished with short spurs. Called also Cayenne lapwing.
One who carries the cross before an archbishop. [Obs.]
A sort of fillet worn by dignitaries, priests, and others amongthe ancient Romans. It was generally white.
The quality or state of being pendulous; the state of hangingloosely; pendulosity.
One who hangs about women; a male flirt. [R.] C. Kingsley.
Of the nature of, or by means of, a paction. Bp. Sanderson.
The critical moment in a play, when, contrary to expectation,the action is embroiled in new difficulties. Dryden.
A shirt worn next the skin, under another shirt; -- called alsoundervest.
The contents or substance of the ovum; egg yolk. See Illust. ofOvum.

A name given to three several issues of United States Treasurynotes, made during the Civil War, in denominations of $50 and over,bearing interest at the rate of seven and three tenths (thirtyhundredths) per cent annually. Within a few years they were allredeemed or funded.
A customhouse clearance for a coasting vessel; a permit.
A process of bone formation in which ossification takes placewithin the substance of the cartilage.
A spirituous liquor distilled by the Chinese from the yeastyliquor in which boiled rice has fermented under pressure. S. W.Williams.
The bending or twining of any part of a plant toward one sideor the other, or in any direction from the vertical.
A genus of valuable trees, including the true walnut of Europe,and the America black walnut, and butternut.
A light, covered, four-wheeled pleasure carriage with twoseats.
An instrument for measuring depths, esp. one for takingsoundings without a sounding line.
The quality of being allowable; permissibleness; lawfulness;exemption from prohibition or impropriety. South.
The female or young of the goshawk (Astur palumbarius).
The state of being litigious; disposition to engage in or carryon lawsuits.
Antimonic; -- used with reference to certain compounds ofantimony.
A wooden flat-bottomed boat, a metallic cylinder, or a framecovered with canvas, India rubber, etc., forming a portable float,used in building bridges quickly for the passage of troops.
A Chinese weight ( 1/10 catty) equivalent to 1 1/3 oz. or37.801 g.

A unit of measurement of the passenger transportation performedby a railroad during a given period, usually a year, the total ofwhich consists of the sum of the miles traversed by all thepassengers on the road in the period in question.
One who has been fondled to excess; one fond of ease andsensual delights; -- a term of contempt.
The hypothetical radical C4H3S, regarded as the essentialresidue of thiophene and certain of its derivatives.
Insurrection; commotion; disturbance. [Obs.] Sir J. Cheke.
Implying or requiring rejection; rejectable. Cudworth.
A confidential officer employed in the service of the tribunal,especially in apprehending and imprisoning the accused.
An instrument for describing circles, measuring figures, etc.,consisting of two, or (rarely) more, pointed branches, or legs,usually joined at the top by a rivet on which they move.
The care and support of orphans. [R.] Cotton Mather (1711).
An apparatus resembling a Jacquard for weaving small figures(usually about 12 - 16 threads, seldom more than 36 - 40 threads).
A bull issued by a pope in the period between his election andcoronation.
Passages selected from various authors, usually for purposes ofinstruction; miscellany; anthology.

A saxicoline singing bird (Kittacincla macroura) of India,noted for the sweetness and power of its song. In confinement itimitates the notes of other birds and various animals with accuracy.Its head, neck, back, breast, and tail are glossy black, the rumpwhite, the under parts chestnut.

A rare element, recently discovered (1885), in a silver ore(argyrodite) at Freiberg. It is a brittle, silver-white metal,chemically intermediate between the metals and nonmetals, resemblestin, and is in general identical with the predicted ekasilicon.Symbol Ge. Atomic weight 72.3.
In a wild manner; without cultivation; with disorder; rudely;distractedly; extravagantly.
A half bastion, or that part of a bastion consisting of oneface and one flank.
A carnivorous quadruped (Proteles Lalandii), of South Africa,resembling the fox and hyena. See Proteles.
To examine or search thoroughly; to exhaust a remedy against,as against a principal debtor before proceeding against the surety.Burrill.
To rail in; to inclose or surround, as with rails. Hooker.
The quality or state of being puny; littleness; pettiness;feebleness.
The art of measuring shells or their curves; conchyliometry.
A woman plaintiff, or complainant, in equity pleading. Burrill.
A note or memorandum, esp. one containing an enumeration ofdocuments.
A disease affecting grapes, esp. in California, manifested bythe premature dropping of the fruit.
One who rides over a post road to carry the mails. Bancroft.
A self-registering thermometer, especially one that registersthe maximum and minimum during long periods. Nichol.
A figure supposed to resemble an apple; a roundel, -- always ofa green color.
To walk with labor, or heavily; to tramp. [Law, U. S.]Bartlett.
One who makes trees his study, or who is versed in theknowledge of trees. Howell.
To declare elapsed, as the time allowed for introducingevidence. Sir W. Scott.
A short expressive title used for abbreviated book lists, etc.
Mannite; -- so called because found in the pomegranate.
An animal (usually an old mare), wearing a bell and acting asthe leader of a troop of pack mules. [S. America]
Rising to a point; conical; copped. [Obs.] Woodward.
A tribe of Indians inhabiting New Mexico and Arizona, allied tothe Apaches. They are now largely engaged in agriculture.
The process of smooth filing by working the file sidewiseinstead of lengthwise.
With a cheerful spirit; in a cheerful or good-tempered manner.
The quality or state of being orthognathous. Huxley.
An amphibian (Amphiuma means) of the order Urodela, found inthe southern United States. See Amphiuma.
A made-up story; stuff; nonsense; humbug; -- often anexclamation of contempt.
A living plant set to grow, esp. when set for a hedge;specifically, the hawthorn.
The day following Whitsunday; -- called also Whitsun Monday.
In a selfish manner; with regard to private interest only orchiefly.
The evening star; Hesper; Venus, when seen after sunset; hence,the evening. Shak.
Having two of the intersections between the three axes oblique.See Crystallization.
One of a court of about one hundred judges chosen to try civilsuits. Under the empire the court was increased to 180, and metusually in four sections.
A broken state; decrepitude; an impaired state of theintellect.
A morbid condition in which the blood contains black pigmenteither floating freely or imbedded in the white blood corpuscles.
A road prepared for easy transit of trams or wagons, by formingthe wheel tracks of smooth beams of wood, blocks of stone, or platesof iron.
Of or pertaining to infanticide; engaged in, or guilty of,child murder.
A species of divination, by means of an ax or hatchet.
Wearing a coarse gown or shaggy garment made of rug. Beau. &Fl.
A substance resembling gutta-percha, and used to adulterate it,obtained from the East Indian tree Isonandra acuminata.
Small grains or dust of cochineal or the coccus insect.
One of the veins of the neck when swollen with anger or otherexcitement. [Obs.]
An alkaloid obtained from the Buxus sempervirens, or common boxtree. It is identical with bebeerine; -- called also buxina.
A stick or switch used among some American Indians in making orcounting a coup.
A cavity in the primary nectocalyx of certain Siphonophora. SeeIllust. under Nectocalyx.
Of, relating to, or characterized by, platycnemism.
One who has shaken off restraint; a prodigal. [Obs.] Cotgrave.
Of or pertaining to Acheron; infernal; hence, dismal, gloomy;moribund.
Such things, in respect to infants, lunatics, and marriedwomen, as are requisite for support suitable to station.
In the United States navy, a sick-bay nurse; -- now officiallydesignated as hospital apprentice.
Relating to the production of light by the lower animals.
By distribution; singly; not collectively; in a distributivemanner.
One who advocates national unity and independence; one of aparty favoring Irish independence.
A small British lake whitefish (Coregonus clupeoides, or C.ferus); -- called also gwyniad and lake herring.
That part of the army, in Germany and Austria, which hascompleted the usual military service and is exempt from duty in timeof peace, except that it is called out occasionally for drill.
Cotton cloth, printed with flowers and other devices, in anumber of different colors, and often glazed. Swift.
The conversion of obscure radiant heat info kight; thetransmutation of rays of heat into others of higher refrangibility.Tyndall.
Having the outer and middle toes partially united; -- said ofcertain birds related to the creepers.
One of a tribe of wading birds (Pressirostres) including thosewhich have a compressed beak, as the plovers.
To inclose or defend with a bank or banks. See Embank.
A voracious ganoid fish (Amia calva) found in the fresh watersof the United States; the mudfish; -- called also Johnny Grindle, anddogfish.
A window placed in the roof of a building, in the ceiling of aroom, or in the deck of a ship, for the admission of light fromabove.
Government by planters; planters, collectively. [R.]
Capable of being protracted, or protruded; protrusile.
A California rosaceous shrub (Adenostoma fasciculatum) whichoften forms an impenetrable chaparral.
Multiplication or increase by gemmation or budding.
A compact granular cryptocrystalline mineral of a dull grayishor greenish white color. It is a hydrous alkaline silicate, and isderived from the alteration of other minerals, as iolite.
A compound of hydrobromic acid with a base; -- distinguishedfrom a bromide, in which only the bromine unites with the base.

A spiral scroll which forms the chief feature of the Ioniccapital, and which, on a much smaller scale, is a feature in theCorinthian and Composite capitals. See Illust. of Capital, alsoHelix, and Stale.
that which gives a rotary or rolling motion, as a muscle whichpartially rotates or turns some part on its axis.
Something that whirls or turns about in a rapid manner; awhirligig.
A person devoted to worldly pleasure. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
To ordain or appoint for some purpose along with another.
In the university of Cambridge, England, one who pays for hisliving in commons; -- corresponding to commoner at Oxford. Ld.Lytton.
A roundish, flattened, sesamoid bone in the tendon in front ofthe knee joint; the patella; the kneecap.
The quality or state of being tall; height of stature.
The sordid friar bird of Australia (Tropidorhynchus sordidus).
To use persuasion; to plead; to prevail by persuasion. Shak.
One who circumvents; one who gains his purpose by cunning.
An old Portuguese coin, worth about seventy cents. [Writtenalso cruade.] Shak.

The prosecution or defense of a suit, whether by furnishingmoney or personal services, by one who has no legitimate concerntherein, in consideration of an agreement that he shall receive, inthe event of success, a share of the matter in suit; maintenance withthe addition of an agreement to divide the thing in suit. SeeMaintenance.
One who propounds, proposes, or offers for consideration.Chillingworth.
A condition of the muscles induced by exposure to severe cold,in which the electrical action of the muscle is reversed.
Turbid; muddy. [Scot. & Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Wodroephe (1623).Burns.
A collection of small houses surrounded by a wall and occupiedby a community of Beguines.
A neuropterous insect, the larva of which makes in the sand apitfall to capture ants, etc. The common American species isMyrmeleon obsoletus, the European is M. formicarius.
Of or pertaining to, or designating, a certain thionic acid,H2S3O6 which is obtained as a colorless, odorless liquid.
A hypothetical radical of quinine and related alkaloids.
A large and valuable sparoid food fish (Archosargus, orDiplodus, probatocephalus) found on the Atlantic coast of the UnitedStates. It often weighs from ten to twelve pounds.
A proteid substance (acid albumin) formed from the albuminousmatter of muscle by the action of dilute acids; -- formerly calledmusculin. See Acid albumin, under Albumin.
The innermost sanctuary or shrine in ancient temples, whenceoracles were given. Hence: A private chamber; a sanctum.
A monk of an order founded in 1197; -- so called because theorder was especially devoted to the redemption of Christians held incaptivity by the Mohammedans. Called also Trinitarian.
A chief priest; also, a kind of vicar, or a rural dean.

A degraded form of superstition and sorcery, said to includehuman sacrifices and cannibalism in some of its rites. It isprevalent among the negroes of Hayti, and to some extent in theUnited States, and is regarded as a relic of African barbarism.
The joint or interstice between stones, to be filled withmortar. Gwilt.
A supposed new metallic element. It is said to have beendiscovered in pyrites, and some other minerals, and to be of asilver-white color, and malleable.
A play for representation or exhibition by moving pictures;also, the moving-picture representation of a play.
The hypothetical radical C3H7, regarded as the essentialresidue of propane and related compounds.
A body or space contained under a single surface, which inevery part is equally distant from a point within called its center.
An African bird of the genus Schizorhis, related to theplantain eaters.
The person to whom a guaranty is made; -- the correlative ofguarantor.
The lapse or interval of time between two events. [R.] Harvey.
A garment worn throughout the Levant, consisting of a long gownwith sleeves reaching below the hands. It is generally fastened by abelt or sash.
That part of the skeleton of the hind or lower limb between thetarsus and phalanges; metatarse. It consists, in the human foot, offive bones. See Illustration in Appendix.
Pertaining to the country, people, or language of Biscay;Basque [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Having the margins only a little curved; -- said of leaves.Henslow.
The posterior part of the alimentary canal, including therectum, and sometimes the large intestine also.
The art of manner of uttering a discourse publicly withpropriety and gracefulness; -- now called delivery. J. Q. Adams.
Originally, a dealer in any kind of goods or wares; nowrestricted to a dealer in textile fabrics, as silks or woolens.[Eng.]
The process of artificially repairing lesions by taking a pieceof healthy tissue, as from a neighboring part, to supply thedeficiency caused by disease or wounds.
The delicate bands of connective tissue interspersed amongmuscular fibers.
An opera glass or field glass with an oblique mirror arrangedfor seeing objects do not lie directly before the eye; -- called alsodiagonal, or side, opera glass.
Having the quality of acting upon or affecting the nerves;quieting nervous excitement.-- n.
A part of the alimentary canal. See under Mesenteron.
A carbohydrate, isomeric with cane sugar, contained in gumarabic, from which it is extracted as a white, amorphous substance.
The young of an insect in a stage between the larva and pupa.
A beautiful black marble found in fragments among Roman ruins,and usually thought to have come from ancient Laconia.
One of the common people; a low person; also, the common peopleas a class or estate in a country.
A second lending of the same thing; a renewal of a loan.
One aiming at or pretending to a greater purity of like thanothers about him; -- applied to persons of various sects. SeeAlbigenses.
A dwarf wall or partition carried up to a certain height forseparation and protection, as in a church, to separate the aisle fromthe choir, or the like.
The skin of a dog, or leather made of the skin. Also usedadjectively.
To become channeled, as a candle when the flame flares in thewind.
The condition or quality of being crooked; hence, deformity ofbody or of mind; deviation from moral rectitude; perverseness.
The name of several plants of the genera Spermacoce and Diodia,of the Madder family.
The quality or state of being variable; variability. James i.17.
A discharge of fetid matter from the nostril, particularly ifassociated with ulceration of the soft parts and disease of the bonesof the nose.
A group of birds characterized by having long slender bills, asthe sandpipers, curlews, and ibises. It is now regarded as anartificial division.
an argument from the cause to the effect; an a priori argument.Johnson.
A solid of five sides, having a rectangular base, tworectangular or trapezoidal sides meeting in an edge, and twotriangular ends.
One of numerous species of long-winged, shrikelike birds ofAustralia and the East Indies, of the genus Artamus, and alliedgenera; called also wood swallow.

A kind of lichen (Cetraria Icelandica) found from the Arcticregions to the North Temperate zone. It furnishes a nutritious jellyand other forms of food, and is used in pulmonary complaints as ademulcent.
Sung or played in a restless, hurried, and spasmodic manner.
To talk unmeaningly; to chatter or prattle. [R.] Latimer.
Containing or resembling brimstone; sulphurous. B. Jonson.
Pertaining to, or designating, an organic amido acid, which isregarded as a derivative of lactic acid and urea.
A genus of large extinct Eocene mammals from Wyoming; -- calledalso Uintatherium. See Illustration in Appendix.
Eager or immoderate excitement or action; the state ofturgescence of any organ; erethism; esp., the height of venerealexcitement in sexual intercourse.
An advocate of the doctrine of philosophical necessity; anacessitarian.
Quality, state, or degree, of a multivalent element, atom, orradical.
The evil and malicious disposition of Satan; a diabolicalsprit. [R.]
A green pigment found in the feathers of the turacou. SeeTuracin.
A granary; a building or place where grain is stored forpreservation.
A substance obtained from euchroic acid. See Eychroic.
The European smooth blenny (Blennius pholis). It is olive-greenwith irregular black spots, and without appendages on the head.
An annual plant of the genus Iberis, cultivated in gardens. Thename was originally given to the I. umbellata, first, discovered inthe island of Candia.
To walk or run about in an idle or slatternly manner; totraipse. [Obs. or Colloq.]
The quality or state of being protective. W. Pater.
The act of eating out or through. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Of or pertaining to the tympanum and the hyoidean arch.-- n.
Of or pertaining to uxoricide; tending to uxoricide.
The science or study of Egyptian antiquities, esp. thehieroglyphics.
A chisel, thin in proportion to its width. It has a tang toenter the handle instead of a socket for receiving it. Knight.
A medicine which eats away extraneous growths; a caustic.
Without, or apparently without, a scutellum; -- said of certaininsects.
One who writers a dissertation; one who discourses. Boyle.
To forbid; to renounce; to forsake; to deny. [Obs.] Spenser.
Having the appearance of ruins, or of the ruins of houses; --said of certain minerals.
To convert into opal, or a substance like opal. Lyell.
The front median plate of the labium in insects. See Labium.
A regaining; recovery of something lost. [Obs.] Bacon.
A house where ale is retailed; hence, a tippling house.Macaulay.
An actor in pantomime; also, a composer of pantomimes.
To qualify again; to confer capacity on again. Atterbury.
A mineral, consisting of the sulphates of soda and lime.

A contrivance for regulating and controlling motion, as: (a)The lever or index in a watch, which controls the effective length ofthe hairspring, and thus regulates the vibrations of the balance. (b)The governor of a steam engine. (c) A valve for controlling theadmission of steam to the steam chest, in a locomotive.

One of a race of giants, sons of Neptune and Amphitrite, havingbut one eye, and that in the middle of the forehead. They were fabledto inhabit Sicily, and to assist in the workshops of Vulcan, underMt. Etna.

A genus of minute insects parasitic, in their larval state, onbees and wasps. It is the typical genus of the group Strepsiptera,formerly considered a distinct order, but now generally referred tothe Coleoptera. See Strepsiptera.
Of or pertaining to parricide; guilty of parricide.
A wooden rattle sometimes used as a substitute for a bell, inthe Roman Catholic church, during the latter part of Holy Week, orthe last week of Lent.
A short caulis or stem, esp. the rudimentary stem seen in theembryo of seed; -- otherwise called a radicle.
Of or pertaining to an orchestra; suitable for, or performed inor by, an orchestra.
Not perspicuous; not clear; obscure; vague; ambeguous.
A female servant or attendant; specifically, as a term of thetheater, a lady's maid, in comedies, who acts the part of anintrigante; a meddlesome, mischievous female servant or young woman.
Of or pertaining to termination; forming a termination.
A garment worn by men and boys, extending from the waist to theknee or to the ankle, and covering each leg separately. pants; usedattrib. in the singular, as a trouser leg; see pant
Any seasoning preparation used to stuff meat; especially, acomposition of bread, condiments, spices, etc.; forcemeat; dressing.

A nitrogenous, organic base, NH2.OH, resembling ammonia, andproduced by a modified reduction of nitric acid. It is usuallyobtained as a volatile, unstable solution in water. It acts as astrong reducing agent.
A place near the fire or hearth; home; domestic life orretirement.
A climbing shrub (Tetracera alnifolia, or potatoria) of WesternAfrica, which pours out a watery sap from the freshly cut stems.
The milk secreted just before, or directly after, the birth ofa child or of the young of an animal; colostrum.
A kind of shell limestone, whose strata form the middle one ofthe three divisions of the Triassic formation in Germany. See Chart,under Geology.
An unnatural collection of serous fluid in any serous cavity ofthe body, or in the subcutaneous cellular tissue. Dunglison.
One who, or that which, lets blood; a phlebotomist.
Pointing two ways, as leaves that grow only on opposite sidesof a branch; in two vertical rows.
A discharge or flowing of humors or fluid matter, as from thenose in catarrh; -- sometimes used synonymously with inflammation.Dunglison.
Invested by a sheath, or cylindrical membranaceous tube, whichis the base of the leaf, as the stalk or culm in grasses; vaginate.
The smaller of the two otoliths found in the inner ear of manyfishes.
A contriver; an inventor; a contriver of engines. [Obs.] Shak.
The condition or quality of being general; frequency;commonness. Sir P. Sidney.
Deprived of the privileges or form of a body corporate. [Obs.]Jas. II.
Unnatural softness of any organ or part. Dunglison.
A positive statement of facts; an allegation; an offer tojustify or prove what is alleged.
The four "liberal arts," arithmetic, music, geometry, andastronomy; -- so called by the schoolmen. See Trivium.
A colorless, crystalline, nitrogenous base, obtained by thedecomposition of cocaine.
Of or pertaining to prey; plundering; predatory. [R.] Boyse.
To pasture; to feed; to graze; also, to use for pasture. [R.]Cattle, to graze and departure in his grounds. Blackstone.A right to cut wood upon or departure land. Washburn.
To gaze; to overlook. [Poetic] "Earth's o'ergazing mountains."Byron.
The shell of a large Dentalium (D. pretiosum), formerly used asshell money, and for ornaments, by the Indians of the west coast ofNorth America.
A form of hygrometer having wet and dry bulb thermometers, withan adjustable index showing directly the percentage of moisture inthe air, etc.
A hot, oppressive wind which sometimes blows in theMediterranean, particularly on the eastern coast of Spain.

Any one of several species of Old World birds of the genusJynx, allied to the woodpeckers; especially, the common Europeanspecies (J. torguilla); -- so called from its habit of turning theneck around in different directions. Called also cuckoo's mate,snakebird, summer bird, tonguebird, and writheneck.
The quality or condition of being fugitive; evanescence;volatility; fugacity; instability.
Like a companion; companionable; on equal terms; sympathetic.[Obs.] Udall.
A kind of linen cloth anciently used in England, originallyimported from Brittany. Shak.
A species of Magnolia (M. conspicua) with large white blossomsthat open before the leaves. See the Note under Magnolia.
A transparent mucous discharge from the membrane of theurethra, commonly an effect of gonorrhea. Hoblyn.
One of several American marine fishes. See Sea robin, andGrunt, n., 2.
An instrument for executing minute writing or engraving.
Action by, or originating in, one's self or itself.
Collared; having a torques, or distinct colored ring around theneck.
Drawing together; contracting; -- said of the corrugator.[Obs.]
The operation of crushing a stone in the bladder with aninstrument called lithotriptor or lithotrite; lithotrity.
One who kills a human being; one who commits manslaughter.
A position in thrusting or parrying, with the inside of thehand turned upward and the point of the weapon toward the adversary'sright breast.
The act of joining, or the state of being joined, together;union. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
Suitable for walking; -- said of the limbs of an animal whenadapted for walking on land.

The surface of constant negative curvature generated by therevolution of a tractrix. This surface corresponds in non-Euclidianspace to the sphere in ordinary space. An important property of thesurface is that any figure drawn upon it can be displaced in any waywithout tearing it or altering in size any of its elements.
An extinct genus of huge vertebrates, probably dinosaurs, knownonly from four-toed tracks in Triassic sandstones.
A division or distribution by four, or into four parts; also, ataking the fourth part of any quantity or number.
One of two or more words identical in orthography, but havingdifferent derivations and meanings; as, fair, n., a market, and fair,a., beautiful.
The drink of the gods (as ambrosia was their food); hence, anydelicious or inspiring beverage.
The quality of being acrimonious; asperity; acrimony.
The seventh or last day of the week; the day following Fridayand preceding Sunday.
Plaited strips or bark, cane, straw, etc., used for making hatsor the like.
Having unlucky omens; inauspicious. See Note under Ill, adv.
One of the steps in which a gable wall is often finished inplace of a continuous slope; -- also called crowstep.
To produce or form cells; especially, to produce cells rapidly.
Pertaining to the segments above the epibranchial in thebranchial arches of fishes.-- n.
Of or pertaining to a finger or toe, or to the claw of aninsect crustacean.
An extinct group of Mammalia found fossil in the Eoceneformation. The species are related to the carnivores, ungulates, androdents. Called also Tillodonta.
The state of having, or being full of, ears like corn. [R.]Bailey.
A fish of the genus Silurus, as the sheatfish; a siluroid.
A pestilence which ravaged Europe and Asia in the fourteenthcentury.
The ramus of the lower jaw of a bird as far as it is naked; --commonly used in the plural.
The act of thrusting or pushing out; a driving out; expulsion.
Of, pertaining to, or containing, argument; argumentative.
The act of taking by assault; conquest. [R.] Sandys.
The state or quality of being puissant; puissance; power.
Pertaining to the foot, or to any organ called a foot; pedal.Dana.
A cake baked or fried on a griddle, esp. a thin batter cake, asof buckwheat or common flour.
, One who, or that which, qualifies; that which modifies,reduces, tempers or restrains.
To greet again; to resalute; to return a salutation to; togreet. Shak.
One who regards Father, Son, and Spirit as modes of being, andnot as persons, thus denying personal distinction in the Trinity.Eadie.
An orange-red crystalline substance, C15H10O5, obtained fromthe buckthorn, rhubarb, etc., and regarded as a derivative ofanthraquinone; -- so called from a species of rhubarb (Rheum emodei).
A hydrous sulphate of iron of a deep red color. It often occursin botryoidal form.
The quality of being alimentary; nourishing quality. [R.]
Containing tartar; consisting of tartar, or partaking of itsqualities; tartareous.
A spasmodic state of the glottis, giving rise to contraction orclosure of the opening.
In the way of conclusion; decisively; positively. Burke.
A kind of madness in which men fancy themselves changed intodogs, and imitate the voice and habits of that animal.
Having a complete metamorphosis;-said of certain insects, asthe butterflies and bees.
Between the sternal; -- said of certain membranes or parts ofinsects and crustaceans.
Coupled without intermediate connections, as an engine and adynamo.
Having the quality of thickening; tending to thicken. Harvey.
The act of pouring off a clear liquor gently from its lees orsediment, or from one vessel into another.
Any ruminant of the genus Rangifer, of the Deer family, foundin the colder parts of both the Eastern and Western hemispheres, andhaving long irregularly branched antlers, with the brow tinespalmate.
Quicklime; also, plaster or mortar. [India] Whitworth.
Plain India muslin, of various qualities and widths.
A scheme or desire to unite all the Slavic races into oneconfederacy.
To convert into, or cause to resemble, glass or a glassysubstance, by heat and fusion.
To bite by little at a time; to seize gently with the mouth; toeat slowly or in small bits.Thy turfy mountains, where live nibbling sheep. Shak.
Somewhat resembling the Roman; -- applied sometimes to thedebased style of the later Roman empire, but esp. to the moredeveloped architecture prevailing from the 8th century to the 12th.
Having two balls or protuberances at each end; -- said of across.
Having a tendency by nature; prone; proclivous. [R.] Mrs.Browning.
A recessed portion of a room, or a small room opening into alarger one; especially, a recess to contain a bed; a lateral recessin a library.
Of or pertaining to breathing; suited to the inhaling of air
The act of burying with funeral rites. [Obs.] Knatchbull.
To insert, as one piece of timber into another, by alternatescores or projections from the middle, to prevent slipping; to scarf.
A young salmon after its first return from the sea.
In the mind; in thought or meditation; intellectually; in idea.
Of or pertaining to a presbyter or presbytery; presbyterial.
The flower of a rose before it opens, or when but partiallyopen.
The state or quality of being sectional; sectionalism.
The science which treats of the structure and functions of thestomach; a treatise of the stomach.
In the Ethiopic church, a small building attached to a churchedifice, in which the bread for the eucharist is made. Audsley.
Possessing only small coins; impoverished. [R.] Lamb.
Situated back of the temporal bone or the temporal region ofthe skull; -- applied especially to a bone which usually connects thesupraclavicle with the skull in the pectoral arch of fishes.-- n.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a complex organic acidproduced as a white crystalline substance by the action of nitrousacid on hydroquinone.
A sheet of partially felted fur before it is united to the hatbody. Knight.
Descending from the same stock or ancestor, but not in the sameline or branch or one from the other; -- opposed to lineal.
Deserving compassion or pity; pitiable. [R.] Barrow.
Farthest toward the south; southernmost. [R.] Milton.
To renew or renovate; to instaurate. [Obs.] Marston.
A motion in dancing, when one leg is a little bent, and raisedfrom the floor, and with the other a forward motion is made.Chambers.
Consisting of, or reducible to, fine powder; covered with dustor powder; powdery; dusty.
Any species of ophiuran starfishes. See Ophiuroidea.
Sown during the last years of a tenancy, but not ripe untilafter its expiration; -- said of crops. Wharton.
The spirit of those who extol the advantage to ignorance;obscuriantism.
A colorless, oily liquid, formerly obtained by distillation ofcolophony. It is regarded as a polymeric form of terebenthene. Calledalso diterebene.
Either one of the three common American scaup ducks. See Scaupduck, under Scaup.
To compare (a proof) with a previous proof of the same matter,and mark again such errors as have not been corrected in the type.

A cutting or engraving; a figure cut into something, as a gem,so as to make a design depressed below the surface of the material;hence, anything so carved or impressed, as a gem, matrix, etc.; --opposed to cameo. Also used adjectively.
Capable of being gathered or collected; deducible frompremises. [R.] Godwin.

An Appalachian tribe of Indians, formerly inhabiting the regionabout the head waters of the Tennessee River. They are now mostlysettled in the Indian Territory, and have become one of the mostcivilized of the Indian Tribes.
Not admitting of appeal; not appealable. Coleridge.
The period of violence in a fever or disease; paroxysm.Dunglison.
A stitch in lace making used to fill in open spaces withthreads resembling a cobweb.
To speak extempore; especially, to discourse without specialpreparation; to make an offhand address.
The act of waiving, or not insisting on, some right, claim, orprivilege.
The strong double leathers by which the two parts of a flailare united. Halliwell.
The quality or state of being titular. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Any one of the gills of a crustacean that is attached to theside of the thorax.
A cannon ball; -- so called because originally made of stone.[Obs.] Shak.
A genus of ganoid fishes, including the sturgeons, having thebody armed with bony scales, and the mouth on the under side of thehead. See Sturgeon.

An instrument by means of which a sound can be made to producea visible trace or record of itself. It consists essentially of aresonant vessel, usually of paraboloidal form, closed at one end by aflexible membrane. A stylus attached to some point of the membranerecords the movements of the latter, as it vibrates, upon a movingcylinder or plate.
Having the anthers raised above the stigma, and visible at thethroat of the corolla, as in long-stamened primroses; -- the reverseof pin-eyed.
That departament of natural history which treats of technicalterms.
The son of Jason and Ceres, and the god of wealth. He wasrepresented as bearing a cornucopia, and as blind, because his giftswere bestowed without discrimination of merit.
A kind of monomania in which the patient believes himselftransformed into one of the lower animals.

An evergreen shrub (Hibiscus -- formerly Abelmoschus-moschatus), of the East and West Indies and Northern Africa, whosemusky seeds are used in perfumery and to flavor coffee; -- sometimescalled musk mallow.
A square sail bent upon a yard that hangs obliquely to the mastand is raised or lowered with the sail. Totten.
An instrument for determining the dip of beds or strata, pr theslope of an embankment or cutting; a kind of plumb level. Dana.
To exceed in blushing; to surpass in rosy color. T. Shipman.
A verbal or acted enigma based upon a word which has two ormore significant syllables or parts, each of which, as well as theword itself, is to be guessed from the descriptions orrepresentations.
A kind of weir or dam for trapping salmon; also, a hovel.[Scot.]
A painful affection of the side, simulating pleurisy, usuallydue to rheumatism.
The state of the devil or of devils; doctrine of the devil orof devils. Bp. Hall.
A person who is seventy years of age; a septuagenary.
Tending or serving to expurgate; expurgatory. Milman.
Twin; paired; -- said of various objects made or formed inpairs, as a binocular opera glass, a pair of gimmal rings, etc.
The quality of being immeasurable; immensurability.
A style of painting on plastered walls or stone, in which thecolors are rendered permanent by sprinklings of water, in which ismixed a proportion of soluble glass (a silicate of soda).
The layer, or stratum, of earth on which the mold, or soil,rests; subsoil.
A genus of large trilobites characteristic of the primordialformations.
That part of the ovary from which the ovules arise; theplacenta.
One who, or that which, diminishes anything. Clerke (1637).
To comprise in, or reduce to, a summary; to present briefly.Chambers.
Sounding dreadfully; uttering a terrible sound. [Obs.] Bailey.

The Beaks; the stage or platform in the forum where orations,pleadings, funeral harangues, etc., were delivered; -- so calledbecause after the Latin war, it was adorned with the beaks ofcaptured vessels; later, applied also to other platforms erected inRome for the use of public orators.
That branch of military science which comprehends the theory ofprojectiles, and the manner of constructing and using ordnance.
One to whom a right of surface occupation is granted; one whopays quitrent for a house built upon another man's ground.
A culture made by inoculating a solid medium, as gelatin, withthe puncture of a needle or wire. The growths are usually ofcharacteristic form.
Quality of being glandulous; a collection of glands. [R.] SirT. Browne.
A white crystalline hydrocarbon produced indirectly fromretene.
A European herbaceous plant (Achillea Ptarmica) allied to theyarrow, having a strong, pungent smell.
The act of painting or staining, especially of painting theface.
Wearing a collar; -- said of a man or beast used as a bearingwhen a collar is represented as worn around the neck or loins.
A remora. It was fabled to stop ships by attaching itself tothem. Sylvester.

A wooden pin tapering toward both ends with a groove around itsmiddle, fixed transversely in the eye of a rope to be secured to anyother loop or bight or ring; a kind of button or frog capable ofbeing readily engaged and disengaged for temporary purposes.
One who makes a surrender, as of an estate. Bouvier.
Inclined to much writing; -- correlative to talkative. [R.]Pope.
The introduction of water subcutaneously for the relief ofpain.
A feast or merry-making made by or for a family or businessfirm on taking possession of a new house or premises. Johnson.
A white organic base, resembling morphine, and obtained fromcertain varieties of opium.
One who writes a chronography; a chronologer. Tooke.
To deceive by trickery; to cajole by confusing the senses; tohoax; to mystify; to humbug. [Colloq.] Addison.What oriental tomfoolery is bamboozling you J. H. Newman.
One who lives in a garret; a poor author; a literary hack.Macaulay.
To observe inaccurately; to mistake in observing. Locke.
To mention among other things, or casually or incidentally.[Obs.]
The state or quality of being canonical; agreement with thecanon.
A straight line considered as drawn from a center to anindefinite distance in one direction, the complete ray being thewhole line drawn to an indefinite distance in both directions.
A handsome fish of Florida and the West Indies (Platyglossusradiatus). The name is applied also to the ladyfish (Harpe rufa) ofthe same region.
Having three dimensions; extended in three differentdirections.
A large nocturnal beetle of the genus Lucanus (as L. capreolus,and L. dama), having long, curved upper jaws, resembling a sickle.The grubs are found in the trunks of old trees.
A vessel with two or three masts, used in the Mediterranean.The masts are usually of one piece, and without tops, caps, orcrosstrees.
The complement of attributes which make up the notion signifiedby a general term.
A member of the lobby; a person who solicits members of alegislature for the purpose of influencing legislation. [U.S.]
A white substance extracted from the lichen, Iceland moss(Cetraria Islandica). It consists of several ingredients, among whichis cetraric acid, a white, crystalline, bitter substance.
To act inefficiently or idly; to trifle; to potter.
One who unfolds or explains; an expounder; an explainer.
A rule for construing written instruments so as to conform asnearly to the intention of the parties as is consistent with law.Mozley & W.
Of or pertaining to a group of carnivores, including the wovelsand the dogs.
One who plunders; especially, a plunderer of wrecks; a pirate;a corsair; a marauder; a sharper. Sir W. Temple.
A struggling to resist; a striving against; resistance;opposition of nature. [Obs.]
Closely united by the coalescence, or sticking together, ofcontiguous faces, as in the case of the cotyledons of the live-oakacorn.
One who believes in, or defends, the Apocrypha. [R.]
Lordship or supremacy of a person or a people over others. J.R. Green.
An extravagant fiction embodying an account of some marvelousexploit or adventure.
A tribe of southern Sioux Indians, now living in the IndianTerritory.
A substance resembling gun cotton in composition andproperties, but distinct in that it is more highly nitrified and issoluble in alcohol, ether, etc.; -- called also pyroxyle.
Haste or speed in traveling, like that of a post or courier.Shak.
Admitting of being easily wielded or managed. [Obs.] Golding.
One who deals in news; one who is active in hearing and tellingnews.
To extricate by winding; to unloose. [R.] Spenser. Dr. H. More.
One who makes a bargain; -- sometimes in the sense ofbargainor.
Tending to increase the secretion and discharge of urine.-- n.

An ancient high court exercising jurisdiction in certain cases,mainly criminal, which sat without the intervention of a jury. Itconsisted of the king's council, or of the privy council only withthe addition of certain judges. It could proceed on mere rumor orexamine witnesses; it could apply torture. It was abolished by theLong Parliament in 1641. Encyc. Brit.
The state of being the only begotten. [R.] Bp. Pearson.
Sticky; adhesive; raw; -- said of paint, varnish, etc., whennot well dried. [U. S.]
One skilled in pyrotechny; one who manufactures fireworks.Steevens.

The sperm whale (Physeter macrocephalus). It has in the top ofits head a large cavity, containing an oily fluid, which, afterdeath, concretes into a whitish crystalline substance calledspermaceti. See Sperm whale.
A division of swimming birds in which all four toes are unitedby a broad web. It includes the pelicans, cormorants, gannets, andothers.
Absence or lack of reverence; irreverence. [Obs.] Wyclif.
One who holds the existence of matter to be from eternity. T.Burnet.
The ripened ovary; the walls of the fruit. See Illusts. ofCapsule, Drupe, and Legume.
The swamp hickory (Carya amara). Its thin-shelled nuts arebitter.
A European flounder (Arnoglosus laterna, or Psetta arnoglossa);-- called also megrin, and smooth sole.
Decorated by glaze splashed or irregularly spread upon thesurface, or apparently applied at the top and allowed to run down thesides; -- said of pieces of Chinese porcelain.
Desire; a longing for, or seeking after, something. Holland.
Having a wicked, malignant disposition; morally bad.
Land of superior quality, on which successive crops are raised.[Scot.] Jamieson.

An optical toy, in which figures made to revolve on the insideof a cylinder, and viewed through slits in its circumference, appearlike a single figure passing through a series of natural motions asif animated or mechanically moved.
A small flag sometimes carried at the head of the baggage of abrigade. [Obs.]
A road that crosses another; an obscure road intersecting oravoiding the main road.
The quality or state of being sulphureous. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
Not methodical; without method or systematic arrangement;without order or regularity; confused. Addison.
To eat greedily; to swallow voraciously; to feed ravenously orlike a glutton. Shak.
The state of being unemployed; want of occupation. [R.]
A cement made in India from sea shells, pulverized and mixedwith oil, and spread over a ship's bottom, to prevent the boring ofworms.
Full of torment; causing, or accompainied by, torment;excruciating. [R.] Tillotson.
An abscess; a swelling filled with purulent matter. [Writtencorruptly imposthume.]
A dark green aluminous variety of amphibole, or hornblende.
One who favors or adheres strictly to a liturgy. Milton.
A soft tumor or synovial swelling on the fetlock joint of ahorse; -- so called from having formerly been supposed to containair.
To put too much freight in or upon; to load too full, or tooheavily; to overload.
Having, or occurring in, several distinct forms; -- opposed tomonomorphic.
To assign back or again; to transfer back what has beenassigned.

A viceroy; in Ravenna, the title of the viceroys of theByzantine emperors; in the Eastern Church, the superior over severalmonasteries; in the modern Greek Church, a deputy of the patriarch ,who visits the clergy, investigates ecclesiastical cases, etc.
To bite or nibble like a sheep; hence, to practice pettythefts. [Obs.] Shak.
One of the portions of space bounded by the three coordinateplanes. Specif. (Crystallog.), one of the parts of a crystal intowhich it is divided by the axial planes.
A rude, wild, wanton girl; a hoiden; a tomboy. Dennis.
Shaped like a whiplash; long, slender, round, flexible, and(comming) tapering.
A present or bonus; -- originally applied to that paid on shipswhich entered the port of Canton. S. Wells Williams.
A proteid body, separated by some physiologists from bloodplasma. It is probably identical with fibrinogen.
Relating to commission; of the nature of, or involving,commission. [R.]
One who, or that which, perforates; esp., a cephalotome.
The parenchyma of a leaf between the skin of the two surfaces.Gray.
The state of being insanable; insanability; incurableness.
A mock serenade of discordant noises, made with kettles, tinhorns, etc., designed to annoy and insult.
Serving to show forth, explain, or exhibit; -- applied by theGreeks to a kind of oratory, which, by full amplification, seeks topersuade.
To render pagan or heathenish; to convert to paganism.Hallywell.

A piece generally projecting from a rotating or swinging piece,as an axle or rock shaft, for the purpose of raising stampers,lifting rods, or the like, and leaving them to fall by their ownweight; a kind of cam.
Having a large admixture of small pebbles or gravel; -- said ofa soil. Gardner.

The state or quality of being congenial; natural affinity;adaptation; suitableness. Sir J. Reynolds.If congeniality of tastes could have made a marriage happy, thatunion should have been thrice blessed. Motley.
The group of hydroids to which the fresh-water hydras belong.

A separate incident, story, or action, introduced for thepurpose of giving a greater variety to the events related; anincidental narrative, or digression, separable from the main subject,but naturally arising from it.
Of or pertaining to Laconia, a division of ancient Greece;Spartan.-- n.
The consort of an archduke; also, a princess of the imperialfamily of Austria. See Archduke.

An Egyptian clover (Trifolium alexandrinum) extensivelycultivated as a forage plant and soil-renewing crop in the alkalinesoils of the Nile valley, and now introduced into the southwesternUnited States. It is more succulent than other clovers or thanalfalfa. Called also Egyptian clover.
A plant, drug, or medicine, characterized by a fragrant smell,and usually by a warm, pungent taste, as ginger, cinnamon spices.
An apartment for the reception of company; hence, in theplural, faschionable parties; circles of fashionable society.
A tenure of lands held by knights on condition of performingmilitary service. See Chivalry, n., 4.
An albuminous substance, existing in the blood, which incombination with fibrinogen forms fibrin; -- called alsoparaglobulin.
One of the hexane paraffins, found in petroleum, consisting oftwo propyl radicals. See Hexane.
To cause to pass through a sieve or riddle; to sift.
A person bound by monastic vows, or sequestered from secularconcern, and devoted to a life of piety and religion; a monk orfriar; a nun. Addison.
A granular igneous rock composed almost exclusively of a soda-lime feldspar, usually labradorite.
Flight, such as gliding and soaring, accomplished without theuse of motive power.
A rude musical instrument somewhat like a cittern. [R.]Dampier.
The outer membrane of the grains of pollen of flowering plants.
One who offers; esp., one who offers something to God inworship. Hooker.
One who makes, sells, or applies salt; one who salts meat orfish.
Retarding; -- a direction for slower time; rallentado.
The fold of peritoneum connecting the stomach with the dorsalwall of the abdominal cavity; the mesogastrium.
A document carried by neutral merchant vessels in time of war,to show their nationality; a sea letter or passport. See Passport.
Pertaining to, consisting of, or resembling, festoons. Sir J.Herschel.
The science which treats of testaceans, or shellfish; thedescription of shellfish. [R.]
To receive confessions, as a priest; to administer confessionand absolution. Spenser.

A painful and usually fatal disease, resulting generally from awound, and having as its principal symptom persistent spasm of thevoluntary muscles. When the muscles of the lower jaw are affected, itis called locked-jaw, or lickjaw, and it takes various names from thevarious incurvations of the body resulting from the spasm.
A fresh-water sponge (Spongilla), common in the north ofEurope, the powder of which is used to take away the livid marks ofbruises.
A mineral of a copper-red color and metallic luster; anarsenide of nickel; -- called also coppernickel, kupfernickel.
A rail of wood or iron stretching along a yard of a vessel, towhich the sails are fastened.

A white, nitrogenous, crystallizable substance, C4H8N2O3+H2O,found in many plants, and first obtained from asparagus. It isbelieved to aid in the disposition of nitrogenous matter throughoutthe plant; -- called also altheine.
Situated under the podophyllous tissue of the horse's foot.
An ornamental cup or vase with a large, flat, shallow bowl,resting on a pedestal and often having handles.
To surrender or transfer, as an army or a fortress, on certainconditions. [R.]
Serving as a prefix in a compound name. Sir T. Browne.

Formerly, a light, low, four-wheeled carriage, with standingtop, open at the sides, but having waterproof curtains which could belet down when occasion required; now, a somewhat similar, butheavier, carriage, inclosed, except in front, and having a door ateach side.
In a steadfast manner; firmly.Steadfast believe that whatever God has revealed is infallibly true.Wake.
The glandular stomach of birds, situated just above the crop.
In the classification of Cohn, one of the four tribes ofBacteria.
Native silver chloride, a mineral of a white to pale yellow orgray color, darkening on exposure to the light. It may be cut by aknife, like lead or horn (hence called horn silver).
The exposing of a sensitized plate to the action of light.
The opening in the furnaces through which fuel is introduced.
To unite, or cause to adhere, as with glue or other viscoussubstance; to unite by causing an adhesion of substances.
The state or quality of being adapted; suitableness; specialfitness.
A rushlike plant, the reed mace or cat-tail, or some species ofthe genus Scirpus. See Bulrush.
The theological tenets or doctrines of John Calvin (a Frenchtheologian and reformer of the 16th century) and his followers, or ofthe so-called calvinistic churches.
An apparatus for the production of sound by the action of theactinic, or ultraviolet, rays.
The creaking of a door, or a noise resembling it. [Obs.]Johnson.
One of the dimorphic forms of the species of Dicyemata, whichproduced vermiform embryos; -- opposed to Ant: rhombogene.
A fossil crinoid, esp. one belonging to, or resembling, thegenus Encrinus. Sometimes used in a general sense for any crinoid.
The act or process of recruiting; especially, the enlistment ofmen for an army.
The state or quality of being massy; ponderousness.

A fine, strong fiber obtained from the young leaves of aBrazilian palm (Astrocaryum vulgare), used for cordage, bowstrings,etc.; also, the plant yielding this fiber. Called also tecum, andtecum fiber.
A genus of herbaceous plants of which several species areextensively cultivated for the great beauty of their flowers;vervain.
To go the rounds along a chain of sentinels; to traverse apolice district or beat.
A trader who secretes himself, or does certain other actstending to defraud his creditors. Blackstone.
An ornamental stand or receptacle for plants, flowers, etc.,used as a piece of decorative furniture in room.
Provoking the flow of urine; uretic; diuretic. [R.] Bacon.
An attempt to influence a court, jury, etc., corruptly, bypromises, entreaties, money, entertainments, threats, or otherimproper inducements.
A small child; especially, a negro or mulatto infant. [U.S. &West Indies]
Pertaining to, or of the nature of, emphysema; swelled;bloated.
A system of bars crossing in the middle to form braces betweenprincipal longitudinal members, as of a strut.
A small, sharp-pointed instrument used in piercing eyeletholes; a stiletto.

A colorless liquid, C7H8O2, with a peculiar odor. It is themethyl ether of pyrocatechin, and is obtained by distilling guaiacumfrom wood-tar creosote, and in other ways. It has been used intreating pulmonary tuberculosis.
The larve of any species of botfly which is parasitic upon thestag, as , which burrows beneath the skin, and Cephalomyiaauribarbis, which lives in the nostrils.
Belonging to a region of the earth's surface which includes allEurope to the Azores, Iceland, and all temperate Asia.
A small opening, as in the walls of fortification, or in thebulkhead of a ship, through which small arms or other weapons may bedischarged at an enemy.
A common; a piece of land in which two or more persons have acommon right. Bell.
A style of printing calico, paper hangings, etc., in which thecolors are in bands and graduated into each other. Ure.
An instrument for cutting or scarifying the uterus or the neckof the uterus.
A curtain of light and translucent material intended to besecured directly to the woodwork of a French casement window or aglazed door.
A genus of parasitic mites including the itch mites.
Side by side; also, opposite; over against; on a line with thevessel's beam; -- with of.
Characterized by containing the rudiments of both flowers andleaves; -- applied to a bud.
Sounding harshly in the throat; inharmonious; rough. [Obs.]Carew.
Excessively logical; adhering too closely to the forms or rulesof logic.
The quality or state of being northerly; direction toward thenorth.
An extinct, long-necked, marine, cretaceous reptile fromKansas, allied to Plesiosaurus.
A petrified or fossil shrub, plant, or part of a plant.
Concurrence of starry position or influence; hence, similarityof condition, fortune, etc., as prefigured by astrologicalcalculation. [R.] Motley.
The quality or state of being total; entireness; totality.
A pteroid of the genus Cavolina. See Pteropoda, andIllustration in Appendix.
The state of being curved; a bending in a regular form;crookedness. Holder.
The side of a ship above the water line, from the bow to thequarter.
Same as Rose window and Wheel window. Called also Catherine-wheel window.
A name applied to the elasmobranch fishes, because the nasalsac is double.
A swimming leg (of an insect) having a fringe of hairs on themargin.
Red sulphide of mercury, occurring in brilliant red crystals,and also in red or brown amorphous masses. It is used in medicine.
The good humor or mirth indulged in upon festive occasions; aconvivial spirit or humor; festivity.
A whitish substance which is cast up, as a scum, from thematerials of glass in fusion, and, floating on the top, is skimmedoff; -- called also glass gall. [Formerly written also sandever.]
the process by which plants and animals give rise to offspring.
A word or expression admitting of a double interpretation, oneof which is often obscure or indelicate.
A girl or woman with a somewhat brown or dark complexion.-- a.
Under the influence of nympholepsy; ecstatic; frenzied.[Poetic]
Without the usual forms, or not in the official character.
One peculiarly dexterous and tasteful in almost any employment,as an opera dancer, a hairdresser, a cook.

A tropical plant (Ananassa sativa); also, its fruit; -- socalled from the resemblance of the latter, in shape and externalappearance, to the cone of the pine tree. Its origin is unknown,though conjectured to be American.
The quality of being sabulous; sandiness; grittiness.
One who admires; one who esteems or loves greatly. Cowper.
Having long and nearly parallel clefts or chinks, like those inthe bark of trees.
Carnal copulation in a manner against nature; buggery. Gen.xix. 5.
The curved elevation of the cartilage of the ear, within or infront of the helix. See Ear.
One of a series of bases containing the amido and theisonitroso groups united to the same carbon atom.
An acid amide derivative of tartaric acid, obtained as a whitecrystalline substance.
A salt of sulphurous acid in which the base replaces but halfthe hydrogen of the acid; an acid sulphite.
The showing of the sacrament on the altar in order that it mayreceive the adoration of the communicants.
A small interval, less than any in actual practice, but used inthe mathematical calculation of intervals.
A band of minute tubercles, bearing modified spines, on theshells of spatangoid sea urchins. See Spatangoidea.
An ornament supposed to be of Greek origin, esp. a fret ormeander,
That which is educed, as by analysis. Sir W. Hamilton.
An American shrub (Lindera Benzoin), the bark of which has aspicy taste and odor; -- called also Benjamin, wild allspice, andfever bush.
Boring; perforating; -- applied to molluskas which form holesin rocks, wood, etc.
One who puns, or is skilled in, or given to, punning; aquibbler; a low wit.
An extensive division of ruminants, including the antelopes,deer, and cattle.
A muscle which serves to extend or straighten any part of thebody, as an arm or a finger; -- opposed to flexor.
A kind of bread made of the meal of maize (Indian corn), mixedwith water or milk, etc., and baked. [U.S.] J. Barlow.
The quality or state of being unlike; want of resemblance;dissimilarity. Tennyson.
Lace whose pattern includes one or more representations ofbaskets or bowls from which flowers spring.
A discharge from the bowels of black matter, consisting ofaltered blood.
Crooked; tortuous; hence, perverse; unfair; dishonest. [Slang,U. S.] Bartlett.
Ring-shaped structures or markings, found in, or upon, variousanimals.
A house where insane persons are confined; an insane asylum; abedlam.
Meal-taking; dining or supping. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A parenthetic flourish or flight of ornament in the course of apiece, commonly just before the final cadence.
The crowing noise made by children affected with spasm of thelaryngeal muscles; false croup.

That branch of the science of mechanics which relates tofluids, or, as usually limited, which treats of the laws of motionand action of nonelastic fluids, whether as investigatedmathematically, or by observation and experiment; the principles ofdynamics, as applied to water and other fluids.
A hideous or confused noise; an uproar. [Obs.] Howell.
A hydrous silicate of copper, occurring massive, of a blue orgreenish blue color.
A genus of trees including the orange, lemon, citron, etc.,originally natives of southern Asia.
Bent into a curve; -- said of a bend or other ordinary.
Manner of supporting or continuing life or vegetation. [Obs.]Sir T. Browne.
Mississippi; -- a nickname, from its numerous bayous.
A clumsy boat, used for conveying provisions, fruit, etc., forsale, to vessels lying in port or off shore.
A Slavic tribe which once occupied the northern and easternparts of Germany, of which a small remnant exists.
To impregnate with a preservative solution of copper sulphate,as timber, railroad ties, etc.
A line rigged to a mast; -- used in hoisting rigging; agirtline.
Cotton prepared in sheets or rolls for quilting, upholstering,and similar purposes.
The process of finding the roots of an equation. [Obs.]
The act of enchaining, or state of being enchained.
The act of abasing, humbling, or bringing low; the state ofbeing abased or humbled; humiliation.

A tall rush or flag (Typha latifolia) growing in marshes, withlong, glat leaves, and having its flowers in a close cylindricalspike at the top of the stem. The leaves are frequently used forseating chairs, making mats, etc. See Catkin.
A professional builder who erects cheap dwellings of poormaterials and unsubstantial and slovenly construction.
An optical instrument or toy, resembling the phenakistoscope,and illustrating the same principle; -- called also phantasmascope.
A form of corbel arch employing regular small corbels.
A European herb (Swertia perennis) of the Gentian family.
One of the parts which by their repetition make up a floweringplant, each being a single joint of a stem with its leaf or leaves; aphytomer.

An instrument of music used in Austria and Germany. It has fromthirty to forty wires strung across a shallow sounding-board, whichlies horizontally on a table before the performer, who uses bothhands in playing on it.
A method of printing, in which the image is fully brought outby the direct actinic action of light without subsequent developmentby means of chemicals.
Destitute of dower; having no marriage portion. Shak.
A yard, courtyard, or piece of ground, included within thefence surrounding a dwelling house. Burrill.
Deficiency; imperfection. [R.] Ld. Digby. Jer. Taylor.

A decree of the Congregation of the Council declaring invalid[so far as the laws of the Roman Catholic Church are concerned] anymarriage of a Roman Catholic, or of a person who has ever been aRoman Catholic, if not contracted before a duty qualified priest (orthe bishop of the diocese) and at least two witnesses. The decree wasissued Aug. 2, 1907, and took effect on Easter Apr. 19, 1908. Thedecree by its terms does not affect mixed marriages (those betweenRoman Catholics and persons of another faith) in Germany.

An eccentric ragtime dance, danced with the feet well apart andwith a characteristic rise on the ball of the foot, followed by adrop upon the heel. The original form, owning to the positionsassumed by the dancers, is offensively suggestive. Similar dances arethe bunny hug and grizzly bear, so called in allusion to themovements and the positions assumed by the partners in dancing.
To roll round; to cause to revolve; to put into a circularmotion. Herrick.
A dome parallel to the shorter lateral axis. See Dome.
To press between rollers for the purpose of making smooth andglossy, or wavy, as woolen and silk stuffs, linens, paper, etc. Ure.
One who has a fixed income, as from lands, stocks, or the like.
Beaten or harassed by the severe weather of winter. Spenser.
The gallery or open space between the vaulting and the roof ofthe aisles of a church, often forming a rich arcade in the interiorof the church, above the nave arches and below the clearstorywindows.
The period in which the American Upper Silurian system,containing the brine-producing rocks of central New York, was formed.See the Chart of Geology.
Thickly covered or sown, as with seeds. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A river in the Nether World or infernal regions; also, theinfernal regions themselves. By some of the English poets it wassupposed to be a flaming lake or gulf. Shak.
An earth of a blackish or deep blue color. Woodward.
A fabric of woolen, silk, or cotton knitted, or women toresemble knitted work.
The production or absorption of heat at the junction of twometals on the passage of a current. Heat generated by the passage ofthe current in one direction will be absorbed if the current isreversed.
A genus of marine Bryozoa in which the tubular cells have acentralchitinous axis and the tentacles are borne on a bilobedlophophore. It is the type of the order Pterobranchia, or Podostomata
The anterior of the body of an animal, as of a cephalopod; thethorax of an arthropod.
The performer of any work; a master workman. [R.] Spenser.
Want of legal ability or competency to do, give, transmit, orreceive something; inability; disqualification; as, the inacapacityof minors to make binding contracts, etc.
To ornament, as shells, ivory, etc., by engraving, and(usually) rubbing pigments into the incised lines. [Sailor's cant.U.S.]
The quality or state of being ingenious; ingenuity.
That branch of botany which relates to the structure of seedsand fruit.
Having power, capacity, or tendency to absorb or imbibe. E.Darwin.
A buccaneer; an American pirate. See Flibuster. [Obs.]
An American aquatic plant (Dianthera Americana) with longwillowlike leaves, and spikes of small purplish flowers.
A rare sulphide of osmium and ruthenium found with platinum inBorneo and Oregon.
A disease of wheat and other grasses caused by the rust fungusPuccinia graminis; also, the fungus itself.
To remove, as a planet, from its sphere or orb. Shak.
Cut flat on the reverse, and with a convex face formed oftriangular facets in rows; -- said of diamonds and other preciousstones. See Rose diamond, under Rose. Cf. Brilliant, n.
Wilson's thrush; -- so called from its note. [Local, U.S.]
One of a family of fresh-water pectinibranchiate mollusks,having a turret-shaped shell.
To deprive of happiness like that of paradise; to renderunhappy. [R.] Young.
Vain boasting or assertions repeated to the prejudice ofanother's right; false claim. Mozley & W.
The art of using the microtome; investigation carried on withthe microtome.
A general name for the numerous species of diurnal Lepidoptera.
Deviation from the true order of time; anachronism. [R.]Selden.
To become dim-sighted; to become dazed or dazzled. [Obs.]Chauscer.
A pile of roots, set with plants, mosses, etc., and used as anornamental object in gardening.
A deposit of pebbles, gravel, and ferruginous sand, in whichthe Brazilian diamond is usually found.
One who, or that which, adds; esp., a machine for addingnumbers.
An instrument for exhibiting and measuring wave motion; specif.(Elec.),
A specific gravity bottle; a standard flask for measuring andcomparing the densities of liquids. [Also written pyknometer.]
The condition or property of being binding; obligatory quality.Coleridge.
One given to forming schemes; a projector; a schemer. Swift.
Capable of being guided; willing to be guided or counseled.Sprat.
The disposition or the practice of a hector; a bullying. [R.]

An Alkali element, occurring abundantly but always combined, asin the chloride, sulphate, carbonate, or silicate, in the mineralssylvite, kainite, orthoclase, muscovite, etc. Atomic weight 39.0.Symbol K (Kalium).
That in which anything is packed; bagging, as for hops. [Obs.]Halliwell.

A fortification, made in haste, of trees, earth, palisades,wagons, or anything that will obstruct the progress or attack of anenemy. It is usually an obstruction formed in streets to block anenemy's access.
One of many small loops, as of thread, forming an ornamentalborder, as on a ribbon.
A cavity or pouch beneath the lower eyelid of most deer andantelope; the lachrymal sinus; larmier. It is capable of being openedat pleasure and secretes a waxy substance.
A going out of the way; a digression. [Obs.] Fuller.
The power of the county, or the citizens who may be summoned bythe sheriff to assist the authorities in suppressing a riot, orexecuting any legal precept which is forcibly opposed. Blackstone.
A large, open-headed cask, set up on end, to contain water.Dickens.
A person or persons not elected, or chosen, to salvation.
Treatment of disease by vapors or gases, as by inhalation.
Executed in a workmanlike manner; ingeniously made. [R.]Bailey.
Having the form or the qualities of a salt, especially ofcommon salt.
A collection of the Holy Scriptures in six languages or sixversions in parallel columns; particularly, the edition of the OldTestament published by Origen, in the 3d century.
One who boards a ship; one selected to board an enemy's ship.Totten.
To lay bare, as the roots of a tree. [Obs.] Bailey.
A cistern or vault at the point where a street gutterdischarges into a sewer, to oatch bulky matters which would not passreadly throught the sewer. Knight.
One who accuses; one who brings a charge of crime or fault.
Having the anterior limbs or hands adapted for flight, as thebats and pterodactyls.

The principal or most important spring in a piece of mechanism,especially the moving spring of a watch or clock or the spring in agunlock which impels the hammer. Hence: The chief or most powerfulmotive; the efficient cause of action.
To open or undo, as what is wrapped or folded. Chaucer.
A place where tripe is prepared or sold. London Quart. Rev.
In any framed work, a horizontal tie other than sill and plateor other principal ties, securing uprights to one another.
A dark red crystalline substance, isomeric with and resemblingindigo blue, and obtained from isatide and dioxindol.
A fossil resin occurring in large masses in New Zealand.
Any one of numerous species of Hemiptera belonging toTettigonia and allied genera; a leaf hopper.
A method of reducing corpulence by avoiding food containingmuch farinaceous, saccharine, or oily matter; -- so called fromWilliam Banting of London.
Divided into secondary compartments or cells, as where onecavity is separated into several smaller ones.
A follower of Robert Sandeman, a Scotch sectary of theeighteenth century. See Glassite.
Shafts, collectivelly; a system of connected shafts forcommunicating motion.
Any external topical application to the body, except ointmentsand plasters, as a poultice, lotion, etc.
One who believes that Christ will reign personally on earth athousand years; a Chiliast; also, a believer in the universalprevalence of Christianity for a long period.
To drench; to saturate with moisture; to soak. Shak.
A broad board painted black, or any black surface on whichwriting, drawing, or the working of mathematical problems can be donewith chalk or crayons. It is much used in schools.
A division of birds, including the clamatorial and picarianbirds, which do not have well developed singing organs.
To produce cinchonism in; to poison with quinine or withcinchona.
A state of exhaustion; faintness, especially as resulting fromhunger. [Colloq. U. S.]
A machine or implement for applying fresh primers to spentcartridge shells, so that the shells be used again.
