Wishing evil; disposed to injure others; rejoicing in another'smisfortune.
A miscreant, or believer in a false religious doctrine. [Obs.]Holinshed.
Any one of several species of small lemurs, as Lemur murinus,which resembles a rat in size.
A disruptive discharge between a conductor traversed by anoscillatory current of high frequency (as lightning) and neighboringmasses of metal, or between different parts of the same conductor.
Small branches of a tree; twigs; sprays. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
That branch of natural history which treats of the origin andfunctions of eggs.
Of or pertaining to the life and occupation of a shepherd;pastoral; rustic.
The quality or state of being credible; worthness of belief;credibility. [R.] Boyle.
A written account of the particulars of merchandise shipped orsent to a purchaser, consignee, factor, etc., with the value orprices and charges annexed. Wharton.
Before the judge, or court; not yet decided; under judicialconsideration.
Of or pertaining to the bone in the base of the cranium,frequently forming a part of the occipital in the adult, but usuallydistinct in the young.-- n.
Made sure; safe; insured; certain; indubitable; not doubting;bold to excess.
The character or quality of saints; also, hypocritical pretenseof holiness. Wood.
Having an indefinite number of small charges scattered orstrewed over the surface. Cussans.
The hypothetical radical C5H9O, regarded as the essentialnucleus of certain valeric acid derivatives.
The science which treats of the blood. Same as Hematology.
To recover its natural or metallic state, as a metal.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from malicacid, and now called fumaric acid. [Obs.]
A name given to a vase having a rounded body; esp.:(a) A closed vessel of nearly spherical form on a high stem orpedestal. Fairholt.(b) A drinking cup having a foot and stem.
The state of being huffish; petulance; bad temper. Ld. Lytton.
The tenth part of the stere or cubic meter, equal to 3.531cubic feet. See Stere.
Of or pertaining to sinapine; specifically, designating an acid(C11H12O5) related to gallic acid, and obtained by the decompositionof sinapine, as a white crystalline substance.
Property acquired by purchase, gift, or otherwise than byinheritance. Bouvier.
A double salt of boric and silicic acids, as in the naturalminerals tourmaline, datolite, etc.
The third above the keynote; -- so called because it dividesthe interval between the tonic and dominant into two thirds.
state or quality of being contrary; opposition; inconsistency;contrariety; perverseness; obstinancy.
A boot with a short top covering only the ankle. See Cocker,and Congress boot, under Congress.
A tree of the genus Carpinus, of compact, horny texture;hornbeam.

A specific epidemic disease attended with high fever, cutaneouseruption, and severe pains in the head and limbs, resembling those ofrheumatism; -- called also breakbone fever. It occurs in India,Egypt, the West Indies, etc., is of short duration, and rarely fatal.
Luxuriousness; effeminacy; wantonness; voluptuousness.
A person with slender shanks, or legs; -- used humorously or incontempt.
Characterized by abstinence; self-restraining. Farrar.
A fisherman; -- so called after the apostle Peter. [An obs.local term in Eng.] Chapman.
Resembling marl; partaking of the qualities of marl.
A line connecting points on the earth's surface having the samemean temperature in the coldest month of the year.
An acid containing hydrogen; -- sometimes applied todistinguish acids like hydrochloric, hydrofluoric, and the like,which contain no oxygen, from the oxygen acids or oxacids. See Acid.
A plant (Fagopyrum esculentum) of the Polygonum family, theseed of which is used for food.
One who enjoys the profits, income, or increase of anything.Kings are not proprietors nor fructuaries. Prynne.
The art of describing or delineating the stars; a descriptionor mapping of the heavens.
A saw in the form of a hollow cylinder, with teeth on the endor edge, and operated by a rotative motion.
The art or practice of hunting, or the qualification of ahunter. Donne.
A rope or stay extending from the masthead to the side of aship, slanting a little aft, to assist the shrouds in supporting themast. [ Often used in the plural.]
An allowance for traveling expenses made to those who were sentinto the provinces to exercise any office or perform any service.
Formerly the title of the sealer of writs in chancery. Mozley &W.
To make rare, thin, porous, or less dense; to expand or enlargewithout adding any new portion of matter to; -- opposed to condense.
One engaged in the scientific measurement of light.
Of or pertaining to Indo-China (i. e., Farther India, or Indiabeyond the Ganges).
The art of preparing, preserving, and mounting the skins ofanimals so as to represent their natural appearance, as for cabinets.
Pertaining to, of the nature of, or characterized by,intercession or entreaty.
A French mechanical lamp, for lighthouses, in which asuperbundance of oil is pumped to the wick tube by clockwork.
One who, or that which, dispeoples; a depopulator. Gay.
An acid amide derivative of xylic acid, obtained as a whitecrystalline substance.
To unyoke; to free from a yoke; to disjoin. [Poetic] R.Browning.
The British sand lance or sand eel (Ammodytes lanceolatus).
A jacket having air-tight cells, or cavities which can befilled with air, to render persons buoyant in swimming.
A species of small opossum (Didelphus murina) ranging fromMexico to Brazil.
The act or the place of entrance; an inlet. Tennyson.
Relating to accretion; increasing, or adding to, by growth.Glanvill.

A game played with ivory balls o a cloth-covered, rectangulartable, bounded by elastic cushions. The player seeks to impel hisball with his cue so that it shall either strike (carom upon) twoother balls, or drive another ball into one of the pockets with whichthe table sometimes is furnished.
One of three fabled sisters, Stheno, Euryale, and Medusa, withsnaky hair and of terrific aspect, the sight of whom turned thebeholder to stone. The name is particularly given to Medusa.
Fast by contract; betrothed by joining hands. [Obs.] Bale.
A boy who opens and shuts a trapdoor in a gallery or level.Raymond.
A small fishlike animal (Amphioxus lanceolatus), remarkable forthe rudimentary condition of its organs. It is the type of the classLeptocardia. See Amphioxus, Leptocardia.
The doctrine of the elementary requisites of mere thought. SirW. Hamilton.
The quality of being inapplicable; unfitness; inapplicableness.
To form an abscess; to swell and fill with pus. Wiseman.
One who measures; one whose occupation or duty is to measurecommondities in market.
The keeper of an eating house, or restaurant; a restaurateur.Simmonds.
The art of forming melody; melody; -- now often used for amelodic passage, rather than a complete melody.
Devotion to, or persistence in, conditions of the primordialstate. H. Spencer.
To bruise sorely or exceedingly. [Obs.]All forbrosed, both back and side. Chaucer.
Having two valves, as the oyster and some seed pods; bivalve.
A small building, or a part of a building, more or less open,constructed in a place commanding a fine prospect.

A shaft that oscillates on its journals, instead of revolving,-- usually carrying levers by means of which it receives andcommunicates reciprocating motion, as in the valve gear of some steamengines; -- called also rocker, rocking shaft, and way shaft.
Plaintive; pathetic; -- used adverbially as a musicaldirection.
One who belongs to the ultramontane party in the Latin Church.Shipley.
Without design; accidentally; fortuitously; by chance;occasionally.
The qualities or condition of a gentleman. [R.] Thackeray.

Lead monoxide; a yellowish red substance, obtained as anamorphous powder, or crystallized in fine scales, by heating leadmoderately in a current of air or by calcining lead nitrate orcarbonate. It is used in making flint glass, in glazing earthenware,in making red lead minium, etc. Called also massicot.
An instrument for determining the rate of vibrations in tones.
Any one of numerous species of beetles of the genus Necrophorusand allied genera; -- called also burying beetle, carrion beetle,sexton beetle.
A room specially fitted for broiling food, esp. one in arestaurant, hotel, or clubhouse, arranged for prompt service.
One of a class of fabled female water spirits who might receivea human soul by intermarrying with a mortal.
An order of small hoofed mammals, comprising the single livinggenus Hyrax.
An opinion or notion formed beforehand; a preconception.Hooker.

Any of several arthropods erroneously supposed to kill livestock, in the southern United States, by stinging or by beingswallowed; as:(a) A whip scorpion. [Florida](b) A walking-stick insect. [Texas](c) A mantis.(d) A wheel bug.
To serve as a medium for conveying; to transmit, as heat,light, electricity, etc.
The positive pole of an electric battery, or more strictly theelectrode by which the current enters the electrolyte on its way tothe other pole; -- opposed to cathode.
A calcareous tufa, in part crystalline, occurring on a largescale as a shore deposit about the Quaternary lake basins of Nevada.

Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, oenanthyl;specifically, designating an acid formerly supposed to be identicalwith the acid in oenanthic ether, but now known to be identical withheptoic acid.
Excitement of imagination such as animates a poet, artist, ormusician, in composing or performing; rapture; enthusiasm; spirit;energy.
A kind of feldspar commonly showing a beautiful play of colors,and hence much used for ornamental purposes. The finest specimenscome from Labrador. See Feldspar.
One who traffics, or carries on commerce; a trader; a merchant.
A short ballet, or other entertainment, between the acts of aplay. Smart.
An ancient special kind of cessavit used in Kent and London forthe recovery of rent. [Obs.]
To daub, soil, or make foul with spawl or spittle. [Obs.]Milton.
A branching frame, often of ornamental design, to supportelectric illuminating lamps.
A mineral of a brownish black color, essentially a tantalo-niobate of yttrium, erbium, and cerium; -- so called after RobertFerguson.

A niobate of calcium, cerium, and other bases, occurringusually in octahedrons of a yellowish or brownish color and resinousluster; -- so called from its becoming grass-green on being subjectedto heat under the blowpipe.
An alloy of nickel and silver electroplated with silver.
To reduce to, or express in, a formula; to put in a clear anddefinite form of statement or expression. G. P. Marsh.
One of a series of artificial, organic bases, usually producedas thick viscous liquids by the action of ammonia on ethylene oxide.They have the properties both of alcohol and amines.
The quality of being magniloquent; pompous discourse;grandiloquence.
A pill or bolus for introduction into the rectum; esp., acylinder or cone of medicated cacao butter.
The representation of chords by figures placed under the base;figured bass; basso continuo; -- sometimes used as synonymous withharmony.
Being under the sun; hence, terrestrial; earthly; mundane. [R.]
To alter wrongly; esp., to alter for the worse. Bp. Hall.
The hard parts or skeleton of various Anthozoa, and of a fewHydrozoa. Similar structures are also formed by some Bryozoa.
The act of sleeping, or of lulling, to sleep. [Obs.] Pope.
An apparatus which illustrates, by the revolution of ballsmoved by wheelwork, the relative size, periodic motions, positions,orbits, etc., of bodies in the solar system.
The spiritual court of a diocesan bishop held before hischancellor or commissioner in his cathedral church or elsewhere.Hook.
As if in a dream; softly; slowly; languidly. Longfellow.
Resembling glass; glasslike; glazed. [Obs.] Wyclif.
To fall or glide; to pass; -- usually followed by into. Cheyne.
Any flying marsupial of the genera Petaurus, Phalangista,Acrobata, and allied genera. See Flying mouse, under Flying, andPhalangister.
One who advocates or adopts the principles of Raphaelism.
The wych-elm; -- so called because its leaves are like those ofthe hazel.
A pit or excavation from which sand is or has been taken.
In the Philippines, a light, two-wheeled, boxlike vehicleusually drawn by a single native pony and used to convey passengerswithin city limits or for traveling. It is the common publiccarriage.
A plant reared from the seed, as distinguished from onepropagated by layers, buds, or the like.
The act of unsettling, or state of being unsettled;disturbance. J. H. Newman.
The quality of being capacious, as of a vessel, a reservoir abay, the mind, etc.
Not belonging to a profession; not done by, or proceeding from,professional men; contrary to professional usage.
The removal of the articular extremity of a bone, or of theends of the bones in a false articulation.
A deceiver; one who deludes, or uses guile. [Obs.] Spenser.
A portable bier or shrine, variously adorned, used forcontaining relics of saints. Mollett.
A bookbinder's shop; a place or establishment for bindingbooks.
Occurring or happening; hence, incidental; accidental.
A trustworthy citizen; a skilled workman. See Citation under 3dCommune, 1.
A purse or bag in which to carry or measure diamonds, etc.[India] Macaulay.
One who corrupts, or who upholds corruption. Sydney Smith.
Used only or chiefly in the preterit or past tenses, as certainverbs.
To render impervious to sound, as a partition or floor, byfilling the space within with mortar, by lining with paper, etc.
a lynxlike animal of Asia and Africa (Lynx Lybicus).
The division of Cetacea in which the teeth are developed,including the sperm whale, dolphins, etc.
The quality of being palpable, or perceptible by the touch.Arbuthnot.
A rudimental antler of a young male of the red deer.
A red liquid or soft resin extracted from various species ofcapsicum.
An exhibition of arms. according to the rank of the individual,by all persons bearing arms; -- formerly made at certain seasons ineach district. [Scot.] Jamieson. Sir W. Scott.
The act of desecrating; profanation; condition of anythingdesecrated.

To beat rapidly and more strongly than usual; to throb; tobound with emotion or exertion; to pulsate violently; to flutter; --said specifically of the heart when its action is abnormal, as fromexcitement.
A mineral of a dark bluish color, related to amphibole. It ischaracteristic of certain crystalline rocks.
A variety of chorea, marked by peculiar tremors of the fingersand toes.
One who strolls about aimlessly; a lounger; a loafer.
Places where ore is dug; especially, certain localities inCalifornia, Australia, and elsewhere, at which gold is obtained.[Recent]
An implement shaped like a knife, flat, thin, and somewhatflexible, used for spreading paints, fine plasters, drugs incompounding prescriptions, etc. Cf. Palette knife, under Palette.
Any one of a series of metameric hydrocarbons (C8H16) of theethylene series. In general they are combustible, colorless liquids.
A reddish herb (Pterospora andromedea) of the United States,found parasitic on the roots of pine trees.
Having phthisis, or some symptom of it, as difficulty inbreathing.
An extinct mammal of the Horse family, but not larger than asheep, and having three toes on each foot.
Belonging to the Moesogoths, a branch of the Goths who settledin Moesia.
That which depends upon guess; guesswork. [R.] Sir T. Browne.

A variety of water-tube boiler, used chiefly in steamautomobiles, consisting of a nest of strong tubes with very littlewater space, kept nearly red hot so that the water as it tricklesdrop by drop into the tubes is immediately flashed into steam andsuperheated.
A plug in a flute or an organ pipe, to modulate the tone.Knight.
A composition of dust of ivory or of bone with a cement; --used for imitations of valuable stones and in making moldings, seals,etc. Knight.
A man who rings a bell, especially to give notice of anythingin the streets. Formerly, also, a night watchman who called thehours. Milton.
The study, by means of the plethysmograph, of the variations insize of a limb, and hence of its blood supply.
A strong rope rove through the cascabel of a cannon and securedto ringbolts in the ship's side, to limit the recoil of the gun whenit is discharged.
A compound radical, regarded as butane, less one atom ofhydrogen.

A genus of plants of the Primrose family, having depressedrounded corms, and pretty nodding flowers with the petals so reflexedas to point upwards, whence it is called rabbit's ears. It is alsocalled sow bread, because hogs are said to eat the corms.

A curve described by the moving extremity of a line the otherend of which is fixed, this line being constantly parallel to thedirection of motion of, and having its length constantly proportionalto the velocity of, a point moving in any path; -used ininvestigations respecting central forces.

Forgiveness, either express or implied, by a husband of hiswife or by a wife of her husband, for a breach of marital duty, asadultery, with an implied condition that the offense shall not berepeated. Bouvier. Wharton.
To lay out, as money; to deal out; to expend. [Obs.]

One that covers a group or class of things or propertiesinstead of one or more things mentioned individually, as where amortgage secures various debts as a group, or subjects a group orclass of different pieces of property to one general lien.
To pester exceedingly or excessively. Sir W. Raleigh.
The act of calming, or the state of being calm. [R.] Coles.
The person at whose suit an arrestment is made. [Also writtenarrestor.]
A small lion, especially one of several borne in the same coatof arms.
To cause to form crystals, or to assume the crystalline form.
To rot, as flax or hemp, by exposure to rain, dew, and sun. SeeDewretting.

A collective name for the Indians of several tribes formerlyliving along the Klamath river, in California and Oregon, but nowrestricted to a reservation at Klamath Lake; -- called also Clametsand Hamati.
A red crystalline compound related to, or produced from,erythrin. So called because regarded as the end of the series oferythrin compounds.
Capable of being reproduced; ablle to spring again into being.
Absence of expectation; want of foresight. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
An artificer who works in timber; a framer and builder ofhouses, ships, etc.

The reading of the leveling staff in its unchanged positionwhen the leveling instrument has been taken to a new position; asight directed backwards to a station previously occupied. Cf.Foresight, n., 3.
Resembling Achilles, the hero of the Iliad; invincible.
A preparation for desserts, etc., made from isinglass, seamoss, cornstarch, or other gelatinous or starchy substance, withmild, usually sweetened and flavored, and shaped in a mold.

A curve such that the part of the tangent between the point oftangency and a given straight line is constant; -- so called becauseit was conceived as described by the motion of one end of a tangentline as the other end was drawn along the given line.
An African carnivore (Nandinia binotata), allied to the civets.It is spotted with black.
A sea turtle (Eretmochelys imbricata), which yields the bestquality of tortoise shell; -- called also caret.
Transposition, as of the letters or syllables of a word; as,pistris for pristis; meagre for meager.
A small ovoid or cylindrical roil or pledget of lint, forkeeping a sore, wound, etc., open; a tent.
Pertaining to, or designating, any one of several acids (knownonly in their salts) which contain more than one atom of chromium.
The quality of being diaphanous; transparency; pellucidness.
The process of reasoning, or deducing conclusions frompremises; deductive reasoning.
An article of merchandise of a grade inferior to the best;esp., a coarse or inferior kind of flour.
Not wormed; not having had the worm, or lytta, under the tonguecut out; -- said of a dog.
To throw out of one's hand, as superfluous cards; to lay aside(a card or cards).
The act of giving a jog or jogs; traveling at a jog.
Having the nature or qualities of oil; oily; unctuous.
The doctrine that all the functions of a living organism aredue to an unknown vital principle distinct from all chemical andphysical forces.
A supposed metal alleged to have been discovered in zircon.
A superficial growth of vascular tissue radiating in a fanlikemanner from the cornea over the surface of the eye.
In a slow manner; moderately; not rapidly; not early; notrashly; not readly; tardly.
A large bale or package of wool, containing eighty tods, or2,240 pounds, in weight. [Eng.]
A name given to several species of the composite genus Senecio.
A game of cards in which the players bid for the privilege ofdetermining or "pitching" the trump suit.  R. F. Foster.
A European marine fish (Cottus bubalis), allied to the sculpin;-- called also lucky proach.
More than politic; above or exceeding policy. Milton.
A system of phonetic spelling based upon the present values ofEnglish letters, but invariably using one symbol to represent onesound only.Ingglish Glosik konvaiA. J. Ellis.
Of or pertaining to a family or household; domestic. [Obs.]Milton.
To represent on a plane surface, as if extended in a directiontoward the spectator or nearly so; to shorten by drawing inperspective.
Of or pertaining to the genus Miliola; containing miliolites.
Like, or having the qualities of, antimony; antimonial.
One of a series of compounds that may be regarded as ammonia inwhich a part of the hydrogen has been replaced by basic, and anotherpart by acid, atoms or radicals.
A collection of eight books; especially, the first eight booksof the Old Testament. [R.]
A second charter; a renewal of a charter. D. Webster.
One of a branch of the Order of Franciscans, who profess toadhere more strictly than the Conventuals to the intention of thefounder, especially as to poverty; -- called also Observants.
The buildings and yards necessary for the business of a farm; ahomestead. [Eng.]
A treatise upon, or a history and description of, the water ofthe earth.

A large, handsome, North American woodpecker (Campephilusprincipalis), having a large, sharp, ivory-colored beak. Its generalcolor is glossy black, with white secondaries, and a white dorsalstripe. The male has a large, scarlet crest. It is now rare, andfound only in the Gulf States.
That branch of science which treats of the measurement of theintensity of light.
The art of judging character by the shape and apperance of thehand.
The branch of science which treats of fossil plants; -- usuallycalled paleobotany, sometimes paleophytology.

A large and handsome American moth (Hyperchiria Io), having alarge, bright-colored spot on each hind wing, resembling the spots onthe tail of a peacock. The larva is covered with prickly hairs, whichsting like nettles.
Adapted for producing or for receiving either of two speeds; --said of a power-transmitting device.

One of a group of compounds including the sugars, starches, andgums, which contain six (or some multiple of six) carbon atoms,united with a variable number of hydrogen and oxygen atoms, but withthe two latter always in proportion as to form water; as dextrose,C6H12O6.
The phylogeny of groups or families of individuals. Haeckel.
A cutting for the cure or relief of hernia; celotomy.
A liquid ketone obtained by heating calcium butyrate.
To advance or gain upon; -- said of a vessel that gains uponanother when sailing closehauled.
A hobbler; one who limps; a shuffer. [Obs. or Prov.Eng.]
A transparent variety of calcite, the best of which is obtainedin Iceland. It is used for the prisms of the polariscope, because ofits strong double refraction. Cf. Calcite.
A mask carved in imitation of a Gorgon's head. Elmes.

The quality or state of being perplexed or puzzled;complication; intricacy; entanglement; distraction of mind throughdoubt or difficulty; embarrassment; bewilderment; doubt.By their own perplexities involved, They ravel more. Milton.
Pertaining to Biscay, its people, or their language.
A board placed temporarily upon a milldam, to raise the waterin the pond above its usual level; a flushboard. [U.S.]
Shieldlike, with the outline nearly circular; peltate. Henslow.

A lark that mounts and sings as it files, especially the commonspecies (Alauda arvensis) found in Europe and in some parts of Asia,and celebrated for its melodious song; -- called also sky laverock.See under Lark.
The lateral movement of a ship to the leeward of her course;drift.
Pertaining to, or designating, a certain one of the highlyoxidized compounds of chromium, which has a deep blue color, and isproduced by the action of hydrogen peroxide.
The act of beguiling, or the state of being beguiled.
Having the qualities, or showing the characteristics, of animp.
A policy in which the value of the goods, property, or interestinsured is specified; -- opposed to open policy.
Of or pertaining to the rachis; spinal; vertebral. Same asRhachidian.
An instrument in writting whereby a defendant in an actionacknowledges a plaintiff's demand to be just. Mozley & W.
One whose occupation is to construct ships; a builder of shipsor other vessels.
A citizen who put himself under the protection of a man ofdistinction and influence, who was called his patron.
One of two walls built on either side of the junction of abridge with the bank of a river, to protect the abutment of thebridge and the bank from the action of the current.
A perambulator which records distances and delineates aprofile, as of a road.
In a consecutive manner; by way of sequence; successively.
One of the tubes of which the ovaries of most insects arecomposed.
Struck with wonder, admiration, or surprise. Dryden.
In the breech mechanism of a firearm, the pin which strikes thehead of the cartridge and explodes it.

A yellowish translucent resin resembling copal, found as afossil in alluvial soils, with beds of lignite, or on the seashore inmany places. It takes a fine polish, and is used for pipemouthpieces, beads, etc., and as a basis for a fine varnish. Byfriction, it becomes strongly electric.
One who depends on merit for salvation. [Obs.] Milner.
An officer who is appointed to guard hedges, and to keep cattlefrom breaking or cropping them, and whose further duty it is toimpound animals found running at large.
Undercutting in a bed of coal, in order to bring down the uppermass. Raymond.

A lunisolar calendar in use among Hebraic peoples, reckoningfrom the year 3761 b. c., the date traditionally given for theCreation. It received its present fixed form from Hillel II. about360 a. d. The present names of the months, which are Babylonian-Assyrian in origin, replaced older ones, Abib, Bul, etc., at the timeof the Babylonian Exile. Nineteen years constitute a lunar cycle, ofwhich the 3d, 6th, 8th, 11th, 14th, 17th, and 19th years are leapyears. The year 5663 [1902-3 a. d.] was the first year of the 299thlunar cycle. The common year is said to be defective, regular, orperfect (or abundant) according as it has 353, 354, or 355 days. Theleap year has an intercalary month, and a total of 383 (defective),384 (regular), or 385 (perfect, or abundant) days. The calendar iscomplicated by various rules providing for the harmonious arrangementof festivals, etc., so that no simple perpetual calendar can beconstructed. The following table gives the months in order, with thenumber of days assigned to each. Only three months vary in length.They are: Heshvan, which has 30 days in perfect years; Kislev, whichhas 30 days in regular and perfect years; and Adar, which has 30 daysin leap years. The ecclesiastical year commences with Nisan and thecivil year with Tishri. The date of the first of Tishri, or theJewish New Year, is also given for the Jewish years 5661-5696 (1900-1935 a. d.). From these tables it is possible to transform any Jewishdate into Christian, or vice versa, for the years 1900-1935 a. d.
Having two masts with fore-and-aft sails, but differing from aschooner in that the after mast is very small, and stepped as far aftas possible. See Illustration in Appendix.
An inferior officer of justice in Spain; a warrant officer; aconstable. Prescott.
The science of spectrum analysis in any or all of its relationsand applications.
The practice of self-immolation of widows in Hindostan.
A European toad (Bufo calamita), having a yellow line along itsback.
A well-known plant of the genus Taraxacum (T. officinale,formerly called T. Dens-leonis and Leontodos Taraxacum) bearinglarge, yellow, compound flowers, and deeply notched leaves.
A small ball of rich minced meat or fish, covered with pastryand fried.
Pertaining to, resembling, or containing uranium; specifically,designating those compounds in which uranium has a valence relativelyhigher than in uranous compounds.
An English breed of black-faced hornless sheep similar to theSouthdown, but larger, now extensively raised in many parts of theworld.
One who, or that which, tempers; specifically, a machine inwhich lime, cement, stone, etc., are mixed with water.
Of or pertaining to a proctor, esp. an academic proctor;magisterial.
One who toddles; especially, a young child. Mrs. Gaskell.
A small piece of money, in value about a farthing, or a halfcent. [Obs.]
The bunch of looped capillary blood vessels in a Malpighiancapsule of the kidney.
An Australian tree (Casuarina), and its red wood, used forcabinetwork; also, the trees Stenocarpus salignus of New South Wales,and Banksia compar of Queensland.
Drawn outside of; -- used to designate a circle that touchesone of the sides of a given triangle, and also the other two sidesproduced.
That branch of physical science which treats of the properties,phenomena, or effects of heat; also, a treatise on heat.
Palmate, with the divisions separated less than halfway to thecommon center.
The quality of being diuretical; diuretic property.
Embroidery in crewels, commonly done upon some plain material,such as linen.
The basal portion, or two proximal and more or lessconsolidated segments, of an appendage of a crustacean.
A weaver; originally, a female weaver. [Obs.] Brathwait.
The continuous development of cells in tissue formation; cellformation. Virchow.
One appointed to keep silence and order in court; also, onesworn not to divulge secre
An instrument for measuring sounds, as to their intensity, orthe frequency of the vibrations.
The conversion of certain substances into others which have theappearance or characteristics of ivory.
To make bestial, or like a beast; to degrade; to brutalize.The process of bestializing humanity. Hare.
Little images or figures of earthenware exposed for sale, orgiven as presents, on the last two days of the Saturnalia; hence, thelast two, or the sixth and seventh, days of the Saturnalia.
Similar to, or in the style of, the poem "Hudibras," by SamuelButler; in the style of doggerel verse. Macaulay.
A sporangium or conceptacle containing only very minute spores.Cf. Macrosporangium.
Dying; a gradual decrescendo at the end of a strain or cadence.
To drive close; to press firmly together: to wedge into aplace. Woodward.
A piece in a free form, with frequent digressions from thetheme; a fantasia; -- often called caprice.

An order of wingless hexapod insects which have setiform caudalappendages, either bent beneath the body to form a spring, orprojecting as bristles. It comprises the Cinura, or bristletails, andthe Collembola, or springtails. Called also Thysanoura. See Lepisma,and Podura.
Having perennial rootstocks or bulbs, but annual floweringstems; -- said of all perennial herbs.
The tangent of the complement of an arc or angle. See Illust.of Functions.
That which conveys contagion or infection. [Obs.] Donne.
Dishes, vases, ornaments, and utensils of various sorts, madeof silver.
One of the labial palpi of an insect. See Illust. under Labium.
A subdivision of decapod Crustacea, having the abdomen largelydeveloped. It includes the lobster, prawn, shrimp, and many similarforms. Cf. Decapoda.
A form of divorce, among the ancient Romans, in which a cakewas used. See Confarreation.
Said of potash, probably in reference to its having beenobtained from billets of wood by burning. [Obs.]
A mode of writing or tracing lines by means of a style on cardsor tablets.
A binary compound of sulphur containing two atoms of sulphur ineach molecule; -- formerly called disulphuret. Cf. Bisulphide.
The theory which seeks to explain certain physiological andpathological by means of animalcules.
A kind of linen cloth with raised figures, used for towelings.
Resembling lightning; -- used to describe intense lancinatingpainsaccompanying locomotor ataxy.
Any bivalve mollusk which secretes a shelly tube around itssiphon, as the watering-shell.
Of or pertaining to the positive pole of a galvanic battery;electro-positive.
Pertaining to a passion for books; relating to a bibliomaniac.
A possession; the Israelites, as God's chosen people; also, aflock under pastoral charge. Joel iii. 2.1 Peter v. 3.
An artifical group of birds formerly regarded as an order. Theyare distributed among several orders by modern ornithologists.
A greenish or reddish crystalline substance, NaNH2, obtained bypassing ammonia over heated sodium.
Large balls or rolls of dark cloud which frequently cover thewhole sky, esp. in winter, and give it at times an undulatedappearance.
The state of being excessively or abnormally full, so as tocause overflow, distention, or congestion; excess of fullness;surfeit.
The mechanism for closing the breech of a breech-loadingfirearm, in artillery consisting principally of the breechblock,obturator, and carrier ring.
Of or pertaining to Bordeaux, in France, or to the districtaround Bordeaux.
An intermeddling with the affairs of another, either on legalgrounds or without authority.
An instrument, as a lyre or harp, having three strings.
A large variety of the domestic fowl, originally from CochinChina (Anam).
A boastful pretender to medical skill; an empiric; an ignorantpractitioner.

A fruit consisting of pulpy, coriaceous, or fibrous exocarp,without valves, containing a nut or stone with a kernel. The exocarpis succulent in the plum, cherry, apricot, peach, etc.; dry andsubcoriaceous in the almond; and fibrous in the cocoanut.
A seasoned preparation, as of chicken, lobster, cheese, orfish, cooked in a drum-shaped mold; also, a pastry case, usuallysmall, filled with a cooked mixture.
A certain game of children; seesaw; -- called also titter-totter, and titter-cum-totter.
To gather what harvesters have left behind; to glean. [Obs.]Dryden.
A volatile, terpenelike oil extracted from the eucalyptus, andconsisting largely of cymene.
A hardened body formed by certain fungi, as by the Clavicepspurpurea, which produced ergot.
The act of redacting; work produced by redacting; a digest.
A young bullock or heifer. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.] Sir W. Scott.
To vex; to annoy; to offend contemptuously. [Obs.] Sir W.Raleigh.
Rudiments; first principles, as of grammar. [Obs.] Ford.
Approximately arctic; belonging to a region just without thearctic circle.
An agreement by which parties engage to submit any matter ofcontroversy between them to the decision of arbitrators. Wharton (LawDict.). Bouvier.
Not resilient; not recoiling or rebounding; inelastic.
One of several spores growing in a series or chain, andproduced by one of the fungi called brand.
In a catholic manner; generally; universally. Sir L. Cary.
To shudder with terror; to tremble with fear. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Quality of being corrigible; capability of being corrected;corrigibleness.
One who practices necromancy; a sorcerer; a wizard.
A trailing plant of the heath family (Arctostaphylos uva-ursi),having leaves which are tonic and astringent, and glossy red berriesof which bears are said to be fond.
A manufacturer of iron, or large dealer therein. Bp. Hurd.
The quality or state of being national; nationality. Johnson.
To name over or in a series; to recount. [Obs.] Shak.
One who deprives another of the possession of an estate bydiscontinuance. See Discontinuance, 2.
A litany beginning with the words. "Kyrie eleison." Shipley.
f or pertaining to the Trematodea. See Illustration inAppendix.
A bell; also, a set or combination of bells or metal platesused as a musical instrument or as a toy.
Resembling soap; having the qualities of soap; soapy.
The common sort of people; the crowd; the mob. [Obs.] Fuller.
The offense of marrying one person when already legally marriedto another. Wharton.
The process of restoring a cheek which has been destroyedwholly or in part.

A form of sleep or somnambulism brought on by artificial means,in which there is an unusual suspension of some powers, and anunusual activity of others. It is induced by an action upon thenerves, through the medium of the senses, as in persons of veryfeeble organization, by gazing steadly at a very bright object heldbefore the eyes, or by pressure upon certain points of the surface ofthe body.
A diarrhea, in which the food is discharged imperfectlydigested, or with but little change. Dunglison.
A charming; state of being bewitched or deluded. [Obs.]

Of or pertaining to Seljuk, a Tartar chief who embracedMohammedanism, and began the subjection of Western Asia to that faithand rule; of or pertaining to the dynasty founded by him, or theempire maintained by his descendants from the 10th to the 13thcentury. J. H. Newman.
To take one's self off; to decamp. [A jocular word. U. S.]
To state in too strong terms; to exaggerate. Fuller.
Long and tedious talk without much substance; superfluity ofwords.
An african ape (Anthropithecus troglodytes or Troglodytesniger) which approaches more nearly to man, in most respects, thanany other ape. When full grown, it is from three to four feet high.
To utter a deep guttural sound, sa an angry dog; to give forthan angry, grumbling sound. Gay.
The office of a deacon; deaconship; also, a body or board ofdeacons.
That branch of biological science, which treats of the minute(microscopic) structure of animal and vegetable tissues; -- calledalso histiology.
One who, or that which, twinkles, or winks; a winker; an eye.

One of the three surd mutes k, p, t; -- so called in relationto their respective middle letters, or medials, g, b, d, and theiraspirates, x, f, th. The term is also applied to the correspondingletters and articulate elements in other languages.
Any plant of the genus Arenaria, low, tufted herbs (orderCaryophyllace\'91.)
A genus of rosaceous plants, including the raspberry andblackberry.
The act or process of reducing to a formula; the state of beingformulized.
A salt of ricinoleic acid; -- formerly called palmate.
A narrow bend, esp. one half the width of the bend.
A sulphide of arsenic and silver of a beautiful cochineal-redcolor, occurring in rhombohedral crystals, and also massive; rubysilver.
Inserted in the manner of an interlude; having or containinginterludes.

A clay tablet on which was inscribed a contract, for safekeeping.  Such tablets were inclosed in an outer case (often calledthe envelope), on which was inscribed a duplicate of the inscriptionon the inclosed tablet.
A board with sixty-four squares of alternate color, used forplaying checkers or draughts.
The person against whom a judgment is obtained in commonrecovery.
A mineral water from Sellers, in the district of Nassan,Germany, containing much free carbonic acid.
That philosophy or doctrine which recognizes or deals only withexternals, or objects of sense perception; positivism; phenomenalism.
A lock, as on a canal, in which boats are weighed and theirtonnage is settled.
A cross formed of four capital gammas, formerly used as amysterious ornament on ecclesiastical vestments, etc. See Fylfot.
A smooth kind of cartridge paper used for making cards. Knight.
Any dipterous insect of the genus Oestrus, and allied genera ofbotflies.
The act of depriving or divesting of shoes. [Obs.] Chambers.
A disburser; especially, one of the disbursers of taxes for therepair of sewers. Mozley & W.
A ludicrous descent from the elevated to the low, in writing orspeech; anticlimax.
That part of the skeleton which is developed in tendons,ligaments, and aponeuroses.
Indentation in curved lines, as of a line of division or theedge of an ordinary.
The free-swimming, bivalve larva of certain Bryozoa.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a callithump. [U. S.]
A peculiar bronze adz, used in prehistoric Europe about themiddle of the bronze age. Dawkins.
A book kept by a depositor, in which an officer of a bankenters the debits and credits of the depositor's account with thebank.
The slope of a bank, especially of the bank of a steam.
An artificial division of vertebrates including those thatproduce their young alive; -- opposed to Ovipara.
A word consisting of three syllables only; as, a-ven-ger.

A kind of mica having generally a peculiar bronze-red orcopperlike color and a pearly luster. It is a silicate of aluminia,with magnesia, potash, and some fluorine. It is characteristic ofcrystalline limestone or dolomite and serpentine. See Mica.
The pitching or tossing of a vessel which results in thestraining of timbers and rigging.
Uncustomable; also, not having paid duty or customs. Smollett.
A depth of water so great that only those organisms can existthat do not assimilate.
A variety of black limestone, often polished for ornamentalpurposes.
A sleeper supporting and connecting the rails, and holding themin place.
An instrument in which motion is produced by the vibrations ofa sounding body.
The prominence in front of the external opening of the ear. SeeIllust. under Ear.
Of or pertaining to mountains; consisting of mountains.
A thin watery animal fluid, as synovial fluid and pericardialfluid.
Pertaining to an acid now called sulphovinic, or ethylsulphuric, acid.
One who snarls; a surly, growling animal; a grumbling,quarrelsome fellow.
One of a number of copies of anything multiplied mechanically.
Of great bulk or consequence; very important. [Obs.] Dr. H.More.
Of or relating to an arbiter or an arbitration. [R.]
A history or account of martyrs; a register of martyrs. Bp.Stillingfleet.
To break or separate into parts; to deflect, or decompose bydeflection, a
the common guillemot; -- applied also to various other seabirds.
The right of erecting a stalls in fairs; rent paid for a stall.

In an abbey or monastery, the room set apart for writing orcopying manuscripts; in general, a room devoted to writing.Writing rooms, or scriptoria, where the chief works of Latinliterature . . . were copied and illuminated. J. R. Green.
On of the native inhabitants of the pampas, of Spanish-Americandescent. They live mostly by rearing cattle.
Quickly; rapidly; -- a direction for a quick, lively movementor performance; quicker than allegro, or any rate of time exceptprestissimo.
A rough, hairy, perennial plant of several species, of thegenus Symphytum.
Remaining unchanged or invariable, as a quantity, forc, law,etc.
A long cloak or overcoat, especially one with a hood.
An autographic device to test the strength of raw silk.
An apple roasted till black, to be served in a dish of boiledcustard.
An apparatus for exposing briefly to view a screen bearingletters or figures. It is used in studying the range of attention, orthe power of distinguishing separate objects in a single impression.
Of small stature; not grown to a full height or size.
The process of separating a fusible substance from one lessfusible, by means of a degree of heat sufficient to melt the one andnot the other, as an alloy of copper and lead; liquation. Ure.

The god of the waters; the Indian Neptune. He is regarded asregent of the west, and lord of punishment, and is represented asriding on a sea monster, holding in his hand a snaky cord or noosewith which to bind offenders, under water.

A roofed open gallery. It differs from a veranda in being morearchitectural, and in forming more decidedly a part of the mainedifice to which it is attached; from a porch, in being intended notfor entrance but for an out-of-door sitting-room.
The annihilation or extinction of a right or obligation.Abbott.
One of the oil tubes in the fruit of umbelliferous plants.
Without bracteoles, or little bracts; -- said of a pedicel orflower stalk.
Near the umbilicus; -- applied especially to one or more smallveins which, in man, connect the portal vein with the epigastricveins in the front wall of the abdomen.

An albuminous body, belonging to the class of globulins,obtained from yolk of egg, of which it is the chief proteidconstituent, and from the seeds of many plants. From the latter itcan be separated in crystalline form.
To breathe; to inhale air into the lungs, and exhale it fromthem, successively, for the purpose of maintaining the vitality ofthe blood.
A representation, in the same picture, of two or events whichoccured at different times.
Wood allowed to a tenant for repairing the house and for fuel.This latter is often called firebote. See Bote.
The power or capacity of receiving impressions, as those of theexternal senses.
Bearing two kinds of heads or capitula; -- said of certaincomposite plants.
The state or quality of being conjunctive. Johnson.
Flowery; ornamental; running in rapid melodic figures,divisions, or passages, as in variations; full of fioriture or littleornamentations.
Of or pertaining to the periople; connected with the periople.
A group of Bryozoa in which the anus is within the circle oftentacles. See Pedicellina.
A machine for drawing and twisting slivers to form rovings.
To state or represent less strongly than may be donetruthfully.
To wander; to go astray; to err; to blunder; -- used of mentalprocesses. [R.] Byron.

The transfer of possession of personal property from a debtorto a creditor as security for a debt or engagement; also, thecontract created between the debtor and creditor by a thing being sodelivered or deposited, forming a species of bailment; also, thatwhich is so delivered or deposited; something put in pawn.
The condition of being composed of elements, or a thing socomposed.
A person employed in, or skilled in, diplomacy; a diplomat.In ability, Avaux had no superior among the numerous able diplomaticswhom his country then possessed. Macaulay.
A glyceride formed by the replacement of three hydrogen atomsin glycerin by acid radicals.
To bathe; to soothe or lull as by bathing. [Obs.] Spenser.
A dike of piles in the sea, a river, etc., to check theapproach of an enemy.

A stream; especially, a passage channel, or conduit for thewater that drives a mill wheel; or an artifical channel of water forhydraulic or placer mining; also, a chute for conveying logs orlumber down a declivity.
To make or become lively; to enliven; to animate; to take, orcause to take, an erect or bold attitude; -- usually with up.
To salute. [Obs.]There was no "good day" and no saluyng. Chaucer.
Having the longer axis vertical; -- said of erect stems. Encyc.Brit.

A natural susceptibility, characteristic of all livingorganisms, tissues, and cells, to the influence of certain stimuli,response being manifested in a variety of ways, -- as that quality inplants by which they exhibit motion under suitable stimulation; esp.,the property which living muscle processes, of responding either to adirect stimulus of its substance, or to the stimulating influence ofits nerve fibers, the response being indicated by a change of form,or contraction; contractility.
The swinging part of a flail which falls on the grain inthrashing; the swiple.
Serving to gratify; agreeable. [Obs.] Sir T. Herbert.
One who makes ar a trade or business; a mercenary. [R.]Spenser.
Not capable of being equaled or paralleled. [Obs.] Boyle.
Capacity of being kindled, or of becoming inflamed;inflammability.
The faculty of tracing effects to their causes. G. Combe.
To strip or deprive of hoops; to take away the hoops of.
A genus of pterodactyls in which the elongated tail supported aleathery expansion at the tip.
A genus of meliaceous trees consisting of one species(Sweitenia Mahogoni), the mahogany tree.
A silicate of iron and lime occurring in black prismaticcrystals and columnar masses.
Specifically, a lay association for devotion or for charitablepurposes.
The Athecata; -- so called because the medusoid buds are notinclosed in a capsule.
Magic in which the aid of demons is invoked; black or infernalmagic. Bp. Hurd.
To feed, attend, and bring up without the breast. Hudibras.
Of or pertaining to the ocean; -- applied especially to animalsthat live at the surface of the ocean, away from the coast.
An instrument to test the decoloring or bleaching power ofchloride of lime.
To dwell or reside for a time; to be temporary housed.
Capable of being extended or prolonged; extensible; ductile.

A powerful brass instrument of the trumpet kind, thought bysome to be the ancient sackbut, consisting of a tube in three parts,bent twice upon itself and ending in a bell. The middle part, bentdouble, slips into the outer parts, as in a telescope, so that bychange of the vibrating length any tone within the compass of theinstrument (which may be bass or tenor or alto or even, in rareinstances, soprano) is commanded. It is the only member of the familyof wind instruments whose scale, both diatonic and chromatic, iscomplete without the aid of keys or pistons, and which can slide fromnote to note as smoothly as the human voice or a violin. Softlyblown, it has a rich and mellow sound, which becomes harsh andblatant when the tones are forced; used with discretion, its effectis often solemn and majestic.
A South American wild dog (Canis cancrivorus); the crab-eatingdog.
The quality or state of being lean or thin; leanness.
Union of things in one mass or body. [R.] Dr. H. More.
Surrounding the stomach; -- applied to the body cavity ofBryozoa and various other Invertebrata.
In an inexpiable manner of degree; to a degree that admits ofno atonement.
One who, or that which, atomizes; esp., an instrument forreducing a liquid to spray for disinfecting, cooling, or perfuming.
A lively Scottish dance, resembling the reel, but slower; also,the tune.
A marine animal that spouts water; -- applied especially tocertain bivalve mollusks, like the long clams (Mya), which spout, orsquirt out, water when retiring into their holes.
One who lives on the common, without paying any rent, or havingland of his own.
The act of starving, or the state of being starved.
The relinquishment by the insured to the underwriters of whatmay remain of the property insured after a loss or damage by a perilinsured against.
One who practices the style of ornamentation called niello.
That which amuses, and serves to make time pass agreeably;sport; amusement; diversion.
To exist previously; to exist before something else.
A partition or door to direct or prevent a current of air.
asserting one's self, or one's own rights or claims; hence,putting one's self forward in a confident or assuming manner.
To exchange anew; to reverse (a previous exchange).
A measure of length; the eighth part of a mile; forty rods; twohundred and twenty yards.
A partaker of supremacy; one jointly supreme. Shak.
A young kitten; a whelp. [Obs. or Scot.] B. Jonson.
A tribe of Indians who formerly occupied Florida, where some ofthem still remain. They belonged to the Creek Confideration.
The state of being a son, or of bearing the relation of a son;filiation. Dr. H. More.
Spur gearing having teeth slanting across the face of thewheel, sometimes slanting in opposite directions from the middle.
A person who holds the bonds of a public or private corporationfor the payment of money at a certain time.
Successor or vicar; -- a title of the successors of Mohammedboth as temporal and spiritual rulers, now used by the sultans ofTurkey, [Writting also calif.]
A pale buff or white crystalline alkaloid derived fromquinoline, and used as an antipyretic in medicine.

Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C8H12O4 (calledalso terpentic acid), homologous with terebic acid, and obtained as awhite crystalline substance by the oxidation of oil of turpentinewith chromic acid.

To treat or test, as a liquid, with a solution of mercuriciodide in potassium iodide and potassium hydroxide, which is calledNessler's solution or Nessler's test, and is used to detect thepresence of ammonia.
One of a party among the Jews, composed of partisans of Herodof Galilee. They joined with the Pharisees against Christ.
The act of stripping off bark, or the state of being thusstripped; decortication.
Serving to recommend; recommending; commendatory. Swift.
The foramen or passage through the inner integument of anovule.
Lit., remember to die, i.e., that you must die; a warning to beprepared for death; an object, as a death's-head or a personalornament, usually emblematic, used as a reminder of death.
Force; compulsion, either in restraining or impelling. Sojth.
The practice of hanging, upon the cultivated fig tree, branchesof the wild fig infested with minute hymenopterous insects.
One skilled in breaking and extracting stone in the bladder.
Clear space under an arch, girder, and the like, sufficient toallow of easy passing underneath.
A small pocketknife; formerly, a knife used for making andmending quill pens.
The following of a profession, sport, etc., as an occupation; -- opposed to Ant: amateurism.
A peculiar affection or condition of the rays of light or heat,in consequence of which they exhibit different properties indifferent directions.
Dead pay; the crime of taking pay for the service of deadsoldiers, or for services not actually rendered by soldiers. [Obs.]Bacon.
A lively or mettlesome fellow. [Jocular, Scot.] Burns.
Any one of a series of hydrocarbons containing the nitro andthe nitroso or isonitroso group united to the same carbon atom.

Thinking chiefly or most readily through, or in terms relatedto, the sense of hearing; specif., thinking words as spoken, as aresult of familiarity with speech or of mental peculiarity; --opposed to eye-minded.
The quality or state of being volcanic, or volcanic origin;volcanicity. [R.]
Of or pertaining to flesh; specif. (Physiol. Chem.),
Sorrow or sadness over the present or future evils or woes ofthe world in general; sentimental pessimism.
In Europe, particularly in Belgium and Holland, and outdoorfestival and fair; in the United States, generally an indoorentertainment and fair combined.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acidrelated to the ureids, and obtained from parabanic acid as a whitesilky crystalline substance.

A rare metallic element, of the same group as platinum, whichit much resembles, being silver-white, but harder, and brittle, andindifferent to most corrosive agents. With the exception of osmium,it is the heaviest substance known, its specific gravity being 22.4.Symbol Ir. Atomic weight 192.5.
In an arbitrary manner; by will only; despotically; absolutely.
The dorsal transverse, or tubercular, process of a vertebra.See Vertebra.
To unsettle or disturb the order or due arrangement of; tothrow out of order.
A framework of timbers and plank backing for a shaft lining, toprevent caving, percolation of water, etc.
Having opposite surfaces exactly plane and parallel, as a pieceof glass.
Full of daring; adventurous. [Archaic] T. Campbell.
A finegrained rock, flintlike in fracture, consistingessentially of orthoclase feldspar with occasional grains of quartz.
A house or building appropriated to brewing; a brewery.
To be, to come, or to pass, between; to separate. [Obs.] Sir I.Newton.
The general plea or denial in an action of assumpsit.
Those books of the New Testament which were acknowledged ascanonical by the early church; -- distinguished from antilegomena.
One who enters accounts or names, etc., in a book; abookkeeper.
Of or pertaining to a vintage, or grape harvest. [R.]
Having lungs, or breathing organs similar to lungs.
In a illustrious manner; conspicuously; eminently; famously.Milton.
An instrument for measuring the volumes of gases or liquids byintroducing them into a vessel of known capacity.
To decree beforehand; to foreordain; to predestinate. Young.
A chitinous structure above the nervous cord in the thorax ofcertain Crustacea.
The process of finding how many times one number or quantity iscontained in another; the reverse of multiplication; also, the ruleby which the operation is performed.
Pertaining to the time before the Passover, or before Easter.
One whose employment is to remove dirt and defuse. Gay.
Pertaining to, or derived from, an acid intermediate betweenglutaric and aconitic acids.
That which is thrown into a scale to make weight; something oflittle account added to supply a deficiency or fill a gap.
A fetid European species of elder (Sambucus Ebulus); dwarfelder; wallwort; elderwort; -- called also Daneweed, Dane's weed, andDane's-blood.
To ordain or appoint beforehand: to predetermine: toforeordain. Milton.
To fail to apprehend; to misunderstand. [Obs.] Holland.
A colorless, aromatic, liquid hydrocarbon, C10H12O2 resemblingthe phenols, and hence also called eugenic acid. It is found in theoils of pimento and cloves.
A writing paper made in sheets, ordinarily 16 x 13 inches, andfolded so as to make a page 13 x 8 inches. See Paper.
A division of Coleoptera, having heteromerous tarsi.
The thin-walled summer spore which is produced during the so-called Uredo stage of certain rusts. See (in the Supplement)Uredinales, Heteroecious, etc.
Pertaining to saltpeter, or partaking of its qualities;impregnated with saltpeter. [Obs.]
Figures or half figures of men, used as columns to support anentablature; -- called also telamones. See Caryatides. Oxf. Gloss.
A topmast arranged with metal bands so that it will readilyslide up and down the lower mast.
Like, or pertaining to, the crocodile; characteristic of thecrocodile.-- n.
A stupid or insignaficant fellow; a fool; a simpleton. [R.]Hudibras.
One who tears or rends anything; also, one who rages or raveswith violence.
A plea, in which it is alleged that the woman suing for dowerwas not lawfully married to the man in whose lands she seeks to beendowed, but that she was his concubine.
The tin ore which collects in the central part of the washingpit or buddle.

A rare nonmetallic element found in certain minerals, astantalite, samarskite, and fergusonite, and isolated as a dark powderwhich becomes steel-gray by burnishing. Symbol Ta. Atomic weight182.0. Formerly called also tantalium.
Exhibiting a downward convexity caused by unequal growth. Cf.Epinastic.
Not capable of being shaken; firm; fixed. Shak. J. S. Mill.
Induration of the tissues. See Sclerma, Scleroderma, andSclerosis.
A woman born, or dwelling, in the country, as opposed to thecity; a woman born or dwelling in the same country with anothernative or inhabitant. Shak.
A wall built across the ditch of a fortification, with a sluicegate to regulate the height of water in the ditch on both sides ofthe wall.
Approximately polygonal; somewhat or almost polygonal.
Pertaining to one or more small elements in the hyoidean archof fishes, between the caratohyal and urohyal.-- n.
An ornamental stand, usually with three legs, having caddiesfor holding tea.
An officer selected by a general to carry orders, also toassist or represent him in correspondence and in directing movements.
To tell beforehand; to signify by tokens; to predestine. [Obs.]Spenser.

Orig., a method of therapeutic treatment administered, esp. forchronic diseases of the curculatory system, at Bad Nauheim, Germany,by G. Schott, consisting in baths in the natural mineral waters ofthat place, which are charged with carbonic acid, and the use of agraduated course of rest, physical exercises, massage, etc.; hence,any similar treatment using waters artificially charged with theessential ingredients of the natural mineral waters of Bad Nauheim.Hence, Nauheim bath, etc.
Intermediate time or space; interval. [Poetic & R.] Shak.
Designating, or pertaining to, an acid isomeric with cyanuricacid, and called also fulminuric acid. See under Fulminuric.
The group of Arachnida which includes the mites and ticks. Manyspecies are parasitic, and cause diseases like the itch and mange.
Of or pertaining to the realists; in the manner of therealists; characterized by realism rather than by imagination.
A preliminary sketch of the plot, or main incidents, of anopera.
A road or way open to the use of the public; a main road orthoroughfare.
Of the Hedgehog family; like, or characteristic of, a hedgehog.
To cause an overfullness of the blood vessels (esp. thecapillaries) of an organ or part.
One of two magistrates of Rome who took a register of thenumber and property of citizens, and who also exercised the office ofinspector of morals and conduct.
Having the same properties in all directions; specifically,equally elastic in all directions.
State of being backhanded; the using of backhanded or indirectmethods.
An instrument of metal, ivory, etc., used for scraping the skinat the bath.
An apparatus for the production of sound by the action of raysof light. A. G. Bell.
The sterm of a tree., esp. a sterm without a branch, as of apalm or a tree fern; also, the pernnial rootstock of an herbaceousplant.
The green papery fronds of several seaweeds of the genus Ulva,sometimes used as food.
The operation of dividing a bone or of cutting a piece out ofit, -- done to remedy deformity, etc.
A dark race inhabiting the Micronesian Islands. They aresupposed to be a mixed race, derived from Polynesians and Papuans.
The act of avouching; positive declaration. [Obs.] Milton.
To strew or scatter over; to besprinkle. [Spelt also bestrow.]Milton.
To put out of phase, as two parts of a single alternatingcurrent.
A strap leading from the bellyband to the lower part of thecollar, to keep the collar in place.
Of or pertaining to meadows; resembling, or consisting of,meadow.
One who analyzes; formerly, one skilled in algebraicalgeometry; now commonly, one skilled in chemical analysis.
The middle bark of a tree; the green layer of bark, usuallysoon covered by the outer or corky layer, and obliterated.
The winged cap of Mercury; also, a broad-brimmed, low-crownedhat worn by Greeks and Romans.
Thin boards for shealting, as above the rafters, and under theshingles or slates, and for similar purposes.
To bring together, or nearer together, in masonry, as where thewidth of a fireplace is rapidly diminished to the width of the flue,or the like.
One of the segments first formed by the division of the ovum.Balfour.
In two figures having relative motion, one of the two curveswhich are the loci of the instantaneous center.
A lesson from the Torah, or Law, from which at least onesection is read in the Jewish synagogue on every Sabbath andfestival.
The sixth tone of the scale; the under mediant, or third belowthe keynote; the superdominant.
That has no finite period of revolution; not revolving. [R.]The dateless and irrevocable circle of eternity. Milton.
A modification of the magic lantern, used esp. for throwing amagnified image of an opaque object on a screen, solar or artificiallight being used.
A compound similar to sulphonal, used as a hypnotic inmedicine.
A battlement in ancient fortifications with interstices forfiring through.
To make sibilant; to change to a sibilant. J. Peile.
A carbonate containing an excess of the basic constituent.
A genus of water lilies, growing in India and China. The onlyspecies (E. ferox) is very prickly on the peduncles and calyx. Therootstocks and seeds are used as food.
In a neutral manner; without taking part with either side;indifferently.
The person at a geodetic station who has charge of theheliotrope.
To say by way of derogation or contradiction. [Obs.] Spenser.
A hydrous silicate of magnesium, allied to serpentine,occurring in waxlike masses of a yellow or greenish color.
Drying oil; a substance mingled with the oil used in oilpainting to make it dry quickly.
Pertaining to, or designating, a yellow crystalline substance(called also perthiocyanic acid), analogous to sulphocyanic acid, butcontaining more sulphur.
A concretion of mineral matter within a leaf or other part of aplant.

Sugar of milk or milk sugar; a crystalline sugar present inmilk, and separable from the whey by evaporation and crystallization.It has a slightly sweet taste, is dextrorotary, and is much lesssoluble in water than either cane sugar or glucose. Formerly calledlactin.
A term applied to fabrics for the gowns of women and girls; --most commonly to fabrics of mixed materials, but also applicable tosilks, printed linens, and calicoes.
Any larval gastropod or bivalve mollusk in the state when it isfurnished with one or two ciliated membranes for swimming.
The faculty possessed by all substances capable of self-nourishment of manifesting the nutritive acts by changes of form, ofvolume, or of structure. Syd. Soc. Lex.
A crystalline rock consisting of quarts and mica, common in thetin regions of Cornwall and Saxony.
An instrument, acting on the principle of Pitot's tube, formeasuring the velocity of a fluid current, the speed of a ship, etc.
The art of measuring the world or the universe. Blount.
The theory or practice of paternal government. See Paternalgovernment, under Paternal. London Times.
Applied to spokes when they are arranged alternately in twocircles in the hub. See Straddle, v. i., and Straddle, v. t., 3.Knight.
The person on whom an order or bill of exchange is drawn; --the correlative of drawer.
Spent with heat; covered with sweat. [Obs.] P. Sidney.
A set of verses so disposed that the name forming the subjectof the acrostic occurs five times -- the whole set of verses beingdivided into five different parts from top to bottom.
Designating, or pert. to, a gear for reducing or increasing avelocity ratio two to one.

A genus of plants embracing several species ad varietiesdiffering much in appearance and qualities: such as the commoncabbage (B. oleracea), broccoli, cauliflowers, etc.; the wild turnip(B. campestris); the common turnip (B. rapa); the rape of coleseed(B. napus), etc.
Having the heart completely divided or double, one sidesystemic, the other pulmonary.
The crushing of a child's head, as with the cranioclast orcraniotomy forceps in cases of very difficult delivery. Dunglison.
Inferior or subordinate work; petty business. Addison.
To mark with spots of different color, or shades of color, asif stained; to spot; to maculate.
A vertical iron bolt, by which the forward axle and wheels of avehicle or the trucks of a railroad car are connected with the otherparts.
The art practiced by conjurers and witches; necromancy;conjuration; magic.
An uxorious, effeminate, or spiritless man. [Obs.] Johnson.
To bathe; also, to dry or heat, as unseasoned wood. [Obs.]Spenser.
Pertaining to a process or a style of printing from charactersin relief on zinc plates.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of antimony analogous topyrophosphoric acid.
The bank of a canal opposite, and corresponding to, that of thetowpath; berm. [U. S.]
Of or pertaining to the centumviri, or to a centumvir.
Of or pertaining an acid intermediate between malic acid andmalamide, and known only by its salts.
A tax or imposition an a dwelling within a certain distance ofa castle, for the purpose of maintaining watch and ward in it;castle-ward.
A kind of musical toy into which one sings, hums, or speaks,producing a coarse, reedy sound.
To convene or assemble again; to call or come together again.
A smooth triangular area on the inner surface of the bladder,limited by the apertures of the ureters and urethra.
A greedy or ravenous eater; a luxurious feeder; a gourmand.
A table for holding working materials and implements; esp., asmall table with drawers and other conveniences for needlework, etc.
A little sac; esp., a part of the membranous labyrinth of theear. See the Note under Ear.
Scent or savor of meat or food, cooked or cooking. [Obs.] Jer.Taylor.
To arrange or dispose in a certain form, figure, or shape.Bentley.

A word of doubtful meaning, occuring frequently in the Psalms;by some, supposed to signify silence or a pause in the musicalperformance of the song.Beyond the fact that Selach is a musical term, we know absolutelynothing about it. Dr. W. Smith (Bib. Dict.)
The art of measuring and computing the cubical contents ofbodies and figures; -- distinguished from planimetry.
Of or pertaining to a seismograph; indicated by a seismograph.
The smaller intestines of swine, etc., fried for food.
The proboscis of hemipterous insects. See Illust. underHemiptera.
One who, or that which, excavates or hollows out; a machine, asa dredging machine, or a tool, for excavating.
An apparatus for determining the temperature of a distantpoint, as by a thermoelectric circuit or otherwise.
Any law, which, after it had passed the Athenian senate, wasfixed on a tablet for public inspection previously to its beingproposed to the general assembly of the people.
A kind of granite from Luxullian, Cornwall, characterized bythe presence of radiating groups of minute tourmaline crystals.
A large, fat variety of the namaycusa found in Lake Superior; -- called also siskawet, siskiwit.
Any species of the order Ophidia; an ophidian; a serpent,whether harmless or venomous. See Ophidia, and Serpent.
Of or pertaining to a syrt; resembling syrt, or quicksand. [R.]Ed. Rev.
A division of raptorial birds composing the vultures.
A person in some way remarkable with regard to the number four,as one born on the fourth day of the month, or one who reverencedfour persons in the Godhead. Smart.
To remove the face or cover from; to unmask; to expose.
A dealer in aphorisms. [Used in derogation or contempt.]Milton.
A wig, in use in the 18th century, with the hair at the back ofthe head in a bag.
A defender or an advocate in court; a guardian or protector.
The quality of being inexcusable; enormity forgiveness. South.
A furnace and forge in which wrought iron in the form of bloomsis made directly from the ore, or (more rarely) from cast iron.
A fruit consisting of many dry indehiscent cells, which containbut few seeds and cohere about a common style, as in the mallows.
The time or state of being a puppy; the time of being young andundisciplined.
An alloy of copper and zinc, resembling gold; a yellow metal,composed of about three ounces of zinc to a pound of copper. It ismuch used as an imitation of gold in the manufacture of cheapjewelry.
The reciprocal existence in each other of the three persons ofthe Trinity.
A fish of the Pacific coast (Chromis, or Heliastes,punctipinnis), of a blackish color.
Pertaining to the firmament; celestial; being of the upperregions. Dryden.
Of or pertaining to a professor; as, the professional chair;professional interest.
The condition of being a beggar; also, the class of beggars.
An officer in the Court of Chancery, whose business is to makeout original writs.
A tree (Galactodendron utile or Brosimum Galactodendron) ofSouth America, which yields, on incision, a nourishing fluid,resembling milk.
Not abridged, or shortened; full; complete; entire; whole.
A floss or waste obtained from the cocoon after the silk hasbeen reeled off, used for shag.
A Highland robber: a kind of irregular soldier. [Scot.] Sir W.Scott.
A body of felons; specifically, the convict population of apenal colony. Howitt.
One who keeps a stall for the sale of merchandise, especiallybooks. Sterne.
The formation of bone; the process, in the growth of an animal,by which inorganic material (mainly lime salts) is deposited incartilage or membrane, forming bony tissue; ostosis.
A case or box placed near the helmsman, containing the compassof a ship, and a light to show it at night. Totten.
A blustering, talkative fellow. [Local slang, U. S.] Barllett.
Pertaining to, or resembling, zinc; -- said of the electricityof the zincous plate in connection with a copper plate in a voltaiccircle; also, designating the positive pole. [Obs.]
The act of reflexing; the state of being retroflexed. Cf.Retroversion.
A fragrant essential oil; esp., a volatile and highly fragrantessential oil obtained from the petals of roses. [Also written ottoand ottar.]
In games, a zero; a score or record of naught; -- so named inallusion to the egglike outline of the zero sign 0. Called also duckegg. [Slang]
To cure, as herrings, by salting and smoking them; to bloat.[Obs.]
An assembly or association of Greeks from all the states ofGreece.
A yellow amorphous substance extracted from juniper berries.
Want of dexterity or readiness, especially in the use of thehands; clumsiness; awkwardness. Harvey.
The state or quality of being unreconciled; disagreement.
Winding around something; twisting; embracing; climbing bywinding about a support; as, the hop is a twinning plant.
The condition or quality of being fuliginous; sootiness; matterdeposited by smoke. [R.]
The quality of being done or devised extempore [Obs.] Johnson.
The ancient custom of betrothing by the bestowal, on the partof the man, of marriage gifts or tokens, as money, rings, or otherpresents, upon the woman.

A fish (Lophius piscatorius), of Europe and America, having alarge, broad, and depressed head, with the mouth very large. Peculiarappendages on the head are said to be used to entice fishes withinreach. Called also fishing frog, frogfish, toadfish, goosefish,allmouth, monkfish, etc.

Shaped like a saddle. Specifically:(a) (Bot.) Bent down at the sides so as to give the upper part arounded form. Henslow.(b) (Geol.) Bent on each side of a mountain or ridge, without beingbroken at top; -- said of strata.
Pertaining to the interior of the stomach; -- applied to a modeof budding from the interior of the gastric cavity, in certainhydroids.
A leap that a horse makes with all fours, upwards only, withoutadvancing, but with a kick or jerk of the hind legs when at theheight of the leap.
The bone of the rump; also, the cut of beef surrounding thisbone. [Spelt also edgebone.]
A steam engine having two or more steam cylinders in line, witha common piston rod.
A group of African edentates including the aard-vark.

That property which some transparent bodies have of producingat their surface, or within their substance, light different in colorfrom the mass of the material, as when green crystals of fluor sparafford blue reflections. It is due not to the difference in the colorof a distinct surface layer, but to the power which the substance hasof modifying the light incident upon it. The light emitted byfluorescent substances is in general of lower refrangibility than theincident light. Stockes.
A sparoid fish (Diabasis aurolineatus) of the Gulf of Mexico,esteemed as a food fish; -- called also red-mouth grunt.
Any small leguminous plant of the genus Lathyrus, especially L.Nissolia.
By presumption, or supposition grounded or probability;presumably.
A mineral of a brownish red color and vitreous luster,consisting chiefly of the silicates of iron, zirconia, and lime.
An ecclesiastic council or meeting to consult on churchmatters.
A work constructed beyond the main ditch of a fortress, and infront of the curtain between two bastions, intended to defend thecurtain; a ravelin. See Ravelin.
A division of parasitic hemipterous insects, including the truelice. See Illust. in Appendix.

A contract in the nature of a mortgage, by which the owner of aship, or the master as his agent, hypothecates and binds the ship(and sometimes the accruing freight) as security for the repayment ofmoney advanced or lent for the use of the ship, if she terminates hervoyage successfully. If the ship is lost by perils of the sea, thelender loses the money; but if the ship arrives safe, he is toreceive the money lent, with the interest or premium stipulated,although it may, and usually does, exceed the legal rate of interest.See Hypothecation.

An arrangement of two photographic cameras, the plates of whichmay be brought into exactly the same plane, used in surveying and mapmaking. From the differences between two pictures taken at the samemoment, measurements in all dimensions of the region may be obtained.
A male person castrated for the purpose of improving his voicefor singing; an artificial, or male, soprano. Swift.

An epithet applied to editions (chiefly of the classics) whichproceeded from the press of Aldus Manitius, and his family, ofVenice, for the most part in the 16th century and known by the signof the anchor and the dolphin. The term has also been applied tocertain elegant editions of English works.
One of the leather screens on a bridle, to hinder a horse fromseeing objects at the side; a blinker.
Any one of three metameric substances, CH3.C6H4.OH, homologouswith and resembling phenol. They are obtained from coal tar and woodtar, and are colorless, oily liquids or solids.
A patriarchal form of government or society. See Patriarchal,a., 3.
Capable of being plowed or cultivated; arable; tillable. [Obs.]Cowell.
A small collection of sheaves set up in the field; a shock; inEngland, twelve sheaves.
One of a faction in Italy, in the 12th and 13th centuries,which favored the German emperors, and opposed the Guelfs, oradherents of the poses. Brande & C.
Caused to ride or drive by the wind in opposition to the courseof the tide; -- said of a vessel lying at anchor, with wind and tideopposed to each other. Totten.
A kind of divination performed by drawing a ring or circle, andwalking in or around it. Brande & C.
A dioptric telescope, fitted with two tubes joining, so as toenable a person to view an object with both eyes at once; a double-barreled field glass or an opera glass.
In Louisiana, a person reputed to be Acadian French descent.
A cave, grotto, or subterraneous place of large extent used forthe burial of the dead; -- commonly in the plural.
A writing upon the back of anything, as upon the back of a leafor sheet already written upon on one side. [R.] Scudamore.
Of or pertaining to Freemasons or to their craft or mysteries.
One who does homage, or holds land of another by homage; avassal. Bacon.
An Anglo-Indian name for a person just arrived from Europe. H.Kingsley.
A European fresh-water fish (Tinca tinca, or T. vulgaris)allied to the carp. It is noted for its tenacity of life.
A figure by which a person seeks to convince and move by anelegant kind of upbraiding.
One whose official duty it is to examine and inquire, ascoroners, sheriffs, etc. Mozley & W.
A verdict on a preliminary investigation, finding the fact of acrime but not stating the criminal, or finding the fact of a violentdeath without disclosing the cause.
Banishment by popular vote, -- a means adopted at Athens to ridthe city of a person whose talent and influence gave umbrage.
The doctrine that all things exist or are controlled by chance.
The union of being and relation as distinguished from, andcontrasted with, the ego. See Ego.
In a concerned manner; solicitously; sympathetically.
Broken out, or marked, with smallpox; pock-fretten.
Am, is, or are, not able; -- written either as one word or two.
A kind of furnace used in refining, to separate the metal fromcinders and other foreign matter. Chambers.
An acute specific disease with a dusky red cutaneous eruptionresembling that of measles, but unattended by catarrhal symptoms; --called also German measles.
Any one of certain class of organic bases regarded as formedfrom ammonia by the substitution of phenyl for hydrogen.
Brisk; vivacious; with spirit; -- a direction to perform apassage in a brisk and lively manner.
Having but one septum, or partition; -- said of two-celledfruits, such as the silicles of cruciferous plants.
Pertaining to tufa; consisting of, or resembling, tufa.
The offense of violating the pledge given by every inhabitantof a tithing to keep the peace; breach of the peace. Burrill.
To adopt the opinion of Plato or his followers. Milner.
The system of doctrines and church polity inculcated by JohnWesley (b. 1703; d. 1791), the founder of the religious sect calledMethodist; Methodism. See Methodist, n., 2.
