A figure or polygon having nine sides and nine angles.
A time of feasting or celebration; an anniversary day of joy,civil or religious.The morning trumpets festival proclaimed. Milton.
To prate; to talk much and idly; to gabble; to chatter; totwaddle; as, a twattling gossip. L'Estrange.
A form of malarial fever occurring along the Chagres River,Panama.
The act of driving away or repelling; a keeping at a distance.[Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Of or pertaining to the plague or contagious disorders.
To procure or cause to take a false oath amounting to perjury,such oath being actually taken. Sir W. O. Russell.
One who defiles; one who corrupts or violates; that whichpollutes.
The quality or state of being abominable; odiousness. Bentley.
Pertaining to Abraham, the patriarch; as, the Abrachamiccovenant.
The act of sensualizing, or the state of being sensualized.
One who performs little though professing much. [Colloq.]Great talkers are commonly dolittles. Bp. Richardson.
One who sympathizes; a sympathizer. [R.] Coleridge.
Bearing the cross; marked with the figure of a cross. Sir. T.Browne.
Belonging to present times or those recent by comparison.
A kind of light armor used in the sixteenth century, esp. bythe Swiss. Fairholt.
A genus of poisonous serpents, including the rattlesnakes.
Opinion previously formed; prepossession; prejudice. Sir T.Browne.
The art of writing or compiling encyclopedias; also, possessionof the whole range of knowledge; encyclopedic learning.
Work made of wood; that part of any structure which is wroughtof wood.
An alkaloid obtained, as a bitter, yellow substance, from theroot of the barberry, gold thread, and other plants.
A prism whose refracting angle is very nearly 180 degrees.
Merchantlike; suitable to the character or business of amerchant. [Obs.] Gauden.
Any one of five hydrocarbons, C6H14, of the paraffin series.They are colorless, volatile liquids, and are so called because themolecule has six carbon atoms.
An old form of gunlock containing a match for firing thepriming; hence, a musket fired by means of a match.
An outer garment for men or women, originally of fur, or linedwith fur; a lady's outer garment, made of silk or other fabric.
The art of mechanically multiplying copies of a writing, or anywork of art.
To travel from place to place, or from one country to another;hence, to sojourn in foreign countries.
Semipalmate and loboped, as a grebe's foot. See Illust. underAves.
Having nerves, or simple and parallel ribs or veins. Gray.
Capable of neutralizing, or combining with, five molecules of amonobasic acid; having five hydrogen atoms capable of substitution byacid residues; -- said of certain complex bases.
The dwarf cornel (Cornus Canadensis), which bears a densecluster of bright red, edible berries.
A representation of the dead Christ, attended by the VirginMary or by holy women and angels. Mollett.

That property, due to molecular forces, which exists in thesurface film of all liquids and tends to bring the contained volumeinto a form having the least superficial area. The thickness of thisfilm, amounting to less than a thousandth of a millimeter, isconsidered to equal the radius of the sphere of molecular action,that is, the greatest distance at which there is cohesion between twoparticles. Particles lying below this film, being equally acted onfrom all sides, are in equilibrium as to forces of cohesion, butthose in the film are on the whole attracted inward, and tensionresults.
The art or science of cultivating the earth; agriculture.Evelin.
The pharalope; -- so called because its toes are like thecoot's.

A plane surface divided in one direction with linesrepresenting hours and minutes, and in the other with linesrepresenting miles, and having diagonals (usually movable strings)representing the speed and position of various trains.
Capable of being wearied or tired out. [R.] Glanvill.
A militiaman who was to be ready to march at a moment's notice;-- a term used in the American Revolution.
An instrument of horn used for collecting painters' colors onthe stone in the process of grinding.

A form of impulse turbine or water wheel, consisting of a rowof double cup-shaped buckets arranged round the rim of a wheel andactuated by one or more jets of water playing into the cups at highvelocity.
Divided in a pinnate manner, with the divisions not reaching tothe midrib.
An extensive division of Coleoptera, including those thatnormally have five-jointed tarsi. It embraces about half of all theknown species of the Coleoptera.
A deposit more or less resembling an inverted stalactite,formed by calcareous water dropping on the floors of caverns; hence,a similar deposit of other material.
Act of winding up, or closing; a concluding act or part; theend.
The state or quality of being big; largeness; size; bulk.
A Paris candle anciently used in England; also, a large waxcandle formerly set upon the altar. [Obs.] Bailey.
A switchboard in which connections are made by means of plugs.
An exclamation of contempt, disgust, or abhorrence.
A small genus of perennial herbaceous plants, with poisonousmilky juice, bearing slender pods pods in pairs.
An ulcer or fistula in the inner corner of the eye.
A mineral occurring in yellowish, and ruby-red hexagonalcrystals. It consist of lead vanadate with a small proportion of leadchloride.
The state or quality of being imperdible. [Obs.] Derham.

A subdivision in the lower Silurian system of America; -- sonamed from Trenton Falls, in New York. The rocks are mostlylimestones, and the period is divided into the Trenton, Utica, andCincinnati epochs. See the Chart of Geology.
A book containing a collection of antiphons; the book in whichthe antiphons of the breviary, with their musical notes, arecontained.
Having the toes firmly united together for some distance, andwithout an intermediate web, as the kingfishers; gressorial.
The pomegranate tree (Punica granatum). The bark of the root,the rind of the fruit, and the flowers are used medicinally.
Having a very narrow border of another tincture; -- said esp.of an ordinary or subordinary.
A propensity to steal, claimed to be irresistible. This doesnot constitute legal irresponsibility. Wharton.
Of or pertaining to Nepaul, a kingdom in Northern Hindostan.-- n. sing. & pl.
Pertaining to, or connected with, nutrition; nutritious. [Obs.]Chapman.
One of a fraternity of seculars, also called Penitents.
A male who submits to the crime against nature; a catamite.[R.] B. Jonson.
Not decimable, or liable to be decimated; not liable to thepayment of tithes. Cowell.
Emotion of desire; inclination; velleity. [Obs.] Hammond.
A poetic foot, composed of one short syllable between two longones (-Bentley.
A method of going from one tack to another. See Boxhaul.
The act of nasalizing, or the state of being nasalized.
A game in which the object is to snap small disks of bone,ivory, or the like, from a flat surface, as of a table, into a smallcup or basket; --called also tiddlywinks. [U. S.]
To ornament with a bordure of emines, furs, and the like; also,with gold studs or mountings.
A cooper's tool for making the grooves for the heads of casks,etc.; also, the groove itself.
An American grape, a form of Vitis vulpina, found in theSouthern Atlantic States, and often cultivated.
A shop where slops. or ready-made clothes, are sold.

The act of a feudatory, vassal, or tenant, by which heconsents, upon the alienation of an estate, to receive a new lord orsuperior, and transfers to him his homage and service; the agreementof a tenant to acknowledge the purchaser of the estate as hislandlord. Burrill. Blackstone.
The act of stripping off the bark, rind, hull, or outer coat.
One who believes in the millennium. [Obs.] Johnson.
Signals made by burning lights of different colors and used byvessels at sea, and in the life-saving service; -- named after theirinventor.
To divest of reality; to make uncertain. [Obs.] Udall.
An artificial, orange dyestuff, analogous to tropaolin, andlike it used as an indicator in alkalimetry; -- called also methylorange.
A measure of grain equal to 0.7218 of an imperial quarter, or5.95 Winchester bushels. [Russia]
A disease in which worms are present in some part of the body.
Pain; especially, pain of travail; throe. [Obs.] Spenser.Dryden.
To struggle, as in sport; to scuffle; to struggle with.[Colloq.]
A tuft or ball of wool, or the like, sometimes worn by soldierson the front of the hat, instead of a feather.
The act of pronouncing; a declaration; a formal announcement.
To make, or to describe as, female or feminine. Shaftesbury.
The highest judicial court at Athens. Its sessions were held onMars' Hill. Hence, any high court or tribunal
Having but one pair of leaflets; -- said of a pinnate leaf.

Dizziness or swimming of the head; an affection of the head inwhich objects, though stationary, appear to move in variousdirections, and the person affected finds it difficult to maintain anerect posture; giddiness. Quian.
A picture made up of several smaller pictures, drawn uponseparate pieces in such a manner as to admit of combination in manydifferent ways, thus producing a great variety of scenes orlandscapes.
Three times ternate; -- applied to a leaf whose petioleseparates into three branches, each of which divides into three partswhich each bear three leafiets.
The state or condition of being perpetual. [Obs.] Testament ofLove.
The quality or state of being placid; calmness; serenity.Hawthorne.
Capable of being endowed; entitled to dower. Blackstone.
In Japan, under the feudal system, a samurai who had renouncedhis clan or who had been discharged or ostracized and had become awanderer without a lord; an outcast; an outlaw.
The state of a parent; the office or character of a parent.
A myrtaceous genus of trees, mostly Australian. Many of themgrow to an immense height, one or two species exceeding the heighteven of the California Sequoia.
A voice or utterance which appears to proceed from the stomach;ventriloquy.
Having the edge veined or spotted with different colors likemarble, as a book.
The art or process of reducing gold to extremely thin leaves,by beating with a hammer. Ure.
The state or quality of being remissible. Jer. Taylor.
The Spanish sweet pepper, the fruit of which is used as avegetable, to stuff olives, etc.
Cabbage cut fine and allowed to ferment in a brine made of itsown juice with salt, -- a German dish.
Incapable of being mastered or subdued. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
On the Austrian side of the river Leitha; Austrian.
A knight of the most ancient, but lowest, order of Englishknights, and not a member of any order of chivalry. See Bachelor, 4.
A design of motor-boat stern, for  use in shallow waters, inwhich the propeller is housed in a tunnel and does not extend belowthe greatest draft.
A member of a vestry; especially (Prot. Epis. Ch.), a memberother than a warden. See Vestry.
One whose employment it is to catch birds; a fowler.
To attend to; to apply one's self to. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A non-metallic, gaseous element, strongly acid or negative, orassociated with chlorine, bromine, and iodine, in the halogen groupof which it is the first member. It always occurs combined, is veryactive chemically, and possesses such an avidity for most elements,and silicon especially, that it can neither be prepared nor kept inglass vessels. If set free it immediately attacks the containingmaterial, so that it was not isolated until 1886. It is a pungent,corrosive, colorless gas. Symbol F. Atomic weight 19.

A phenol metameric with phloroglucin, obtained by thedistillation of gallic acid as a poisonous white crystallinesubstance having acid properties, and hence called also pyrogallicacid. It is a strong reducer, and is used as a developer inphotography and in the production of certain dyes.
A bushman carrying a swag and traveling on foot; -- called alsoswagsman, swagger, and swaggie.
Capacity for induction; the coefficient of self-induction.
Serving or tending to excite; excitative. [R.] Bamfield.
Having a back like that of roach; -- said of a horse whose backa convex instead of a concave curve.
A very small libratory motion of the earth's axis, by which itsinclination to the plane of the ecliptic is constantly varying by asmall amount.
Tending to contract; having the property or power or power ofcontracting.
A kind of fustian made of coarse twilled cotton, shorn afterdyeing. Simmonds.
Compact; pressed close; concentrated; firmly united.
The principal rafters of a roof, especially a pair of rafterstaken together. [Obs.]

A feeler; especially, one of the jointed sense organs attachedto the mouth organs of insects, arachnids, crustaceans, and annelids;as, the mandibular palpi, maxillary palpi, and labial palpi. Thepalpi of male spiders serve as sexual organs. Called also palp. SeeIllust. of Arthrogastra and Orthoptera.

Hydrous sesquixoide of iron, an important ore of iron,occurring in stalactitic, mammillary, or earthy forms, of a darkbrown color, yellowish brown powder. It includes bog iron. Alsocalled brown hematite.
The name of several poisonous umbelliferous herbs having finelycut leaves and small white flowers, as the Cicuta maculata,bulbifera, and virosa, and the Conium maculatum. See Conium.
An order of insects, which includes the butterflies and moths.They have broad wings, covered with minute overlapping scales,usually brightly colored.
One who gets, gains, obtains, acquires, begets, or procreates.
Any extension of a church behind the higggggggh altar, as achapel; also, in an apsidal church, all the space beyond the line ofthe back or eastern face of the altar.
A short blunt arrow for killing birds without piercing them.Hence: Anything which smites without penetrating. Shak.
Wanting a distinct meaning; having no certain signification.[R.] Puller.
A present, as of corn, wine, or oil, made by a Roman emperor tothe soldiers or the people; -- so called because measured to each ina congius. Addison.
The theory or doctrine that the human races have a commonorigin, or constitute a single species.
Any organ of an animal having a structure adapted to produce aratting sound.
The quality or state of being produced by nature. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
Defending, or tending to defend, one's own person, property, orreputation.
A receding or giving up; a complete surrender. [Colloq.]
The sprout at the end of a seed when it begins to germinate;the plumule in germination; -- so called from its spiral form.
. A fine oil obtained from the kernel of Prunus brigantiaca. Itis used instead of olive or almond oil. De Colange.
A free-swimming, dimorphic, sexual form of certain species ofNereis.
A throwing or tossing of the body; a shaking or agitation. Sir.W. Temple.
Pertaining to, or derived from, or designating, an organic acidobtained by the decomposition of phloretin.
A male cat, esp. an old one. See lst Gib. n. [Obs.] Shak.
The main part or blade of the rudder, which is connected byhinges, or the like, with the sternpost of a vessel.
The state of being fleshly; carnal passions and appetites.Spenser.
Tending to allay venereal excitement or desire; sedative.
Ossification which takes place in purely fibrous tracts; theformation of bone outside of the periosteum.
A minute smooth rodlike or fusiform structure found in thetissues of many Turbellaria.
The act of fuming with incense, or the act of burning incense.
A kind of worsted braid, about an inch broad. [Scot.] Jamieson.
A writ commanding the sheriff to distrain a person by his goodsor chattels, to compel a compliance with something required of him.
A division of the Turbellaria in which the digestive cavitygives off lateral branches, which are often divided into smallerbranchlets.
A woman invested with authority to command. Hooker.
A plant (Eryngium foetidum) supposed to be a remedy for fits.
Living through the winter, or from year to year; perennial.[R.]
A soothsaying; a foretelling. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Pertaining to, or designating, one of several isomeric acidsobtained from citric acid.
A style of type having a narrow and heave face. It is made inall sizes.
A small European kinglet (Regulus ignicapillus), having abright red crest; -- called also fire-crested wren.
Mild as a dove; gentle; pure and lovable. Longfellow.
A proclamation or manifesto; a formal announcement ordeclaration.
Resembling the capitulum of burdock; covered with forkedpoints.
An organic base, especially one of a class of substancesoccurring ready formed in the tissues of plants and the bodies ofanimals.
A bending downward; a sloping; incurvation downward; declivity.[R.] Davies (Wit's Pilgr.)
A receptacle, as in a dining room, for a few bottles of wine orliquor, made in the form of a chest or coffer, or a deep drawer in asideboard, and usually lined with metal.
Having the faculty of speech but imperfectly developed orpartially lost.
In a contingent manner; without design or foresight;accidentally.
The inflicting of retributive punishment; satisfaction taken.[R.] Milton.
A small lobe in the under surface of the cerebellum, near themiddle peduncle; the subpeduncular lobe.
The space between the strands on the outside of a rope. Knight.
Having part, or all, of the feathers imperfectly developed.
The citadel of a town or city; especially, the citadel ofMoscow, a large inclosure which contains imperial palaces,cathedrals, churches, an arsenal, etc. [Russia]
Pertaining to the measurement of the intensity of the solarrays, either (a) heating, or (b) actinic.
Waved obtusely up and down, near the margin, as a leaf orcorolla; wavy.
A bench or board on which work is performed; a workbench.South.

An order of Entomostraca including a large number of species,most of which live in fresh water. They have flattened or leaflikelegs, often very numerous, which they use in swimming. Called alsoBranchiopoda.
A pleasing or sweet sound; an easy, smooth enunciation ofsounds; a pronunciation of letters and syllables which is pleasing tothe ear.
A system of working in ore, etc., when it lies not in strata orveins, but in solid masses, so as to be worked in chambers orstories.
An instrument for measuring the declination of the magneticneedle.
An instrument measuring the dimensions of the head of a fetusduring delivery.
The cavity from which the earth for parapets, etc. (remblai),is taken.

A low four-wheeled carriage used in Russia. The carriage boxrests on two long, springy poles which run from the fore to the hindaxletree. When snow falls, the wheels are taken off, and the body ismounted on a sledge.
A glimpse or flash of the sun. [Scot.] Sir W. Scott.
A gallery or circle in a theater, generally the first above thefloor, in which originally dress clothes were customarily worn.
An obligation by which property of a debtor was made over tohis creditor in security of his debt.
The quality of being immoderate; excess; extravagance. Puller.
A group of rocks having a common age or origin; -- nearlyequivalent to formation, but used somewhat less comprehensively.
Forming a judgment without due examination; prejudging. Dr. H.More.
Pertaining to that part of the columella of the ear which, insome animals, connects the stapes with the other parts of thecolumella.-- n.
A writ brought before a proper tribunal, to inquire by whatwarrant a person or a corporation acts, or exercises certain powers.Blackstone.
In an apish manner; with servile imitation; foppishly.
To reduce to a unit, or one whole; to form into a unit; tounify.
Capable of being succored or assisted; admitting of relief.
A European owl (Syrnium aluco) of a tawny color; -- called alsouluia.
To release, as one thing stuck to another. Richardson.
The adjustable socket, or step, of a millstone spindle. Knight.
A bare axis or cylinder with staves or levers in it to turn itround, but without any drum.

Of camel's hair. Camel's-hair pencil, a small brush used bypainters in water colors, made of camel's hair or similar materials.-- Camel's-hair shawl. A name often given to a cashmere shawl. SeeCashmere shawl under Cashmere.
Relating to principles or beginnings. [R.] Jer. Taylor.
The act or process of discharging anything from the body,particularly the excretions.
One of the rowers on the topmost of the three benches in atrireme.
A sacred or holy work or worship. [Obs.] Waterland.
A soft black, iron ore, nearly earthy, a hydrous silicate ofiron.
To grow to an inferior, or less than the usual, size or height.Wyclif.
One who enters a religious house, whether of monks or nuns, asa probationist. Shipley.No poore cloisterer, nor no novys. Chaucer.
The second month of the calendar adopted by the first Frenchrepublic. It began thirty days after the autumnal equinox. SeeVendemiaire.
In the manner or form of an ecclesiastical chapter. Sterne.
Inclined or able to range, or rove about, for considerabledistances; apt or suited for much roving, --chiefly used of cattle.
Diligence; care; persevering endeavor. [Obs.] Milton.
A colorless liquid hydrocarbon of the octylene series,occurring in Caucasian petroleum.
A tribe of North American Indians formerly inhabiting thecountry from the upper Missouri River to the Saskatchewan, but nowmuch reduced in numbers.
The impression of a vivid sensation retained by the retina ofthe eye after the cause has been removed; also extended toimpressions left of tones, smells, etc.
One of the peculiar minute chitinous hooks found in largenumbers in the tori of tubicolous annelids belonging to the Uncinata.
Any of two or more narrow paths, of steel, smooth stone, or thelike, laid in a public roadway otherwise formed of an inferiorpavement, as cobblestones, to provide an easy way for wheels.
The art of healing; skill of a physician. [Archaic] Chaucer.

A love-singer; specifically, one of a class of German poets andmusicians who flourished from about the middle of the twelfth to themiddle of the fourteenth century. They were chiefly of noble birth,and made love and beauty the subjects of their verses.
A luminous image or appearance of a hallucinatory character.
Having four branches diverging at right angles; -- said ofcertain spicules of sponges.
So as to secure approbation; in an approved manner.
A chime of bells diatonically tuned, played by clockwork or byfinger keys.
A poisonous amido acid, C6H13NO2, separated by Brieger fromdecaying horseflesh. In physiological action, it is similar tocurare.
One of a genus (Calochortus) of tuliplike bulbous herbs withlarge, and often gaycolored, blossoms. Called also butterfly lily.Most of them are natives of California.
Capable of resisting bombs or other shells; bombproof.

Any of several flags adopted by South California after itssecession. That adopted in November, 1860, had a green cabbagepalmetto in the center of a white field; the final one, January,1861, had a white palmetto in the center of a blue field and a whitecrescent in the upper left-hand corner.
The plural of himself, herself, and itself. See Himself,Herself, Itself.

The process of estimating the caliber a tube, as of athermometer tube, in order to graduate it to a scale of degrees;also, more generally, the determination of the true value of thespaces in any graduated instrument.
Of or pertaining to the vagus, or pneumogastric nerves;pneumogastric.
The young of the great black-backed gull (Larus marinus),formerly considered a distinct species. [Prov. Eng.]
Pertaining to, or according to the rules of, counterpoint.

A form of blood poisoning produced by the absorption into theblood of morbid matters usually originating in a wound or localinflammation. It is characterized by the development of multipleabscesses throughout the body, and is attended with irregularlyrecurring chills, fever, profuse sweating, and exhaustion.
Tending or relating to a purpose or an end. [R.] Cudworth.
The quality of being dissoluble; dissolubility. Boyle.
The taking of the position of a candidate; specifically, thepreaching of a clergyman with a view to settlement. [Cant, U. S.]
The act of selecting, or the state of being selected; choice,by preference.
A genus of Foraminifera, having a porcelanous shell withseveral longitudinal chambers.
Containing heresy; of the nature of, or characterized by,heresy.

The returning of an esttate to the grantor or his heirs, byoperation of law, after the grant has terminated; hence, the residueof an estate left in the proprietor or owner thereof, to take effectin possession, by operation of law, after the termination of alimited or less estate carved out of it and conveyed by him. Kent.
A preliminary remark or observation; an introductory discourseprefixed to a book or treatise. D. Stokes (1659). Sir W. Scott.
The operation of expelling one substance from another by heat,as sulphur or arsenic from ores, in a muffle.
Act of disappearing; disappearance. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
A species of violet (Viola tricolor); -- called also pansy.
A comprehensive division of animals including all Vertebratatogether with the Tunicata, or all those having a dorsal nervouscord.
A degeneration of animal tissue into a cheesy or curdy mass.
Any plant of the genus Arum, especially, in England, thecuckoopint (Arum maculatum).
The state or quality of being fishy or fishlike. Pennant.
The second lateral plate in the plastron of turtles; -- calledalso hyosternum.
The act of reclining at table according to the manner of theancients at their meals. Sir T. Browne.
The outer, hardened integument which covers most hydroids.
Pertaining to sexual desire; sensual. Sir T. Browne.
An oyster which has the gills tinged with a green pigment, saidto be due to an abnormal condition of the blood.
A species of poem of a mournful character, in which a singlemourner expresses lamentation; a song for one voice.

To move forward and backward alternately; to recur invicissitude; to act interchangeably; to alternate.One brawny smith the puffing bellows plies, And draws and blowsreciprocating air. Dryden.Reciprocating engine, a steam, air, or gas engine, etc., in which thepiston moves back and forth; -- in distinction from a rotary engine,in which the piston travels continuously in one direction in acircular path.-- Reciprocating motion (Mech.), motion alternately backward andforward, or up and down, as of a piston rod.
To hold or value too highly; to estimate at too dear a rate.[Obs.] Shak.

A plant of the genus Aralia, the root of which is highly valuedas a medicine among the Chinese. The Chinese plant (Aralia Schinseng)has become so rare that the American (A. quinquefolia) has largelytaken its place, and its root is now an article of export fromAmerica to China. The root, when dry, is of a yellowish white color,with a sweetness in the taste somewhat resembling that of licorice,combined with a slight aromatic bitterness.
A firearm which receives its charge through the muzzle, asdistinguished from one which is loaded at the breech.
A heron. [Written variously hernshaw, harnsey, etc.]
The perceptive faculty concerned with the ability to rememberthe relative positions of places.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, any one of a series ofdouble acids of silicon and tungsten, known in the free state, andalso in their salts (called silicotungstates).
A (patented) alloy of aluminium and silver, with a density ofabout 2.9.
A substance analogous to chloranil but containing bromine inplace of chlorine.
The tissue which fills the cavities of most bones; the medulla.In the larger cavities it is commonly very fatty, but in the smallercavities it is much less fatty, and red or reddish in color.
Of or pertaining to Myrmica, a genus of ants including thesmall house ant (M. molesta), and many others.
An alkaloid extracted from fumitory, as a white crystallinesubstance.
In a puffing manner; with vehement breathing or shortness ofbreath; with exaggerated praise.
A small village containing a church. [Scot.] Sir W. ScottSitting at the clachon alehouse. R. L. Stevenson.
An aromatic composite herb, the costmary; also, the SouthEuropean Achillea Ageratum, a kind of yarrow.
The descent of the moon below the horizon; also, the time whenthe moon sets.
That department of medicine which relates to the preservationof health; prophylaxis. [Obs.]
Attachment to the doctrines of Epicurus; the principles orbelief of Epicurus.
Lack of sanitation; careless or dangerous hygienic conditions.
The introduction of a tube into an organ to keep it open, asinto the larynx in croup.
, adv. In a fell or cruel manner; fiercely; barbarously;savagely. Spenser.
A substance (C6H5.N2.C6H5) derived from nitrobenzene, formingorange red crystals which are easily fusible.
A North American plant (Collinsonia Canadensis) having a veryhard root; horse balm. See Horse balm, under Horse.
To act the part of a patron towards; to patronize. [Obs.] Shak.
Of or pertaining to the thermostat; made or effected by meansof the thermostat.
A bamboo frame or trellis hung at a door or window of a house,over which water is suffered to trickle, in order to moisten and coolthe air as it enters. [India]
An aggregate or collection of rays of light, especially whendiverging from, or converging to, a point.
A polymeric modification of acrolein obtained by heating itwith caustic potash. It is a crystalline substance having an aromaticodor.
In the manner of a duke, or in a manner becoming the rank of aduke.

A thousand years; especially, thousand years mentioned in thetwentieth chapter in the twentieth chapter of Revelation, duringwhich holiness is to be triumphant throughout the world. Some believethat, during this period, Christ will reign on earth in person withhis saints.
An East Indian plant of the genus Curcuma, of the Gingerfamily.
Any one of numerous species of small aquatic Entomostracabelonging to the genera Cyclops, Daphnia, etc; -- so called becausethey swim with sudden leaps, or starts.
To tend or point toward the north; to north. Sir T. Browne.
To reason falsely; to draw conclusions not warranted by thepremises. [R.]
A perennial rosaceous herb (Potentilla Anserina) having theleaves silvery white beneath.
One of the ten laws or precepts given by God to the Israelitesat Mount Sinai.

A linguistic family or stock of North American Indians,comprising many tribes, which extends from Montana and Idaho intoMexico. In a restricted sense the name is applied especially to theSnakes, the most northern of the tribes.
A specied of wild sheep (Ovis Hodgsonii), native of Nepaul andThibet. It has a dorsal mane and a white ruff beneath the neck.
America; the United States; -- a poetical appellation given inhonor of Columbus, the discoverer. Dr. T. Dwight.
The place where an almoner resides, or where alms aredistributed.

Rays of relatively low penetrating power emitted by radium andother radioactive substances, and shown to consist of positivelycharged particles (perhaps particles of helium) having enormousvelocities but small masses. They are slightly deflected by a strongmagnetic or electric field.
One employed on work on the track; specif., a trackwalker.
The quality or state of being like a vulture; rapaciousness.
To expose too long to the influence of the weather. [Obs.]Shak.
A group of pterodactyls destitute of teeth, as in the genusPteranodon.
A lustration or purification, especially the purification ofthe whole Roman people, which was made by the censors once in fiveyears. Hence: A period of five years.
Of or pertaining to the art or process of electrotyping;employing, or produced by, the process of electolytic deposition; as,a galvano-plastic copy of a medal or the like.
Having light and active wings; volatile; fleeting. Shak.
Capable of being employed; capable of being used; fit or properfor use. Boyle.
An underground drain or trench with openings through which thewater may percolate from the soil or ground above.
A defensive covering for the head. See Casque, Headpiece,Morion, Sallet, and Illust. of Beaver.
The quality or state of being grisly; horrid. Sir P. Sidney.
A white, amorphous, deliquescent powder, (CO.H)2, obtained bythe partial oxidation of glycol. It is a double aldehyde, betweenglycol and oxalic acid.
A thick gruel of oatmeal and milk or water; food of theporridge kind. [Scot.]
The act, art, or practice of a pedestrian; walking or running;traveling or racing on foot.
To take effect or vest again, as a title; to revert to formerowner; as, the title or right revels in A after alienation.
One who founds, establishes, and erects; one who lays afoundation; an author; one from whom anything originates; one whoendows.
Any one of numerous species of Bryozoa belonging to Tubuliporaand allied genera, having tubular calcareous calicles.
A species of mica, of a lilac or rose-violet color, containinglithia. It usually occurs in masses consisting of small scales. SeeMica.
The left-hand side of a ship to one on board facing toward thebow; port; -- opposed to Ant: starboard.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex organic acid, obtainedas a yellowish white gum by the oxidation of croconic acid.
A flat or somewhat hollowed stone upon which grain or otherfood is ground, by means of a smaller stone or pestle. [SouthwesternU. S. & Sp. Amer.]
A chloride having three atoms of chlorine in the molecule.
One of a peculiar kind of zooids situated on the polyp-stem ofcertain Siphonophora. They somewhat resemble the feeding zooids, butare destitute of mouths. See Siphonophora.
An extinct South American quaternary mammal, allied to thearmadillos. It was as large as an ox, was covered with tessellatedscales, and had fluted teeth. Owen.
A Mohammedan professor or teacher of language. [India]
The quality or state of being sweet (in any sense of theadjective); gratefulness to the taste or to the smell; agreeableness.

Sustained; -- applied to a movement or passage the sounds ofwhich are to sustained to the utmost of the nominal value of thetime; also, to a passage the tones of which are to be somewhatprolonged or protacted.
The quality or state of being punctual; especially, adherenceto the exact time of an engagement; exactness.
Each particular taken singly; distinction. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
A morbidly increased discharge of sebaceous matter upon theskin; stearrhea.
A buck in his second year. See Note under 3d Buck. Shak.
To subject to the operation of integration; to find theintegral of.
Strontium carbonate, a mineral of a white, greenish, oryellowish color, usually occurring in fibrous massive forms, butsometimes in prismatic crystals.
The punctuation mark [;] indicating a separation between partsor members of a sentence more distinct than that marked by a comma.
One who seeks or asks; a seeker; an applicant. [R.] Fuller.
The use of a picture symbol of an object to representphonetically the initial sound of the name of the object.
A form of apparatus (somewhat different from the hemadrometer)for measuring the velocity of the blood.
A condition in which the prepuce, after being retracted behindthe glans penis, is constricted there, and can not be brought forwardinto place again.
That part of military force which serves on horseback.
Of or pertaining to Geneva, in Switzerland; Genevese.
Convex on one side, and concave on the other. The curves of theconvex and concave sides may be alike or may be different. SeeMeniscus.
The theory or practice of living upon vegetables and fruits.
The quality of being unalterable or unchangeable; permanence.
A kind of graduated breech sight for a small arm, or a cannon.
A key adapted to open only one of a set of locks; --distinguished from a master key.
One who discourses on the skin and its diseases; one versed indermatology.
A plant growing on another, as the mistletoe; an epiphyte.[Obs.] Bacon.
To chirp or to make a mournful cry, as a bird. [Obs.] Huloet.
A chief treasurer. Specifically, the great treasurer of theGerman empire.
Half of a diameter; a right line, or the length of a rightline, drawn from the center of a circle, a sphere, or other curvedfigure, to its circumference or periphery; a radius.
The sun shining at midnight in the arctic or antarctic summer.
A court consisting of military or naval officers, for the trialof one belonging to the army or navy, or of offenses against militaryor naval law.
Producing or bringing forth all things; all-producing. [R.]
A glucoside found in ripe and unripe fruit (as the orange), andextracted as a white crystalline substance.
Pertaining to an autocrator; absolute. [Obs.] Bp. Pearson.
Pertaining to the monks of St. Benedict, or St. Benet.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid now called maleic acid.
The art of dramatic composition and representation.
An order of Schizophyta, including the so-called fission fungi,or bacteria. See Schizophyta, in the Supplement.
A cross having the three upper ends crossed, so as to fromthree small crosses.
One of a group of crystalline bodies produced by the action ofammonia on certain aldehydes.
An instrument for recording both pressure and temperature, asof the atmosphere.
The act or process of gilding or covering with gold.
The viscid, tenacious substance which gives adhesiveness todough.
A sum of money, payable yearly, to continue for a given numberof years, for life, or forever; an annual allowance.

A certain tenure in tail special; an estate of inheritancegiven to a man his wife (the wife being of the blood of the donor),and descendible to the heirs of their two bodies begotten. [Obs.]Blackstone.
Fascinated by the stage; seized by a passionate desire tobecome an actor.
One who mangles or tears in cutting; one who mutilates any workin doing it.
Having to stomach, or distinct digestive canal, as thetapeworm.
One of the nobility; a noble; a peer; one who enjoys rank abovea commoner, either by virtue of birth, by office, or by patent.
Theatrical representation; acting; affectation. Sir T. Browne.
The act of one who stutters; -- restricted by somephysiologists to defective speech due to inability to form the propersounds, the breathing being normal, as distinguished from stammering.
The complement of the latitude, or the difference between anylatitude and ninety degrees.
A plastic, unctuous clay of a grayish white color, -- used inmaking tobacco pipes and various kinds of earthenware, in scouringcloth, and in cleansing soldiers' equipments.
A genus of leguminous plants containing but a single species,the H. Campechianum or logwood tree, native in Yucatan.
Drops of some drug put in one's drink to stupefy him forpurpose of robbery, etc. [Slang, U. S.]
Having, in some respects, the nature of light; resemblinglight. Berkeley.
An oversight in pleading, or the acknowledgment of a mistake oroversight. Blackstone.
Tending to distribute or be distributed; that distributes;distributive.
A particular rural district; a country neighborhood. [Eng.] W.Black. Blackmore.
A woman who administers; esp., one who administers the estateof an intestate, or to whom letters of administration have beengranted; a female administrator.
A portion of the Old Testament prepared by Origen in the 3dcentury, containing the Hebrew text and seven Greek versions of it,arranged in eight parallel columns.
Attack at once; -- a direction at the end of a movement to showthat the next is to follow immediately, without any pause.
A sudden awkening associated with a sensation of terror,occurring in children, esp. those of unstable nervous constitution.
One who takes pains; one careful and faithful in all work. Gay.
A shop or barroom where gin is sold as a beverage. [Colloq.]
Guaiacol benzoate, used as an intestinal antiseptic and as asubstitute for creosote in phthisis. It is a colorless crystallinepewder.
Suspended by one's self or by itself; balanced. Southey.
Not according to the forms of law; not judicial. [R.]
In an agreeing manner (to); correspondingly; agreeably. [Obs.]
To pass, or to draw off, (as steam) through narrow ports, orthe like, thus reducing its pressure or force by friction.
A daughter of one's stepfather or stepmother by a formermarriage.
The green mineral characteristic of the greensand of the chalkand other formations. It is a hydrous silicate of iron and potash.See Greensand.
A vessel with a perforated cover, for sprinkling with a liquid;a sprinkler.
The state or quality of being appropriate; peculiar fitness.Froude.
A disease in which the body is colored blue in its surface,arising usually from a malformation of the heart, which causes animperfect arterialization of the blood; blue jaundice.
An order of Bryozoa in which the anus lies outside the circleof tentacles.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by thereduction of sulphurous acid. See Hyposulphurous acid, underHyposulphurous.
An extinct Eocene bird having the jaws strongly serrated, ordentated, but destitute of true teeth. It was found near London.
A colorless, oily substance, C4H4O, obtained by distillingcertain organic substances, as pine wood, salts of pyromucic acid,etc.; -- called also tetraphenol.
The interweaving of branches of trees. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Want of opportunity; unseasonableness; inconvenience. [R.]
To unfold or undo, as a tuck; to release from a tuck or fold.

The principles of Dr. Pusey and others at Oxford, England, asexhibited in various publications, esp. in a series which appearedfrom 1833 to 1841, designated " Tracts for the Times;" tractarianism.See Tractarianism.
Of or pertaining both to the cricoid and the thyroidcartilages.
An Australian insessorial bird (Corcorax melanorhamphus) notedfor the curious actions of the male during the breeding season. It isblack with a white patch on each wing.
The quality or state of being tenable; tenableness.
On the day after the present day; on the next day; on themorrow.Summon him to-morrow to the Tower. Shak.
A small, strong-winged European falcon (Falco subbuteo),formerly trained for hawking.

One of a group of shooting stars which appear yearly about the10th of August, and cross the heavens in paths apparently radiatingfrom the constellation Perseus. They are beleived to be fragmentsonce connected with a comet visible in 1862.
Pertaining to, or resembling, a corolla; having the form ortexture of a corolla.
A scarecrow, generally made of feathers tied to a string, hungup to prevent deer from breaking into a place. Halliwell.
Athwart; adversely; unfortunately; peevishly; fretfully; withill humor.
A white crystalline substance, C6H5.C6H5, obtained by leadingbenzene through a heated iron tube. It consists of two benzene orphenyl radicals united.
Inverted; having a position or mode of attachment the reverseof that which is usual.
A kind of machine gun; -- named after its inventor, Hiram S.Maxim.
Relating to Hygeia, the goddess of health; of or pertaining tohealth, or its preservation.
Characterized by the presence of thin parallel strata, orlayers, as in an agate.
An indirect argument which proves a thing by showing theimpossibility or absurdity of the contrary.
The essential principle of cacao; -- now called theobromine.
Land adjoining a road or highway; the part of a road or highwaythat borders the traveled part. Also used ajectively.
An acquittal, or sentence of a judge declaring and accusedperson innocent. [Obs.]
A crested black monkey (Semnopithecus maurus) of Java.
That part of a prescription which contains the Latin wordrecipe (Take) or the sign
Like ashes; having the color of ashes, -- as the corticalsubstance of the brain.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid (called also lithicacid) found in certain red precipitates of urine. See Uric. [Obs.]
The double cyanide of ferrous and ferric iron, a dark blueamorphous substance having a coppery luster, used in dyeing, calicoprinting, etc. Cf. Prussian blue, under Prussian.
Pertaining to an advocate, or to the maintenance and defense ofsuits.
A room where news is collected and disseminated, or periodicalssold; a reading room supplied with newspapers, magazines, etc.

A French political group, also known as the ConstitutionalRight from its position in the Chambers, mainly monarchists whorallied to the support of the Republic in obedience to the encyclicalput forth by Pope Leo XIII. in Feb., 1892.

An unsymmetrical, divalent, hydrocarbon radical, C2H4 metamericwith ethylene but written thus, CH3.CH to distinguish it from thesymmetrical ethylene, CH2.CH2. Its compounds are derived fromaldehyde. Formerly called also ethidene.
A remedy which restores the natural order of the invertedirritative motions in the animal system. [Obs.] E. Darwin.
An order of fungi, in which the spores are borne inside a saccalled the peridium, as in the puffballs.
The number from which another number is to be subtracted.
A genus of parasitic Acarina, which includes various species ofticks. See Tick, the insect.
Pertaining to moss of the genus Sphagnum, or bog moss;abounding in peat or bog moss.
A Spanish gold coin, no longer issued, varying in value atdifferent times from over fifteen dollars to about five. See Doblonin Sup.
A kind of bellflower, Companula Trachelium, once called ViolaMariana; but it is not a violet.
A genus of beetles without wings, but having short oval elytra;the oil beetles. These beetles are sometimes used instead ofcantharides for raising blisters. See Oil beetle, under Oil.
An injury caused by violent strains or by overloading; -- saidof the backs of horses. Crabb.
A tribe of Pueblo Indians occupying a village in New Mexico, onthe Zuni River.
A person employed to do all kinds of work or business. B.Jonson.
A woman excelling both in beauty and goodness; a fair maid.[Obs.] Spenser.
Poison spittle; poison ejected from the mouth. [R.] Hooker.
The Chinese name for a highly prized variety of pale greenjade. See Jade.
Tending to add; making some addition. [R.] Arbuthnot.
An extensive division of Mammalia including those having clawsor nails, as distinguished from the hoofed animals (Ungulata).
The quality or state of being soggy; soddenness; wetness.
A platform; the bottom of a room; a floor; pavement. See Floor,n. Addison.
A division of gastropods in which the odontophore is withoutteeth.
A medicine that strengthens the stomach and excites its action.
To remove a prop or props from; to deprive of support.
A plant which has no cotyledons, as the dodder and allflowerless plants.
Of or pertaining to staphyloma; affected with staphyloma.
To free from the body; to disembody.Her soul unbodied of the burdenous corse. Spenser.
A stone, often of great size and weight, resting upon anotherstone, and so exactly poised that it can be rocked, or slightlymoved, with but little force.
The finishing course of a wall showing above a cornice.
A small line made of spun yarn, to bind or worm cables, seizetackles, etc.
A mean, worthless fellow; a rascal; a villain; a man withouthonor or virtue.Go, if your ancient, but ignoble bloodHas crept through soundrels ever since the flood. Pope.
Of or pertaining to a semivowel; half cocal; imperfectlysounding.
Of or pertaining to resin; derived from resin; specifically,designating an acid found in certain fossil resins and hydrocarbons.
The practice or arts of a pettifogger; disreputable tricks;quibbles.Quirks of law, and pettifoggeries. Barrow.
To lease again; to grant a new lease of; to let back.
Intense fear or dread of the pope, or of the Roman CatholicChurch. [R.]
A cloth for covering a coffin when on a bier; a pall. Bp.Sanderson.

Of, pertaining to, or derived from, mutton suet; -- applied byChevreul to an oily acid which was obtained from mutton suet, and towhich he attributed the peculiar taste and smell of that substance.The substance has also been called hircin. Watts.
The dignity, office, or government, of a prior. T. Warton.
A large, handsome, marine, univalve shell (Triton femorale).
To mark with points; to separate into sentences, clauses, etc.,by points or stops which mark the proper pauses in expressing themeaning.
The idolizing of one's self; immoderate self-conceit.
The setting of one above another; preference. [R.] Jer. Taylor.
A violent and widely extended change in the surface of theearth, as, an elevation or subsidence of some part of it, effected byinternal causes. Whewell.

A small North American dace (Minnilus cornutus, or Notropismegalops). The male, in the breeding season, has bright red fins.Called also red dace, and shiner. Applied also to Notropis ardens, ofthe Mississippi valley.
That part of natural history which treats of the ophidians, orserpents.
Vaulting formed by the intersection of two or more simplevaults.
The edible drupaceous fruit of an Australian tree (Fusanusacuminatus) of the Sandalwood family; -- called also quandang.
A climbing plant (Ullucus officinalis) of the Andes, havingtuberous roots which are used as a substitute for potatoes.
A licensed or official coal measurer in London. See Meter.Simmonds.
In a leaping position; springing forward; -- applied especiallyto the squirrel, weasel, and rat, also to the cat, greyhound, monkey,etc.
Not moral nor immoral; having no connection with morals; not inthe sphere of morals or ethics; not ethical.
Subdivided into many distinct subordinate parts, which,however, not being jointed to the petiole, are not true leaflets; --said of leaves. Henslow.
The larva of the spiny lobsters (Palinurus and allied genera).Its body is remarkably thin, flat, and transparent; the legs are verylong. Called also glass-crab, and glass-shrimp.
Capable of being appropriated, set apart, sequestered, orassigned exclusively to a particular use. Sir T. Browne.
To interweave or twist together.Raddling or working it up like basket work. De Foe.

A qualification involving the idea of variation or departurefrom some general rule or form, in the way of either restriction orenlargement, according to the circumstances of the case, as in thewill of a donor, an agreement between parties, and the like. Bracton.
Affected with ennui; weary in spirits; emotionally exhausted.
An officer in the Spartan army commanding fifty men. Mitford.
An alkaloid accompanying harmaline (in the Peganum harmala),and obtained from it by oxidation. It is a white crystallinesubstance.
A solid contained by six rhomboids; a parallelopiped.
The quality or condition of being two or twofold; dualcharacter or usage.
A piece of wood set between two studs, posts, etc., to stiffenand support them.
The act of mollifying, or the state of being mollified; asoftening. Chaucer.
A gallery, drift, or adit in a mine; also, the end of a driftor gallery; the vein above a drift.
(adv. In a contrary manner; in opposition; on the other side;in opposite ways.
Tasting beforehand; having a foretaste. [R.] Ed. Rev.
A colorless liquid of an agreeable odor, C6H10O, obtained bydistilling a mixture of sugar and lime; -- so called because formerlyregarded as a polymeric modification of acetone.
The quality or state of being a precisian; the practice of aprecisian. Milton.

The position of a man who is found at his standing in theforest, with a crossbow or a longbow bent, ready to shoot at a deer,or close by a tree with greyhounds in a leash ready to slip; -- oneof the four presumptions that a man intends stealing the king's deer.Wharton.
A medicinal tablet or lozenge; strictly, one of circular form.
Want of love to mankind; -- the opposite of philanthropy. Coxe.
One who exlpains geological phenomena by the action of streams.[R.]
A syllogism with three conditional propositions, the majorpremises of which are disjunctively affirmed in the minor. SeeDilemma.
A kind of inferior cigar of a long slender shape, tapered atone end. [Local, U. S.]
Formed by the joint action of a river and the sea, as depositsat the mouths of rivers.
A rebated cross, formerly used as a secret emblem, and a commonornament. It is also called gammadion, and swastika.
Work done at a desk, as by a clerk or writer. Tennyson.
A woman of doubtful reputation or suspected character; anadventuress. [Colloq.] De Quincey.
Of or pertaining to the lymphatics, or lymphoid tissue;lymphatic.

A gaseous compound of carbon and hydrogen, in the proportion oftwo atoms of the former to two of the latter. It is a colorless gas,with a peculiar, unpleasant odor, and is produced for use as anilluminating gas in a number of ways, but chiefly by the action ofwater on calcium carbide. Its light is very brilliant. Watts.
One who makes or favors a version; a translator. [R.]
Athletic or disciplinary exercises; the art of performinggymnastic exercises; also, disciplinary exercises for the intellector character.

A cement having the color of the Portland stone of England,made by calcining an artificial mixture of carbonate of lime andclay, or sometimes certain natural limestones or chalky clays. Itcontains a large proportion of clay, and hardens under water.
An organ stop of delicate stringlike quality, having for eachfinger key a pair of pipes, of which one is tuned slightly sharp togive a wavy effect to their joint tone.

A name given to any one of the four elements, carbon, hydrogen,oxygen, and nitrogen, which are especially characteristic ingredientsof organic compounds; also, by extension, to other elements sometimesfound in the same connection; as sulphur, phosphorus, etc.
One who devises, or gives real estate by will; a testator; --correlative to devisee.
The outer husk, pod, or shell, as of oats, pease, etc.; sheal;shell. [Obs. or Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
An editor who inspects, and culls from, periodicals, orexchanges, for his own publication.
The art of making measurements among the stars, or ofdetermining their relative magnitudes.
A chief or great heresy. [R.]The book itself [the Alcoran] consists of heresiarchies against ourblessed Savior. Sir T. Herbert.
Strictness, or the doctrine of strictness, in conforming tolaw.
Lucky, without judgment or contrivance. [Obs.] Spenser.
To empty or unload, as the vessels of human system, bybloodletting or by medicine. Copland.
Manufacture of glass; articles or ornamentation made of glass.
The momentary current between two alternating-currentgenerators when juxtaposed in parallel and not agreeing exactly inphase or period.
One of the bishops of the Episcopal Church of Scotland, whopresides at the meetings of the bishops, and has certain privilegesbut no metropolitan authority. Internat. Cyc.
A foot of three syllables, the first two long, and the lastshort.
Direction; command; authoritative admonition. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
Streaked or spotted on the back; -- said of cattle.
A palsy that affects one side only of the body.-- Hem`i"pleg"ic, a.

The C.G.S. unit of magnetic reluctance or resistance, equal tothe reluctance of a centimeter cube of air (or vacuum) betweenparallel faces. Also, a reluctance in which unit magnetomotive forcesets up unit flux.
The quality or state of being self-active; self-action.
The act of retracting what has been said; recantation.
A coat worn over the other clothing; a greatcoat; a topcoat.
A cotton fabric employed for hangings and furniture coverings,and formerly used for women's under-garments. It is of many patterns,both plain and twilled, and occasionally is printed in colors.
Diminution of swelling; subsidence of anything swollen. [R.]Cudworth.
Of or pertaining to Napoleon Bonaparte or his family.
Composed of peat; abounding in peat; resembling peat.
The quality or state of being adventurous; daring;venturesomeness.
The service formerly required of a tenant, to carry timber fromthe woods to the lord's house. Bailey. Mozley & W.
A transverse commissure in the anterior part of the thirdventricle of the brain; the anterior cerebral commissure.
One who raises sheep for the production of wool.-- Wool"grow`ing, n.
To ply to excess; to exert with too much vigor; to overwork.Milton.
A crystalline, nitrogenous base, C10H14N2, isomeric withnicotine.
In an elastic manner; by an elastic power; with a spring.
A binary compound of boron with a more positive or basicelement or radical; -- formerly called boruret.
The quality or state of being ponderous; ponderosity.
A concretion, or calculus, formed in the gall bladder orbiliary passages. See Calculus, n., 1.
The doctrine of certain extreme adherents or disciples ofDescartes and Johann Gottlieb Fichte, which finds all the elements ofknowledge in the ego and the relations which it implies or providesfor.

The inspissated juice of an umbelliferous plant (the OpoponaxChironum), brought from Turkey and the East Indies in loose granules,or sometimes in larger masses, of a reddish yellow color, with specksof white. It has a strong smell and acrid taste, and was formerlyused in medicine as an emmenagogue and antispasmodic. Dunglison.
A plane of fracture, or divisional plane, of a rock transverseto the stratification.
A figure in which the idea is expressed by two nouns connectedby and, instead of by a noun and limiting adjective; as, we drinkfrom cups and gold, for golden cups.
Not behooving or becoming; unseemly. [Obs. & R.] Gower.
A thin piece placed between two parts to hold or adjust them,fill a space, etc., ; a shim.
A dealer in cogware or coarse cloth. [Obs.] Wright.
A wheel, usually with radial handles projecting from the rim,for traversing the saddle of a machine tool, esp. an automaticmachine tool, by hand.
One who claims; one who asserts a right or title; a claimer.
That branch of pharmacology which treats of unpreparedmedicines or simples; -- called also pharmacography, andpharmacomathy.
The art or act of recognizing the presence of disease from itssigns or symptoms, and deciding as to its character; also, thedecision arrived at.
The saving of a son or a slave with the father's or master'sconsent; a little property or stock of one's own; any exclusivepersonal or separate property. Burrill.
A group of small wormlike animals, having cilia on the ventralside. The group is regarded as an ancestral or synthetic one, relatedto rotifers and annelids.
A niche near the altar in a church, containing a small basinfor rinsing altar vessels.
A play or part of play in which the harlequin is conspicuous;the part of a harlequin. Macaulay.
Without events; tame; monotomous; marked by nothing unusual;uneventful.
Any long, slender nematode worm, especially the pinworm andfilaria.
The preliminary learning connected with any art or science;preparatory instruction.

State of being adjusted to a certain wave length; agreement ortuning between the time period of an apparatus emitting electricoscillations and that of a receiving apparatus, esp. in wirelesstelegraphy.
One learned in science; a scientific investigator; one devotedto scientific study; a savant. [Recent]
Measurement of life; calculation of the probable duration ofhuman life.
Young cabbage, used as "greens"; esp. a kind cultivated forthat purpose; colewort. [Colloq. Souther U. S.]
To put money to usury; to lend on interest. [Obs.] Cockeram.
To think; to deliberate; to muse; -- usually followed by on orover. Longfellow.
Of or pertaining to a hermit; solitary; secluded from society.Pope.
To wind, or wrap; especially, to wind a rope round, as a mastor yard made of two or more pieces, at the place where it has beenfished or scarfed, in order to strengthen it.
A prostrate filiform stem or runner, as of the strawbwrry. SeeRunner.
A salt formed by the combination of azotous, or nitrous, acidwith a base; a nitrite. [R.]
A folded piece of cloth, pledget of lint, etc., used to coverthe dressing of wounds, and so placed as, by the aid of a bandage, tomake due pressure on any part.
The jurisdiction or office of an archbishop; the see orprovince over which archbishop exercises archiepiscopal authority.
Such as can be presented in opposition; that may be put forwardas an objection. [R.]
Hydrous sulphate of magnesia found at the salt mines ofStassfurt, Prussian Saxony.
Attached partly to an organ or limb and partly to some otherpartintrinsic.
The act or process of vaporizing, or the state of beingconverted into vapor; the artificial formation of vapor;specifically, the conversion of water into steam, as in a steamboiler.
A so-called immediate inference which consists in denying theoriginal subject of the contradictory predicate; e.g.: Every S is P;therefore, no Not-P is S.
To divide into plots or parts; to apportion. Milton.
That which is obvious, public, or common.Dealing out exoteries only to the vulgar. A. Tucker.
A group of fossil amphibians allied to the labyrinthodonts,having the head defended by bony, sculptured plates, as in someganoid fishes.
The Cornus, a genus of large shrubs or small trees, the wood ofwhich is exceedingly hard, and serviceable for many purposes.
Having the character of a whoremaster; lecherous; libidinous.

The hiding of a heavenly body from sight by the intervention ofsome other of the heavenly bodies; -- applied especially to eclipsesof stars and planets by the moon, and to the eclipses of satellitesof planets by their primaries.
A writing, as the means of giving formal expression to someact; a writing expressive of some act, contract, process, as a deed,contract, writ, etc. Burrill.
Varieties of kersey; also, trousers made of kersey.
Serving to translate; transferring. [R.] Arbuthnot.
A patrolman; also, a policeman who acts as an inspector overthe rounds of the patrolmen.
A large blackfish seaweed (Agarum Turneri), the frond of whichis punctured with many little holes.

To hew less than is usual or proper; specifically, to hew, as apiece of timber which should be square, in such a manner that itappears to contain a greater number of cubic feet than it really doescontain. Haldeman.
Half or imperfectly transparent; translucent. Woodward.
A universal proposition. See Subaltern, 2. Whately.
The process or operation of obtaining the mercury, in its fluidform, from mercuric minerals.
The act of producing pustules; the state of being pustulated.
To reclaim; to demand the restoration of. [R.] Vattel (Trans.).
An evergreen Chinese shrub of the Magnolia family (Illiciumanisatum), and its aromatic seeds; Chinese anise; star anise.
A zeolite occuring in groups of glassy acicular crystals, andin masses which often have a radiated structure. It is a hydroussilicate of alumina and soda.
An instrument for measuring the intensity of light, or, moreespecially, for comparing the relative intensities of differentlights, or their relative illuminating power.
Having the property of applying; applicative; practical.-- n.
A nearly pellucid variety of feldspar, showing pearly oropaline reflections from within. It is used as a gem. The bestspecimens come from Ceylon.
Maryland; a nickname, alluding to the fact that its northernboundary in Mason and Dixon's line.
Belief in, or the practice of, the obi superstitions and rites.
Of or pertaining to a climate; depending on, or limited by, aclimate.
An upright or curved piece of timber connecting the plank sheerwith the gunwale; also, a scroll terminating a rail.
An oily substance, C8H14, obtained from several derivatives ofconine.
to assert or confirm, as a judgment, decree, or order, broughtbefore an appelate court for review.
A genus of nemertean worms, parasitic in the gill cavity ofclams and other bivalves. They have a large posterior sucker, likethat of a leech. See Illust. of Bdellomorpha.
An amorphous huminlike substance resembling sacchulmic acid,and produced together with it.
A disease of the skin, in which a diffused inflammation formsrose-colored patches of variable size.
A circle, or disk, or any indication of radiant light aroundthe heads of divinities, saints, and sovereigns, upon medals,pictures, etc.; a halo. See Aureola, and Glory, n., 5.
Converting forest land into cleared or arable land; removal ofa forest. Sir W. Scott.
To wander without a settled habitation; to travel from place oron a circuit, particularly for the purpose of preaching, lecturing,etc.
The title of a heathen deity to whom the Jews ascribed thesovereignty of the evil spirits; hence, the Devil or a devil. SeeBaal.
To cause to fail in spirit or power; to quell; to crush; tosubdue. [Obs.] Spenser.
A genus of beautiful trees, natives of the East Indies. Thetree imperfectly di
One that sterilizes anything; specif., an apparatus forsterilizing an organic fluid or mixture.
One who dribs; one who shoots weakly or badly. [Obs.] Ascham.
Any alloy of copper, zinc, tin, and iron, of which cannon aresometimes made.
The property of crystallizing under two or more distinctfundamental forms, including dimorphism and trimorphism.
To gain anew; to get again; to recover, as what has escaped orbeen lost; to reach again.
A commercial traveler; one employed to solicit orders formanufacturers and tradesmen. Thackeray.
A kind of fine, hard, white or mottled soap, made with oliveand soda; also, a soap made in imitation of the above-described soap.
A frame or barrow, without a wheel, carried by hand.
Snowy; resembling snow; partaking of the qualities of snow. SirT. Browne.
A wood cell with spiral or other markings and closedthroughout, as in pine wood.
To separate, as sisters; to disjoin. [Poetic & R.] Tennyson.
The act or process of sterilizing an animal or human being, asby vasectomy.
The business of felling trees, cutting them into logs, andtransporting the logs to sawmills or to market.
A compound formerly supposed to be modification of oxygen, butnow known to be hydrogen dioxide; -- so called because apparentlyantagonistic to ozone, converting it into ordinary oxygen.
One who writes an account or history of the life of aparticular person; a writer of lives, as Plutarch.

The process of giving an orange color to goods formed of animaltissue, as silk or wool, not by coloring matter, but by producing acertain change in the fiber by the action of dilute nitric acid.Tomlinson.
A mineral of a gray, red, brown, or green color, and glisteningluster. It is a silicate of iron and manganese.
A water course, esp. a dry one; a gully; a gorge; -- orig. anEast Indian term.  E. Arnold.
The act of depositing a sediment; specifically (Geol.), thedeposition of the material of which sedimentary rocks are formed.
Before death; -- generally used adjectivelly; as, an ante-mortem statement; ante-mortem examination.
A contrivance for exhibiting and measuring the refraction oflight.
One who is acquainted with, or skilled in, anything bypractice; a practitioner.
A crisp, hard, thin paper, sometimes used for postage stamps.
A small European rodent of the genus Myoxus, of severalspecies. They live in trees and feed on nuts, acorns, etc.; -- socalled because they are usually torpid in winter.
An apparatus for taking the conformation of anything, as of thehead for fitting a hat, or, in craniometry, finding the largesthorizontal area of the head.
A salt of chromic acid containing two equivalents of the acidradical to one of the base; -- called also bichromate.
An instrument for measuring the specific gravity of fluids; aform hydrometer.
Pertaining to the genital organs and the thigh; -- appliedespecially to one of the lumbar nerves.
A celebrated cinerary urn or vase found in the tomb of theEmperor Alexander Severus. It is owned by the Duke of Portland, andkept in the British Museum.
Materia Medica; that branch of therapeutics which treats ofremedies.
The act of remodifying; the state of being remodified.
A large European bat (Vespertilio, or Noctulina, altivolans).
The dark space within the negative-pole glow at the cathode ofa vacuum tube, observed only when the pressure is low enough to givea striated discharge; -- called also Crookes layer.
The fitful naps taken when all hands are kept up by stress.
Of half the whole or ordinary length, as a picture.
Cast steel made by fusing in crucibles crude or scrap steel,wrought iron, and other ingredients and fluxes.
The manner of holding lands and tenements of a superior.
A condition of the system produced by long use of belladonna.
A saw for dividing timber lengthwise, usually set in a frame,and worked by two persons; also, a fret saw.
Any large ape; especially, the chimpanzee and the orang-outang.
The act of regaling; anything which regales; refreshment;entertainment.
The gate of a mold, through which the melted metal is poured;runner, geat.
A small nematoid worm (Oxyurus vermicularis), which isparasitic chiefly in the rectum of man. It is most common in childrenand aged persons.
Thrice pinnately cleft; -- said of a pinnatifid leaf when itssegments are pinnatifid, and the subdivisions of these also arepinnatifid.
Cited before; quoted in a foregoing part of the treatise oressay.

A divice of gauze or wire, covering the mouth or nose, toprevent the inhalation of noxious substances, as dust or smoke. Beingwarmed by the breath, it tempers cold air passing through it, and mayalso be used for the inhalation of medicated vapors.
In the following part of this (writing, document, speech, andthe like).
The record of a single event or item. "In deathless annal."Young.
Of or pertaining to the region of lower Babylonia, which wasanciently called Sumer, or its inhabitants or their language.
The quality or characteristics of a flunky; readiness to cringeto those who are superior in wealth or position; toadyism. Thackeray.
A sharpening; termination in a sharp point; a tapering point.Bp. Pearson.
Including, or relating to, an interval of three hundred years.-- n.
The fragrant wood of several shrubs and trees, especially ofspecies of Rhodorhiza from the Canary Islands, and of the West IndianAmyris balsamifera.
A superior kind of earthenware into whose composition flintenters largely. Knight.
A hood-shaped organ, resembling a cowl or monk's hood, ascertain concave and arched sepals or petals.
A Flemish sloop with a castle at each end. Sir W. Raleigh.
Glazed earthenware; esp., that which is decorated in color.

An unorganized proteolytic ferment or enzyme contained in thesecretory glands of the stomach. In the gastric juice it is unitedwith dilute hydrochloric acid (0.2 per cent, approximately) and thetwo together constitute the active portion of the digestive fluid. Itis the active agent in the gastric juice of all animals.
A collection of tents; an encampment. [Obs.] Drayton.
Supported by a stipe; elevated on a stipe, as the fronds ofmost ferns, or the pod of certain cruciferous plants.
A genus of South American monkeys, including the howlers. SeeHowler, 2, and Illust.
The character of a doughface; truckling pliability.
Capable of being affiliated to or on, or connected with inorigin.
Capable of being eaten; fit to be eaten; proper for food;esculent; edible.-- n.

A glucoside found in the leaves of several species of willow(Salix) and poplar, and extracted as a bitter white crystallinesubstance.salicyl alcohol glucoside, salicyl alcohol b-D-glucopyranoside, saligenin b-D-glucopyranoside, C13H18O7. It is usedin biochemistry as a standard substrate for evaluating the potency ofb-glucosidase in enzymatic preparations. It is also an analgesic.
A kind of ingrain carpeting, named from the English town whereformerly most of it was manufactured.
A projecting face like the triglyph, but having only twochannels or grooves sunk in it.

A printing process depending on the effect of light onbichromatized gelatin. Paper coated with a mixture of the gelatin anda pigment is called carbon paper or carbon tissue. This is exposedunder a negative and the film is transferred from the paper to someother support and developed by washing (the unexposed portions beingdissolved away). If the process stops here it is called singletransfer; if the image is afterward transferred in order to give anunreversed print, the method is called double transfer.
An extract or preparation of opium, used in China and India forsmoking. Balfour.
A flowerless plant which forms a true fruit as the result offertilization, as the red seaweeds, the Ascomycetes, etc.
The act of reinstating; the state of being reinstated; re
A genus of limicoline birds including many species ofsandpipers. See Dunlin, Knot, and Sandpiper.
To combine with oxygen so as to form a suroxide or peroxide.[Obs.]
A European leguminous plant (Ononis arvensis) with long, toughroots.
A marine bivalve shell belonging to the genus Arca and itsallies.
Of or pertaining to animals of the tortoise kind.-- n.
The inferior and posterior of the three elements forming theperiotic bone.

The retention by the President of the United States of a billunsigned so that it does not become a law, in virtue of the followingconstitutional provision (Const. Art. I., sec. 7, cl. 2): "If anybill shall not be returned by the President within ten days (Sundaysexcepted) after it shall have been presented to him, the same shallbe a law, in like manner as if he had signed it, unless the Congressby their adjournment prevent its return, in which case it shall notbe a law." Also, an analogous retention of a bill by a Stategovernor.
A gripping device, as for stretching wire, etc., consisting oftwo jaws so attached to a ring that they are closed by pulling on thering.
Having the leaves so placed that the upper part of each one iscovered by the base of the next higher leaf, as in hepatic mosses ofthe genus Plagiochila.
In France, an official government publication bound in yellowcovers.
The dissection of an animal while alive, for the purpose ofmaking physiological investigations.
The interval of three tones and a semitone, embracing fivediatonic degrees of the scale; the dominant of any key.
The practice or habit of drinking too much; tippling. Blount.
An evergreen tree of the cypress tribe, genus Thuja. TheAmerican species is the T. occidentalis.

That which gives a safe, passage; either(a) a convoy or guard to protect a person in an enemy's country or aforeign country, or(b) a writing, pass, or warrant of security, given to a person toenable him to travel with safety. Shak.
A fermented liquor made from pears; pear cider. Mortimer.
Of or pertaining to the pontiff or pope. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
One who, or that which, dilates, expands, o r enlarges.
One of a religious congregation of the Roman Catholic Churchdevoted to the improvement of Armenians.
A kind of drawing knife or planing tool for dressing the spokesof wheels, the shells of blocks, and other curved work.
A state of separation or disunion; want of unity. Dr. H. More.
To a vast extent or degree; very greatly; immensely. Jer.Taylor.
Purification by washing the hands before prayer; -- aMohammedan rite. Heyse.

A game played with five dice in which the count is usuallymade, in order, by pairs, two pairs, three of a kind, full houses,four of a kind, and five of a kind (the highest throw), similar topoker; also, the dice used in this game, esp. when marked with theace, king, queen, jack, ten, and nine instead of the usual digits.
The quality of being biblical; a biblical subject. [R.]

A disease of the liver in which it usually becomes smaller insize and more dense and fibrous in consistence; hence sometimesapplied to similar changes in other organs, caused by increase in thefibrous framework and decrease in the proper substance of the organ.
Small pinchers used to pluck out hairs, and for other purposes.
A fabric resembling velvet, but having the nap flat and lessclose.
Having a sharp point; armed with prickles; prickly; aculeate.
A plant whose seeds divide into two seed lobes, or cotyledons,in germinating.
Creeping; -- said of lesions which heal over one portion whilecontinuing to advance at another.
One who indulges in persiflage; a banterer; a quiz. Carlyle.
The state of being sightly; comeliness; conspicuousness.
Native iron protosulphide, FeS. It is known only in meteoricirons, and is usually in imbedded nodular masses of a bronze color.
Act of rejecting; matter rejected, or thrown away. Eaton.

The process by which miners seek to discover metallic lodes. Itconsist in sinking small pits through the superficial deposits to thesolid rock, and then driving from one pit to another across thedirection of the vein, in such manner as to cross all the veinsbetween the two pits.
One skilled in some trade or manual occupation; an artificer; amechanic.
A small stuffed puppet to be pelted in Lent; hence, a simplefellow.
A pastoral poem, in which shepherds are introduced conversingwith each other; a bucolic; an idyl; as, the Ecloques of Virgil, fromwhich the modern usage of the word has been established.
To free from deafness; to cause to hear. [Obs.] Shak.
Having a lap joint, or lap joints, as many kinds of woodworkand metal work.
Tending to mitigate; mitigating; lentitive. Johnson.
The condition of sleeping or becoming dormant by day, as is thecase of the bats.

A process, invented by P. Ostberg, for producing malleable ironcastings by melting wrought iron, to which from 0.05 to 0.1 per centof aluminium is added to lower the melting point, usually in apetroleum furnace, keeping the molten metal at the bubbling pointuntil it becomes quiet, and then pouring the molten metal into a moldlined with a special mixture consisting essentially of molasses andground burnt fire clay; also, a casting made by this process; --called also wrought-iron casting.
One who justifies or vindicates; a justifier. Johnson.
A local name in parts of the Mississippi Valley for theAmerican lotus (Nelumbo lutea).
The state of bachelorhood; the whole body of bachelors.
The act of pointing out as with the finger; indication. [Obs.]Dr. H. More.
One who dedicates; more especially, one who inscribes a book tothe favor of a patron, or to one whom he desires to compliment.
The art or process of reproducing sounds at a distance, as withthe telephone.
Of or pertaining to Asia or to its inhabitants.-- n.
Of or pertaining to Caledonia or Scotland; Scottish; Scotch.-- n.
Participation of the same nature; natural union. I. Walton.
Having the maxilla, or lower jaw, longer than the upper, as inthe skimmer.
A genus of birds including the common European partridge.Formerly the word was used in a much wider sense to include manyallied genera.
A popular name, esp. in the United States, for variouscutaneous eruptions, particularly for those of eczema. See Eczema.
Resembling aphanite; having a very fine-grained structure.
A credence table; -- so called by the Eastern or Greek Church.
An order of curious parasitic worms found on crinoids. The bodyis short and disklike, with four pairs of suckers and five pairs ofhook-bearing parapodia on the under side.
To talk much and idly; to prate; hence, to talk lightly andartlessly, like a child; to utter child's talk.
In a topical manner; with application to, or limitation of, aparticular place or topic.
A note issued by a bank, payable at some future specified time,as distinguished from a note payable on demand. Burrill.
A form of prayer in which public confession of sins is made.
The act of masticating or chewing again or repeatedly.
A kind of frenzy in which the patient is tormented by fantasticvisions and want of sleep. Dunglison.
A sport piece of bar iron for rolling into a sheet; a smallbillet.
A group of butterflies which includes the satyrs. See Satyr, 2.
A red cap worn by Turks and other Eastern nations, sometimesalone and sometimes swathed with linen or other stuff to make aturban. See Fez.
One of a class of respiratory pigments, widely distributed inthe animal kingdom, capable of ready oxidation and reduction.

A repetition of the same meaning in different words; needlessrepetition of an idea in different words or phrases; a representationof anything as the cause, condition, or consequence of itself, as inthe following lines: --The dawn is overcast, the morning lowers, And heavily in cloudsbrings on the day. Addison.

Of or pertaining to a presbyter, or to ecclesiasticalgovernment by presbyters; relating to those who uphold churchgovernment by presbyters; also, to the doctrine, discipline, andworship of a communion so governed.
The science of plants; a description of the kinds andproperties of plants; botany. Sir T. Browne.
An instrument for obtaining directly, without calculation, thetrue bearing of the sun, and thence the variation of the compass
The clusters of gelatinous egg capsules of a squid (Loligo).
An abnormal dryness of the eyeball produced usually by long-continued inflammation and subsequent atrophy of the conjunctiva.
