An instrument attached to a locomotive for recording its speedand the number and duration of its stops.
An anatomical description of, or treatise on, the skin.
The act of praying; supplication; entreaty. Cotton.
An East Indian palm (Caryota urens) having leaves pinnate withwedge-shaped divisions, the petiole very stout. It is the principalsource of jaggery, and is often cultivated for ornament.
The act of scoffing; scoffing conduct; mockery. Holinshed.
Having the whorls of the spire revolving or rising to the left;reversed; -- said of certain spiral shells.
The beam which supports the spindle socket of the runner in agrinding mill. Knight.
One who, or that which, retracts. Specifically:(a) In breech-loading firearms, a device for withdrawing a cartridgeshell from the barrel. (b) (Surg.)
To loose from shackles or bonds; to set free from restraint; tounfetter. Addison.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling asbestus; inconsumable;asbestine.
The science which treats of the cultivation of the cinchona,and of its use in medicine.
The voluntary failure of the members of a race or people tohave a number of children sufficient to keep the birth rate equal tothe death rate.
A rope used in hoisting the anchor to the cathead. Totten.
Pertaining to, or having the character of, a jubilee. [R.] Bp.Hall.
A tumor consisting mainly of fibrous tissue, or of samemodification of such tissue.
A curl of hair or silk; a pad of frizzed hair or silk worn bywomen under the hair to stuff it out.
A tree from which the branches have been cut; a pollard.
A Spanish silver coin, and money of account, equal to aboutnineteen cents, and divided into 100 centesimos.
The first sketch of a picture or model of a statue.
Becoming hard and thorny; tapering gradually to a rigid,leafless point; armed with spines. Gray.
A soldier of the ancient Muscovite guard or Russian standingarmy; also, the guard itself.
A patent anodyne medicine, containing opium, chloroform, Indianhemp, etc.
A polynomial of four terms connected by the signs plus orminus.
A cart so constructed that the body can be easily tipped, inorder to dump the load.
A piece of timber placed across the stem, to unite the bows andstrengthen the fore part of the ship; a breast hook.
A European lake whitefish (Coregonus Willughbii, or C.Vandesius) native of certain lakes in Scotland and England. It isregarded as a delicate food fish. Called also vendis.
A genus of moths, which includes the silkworm moth. SeeSilkworm.
The large, hard-shelled nut of the cocoa palm. It yields anagreeable milky liquid and a white meat or albumen much used as foodand in making oil.
A genus of extinct crocodilian reptiles of the Jurassic period,having a long and slender snout.
Any fish whose scales yield a pearl-like pigment used inmanufacturing artificial pearls, as the bleak, and whitebait.

The art or process of making a kind of hard, stereotypeplate,by pressing into a mold, taken from a page of type or other matter, acomposition of gum shell-lac and sand of a fine quality, togetherwith a little tar and linseed oil, all in a heated state.
The lowest title of nobility in Portugal, corresponding to thatof Hidalgo in Spain.
Not to be injured by shot; shot-proof. [Obs.] Feltham.
Pertaining to, or resembling, youth; youthful. [Obs.] Spenser.
A bivalve mollusk, with radiating ribs, of the genus Cardium,especially C. edule, used in Europe for food; -- sometimes applied tosimilar shells of other genera.
A description or definition contrary to that which is given bythe adverse party. [R.]
The commercial language of the Levant, -- a mixture of thelanguage of the people of the region and foreign traders.
The muscle which makes the greater part of the calf of the leg.
Covered with a fine bloom or fine white powder easily rubbedoff, as that on a blue plum, or on a cabbage leaf. Gray.
A name locally applied to various wild plants, as dandelion,bluet, oxeye daisy, etc.
Pertaining to, consisting of, or containing, blende.
A kind of Venetian glass or glassware in which white threadsare embedded in transparent glass with a lacelike or netlike effect.
A group of nemerteans comprising those having a deep slit alongeach side of the head. See Illust. in Appendix.
A crystalline nitrogenous base, C10H8N2, obtained by thereduction of pyridine.
The system of teaching law in which the instruction isprimarily a historical and inductive study of leading or selectedcases, with or without the use of textbooks for reference andcollateral reading.
A general name for organ stops in which the sound is caused bywind passing through a flue or fissure and striking an edge above; --in distinction from reedwork.

In certain Sporozoa, a cell formed by the growth of asporozoite or merozoite (in a cell or corpuscle of the host) whichsegment by superficial cleavage, without encystment or conjugation,into  merozoites.
A small appendage situated above the base of the wings ofHymenoptera and attached to the mesonotum.
A genus of spiders, including the common garden spider (E.diadema). They spin geometrical webs. See Garden spider.
The process of sending any matter, for inquiry in a cause, to amaster or other officer, in order that he may ascertain facts andreport to the court.
Propensity to form and maintain attachments to persons, and topromote social intercourse.
To cause to be disbelieved; to discredit. [Obs.] Fuller.
The act of imploring; earnest supplication. Bp. Hall.

Two small, concave shells of ivory or hard wood, shaped likespoons, fastened to the thumb, and beaten together with the middlefinger; -- used by the Spaniards and Moors as an accompaniment totheir dance and guitars.
Any one of several of South African lizards of the genusZonura, common in rocky situations.

Orig., an officer appointed to look to the goodness of ale andbeer; also, one of the officers chosen by the liverymen of London toinspect the measures used in public houses. But the office is asinecure. [Also called aletaster.] [Eng.]
The act of exposing one's self; the state of being so exposed.
The rim which encompasses and fastens a jewel or other object,as the crystal of a watch, in the cavity in which it is set.
A genus of large oceanic Siphonophora which includes thePortuguese man-of-war.
To catch or entangle in, or as in, the meshes of a net. or in aweb; to insnare.
The solid contents of a body; volume; amount of inclosed space.
A papular disease of the skin, of which intense itching is thechief symptom, the eruption scarcely differing from the healthycuticle in color.
To make wrong distinctions in or concerning. Hooker.
Of, pertaining to, or like, Trachinus, a genus of fishes whichincludes the weevers. See Weever.
The breaking of a public pound for releasing impounded animals.Blackstone.
Bread made of unbolted wheat flour. [U. S.] Bartlett.
The thickened posterior border of the corpus callosum; -- socalled in allusion to its shape.
Tasting; the appreciation of sapid qualities by the tasteorgans. Bp. Hall.
A genus of biennial, poisonous, white-flowered, umbelliferousplants, bearing ribbed fruit ("seeds") and decompound leaves.

To bear up; to raise aloft; to support in an elevatedsituation; to sustain. Spenser.One short sigh of breath, upbore Even to the seat of God. Milton.A monstrous wave upbore The chief, and dashed him on the craggyshore. Pope.
To implant a portion of (living flesh or akin) in a lesion soas to form an organic union.
Not using words; not speaking; silent; speechless. Shak.
A foliar part of a plant; any organ homologous with a leaf, orproduced by metamorphosis of a leaf.
The bow or arch in the front part of a saddle, or the pieceswhich form the front.
The lowest division of rhizopods, including those whichresemble the amoebas, but are destitute of a nucleus.
To unwind, unfold, or untie; hence, to undo; to ruin. Shak.
The thin, new growth around the edge of a shell, of an oyster.
One in genesis; resulting from one process of formation; --used of a mountain range. Dana.
A dark green igneous rock, consisting largely of chrysolite,with hornblende, augite, biotite, etc.
Incapable of being supposed; not supposable; inconceivable.
A week day, esp. a day which is neither a festival nor a fast.Shipley.
The refrain of a famous song of the French Revolution.
Of or pertaining to a vestige or remnant; like a vestige.
The common English milkwort (Polygala vulgaris), so called fromblossoming in gang week. Dr. Prior.
The act of pledging, or drinking first, and then offering thecup to another. [Obs.] Abp. Potter.
Of or pertaining to turpentine; resembling turpentine;terbinthine; as, terbinthic qualities.
Toward the inside or central part; away from the surface; --opposed to ectad. B. G. Wilder.
The quality or state of being tumulous; hilliness. [R.] Bailey.
Balancing; moving like a balance, as it tends to an equipoiseor level.
The free-swimming, hat-shaped larva of certain nemertean worms.It has no resemblance to its parent, and the young worm develops inits interior.
Bad address; an awkward, tactless, or offensive way ofaccosting one or talking with one. W. D. Howells.
Having the shape of an egg, or of the longitudinal sectior ofan egg, with the broader end basal. Gray.
To sound wrongly; to utter or pronounce incorrectly. E,Hall.
A sea bird of the Atlantic (Rhynchops nigra); -- called alsoblack skimmer, scissorsbill, and razorbill. See Skimmer.
Depending on, or derived from, prescription; proper to beprescribed. Grafton.
One who deputes, or makes a deputation. [R.] Locke.
A small arch thrown across the corner of a square room tosupport a superimposed mass, as where an octagonal spire or drumrests upon a square tower; -- called also sconce, and sconcheon.
Of or pertaining to Universalism; Universalist. [R.]
One who conforms to or inculcates Judaism; specifically, pl.(Ch. Hist.), those Jews who accepted Christianity but still adheredto the law of Moses and worshiped in the temple at Jerusalem.
A thickened glandular portion of the body of the adultearthworm, consisting of several united segments modified forreproductive purposes.
Pertaining to lithophosphor; becoming phosphoric by heat.
An oval lobe beneath each of the optic lobes in many fishes;one of the inferior lobes. Owen.
One of several species of edentates and monotremes that feedupon ants. See Ant-bear, Pangolin, Aard-vark, and Echidna.
Capable of being suspended; capable of being held from sinking.
A morbid condition due to excessive increase of albuminouselements in the blood.
The pressure of one dyne per square centimeter; -- used as aunit of pressure.
The quality or state of being careless; heedlessness;negligenece; inattention.
Of or pertaining to the Fiji islands or their inhabitants.-- n.
The condition of certain species of plants, in which thestamens and pistil do not mature simultaneously, so that these plantscan never fertilize themselves.
One who upholds or supports that which props; one who, or thatwhich, stays, stops, or restrains; also, colloquially, a horse, man,etc., that has endurance, an a race.
A small marine isopod crustacean (Limnoria lignorum or L.terebrans), which burrows into and rapidly destroys submerged timber,such as the piles of wharves, both in Europe and America.
A compound of iron, such as puddled steel, made withoutcomplete fusion.
The act or process of making and applying rands for shoes.

The European golden-crested kinglet (Regulus cristatus, or R.regulus); -- called also golden-crested wren, and golden wren. Thename is also sometimes applied to the American golden-crestedkinglet. See Kinglet.
A small coin, and money of account, in England, equivalent totwo pennies, -- minted to a fixed annual amount, for almsgiving bythe sovereign on Maundy Thursday.
Anything in three parts or leaves. Specifically: --(a) A writing tablet in three parts, two of which fold over on themiddle part.(b) A picture or altarpiece in three compartments.
A large cup or deep saucer, containing fatty matter in which awick is placed, -- used for public illuminations, as at St. Peter's,in Rome. Called also padelle.
An order of Merostomata, including among living animals thegenus Limulus, with various allied fossil genera, mostly of theCarboniferous period. Called also Xiphosura.
A machine for spreading out cotton cloths to prepare them forprinting.
The dried twigs of a Syrian tree (Balsamodendron Gileadense).U. S. Disp.
A kind of black raspberry (Rubus occidentalis), common inAmerica.
The quality or state of being pallid; paleness; pallor;wanness.
Completely crystalline; -- said of a rock like granite, all theconstituents of which are crystalline.
Over; above; before; also, beyond; besides; -- much used as aprefix.
The order of amphibians which includes the frogs and toads; theAnura. Sometimes the word is used in a wider sense as equivalent toAmphibia.
Similar. [Obs.]Rhyming cadences of similarly words. South.
The nobility or aristocracy of ancient Rome, as opposed to thepopulares.
Rubbish. Specifically: (a) Dross or refuse of metals. [Obs.](b) Light, dry wood, or stuff used for fuel. [Prov. Eng.]
A person without thought fulness, prudence, or judgment.[Colloq.] Burton.
A fluosilicate of magnesia and iron, yellow to red in color,often occurring in granular form in a crystalline limestone.
The quality or condition of having strong reproductive powers;generation with full fertility between different species or races,specif. between hybrids of the first generation.
An instrument for estimating the purity or richness of milk, asa measuring glass, a specific gravity bulb, or other apparatus.

An elementary substance found combined in the mineralsmanaccanite, rutile, sphene, etc., and isolated as an infusible iron-gray amorphous powder, having a metallic luster. It burns when heatedin the air. Symbol Ti. Atomic weight 48.1.
A transparent, extensible membrane of extreme tenuity, whichforms the innermost coating of grains of pollen.
The name of Vishnu in his tenth and last avatar. Whitworth.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, official formality. See Redtape, under Red, a.
Play in which the score is reckoned by counting the number ofstrokes.
The study or science of the life of marine organisms. Agassiz.
One who gives birth to twins; a breeder of twins. Tusser.
To make drunk; to intoxicate; to fuddle. [Obs.] Burton.
A medicinal plant, the thoroughwort (Eupatorium perfoliatum).Its properties are diaphoretic and tonic.
Having the inferior rays of the pectoral fins partially orentirely free, as in the gurnards.
A sign or memorial of a victory raised on the field of battle,or, in case of a naval victory, on the nearest land. Sometimestrophies were erected in the chief city of the conquered people.
The quality of being invariable; invariableness; constancy;uniformity.
A word from the vocabulary of Mrs. Quickly, the hostess inShakespeare's Henry IV., probably meaning terror.
The rough surface of a congealed lava stream. [Southwestern U.S.]
A member of a club; a frequenter of clubs. [R.] Burke.
Considered as having done sufficient public service, andtherefore honorably discharged. [Obs.] Evelyn.
Deviating from ordinary forms or rules; irregular; anomalous;abnormal.
The black-backed gull (Larus marinus); -- called also swarbie.[Prov. Eng.]
A genus of showy flowering shrubs, mostly natives of China orof North America; false honeysuckle. The genus is scarcely distinctfrom Rhododendron.
To distill, as spirit from molasses or some saccharinepreparation.
(Bot.) A kind of bindweed (Convolvulus Soldanella) growing onthe seacoast of Europe.
Relating to, or containing, a subsumption. Coleridge.
A spherulitic cavity often with concentric chambers, observedin some volcanic rocks, as in rhyolitic lavas. It is supposed to beproduced by expanding gas, whence the name.
To supply with provender or provisions; to provide for. [Obs.]Nash.
A contrivance in some of the ealier steam engines for movingthe valves for the alternate admission and shutting off of the steam.
Loss of the power of speaking, while retaining the power ofwriting; -- a disorder of cerebral origin.
A sweet amorphous deliquescent substance obtained indirectlyfrom benzene, and isometric with, and resembling, dextrose.
Speaking with directness; plain-spoken. [Colloq. U.S.] Lowell.
A black, granular, explosive substance, consisting of anintimate mechanical mixture of niter, charcoal, and sulphur. It isused in gunnery and blasting.
A subdivision of a regiment of troops under the command of acaptain, numbering in the United States (full strength) 100 men.
In an exorbitant, excessive, or irregular manner; enormously.
A kind of narrow braid, usually of silk; -- also known asRussian braid.
Of or pertaining to sound; of the nature of sound; acoustic.Tyndall.
The absence or loss of the power of expressing ideas by writtensigns. It is one form of aphasia.
The quality of having similar sexual zooids or gonophores anddissimilar hydrants; -- said of certain hydroids.
A whisk to keep off files, used in the East Indies. Malcom.
Between the neural arch and the centrum of a vertebra; as, theneurocentral suture. Huxley.
An endemic disease occurring in the Andes in Peru,characterized by warty tumors which ulcerate and bleed. It isprobably due to a special bacillus, and is often fatal.

The act of apportioning; a dividing into just proportions orshares; a division or shares; a division and assignment, to eachproprietor, of his just portion of an undivided right or property. A.Hamilton.
Of or pertaining to a relic or relics; of the nature of arelic. [R.]
Full of trade; busy in traffic; commercial. Spenser.
One who, or that which; sounds; specifically, an instrumentused in telegraphy in place of a register, the communications beingread by sound.
Plumes, collectively or in general; plumage. [R.] Southey.
Intense excitement at the sight of deer or other game, such asoften unnerves a novice in hunting. [Colloq.]

Land held in villenage, being distributed among the folk, orpeople, at the pleasure of the lord of the manor, and resumed at hisdiscretion. Not being held by any assurance in writing, it wasopposed to bookland or charter land, which was held by deed. Mozley &W.
In a naked manner; without covering or disguise; manifestly;simply; barely.
An animal, not truly parasitic, which lives in with, or on,another, partaking usually of the same food. Both species may bebenefited by the association.
Having the planes arranged spirally, so that they incline allto the right (or left) of a vertical line; -- said of certainhemihedral forms.
To make red or somewhat red; to give a red color to.
The point or line in which one line or surface cuts another.

An alkaloidal ureide, C7H8N4O2, homologous with and resemblingcaffeine, produced artificially, and also extracted from cacao andchocolate (from Theobroma Cacao) as a bitter white crystallinesubstance; -- called also dimethyl xanthine.
The peculiar character, manners, tenets, etc., of the Quakers.
To feed with eagerness or voracity; to stuff one's self withfood. Beaumont.
A species of pine (Pinus sylvestris), and its wood, whichaffords a valuable timber; -- called also Scotch pine, and red oryellow deal. It grows in all parts of Europe, in the Caucasus, and inSiberia.
A long, winding constellation extending southward from Taurusand containing the bright star Achernar.
A mineral occurring in hexagonal crystals, also massive,generally of a yellow color, containing silica, alumina, lime, soda,and carbon dioxide.
That part of arithmetic which treats of adding numbers.
A substance of a resinous nature, obtained from the outer barkof the common European birch (Betula alba), or from the tar preparedtherefrom; -- called also birch camphor. Watts.
Flesh-colored; of a carnation or pale red color. [Obs.]Lovelace.
A variety of rhodonite, from Franklin Furnace, New Jersey,containing some zinc.
The state of being perspicacious; acuteness of sight or ofintelligence; acute discernment. Sir T. Browne.
A florid style of ornamentation which prevailed in Europe inthe latter part of the eighteenth century.

Production of decorative designs by scratching them through asurface of layer plaster, glazing, etc., revealing a different-colored ground; also, pottery or ware so decorated; -- chiefly usedattributively.
Loathsome; disgusting; hateful. [Obs.]Murder is . . . wlatsom and abhominable to God. Chaucer.
One who engraves; a person whose business it is to produceengraved work, especially on metal or wood.

Comprehending, or relating to, many arts and sciences; --applied particularly to schools in which many branches of art andscience are taught with especial reference to their practicalapplication; also to exhibitions of machinery and industrialproducts.
First brought forth; first in the order of nativity; eldest;hence, most excellent; most distinguished or exalted.
The office or station of a presbyter; presbyterate.
Absence or lack of peace. [Obs.] Testament of Love.
The figure of a horse, mounted upon rockers, for children toride.
Alternating transparent and opaque white rings which are seenoutside the blastoderm, on the surface of the developing egg of thehen and other birds.
A person excluded from the benefit of the law, or deprived ofits protection. Blackstone.
To make smooth or plane, as a metallic surface; to condense,toughen, and polish by light blows with a hammer.
Situated above, or on the dorsal side of, the body of thesphenoid bone.
A frame or support for holding something in place, as journalboxes, etc.
Having a high or noble spirit; honorable. E. Everett.
The fragrant flowers of the Chloranthus inconspicuus, used inChina for perfuming tea.
Of or pertaining to a reed; resembling the reed or cane.
A strip of wood or iron fastened on transversely to somethingin order to give strength, prevent warping, hold position, etc.
One of the sweet spices used by the ancient Jews in thepreparation of incense. It was perhaps an oil or other form of myrrhor cinnamon, or a kind of storax. Ex. xxx. 34.
Six times ten; fifty-nine and one more; threescore.
That stage of growth or development in an organism, in whichthe reproductive elements are generated and matured in preparationfor propagating the species.
Termination a disease; indicating the end of a disease.
To free from feudal customs or character; to make not feudal.Carlyle.
The act or manner of binding up; bandage; also, the conditionof being fasciated.
The quality or state of being triangular. Bolingbroke.
To follow closely; to endeavor to overtake; to pursue. [Obs.]Bp. Burnet.
The act of resulting; that which results; a result. Donne.
Hydrous carbonate of lanthanum, found in tabular whilecrystals.
A genus of herbaceous prickly plants, found in the south ofEurope, Asia Minor, and India; bear's-breech.
Those birds whose young are covered with down when hatched.
A cone-shaped piece of wood on the point of the spindle abovethe vane, on the mast-head.
A small cone or mass made of paste of gum, benzoin, cinnamon,and other aromatics, -- used for fumigating or scenting the air of aroom.
A mineral consisting of sulphate of lead, occurring eithermassive or in long slender prisms, of a greenish white or gray color.
One who sells rum; one who deals in intoxicating liquors;especially, one who sells spirituous beverages at retail.
A curious colubriform snake of the genus Xyphorhynchus, fromMadagascar. It is brownish red, and its hose is prolonged in the formof a sharp blade.
A bearing representing the head of a dart or javelin, with longbarbs which are engrailed on the inner edge.
An overfullness or obstruction of the vessels in some part ofthe system; congestion. Hoblyn.
To make efficacious; to give virtue of efficacy. [Obs.] Harvey.
The great extensor muscle of the knee, divided above into fourparts which unite in a single tendon at the knee.
Uniformly bending or curving to one side; -- said of leaveswhich grow on several sides of a stem.
One of the bones or cartilages of the carpus, which articulateswith the ulna and corresponds to the cuneiform in man.
Deprived of the faculty of will or volition. Mrs. Browning.
A sentence, phrase, or word, forming part of an heraldicachievment.
One of the dorsal branches of the main bronchi in the lungs ofbirds.
The root of a leguminous plant (Psoralea esculenta), found nearthe Rocky Mountains. It is usually oval in form, and abounds infarinaceous matter, affording sweet and palatable food.

A species of palm (Borassus flabelliformis) having a straight,black, upright trunk, with palmate leaves. It is found native alongthe entire northern shores of the Indian Ocean, from the mouth of theTigris to New Guinea. More than eight hundred uses to which it is putare enumerated by native writers. Its wood is largely used forbuilding purposes; its fruit and roots serve for food, its sap formaking toddy, and its leaves for thatching huts.
A shelter to protect from snow, esp. a long roof over anexposed part of a railroad.
A genus of fishes, including the fresh-water perch.

A genus of herbaceous composite plants, having the achenes two-horned and remotely resembling some insect; tickseed. C. tinctoria,of the Western plains, the commonest plant of the genus, has beenused in dyeing.
One of the terminal branches or divisions of the beam of theantler of the stag or other large deer.
A bar connecting the ends of the side rods or levers of abackaction or side-lever engine.
A thick plain silk, generally black, and used for clerical.Simmonds.
One who frequents playhouses, or attends dramatic performances.
A hold in which the agressor bends back his opponent's foot.
The collective lighter equipments or outfit of a bride,including clothes, jewelry, and the like; especially, that which isprovided for her by her family.
An insect which has the anterior pair of wings coriaceous, anddoes not use them in flight, as the earwig.
A morbid condition in which the urine contains chyle or fattymatter, giving it a milky appearance.
Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the eye.
A fragrant liquid, used for cosmetic and medicinal purposes.
One who holds a shield over another; hence, a defender. [Obs.]Chillingworth.
Having all the parts or organs which belong to it or to thetypical form; having calyx, corolla, stamens, and pistil.
An organ of the Ctenophora, supposed to be sensory.
Curved somewhat in the form of the letter S. Cussans.
A kind of rich, sweet cake; -- so called from the ingredientsbeing used by pounds, or in equal quantities.
The system or theory that denies the existence of materialbodies, and teaches that we have no rational grounds to believe inthe reality of anything but ideas and their relations.
An instrument used for measuring the distance of an object froman observer; as, a telescope with a micrometer for measuring theapparent diameter of an object whose real dimensions are known.
The act of porphyrizing, or the state of being porphyrized.
A common name of dolomite; -- so called because it containsmagnesia, the soluble salts of which are bitter. See Dolomite.
One's own affairs; one's private business. [Obs.] Shak.
Madeira mahogany; the coarse, dark-colored wood of the PerseaIndica.
Not liable to sin; exempt from the possibility of doing wrong.-- n.
Any of several isomeric iodine derivatives of the cresols,C6H3I(CH3)OH, esp. one, an odorless amorphous powder, used inmedicine as a substitute for iodoform.
A remedy possessing the property of preventing the return ofperiodic paroxysms, or exacerbations, of disease, as in intermittentfevers.
To challenge or discredit the credibility of, as of a witness,or the validity of, as of commercial paper.
To impregnate with azote, or nitrogen; to nitrogenize.
A kind of atomizer for applying liquid coloring matter in aspray by compressed air.
Capable of being prognosticated or foretold. Sir T. Browne.
Supplying its own power; -- applied to an instrument of thenature of a water-ram.
Destructive or downward metabolism; regressive metamorphism; --opposed to anabolism. See Disassimilation.
The reducing of anything to ashes by combustion; cinefaction.
Pertaining to an army marching, or to a train. [R.]
A subordinate officer on an extensive estate, who acts as anassistant to the steward.

A heavy, brilliant red pigment, consisting of an oxide of lead,Pb3O4, obtained by exposing lead or massicot to a gentle andcontinued heat in the air. It is used as a cement, as a paint, and inthe manufacture of flint glass. Called also red lead.
An herb used in medicine (Plantago Psyllium), named from theshape of its seeds. Loudon.
Of or pertaining to Clement, esp. to St.Clement of Rome and thespurious homilies attributed to him, or to Pope Clement V. and hiscompilations of canon law.
A harmless lizard of the Gecko family (PlatydactylusMauritianicus) found in Southern Europe and adjacent countries,especially among old walls and ruins.
The act or process of uniting lands, rights, or revenues, tothe ecclesiastical chamber, i. e., to the pope's domain.
A division of copepod crustaceans, including numerous speciesparasitic on fishes.
The doctrine or theory of the gyrostat, or of the phenomena ofrotating bodies.
A species of elm (Ulmus montana) found in Northern and WesternEurope; Scotch elm.
A suborder of corals including many reef-building species,having round, starlike calicles.
A variety of amianthus which is very light, like cork.
Of or pertaining to silver; resembling, containing, or combinedwith, silver.
To cause to wheel or turn in an opposite direction.
Composed largely of hornblende; resembling or relating tohornblende.
Anything scattered, as flowers for decoration. [Obs.] Shak.
That state or condition of the pulse in which the pulse curve,or sphygmogram, shows several secondary crests or elevations; --contrasted with monocrotism and dicrotism.
A mineral of a brownish black color, related to titanite inform. It consists chiefly of silica, titanium dioxide, lime, andyttria.
An American shrub (Andromeda Mariana) having clusters ofnodding white flowers. It grows in low, sandy places, and is said topoison lambs and calves. Gray.
A woman who governs and teaches a school; a female school-teacher.
To unite with glue; to cement; to stick together. Bailey.
Cloth, specifically cotton cloth, suitable for making shirts.
The quality or state of being vivid; vividness. [R.]
A genus of Branchiopoda, having a disklike shell, attached byone valve, which is perforated by the peduncle.
The edible fruit of an East Indian tree (Baccaurea Malayana) ofthe Spurge family. It somewhat resembles an apple.
An American endogenous plant (Tradescantia Virginica), withlong linear leaves and ephemeral blue flowers. The name is sometimesextended to other species of the same genus.
A tract of low land reclaimed from the sea by of highembankments. [Holland & Belgium]
A common prostitute who walks the streets to find customers.
Situated behind the palate, or behind the palatine bones.
One who, or a vessel that, cruises; -- usually an armed vessel.
Having the two main flexor tendons of the toes blendedtogether.
In a nonchalant, indifferent, or careless manner; coolly.
The state or quality of being a dilettante; the desultorypursuit of art, science, or literature.
A movement or phase in post-impressionism (which see, below). -- Cu"bist (#), n.
Sullenness; silent displeasure; the sulks. Skinner.
The state of being stormy; tempestuousness; biosteruousness;impetuousness.
A peculiar albuminous body considered a normal constituent ofmilk.
A marsupial of Australia (Dasyurus macrurus), about the size ofa cat.
In an apocryphal manner; mythically; not indisputably.
A nitrogenous organic base, C8H6N2, analogous to quinoline,obtained from certain complex diazo compounds.
Full of news; abounding in information as to current events.[Colloq.]
The pains which succeed childbirth, as in expelling theafterbirth.
An apparatus for measuring speed, as of machinery or vessels,but especially of projectiles.
To withdraw from fellowship, communion, or association; toseparate one's self by a solemn act; to draw off; to retire;especially, to withdraw from a political or religious body.
As much as a vessel will hold; enough to fill a vessel.
The doctrines, principles, or practices, of the Know-nothings.
The quality of being profligate; an abandoned course of life;profligacy.
A member of a chapter or convent, whose week it is to officiatein the choir, and perform other services, which, on extraordinaryoccasions, are performed by the superiors.
A building in which vessels' masts are shaped, fitted, etc.
Grief for sin arising only from fear of punishment or feelingsof shame. See Contrition. Wallis.
A tableau in which persons take part; also, specif., such atableau as imitating a work of art.
The quality of being chargeable or expensive. [Obs.]Whitelocke.
A book, or a list, of lections, for reading in divine service.
The quality or state of being infrangible; infrangibleness.
One who opposes; an opponent; an antagonist; an adversary.
A female heir who inherits with other heiresses; a jointheiress.
A division of nudibranchiate Mollusca, in which the gills forma wreath or cluster upon the posterior part of the back. SeeNudibranchiata, and Doris.
Historical narration on a small scale; a brief recital; astory. Emerson.
The quality of being costy; expensiveness; sumptuousness.
A complex nitrogenous compound obtained as a scarletcrystalline substance, and regarded as related to murexide.
A canopy usually standing free and supported on four columns,covering the high altar, or, very rarely, a secondary altar.
The principal bone of the shoulder girdle in mammals; theshoulder blade.

The larva of a small, hymenopterous fly (Eurytoma hordei),which is found in gall-like swellings on the stalks of wheat, usuallyat or just above the first joint. In some parts of America it doesgreat damage to the crop.
The outfit of clothing, blankets, etc., prepared for a newborninfant, and placed ready for used.
The act of disinfecting; purification from infecting matter.
The larva of any species of geometrid moths. See Geometrid.

The dramatic practice or purpose characteristic of the writingsof Henrik Ibsen (1828-1906), Norwegian poet and dramatist, whosebest-known plays deal with conventional hypocrisies, the story ineach play thus developing a definite moral problem.

Of or pertaining to a region of the earth's surface includingall of temperate and arctic North America and Greenland. In thegeographical distribution of animals, this region is marked off asthe habitat certain species.
Having all the teeth similar in front, as in the porpoises; --opposed to heterodont.
Of or pertaining to separatism in religion; schismatical. [R.]Dr. T. Dwight.
An optical instrument used in determining the position of theplanes of light-vibration in sections of crystals.
The quality of being peevish; disposition to murmur; sournessof temper.
One of a group of arachnids, including the mites and ticks.

Any Friday on which a public disaster has occurred, as: InEngland, December 6, 1745, when the news of the landing of thePretender reached London, or May 11, 1866,  when a financial paniccommenced. In the United States, September 24, 1869, and September18, 1873, on which financial panics began.
An advocate of, or believer in, solidism. Dunglison.
A kind of oven, or reverberatory furnace, used for thecalcination of sand and potash, and converting them into frit. Ure.
Of or pertaining to an electrograph or electrography.

The system of the Quietists, who maintained that religionconsists in the withdrawal of the mind from worldly interests andanxieties and its constant employment in the passive contemplation ofGod and his attributes.
A society or body of men united for some purpose, or in someprofession; a brotherhood.
The trade or work of an engraver. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
The act of searing some morbid part by the application of acautery or caustic; also, the effect of such application.
A small molding, carved into beads, pearls, olives, etc.
A variety of lignin or cellulose found in the medulla, or pith,of certain plants. Cf. Lignin, and Cellulose.

A cylindrical bundle of small sticks of wood, bound together,used in raising batteries, filling ditches, strengthening ramparts,and making parapets; also in revetments for river banks, and in matsfor dams, jetties, etc.
A severe beating with a stick, cudgel, or the fist.
Tired or sore of foot from travel; lamed. [Obs.] Nares.
Designed to facilitate discharges of phlegm or mucus from mouthor nostrils.-- n.
Hollow and cylindrical, like a pipe or reed. Johnson.
The quality of having a nap; abundance of nap, as on cloth.
The science or study of antiquities, esp. prehistoricantiquities, such as the remains of buildings or monuments of anearly epoch, inscriptions, implements, and other relics, writtenmanuscripts, etc.
One who pays; specifically, the person by whom a bill or notehas been, or should be, paid.
In every place; in all places; hence, in every part; throughly;altogether.
To unwind; to disentangle; to loose. [Obs.] Spenser.
A hydrocarbon (C13H10) obtained in white fluorescent crystals,in the distillation products of the needles of the California "bigtree" (Sequoia gigantea).

The matter secreted by any of the sebaceous glands.Specifically:(a) The soapy substance covering the skin of newborn infants.(b) The cheesy, sebaceous matter which collects between the glanspenis and the foreskin.
Any one of the Fungi, a large and very complex group ofthallophytes of low organization, -- the molds, mildews, rusts,smuts, mushrooms, toadstools, puff balls, and the allies of each.
A translation or paraphrase of some portion of the OldTestament Scriptures in the Chaldee or Aramaic language or dialect.
A public assembly of the Roman people for electing officers orpassing laws.
Belonging to, or constituted by, timocracy. Sir G. C. Lewis.
An ethereal fluid that supplied the place of blood in the veinsof the gods.
Alack the day; alas; -- an expression of sorrow, regret,dissatisfaction, or surprise.
To prepare, treat, impregnate, or coat with bitumen.
Separated or broken up; -- said of the crest of birds when thefeathers are divergent.
A native of India employed as a soldier in the service of aEuropean power, esp. of Great Britain; an Oriental soldierdisciplined in the European manner.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, copper; containing copper;-- said of those compounds of copper in which this element is presentin its lowest proportion.
A noun which has no distinction of cases; an indeclinable noun.
A harmless North American snake of the genus Heterodon, esp. H.platyrhynos; -- called also puffing adder, blowing adder, and sandviper.
An aquatic European plant (Stratiotes aloides) with bayonet-shaped leaves.
One who holds the doctrine that immersion is essential toChristian baptism.
Having an umbrella-shaped or bell-shaped body, with a wide,open cavity beneath; -- said of certain jellyfishes.
A kind of coarse grass growing in wet grounds, and supposed tobe injurious to sheep. [Prov. Eng.]
The berrylike drupe of the elder. That of the Old World elder(Sambucus nigra) and that of the American sweet elder (S. Canadensis)are sweetish acid, and are eaten as a berry or made into wine.
The hypothetical principle of fire, or inflammability, regardedby Stahl as a chemical element.
The establishment or ascertaining of parentage; the assignmentof a child, as a bastard, to its father; filiation.
Any one of numerous species of water; the skater. See Skater,n., 2.
To flow over the brim; to be so full as to overflow. [R.]

The thick, brown or dark colored, viscid, uncrystallizablesirup which drains from sugar, in the process of manufacture; anythick, viscid, sweet sirup made from vegetable juice or sap, as ofthe sorghum or maple. See Treacle.
A person competent to serve on a jury, in an action for land inthe hundred to which he belongs.
A low public house; especially, a place where spirits and otherexcisable liquors are illegally and privately sold. [Ireland]
A solid, the faces of which are six parallelograms, theopposite pairs being parallel, and equal to each other; a prism whosebase is a parallelogram.
Capable of being, or fit to be, pursued, followed, orprosecuted. Sherwood.
Of or pertaining to the movement of the eye; -- appliedespecially to the common motor nerves (or third pair of cranialnerves) which supply many of the muscles of the orbit.-- n.
An inhabitant of the more southern part of a country; formerly,a name given in Scotland to any Englishman.
Asserting that a thing is; -- opposed to problematical andapodeictical.
A measure of length in Italy, varying from six to seven feet.See Cane, 4.
A believer in the doctrine of William Miller (d. 1849), whotaught that the end of the world and the second coming of Christ wereat hand.
Forming part of the same family. [Obs.] Sir E. Dering.
Of or pertaining to dew; consisting of dew; dewy. [R.] M.Green.
A surgical instrument consisting of a slender knife, eitherstraight or curved, generally used by introducing it beneath the partto be divided, and cutting towards the surface.
The Greek letter S, or s). It originally had the form of theEnglish C.
Of or pertaining to the woodpeckers (Pici), or to thePiciformes.
A subordinate, or inferior, division into parts; a subdivision.[R.]Many subdichatomies of petty schisms. Milton.
A person well versed in theology; a professor of theology ordivinity; a divine.
The quality or state of being whitish or somewhat white.
Of or pertaining to covering; -- applied to a membraneimmediately over the organ of Corti in the internal ear.
The state of being contracted; narrowness; meannes;selfishness.
A solid hydrocarbon, C20H42, of the paraffine series, ofartificial production, and also probably occurring in petroleum.
To intimidate by bullying; to rally contemptuously; to badger.[Low]
Aftermath; also, stubble and stubble field. See Arrish. [Eng.]
Of or pertaining to the sternum and the thyroid cartilage.
One of a family of extinct edentates found in America. Thefamily includes the megatherium, the megalonyx, etc.
The act of solacing, or the state of being solaced; also, thatwhich solaces. [R.]
The closely matted hair or downy nap covering the leaves orstems of some plants.
The projector, manager, or conductor, of an opera or concertcompany.
The free-swimming larva of sea urchins and ophiurans, havingseveral long stiff processes inclosing calcareous rods.
Trembling or tottering, as if about to fall; un steady.[Colloq. U.S.]
An instrument for indicating and recording shocks to railwaycars occasioned by sudden stopping.
A base resembling and isomeric with conine, and obtained as acolorless liquid from butyric aldehyde and ammonia.
A nodule of flint, or a pebble, which resembles a fig. [Obs.]
The movable part of a stuffing box by which the packing iscompressed; -- sometimes called a follower. See Illust. of Stuffingbox, under Stuffing.
A colorless liquid, C6H4,OCH3.OH, resembling the phenols, foundas a constituent of woodtar creosote, aud produced by the drydistillation of guaiac resin.
An extinct genus of marine reptiles allied to Plesiosaurus, buthaving a much shorter neck.
Depression occasioned by terror; dismay. [Obs.] Bacon.

To have secretly a joint part or share in an action; to playinto each other's hands; to conspire; to act in concert.If they let things take their course, they will be represented ascolluding with sedition. Burke.
One who hinders progress; one who obstructs business, as in alegislative body.-- a.
An instrument which exhibits objects with their proper reliefreversed; -- an effect opposite to that produced by the stereoscope.Wheatstone.
One who exasperates or inflames anger, enmity, or violence.

An officer whose business was to denounce or proclaim war, tochallenge to battle, to proclaim peace, and to bear messages from thecommander of an army. He was invested with a sacred and inviolablecharacter.
Seaweed; esp., coarse seaweed. See Ware, and Sea girdles.
A plant, Globularia Alypum, a violent purgative, found inAfrica.
A small due, in meal, established by usage, which is paid tothe under miller. [Scot.]
A person who is not of full age, or who has not attained theage of legal capacity; a person under the age of twenty-one years; aminor.
Any revolving contrivance for affording amusement; esp., a ringof flying hobbyhorses.
A colorless liquid hydrocarbon, having a garlic odor; heptine.
To contend in law litigiously or cavilously. [Obs.]
A description of sculpture such as bas-relief in metal.
The condition of being flaggy; laxity; limberness. Johnson.
Having the spores contained in a case; -- applied to fungi.

In the modern Olympic Games, a composite contest consisting ofa 100-meter run, a broad jump, putting the shot, a running high-jump,a 400-meter run, throwing the discus, a 100-meter hurdle race, polevaulting, throwing the javelin, and a 1500-meter run.
A contract or convention between Spain and other powers forfurnishing negro slaves for the Spanish dominions in America, esp.the contract made with Great Britain in 1713.
Situated behind the glenoid fossa of the temporal bone.
A celebrated Egyptian statue near Thebes, said to have theproperty of emitting a harplike sound at sunrise.
Soft material lying between the wall of a vein aud the solidvein. Raymond.
A transfer of meaning in a word or phrase, a metaphor; atralation. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
One who advocates the doctrine of pessimism; -- opposed to Ant:optimist.
To let; to hinder. See Let, to hinder. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A large stone reaching through a wall so as to appear on bothsides of it, and acting as a binder; -- called also perbend, perpendstone, and perpent stone.
Act or process of syndicating or forming a syndicate.
Confinement within narrow limits, -- as of foreign troops, tothe interior of a country.
An unfermentable sugar, isomeric with glucose, found in theripe berries of the rowan tree, or sorb, and extracted as a sweetwhite crystalline substance; -- called also mountain-ash sugar.
To consume or reduce to ashes by burning, as a dead body; tocremate.
A package of gold beater's skins in which gold is subjected tothe second process of beating.
Up to this time; hitherto; before; in time past. Shak.
An instrument for measuring the rate of evaporation from amoist surface; an evaporometer. Huxley.

A species of the genus Bos or Bubalus (B. bubalus), originallyfrom India, but now found in most of the warmer countries of theeastern continent. It is larger and less docile than the common ox,and is fond of marshy places and rivers.
The art or process of producing or gauging a plane surface.
A tribe of sea birds comprising the petrels, shearwaters,albatrosses, hagdons, and allied birds having tubular horny nostrils.
A strong flat bar of iron, so bent as to support, as in astirrup, one end of a floor timber, etc., where no sufficient bearingcan be had; -- called also stirrup and hanger.
In an initial or incipient manner or degree; at the beginning.Barrow.
The state of consisting of monosyllables, or having amonosyllabic form; frequent occurrence of monosyllables.
A plate which supports the labrum in certain Crustacea.
A harbor on the east coast of Australia, and an English convictsettlement there; -- so called from the number of new plants found onits shore at its discovery by Cook in 1770.
To repeat the distillation of, pouring the liquor back upon thematter remaining in the vessel. Arbuthnot.
The act of hereticating or pronouncing heretical. London Times.
Of or pertaining to Assyria, or to its inhabitants.-- n. A native or an inhabitant of Assyria; the language of Assyria.
Counselor at law; a counsel admitted to plead at the bar, andundertake the public trial of causes, as distinguished from anattorney or solicitor. See Attorney. [Eng.]
Filled with hommocks; piled in the form of hommocks; -- said ofice.
One who lays informations, and encourages petty lawsuits.[Obs.] Bacon.
A public establishment for the storage, or for the manufactureand storage, of arms and all military equipments, whether for land ornaval service.
The finishing of any face of a wall with material differentfrom that of which it is chiefly composed, or the coating or materialso used.
Pert. to or designating heat rays that have undergone selectiveabsorption and are therefore analogous to colored light rays.
The right or duty of a patron; patronage. [R.] Westm. Rev.
To open the seam or seams of; to rip; to cut; to cut open.Shak.
A lifting or rising; a swell; a panting or deep sighing.Addison. Shak.
The act or process of subliming, or the state or result ofbeing sublimed.
An affected elegance or euphuism of style, for which theSpanish poet Gongora y Argote (1561-1627), among others of his time,was noted.
The act of softening by mixing with a thinner substance; theformation of ingredients into a mass for pills or plasters. [R.]
In water-color painting, work in, or a work done chiefly in,washes, as distinguished from that done in stipple, in body color,etc.
A golf club like the iron, but with a shorter head, slightlymore lofted, used chiefly for short approaches.
To divide into two branches; to cause to branch apart.
The root of Spigelia Marilandica, used as a powerful vermifuge;also, that of S. Anthelmia. See definition 2 (below).
A slattern; an idle, sluttish, or untidy woman. [Obs. orColloq.]
Hanging down at the side; limp; drooping; without firmness orshapeliness; moving in an ungainly manner.
Divination by serpents, as by their manner of eating, or bytheir coils.
Color blindness; inability to distinguish colors; Daltonism.
A tasteless, yellow, crystalline substance, obtained from thegentian; -- called also gentianin.
The pore or opening leading into the cavity of invagination, orarchenteron.
The cob or axis on which the kernels of Indian corn grow.[U.S.]
Absence or closure of a natural passage or channel of the body;imperforation.
Producing decomposition, as diseases which are supposed to beaccompanied or caused by decomposition.
Careful consideration; pondering. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
To go back; to retrograde, as the apsis of a planet's orbit.[R.] Todhunter.
Designating a method of shaft excavation by drifting to a pointbelow, and then raising instead of sinking.
A muslin wrapper for the head and the lower part of the face,worn by Turkish and Armenian women when they go abroad.
A plant growing entirely in the air, and receiving itsnourishment from it; an air plant or epiphyte.
The exhaust pipe of a steam engine, or any pipe deliveringsteam or air, when so constructed as to cause a blast.
A solution of alkaline salts extracted from wood ashes; hence,any solution obtained by lixiviation.
A bulkhead on the forecastle and half deck of a ship.
An instrument for ascertaining the weight and purity of oil; anelaiometer.
One who has the use of anything in trust for another. [Obs.]Daniel.
To graft by cutting the scion and stock in a certain manner.See Whip grafting, under Grafting.
An imaginary speech or discussion between two or more;dialogue. Fulke.
One who obscures; one who prevents enlightenment or hinders theprogress of knowledge and wisdom. Coleridge.
To join, as the electrodes of a battery or dynamo or any twopoints of a circuit, by a conductor of low resistance.
An openwork frame on which vessels are placed for examination,cleaning, and repairs. 3. (Sport)
A fine kind of French cotton goods, usually of one color.
Having the quality of not being impressed or affected; notsusceptible.
An organic base obtained from quinoline. It is used as afebrifuge, and resembles kairine.
To stop (a leak in a ship at sea) by drawing under its bottom athrummed sail, so that the pressure of the water may force it intothe crack. Totten.

A follower of the Count de St. Simon, who died in 1825, and whomaintained that the principle of property held in common, and thejust division of the fruits of common labor among the members ofsociety, are the true remedy for the social evils which exist. Brande& C.
The science of the universe, and the relations which itinvolves.
Relating to acceleration; adding to velocity; quickening. Reid.
Not perceiving, or not able to perceive. A. Baxter.
A genus of violaceous plants, chiefly found in tropicalAmerica, some species of which are used as substitutes foripecacuanha.
Courage without sense or judgment; foolish rashness;recklessness. Dryden.
A piece of ground between the wall of a place and the moat.Farrow.
A mass or stratum of fragments or rock lying under thealluvium, and derived from the neighboring rock. Lyell.
A leguminous shrub of southern Europe, with trifoliate leaves(Anagyris foetida).
Not apprehensive; regardless; unconcerned. Jer. Taylor.
In an audacious manner; with excess of boldness; impudently.
To refurnish with a voice; to refit, as an organ pipe, so as torestore its tone.
Twisted; bent; -- said of a dolphin haurient, which forms afigure like the letter S.
To make like an angel; to angelize. [Obs.] Farindon (1647).
Germinating inside the pericarp, as the mangrove. Brande & C.
Of or pertaining to roads; happening on roads. [Obs.]
One who makes widows by destroying husbands. [R.] Shak.
Heathy; abounding in heather; of the nature of heath.
Interlaced; linked together; -- said of charges or bearings.See Fretted.
(a) One who abates a nuisance. (b) A person who, without right,enters into a freehold on the death of the last possessor, before theheir or devisee. Blackstone.
Generally or popularly admitted or received. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
A trifoliate plant used as a national emblem by the Irish. Thelegend is that St. Patrick once plucked a leaf of it for use inillustrating the doctrine of the trinity.
Hatred of, or dislike to, mankind; -- opposed to philanthropy.Orrery.
A peculiar rounded granule of some mineral, usually enstatiteor chrysolite, found imdedded more or less aboundantly in the mass ofmany meteoric stones, which are hence called chondrites.
A dark resinous substance, polymeric with indol, and obtainedby the reduction of indigo white.
Equality of condition, blood, or dignity; also, equality in thepartition of an inheritance. Spelman.
A duty or tax paid by merchants for the protection of theirconnerce by means of a consul in a foreign place.
A joint of the cirri of the Crinoidea; a joint or segment of anarthropod appendage.
A mineral occurring in small, green, transparent, monocliniccrystals. It is a hydrous phosphate of iron.
The branchiostegal membrane. See Illustration in Appendix.

A large extent or precinct of country, generally waste andwoody, belonging to the sovereign, set apart for the keeping of gamefor his use, not inclosed, but distinguished by certain limits, andprotected by certain laws, courts, and officers of its own. Burrill.
Of or pertaining to manipulation; performed by manipulation.
Given to viewing one's self in a glass or mirror; finical.[Poetic] Shak.
The modes or scales used in ancient church music. SeeGregorian.

A human skull reported, by Prof. J. D. Whitney, as found in1886 in a Tertiary auriferous gravel deposit, lying below a bed ofblack lava, in Calaveras County, California. It is regarded as verydoubtful whether the skull really belonged to the deposit in which itwas found. If it did, it indicates an unprecedented antiquity forhuman beings of an advanced type.
That part of the alimentary canal between the stomach and theanus. See Illust. of Digestive apparatus.
One who, or that which, extinguishes; esp., a hollow cone orother device for extinguishing a flame, as of a torch or candle.
One who fakes something, as a thief, a peddler of petty things,a workman who dresses things up, etc. [Slang]
A kind of Italian pressed milk cheese; -- so called from avillage near Milan.
A Chinese provincial tax levied at many inland stations uponimports or articles in transit.
A genus of Infusoria which form minute vaselike or tubularcases in which they dwell.
One of the two ecclesiastics allowed to attend a cardinal inthe conclave.
The state of being deplored or deplorable. [R.] Bp. Hail.
Native sulphide of manganese a reddish brown or brownish blackmineral.
Divination by observing the objects offered in sacrifice.
An instrument for cutting into the urethra so as to enlarge itsorifice.
An instrument resembling the organ in tine and the uprightpiano in form. It is characterized by great strength and sweetness oftone.

a small thrush (Turdus pilaris) which breeds in northern Europeand winters in Great Britain. The head, nape, and lower part of theback are ash-colored; the upper part of the back and wing coverts,chestnut; -- called also fellfare.
Containing more alcohol than proof spirit; stronger than proofspirit; that is, containing more than 49.3 per cent by weight ofalcohol.
The spur-winged goose; -- so called from the red circle aroundthe eyes.
The subclass of Mammalia which includes the marsupials. SeeMarsupialia.
The quality of being despicable; meanness; vileness;worthlessness.
The act of killing, or one who kills, a giant. Hallam.
A digression in which a person is introduced speaking his ownwords.
An arrow or bolt for a crossbow having feathers or brass placedat an angle with the shaft to make it spin in flying.

An instrument for determining the torque on a shaft, and hencethe horse power of an engine, esp. of a marine engine of high power,by measuring the amount of twist of a given length of the shaft.Called also torsimeter, torsiometer, torsometer.
Apt to censure or cavil; faultfinding; captious. [Obs.]Whitlock.
An east Indian wood of a reddish orange color, handsomelyveined with darker marks. It is occasionally used for cabinetwork.Ure.
Sudden diminution or loss of consciousness, sensation, andvoluntary motion, usually caused by pressure on the brain.
The posterior horn of each lateral ventricle of the brain. B.G. Wilder.
The quality or condition of being salable; salableness. Duke ofArgyll.

An accumulation of liquid within the cavity of the cranium,especially within the ventricles of the brain; dropsy of the brain.It is due usually to tubercular meningitis. When it occurs ininfancy, it often enlarges the head enormously.
Depopulation; destruction of population. [R.] Chapman.
White and black; -- said of a white animal of a black species,or the albino of the negro race.
The quality of being damnable; damnableness. Sir T. More.
A publication issued once in seven days, or appearing once aweek.
A term suggested by Haeckel to be instead of serial homology.See Homotype.
Perfect in what is undertaken; complete; going all lengths; as,a thoroughplaced Tory or Whig.If she be a thoroughplaced impostor. Sir W. Scott.
Hard steel, usually crucible steel, capable of being temperedso as to be suitable for tools.
Private interest; the interest or advantage of one's self.
An instrument for measuring the variations in size of theinternal organs of the body, as the kidney, spleen, etc.
Of or pertaining to the gallows, or to execution. [R.] Carlyle.
Tears; also, lachrymal feelings or organs. [Colloq.]
Having breasts; of, pertaining to, or derived from, theMammalia.
The last reef in a fore-and-aft sail, taken to steady the ship.

Any of various bodies or substances in the blood which act inantagonism to harmful foreign bodies, as toxins or the bacteriaproducing the toxins. Normal blood serum apparently containsvariousantibodies, and the introduction of toxins or of foreign cellsalso results in the development of their specific antibodies.
Having a downcast countenance; dejected; gloomy; sullen. [R.]Dryden.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the plant acanthus.
Sorrowful; wretched; full of trouble. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To link together; to join, as one chain to another. Dryden.

A common, large, handsome, American swallowtail butterfly, nowregarded as one of the forms of Papilio, or Jasoniades, glaucus. Thewings are yellow, margined and barred with black, and with an orange-red spot near the posterior angle of the hind wings. Called alsotiger swallowtail. See Illust. under Swallowtail.
In Holland, and, until the 19th century, also in Cape Colony, acouncil to assist a local magistrate in the government of ruraldistricts; hence, also, a member of such a council.
A division of the Cetacea, including the right whale and allother whales having the mouth fringed with baleen. See Baleen.
Having the shape of a widemouthed bell; campanulate.
Graphite, or black lead, often used on the bottoms of racingvessels to diminish friction.
A device for recording the amount of cash received, usuallyhaving an automatic adding machine and a money drawer and exhibitingthe amount of the sale.
A genus of American and Asiatic trees, with aromatic bark andlarge sweet-scented whitish or reddish flowers.
A contrivance for recording the revolutions of a wheel, as of abicycle.
Any corporation formed for the purpose of acting as trustee.Such companies usually do more or less of a banking business.
Any one of a series of artificial ethereal salts derived fromthe alkaloidal base tropine.
Alluring; attractive; enticing. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
Of or pertaining to a natural order of plants, of which theviolet is the type. It contains about twenty genera and two hundredand fifty species.
A woman who practices unlawful sexual commerce with men,especially one who prostitutes her body for hire; a prostitute; aharlot. Wyclif.
A blue coloring matter found in some stentors. See Stentor, 2.
A relater of stories; an historian. [Obs.] Bp. Peacock.
The upper, contrary-moving current of the atmosphere over amonsoon.
One who, or that which, cleanses; a detergent. Arbuthnot.
The satirical or ribald poetry of the Goliards. Milman.
That which serves as a reminder; a remembrancer; a memento; akeepsake.
Charged with vair; variegated with shield-shaped figures. SeeVair.
Bastardlike; baseborn; spuripous; corrupt. [Obs.] -- adv.
The plain semidome of an apse; sometimes used for the entireapse.
An opening made in the interior walls of a cruciform church toafford a view of the altar to those in the transepts; -- called, inarchitecture, a squint. Hook.
A circular ornament, resembling a dish, often worked in reliefon friezes, and the like.
A cutaneous, pustular eruption, not attended with fever;usually, a kind of eczema with pustulation.

A leader of a choir; a directing singer. Specifically:(a) The leader of the choir in a cathedral; -- called also thechanter or master of the choir. Hook.(b) The leader of the congregational singing in Scottish and otherchurches.
To unfold; to undo; to ravel, as what has been woven.
The practice or habit of frequenting. [R.] Southey.
The siliceous shell of a diatom. It is composed of two valves,one overlapping the other, like a pill box and its cover.
A word or phrase used in conversation; a colloqualism.
The business of one who spins; spinning. [Obs.] Milton.
An extensive group of echinoderms, comprising the starfishesand ophiurans.
A tool for turning screws so as to drive them into their place.It has a thin end which enters the nick in the head of the screw.
A spark produced by the jumping of electricity across apermanent gap.
Having three petals, or flower leaves; three-petaled.
The bindings of a hedge. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
Capable of being paralleled, or equaled. [R.] Bp. Hall.
Not perplexed; having a mind free from care. Bacon.
An optical toy; a card on which confused or imperfect figuresare drawn, but which form to the eye regular figures when the card israpidly revolved. See Thaumatrope.
The business of a housewife; female domestic economy and skill.Tusser.
Divination by the letters of a name; nomancy. [R.] Camden.
Of or pertaining to Northumberland in England.-- n.
To release from a charm, fascination, or secret power; todisenchant. Beau. & Fl.
Situated the farthest towards the west; most western.
An American shrub (Symphoricarpus occidentalis) which bearssoft white berries.
The perception attendant upon the movements of the muscles.Bastian.
The matter of which the philosopher's stone was believed to becomposed.

A genus of flowering plants having elegant drooping flowers,with four sepals, four petals, eight stamens, and a single pistil.They are natives of Mexico and South America. Double-floweredvarieties are now common in cultivation.
The nutritive zooids of a hydroid, collectively, asdistinguished from the gonosome, or reproductive zooids.
Any one of numerous species of soft-bodied Anthozoa, belongingto the order Actrinaria; an actinian.
An officer whose duty is to provide quarters, provisions,storage, clothing, fuel, stationery, and transportation for aregiment or other body of troops, and superintend the supplies.
One who vents; one who utters, reports, or publishes. [R.]Barrow.
Being of the nature of soap; soapy; cleansing; detersive.
A malignant growth containing epithelial cells; -- called alsoepithelial cancer.
A genus of leguminous shrubby plants and herbs, mostly found intropical countries, a few herbaceous species being North American.The foliage is often ashy-pubescent, whence the name.
A coarse umbelliferous weed of the genus Heracleum (H.sphondylium in England, and H. lanatum in America).
One who makes a trust; -- the correlative of trustee.
Plaiting or joining together; -- said of a bone next above thequadrate in the mandibular suspensorium of many fishes, which unitestogether the other bones of the suspensorium.-- n.
Pertaining to the Cimbri, an ancient tribe inhabiting NorthernGermany.-- n.
A warming cathartic medicine, made of aloes and canella bark.Dunglison.
Eaten into, defaced, or worn, by exposure to the weather.Coleridge.
A wagon or cart, usually heavy and without springs, and oftencovered. [Oriental]
A subdivision of the Primordial or Cambrian period in Americangeology; -- so named from the sandstone of Potsdam, New York. SeeChart of Geology.
A key split at one end like a split pin, for the same purpose.
A genus of monkeys, found in Asia and the East Indies. Theyhave short tails and prominent eyebrows.
One who gropes; one who feels his way in the dark, or searchesby feeling.
A kind of sleeping car; also, a palace car; -- often shortenedto Pullman.
Act of bringing down; depravation; deterioration. South.
Of or pertaining to ancient Idumea, or Edom, in Western Asia.-- n.
An unfermentable sugar of the pentose class, C5H10O5, formed bythe hydrolysis of xylan; wood sugar.
A rare mineral, occurring crystallized and in cleavable masses,usually white, or nearly so, in color. It is a silicate of aluminiaand lithia.
A movable parapet, serving to support fascines to coverpioneers. [Obs.]

Belonging to, or characteristic of, a system of elementaryeducation which combined manual training with other instruction,advocated and practiced by Jean Henri Pestalozzi (1746-1827), a Swissteacher.-- n.
That which is to supply what is wanted.Invent suppletories to excuse an evil man. Jer. Taylor.

Any small square or quadrangular member; as:(a) A square of glass, esp. when set diagonally.(b) A small opening in window tracery, of which the cusps, etc., makethe form nearly square.(c) A square or lozenge-shaped paving tile.
A phenol derivative of anthracene obtained as a whitecrystalline substance, which on oxidation produces a red dyestuffrelated to anthraquinone.
Having the same bounds; conterminous. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A national bank not in a reserve city. [Colloq., U. S.]
Of or pertaining to Hibernia, now Ireland; Irish.-- n.
A lazy or cowardly person; a rascal. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Half or partially ligneous, as a stem partly woody and partlyherbaceous.
The skin of a deer, or the leather which is made from it.Hakluyt. Longfellow.
A marine European fish (Crenilabrus melops); also, the relatedAmerican cunner. See Cunner.
To deaden the sound of (bells) by muffling the clapper.
Pertaining to oratorical expression. [Obs.] Feltham.
One who has charge of the baggage at a railway station or upona line of public travel. [U.S.]
The act or business of stealing or kidnaping human beings,especially with a view to e
A beautiful American ascidian (Cynthia, or Halocynthia,pyriformis) having the size, form, velvety surface, and color of aripe peach.
A man who is engaged in quarrying stones; a quarrier.

Any money, bullion, or the like, found in the earth, orotherwise hidden, the owner of which is not known. In England suchtreasure belongs to the crown; whereas similar treasure found in thesea, or upon the surface of the land, belongs to the finder if noowner appears.
A division of sponges including those which have independentsiliceous spicules.

The path by which electricity is conveyed into or from asolution or other conducting medium; esp., the ends of the wires orconductors, leading from source of electricity, and terminating inthe medium traversed by the current.
The acid amide derived from malic acid, as a white crystallinesubstance metameric with asparagine.
To celebrate loudly; to extol; to praise. [Obs.]In fable, hymn, or song so personating Their gods ridiculous. Milton.
Small hard yellowish aggregations found in the Caucasus region,and containing various yeasts and bacteria. They are used as aferment in preparing kefir.
Not swearing allegiance; -- applied to the party in GreatBritain that would not swear allegiance to William and Mary, or theirsuccessors.
The giant cactus (Cereus giganteus); -- so named by the Indiansof Arizona. Called also saguaro.
Pertaining to, or derived from, fat. The word was formerly usedspecifically to designate a supposed acid obtained by the oxidationof oleic acid, tallow, wax, etc.
Hatred of argument or discussion; hatred of enlightenment. G.H. Lewes.
A custom, as in some ancient boroughs, by which lands andtenements descend to the youngest son, instead of the eldest; or, ifthe owner have no issue, to the youngest brother. Blackstone.
To leap over or across; hence, to omit; to ignore. "Let meo'erleap that custom." Shak.
An herbaceous grasslike plant (Triglochin palustre, and otherspecies) with pods opening so as to suggest barbed arrowheads.
A district or local division, as of a province. [India]
A white, bitter, crystallizable substance, obtained fromcoffee. It is identical with the alkaloid theine from tea leaves, andwith guaranine from guarana.
A skullcap covering the tonsure, worn under the berretta. Thepope's is white; a cardinal's red; a bishop's purple; a priest'sblack.
A European composite herb (Centaurea nigra); -- so called fromthe resemblance of its knobbed head to an iron ball fixed on a longhandle. Dr. Prior.
The state of being relative, or having relation; relativity.
A lantern having a lamp surrounded by a hollow cylindricalFresnel lens.
Capable of living; born alive and with such form anddevelopment of organs as to be capable of living; -- said of anewborn, or a prematurely born, infant.
A contrivance for measuring a supply of water delivered orreceived for any purpose, as from a street main.
A small South American species of tiger cat (Felis mitis).

Correspondence or relation in type of structure incontradistinction to similarity of function; as, the relation instructure between the leg and arm of a man; or that between the armof a man, the fore leg of a horse, the wing of a bird, and the fin ofa fish, all these organs being modifications of one type ofstructure.
Soft; -- a direction to the performer to execute a certainpassage softly, and with diminished volume of tone. (Abbrev. p.)
A device for saving power in stopping and starting a railroadcar, by means of a heavy fly wheel.
That branch of botanical science which relates to the musgroomsand other fungi.
Not capable of being extirpated or rooted out; ineradicable.
A game, usually played indoors, in which two parties of playerscontest with each other to toss a large inflated ball into oppositegoals resembling baskets.
One who propagates; one who continues or multiplies.
In the form of a globe or sphere; -- applied to nebulous mattercollected into a sphere by the force of gravitation.
A split of a sheepskin; one of the thin sections made bysplitting a sheepskin with a cutting knife or machine.
Counteracting, or deemed of use in, diseases of the kidneys.-- n.

An alkaline salt of fluorescein, obtained as a brownish redsubstance, which is used as a dye; -- so called from the peculiaryellowish green fluorescence (resembling that of uranium glass) ofits solutions. See Fluorescein.
To remove the dullness of; to clear. [Obs.] Whitlock.
An odd thing, or one that is left over, disconnected,fragmentary, or the like; something that is separated or disconnectedfrom its fellows; esp. (in pl.),

An instrument consisting of a thin metal frame, through whichpassed a number of metal rods, and furnished with a handle by whichit was shaken and made to rattle. It was peculiarly Egyptian, andused especially in the worship of Isis. It is still used in Nubia.
To top off; to finish by putting on a cap of top (uppermost)course (called a top`ping-out" course).
The person to whom a surrender is made. Mozley & W.
To mistake in remembering; not to remember correctly. Sir T.More.
A defect in pronouncing the letter m, or a too frequent use ofit.
A clear soup or bouillion boiled down so as to be very rich.
Pertaining to, or designating, a variety of tannin or tannicacid found in Acacia, Mimosa, etc.
The quality or state of being unwary; carelessness;heedlessness.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by thedistillation of terebic acid, and homologous with citraconic acid.
A queer old fellow; an old chap; an old woman. [Contemptuous,Slang or Dial.]
The double bassoon, an octave deeper than the bassoon.
As much or as many as a ship will hold; enough to fill a ship.
One of the ropes or chains serving as stays for the dolphinstriker or the bowsprit; -- called also gobrope and gaubline.
A product of gastric digestion intermediate between albumin andpeptone, identical with hemialbumose.
A cuirassier or cuirassiers; also, hardy veteran soldiers; --applied specifically to Cromwell's cavalry.
A young German noble or squire; esp., a member of thearistocratic party in Prussia.
One who favors the use or establishment of silver as a monetarystandard; -- so called by those who favor the gold standard. [Colloq.or Cant]
With great violence; with a slamming or banging noise.[Colloq.]
An instrument for determining and registering the duration ofmore or less complex operations of the mind. Dunglison.
A brush of feathers, bristles, or hair, for removing dust fromfurniture.
A glass show case for displaying fine wares, specimens, etc.
The common title of honor in Persia, prefixed to the surname ofan individual. When appended to the surname, it signifies Prince.
One who gilds; one whose occupation is to overlay with gold.
A trespass; a wrong done; the improper doing of an act which aperson might lawfully do. Bouvier. Wharton.
The quality or state of being orthodox; orthodoxy. Waterland.
A light, spongy, cylindrical cake, used for breakfast and tea.
An alkaloid extracted from jaborandi (Pilocarpus pennatifolius)as a white amorphous or crystalline substance which has a peculiareffect on the vasomotor system.
To become thinner; to make excuses; to advance palliatingconsiderations. Burke.
A white crystalline substance, C6H4(OH)2, obtained by thereduction of quinone. It is a diacid phenol, resembling, andmetameric with, pyrocatechin and resorcin. Called also dihydroxybenzene.

Of, pertaining to, or designating, the view or doctrine thatexisting causes, acting in the same manner and with essentially thesame intensity as at the present time, are sufficient to account forall geological changes.
The act of turning or diverting any disease from one part ofthe body to another. It resembles derivation, but is usually appliedto a more active form of counter irritation.
A raised way or foot bank, running along the inside of aparapet, on which musketeers stand to fire upon the enemy.
A waste weir for a canal, discharging into a lock chamber.
To adorn; to grace; to honor; to make becoming, appropriate, orhonorable. [Obs.] Abp. Sandys.
Having the mandibular arch articulated with the hyoid arch andthe cranium, as in the cestraciont sharks; -- said of a skull.
A genus of mollusks, including the cowries. See Cowrie.

That branch of logic which teaches the rules and modes ofreasoning; the application of logical principles to discursivereasoning; the science or art of discriminating truth from error;logical discussion.
The quality of being sanguine; sanguineness. Swift.
An earthwork; a mound; a raised work. [Obs.] Hearne.
The act or process or freeing from hydrogen; also, thecondition resulting from the removal of hydrogen.
Chopped meat stuffed into small bags of tripe. They are cut inslices and fried. [Local, New York]
A machine of great antiquity, used in Bengal for raising waterto irrigate land. Knight.
A white variety of amphibole, or hornblende, occurring in long,bladelike crystals, and coarsely fibrous masses.
A genus of plants of the Ranunculus or Crowfoot family;windflower. Some of the species are cultivated in gardens.
A traversing base frame, or movable railway, along which thecarriage of a barbette or casemate gum moves backward and forward.[See Gun carriage.]
Having the power to beget; generative. Sir M. Hale.
Copper wire with a strong but light insulation, used in wiringhouses, etc.
An instrument for measuring in volts the differences ofpotential between different points of an electrical circuit.
A genus of birds that comprises the white-eyes. See White-eye.
The application of chemical tests to minute objects or portionsof matter, magnified by the use of the microscopy; -- distinguishedfrom macro-chemistry.

A Spanish mode of execution by strangulation, with an ironcollar affixed to a post and tightened by a screw until life becomeextinct; also, the instrument by means of which the punishment isinflicted.
A divinity of the modern Hindoo trimurti, or trinity. He isregarded as the preserver, while Brahma is the creator, and Siva thedestroyer of the creation.
To observe and study the physiognomy of. [R.] Southey.
A real or fancied bristling of the hair of the head or body,resulting from disease, terror, chilliness, etc.
A bunch of odorous and showy flowers; a bouquet; a posy. Pope.
The state of being absent; withdrawal. [R.] Barrow.
The act or process of refining gold or silver, etc., in acupel.
The skin or coat of a seed, especially the outer coat. SeeTesta.
A household servant; also, one of the bodyguard of King Canute.

An instrument for studying the motions of sounding bodies byoptical means. It consists of a tube across the end of which isstretched a film of soap solution thin enough to give colored bands,the form and position of which are affected by sonorous vibrations.
Any one of several species of large, long-legged sandpipersbelonging to the genus Totanus.
Such as may be presumed or supposed to be true; that seemsentitled to belief without direct evidence.
The act of deceiving one's self, or the state of being self-deceived; self-deception.
Not having redress; such as can not be redressed; irremediable.Sherwood.
Relating to the foot, or to a metrical foot; pedal. [R.]Maunder.
Sought for; demanded. [R.] Summary on Du Bartas (1621).

A wheel with a broad rim, or grooved rim, for transmittingpower from, or imparting power to, the different parts of machinery,or for changing the direction of motion, by means of a belt, cord,rope, or chain.
The state of acquiring or having an excess of fibrin.
Having two teeth or two toothlike processes; two-toothed.
A large ironbound block strapped with a hook, and, when used,hung to an eyebolt in the cap, -- used in swaying and lowering thetopmast. Totten.
The science of calculating nativities, or predicting the futureevents of life from the stars which preside at birth. Jhonson.
Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the cranium; facial.
A follower of Henry Barrowe, one of the founders ofIndependency or Congregationalism in England. Barrowe was executedfor nonconformity in 1953.
An incorrect union of parties or of causes of action in aprocedure, criminal or civil. Wharton.
A woodpecker; -- called also specht, spekt, spight. [Obs. orProv. Eng.]
