The germ history of the functions, or the history of thedevelopment of vital activities, in the individual, being one of thebranches of ontogeny. See Morphogeny. Haeckel.
A kind of gilt leather. See Checklaton. [Obs.] Spenser.
To unite by twining one with another; to entangle; tointerlace. Milton.
A coarse grass found on sandy beaches (Ammophila arundinacea).See Beach grass, under Beach.
The act or process of separating mingled gases of unequaldiffusibility by transmission through porous substances.

The zone lying between the Boreal and Sonoran zones of NorthAmerica. It includes an eastern or humid subdivision and a westernarid one of corresponding temperature comprising the northern GreatPlains and the lower slopes of the mountains of the western UnitedStates and Mexico. Called also Neutral zone.

A Malayan fruit produced by the tree Nephelium lappaceum, andclosely related to the litchi nut. It is bright red, oval in shape,covered with coarse hairs (whence the name), and contains a pleasantacid pulp. Called also ramboostan.
A white, amorphous, tenacious substance resembling caoutchouc,and obtained as an insoluble residue of mastic.
For the greatest part; for the most part; chiefly; in the main.
Electrically polarized like the surface of the zinc presentedto the acid in a battery, which has zincous affinity. [Obs.]

A case containing powder to be exploded, esp. a conical orcylindrical case of metal filled with powder and attached to a plank,to be exploded against and break down gates, barricades, drawbridges,etc. It has been superseded.
In a triangular manner; in the form of a triangle. Dampier.
Beneath the scapula, or shoulder blade; subscapular.
To wander about; to saunter; to talk incoherently. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
Having an undivided, horny, bootlike covering; -- said of thetarsus of some birds.
Crafty, unfair, or underhand dealing; unfair practice;trickery. Milton.
To convert to the religion of Mohammed; to Mohammedanize.
Mottled pottery made from scraps of differently colored clays.
One who is lord over another or others; a superior lord; amaster. Freeman.
An herbaceous or woody stem which bears leaves, and may bearflowers.
A textualist; a textman. [Obs.]The crabbed textualists of his time. Milton.
To wrench; to tear; to sprain; to injure by violent strainingor contortion. [R.] Dryden. "Hasting to raunch the arrow out."Spenser.
A toxic alkaloid (ptomaine) obtained from putrid flesh and fromherring brines. As a poison it is said to execute profuse diarrhoea,vomiting, and intestinal inflammation. Brieger.
A coating or covering resembling ice, as of sugar and milk orwhite of egg; frosting.

A vessel propelled by oars, whether having masts and sails ornot; as:(a) A large vessel for war and national purposes; -- common in theMiddle Ages, and down to the 17th century.(b) A name given by analogy to the Greek, Roman, and other ancientvessels propelled by oars.(c) A light, open boat used on the Thames by customhouse officers,press gangs, and also for pleasure.(d) One of the small boats carried by a man-of-war.
One who advocates polyarchy; -- opposed to monarchist.Cudworth.

The earth alumina, as found native in a crystalline state,including sapphire, which is the fine blue variety; the orientalruby, or red sapphire; the oriental amethyst, or purple sapphire; andadamantine spar, the hair-brown variety. It is the hardest substancefound native, next to the diamond.
A foot of three syllables, the middle one short and the otherslong, as in cast. Andrews.
A large Mediterranean food fish (Umbrina cirrhosa): -- calledalso umbra, and umbrine.
A boy's play, called also fivepenny morris. See Morris.
Capability of being contracted; quality of being contractible;as, the contractibiliy and dilatability of air. Arbuthnot.
A shop where any manufacture or handiwork is carried on.
A small membranous bladder or tube in which are inclosed theseedlike reproductive particles or sporules of lichens and certainfungi.
A kind of laminated shale or sandstone belonging to some of thelayers of the Upper Silurian.
To render capable; to enable; to qualify.By thih instruction we may be capaciated to observe those errors.Dryden.
The process of becoming white, or developing white patches, orstreaks.

A medley or mixture. Specifically:(a) A ragout composed of different sorts of meats, vegetables, etc.,cooked together.(b) A jar or packet of flower leaves, perfumes, and spices, used toscent a room.(c) A piece of music made up of different airs strung together; amedley.(d) A literary production composed of parts brought together withoutorder or bond of connection.

Formerly, a man hired to work by the day; now, commonly, onewho has mastered a handicraft or trade; -- distinguished fromapprentice and from master workman.I have thought some of nature's journeymen had made men, and not madethem well. Shak.
The Oregon grape, a species of barberry (Berberis Aquifolium),often cultivated for its hollylike foliage.
An assistant to the ship's cook in washing, steeping, andshifting the salt provisions.
A prominence on the lower posterior portion of the concha ofthe external ear, opposite the tragus. See Ear.
An improvement of an estate which renders it better than mererepairing would do; -- generally used in the plural. [U. S.] Bouvier.

A large, thick, clumsy, marine fish (Cyclopterus lumpus) ofEurope and America. The color is usually translucent sea green,sometimes purplish. It has a dorsal row of spiny tubercles, and threerows on each side, but has no scales. The ventral fins unite and forma ventral sucker for adhesion to stones and seaweeds. Called alsolumpsucker, cock-paddle, sea owl.
Having undulations like waves; -- said of one of the lines inheraldry which serve as outlines to the ordinaries, etc.

A disease, characterized by difficulty of breathing (due to aspasmodic contraction of the bronchi), recurring at intervals,accompanied with a wheezing sound, a sense of constriction in thechest, a cough, and expectoration.
One who has narrowly escaped the gallows for his crimes.[Colloq.] Dickens.
A quantity greater than any assignable quantity of the samekind.
A large flatboat, used in the West Indies for taking freightfrom shore to ship.
In an adventurous manner; venturesomely; boldly; daringly.
A large heart-shaped cherry, either black, red, or white.
Paper coated with starch and potassium iodine. It turns bluewhen exposed to ozone.>-- also called starch-iodide paper -->
A species of tetanus, in which the body is curved laterally.Quain. Dunglison.
A genus of cetaceans having a long, pointed, bony beak, usuallytwo tusklike teeth in the lower jaw, but no teeth in the upper jaw.
One to, or for, whom anything is reserved; -- contrasted withreservor.
An instrument for detecting and measuring the amount of carbonwhich is present, or more esp. the amount of carbon dioxide, by itsaction on limewater or by other means.
An attendant at a theater who has charge of the boxes.
With the flat side downward, or next to another object; notedgewise.
The act or process of portraying; description; delineation.
An architectural member, plain or ornamental, projecting from awall or pier, to support weight falling outside of the same; also, adecorative feature seeming to discharge such an office.
A heathlike plant of the genus Empetrum, and its fruit, ablack, scarcely edible berry; -- also called crakeberry.
Derived from wood by distillation; -- formerly used indesignating crude wood spirit.
The faith or system of the Sandemanians. A. Fuller.
A line connecting points on the earth's surface having the samemean summer temperature.
Semblance; fair appearance; plausibility. Sir K. Digby.
One who derides, or laughs at, another in contempt; a mocker; ascoffer.

An arctic sea bird Fratercula arctica) allied to the auks, andhaving a short, thick, swollen beak, whence the name; -- called alsobottle nose, cockandy, coulterneb, marrot, mormon, pope, and seaparrot.
The highest class in society; the upper ten. See Upper ten,under Upper. [Colloq.]
Of or pertaining to Tahiti, an island in the Pacific Ocean.-- n.
The act of inflicting pain on one's self; pain inflicted onone's self.
Of or pertaining to the myelencephalon; cerebro-spinal.
The art or method of determining the coloring power of indigo.
An officer who has authority to direct in the extinguishing offires, or to order what precautions shall be taken against fires; --called also fireward.
To melt or be dissolved; to deliquesce. [Obs.] Boyle.
Copied, reproduced as a molding or cast, in contradistinctionfrom the original model.
A woman's headband (sometimes of metal), for binding the fronthair.
a creator of great skill in the manual arts.Syn. -- craftsman.[WordNet 1.5]

A by-product from the manufacture of steel by the basicprocess, used as a fertilizer. It is rich in lime and contains 14 to20 per cent of phosphoric acid. Called also Thomas slag, phosphaticslag, and odorless phosphate.
A base, C15H27N, produced together with valeridine, which itresembles.
A yellow dye obtained from the leaves of the holly.
Act of thinning a wood to let in light. [Obs.] Evelyn.
Producing but one kind of spore, as the ferns and Equiseta. Cf.Heterosporic.
Was, should be, or would be, able, capable, or susceptible.Used as an auxiliary, in the past tense or in the conditionalpresent.
Omnipotence; infinite or boundless power; unlimited might. Jer.Taylor.
Having power to excite; tending or serving to excite;excitatory. Barrow.
The upper part, or the citadel, of a Grecian city; especially,the citadel of Athens.
Broken or strained so as to have an upward curve between theends. See Hog, v. i.

A valve permitting a fluid under pressure an easier avenue ofescape than normally; specif., a valve, actuated by the governor,used in one system of marine-engine governing to connect both ends ofthe low-pressure cylinder as a supplementary control.

A mineral of the pyroxene group, orthorhombic incrystallization; often fibrous and massive; color grayish white orgreenish. It is a silicate of magnesia with some iron. Bronzite is aferriferous variety.
The condition or quality of being glossy; the luster orbrightness of a smooth surface. Boyle.
A natural occurrence of a useful mineral under the conditionsto invite exploitation. Raymond.
A poem of fourteen lines; a sonnet. R. H. Stoddard.
The act of rolling or revolving round, as a wheel;circumvolution; the state of being whirled round. J. Gregory.
One who uses, or fights with, a sword; a swordsman; a soldier;a cutthroat. [Obs.] Shak.

A limited reciprocating motion of a particle of an elastic bodyor medium in alternately opposite directions from its position ofequilibrium, when that equilibrium has been disturbed, as when astretched cord or other body produces musical notes, or particles ofair transmit sounds to the ear. The path of the particle may be in astraight line, in a circular arc, or in any curve whatever.
A genus of Bryozoa, of the order Entoprocta, having a bell-shaped body supported on a slender pedicel. See Illust. underEntoprocta.
Inflammation of the pleura and lungs; a combination of pleurisyand pneumonia, esp. a kind of contagions and fatal lung plague ofcattle.
A series of short, convulsive inspirations, the glottis beingsuddenly closed so that little or no air enters into the lungs.
Having the inner part cut away, or left vacant, a narrow borderbeing left at the sides, the tincture of the field being seen in thevacant space; -- said of a charge.
The horny egg case of a skate, and of certain sharks.
The act of devoting one's self, or the state of being self-devoted; willingness to sacrifice one's own advantage or happinessfor the sake of others; self-sacrifice.
Any one of six metameric phenol derivatives of xylene, obtainedas crystalline substances, (CH3)2.C6H3.OH.
A yellow coloring matter extracted from chlorophyll.
The bone or cartilage of the tarsus, which articulates with thefibula, and corresponds to the calcaneum in man and most mammals.
The state of being intestate, or of dying without having made avalid will. Blackstone.
The time during which there is daylight, as distinguished fromthe night.
A supposed metal, said by Phipson to be contained in commercialzinc; -- so called because certain of its compounds are darkened byexposure to light.

Having straight joints. Specifically:(a) Applied to a floor the boards of which are so laid that thejoints form a continued line transverse to the length of the boardsthemselves. Brandle & C.(b) In the United States, applied to planking or flooring puttogether without the tongue and groove, the pieces being laid edge toedge.
Want of equity or uprightness; injustice; wickedness; iniquity.[Obs.] Wyclif.
To cause to shrink or shrivel with cold; to benumb. [Prov.Eng.]
A temporary and incomplete subsidence of the force or violenceof a disease or of pain, as destinguished from intermission, in whichthe disease completely leaves the patient for a time; abatement.
An igneous rock,usually light gray in color and breaking with arough surface. It consists chiefly of orthoclase feldspar withsometimes hornblende and mica.
Capable of being, or liable to be, distrained. Blackstone.
A glazed earthen pot or vessel, used by druggists andapothecaries for containing medicines, etc.
A large toadfish the Southern United States and the Gulf ofMexico (Batrachus tau, var. pardus).
An officer who presides over the academic senate of a Germanuniversity. Heyse.
Shortening by apocope; the state of being apocopated.

A revolving disk on which figures drawn in different relativeattitudes are seen successively, so as to produce the appearance ofan object in actual motion, as an animal leaping, etc., inconsequence of the persistence of the successive visual impressionsof the retina. It is often arranged so that the figures may beprojected upon a screen.
To adjust or settle again; to put in a different order orrelation; to rearrange.
That part of geology which treats of the materials of theearth's structure, and its general exterior and interiorconstitution.
A decomposed granite, forming a mass of gravel, as in tin lodesin Cornwall.
To turn away from the east, or (figuratively) from the right orthe truth. [R.]
That which disinfects; an agent for removing the causes ofinfection, as chlorine.
Having great tension, or exaggerated action. Dunglison.
The act or art of taking off the top soil of land before anexcavation or embankment is begun.
Act of accentuating; applications of accent. Specifically(Eccles. Mus.),
A permanent colony of cells or plastids which may remainisolated, like Rotifer, or may multiply by gemmation to form higheraggregates, termed zoides. Perrier.
Lit., my lady; hence (as used on the Continent), an Englishnoblewoman or gentlewoman.
Tabular parenchyma, a form of cellular tissue in which thecells are broad and flat, as in some kinds of epidermis.
The indigent class in the State; the body of proletarians.
To spend time in trifling employments, or to attend to usefulsubjects in an indifferent or superficial manner; to dawdle.

A wind instrument whose sounding parts are reeds, consisting ofa thin tongue of brass playing freely through a slot in a plate. Ithas a case, like a piano, and is played by means of a similarkeybord, the bellows being worked by the foot. The melodeon is aportable variety of this instrument.
A unit of energy or work, equal to the work done in moving abody through one foot against the force of one poundal.

An instrument or apparatus for comparing and grading thesensitiveness of plates, films, etc., as a screen divided intosquares of different shades or colors, from which a picture is madeon the plate to be tested.
A double cyanide of gold and some other metal or radical; --called also cyanaurate.
A beautiful North American butterfly (Basilarchia, orLimenitis, astyanax). Its wings are nearly black with red and bluespots and blotches. Called also red-spotted purple.
Having the shape or appearance of a julus or catkin.
A grocer; -- formerly so called because he sold pepper. [Obs.]
A white crystalline compound of piperidine and piperic acid. Itis obtained from the black pepper (Piper nigrum) and other species.
An apple-green variety of chalcedony, colored by nickel. It hasa dull flinty luster, and is sometimes used in jewelry.
A slip from a plant; a scion; a cutting. [R.] Holished.
An extensive plain with or without vegetation. [SpanishAmerica]
A division of swimming birds which includes the grebes, divers,auks, etc., in which the legs are placed far back.

A process of extracting perfumes by exposing absorbents, asfixed oils or fats, to the exhalations of the flowers. It is used forplants whose volatile oils are too delicate to be separated bydistillation.

A picture (as of a slice of wood) obtained by first wetting theobject slightly with hydrochloric or dilute sulphuric acid, thentaking an impression with a press, and next strongly heating thisimpression.
Government by a woman, female power; gyneocracy. Bailey.
Of or pertaining to phlogiston, or to belief in its existence.
Self-fertilization, the fertilizing pollen being derived fromthe same blossom as the pistil acted upon.
Soup made chiefly from vegetables or fish with a little butterand a few condiments.
Any long-legged bird that wades in the water in search of food,especially any species of limicoline or grallatorial birds; -- calledalso wading bird. See Illust. g, under Aves.
A tool for lifting loose sand from the mold; also, acontrivance attached to a cope, to hold the sand together when thecope is lifted.
A knife with one or more blades, which fold into the handle soas to admit of being carried in the pocket.
A small kind of onion (Allium Ascalonicum) growing in clusters,and ready for gathering in spring; a scallion, or eschalot.
To stand on the price or conditions of, so as to lose a sale;to lose by an extravagant price or hard conditions. [Obs.]What madman would o'erstand his market twice Dryden.
The felonious removal of goods from the place where they weredeposited.
In a variable expansion central-valve engine, a small auxiliaryengine for automatically adjusting the steam distribution to the loadon the main engine.[Webster 1913 Suppl.]
A small isolated mass of ore, as distinguished from acontinuous vein. Page.
The process of making mammonish; the state of being under theinfluence of mammonism.
Act of martyrizing, or state of being martyrized; torture. B.Jonson.
A room occupied as a messroom by the commissioned officers of awar vessel. See Gunroom. Totten.
One who, or that which, sets type; a compositor; a machine forsetting type.
Capability of being modified; state or quality of beingmodifiable.
The act of enthroning, or state of being enthroned. [Recent]
Having a plainted and convolute arrangement in the bud, as inthe morning-glory.
The inner, or preaxial, and usually the larger, of the twobones of the leg or hind limb below the knee.
Of or pertaining to Geneva, in Switzerland; Genevan.-- n. sing. & pl.
A tackle or purchase used to raise the flukes of the anchor upto the gunwale. The block used is called the fish-block.
Having all the florets ligulate, as in the dandelion.
Having power to transmit light; transparent; diaphanous.
The amphitheater of Vespasian in Rome. [Also written Coliseum.]
Small or portable articles for dress, furniture, or use; goods;luggage; things. [Colloq.]
One who exchanges; one who practices exchange. Matt.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid called also inactivetartaric acid.
The quality or state of being redeemable; redeemability.
Suppressed or concealed mirth. [Obs.] The Coronation.
To cast about; to consider; to ponder. [Obs.] Sir T. Malory.
A cloth for carrying bread, so as not to touch it with thehands. [Obs.]
The name given to one the cultivated Dravidian languages,closely related to the Tamil. Yule.
A pale green mineral occurring in crystalline aggregates havinga botryoidal or mammillary structure, and rarely in distinctcrystals. It is a hydrous silicate of alumina and lime.
An instrument of eight strings; a system of eight tones. [Alsowritten octochord.]

Any one of numerous species of pigeons belonging to Turtur andallied genera, native of various parts of the Old World; especially,the common European species (Turtur vulgaris), which is noted for itsplaintive note, affectionate disposition, and devotion to its mate.
A mode of opening the game, in which a pawn is sacrificed togain an attacking position.
The act of transforming, or the state of being transformed;change of form or condition. Specifically: --(a) (Biol.)
Inversely ovate, with a deep hollow on each side. Gray.
Such prior insult or injury as may be supposed, under thecircumstances, to create hot blood, and to excuse an assault made inretort or redress.
To restore after hunger or fatique; to refresh. [Archaic] SirT. Browne.
The science, art, or practice of healthful exercise of the bodyand limbs, to promote strength and gracefulness; light gymnastics.
To grow turgid as by effusion of liquid in the cellular tissue;to puff out; to swell. Arbuthnot.
Exposing linen to the sun, on the grass, in the process ofbleaching.
A feasting or feast; banquet. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
The science which treats of the properties of the air, and ofthe part it plays in nature. Craig.
One of a class of plants, so called by Lindley, because theovules are fertilized by direct contact of the pollen. Same asGymnosperm.
Incapable of being treated; not practicable. [R.] Dr. H. More.
A white, crystalline, poisonous substance, regarded as aglucoside, extracted from the lily of the valley (ConvallariaMajalis). Its taste is first bitter, then sweet.
One of the spaces between the septa in the Anthozoa.
A tetrahexahedron; -- so called because it is a common form offluorite.

Orig., at Sydney, a cold and violent south or southwest wind,rising suddenly, and regularly preceded by a hot wind from the north;-- now usually called southerly buster. It blew across theBrickfields, formerly so called, a district of Sydney, and carriedclouds of dust into the city.
The angular distance of any object from the celestial equator,either northward or southward.
A count or earl who presided in the domestic court, and had thesuperintendence, of a royal household in Germany.
The quality or state of being invisible; invisibility.
Of or pertaining to a pseudopod, or to pseudopodia. See Illust.of Heliozoa.
The opening from the pharynx into the larynx or into thetrachea. See Larynx.

A work constructed within another, to prolong the defense ofthe position when the enemy has gained possession of the outer work;or to protect the defenders till they can retreat or obtain terms fora capitulation.
A piece of hard wood loaded at one end with lead, and used tostrike the fleam into the vein. Youatt.
An instrument in which are combined the characteristic tones ofthe organ and various other instruments. [R.]
An order of Crustacea, including Nebalia and allied forms.

A mineral occurring in transparent crystals, usually of awhite, sometimes of a reddish gray, or lemon-yellow, color; nativesodium nitrate. It is used in making nitric acid and for manure.Called also soda niter.
Forked or branched like a pair of forceps; constructed so as toopen and shut like a pair of forceps. Sir T. Browne.
Of or pertaining to Augeus, king of Elis, whose stablecontained 3000 oxen, and had not been cleaned for 30 years. Herculescleansed it in a single day.
An ornamental casing for a flowerpot, of porcelain, metal,paper, etc.
An instrument like a guitar. "Harps, lutes, and giternes."Chaucer.

Composition in mutually related, equally important parts whichshare the melody among them; contrapuntal composition; -- opposed tohomophony, in which the melody is given to one part only, the othersfilling out the harmony. See Counterpoint.
An intermediate depot or station between one commercial city orcountry and another. Mitford.
The act of producing excitement (stimulation); also, theexcitement produced.
The red cap adopted by the extremists in the French Revolution,which became a sign of patriotism at that epoch; hence, arevolutionist; a Red Republican.
The man who rows the aftermost oar, and whose stroke is to befollowed by the rest. Totten.
In French games, a pair royal composed of 2 cards in the handand the card turned.
A kind of dress goods, made with a soft and glossy surface likecashmere.
In an affirmative manner; on the affirmative side of aquestion; in the affirmative; -- opposed to negatively.
A South American armadillo (Dasypus sexcinctus). Called alsosixbanded armadillo.
A yellowish amorphous alkaloid extracted from the rootstock ofVeratrum album.
A tough, horny animal substance entering into the compositionof the skeleton of sponges, and other invertebrates; -- called alsokeratode.
A long-tailed monkey (Semnopithecus schislaceus), from themountainous districts of India.
A liquid hydrocarbon, C7H10, of the valylene series.
A group of chelonians which comprises many species of fresh-water tortoises and terrapins.
A composition adapted to sacred words in the elaboratepolyphonic church style; an anthem.
Having a space equal to two diameters or four modules betweentwo columns; -- said of a portico or building. See Intercolumniation.-- n.
Combined with fluorine; subjected to the action of fluoride.[R.]
Texas; -- a nickname alluding to the single star on its coat ofarms, being the device used on its flag and seal when it was arepublic.
Lead chromate occuring in crystals of a bright hyacinth redcolor; -- called also red lead ore.
A treatise on demons; a supposititious science which treats ofdemons and their manifestations. Sir W. Scott.
Tending to calm, moderate, or tranquilize; specifically (Med.),allaying irritability and irritation; assuaging pain.
Sculptured ornaments, used in classical architecture,representing rams' heads or skulls.
A group of transparent, free-swimming Annelida, having setaeonly in the cephalic appendages.
The act of understanding, or supplying, something notexpressed; also, that which is so understood or supplied. Trench.
A compound of antimonious acid and a base or basic radical.
To reduce to a normal standard; to calculate or adjust thestrength of, by means of, and for uses in, analysis.

A name given to several different fishes, in allusion to theirslippery coating of mucus, as the Stromateus triacanthus of theAtlantic coast, the Epinephelus punctatus of the southern coast, therock eel, and the kelpfish of New Zealand.
One of the first three Gospels of the New Testament. SeeSynoptist.
One of the ribs in a groined arch, springing from the cornersin a diagonal direction.
The act of excarnificating or of depriving of flesh;excarnation. Johnson.

Groups of small shining spots on the surface of the sun whichare brighter than the other parts of the photosphere. They aregenerally seen in the neighborhood of the dark spots, and aresupposed to be elevated portions of the photosphere. Newcomb.
The modern, or true, Crustacea, as distinguished from theMerostomata.
Having the shape of a gourd seed; -- said of certain smallworms.
The act of asperating; a making or becoming rough. Bailey.
To stretch; to extend; hence, to lay out, as a dead body. [Obs.or Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
The pied wagtail; -- so called in allusion to its beating thewater with its tail while tripping along the leaves of water plants.[Prov. Eng.]
To break completely; to break in pieces. [Obs.]With nose and mouth to-broke. Chaucer.
Intended for voices of one kind only, either all male or allfemale; -- opposed to mixed. [R.]
The process of straining; the matter strained; a strainer. [R.]
The act or process of producing, or of subjecting to the actionof, ozone.
One who is garnished; a person upon whom garnishment has beenserved in a suit by a creditor against a debtor, such person holdingproperty belonging to the debtor, or owing him money.
The rootstock or decumbent stem by which a hydroid is attachedto other objects. See Illust. under Hydroidea.
An instrument used by masons and others to trace and formangles.

A kind of grass (Cynodon Dactylon) esteemed for pasture in theSouthern United States. It is a native of Southern Europe, but is nowwide-spread in warm countries; -- called also scutch grass, and inBermuda, devil grass.
To poke or stir up a fire; hence, to tend the fires offurnaces, steamers, etc.
An engine somewhat resembling a massive crossbow, used by theancient Greeks and Romans for throwing stones, arrows, spears, etc.

A small landlocked variety of the Atlantic salmon (Salmo salarounaniche) of Lake St. John, Canada, and neighboring waters, notedfor its vigor and activity, and habit of leaping from the water whenhooked.
Like a grandmother in age or manner; kind; indulgent.
The state or condition of being an albino: abinoism;leucopathy.
One who is deficient in understanding; a witless person. Shak.
The dried hemp plant, used in India for smoking. It isextremely narcotic and intoxicating.
One who commits a trespass; as:(a) (Law) One who enters upon another's land, or violates his rights.(b) A transgressor of the moral law; an offender; a sinner.
One who swerves from and is unfaithful to the marriage vow.[Poetic] Shak.
Of or pertaining to Laodicea, a city in Phrygia Major; like theChristians of Laodicea; lukewarm in religion. Rev. iii. 14-16.

In Australia, a blind channel leading out from a river; --sometimes called an anabranch. This is the sense of the word as usedin the Public Works Department; but the term has also been locallyapplied to mere back-waters forming stagnant pools and to certainwater channels arising from a source.

A provincial name given in England to basaltic rocks, andapplied by miners to other kind of dark-colored unstratified rockswhich resist the point of the pick.-- for example, to masses of chert. Whin-dikes, and whin-sills, arenames sometimes given to veins or beds of basalt.
Antidotal.-- n. Antidote; also, a book of antidotes.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling the style of, Richard Wagner,the German musical composer.
Action of the brain, whether conscious or unconscious.
According to the principles of, or with reference to,mineralogy.

A tenure by which land descended from the father to all hissons in equal portions, and the land of a brother, dying withoutissue, descended equally to his brothers. It still prevails in thecounty of Kent. Cowell.
A tasimeter, especially when arranged for measuring very smallextensions. See Tasimeter.
Characterized by the absence of a decidua; indeciduate.
A tank in which alum is crystallized from a solution.
A wind from the north; esp., a strong and cold north wind inTexas and the vicinity of the Gulf of Mexico.
An instrument for measuring the rain that falls; a rain gauge.
Act of leaning upon something; incumbency. [Obs.] Derham.
Containing, or derived from, tartar; combined with tartaricacid.
The state of being a probationer; novitiate. Locke.
State of being within; interiority. [R.] H. Brooke.
Of or pertaining to Trophonius, his architecture, or his caveand oracle.
A kind of thin translucent paper with a glossy finish.
The unlawful beating of another. It includes every willful,angry and violent, or negligent touching of another's person orclothes, or anything attached to his person or held by him.

A province, prefecture, or territory, under the jurisdiction ofan eparch or governor; esp., in modern Greece, one of the largersubdivisions of a monarchy or province of the kingdom; in Russia, adiocese or archdiocese.
A wind instrument nearly identical with the bagpipe. Drayton.
A easy and concise method of applying the rules of arithmeticto questions which occur in trade and business.
A worker in cordwain, or cordovan leather; a shoemaker.[Archaic.]
An unexpected subsequent event; something disagreeablehappening after an affair is supposed to be at an end. Spenser.

A form of the possessive case of the pronoun thou, nowsuperseded in common discourse by your, the possessive of you, butmaintaining a place in solemn discourse, in poetry, and in the usuallanguage of the Friends, or Quakers.
Pertaining to, or derived from, the locust; -- formerly used todesignate a supposed acid.
A pulley for driving machines, etc., having two or more partsor steps of different diameters; a pulley having a conical shape.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid obtained bythe oxidation of narcotine.
A nocturnal bird of South America and Trinidad (SteatornisCaripensis, or S. steatornis); -- called also oilbird.
The throwing overboard of goods from necessity, in order tolighten a vessel in danger of wreck.
To check (an adversary's king) in such a manner that escape inimpossible; to defeat (an adversary) by putting his king in checkfrom which there is no escape.
The quality or state of being starched; stiffness in manners;formality.
The hypothetical radical PH4, analogous to ammonium, andregarded as the nucleus of certain derivatives of phosphine.
A bird referred to in the Bible (Lev. xi. 18and Deut. xiv. 17)as unclean, probably the Egyptian vulture (Neophron percnopterus).
The European green woodpecker; also, the spotted woodpecker.[Prov. Eng.]
The husks and other refuse of rice mills, used to adulterateoil cake, or linseed cake.
A kind of walking stick made from the stem of an East Asiaticpalm (Licuala acutifida).
Of or pertaining to the Pontus, Euxine, or Black Sea.
A cream-colored limestone for building, found near Caen,France.
An alloy of copper, invented by the Japanese, having a verydark blue color approaching black.
The branch of science which treats of ornithichnites.Hitchcock.
A mucilage obtained from, or containing, gun tragacanth.

Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid which isobtained from several varieties of lichen (Lecanora, Roccella, etc.),as a white, crystalline substance, and is called also orsellic, ordiorsellinic acid, lecanorin, etc.
A maker of gowns, or similar garments; a mantuamaker.
A toga of purple, or ornamented with purple horizontal stripes.-- worn by kings, consuls, and augurs. Dr. W. Smith.
An apparatus for measuring the velocity imparted by gunpowder.

An Australian insectivorous singing bird (Pachycephalagutturalis). The male is conspicuously marked with black and yellow,and has a black crescent on the breast. Called also white-throatedthickhead, orange-breasted thrust, black-crowned thrush, gutturalthrush, and black-breasted flycatcher.
Having the ovule inverted at an early period in itsdevelopment, so that the chalaza is as the apparent apex; -- opposedto orthotropous. Gray.
A scaly parasitic plant (Conopholis Americana) found in oakwoods in the United States; -- called also cancer root.
A term at omber, signifying that the game is won. Pope.
A deciduous plant of warm climates, generally with fleshyleaves and flowers of a yellow or whitish yellow color, of the genusZygophyllum.
An apprehension or opinion formed before examination orknowledge. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
To interpose; to insert or place between. [R.] Cudworth.
Having the flesh attached closely to the stone, as in somekinds of peaches.-- n.
Condition of being a mulier; position of one born in lawfulwedlock.
To lie or sail along the coast or side of; to accost. [Obs.]Whether high towering or accosting low. Spenser.
The wryneck; -- so called from its cry. [Prov. Eng.]
The neck; also, the necklike portion of any part, as of thewomb. See Illust. of Bird.
The position, distribution, and order of persons and propertieson the stage of a theater, as determined by the stage manager inrehearsal.
Having all the flowers alike; -- said of such composite plantsas Eupatorium, and the thistels.
Navigation along the coast; the details of coast pilotage.
That which makes the eyes open, as startling news oroccurrence, or (U. S. Slang), a drink of liquor, esp. the first onein the morning.
Having several leaves; -- used especially when several leavesor leaflets appear where normally there should be only one.
A protoplasmic granule of some other color than green; -- alsocalled chromoleucite.
Having lost the power of development, and become rotten, aseggs; putrid. Hence: Unfruitful or confused, as brains; muddled.Dryden.
A fucus or seaweed much used in the East for soups and jellies;Ceylon moss (Gracilaria lichenoides).
A large tree of the genus Swietenia (S. Mahogoni), found intropical America.
A small stick or rod used as a spike in thatching; a splinter.[Prov. Eng.] Grose.

The half-wild horse of the plains in Mexico, California, etc.It is small, hardy, and easily sustained. Mustard grape (Bot.), aspecies of grape (Vitis candicans), native in Arkansas and Texas. Theberries are small, light-colored, with an acid skin and a sweet pulp.
One who lithographs; one who practices lithography.
Making a clang, or a ringing metallic sound. [Obs.]
Several times compounded or divided, as a leaf or stem;decomposite.
A hawker; specifically, one who travels about selling anddistributing religious tracts and books.
A mineral of a dark brown color, generally with a fibrous,massive structure. It is a fluophosphate of iron and manganese.
The property of two curves, or surfaces, which meet, and at thepoint of meeting have a common direction.
Incapable of being moved; immovable; fixed; stable. Prof.Shedd.
The state of being disposed or inclined; inclination;propensity. [R.]
Lit., closed sea; hence, a body of water within the separatejurisdiction of the nation; -- opposed to open sea, the water open toall nations and over which no single nation has special control.
Enough to fill a sheet; as much as a sheet can hold.
the yarn or thread of any stuff of which the strands of a ropeare made.
Five-twenty bonds of the United States (bearing six per centinterest), issued in 1862, '64, and '65, redeemable after five andpayable in twenty years.
A genus of cruciferous plants, containing the lady's-smock,cuckooflower, bitter cress, meadow cress, etc.
A room before, or forming an entrance to, another; a waitingroom.
To deprive of exercise; to leave untrained. [Obs.]By disexercising and blunting our abilities. Milton.
A great blackish seaweed of the Southern Ocean, having a hollowand expanding stem and a pinnate frond, sometimes twenty feet long.
Having the power of giving life or spirit. Johnson.
An instrument for measuring the harmonic relations of sounds.It is often a monochord furnished with movable bridges.
A remarkable vitreous sponge, of the genus Hyalonema, firstbrought from Japan. It has a long stem, consisting of a bundle oflong and large, glassy, siliceous fibers, twisted together.
Thrusting with the foil; fencing with the point, asdistinguished from broadsword play. [Obs.] Marston.
A treatise on sacred things; especially, the science whichtreats of the ancient writings and inscriptions of the Egyptians, ora treatise on that science.
In the form of tendrils; -- applied especially to the spermaticand ovarian veins.
The homology of metameres. See Metamere. Gegenbaur.
The act or state of growing together, as similar parts; the actof uniting by natural affinity or attraction; the state of beingunited; union; concretion.
To deprive of the position or office a vicar. [R.] Strype.
The act or process of salivating; an excessive secretion ofsaliva, often accompained with soreness of the mouth and gums;ptyalism.
To cause to cease to be pagan; to divest of pagan character.[R.] Cudworth.

A white, crystalline sugar, C6H12O6, isomeric with dextrose,obtained by the decomposition of milk sugar, and also from certaingums. When oxidized it forms mucic acid. Called also lactose (thoughit is not lactose proper).
Resembling or becoming a wizard; wizardlike; weird.
One who has charge of cattle, horses, etc.; a herdsman.[Southwestern U. S.]
Painless vivisection; -- opposed to sentisection. B. G. Wilder.
A peculiar tackle, formed of two or more blocks, or pulleys,the weight being suspended of a hook block in the bight of therunning part.
To rove or wander stealthily, esp. for prey, as a wild beast;hence, to prey; to plunder.
The act of making necessary, or the state of being madenecessary; compulsion. [R.] bp. Bramhall.
A member of a secret association (esp. in Russia), which isdevoted to the destruction of the present political, religious, andsocial institutions.

A system of prison discipline employing for consecutive periodscellular confinement, associated imprisonment under the mark system,restraint intermediate between imprisonment and freedom, andliberation on ticket of leave.
One skilled in the cultivation of flowers; a florist.
Consisting of a network of veins, without intermediateparenchyma, as the leaves of certain plant; latticelike.
Act, or state, of being twice married; deuterogamy. [R.]
The conveyance of a soul from one body to another. [R.] Fuller.
A switch made up of a rail from each track, both rails beingtapered far back and connected to throw alongside the through rail ofeither track.
A kind of food made of milk or cream, eggs, sugar, bread, etc.,baked in a pot. King.
Rubbish or refuse consisting of broken rock containing littleor no ore. Weale.
A gummy or gelatinous substance produced in certain plants bythe action of water on the cell wall, as in the seeds of quinces, offlax, etc.
One skilled in technology; one who treats of arts, or of theterms of arts.
A cultivated variety of the Asiatic gram, now introduced intothe United States.
Lowness in price, considering the usual price, or real value.
A part of a man's beard on the chin or lower lip which isallowed to grow, and trimmed so as to resemble the beard of a goat.
One eminently studious of symmetry of parts. Sir H. Wotton.
A genus of coarse biennial herbs (Lappa), bearing small burswhich adhere tenaciously to clothes, or to the fur or wool ofanimals.
An additional piece of canvas laced to the foot of a jib orforesail in moderate winds. Hakluyt.
A concave molding; -- used chiefly in classical architecture.See Illust. of Calumn.
The triad, or trinity, of Hindoo gods, consisting of Brahma,the Creator, Vishnu, the Preserver, and Siva, the Destroyer. [Spelledalso Trimurtti.]
A single particle of ice falling from a cloud; a frozenraindrop; a pellet of hail.
The art or process of making barometrical measurements.
To fix by the root; to fix fast; to implant deep. Shak.
To deprive of the qualities of a woman; to unsex. [R.] R.Browning.
The protoplasmic substance of the nucleus of a cell:nucleoplasm; -- in opposition to kytoplasma, the protoplasm of thecell.
Government by a single person; undivided rule. Sydney Smith.
The quality or state of being piacular; criminality;wickedness. De Quincey.
The region which is included within the outlet of the pelvis,and is traversed by the urinogenital canal and the rectum.
A substance allied to alkali albumin and to mucin, present insemen, to which it is said to impart the mucilaginous character.
One who studies by night; also, one who produces lucubrations.
The quality or state of being touchy peevishness; irritability;irascibility.
Not admitting excuse, evasion, or plea; rigorous. [R.] T.Adams.
A disproportionately rapid growth of the upper surface ofdorsiventral organs, such as leaves, through the stimulus of exposureto light. Encyc. Brit.
Lace having a needle-made design applied to a net ground, thisground often being machine-made.

A substance of very wide occurrence. It is found dissolved inthe sap of the roots and rhizomes of many composite and other plants,as Inula, Helianthus, Campanula, etc., and is extracted by solutionas a tasteless, white, semicrystalline substance, resembling starch,with which it is isomeric. It is intermediate in nature betweenstarch and sugar. Called also dahlin, helenin, alantin, etc.
The substance from which attraction spheres develop in mitoticcell division, and of which they consist.
An instrument for pruning trees, consisting of two blades, or ablade and a hook, fixed on the end of a long rod.
A red, gummy, coloring matter, extracted from the colorlessjuice of the Otaheite chestnut (Inocarpus edulis).
The wooden boarding used in supporting the roofs and walls ofcoal mines. See Brattice.
A harbor or port at some distance from the chief town or seatof trade. Macaulay.
Informal talk or discussion, as about literary matters; lightconversation; chat.

A process in which, by means of a number of photographssimultaneously taken from different points of view on the same level,rough models of the figure or bust of a person or animal may be madewith great expedition.
One of the orders of Branchiopoda. See Branchiopoda.
Not capable of being remitted; irremissible. Holinshed.
One who, or that which, connects; as:(a) A flexible tube for connecting the ends of glass tubes inpneumatic experiments.(b) A device for holding two parts of an electrical conductor incontact.

A flat, narrow molding, used chiefly to separate the parts ormembers of compartments or panels from one another, or doubled,turned, and interlaced so as to form knots, frets, or otherornaments. See Illust. (12) of Column.
A liturgy, or use, put forth about 1087 by St. Osmund, bishopof Sarum, based on Anglo-Saxon and Norman customs.
One who labors with another; an associate in labor.
To salt or pickle, as fish, and then preserve in oil orvinegar; to prepare by the use of marinade.
A speed regulator, as a water-wheel governor, embodying therelay principle.[Webster 1913 Suppl.]
A painful discharge of urine, drop by drop, produced byspasmodic muscular contraction.
A layer or mass of cellular tissue, especially that part of thethallus of certain fungi which incloses the perithecia.
To signal by means of a flag waved from side to side accordingto a code adopted for the purpose. [Colloq.]
In a half-raised position, as if about to spring on prey.
Having a somewhat glaucous appearance or nature; becomingglaucous.

A "tear-bottle;" a narrow-necked vessel found in sepulchers ofthe ancient Romans; -- so called from a former notion that the tearsof the deceased person's friends were collected in it. Called alsolachrymal or lacrymal.
A strong shutter, made to fit open ports and keep out water ina storm.
The quality or state of being inalienable; inalienability.
Derived from the name of a country, and designating aninhabitant of the country; gentile; -- said of a noun.-- n.
A sweet-scented herb; ambrosia. See Ambrosia, 3. Turner.
To meet. [Obs.]Our very loving sister, well bemet. Shak.
In Spain and Spanish America, a corporation or body ofmagistrates in cities and towns, corresponding to mayor and aldermen.
A contrivance for computing the revolutions of a wheel; anodometer.
A form of micrococcus found in the sputum (and elsewhere) ofpersons suffering with pneumonia, and thought to be the cause of thisdisease.
The iron lap used by diamond polishers in finishing the facetsof the gem.
Adapted for swimming; -- said of the legs of certain insects.
A carnivorous animal of the Weasel family (Mustela Canadensis);the pekan; the "black cat."
An election held by itself, not at the time of a generalelection.
The doctrine that matter possesses a species of life andsensation, or that matter and life are inseparable. [R.] Cudworth.

Not capable of being reduced to the form of a liquid bypressure; -- said of any gas above its critical point; -- alsoparticularly of oxygen, hydrogen, nitrogen, and carbon monoxide,formerly regarded as incapable of liquefaction at any temperature orpressure.
Of or pertaining to protoplasm; consisting of, or resembling,protoplasm.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, plants of the genus Musa.
That part of optics which explants the properties and phenomenaof reflected light, and particularly that which is reflected frommirrors or polished bodies; --- formerly caled anacamptics.
Pertaining to a second marriage, that is, one after the deathof the first wife or the first husband.
A figure oMust I give way and room to your rash choler Shall I be frighted whena madman stares Shak.
One who is skilled in stenography; a writer of shorthand.
One who seeks for things which gratify merely himself; aselfish person; a selfist. [R.] Whitlock.

The closing subdivision of the Devonian age in America. Therocks of this period are well developed in the Catskill mountains,and extend south and west under the Carboniferous formation. See theDiagram under Geology.
A whitish mineral occurring in radiated or fibrous crystallinemasses. It is a hydrous silicate of lime and soda.
Any apparatus for making and breaking an electric circuit; acircuit breaker.
The channel in which tailings, suspended in water, areconducted away.
A sharing among brothers, or brothers' kin. [Obs.] Crabb.
The action of the vital principle, or of the instinctivepowers, toward the preservation of the individual; also, the vitalprinciple. [In this sense, written also autocrasy.] Dunglison.
A decorative cabinet, of a form originating in Spain, the bodybeing rectangular and supported on legs or an ornamental frameworkand the front opening downwards on hinges to serve as a writing desk.
Of or pertaining to the west; toward the west; coming from thewest; western.
The act or practice of using to the best effect. [R.] H.Spenser.
A shallow iron pan to hold glass ware while being annealed.
One of two oval bodies hanging from the interior walls of thebody in the Acanthocephala.
A white, crystalline substance obtained as an anhydride ofalanine, and regarded as an imido derivative of lactic acid.
The state of being overthwart; perverseness. [Obs.] LordHerbert.
The state or quality of being desirable; desirableness.
The state of being doubtful; a doubtful statement or thing.[R.]Men often swallow falsities for truths, dubiosities for certainties,possibilities for feasibilities. Sir T. Browne.
The state or quality of being icy or very cold; frigidity.
A phrase, discourse, or proposition, susceptible of twointerpretations; and hence, of uncertain meaning. It differs fromequivocation, which arises from the twofold sense of a single term.
A warrior of great force and courage. [R. & Obs.] 1 Chron. xi.12.
Having tentacles without vibratile cilia. Carpenter.
A color mixed of white, and red, or a gray violet. [Writtenalso gredaline, grizelin.] Dryden.
A bolt used by shipwrights, to bend and secure the planksagainst the timbers till they are fastened by bolts, spikes, ortreenails; -- not to be confounded with ringbolt.
Any steel containing a notable quantity of some other metalalloyed with the iron, usually chromium, nickel, manganese, tungsten,or vanadium.
The sakti or wife of Brahma; the Hindoo goddess of learning,music, and poetry.
A kind of pack saddle used in the American military service andamong the Spanish Americans. It is made of leather stuffed with hay,moss, or the like.
Any spiral marine shell of the genus Persona, having acuriously twisted aperture.
Having a toothed bill; -- applied to a group of passerinebirds, having the bill notched, and feeding chiefly on insects, asthe shrikes and vireos. See Illust. (N) under Beak.
Produced increased vital action in the organism, or in any ofits parts.
An instrument for ascertaining the weight or density of air andgases.
The quality of being fantastical; fancifulness; whimsicality.Ruskin.
Capable of being deduced; derivable. [R.] Bp. Warburton.
Bent downward or aside; (Bot.) bending downward in a curve;declined.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, hydrogen selenide, H2Se,regarded as an acid analogous to sulphydric acid.
Quality or state of being restringent; astringency. [Obs.] SirW. Petty.
Having the effect of loosening or opening the intestines, andrelieving from constipation; -- opposed to astringent.-- n. (Med.)

One of a board of town officers chosen annually in the NewEngland States to transact the general public business of the town,and have a kind of executive authority. The number is usually fromthree to seven in each town.The system of delegated town action was then, perhaps, the same whichwas defined in an "order made in 1635 by the inhabitants ofCharlestown at a full meeting for the government of the town, byselectmen;" the name presently extended throughout New England tomunicipal governors. Palfrey.
A small species of titmouse, with a black head; the coletit.
Of such a nature that anything may be erased from it; -- saidof paper.
The husk covering an ear of Indian corn. [Colloq. U.S.]
The act of embroiling, or the condition of being embroiled;entanglement in a broil. Bp. Burnet.
Supplying amendment; corrective; emendatory. Bancroft.
Growing white, or assuming a color approaching to white.
Impostrous; deceitful.Strictness fales and impostrous. Beau. & Fl.
Tenderness or stiffness in the foot of a horse, which causeshim to move in a hobbling manner.
A liquid measure formerly used in France and Great Britain,varying from half a pint to a wine quart.
The sum or number to be subtracted, or taken from another.
A suborder of Hemiptera, in which both pairs of wings aresimilar in texture, and do not overlap when folded, as in the cicada.See Hemiptera.
Being without veins or nerves, as the leaves of certain plants.
To befall, as ill luck; to happen to unluckily. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who passes his life on land; -- so called among seamen incontempt or ridicule.

To send or address (by bill of lading or otherwise) to an agentor correspondent in another place, to be cared for or sold, or forthe use of such correspondent; as, to cosign a cargo or a ship; toset apart.
One who, or that which, preys; a plunderer; a waster; adevourer. Hooker.
That which is given under the doctrine of administering apatient's own virus.
The passage of the corpuscular elements of the blood from theblood vessels into the surrounding tissues, without rupture of thewalls of the blood vessels.
To affict with pestilence; to infect, as with plague. [Obs.]
The insertion of a scion in a stock; ingraftment. Ray.
A room containing a bar or counter at which liquors are sold.
The rule or practices of bosses, esp. political bosses. [Slang,U. S.]

A sign at the beginning of a composition or movement, placedafter the key signature, to indicate its time or meter. Also calledrhythmical signature. It is in the form of a fraction, of which thedenominator indicates the kind of note taken as time unit for thebeat, and the numerator, the number of these to the measure.
A plant of the Parsley family (Apium graveolens), of which theblanched leafstalks are used as a salad.
A hybrid between the tangerine orange and the grapefruit, orpomelo; also, the fruit.
The quality or state of succession in a series; sequence. H.Spenser.
The operation or work of cutting grass and curing it for hay.

A mark or short dash, thus [-], placed at the end of a linewhich terminates with a syllable of a word, the remainder of which iscarried to the next line; or between the parts of many a compoundword; as in fine-leaved, clear-headed. It is also sometimes used toseparate the syllables of words.
A mineral of a black color, submetallic luster, and highspecific specific gravity. It is a niobate (or columbate) of iron andmanganese, containing tantalate of iron; -- first found in NewEngland.
An annual composite plant (Carthamus tinctorius), the flowersof which are used as a dyestuff and in making rouge; bastard, orfalse, saffron.
One of a small, hardy breed of horses, with long mane and tail,which originated in the Shetland Islands; a sheltie.
Freedom or deliverance from encumbrance, or anything burdensomeor troublesome. Spectator.
To plow, or fallow, a second time (land that has been oncefallowed).
Serving for example or pattern; exemplary. [Obs.] Hooker.
Protected by an external coat, or covering, of scales orplates.
The act of abstaining; a holding aloof. Jer. Taylor.
The European mountain finch (Fringilla montifringilla); --called also bramble finch and bramble.
The principles or practices of a martinet; rigid adherence todiscipline, etc.
Being or occurring before the creation of the world. Young.
To open, as the eyes of a hawk that have been seeled; hence, togive light to; to enlighten. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A yard or storage place for all sorts of naval stores andtimber for shipbuilding.
a box, or vase with a perforated cover to emit perfumes.
A kind of embryo of certain hydroids (Tubularia), having astellate form.
A hydrous carbonate of magnesia occurring in white, early,amorphous masses.
The state or quality of being literal. Sir T. Browne.
Being, or having its origin, within the external surface of thebody; -- especially applied to feelings, such as hunger, produced byinternal disturbances. Opposed to epiperipheral.
The hypothetical radical, C5H11, of pentane and certain of itsderivatives. Same as Amyl.
One who plays upon an instrument of music, as distinguishedfrom a vocalist.
A fatlike substance in certain marine animals, to which theyowe their phosphorescent properties.
Want or difference of belief; disbelief. [Obs.] Bp. Reynolds.
The quality or state of being irrelevant; as, the irrelevancyof an argument.
In a commensurable manner; so as to be commensurable.
The larva or young of the mussel, formerly thought to be aparasite upon the parent's gills.
The first coating of color, size, or the like, laid on canvas,or on a building, or other surface.
A device for the automatic regulation of temperature; athermostat.
An aspect of the planets when they are distant from each otherby twice the fifth part of a great circle -- that is, twice 72degrees.
One who confers a benefit; -- also, one who receives a benefit.
An Algonquin tribe of Indians, inhabiting a large part ofBritish America east of the Rocky Mountains and south of Hudson'sBay.
Like a rasp, or the sound made by a rasp; grating. R. D.Blackmore.
A chemical process involving the addition of the elements ofwater.

An equilateral parallelogram, or quadrilateral figure whosesides are equal and the opposite sides parallel. The angles may beunequal, two being obtuse and two acute, as in the cut, or the anglesmay be equal, in which case it is usually called a square.
One of the single eyes forming the compound eyes ofcrustaceans, insects, and other invertebrates.
A wind instrument of brass, containing a reed, and partaking ofthe qualities both of a brass instrument and of a clarinet.
The hollow globe or sphere formed by the arrangement of theblastomeres on the periphery of an impregnated ovum.
A broad-leaved species of garlic (Allium ursinum), common inEuropean gardens; -- called also buckram.
To lament in an elegy; to celebrate in elegiac verse; tobewail. Carlyle.
The memorandum or certificate at the end of an asffidavit, or abill or answer in chancery, showing when, before whom, and (inEnglish practice), where, it was sworn or affirmed. Wharton. Bouvier.
The hypothetical homogeneous cosmic material of the originaluniverse, supposed to have been differentiated into what arerecognized as distinct chemical elements.
Relating to a dialect; dialectical; as, a dialectical variant.
Resembling a shepherd; suiting a shepherd; pastoral. Sir T.Sidney.
An instrument for ascertaining the amount of ozone in theatmosphere, or in any gaseous mixture. Faraday.
An orthoceras; also, any fossil shell allied to Orthoceras.

A large carnivorous reptile of the Crocodile family, peculiarto America. It has a shorter and broader snout than the crocodile,and the large teeth of the lower jaw shut into pits in the upper jaw,which has no marginal notches. Besides the common species of thesouthern United States, there are allied species in South America.
A nail with a round head and short shank, tinned and lacquered.
The color or incrustation which age gives to works of art;especially, the green rust which covers ancient bronzes, coins, andmedals. Fairholt.
In a clever manner.Never was man so clever absurd. C. Smart.

Any one numerous species of small brush-tongued parrots orlories, found mostly in Australia, New Guinea and the adjacentislands, with some forms in the East Indies. They are arboreal intheir habits and feed largely upon the honey of flowers. They belongto Trichoglossus, Loriculus, and several allied genera.
Having the power of seeing visions; inspired; also, seen invisions. [R.] Shelley.
A figure in which several things are mentioned that seem tomake against the argument, or in favor of the opposite side, each ofthem being refuted in order.
a nontoxic base, C5H14N2, found in the putrescent matters offlesh, fish, decaying cheese, etc.
To have the effect of a Gorgon upon; to turn into stone; topetrify. [R.]

One of a sect or party among the Jews, noted for a strict andformal observance of rites and ceremonies and of the traditions ofthe elders, and whose pretensions to superior sanctity led them toseparate themselves from the other Jews.
Divination by inspection of entrails of victims offered insacrifice.
The state or condition of being faulted; the process by which afault is produced.
A white, crystalline, nitrogenous substance, C2O2N3H5, formedby heating urea. It is intermediate between urea and cyanuric acid.
Having but one series of stamens, and that equal in number tothe proper number of petals; isostemonous.
A large South African tree snake (Bucephalus Capensis).Although considered venomous by natives, it has no poison fangs.
The skin which a deer frays from his horns. B. Jonson.
Master; sir; -- a title of a Turkish state official and man oflearning, especially one learned in the law.
A slut; a vagabond wench. Same as Drossel. [Obs.] Hudibras.
Capable of being reconverted; convertible again to the originalform or condition.

The system of occasional causes; -- a name given to certaintheories of the Cartesian school of philosophers, as to theintervention of the First Cause, by which they account for theapparent reciprocal action of the soul and the body.
Want of urbanity or courtesy; unpolished manners or deportment;inurbaneness; rudeness. Bp. Hall.
To thicken or bring to greater consistence, as fluids byevaporation.
An old game of ball played with a trap. See 4th Trap, 4.
The state of being anterior or preceding in time or insituation; priority. Pope.
A hymn with no regular meter, sometimes introduced into theMass. See Sequence.
One who dispends or expends; a steward. [Obs.] Wyclif (1 Cor.iv. 1).
Pertaining to, or possessing the properties of, a species ofcaustic curves formed by refraction. See Caustic surface, underCaustic.
Having the stamens come to maturity before the pistil; --opposed to proterogynous.
An old crafty fox or beguiler -- a word of contempt. [Obs.]Cotgrave.
A genus of plants containing some of the most popular ofcultivated flowers, including the pink, carnation, and Sweet William.
An extinct genus of large, fossil, bivalve shells,allied to themussels. The genus is characteristic of the Cretaceous period.
The jurisdiction of a mill, or that extent of ground astrictedto it, the tenants of which are bound to bring their grain thither tobe ground.
A machine for decorticating wood, hulling grain, etc.; also, aninstrument for removing surplus bark or moss from fruit trees.
A bout, or turn, as at fencing; a thrust; a hit; a veney.[Obs.] Fuller.
Direct fertilization in plants, as when the pollen fertilizingthe ovules comes from the stamens of the same blossom; -- opposed toheterogamy.
The Japanese warrior gentry or middle class, formerly calledsamurai; also, any member of this class.
A genus of American perrenial herbs growing in bogs; theAmerican pitcher plant.
The quality or state of being taxable; taxableness.
A plaster or poultice composed principally of powdered mustardseed, or containing the volatile oil of mustard seed. It is apowerful irritant.
A nonnucleated mass of protoplasm, the supposed simplest formof independent life differing from the amoeba, in which nuclei arepresent.
The succession and variation of leaves during differentseasons. R. Brown.
The three-beared rocking, or whistlefish. [Prov. Eng.]
In an orthodox manner; with soundness of faith. Sir W.Hamilton.
A floral ornament, common in Greek and other ancientarchitecture; -- often called the honeysuckle ornament.
A long or short chain of micrococci, more or less curved.
A composite plant (Aster Tripolium) growing along the seacoastof Europe.
That number placed below the line in vulgar fractions whichshows into how many parts the integer or unit is divided.
Relatingto, emanating from or resembling, the poet Dante or hiswritings.
Powdered aromatic herbs, sometimes made into little balls andstrung together. [Obs.]
The resiniferous tree Agathis Dammara, of the Moluccas.
To order ill; to manage erroneously; to conduct badly. [Obs.]Shak.
To deprive of worship or due honor; to dishonor. [Obs.] Wyclif.
Genteel irony; a polite and ingenious manner of deridinganother.
To madden; to rave. [Obs.]An infatuating and delirating spirit in it. Holland.
Subsisting upon blood; -- said of certain blood-sucking batsand other animals. See Vampire.
Producing epilepsy or epileptoid convulsions; -- applied toareas of the body or of the nervous system, stimulation of whichproduces convulsions.

A stage entertainment of successive separate performances,usually songs, dances, acrobatic feats, dramatic sketches,exhibitions of trained animals, or any specialties. Often looselycalled vaudeville show.
A four-wheeled pleasure carriage, (commonly two-seated)somewhat like a phaeton, but having a straight bottom.
Ignorant, unlearned; belonging to the laity. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The act of invigorating, or the state of being invigorated.
A substance employed as a hypnotic, produced by the union ofmercaptan and acetone.
To rate too low; to rate below the value; to undervalue. Burke.
The butting or boundary of land, particularly at the end; aheadland. Spelman.
An agreement between two or more persons to defraud a person ofhis rights, by the forms of law, or to obtain an object forbidden bylaw. Bouvier. Abbott.
An inclined road in a coal mine, on which loaded cars descendby gravity, drawing up empty ones. Knight.
That part of physiology which treats of the integuments ofanimals and plants.
A shrub in the West Indies (Lagetta Iintearia); -- so calledfrom the lacelike layers of its inner bark.
A white crystalline neutral substance (C2O2(NH2)2) obtained bytreating ethyl oxalate with ammonia. It is the acid amide of oxalicacid. Formerly called also oxalamide.
A crystalline vari ety of fruit sugar obtained from dambonite.
The art or practice of measuring gases; also, the science whichtreats of the nature and properties of these elastic fluids. Coxe.
The division of Mollusca which includes the land snails andslugs.
An inferior kind of olive oil, brought from Gallipoli, inItaly.
A yellow crystalline substance, C6Cl4.O2, regarded as aderivative of quinone, obtained by the action of chlorine on certainbenzene derivatives, as aniline.
A soft crayon for use in stump drawing or in shading with thestump.
One who stereotypes; one who makes stereotype plates, or worksin a stereotype foundry.
Having much heat in the constitution and little serum in theblood. [Obs.] Hence: Atrabilious; sallow; gloomy.
Of or pertaining to archangels; of the nature of, orresembling, an archangel. Milton.
To act; to represent on the stage, or theatrically. Urquhart.
A table stove or small furnace, usually a cylindrical box ofsheet iron, with a grate at the bottem, and an open top.

Native tin dioxide; tin stone; a mineral occurring intetragonal crystals of reddish brown color, and brilliant adamantineluster; also massive, sometimes in compact forms with concentricfibrous structure resembling wood (wood tin), also in rolledfragments or pebbly (Stream tin). It is the chief source of metallictin. See Black tin, under Black.
An accumulation of earth and stones carried forward anddeposited by a glacier. Lyell.
An extinct order of herbivorous dinosaurs, including the generaStegosaurus, Omosaurus, and their allies.
An instrument for measuring thickness, as of the glass of amirror, or of paper; a pachymeter.
That part of medicine which treats of regimen for old people.
A variety of albite, whitish and slightly iridescent like apigeon's neck.
Belonging to, or like, the family of plants of which theprickly pear is a common example.
The doctrine of the Cynics; the quality of being cynical; themental state, opnions, or conduct, of a cynic; morose andcontemptuous views and opinions.
A youth; especially, a student in a german university.
Above or beyond chemistry; inexplicable by chemical laws. J. LeConte.
Ill formation; irregular or anomalous formation; abnormal orwrong conformation or structure.
Mortar or the like, laid between the joists under the boards ofa floor, or within a partition, to deaden sound; -- in the UnitedStates usually called deafening.
An amorphous, gummy carbohydrate, found in Gelidium, agar-agar,and other seaweeds.
A whaleback steamer with a hatch coaming, usually about sevenfeet high, extending almost continuously fore and aft.
Lack of sympathy; want of passion; apathy. [R.]Many discrepancies and some dispathies between us. Southey.

A French theory of government which holds that commune shouldbe a kind of independent state, and the national government aconfederation of such states, having only limited powers. It isadvocated by advanced French republicans; but it should not beconfounded with communism.
A strong and offensive smell; rancidity. [R.] Bailey.
The stalk-eyed Crustacea, -- an order of Crustacea having theeyes supported on movable stalks. It includes the crabs, lobsters,and prawns. Called also Podophthalmata, and Decapoda.
The point on the side of the skull where the lambdoid, parieto-mastoid and occipito-mastoid sutures.
Having much beef; of the nature of beef; resembling beef;fleshy.
The act or practice of extorting money by exciting fears ofinjury other than bodily harm, as injury to reputation.
A nitrogenous base, CO.(NH.C3H5)2, related to urea, extractedfrom mustard oil, and also produced artifically, as a whitecrystalline substance; -- called also diallyl urea.
A paste prepared from tobacco, and smoked in hookahs in WesternIndia.
The powder of aloes with canella, formerly officinal, employedas a cathartic.
An unnatural, violent, and unvoluntary contraction of themuscular parts of an animal body.
The action of a go-between or broker in negotiating immoralbargains between the sexes; procuring.
One of the filaments on the inner surface of the gastric cavityof certain jellyfishes.
The act or practice of lying on the ground. [Obs.] Abp.Bramhall.
A sudden breaking off; a violent separation of bodies.Woodward.
A kind of small reed organ; -- a portable form of theseraphine.
The science of worship; history, doctrine, and interpretationof liturgies.
A division of Foraminifera including those that have only onechamber.
The state or quality of being exemplary; fitness to be anexample.
The Jesuit editors of the "Acta Sanctorum", or Lives of theSaints; -- named from John Bolland, who began the work.
A native of Sind, India, esp. one of the native Hindoo stock.
One who makes a business of lending money on the security ofpersonal property pledged or deposited in his keeping.
An order of lowly organized Mollusca belonging to theIsopleura. A narrow groove takes the place of the foot of othergastropods.
One who holds to the belief that a State has the right toseparate from the Union at its will.
Being in conflict or collision, or in opposition; contending;contradictory; incompatible; contrary; opposing.
[Fraise a kind of defense; also Friz.) A kind of small ruffle.Halliwell.
Up, or ahead, as many holes as remain to be played; -- said ofa player or side.
One who favors a form of government in which the unintelligentpopulace rules without restraint. Bayne.
A colloquial or humorous appelation for a negro; sometimes, theoffspring of a black person and a mulatto; a zambo.
A quantity of oats paid by a tenant to a landlord in lieu ofrent. Jacob.
The posterior part of the medulla oblongata. B. G. Wilder.
A land crab of the genus Gecarcinus, or of allied genera.
A believer in the theory of vitalism; -- opposed to physicist.
Lit., an eggshell; hence, an eggshell filled with confetti tobe thrown during balls, carnivals, etc. [Western U. S.]
A small dipterous fly of the genus Oscinis, esp. O. vastator,injurious to grain in Europe, and O. Trifole, injurious to clover inAmerica.
To cause to become cool; to make or keep cold or cool.
The quality or state of being stable, or firmly established;stability.
A bowman, one skilled in the use of the bow and arrow.
A support or column on which stamens are raised. Gray.

A right formerly belonging to an archbishop to select any onedignity or benefice in the gift of a suffragan bishop consecrated orconfirmed by him, for bestowal by himself when next vacant; --annulled by Parliament in 1845.
As much as a wagon will hold; enough to fill a wagon; awagonload.
The process of becoming solid by cooling; a cooling andsolidifying.
A defensive garment formerly in use for the body, made of clothstuffed and quilted.
The passage of the soul, as an immortal essence, at the deathof the animal body it had inhabited, into another living body,whether of a brute or a human being; transmigration of souls. Sir T.Browne.
The act of opening an academical disputation; the propositionof objections to a tenet, as an exercise for a degree. [Eng.] Todd.
A kind of fox found in Sweden (Vulpes alopex), smaller than thecommon fox (V. vulgaris), but probably a variety of it.
A line or curved surface passing beneath the earth's surfacethrough points having the same mean temperature.
A double-edged, sharp-pointed dismembering knife. [Spelt alsocatlin.] Crobb.
The meridian, or middle line of the heavens; the point of theecliptic on the meridian.
The quality or state of being voluntary; spontaneousness;specifically, the quality or state of being free in the exercise ofone's will.
The tendency, as of a rope, to untwist after being twisted.
One who instructs in the art of improving or using the memory.
A venomous snake of India, of the genus Bungarus, allied to thecobras, but without a hood.
In Canada, a legal holiday, July lst, being the anniversary ofthe proclamation of the formation of the Dominion in 1867.
A bladderlike vessel; a membranous cavity; a cyst; a cell.Specifically: --(a) (Bot.)
One of a kind of light cavalry of Tartaric origin, firstintroduced into European armies in Poland. They are armed withlances, pistols, and sabers, and are employed chiefly as skirmishers.
A little lock of hair, plastered in a spiral form on the templeor forehead with spittle, or other adhesive substance. [Colloq.]
A mode of speech peculiar to the French; a French idiom; also,in general, a French mode or custom.
Capable of being acidified, or converted into an acid.
A yard, place, or inclosure where ships are built or repaired.
Of or pertaining to the malleolus; in the region of themalleoli of the ankle joint.
The stomach of a calf, prepared for rennet. Halliwell.
The state or quality of being ordinal. [R.] Latham.
A kind of speedwell (Veronica Anagallis) found in wet places inEurope and America.
An old game in England, played by throwing pieces of wood at astake set in the ground. [Obs.] Shak.
The study of physiognomy; the art of discovering the characterof persons by their features, or the lines of the face.
An apparatus which transmits automatically to a central stationatmospheric changes as marked by the anemometer, barometer,thermometer, etc.
Incombustible; capable of sustaining a strong heat withoutalteration of form or properties.
A tax levied upon land alone, irrespective of improvements, --advocated by certain economists as the sole source of public revenue.

One who forms theories; one given to theory and speculation; aspeculatist. Cowper.The greatest theoretists have given the preference to such agovernment as that which obtains in this kingdom. Addison.
To perplex with scruples; to regard with scruples. [Obs.] Bp.Montagu.
To nerve again; to give new vigor to; to reinvigorate.
Serving to initiate; inceptive; initiatory; introductory;preliminary.
Sledge runners on which a skip is dragged in a mine.
Pressed close to, or lying against, something for its wholelength, as against a stem, Gray.
The operation of putting down or displacing the opaque lens incataract.
The pistillidium or female organ in the higher cryptogamicplants, corresponding to the pistil in flowering plants.
A coheir, or one of two or more persons to whom an estate ofinheritance descends jointly, and by whom it is held as one estate.
A white amorphous substance obtained as a polymericmodification of acrolein.
A condition in which air or other gas is present in the cavityof the chest; -- called also pneumatothorax.
A third person, who is to decide a controversy or questionsubmitted to arbitrators in case of their disagreement. Blackstone.
One of a group of squirrels, of the genera Pteromus andSciuropterus, having parachute-like folds of skin extending from thefore to the hind legs, which enable them to make very long leaps.
The quality or state of being retromingent. Sir T. Browne.
The germinal membrane in an ovum, from which the embryo isdeveloped.
Absence of necessity; the quality or state of beingunnecessary.
A royal charter confirming to a subject all his possessions.[Obs.] Holinshed.
Lead protoxide, PbO, obtained as a yellow amorphous powder, thefused and crystalline form of which is called litharge; lead ocher.It is used as a pigment.
Reaping peas, beans, wheat, etc., with a chopping stroke.[Eng.]
The fillet, listel, or band next to the apophyge at theextremity of the shaft of a column.
Having the qualities or manners of a ruffian; ruffianly.
A gaseous hydrocarbon, C3H6, isomeric with propylene andobtained from it indirectly. It is the base of a series of compoundsanalogous to the aromatic hydrocarbons.
Goods which, after shipwreck, appear floating on the waves, orsea.
Feeding or growing upon decaying anomal or vegetable matter;pertaining to a saprophyte or the saprophytes.
An order of fishes having some of the rays of the dorsal,ventral, and anal fins unarticulated and spinelike, as the perch.
An instrument for measuring the curvature of spherical surface,as of lenses for telescope, etc.
The capability of flying off in fumes or vapor. [Obs.] Boyle.
A straight wind without apparent cyclonic tendency, usuallyaccompanied with rain and often destructive, common in the prairieregions of the United States.
An intermediate shaft; esp., one which receives motion from aline shaft in a factory and transmits it to a machine.
One who, or that which, succeeds to the place of another; thatwhich is used for something else; a substitute; specifically (Med.),
Pertaining to, or involving, taxonomy, or the laws andprinciples of classification; classificatory.
A form of voltaic, or galvanic, battery suitable for useelectrotyping. G. Francis.
An instrument for describing ellipses; -- called also trammel.
Pertaining to the segment between the basibranchial and theceratobranchial in a branchial arch.-- n.

; sing. Choctaw. (Ethnol.) A tribe of North American Indians(Southern Appalachian), in early times noted for their pursuit ofagriculture, and for living at peace with the white settlers. Theyare now one of the civilized tribes of the Indian Territory.
An order of Siphonophora, furnished with an air sac, or float,and a series of nectocalyces. See Illust. under Nectocalyx.
The quality or state of being protestant, especially againstthe Roman Catholic Church; the principles or religion of theProtestants.
A mode of treating disease by appropriate muscular movements; -- also termed kinesitherapy, kinesipathy, lingism, and the movementcure.
The act of literalizing; reduction to a literal meaning.
Of or pertaining to Lima, or to the inhabitants of Lima, inPeru.-- n.
One who, or that which, backs; especially one who backs aperson or thing in a contest.
Of, or relating to, Confucius, the great Chinese philosopherand teacher. -- n.
To render immaterial or incorporeal.Immateralized spirits. Glanvill.
One who, or that which, preludes; one who plays a prelude.Mason.
