To fill with rage; to provoke to frenzy or madness; to makefurious.
The plea of the general issue in an action of debt on bond.
Anything which prevents sleep, or produces wakefulness, asstrong tea or coffee.
Act of eluding; adroit escape, as by artifice; a mockery; acheat; trickery.
A prime mover; a machine by means of which a source of power,as steam, moving water, electricity, etc., is made available fordoing mechanical work.
A master of arts whose regency has ceased. See Regent.
An outpost consisting of four men, forming one of a single lineof posts substituted for the more formal line of sentinels and lineof pickets.

A rare element of the group of the earth metals, allied toaluminium. It occurs in certain rare minerals, as cerite, gadolinite,orthite, etc., and was so named from the difficulty of separating itfrom cerium, didymium, and other rare elements with which it isusually associated. Atomic weight 138.5. Symbol La. [Formerly writtenalso lanthanium.]
Of or pertaining to a cognomen; of the nature of a surname.
A Hindoo system of philosophy which refers all things to souland a rootless germ called prakriti, consisting of three elements,goodness, passion, and darkness. Whitworth.
A kind of large, coarse, short trousers formerly worn. [Local,U. S.] Bartlett.
One who works by the day; -- usually applied to a farm laborer,or to a workman who does not work at any particular trade. Goldsmith.
A kind of shell marble occurring in the Wealden clay atPetworth, in Sussex, England; -- called also Sussex marble.

To enroll; to enter in a register; specifically, to enter oradmit to membership in a body or society, particularly in a collegeor university, by enrolling the name in a register.In discovering and matriculating the arms of commissaries from NorthAmerica. Sir W. Scott.
A title given in the Douay Bible to the Books of Chronicles.
The middle pair of tail feathers, or middle rectrices.
A yellow or brown amorphous substance, of indifferent nature,found in cod-liver oil.
A name given to that part of the Anglican liturgy for thecommunion, which precedes the consecration of the elements.
The quality of being illusive; deceptiveness; false show.
Two small, pointed rods of metal, formerly used in thetreatment called Perkinism.
An albuminous substance formed in gastric digestion, and by theaction of boiling dilute acids on albumin. It is readily convertibleinto hemipeptone. Called also hemialbumin.
A band of rich embroidery, wholly or in part of gold, affixedto vestments, especially those of ecclesiastics. Pugin.
A bitter white crystalline alkaloid extracted from the seeds ofthe castor-oil plant.
Pertaining to, containing, or consisting of, strophes.
A crown-saw or cylindrical saw for perforating the skull,turned, when used, like a bit or gimlet. See Trephine.
Wise after the event; wise or knowing, when it is too late.
Any one of a series of amido compounds obtained by treatingsulphuryl chloride with various amines.
A woman who is a prelate; the wife of a prelate. Milton.
The neck or line of junction between the root of a plant andits stem. Gray.
Out of condition; not in good condition; -- said of a hawk.
A stone for scouring or rubbing; a whetstone; a rub.

An order of small apterous insects having an elongated body,with three pairs of thoracic and about nine pairs of abdominal legs.They are, in many respects, intermediate between myriapods and trueinsects.
One of the orders of Nemertina, characterized by the presenceof a peculiar armature of spines or plates in the proboscis.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acid(C4H5N3O4) not known in the free state, but obtained, in combinationwith its salts, by a slow oxidation of uric acid, to which it isrelated.
Water confined in specially constructed compartments in avessel's hold, to serve as ballast.
In German mythology, the children of the mist, a race of dwarfsor demonic beings, the original possessors of the famous hoard andring won by Siegfrid; also, the Burgundian kings in theNibelungenlied.

A genus of bright-colored Siphonophora found floating in thewarmer parts of the ocean. The individuals are round and disk-shaped,with a large zooid in the center of the under side, surrounded bysmaller nutritive and reproductive zooids, and by slenderdactylozooids near the margin. The disk contains a central float, orpneumatocyst.
One who, or that which, articulates; as: (a) One who enunciatesdistinctly. (b) One who prepares and mounts skeletons. (c) Aninstrument to cure stammering.
A variety of garnet, of a poppy or blood-red color, frequentlywith a tinge of orange. It is used as a gem. See the Note underGarnet.
Having the nerves, or veins, placed in apparent disorder.
A method of working in which the waste is packed into the spaceformed by excavating the vein.
In a flying machine, a tail or rudder, usually fixed,resembling a box kite.
To guard as a churchwarden does. [Obs.] J. Gregory.
The quotient of a unit divided by a thousand; one of a thousandequal parts into which a unit is divided.
A small coin of the value of six and a quarter cents. SeeFippenny bit. [Local, U.S.]
The European small-spotted dogfish, or houndfish. See the Noteunder Houndfish.
To give nervous energy or power to; to give increasedenergy,force,or courage to; to invigorate; to stimulate.
Benne (Sesamum orientale); also, its seeds; -- so called in theWest Indies.

A harp-shaped instrument of music set horizontally on legs,like the grand piano, with strings of wire, played by the fingers, bymeans of keys provided with quills, instead of hammers, for strikingthe strings. It is now superseded by the piano.
The kiang, a wild horse or wild ass of Thibet (Asinushemionus).
One who, or that which, occasions, causes, or produces. Bp.Sanderson.
Having stems which bear flowers and fruit year after year, asmost trees and shrubs.
The art of making baskets; also, baskets, taken collectively.
A soluble poison (ptomaine) present in putrid blood. It is alsoformed in the putrefaction of proteid matter in general.
A colorless corpuscle, as one of the white blood corpuscles, orthose found in lymph, marrow of hone, connective tissue, etc.
The difference between the approximate result and the trueresult; -- used particularly in the rule of double position.
A projecting turret for a sentry, as at the salient angles ofworks, or the acute angles of bastions.
One who rents or leases an estate; -- usually said of a lesseeor tenant.
A genus of small marine bivalve shells, having a pearlyinterior.
Plaster as used in Persian architecture and decorative art.
Narrowed at the forward end; -- said of an automobile framewhen the side members are closer together at the forward end than atthe rear.
One who systemizes, or reduces to system; a systematizer.
A contemptuous nickname for a timid, yielding politician, orone who is easily molded. [Political cant, U. S.]
A stunted shrub, bush, or branch. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
The space between the columns and the wall of the cella, in aGreek or a Roman temple.
Weak in intellect; half-witted; silly. [R.] Bp. Kennet.
Fetid feldspar, a mineral which, when struck, exhales a fetidodor.
To force or let out of the proper vessels or arteries, asblood.
A canonical term for regular induction into a benefice,comprehending nomination, collation, and installation.
The general outward form of any solid object, as of a column ora vase.
A lovely maiden, daughter of a king and mistress of Eros, orCupid. She is regarded as the personification of the soul.
To affect excessive refinement in language; to be overnice inexpression.
One fond of his own notions, or unduly attached to his ownopinions. Glanvill.
An apparent right; as where the defendant in trespass gave tothe plaintiff an appearance of title, by stating his title specially,thus removing the cause from the jury to the court. Blackstone.
The art of preaching; that branch of theology which treats ofhomilies or sermons, and the best method of preparing and deliveringthem.
Honorably discharged from the performance of public duty onaccount of age, infirmity, or long and faithful services; -- said ofan officer of a college or pastor of a church.
Sewed or knit together; united by a suture; stitched.
Deprived of virility, or seminal energy; made a eunuch. [Obs.]
A Roman measure of land, measuring 28,800 square feet, or 240feet in length by 120 in breadth.
A long, covered walk, or a low, level building, where ropes aremanufactured.
A yellow coloring matter, soluble in ether, contained in thesmall round fat drops in the retinal epithelium cells. It is bestobtained from the eyes of frogs.
Turned back; reversed. Specifically: (Her.) Bent or curvedtwice, in opposite directions, or in the form of an S.
To fight with the fists; to box.Bruising was considered a fine, manly, old English custom. Thackeray.
A rapid pulsation; a throbbing; esp., an abnormal, rapidbeating of the heart as when excited by violent exertion, strongemotion, or by disease.
Migrating or passing from one place or state to another;passing from one residence to another.-- n.
A kind of coarse upper coat, or overcoat, formerly worn.
The apart or practice of measuring the diameters of heavenlybodies, their relative distances, etc. See Heliometer.
To change (one proposition) into another, so that what was thesubject of the first becomes the predicate of the second.
To make melodious; to form into, or set to, melody.
The horny covering of the end of the bill of birds.
Having no radiating processes; -- applied particularly tocertain nerve cells.
In electrotypy, the act or art of copying, in metals depositedby electrolytic action, a form or pattern which is made the negativeelectrode. [R.]
A class of Mollusca in which the anterior lobes of the foot aredeveloped in the form of broad, thin, winglike organs, with whichthey swim at near the surface of the sea.
Speedily; with haste or celerity; soon; without delay; quick.
Having the fingers united by a web for a considerable part oftheir length.
The act of hybridizing, or the state of being hybridized.
The anterior portion of any one of the Arachnida and higherCrustacea, consisting of the united head and thorax.
Ascending rivers from the sea, at certain seasons, forbreeding, as the salmon, shad, etc.
To study mineralogy by collecting and examining minerals. MissEdgeworth.
An alkaloid found in small quantities in opium, and extractedas a white crystalline substance of a bitter astringent taste. It isa narcotic. Called also narceia.
One who adheres to the letter of the Koran, rejecting alltraditions.
A slender European weed (Galium Cruciata); -- called alsocrossweed.
A device for automatically counting the revolutions orpulsations of an engine or other machine; -- called also simplycounter.

A thick, circular disk of wood, to which the cartridge bag andprojectile are attached, in fixed ammunition for cannon; also, apiece of soft metal attached to a projectile to take the groove ofthe rifling.
A machine for pressing the water from skins in tanning. Knight.
A peculiar distinguishing mark or device affixed by amanufacturer or a merchant to his goods, the exclusive right of usingwhich is recognized by law.
A small stone taken from the gizzard of a young swallow.-- anciently worn as a medicinal charm.
A telluride of silver and gold, related to hessite.
A group of birds, including auks, divers, and penguins.
The quality or state of being inflexible; inflexibility;rigidity; firmness.
Universal wisdom; esp., a system of universal knowledgeproposed by Comenius (1592 -- 1671), a Moravian educator. [R.]Hartlib.
Comely or decent appearance. [Obs.] Rom. of R. Spenser.
Consisting of a series of parallel cones, each made up of manyconcentric cones closely packed together; -- said of a kind ofstructure sometimes observed in sedimentary rocks.
An extinct order of reptiles which stood erect on the hindlegs, and resembled birds in the structure of the feet, pelvis, andother parts.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the plant spinach, or thefamily of plants to which it belongs.
One whose occupation is to make and repair watches.
The sum allowed to a sheriff or other officer upon the amountrealized by an execution; -- estimated in England, and formerly inthe United States, at so much of the pound. Burrill. Bouvier.
Formed into texture; woven together; arranged; composed. [R.]Carlyle.
Inherent baseness or vileness of principle, words, or actions;shameful wickedness; depravity. Shak.
A sportsman who pursues wild fowl, or takes or kills for food.
To unite in compact, as different States; to confederate forpolitical purposes; to unite by or under the Federal Constitution.Barlow.
Boastful; defiant; exulting. Also used adverbially.
One who maintains the theory of conceptualism. Stewart.
Same as Cordwain. in England the name is applied to leathermade from horsehide.
The bar, or crosspiece, of a carriage, to which the singletreesare attached.
Union by means of bone; the complete closing up andobliteration of sutures.
The radical KO, derived from, and supposed to exist in,potassium hydroxide and other compounds.
The fiery cross, used as a rallying signal in the Highlands ofScotland.
An instrument for measuring the voltaic electricity passingthrough it, by its effect in decomposing water or some other chemicalcompound acting as an electrolyte.

A genus of papaveraceous plants, found in California and uponthe west coast of North America, some species of which producebeautiful yellow, orange, rose-colored, or white flowers; theCalifornia poppy.

To present an answer, by allegation of fact, to the declarationof a plaintiff; to deny the plaintiff's declaration and demand, or toallege facts which show that ought not to recover in the suit; in aless strict sense, to make an allegation of fact in a cause; to carryon the allegations of the respective parties in a cause; to carry ona suit or plea. Blackstone. Burrill. Stephen.

An advocate of confederation; specifically (Amer. Hist.), afriend of the Constitution of the United States at its formation andadoption; a member of the political party which favored theadministration of president Washington.
Hopelessly insensible or stupid; not easily aroused or excited;dull; impassive; foolish.
A variety of pyroxene of olive-green color passing into brown.It contains zinc.

The act, art, or practice of speaking in such a manner that thevoice appears to come, not from the person speaking, but from someother source, as from the opposite side of the room, from the cellar,etc.
Transparent, or semitransparent, colors passed thinly overother colors, to modify the effect.
A reddish fleshy herb of the genus Monotropa (M. hypopitys),formerly thought to be parasitic on the roots of pine trees, but moreprobably saprophytic.
Departing from the main subject; partaking of the nature ofdigression. Johnson.
A leguminous herb (Astragalus glycyphyllos) of Europe and Asia,supposed to increase the secretion of milk in goats.
To comb; also, to beat; to worry. [Obs. or Local] See Feaze, v.
A game of chance, in which four sea shells, each called a prop,are used instead of dice.
To merge again. "Remerging in the general Soul." Tennyson.

A writ to restrain a person from leaving the country, or thejurisdiction of the court. The writ was originally applicable topurposes of state, but is now an ordinary process of courts ofequity, resorted to for the purpose of obtaining bail, or security toabide a decree. Kent.
A collection of names and terms; a dictionary; specif., acollection of Greek names, with explanatory notes, made by JuliusPollux about A.D.180.
A product of the gastric and pancreatic digestion of albuminousmatter.
Of or pertaining to crimination; tending to incriminate;criminatory.
The part of a polariscope which receives the light afterpolarization, and exhibits its properties.
An acid amide derived from lactic acid, and obtained as a whitecrystalline substance having a neutral reaction. It is metameric withalanine.
The fourth joint of a typical appendage of Crustacea.
One learned in the classics; an advocate for the classics.
One who rides a bicycle or tricycle; a cycler, or cyclist.
The back part of the neck; the scruff. [Prov. Eng.] Ld. Lytton.

The three divisions, or "baskets" (pitakas), of buddhistscriptures, -- the Vinayapitaka [Skr. Vinayapitsaka] , or Basket ofDiscipline; Suttapitaka [Pali] , or Basket of Discourses; andAbhidhammapitaka [Pali] , or Basket of Metaphysics.
To ascend or creep upward by twining about a support, or byattaching itself by tendrills, rootlets, etc., to a support orupright surface.
A small South African antelope (Cephalous mergens); -- calledalso impoon, and deloo.
A place or an establishment where bleaching is done.
The business, the place of business, or the goods, of a makerof, or dealer in, oils.

A large estate where work of any kind is done, as agriculture,manufacturing, mining, or raising of animals; a cultivated farm, witha good house, in distinction from a farming establishment with rudehuts for herdsmen, etc.; -- a word used in Spanish-American regions.1.
The triangular middle part of each segment of the shell of abarnacle.
A dish made of fowls, veal, or other meat of small animals cutinto pieces, and stewed in a gravy.
One of a sect in the early Christian church which rejected thedoctrine of the Trinity; -- called also patripassian.
The chipmunk; also, the chickaree or red squirrel. [U.S.]
To supply; to afford; to subminister. [Obs.] Harvey.
A small spoon used in stirring and sipping tea, coffee, etc.,and for other purposes.
To force; to constrain; to compel to yield. [Obs.] Spenser.
An instrument which shows whether there is more or lessmoisture in the atmosphere, without indicating its amount.
The arrangement or system of veins, as in the wing of aninsect, or in the leaves of a plant. See Illust. in Appendix.
A club or company organized for singing glees, and (byextension) part songs, ballads, etc.
Capable of having an oath administered to. [Obs.] Shak.

A mode of arresting hemorrhage resulting from wounds orsurgical operations, by passing under the divided vessel a needle,the ends of which are left exposed externally on the cutaneoussurface. Simpson.
The quality of being intolerable; intolerableness. [R.]
To import or export in violation of the customs laws.
A child born of a white father and Indian mother. [S. Amer.]
With that violation of law called a rout. See 5th Rout, 4.
Having more than one axis; developing in more than a singleline or plain; -- opposed to Ant: monoaxial.
A laboring man; a man who earns his daily support by manuallabor.
Of or pertaining to the monitorial system of instructionfollowed by Joseph Lancaster, of England, in which advanced pupils ina school teach pupils below them.
A sauce, made of vinegar, oil, and other ingredients, -- usedesp. for cold meats.
The lower or apparently anterior petal of an orchidaceousflower, often of a very curious shape.
A genus of plants, some species of which are cultivated fortheir beautiful flowers; day lily.
A newspaper; a printed sheet published periodically; esp., theofficial journal published by the British government, and containinglegal and state notices.

A style of ornamentation either painted, inlaid, or carved inlow relief. It consists of a pattern in which plants, fruits,foliage, etc., as well as figures of men and animals, real orimaginary, are fantastically interlaced or put together.
Disturbance of quiet in body or mind; restlessness; uneasiness.Hooker.
Imitation parchment, made by soaking unsized paper in dilutesulphuric acid.
One who pronounces, utters, or declares; also, a pronouncingbook.
Belonging to, or in the style of, Tully (Marcus TulliusCicero).
The first month of the year, containing thirty-one days.
A handsaw with coarse teeth which have but a slight set, usedfor cutting wood in the direction of the fiber; -- called alsoripping saw.
A fleshy-leaved herb (Rhodiola rosea); rosewort; -- so calledbecause the roots have the odor of roses.
A yellow substance obtained as a by-product in the manufactureof rosaniline. It dyes silk a fine golden-yellow color.
A piece of ground taken out of any regular ground plot orfloor, so as to make a court, yard, etc.; -- sometimes written quink.Gwilt.
To bring back a metal to the metallic form, as from an oxide orsolution; to reduce. [Obs.]

The formation of words in imitation of sounds; a figure ofspeech in which the sound of a word is imitative of the sound of thething which the word represents; as, the buzz of bees; the hiss of agoose; the crackle of fire.

The art or practice of using the manual alphabet or ofcommunicating thoughts by sings made by the hands and fingers; asubstitute for spoken or written language in intercourse with thedeaf and dumb. See Dactylalogy.
The quality of being injurious or hurtful; harmfulness; injury.
The act of reproaching one's self; censure by one's ownconscience.

A drop measurer; a glass tube tapering to a small orifice atthe point, and having a bulb in the middle, used for finding thenumber of drops in equal quantities of different liquids. SeePipette. Sir D. Brewster.
One who makes or enacts a law or system of laws; a legislator.
A vain or blustering boaster; a braggart; a braggadocio. Sir T.Herbert.
A crinoid of the genus Antedon and related genera. When youngthey are fixed by a stem. When adult they become detached and clingto seaweeds, etc., by their dorsal cirri; -- called also featherstars.
A kind of mirage by which distant objects appear inverted,distorted, displaced, or multiplied. It is noticed particularly atthe Straits of Messina, between Calabria and Sicily.
Pertaining to, or resembling, a telegram; laconic; concise;brief. [R.]
An accessory plume arising from the posterior side of the stemof the contour feathers of many birds; -- called also aftershaft. SeeIllust. of Feather.
An exchange, or place where merchants, bankers, etc., meet forbusiness at certain hours; esp., the Stock Exchange of Paris.
Having greater length than breadth, esp. when rectangular.
The laying of the first courses of stone in a foundation.[Eng.]
One of the larger measures of force, amounting to one milliondynes.
Of or pertaining to physic nuts, the seeds of plants of thegenus Jatropha.
Distance of any heavenly body south of the equator; southdeclination; south latitude.
The arch or rib which crosses a Gothic vault diagonally.
An extinct order of marine reptiles, including Ichthyosaurusand allied forms; -- called also Ichthyopterygia. They have not beenfound later than the Cretaceous period.
The act of dividing or opening; the state of being fissured.
A photographic picture taken on an iron plate by a collodionprocess; -- familiarly called tintype.
Branching so that the stem is lost in branches, as in mostdeciduous trees. Gray.
The region of the skull, in the temporal fossa back of theorbit, where the great wing of the sphenoid, the temporal, theparietal, and the frontal hones approach each other.
Any grouse of the genus Lagopus, of which numerous species areknown. The feet are completely feathered. Most of the species arebrown in summer, but turn white, or nearly white, in winter.
A whitish, granular rock, consisting of feldspar and quartzintimately mixed; -- sometimes called whitestone, and leptynite.

Of or pertaining to Ulric Zwingli (1481-1531), the reformer ofGerman Switzerland, who maintained that in the Lord's Supper the truebody of Christ is present by the contemplation of faith but not inessence or reality, and that the sacrament is a memorial withoutmystical elements. -- n.
A certain possible event that may or may not happen, by which,when happening, some particular title may be affected.

Any plant of the genus Drosera, low bog plants whose leaves arebeset with pediceled glands which secrete a viscid fluid thatglitters like dewdrops and attracts and detains insects. After aninsect is caught, the glands curve inward like tentacles and the leafdigests it. Called also lustwort.
Self-heating; warmed, as the body of animal, by process goingon within itself.
A lining of planks or boards (rarely of metal) for protectingan embankment.
A species of merganser (M. merganser) of Northern Europe andAmerica; -- called also merganser, dundiver, sawbill, sawneb,shelduck, and sheldrake. See Merganser.
To give strength or support to; to confirm. [Obs.] Fuller.
The act of redarguing; refutation. [Obs. or R.] Bacon.
Not having good repute; disreputable; disgraceful; inglorius.[R.] Shak.
The triangular, or maioid, crabs. See Illust. under Maioid, andIllust. of Spider crab, under Spider.
The act of ingrafting a sprig or shoot of one tree intoanother, without cutting it from the parent stock; -- called, also,inarching and grafting by approach.

A series of limestone strata found in Ohio and farther west,presenting bluffs along the rivers and valleys, formerly supposed tobe of one formation, but now known to be partly Silurian and partlyDevonian.
The first month of the jewish ecclesiastical year, formerlyanswering nearly to the month of April, now to March, of theChristian calendar. See Abib.
To cleanse, as open drains which are entered by the tide, bystirring up the sediment when the tide ebbs.
A duty paid to the king by the cognizee in a fine of lands,when the same was fully passed; -- called also the king's silver.
An instrument for determining altitudes by the boiling point ofwater.
A yellow crystalline substance having a peculiar unpleasantodor, resembling the quinones, and obtained from beechwood tar andcoal tar, as also by the oxidation of xylidine; -- called alsoxyloquinone.
An instrument for dividing lines, describing circles, etc.,compasses. See Compasses.
A mineral identical in composition with calcite or carbonate oflime, but differing from it in its crystalline form and some of itsphysical characters.
An igneous rock of semiglassy nature, having a luster likepitch.
Any tropical humming bird of the genus Petasophora, havingviolet or purplish ear tufts.
One of several shores used to hold a ship firmly and preventher moving while the blocks are knocked away before launching.
Gestation in the womb from conception to birth; pregnancy.Pritchard.
An outbuilding for washing, esp. one for washing clothes; alaundry.
A whoremaster; a lecher; a man who frequents the society ofwhores.

An albuminous body present in dead muscle, being formed in theprocess of coagulation which takes place in rigor mortis; the clotformed in the coagulation of muscle plasma. See Muscle plasma, underPlasma.
The omission of some person who ought to have been made aplaintiff or defendant in a suit, or of some cause of action whichought to be joined.
In its natural position or place; -- said of a rock or fossil,when found in the situation in which it was originally formed ordeposited.
A winding and circuitous way; a roundabout course; a shift.
The precincts within which a bailiff has jurisdiction; thelimits of a bailiff's authority.
Engaged in, or given to, seeing sights; eager for novelties orcuriosities.
Private grudge or quarrel; as, domestic simulties. [Obs.] B.Jonson.
Having to opposite curvatures, that is, curved longitudinallyin one direction and transversely in the opposite direction, as thesurface of a saddle.
A species of figwort or Scrophularia (S. vernalis), and otherspecies of the same genus, mostly perennials with inconspicuouscoarse flowers.
One who, or that which, blusters; a noisy swaggerer.
The act of upbraiding or taunting; a reproach; a taunt. [Obs.]Improperatios and terms of scurrility. Sir T. Browne
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a nitrogenous acid ofosmium, H2N2Os2O5, forming a well-known series of yellow salts.
Attachment to the system or doctrines of Moses; that which ispeculiar to the Mosaic system or doctrines.
Defamatory by denial of desert; derogatory; calumnious. Sir T.Browne.
Wearing a helmet; furnished with or having a helmet or helmet-shaped part; galeate.
The repetition of a word or phrase at the beginning and anotherat the end of successive clauses; as, Justice came down from heavento view the earth; Justice returned to heaven, and left the earth.
A well or opening, through the successive floors of a warehouseor manufactory, through which goods are raised or lowered. [U.S.]Bartlett.
Having small clusters of minutely branched coral-likeexcrescences. M. C. Cooke.
An embryonic cell which develops into a pigment cell.
A salt of fungic acid. [Formerly written also fungiate.]
The act or process of dwindling; a dwindling. [R.] Mrs.Oliphant.
The privileges, prerogatives, or retinue of a court. [Obs.]Bacon.
Disposed or likely to retrocede; -- said of diseases which gofrom one part of the body to another, as the gout.
A strap placed across a man's forehead to assist him incarrying a pack on his back. [Local, U. S.] Bartlett.
To make alien; to deprive of the privileges of birth. Locke.
Pennsylvania; -- a nickname alluding to its having been thecentral one of the 13 original United States.
Bowed in the form of an arch; -- called also arched.
To be guilty of; to offend; to sin against; to wrong. [Obs.]Chaucer.

One of the harmonics faintly heard with and above a tone as itdies away, produced by some aliquot portion of the vibrating sting orcolumn of air which yields the fundamental tone; one of the naturalharmonic scale of tones, as the octave, twelfth, fifteenth, etc.; analiquot or "partial" tone; a harmonic. See Harmonic, and Tone.Tyndall.
An instrument for registering the velocity of the blood.
The act of marrying, or the state of being married, threetimes; also, the offense of having three husbands or three wives atthe same time.
The sails on the mizzenmast, or on the stays between themainmast and mizzenmast. Totten.
Lydian stone; basanite; -- so called because used to test thepurity of gold and silver by the streak which is left upon the stonewhen it is rubbed by the metal. See Basanite.
To bedeck; to array or equip; to adorn. [Archaic] Milton.
Shaped like a boat; (Bot.) elongated and having the uppersurface decidedly concave, as the glumes of many grasses.

A coat of mail; especially, the long coat of mail of theEuropean Middle Ages, as contrasted with the habergeon, which isshorter and sometimes sleeveless. By old writers it is often usedsynonymously with habergeon. See Habergeon. [Written variouslyhauberg, hauberque, hawberk, etc.] Chaucer.Helm, nor hawberk's twisted mail. Gray.
The grand marshal of the old German empire, a dignity that tothe Elector of Saxony.
One of a coterie who exclude others; one who from real ofaffected fastidiousness limits his acquaintance to a select few.
Bent or turned abruptly inwards, or toward the axis, as thepetals of a flower.
Inflammation of the vagina, or the genital canal, usually ofits mucous living membrane.
The Muse that presides over eloquence and heroic poetry; motherof Orpheus, and chief of the nine Muses.
One who comes out or withdraws from a religious or otherorganization; a radical reformer. [Colloq. U. S.]
To deprive of soul, spirit, or principle. [R.] Shelton.
One who knows everything; hence, one who makes pretension togreat knowledge; a wiseacre; -- usually ironical. [Colloq. or R.]
A muscle that serves to raise some part, as the lip or theeyelid.
Consisting of four; requiring four participants. [Scot. orGolf]
A provisional group in which are placed a number of lowmicroscopic organisms of doubtful nature. Some are probably plants,others animals.
Resembling, or covered with a substance resembling, rust;affected with rust; rubiginous.
Full of dislike; disaffected; malign; disagreeable. [Obs.]Spenser.
Relating to what is now called the Plutonic theory of theearth, first advanced by Dr. James Hutton. Lyell.
To vote or vote with. [Obs.] "Suffragating tribes." Dryden.
A metamere of the vertebrate skeleton; an osteomere; avertebra. Owen.
Unyielding; insensible to argument; uncompromising; strict.[Collog., U.S.]
The act of interposing; interposition; intervention.
A tumultuous crowd of low people; a rabble. "Rude rablement."Spenser.
A shake or fissure between the annual rings of a tree, foundoftenest near the roots.
Pertaining to or designating, an acid of arsenic analogous topyrophosphoric acid.
Capable of being changed from a solid to a liquid state.
A kind of goggles, used to protect the eyes form glare, etc.
In consideration that; seeing that; since; because that; --followed by as. See under For, prep.
One who, or that which, stiffens anything, as a piece of stiffcloth in a cravat.
A thick piece of timber in the form of a knee, placed acrossthe stem of a ship to strengthen the fore part and unite the bows oneach side. Totten.
One of the series of boilers in which the cane juice is treatedin making sugar; especially, the last boiler of the series. Ure.
One to whom a fine of land was ackowledged. Blackstone.
The concluding part of an oration; especially, a final summingup and enforcement of an argument. Burke.
A small tree of the genus Citrus (C. Japonica) growing in Chinaand Japan; also, its small acid, orange-colored fruit used forpreserves.
Of or pertaining to photogeny; producing or generating light.
In general, that which is set off, from, before, or against,something; as: --
A group of Rhizopoda having a distinct nucleus, as the am
That which is more than temporal; that which is eternal. [R.]
The land belonging, or yielding revenue, to a parish church orecclesiastical benefice.
A plastic operation for making a new lip, or for replacing alost tissue of a lip.
Having or manifesting an exaggerated idea of one's ownimportance or merit.
The quality or state of being whimsical; whimsicalness.
A part of a machine or instrument which directs its motion oraction.
An instrument used by carpenters, joiners, etc., for laying offright angles off right angles, and testing whether work is square.
In plate armor, a suspended plate in from of the thigh. SeeIllust. of Tasses.
A raft or float, used principally on the Pacific coast of SouthAmerica.
A covering or inlaying of marble, mosaic, etc., attached to themasonry by cramp irons or cement.
The plant costmary, which was formerly much used for flavoringale.
The small apple-shaped or pear-shaped fruit of an Americanshrub (Pyrus arbutifolia) growing in damp thickets; also, the shrub.

Created by judges or judicial decision; -- applied esp. to lawapplied or established by the judicial interpretation of statutes soas extend or restrict their scope, as to meet new cases, to providenew or better remedies, etc., and often used opprobriously of acts ofjudicial interpretation considered as doing this.
Being of the first production; primitive; original. [Obs.]Ainsworth.
The office or position of a professor, or public teacher.Walton.
A species of flea (Sarcopsylla, or Pulex, penetrans), whichburrows beneath the skin. See Chigoe.
Of or pertaining to the Glaucium or horned poppy; -- formerlyapplied to an acid derived from it, now known to be fumaric acid.

A plate the film of which retains its sensitiveness only whilewet. The film used in such plates is of collodion impregnated withbromides and iodides. Before exposure the plate is immersed in asolution of silver nitrate, and immediately after exposure it isdeveloped and fixed.
The seigniory, dignity, or lordship of a marquis; the territorygoverned by a marquis.
A European species of lavender (Lavandula spica), whichproduces a volatile oil. See Spike.
The space between two axes. See Axis, 6.The doors, windows, niches, and the like, are then placed centrallyin the interaxes. Gwilt.
Fit for plowing or tillage; -- hence, often applied to landwhich has been plowed or tilled.
To sprout; to bud; to shoot; to begin to vegetate, as a plantor its seed; to begin to develop, as a germ. Bacon.
A substance found in the pollen of certain plants. [R.]

The testing of a ledger to discover whether the debits andcredits balance, by finding whether the sum of the personal creditsincreased by the difference between the debit and credit sums in themerchandise and other impersonal accounts equals the sum of personaldebits. The equality would not show that the items were all correctlyposted.
The state or quality of being heavy in its various senses;weight; sadness; sluggishness; oppression; thickness.
A variety of albite, white and lamellar in structure.
Producing cells; -- applied esp. to lymphatic, or adenoid,tissue.
A moaning or sighing sound or noise; a sough. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Of or pertaining to a catechism, having the form of questionsand answers; catechical.
An unexplained epithet used by Chaucer in reference to ships.By some it is defined as "dancing (on the wave)"; by others as"opposing," "warlike." T. R. Lounsbury.
Lying down; -- used of beasts of the chase, as couchant is ofbeasts of prey.
A South African antelope (Alcelaphus albifrons), having a largewhite spot on the forehead.
To yoke or harness, as oxen to a vehicle. [South Africa]
A portion of dead bone which becomes separated from the soundportion, as in necrosis.
Higher than, or beyond the sphere of, the organic. Sir W.Hamilton.
A union, association, or society; -- used in names of Germanorganizations.
A wind instrument or pipe, with a horn at each end, -- used inWales.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, emotion or suffering. [R.]Chalmers.
A kind of latch whose bolt may be so locked by a detent that itcan not be opened from the inside by the handle, or from the outsideby the latch key. Knight.
The science or art of delineating objects according to the lawsof perspective; the theory of perspective.
The process of corroding or eating into metallic plates, bymeans of an acid. See Etch. G. Francis.
Once more; again; -- used by the auditors and spectators ofplays, concerts, and other entertainments, to call for a repetitionof a particular part.
The spasmodic ejection of matter from the stomach through themouth.
The Diet, or House of Representatives, of the German empire,which is composed of members elected for a term of three years by thedirect vote of the people. See Bundesrath.

an organic acid, C3O3N3H3, first obtained by heating uric acidor urea, and called pyrouric acid; afterwards obtained from isocyanicacid. It is a white crystalline substance, odorless and almosttasteless; -- called also tricarbimide.
To send in; to inject; to infuse; -- the correlative of emit.[R.] Boyle.
A small shield, especially one of an approximately ellipticform, or crescent-shaped.
The quality or state or being torpescent; torpidness; numbness;stupidity.
The main part of either auricle of the heart as distinct fromthe auricular appendix. Also, the whole articular portion of theheart.
Any unit of the total obtained by adding the passenger milesand ton miles in a railroad's transportation for a given period; -- aterm and practice of restricted or erroneous usage.
A distinct articulation given in playing quick notes on theflute, by striking the tongue against the roof of the mouth; double-tonguing.
A facsimile plate made by electrotypy for use in printing;also, an impression or print from such plate. Also used adjectively.
A liquid or semiliquid preparation of a consistence thinnerthan an ointment, applied to the skin by friction, esp. one used as asedative or a stimulant.
In wrestling, a hold by which one's opponent is choked. It isusually not allowed.
Restrained by one's self or itself; restrained by one's ownpower or will.
A diffusible substance formed from albumin by the action ofnatural or artificial gastric juice. See Peptone.
Cell-like; -- applied to the corpuscles of lymph, blood, chyle,etc.
The tonic or first tone of the scale in which a piece orpassage is written; the fundamental tone of the chord, to which allthe modulations of the piece are referred; -- called also key tone.
An animal or plant which is much below the ordinary size of itsspecies or kind; especially, a diminutive human being.
A mode of etching upon metals by electrolytic action.
A petition; esp., a written one, with a certificate that theconditions have been complied with.
An Australian honeysucker (Myzomela sanguineolata); -- socalled from the bright red color of the male bird.
Having a margin distinct in appearance or structure.
The condition of being nebulated; also, a clouded, or ill-defined, color mark.
Ethane; -- sometimes so called because regarded as consistingof two methyl radicals. See Ethane.
Serving to indicate the presence or the amount of ozone.
A gaseous hydrocarbon, C3H4, homologous with acetylene;propine. CH3.C.CH
The quality or state of being prim; affected formality orniceness; preciseness; stiffness.
Quality or state of being volcanic; volcanic power.
In a bibulous manner; with profuse imbibition or absorption. DeQuincey.
An order of teleostean fishes, having the gills arranged intufts on the branchial arches, as the Hippocampus and pipefishes.
Originally, a solid exterior angle, as of a building; now,commonly, one of the selected pieces of material by which the corneris marked.
A kind of ocher which is used in some parts of England inmarking sheep. [Prov. Eng.]
An instrument signaling the correct time to distant points byelectricity.
. A color of cloth formerly made in Lincoln, England; the clothitself.
Exhibiting interference figures without the aid of apolariscope, as certain crystals.
A genus of perennial herbs (Iris) with swordlike leaves andlarge three-petaled flowers often of very gay colors, but probablywhite in the plant first chosen for the royal French emblem.
Hardware; a general name for all articles made of iron. Gwilt.
The science of the determination of the density of vapors andgases.
The decimal point; the dot placed at the left of a decimalfraction, to separate it from the whole number which it follows. Theterm is sometimes also applied to other marks of separation.

Designating an internal-combustion engine of a type resemblingthe Diesel engine in using as fuel heavy oil which is injected in aspray just before the end of the compression stroke and is firedwithout electrical ignition. The fuel is sprayed into an iron box(called a hot bulb or hot pot) opening into the combustion chamber,and heated for ignition by a blast-lamp until the engine is running,when it is, ordinarily, kept red hot by the heat of combustion.
The murder of one's sister; also, one who murders or killsone's own sister. Johnson.
The principles or practice of conventionalizing. SeeConventionalize, v. t.
Greater, in respect to scales, intervals, etc., when used inopposition to minor; major. Moore (Encyc. of Music).
The tenets of the Church of Rome; the Roman Catholic religion.
A sweat accompanied by a discharge of blood; a disease, calledsweating sickness, formerly prevalent in England and other countries.
In a continent manner; chastely; moderately; temperately.
An instrument for measuring the degree of rarefaction of aircontained in the receiver of an air pump. [Spelt also elaterometer.]
A breed of sheep originally from Spain, noted for the finenessof its wool.
Having several bellies; -- applied to muscles which are made upof several bellies separated by short tendons.
Of pertaining to, or conferring, a commission; conferred by acommission or warrant. [R.]Delegate or commissionary authority. Bp. Hall.
A hydrocarbon radical, CH2.(CO)2, from malonic acid.
A platform of a staircase where the stair turns at a rightangle only. See Halfpace.
One who vamps; one who pieces an old thing with something new;a cobbler.
One who, or that which, proscribes, denounces, or prohibits.
Capable of being moved by entreaty; pitiful; tender. Milton.
An officer who has charge of a ballot box. [Obs.] Harrington.
A genus of ground beetles, including numerous species. Theydevour many injurious insects.
Any one of numerous species of elasmobranch fishes of the orderPlagiostomi, found in all seas.
The state of being embodied; bodily existence. [Obs.] Dr. H.More.
Containing glands; consisting of glands; pertaining to glands;resembling glands.
The act of involving, or the state of being involved. LewWallace.
The state or quality of being isostatic. Specif. (Geol.),

A theory of the development of mammalian molar teeth. Theprimitive stage is that of simple cones, as in reptiles. The simplecone then developed a smaller cone in front and another behind. Next,a cingulum was developed, and the three cones became arranged in atriangle, the two smaller cusps having moved to the outer side inupper and to the inner in lower molars. This primitive triangle iscalled the trigon or trigonid and this stage the tritubercular ortrigonodont. The trigon being a cutting apparatus, an extension ofthe posterior part of the crown was developed in lower molars forcrushing, and a smaller corresponding part appeared in upper molars.Another large cone then arose, usually from the cingulum. In morecomplex forms, smaller intermediate cusps appeared.
Having a top, or head, shaped like the top of a covered wagon,or resembling in section or outline an inverted U, thus as, awagonheaded ceiling.

Lit., gilded youth; young people of wealth and fashion, esp. ifgiven to prodigal living; -- in the French Revolution, applied toyoung men of the upper classes who aided in suppressing the Jacobinsafter the Reign of Terror.

An American bird of the genus Cassicus, allied to the starlingsand orioles, remarkable for its skillfully constructed and suspendednest; the crested oriole. The name is also sometimes given to thepiping crow, an Australian bird.
A name added, for the sake of distinction, to one's surname, orused instead of it. [Scot.] Jamieson.
The power possessed by a substance to refract a ray; as,different substances have different refringencies. Nichol.
An offset where a wall or bank of earth, etc., retreats,leaving a shelf or footing.
A league of states of ancient Greece; esp. the celebratedconfederation known as the Amphictyonic Council. Its object was tomaintain the common interests of Greece.
The quality of being answerable, liable, responsible, orcorrespondent.
One skilled in simples, or medicinal plants; a simpler. Sir T.Browne.

Any Old Word rodent of the genus Hystrix, having the backcovered with long, sharp, erectile spines or quills, sometimes a footlong. The common species of Europe and Asia (Hystrix cristata) is thebest known.
The theory that the various forms of activity in nature aremanifestations of the same force. G. H. Lewes.
Having or producing nine pistils or styles; -- said of a floweror plant.
The longer of two diagonals, as of a rhombic prism. SeeCrystallization.
The connective tissue sheath which surrounds a muscle, andsends partitions inwards between the bundles of muscular fibers.
The principles, purposes, and methods of the Fenians.
The act of instilling; also, that which is instilled. [Writtenalso instilment.]
Either of two shrubs (Viburnum Lantana, and V. Opulus), socalled on account of their whitish branches.
Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the body of thesphenoid bone.
To sweep over or across; to pass over rapidly. [R.] Thomson.
The segment of the body of an insect to which the wings areattached; the thorax. Kirby.
A genus of marine gastropod mollusks, having a conical orlimpetlike shell, with an opening at the apex; -- called also keyholelimpet.
Having no weight; imponderable; hence, light. Shak.
The quality or state of being primary, or first in time, inact, or in intention. Norris.
An instrument of torture for compressing the thumb; athumbscrew.
Great anxiety accompanied by painful constriction at the upperpart of the belly, often with palpitation and oppression.

That form of electricity which is developed by the chemicalaction between metals and different liquids; voltaic electricity;also, the science which treats of this form of electricity; -- calledalso galvanism, from Galvani, on account of his experiments showingthe remarkable influence of this agent on animals.
A parish lying without the walls of, or in a remote part of, atown. Graunt.
A European mountain trout (Salvelinus alpinus); -- called alsoBavarian charr.
A lamp with lenses or reflectors to collect the rays of lightand throw them in a given direction; -- used in lighthouses.
A key used to raise, or throw back, the latch of a door, esp. anight latch.
A light powder used as a substitute for iodoform. It is acompound of iodoform and albumin.
A movable part of a rail; or of opposite rails, fortransferring cars from one track to another.

The projected spot or circle of light used to illuminatebrilliantly a single person or object or group on the stage; leavingthe rest of the stage more or less unilluminated; hence, conspicuouspublic notice. [Cant or Colloq.]
The branch of science which relates to the pressure andequilibrium of nonelastic fluids, as water, mercury, etc.; theprinciples of statics applied to water and other liquids.
A little shoot; a twig; a sucker. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
To furnish with a fringe; to form a fringe upon; to adorn aswith fringe. Fuller.
A dwarf supposed to dwell in rocks and hills and to be skillfulin working metals.
A mineral occurring in steel-gray flexible folia. It containsiron, nickel, and phosphorus, and is found only in meteoric iron.
Upraised; erect; -- said of the ears of an animal. Mason.
A broken gait of a horse, between an amble and a gallop; --commonly called a Canterbury gallop.
Arrest of development of any organ, so that it remains animperfect formation or is absorbed.
The office, jurisdiction, or duty, of a pastor; pastorate.
The act of relieving, or the state of being relieved; relief;release. [Archaic.]
The larval state (Phyllosoma) of the genus Palinurus and alliedgenera. It is remarkable for its strange outlines, thinness, andtransparency. See Phyllosoma.
Putting the whole foot upon the ground in walking, as somemammals.
To have an opinion; to judge; to think; to suppose. South.
Situated in front of the back; immediately in front, or on theventral side the dorsal part of the vertebral column.
That portion of fibrovascular bundles which corresponds to theinner bark; the liber tissue; -- distinguished from xylem.
The surface of the sand of one section of a mold where it meetsthat of another section.
The daisy (Bellis perennis). The name is often applied also tothe ox-eye daisy and to the China aster. Longfellow.
The act of disclaiming or rejecting; renunciation. Shak.
One who chooses; one who has the power or right of choosing; anelector. Burke.
A chain for slinging the lower yards, in time of action, toprevent their falling, if the ropes by which they are hung are shotaway.
The quality or state of being agreeable to the taste; relish;acceptableness.
A stated meeting of preachers and others, invested withauthority to take cognizance of ecclesiastical matters.
Empty talk; trifling loquacity; prattle; -- used in contempt orridicule. [Colloq.] Abp. Bramhall.
Examination of the abdomen or stomach, as with the gastroscope.
A unit of force equal to the force which, acting for onesecond, will give a pound a velocity of one foot per second; --proposed by J.D.Everett, an English physicist.
The quality or state of being unchristian. [R.] Eikon Basilike.
A tribe of North American Indians who originally occupied theregion about Green Bay, Lake Michigan, but were driven back from thelake and nearly exterminated in 1640 by the IIlinnois.
An iron attachment on one end of a mast or boom, with a ring,through which another mast or boom is rigged out and secured; awythe. R. H. Dana, Jr.
A mineral of a grayish-green or bluish color, consisting of thephosphates of iron, manganese, and lithia.
That portion of the soil formed by the decomposition of animalor vegetable matter. It is a valuable constituent of soils. Graham.
To make search; to try to find something. [Obs.] -- v. t.
Of or pertaining to spasm; spasmodic; especially, pertaining totonic spasm; tetanic.
The state of existing as three persons in one Godhead; trinity.
Allopathy; -- a term used by followers of Hahnemann, orhomeopathists.
To stick over, as with sharp points pressed in; to mark byinfixing points or spots here and there; to pierce.Truth shall retire Bestuck with slanderous darts. Milton.
By alternation; when, in a proportion, the antecedent term iscompared with antecedent, and consequent.
Combining theism and philosophy, or pertaining to thecombination of theism and philosophy.
An instrument for ascertaining the weight and length of anewborn infant.

A sort of riddle in which it is required to discover a chosenword from various combinations of its letters, or of some of itsletters, which form other words; -- thus, to discover the chosen wordchatter form cat, hat, rat, hate, rate, etc. B. Jonson.
Any species of very small woodpeckers of the genus Picumnus andallied genera. Their tail feathers are not stiff and sharp at thetips, as in ordinary woodpeckers.
Up to that time; before then; -- correlative with heretofore.

Diagonal; diametrical; hence; diametrically opposed. [Obs.]Sin can have no tenure by law at all, but is rather an eternaloutlaw, and in hostility with law past all atonement; both diagonalcontraries, as much allowing one another as day and night together inone hemisphere. Milton.

A contrivance for carrying objects from place to place; esp.,one for conveying grain, coal, etc., -- as a spiral or screw turningin a pipe or trough, an endless belt with buckets, or a truck runningalong a rope.

One of the Moravians; -- so called from the settlement ofHerrnhut (the Lord's watch) made, about 1722, by the Moravians at theinvitation of Nicholas Lewis, count of Zinzendorf, upon his estate inthe circle of Bautzen.
The second mast, or that which is next above the lower mast,and below the topgallant mast.
Relating to the creation, organization, and nutrition of livingorgans or parts.
The process of producing a representation of an object on wood,by photography, for the use of the wood engraver.
A plant of the family of grasses, and genus Bambusa, growing intropical countries.
A tribe of North American Indians, which formerly occupied theregion between the Wabash and Mississippi rivers.
The state or quality of being immature; immaturity. Boyle.
The person to whom any property is legally conveyed.
A division of birds, including the cranes, rails, etc.
A rheumatic affection of the muscles of the breast and forelegs of a horse, affecting motion and respiration.
Bread baked in a mold, and scooped out, to serve minces upon.Bishop.
The octave, or interval which includes all the tones of thediatonic scale.
A tin-white arsenide of iron, isomorphous with arsenopyrite.
A follower of the opinions of Molina, a Spanish Jesuit (inrespect to grace); an opposer of the Jansenists.
Not broken or fractured; unharmed; whole. [Obs.] Chapman.
The demandant in a common recovery after judgment. Wharton.
Of or pertaining to the muscles, and taking a spiral course; --applied esp. to a large nerve of the arm.
An American genus of perennial herbs with delicate blossoms; --sometimes called spring beauty.
Devouring knives; swallowing, or pretending to swallow, knives;-- applied to persons who have swallowed, or have seemed to swallow,knives with impunity. Dunglison.
To exalt to the dignity of a deity; to declare to be a god; todeify; to glorify.
A bird having a distinct band of color across the tail, as thehen harrier.
A number of sheaves set together in the field; a stook.
A perspective representation or general view of an object.
Having a rostellum, or small beak; terminating in a beak.
An old form of gunlock, as the flintlock, which ignites thepriming by a spark; perhaps originally, a matchlock. Hence, a gunhaving such a lock.
Any one of the small branches on a stag's head. [Obs.] Howell.
A condition of tonicity with respect to temperature.

The political morality taught by Confucius and his disciples,which forms the basis of the Chinese jurisprudence and education. Itcan hardly be called a religion, as it does not inculcate the worshipof any god.  S. W. Williams.
A vessel for holding or conveying water, or for sprinklingwater on cloth, plants, etc.
The root of a plant which penetrates the earth directlydownward to a considerable depth without dividing.
The quality or state of being utter, or extreme; extremity;utmost; uttermost. [R.]
The war cry, or gathering word, of a Highland clan in Scotland;hence, any rallying cry. Sir W. Scott.
One of the hereditary nobility among the Tatars, esp. one ofthe second class.
The examination or study of the soft palate, posterior nares,etc., by means of a laryngoscopic mirror introduced into the pharynx.
A variety of auction pitch in which the nine (sancho) and five(pedro) of trumps are added as counting cards at their pip value, andthe ten of trumps counts game.
Of or pertaining to the styloid process and the maxilla.
An instrument for copying drawings on the same or a differentscale; a form of the pantograph.
Possessed of properties similar to fibrinogen; capable offorming fibrin.

A very large marine mammal (Trichecus rosmarus) of the Sealfamily, native of the Arctic Ocean. The male has long and powerfultusks descending from the upper jaw. It uses these in procuring foodand in fighting. It is hunted for its oil, ivory, and skin. It feedslargely on mollusks. Called also morse.
A kind of stone containing native vitriol or subphate of iron,used in making ink.
A lamp provided with some arrangement for intensifyingcombustion by means of a blast.
A stone erected over a grave, to preserve the memory of thedeceased.
A Chinese alloy of nickel, zinc, and copper, resembling Germansilver.
To free from ballast; to discharge ballast from. Totten.
One who, or that which, cools or freezes, as a refrigerator, orthe tub and can used in the process of freezing ice cream.
Talk or writing which is weakly sentimental or affectedlypretty. Macaulay.
In Greenland, an insular hill or mountain surrounded by an icesheet.
Same as Drawbar (b). Called also draglink, and drawlink. [U.S.]
A genus of flying Insectivora, formerly called flying lemurs.See Colugo.
An amorphous carbohydrate found in the vegetable kingdom, esp.in unripe fruits. It is associated with cellulose, and is convertedinto substances of the pectin group.
A short musical dramatic piece, of a light and pleasing,sometimes a burlesque, character; an interlude introduced between theacts of a play or an opera.
Opposed to, or not in accordance with, the Holy Scriptures.
A written confession of faith; a formal statement of foctrines.
To honor, as some day, person, or nation, by a discharge ofcannon or small arms, by dipping colors, by cheers, etc.
Not lacerable; incapable of being torn or rent. [Obs.]
An alkaloid associated with cocaine in coca leaves(Erythroxylon coca), and extracted as a thick, yellow oil, having apungent taste and odor.
A large, dark-colored, South American monkey, of the genusLagothrix, having a long prehensile tail.
One who boozes; a toper; a guzzler of alcoholic liquors; abouser.
Trusting beforehand; hence, overconfident. [Obs.] Baxter.
An advocate for a metallic currency, or a paper currency alwaysconvertible into gold.
The Australian Eucalyptus Sideroxylon, used largely bycarpenters and shipbuilders; -- called also ironwood.
A pitcher-shaped, or flask-shaped, organ or appendage of aplant, as the leaves of the pitcher plant, or the little bladderliketraps of the bladderwort (Utricularia).

The bone or cartilage between the radiale and ulnare in thecarpus, and between the tibiale and fibulare in the tarsus. Itcorresponds to the lunar in the carpus, and to a part of theastragalus in the tarsus of man and most mammals.
A returning ascent or ascension; acclivity. Cowper.
To make indefinite; to obliterate or confuse the definition orlimitations of.
A genus of Lower Silurian trilobites in which the glabella andcheeks form three rounded elevations on the head.
Wearing, or entitled to wear, a coronet; of noble birth orrank.
A dish made in the West Indies by beating boiled plantain quitesoft in a wooden mortar.
The curve which on a given surface and with a given perimetercontains the greatest area. Tait.
An inversion of the natural order of words; as, echoed thehills, for, the hills echoed.
Not elaborate; not wrought with care; unpolished; crude;unfinished.
That part of a testeator's estate wwhich is not disposed of inhis will by particular and special legacies and devises, and whichremains after payment of debts and legacies.
The property possessed by some crystals, of showing differentcolors when viewed in the direction of different axes.
The person who selects the appointee. See Appointee, 2.
A kind of mental unsoundness characterized by extremedepression of spirits, ill-grounded fears, delusions, and broodingover one particular subject or train of ideas.
Titanium dioxide occurring in acute octahedral crystals.
The government or jurisdiction of a satrap; a principality.Milton.

A rare metallic element, of a silver white color, and lowspecific gravity (2.1), resembling magnesium. It never occursnaturally in the free state, but is always combined, usually withsilica or alumina, or both; as in the minerals phenacite,chrysoberyl, beryl or emerald, euclase, and danalite. It was namedfrom its oxide glucina, which was known long before the element wasisolated. Symbol Gl. Atomic weight 9.1. Called also beryllium.[Formerly written also glucinium.]
A kind of pad worn on the leg under the boot. [Obs.] Nares.
A substance which prevents or retards putrefaction, ordestroys, or protects from, putrefactive organisms; as, salt,carbolic acid, alcohol, cinchona.
A little lady; -- applied by the writers of Queen Elizabeth'stime, in the abbreviated form Lakin, to the Virgin Mary.
A genus of aroideous plants, of which some species arecultivated for their immense leaves (which are often curiouslyblotched with white and red), and others (in Polynesia) for food.
A substitution, as of one part of speech for another, of onegender, number, case, person, tense, mode, or voice, of the sameword, for another.
Having no drift or direction; without aim; purposeless.
Living upon the exterior of another animal; ectozoic; -- saidof external parasites.
To please; -- chiefly used impersonally. [Obs.] " Sith itlyketh you." Chaucer.
The of instilling; also, that which is instilled. Johnson.
A muscle having three heads; specif., the great extensor of theforearm, arising by three heads and inserted into the olecranon atthe elbow.
Any one of three metameric hydrocarbons, C4H8, of the ethyleneseries. They are gaseous or easily liquefiable.
A kind of fall apple, marked with streaks of deep red andorange, and of excellent flavor and quality.
A kicking back again; opposition; repugnance; refractoriness.
A present given to a guest or stranger, or to a foreignambassador.
A blood feud; private revenge for the murder of a kinsman.
An extinct flying reptile; one of the Pterosauria. SeeIllustration in Appendix.
To raise the anchor of, as a ship; to weigh anchor. [Obs.]Heywood.
Moderately cold; cold and raw or damp so as to cause shivering;causing or feeling a disagreeable sensation of cold, or a shivering.
To consign beforehand; to make a previous consignment of.
Cleft or separated into eight segments, as a calyx.
A fetter for horses, or cattle, when turned out to graze; --chiefly used in the plural.
The last syllable but one of a word; the syllable preceding thefinal one.
A long rope or chain by which an animal is fastened, as to astake, so that it can range or feed only within certain limits.
A large antelope (Alcelaphus bubalis) of Egypt and the Desertof Sahara, supposed by some to be the fallow deer of the Bible.
Formed with different shapes; having various forms; variform.
The principles of painting introduced by Raphael, the Italianpainter.
To admonish beforehand, or before the act or event. Bp. Hall.
A pearly crystalline substance obtained by the decomposition ofphillyrin.
The finest and whitest bread made in the Middle Ages; -- calledalso paynemain, payman. [Obs.]
That refractive condition of the eye in which the rays of lightare all brought accurately and without undue effort to a focus uponthe retina; -- opposed to hypermetropia, myopia, an astigmatism.
A tax or toll paid for building or repairing the walls of afortified town.

A morbid condition produced by exhalations from decayingvegetable matter in contact with moisture, giving rise to fever andague and many other symptoms characterized by their tendency to recurat definite and usually uniform intervals.
Reflecting a milky or pearly light from the interior; having anopaline play of colors.
To act secretly, or in an underhand way; to tamper. [Obs.]Wright.
A genus of prickly shrubs or small trees, the bark and rots ofwhich are of a deep yellow color; prickly ash.
One who acknowledges no head or superior. Dr. Gauden.
A dissertation or digression appended to a work, and containinga more extended exposition of some important point or topic.
An instrument of iron, with sharp prongs, attached to a boot orshoe to enable the wearer to walk securely upon ice; a creeper. Kane.
A house in which tender plants are cultivated and shelteredfrom the weather.
Among Spanish Americans, a foreigner, esp. an Englishman orAmerican; -- often used as a term of reproach.
A light skiff or rowboat used on the Bosporus; also, aLevantine vessel of larger size.
One of the oxides of manganese; -- called also gray manganeseore. It occurs in brilliant steel-gray or iron-black crystals, alsomassive.

A poweful vegetable alkaloid, found, associated withstrychnine, in the seeds of different species of Strychnos,especially in the Nux vomica. It is less powerful than strychnine.Called also brucia and brucina.
Having the surface appearing as if dusty, or covered with finedew.
A number of animals or plants living or growing together,beyond their usual range.
The liver of the lobster, which becomes green when boiled; --called also tomalline.
An instrument for measuring the size of the womb. Knight.
One who, or that which, continues; esp., one who continues aseries or a work; a continuer. Sir T. Browne.
To go ashore from a ship or boat; to disembark; to put ashore.
A yellow crystalline substance allied to pyrrol, obtained bythe distillation of gelatin.

An order of minute worms which usually have one or two groupsof vibrating cilia on the head, which, when in motion, often give anappearance of rapidly revolving wheels. The species are very numerousin fresh waters, and are very diversified in form and habits.
Having a sting; covered with prickles; sharp like a prickle.
Resembling trachyte; -- used to define the structure of certainrocks.
Spars or timbers set up as a support against the side of abuilding.
Promoting uterine contractions, or parturition.-- n.
An Englishman; a subject or inhabitant of Great Britain, esp.one in the British military or naval service. [Now used jocosely]
Apt to start; skittish; shy; -- said especially of a horse.[Colloq.]
A mode of tenure by the payment of a small duty in white rent(silver) or otherwise.
A copious gummy secretion of the humor of the eyelids, inconsequence of some disorder; blearedness; lippitude.
Of or pertaining to Napoleon I., or his family; resembling, orhaving the qualities of, Napoleon I. Lowell.
A chart or map on which the lines of the shore, islands,shoals, harbors, etc., are delineated.
The larva of any geometrid moth, as the cankeworm; a geometer;a measuring worm.
A scaly multiple fruit resulting from the ripening of an amentin certain plants, as the hop or pine; a cone. See Cone, n., 3.
One of numerous species of marine gastropod shells, belongingto Ranella and allied genera.
In a convenient manner, form, or situation; without difficulty.
One opposed to the diffusion of knowledge; an obscuriantist.
A list of passengers in a public vehicle, or of the baggage orgods transported by a common carrier on a land route. When the goodsare transported by water, the list is called a bill of lading.
A liquid hydrocarbon, C10H18, of the acetylene series. It isproduced artificially.
Having one strophe only; not varied in measure; written inunvaried measure. Milton.
One who does not conform to an established church; especially,one who does not conform to the established church of England; adissenter.
Incapable of being severed; indivisible; inseparable. DeQuincey.
A prickle growing on the bark, as in some brambles and roses.Lindley.
A native or resident of Cambridge; esp. a student or graduateof the university of Cambridge, England.
A figure of speech employed when a speaker having begun to saya thing stops abruptly: thus, "He is a man of so much honor andcandor, and of such generosity -- but I need say no more."
The act of reshipping; also, that which is reshippped.
Pertaining to ancient France, or Gaul; Gallic. [R.]
Befitting a church or a churchman; becoming to a clergyman.Shak.
A kind of antidote for poisons; a counter poison formerly invogue. [Obs.]
The modification of an articulation by contraction of the lipopening.
A little intoxicated; fuddled; stupid with liquor; bousy.[Colloq.] C. Kingsley.
One of the two bodies or nuclei (called male and femalepronuclei) which unite to form the first segmentation nucleus of animpregnated ovum.
The state or quality of being knowing or intelligent;shrewdness; skillfulness.
Of or pertaining to the pterygoid processes and the palatinebones.
A reckless, furious man; a person urged by furious passions,and regardless of consequence; a wild ruffian.
The act of entombing or burying, or state of being entombed;burial. Barrow.
The quality of being adequate; suitableness; sufficiency;adequacy.
To free from a gage or pledge; to disengage. [Obs.] Holland.
The removal by operation of a portion of a limb; particularly,the removal of a portion of a bone in the vicinity of a joint; theact or process of cutting out.
Of or pertaining to one or both of the trochanters.
The act of discoursing or reasoning; range, as from thought tothought. Coleridge.
A partner or associate in some civil or ecclesiastical officeor employment. It is never used of partners in trade or manufactures.

A beautiful variety of Brussels pillow lace made originally inBelgium and resembling Honiton guipure. It is worked with fine threadin large sprays, usually of the primrose pattern, with much raisedwork.
An extinct division of Hydrozoa which includes thegraptolities.
A morbid state produced by the use of iodine and its compounds,and characterized by palpitation, depression, and general emaciation,with a pustular eruption upon the skin.
The person in whose hands is the property attached byarrestment.
A rambling or ramble; a passage over bounds; an excursion.[Obs.] Howell.
A brownish black native hydrocarbon occurring in elastic orjellylike masses.
Leadership; preponderant influence or authority; -- usuallyapplied to the relation of a government or state to its neighbors orconfederates. Lieber.
Affording pabulum, or food; alimental. [R.]  Sir T. Browne.
A person much given to melancholy; a hypochondriac. I.Disraeli.
A nitrogenous hydrocarbon base, C13H9N, analogous tophenanthrene and quinoline.
Destruction; -- opposed to creation. [R.] Cudworth.
A ravine caused by heavy rains or a watercourse. [Texas & N.Mex.]
Containing hornblende in a scattered state; of or relating torocks containing disseminated hornblende.

A large Asiatic antelope (Budorcas taxicolor) native of thehigher parts of the Himalayas and other lofty mountains. Its head andneck resemble those of the ox, and its tail is like that of the goat.Called also budorcas.
The common feeling and interest of the Slavonic race.
A substance isomeric with, and resembling, indigo blue, andaccompanying it as a side product, in its artificial production.
To thrust oakum into (seams or chinks) with a chisel , thepoint of a knife, or a chinsing iron; to calk slightly. Chinsingiron, a light calking iron.
The top stone of the gable end of a house. Halliwell.

An extensive division of rhizopods in which the pseudopodia aremore or less slender and coalesce at certain points, formingirregular meshes. It includes the shelled Foraminifera, together withsome groups which lack a true shell.
The sensible or leading note, or sharp seventh, of any key;subtonic.
A stout silk having satin stripes, -- used for furniture.
In a natural manner or way; according to the usual course ofthings; spontaneously.
A hero, fabled to have been the son of Jupiter and Alcmena, andcelebrated for great strength, esp. for the accomplishment of histwelve great tasks or "labors."
A soft, whitish, coral-like stone, formed of broken shells andcorals, found in the southern United States, and used for roadbedsand for building material, as in the fort at St. Augustine, Florida.

An African ruminant (Camelopardalis giraffa) related to thedeers and antelopes, but placed in a family by itself; thecamelopard. It is the tallest of animals, being sometimes twenty feetfrom the hoofs to the top of the head. Its neck is very long, and itsfore legs are much longer than its hind legs.
Chopped meat, bread, etc., used to stuff legs of veal or otherjoints; stuffing; farce. Bacon.
A pot containing melted tin into which the plates are dipped tobe coated.
One who crucifies; one who subjects himself or another to apainful trial.
Vulgar affectation or ostentation; mean admiration of meanthings; conduct or manners of a snob.

An extensive series of strata, principally developed in theRocky Mountain region, as in the Laramie Mountains, and formerlysupposed to be of the Tertiary age, but now generally regarded asCretaceous, or of intermediate and transitional character. Itcontains beds of lignite, often valuable for coal, and is hence alsocalled the lignitic group. See Chart of Geology.
Of or pertaining to the tribe of ruminants of which the goat,or genus Capra, is the type.
To turn, or transfer homage and service, from one lord toanother. This is the act of feudatories, vassals, or tenants, uponthe alienation of the estate. Blackstone.
A portion ofthe printed sheet, in certain sizes of books, thatis cut off before folding.
A process from the middle of the scapula in some animals; thespine of the scapula.
A white, crystalline substance, obtained from also, byextension, any similar substance.
Pertaining to charcoal, or partaking of its qualities.
Having prominent and distorted or rolling eyes. Ascham.
The inward part of a building; the interior. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The framework of some pods, as the cress, which remains afterthe valves drop off. Gray.
A line, within a rotating fluid, whose tangent at every pointis the instantaneous axis of rotation as that point of the fluid.
With economy; with careful management; with prudence inexpenditure.
Animals having two hands; -- a term applied by Cuvier to man asa special order of Mammalia.
An instrument, principally used in cupping, containing severallancets moved simultaneously by a spring, for making slightincisions.
Promoting the discharge of bile from the system.-- n.
The quality of being diseaseful; trouble; trial. [R.] Sir P.Sidney.
Of, pertaining to, or in the region of, the backbone, orvertebral column; rachidian; vertebral.
A kind of overcoat worn upon the shoulders in the manner of acloak. [Scot.]
Temporary residence, as that of a stranger or a traveler. [R.]
Destitute of life; lacking animation; unanimated. Pope.

A peculiar malignant disease, occurring in parts of the westernUnited States, and affecting certain kinds of farm stock (esp. cows),and persons using the meat or dairy products of infected cattle. Itschief symptoms in man are uncontrollable vomiting, obstinateconstipation, pain, and muscular tremors. Its origin in cattle hasbeen variously ascribed to the presence of certain plants in theirfood, and to polluted water.
Reproving one's self; reproving by consciousness of guilt.
One of a special breed of hounds used for chasing foxes.
The twisting of a rope or cable, as it is running out. [Eng.]
A liquid hydrocarbon, C10H22, of the paraffin series, includingseveral isomeric modifications.
Omission; a figure of syntax, by which one or more words, whichare obviously understood, are omitted; as, the virtues I admire, for,the virtues which I admire.
Spontaneous or voluntary movement; movement due to an internalcause.
A substance that is not an electric; that which transmitselectricity, as a metal.
The stipe when developed into an internode between calyx andcorolla, as in the Pink family. Gray.
The art or practice of taking advantage of opportunities orcircumstances, or of seeking immediate advantage with little regardfor ultimate consequences. [Recent]
The grand division of the animal kingdom which includes thesponges; -- called also Spongida, Spongiaria, Spongiozoa, andPorifera.
Possessing the qualities of a prism, obliquely inclined to arhombic base; monoclinic.
A thin, sour beer, made by pouring warm water on rye or barleymeal and letting it ferment, -- much used by the Russians. [writtenalso quas.]
A plant that bears naked seeds (i. e., seeds not inclosed in anovary), as the common pine and hemlock. Cf. Angiosperm.
An ammonite; -- so called from its form, which resembles thatof a coiled snake.
The long jump, with weights in the hands, -- the most importantof the exercises of the Pentathlon.
A group of the human race, including the dark whites.
An instrument for making very thin sections for microscopicalexamination.
An interpreter; -- so called in the Levant and other parts ofthe East.
A kind of striped cotton fabric, usually of superior qualityand striped with blue or red on white.
The quality or state of being jovial. Sir T. Herbert.
A rumbling or gurgling noise produced by wind in the bowels.Dunglison.
To attack with heavy artillery; to batter with cannon shot.
A variety of dog, of remarkable ferocity, courage, and tenacityof grip; -- so named, probably, from being formerly employed inbaiting bulls.

A long, slender rope made of hemp or strips of hide, esp. onewith a noose; -- used as a lasso for catching cattle, horses, etc.,and for picketing a horse so that he can graze without wandering.[Mexico & Western U.S.]
A follower of Eudoxius, patriarch of Antioch and Constantinoplein the 4th century, and a celebrated defender of the doctrines ofArius.

The force exerted between the atoms of elementary substancewhereby they unite to form chemical compounds; chemical attaction;affinity; -- sometimes used as a general expression for chemicalactivity or relationship.
Pertaining to pot herbs; of the nature or having the qualitiesof herbs for cookery; esculent. Sir T. Browne.
Adhesion of the tail of a sheep to the wool from excoriationproduced by contact with the feces; -- called also tagbelt. [Obs.]
An extinct order of flying reptiles of the Mesozoic age; thepterodactyls; -- called also Pterodactyli, and Ornithosauria.
superl. Most remote; most in advance; farthest. See Further, a.
A contrivance for preserving a record of music, by recordingthe action of the keys of a musical instrument when played upon.
To make ready; -- often used reflexively. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The goddess of wisdom, of war, of the arts and sciences, ofpoetry, and of spinning and weaving; -- identified with the GrecianPallas Athene.
A nitro derivative of methane obtained as a mobile liquid; --called also nitrocarbol.
A dangerous inflammatory swelling of a horse's breast, justopposite the heart.
Any one of a series of nitro derivatives of phenol. They areyellow oily or crystalline substances and have well-defined acidproperties, as picric acid.
A European fish (Pagellus centrodontus); the sea bream orbraise.

An order of extinct mesozoic reptiles, mostly of large size(whence the name). Notwithstanding their size, they present birdlikecharacters in the skeleton, esp. in the pelvis and hind limbs. Somewalked on their three-toed hind feet, thus producing the large "birdtracks," so-called, of mesozoic sandstones; others were five-toed andquadrupedal. See Illust. of Compsognathus, also Illustration ofDinosaur in Appendix.
