To decompose by the direct action of electricity. Faraday.
Cylindrical with alternate swellings and contractions; havingthe surface covered with rounded prominences.
Abounding in, or resembling, chips; dry and tasteless.
A flat piece of metal; especially, a disk of metal ready to bestamped as a coin.
Having three bellies; -- said of a muscle. Dunglison.
Of or pertaining to an amulet; operating as a charm.
A part of the log. See Log-chip, and 2d Log, n., 2.
Of a harsh or stern countenance; hard-featured. Burke.
A conspicuous wild flower (Centaurea Cyanus), growing ingrainfields.
Having different essential qualities; of a different nature.
A custom of the Celts, or an idiom of their language. Warton.

A New Zealand starling (Heteralocha acutirostris), remarkablefor the great difference in the form and length of the bill in thetwo sexes, that of the male being sharp and straight, that of thefemale much longer and strongly curved.
Naked-fruited, the fruit either smooth or not adherent to theperianth. Gray.
Consisting of two pyramids placed base to base; having apyramid at each of the extremities of a prism, as in quartz crystals.
A wasting away; a gradual losing of flesh by disease.
A hypothetical radical regarded as the essential residue ofmyricin; -- called also melissyl.
The middle division of the small intestine, between theduodenum and ileum; -- so called because usually found empty afterdeath.
One who, or that which, seasons, or gives a relish; aseasoning.
The pocketing of the red ball in a top corner pocket from offits own spot so as to leave the cue ball in position for an easywinning hazard in either top corner pocket.
A colored albuminous substance in the serum from red-coloredmuscles. It is identical with hemoglobin.
The stud in which the bearing for the lower pivot of the vergeis made.
Cold as a metallic key; lifeless. [Formerly, a proverbialexpression.] Shak. Milton.
A follower of John Huss, the Bohemian reformer, who wasadjudged a heretic and burnt alive in 1415.
Having a separate and simple tendon to flex the first toe, orhallux, as do passerine birds.

One of a sect of rigid Anabaptists, which originated in 1637,and whose tenets were essentially the same as those of theMennonists. In addition, however, they held that Judas and themurderers of Christ were saved. So called from the founder of thesect, Ucke Wallis, a native of Friesland. Eadie.

One who theoretically rejects every form of religious faith,and every kind of religious worship, and accepts only the facts andinfluences which are derived from the present life; also, one whobelieves that education and other matters of civil policy should bemanaged without the introduction of a religious element.
Having the stamens and pistils in separate flowers. Gray.
To rise in value. [See note under Rise, v. i.] J. Morse.
A kind of divination drawn from the responses of oracles amongheathen nations.
A carriage hung on poles, and borne by and between two horses.Milton.
The act of bringing forth a child; travail; labor. Jer. Taylor.
A large ship of burden, in ancient Greece. Mitford.
Not purified according to the ceremonial law of Moses; unclean.
The practice of killing persons for the purpose of sellingtheir bodies for dissection.
Deprived of manly qualities; deficient in vigor, strength,courage, etc.; weak; effeminate.
A morbid state or condition not preceded or occasioned by anyother disease; a primary disease.
A very acrid herb (Ranunculus sceleratus) growing in ditchesand wet places; -- called also cursed crowfoot.
One of various plants, supposed to have efficacy in drivingaway fleas. They belong, for the most part, to the genera Conyza,Erigeron, and Pulicaria.
Any small book carried about for sale by chapmen or hawkers.Hence, any small book; a toy book.
To render rational; to free from radical signs or quantities.
The muscular and tendinous partition separating the cavity ofthe chest from that of the abdomen; the midriff.
A repetition of a word or of words at the beginning of two ormore successive clauses.
A blue-flowered labiate plant (Brunella vulgaris); the healall.

A musical instrument, resembling a small organ and especiallydesigned for church music, in which the tones are produced by forcingair by means of a bellows so as to cause the vibration of freemetallic reeds. It is now made with one or two keyboards, and haspedals and stops.
A byword; a proverb; also, a watchword. [Obs.] hak.
A ball or globe forming part of the regalia of an emperor orother sovereign. It is encircled with bands, enriched with preciousstones, and surmounted with a cross; -- called also globe.
A kind of cloth interwoven with small pieces of sponge andrendered waterproof on one side by a covering of rubber. Whenmoistend with hot water it is used as a poultice.
A plant with a conspicuous, dry, unwithering involucre, as thespecies of Antennaria, Helichrysum, Gomphrena, etc. See Everlasting.
A Buddhist priest of the higher orders in Burmah. Malcom.
A division of ciliated Infusoria, having fine cilia all overthe body, and a circle of larger ones around the anterior end.
A genus of wingless parasitic Hemiptera, including the commonlice of man. See Louse.
The act or state of bursting forth; a bursting out. [R.] Sir T.Browne.
The act of disfurnishing, or the state of being disfurnished.[Obs.]
Destitute of leaves, as the broom rape, certain euphorbiaceousplants, etc.
One who welds, or unites pieces of iron, etc., by welding.
An instrument for measuring and recording automatically therise and fall of a river.
A direction for the performer to return and recommence from thesign

A kind of oil formerly used in dressing the hair; -- so calledbecause originally obtained from Macassar, a district of the Islandof Celebes. Also, an imitation of the same, of perfumed castor oiland olive oil.
The state of being a cenobite; the belief or practice of acenobite. Milman.
A name sometimes applied to a member of any sect holding thatrebaptism is necessary for those baptized in infancy.
The office, or period of office, of an augur. Bacon.
One whose business it is to clean, extract, or repair naturalteeth, and to make and insert artificial ones; a dental surgeon.
Of, like, or pertaining to, a deer of the genus Rucervus, whichincludes the swamp deer of India.
A plant (Polianthes tuberosa) with a tuberous root and aliliaceous flower. It is much cultivated for its beautiful andfragrant white blossoms.

A squirrel-like animal of the genus Tamias, sometimes calledthe striped squirrel, chipping squirrel, ground squirrel, hackee. Thecommon species of the United States is the Tamias striatus. [Writtenalso chipmonk, chipmuck, and chipmuk.]
The proprietor or manager of a barge, or one of the crew of abarge.
A genus of African siluroid fishes, including the electriccatfishes. See Electric cat, under Electric.
A jocosely depreciative name for a dwelling or shop.[Slang,U.S.]
Of or pertaining to the grasses which are cultivated for theiredible seeds (as wheat, maize, rice, etc.), or to their seeds orgrain.
A Lenten dish, composed of eggs boiled hard, chopped, andseasoned with butter, salt, and pepper. Halliwell.
The act of displanting; removal; displacement. Sir W. Raleigh.
A gas burner with a device for lighting by an electric spark.
A digestive gland in Crustacea, Mollusca, etc., usually calledthe liver, but different from the liver of vertebrates.
The quality worthy or qualified to be chosen; suitableness;desirableness.
The solid or insoluble portion of the cell protoplasm. SeeHygroplasm.
Philosophical speculation and discussion. [Obs.] Sir W. Petty.
The operation of opening the fetal head, in order to effectdelivery.
Of or pertaining to the styloid process and the hyoid bone.
Typesetting of tabular nmatter, or the type matter set intabular form.
One of the dilatations of the body wall of Bryozoa in which theova sometimes undegro the first stages of their development. SeeIllust. of Chilostoma.
One who visualizes or is proficient in visualization; esp.(Physiol.),
A mineral, usually of a white or greenish color and pearlyluster, consisting chiefly of the hydrous silicate of alumina.
The act of incapacitating or state of being incapacitated;incapacity; disqualification. Burke.

Any one of several small American cyprinodont fishes of thegenus Fundulus and allied genera. They live equally well in fresh andbrackish water, or even in the sea. They are usually striped orbarred with black. Called also minnow, and brook fish. See Minnow.
An oil expressed from certain animal fats (esp. beef suet), thegreater portion of the solid fat, or stearin, being left behind. Itis mixture of olein, palmitin, and a little stearin.
The European sand ray (Raia maculata); -- called also home,mirror ray, and rough ray.
A species of steel imported from the East Indies, valued formaking edge tools; Indian steel. It has in combination a minuteportion of alumina and silica.
A low, spreading weed (Scleranthus annuus), common in sandysoil.
An infidel; -- a term applied by Turks to disbelievers in theMohammedan religion, especially Christrians. Byron.
A cabal, intrigue, faction, contention, strife, or quarrel.[Obs.] Chesterfield.
A small bronze mortar mounted on a wooden block with handles,and light enough to be carried short distances by two men.
To put to inconvenience; to incommode. [R.] Bp. Warburton.
A division of fishes including the perches and related kinds.
To make perpetual; to cause to endure, or to be continued,indefinitely; to preserve from extinction or oblivion; to eternize.Addison. Burke.
An erythematous affection of the skin, with severeconstitutional and nervous symptoms, endemic in Northern Italy.

A canticle (the Latin version of which begins with this word)which may be used in the order for morning prayer in the Church ofEngland. It is taken from an apocryphal addition to the third chapterof Daniel.
That part of optics which treats of the refraction of light; --commonly called dioptrics. Encyc. Brit.
Of or pertaining to Siam, its native people, or their language.
One who treats of ideas; one who theorizes or idealizes; oneversed in the science of ideas, or who advocates the doctrines ofideology.
Having the sandy brown color of the European larks.
Having the power of uniting; causing, or tending to produce,union. Jer. Taylor.
A constitutional disease characterized by the production oftubercles in the internal organs, and especially in the lungs, whereit constitutes the most common variety of pulmonary consumption.
The act of traducing; misrepresentation; ill-founded censure;defamation; calumny. [R.] Shak.
A hole through which a man may descend or creep into a drain,sewer, steam boiler, parts of machinery, etc., for cleaning orrepairing.
A folding stool, or portable seat, made to fold up in themanner of a camo stool. It was formerly placed in the choir for abishop, when he offciated in any but his own cathedral church.Fairholt.
A kind of aggregate fruit in which the ovaries cohere in asolid mass, with a slender receptacle, as in the magnolia; also, asimilar multiple fruit, as a mulberry.
A genus of large marine gastropods. having a pear-shaped shell.It includes the fig-shells. See Illust. in Appendix.
To toot gently, repeatedly, or continuously, on a windinstrument, as a flute; also, to make a similar noise by any means."The tootling robin."  John Clare.
One who toys; one who is full of trifling tricks; a trifler.
Doubly prostyle; having columns at each end, but not at thesides.-- n.
A smith who works at the vice instead of at the anvil.
Equivalent in combining or displacing power to two atoms ofhydrogen; dyad.
The open sea supposed to surround the north pole. Kane.
A method of forming a joint at the intersection of window-sashbars, by cutting away only enough wood to show a miter.
To render parallel to a certain line or direction; to bringinto the same line, as the axes of telescopes, etc.; to renderparallel, as rays of light.
The anatomy or dissection of the human body; androtomy. Owen.
The formation situated between the Permian and Lias, and sonamed by the Germans, because consisting of three series of strata,which are called in German the Bunter sandstein, Muschelkalk, andKeuper.
A hypothetical radical derived from ammonium by thesubstitution of metallic atoms in place of hydrogen.
The upper part of a horse's hoof, where the horn terminates inskin. James White.
A tribe of Indians native of the region between the Arkansasand Red rivers. They are related to the Pawnees. See Pawnees.
One contemporary with, but older than, another. [Obs.] Fuller.
The alburnum, or part of the wood on any exogenous tree next tothe bark, being that portion of the tree through which the sap flowsmost freely; -- distinguished from Heartwood.
Having only one slope or pitch; -- said of a roof.-- n.
A key for opening more locks than one; a master key.
Apropriate to the relation of neighbors; having frequent orfamiliar intercourse; kind; civil; social; friendly.-- adv.
An American tree (Juglans cinerea) of the Walnut family, andits edible fruit; -- so called from the oil contained in the latter.Sometimes called oil nut and white walnut.
Anemophilous; fertilized by pollen borne by the wind.
Consisting of chyle much diluted with water; -- said of aliquid which forms the circulating fluid of some inferior animals.
A suspension of arms by agreement of the commanders of opposingforces; a temporary cessation of hostilities, for negotiation orother purpose; an armistice.
A document, as a letter, deed, or will, wholly in thehandwriting of the person from whom it proceeds and whose act itpurports to be.
In an abominable manner; very odiously; detestably.
The science of rotary motion, or of wheel work. Wilkins.
An ornamental covering, as of carpet or leather, for a bench orform.
Belonging, or affected by, anasarca, or dropsy; dropsical.Wiseman.
Bearing silicles; pertaining to, or resembling, silicles.
An assemblage of upright stones with others placed horizontallyon their tops, on Salisbury Plain, England, -- generally supposed tobe the remains of an ancient Druidical temple.
The small, troublesome tumors or swellings about the anus andlower part of the rectum which are technically called hemorrhoids.See Hemorrhoids.
A bard, or learned man, among the ancient Goths. Sir W. Temple.
To hearten; to encourage; to incite. [Obs.] Spenser.
To change the nature of; to invest with a different or contrarynature. [Obs.]A right heavenly nature, indeed, as if were unnaturing them, doth sobridle them [the elements]. Sir P. Sidney.
A tribe of Indians formerly inhabiting the northern andweastern shores of Lake Superior; -- called also Objibways.
The defect of stammering; also, a kind of incompletepronunciation.
A carved ornament consisting of flowers, and leaves, intermixedor twisted together, wound with a ribbon, and hanging or depending ina natural curve. See Illust. of Bucranium.
Leading to sleep; -- applied to the illusions of one who ishalf asleep.
obs. 3d pers. sing. pres. of Shend, for shendeth. Chaucer.

A passing tone preceding an essential tone, and borrowing thetime it occupies from that; a short auxiliary or grace note onedegree above or below the principal note unless it be of the sameharmony; -- generally indicated by a note of smaller size, as in theillustration above. It forms no essential part of the harmony.
A switching engine the running gear and driving gear of whichare on a bogie, or truck.
The middle part of the alimentary canal from the stomach, orentrance of the bile duct, to, or including, the large intestine.
A salt of rhodanic acid; a sulphocyanate. [Obsoles.]
A measure of electrical quantity; the millionth part of onecoulomb.
In an irresolute, undecided, or hesitating manner.I am somewhat dainty in making a resolution, because when I make it,I keep it; I don't stand shill-I-shall-I then; if I say 't, I'll do't. Congreve.
A substance capable of producing with another a reaction,especially when employed to detect the presence of other bodies; atest.

One of a mixed white and Indian people living in parts ofTennessee and the Carolinas. They are descendants of earlyintermixtures of white settlers with natives. In North Carolina theCroatan Indians, regarded as descended from Raleigh's lost colony ofCroatan, formerly classed with negroes, are now legally recognized asdistinct.
Any climbing woody vine of the tropics with the habit of aliane; in the Philippines, esp. any of various species of Calamus,the cane or rattan palm.
A mineral occurring in transparent emerald green crystals. Itis hydrous arseniate of copper.
A very large species of frog (Rana Catesbiana), found in NorthAmerica; -- so named from its loud bellowing in spring.

A close garnment with straight sleeves, and skirts reaching tothe ankles, and buttoned in front from top to bottom; especially, theblack garment of this shape worn by the clergy in France and Italy astheir daily dress; a cassock.
To disinherit; to cut off, or detain, from the possession orenjoyment of an inheritance. [Obs.] Spenser.
A fabric made in Manilla from the older leaf sheaths of theabaca (Musa textilis).
The tribal history of organs, -- a branch of morphophyly.Haeckel.
A hydrocarbon, C14H10, related both to the acetylene and thearomatic series, and produced artificially as a white crystallinesubstance; -- called also diphenyl acetylene.
A lemur; -- applied to several species, as the White-fronted,the ruffed, and the ring-tailed lemurs.
The principles of the aristocratic party in Prussia.
One addicted to egotism; one who speaks much of himself ormagnifies his own achievements or affairs.
One of the teeth in the forepart of the mouth; an incisor.
A West Indian name for two large timber trees (Podocarpuscoriaceus, and P. Purdicanus) of the Yew family. The wood, which ismuch used, is pale brownish with darker streaks.
The temperature at which dew begins to form. It varies with thehumidity and temperature of the atmosphere.
Resembling a ladder; formed with steps. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
To dispose in due order, as the different quarterings on anescutcheon, or the different crests when several belong to anachievement.
Of or pertaining to the doctrine of philosophical necessity inregard to the origin and existence of things, especially as appliedto the actings or choices of the will; -- opposed to libertarian.
One of several things signified by a common term. Whately.
In a manner or to a degree that can not be repressed.
A plate of timber for the end of a beam or joist to rest on.Gwilt
1. One who follows; a pursuer; an attendant; a disciple; adependent associate; a retainer.
A primary division of gastropods, including those having spiralshells. The two sides of the body are unequally developed.
The governor of a province in ancient Persia; hence, a pettyautocrat despot.
An agreement between belligerents for the exchange ofprisoners. Wilhelm.
To moisten and rub (a diseased part) with a liquid substance,as with spirit, oil, etc., by means of a cloth or sponge.
A mixtire of caustic lime and orpiment, or tersulphide ofarsenic, -- used in the depilation of hides. Knight.
An intrusion of one vegetable cell into the cavity of another,sometimes forming there an irregular mass of cells. Goodale.
A ridge or projecting edge on a shoulder piece to turn the blowof a lance or other weapon from the joint of the armor.
Of, pertaining to, or containing, sulphur and arsenic; -- saidof an acid which is the same as arsenic acid with the substitution ofsulphur for oxygen.
A punishment sometimes used by the ancients, consisting in thebesmearing of the criminal with honey, and exposing him to insects.It is still in use among some Oriental nations.
Of pertaining to Canopus in egypt; as, the Canopic vases, usedin embalming.
A gaping after; eager desire; craving. [R.] Bp. Hall.
Possessed of the properties of chyle; consisting of chyle.
A kind of ornament consisting of a narrow fillet or bandfolded, crossed, and interlaced.
A tall weed with purplish flowers (Vernonia Noveboracensis).The name is also applied to other plants of the same genus.
The practices or conduct of a scoundrel; baseness; rascality.Cotgrave.
In the manner of a chorus; adapted to be sung by a choir; inharmony.
The plane in crystals of the monoclinic system which isparallel to the vertical and the inclined lateral (clinidiagonal)axes.
. A mode of marching by a body of men going one after anotheras closely as possible, in which the leg of each moves at the sametime with the corresponding leg of the person before him.
To cause loss or damage to; to injure; to imparir. [R.]This work will ask as many more officials to make expurgations andexpunctions, that the commonwealth of learning be not damnified.Milton.
A doctor or teacher in the Armenian church. Members of thisorder of ecclesiastics frequently have charge of dioceses, withepiscopal functions.
Having the character or appearance of both mucus and pus.Dunglison.
A piece of woodland; a small wood. [Obs.] See Holt.
To last beyond the year; -- said of annual plants. [Obs.]Bacon.
A duck (Cairina moschata), larger than the common duck, oftenraised in poultry yards. Called also musk duck. It is native oftropical America, from Mexico to Southern Brazil.
A bucket for removing mud from a bored hole; a sand pump.
The art of, or method for, assisting the memory by associatingthe thing or subject to be remembered with some place. [R.]
One of twe or more occupying the same room or rooms; one whoshares the occupancy of a room or rooms; a chum.
The conductir of a mule team; also, a head shepherd.

A spongy, combustible substance, prepared from fungus (Boletusand Polyporus) which grows on old trees; German tinder; punk. It hasbeen employed as a styptic by surgeons, but its common use is astinder, for which purpose it is prepared by soaking it in a strongsolution of niter. Ure.
The act of obtaining a favor by surprise, or by unfairrepresentation through suppression or fraudulent concealment offacts. Bp. Hall.

A condition of the nervous system in which an individual duringsleep performs actions approppriate to the waking state; a state ofsleep in which some of the senses and voluntary powers are partiallyawake; noctambulism.
The quality or condition of being viviparous. H. Spencer.
Opposed to the Americans, their aims, or interests, or to thegenius of American institutions. Marshall.
Of or performance to Argos, the capital of Argolis in Greece.-- n.
A chitinous membrane covering the exterior of many shells; --called also epidermis.
An instrument for exhibition or illustration of the phenomenaof halos, parhelia, and the like.
Of or pertaining to Whigs; partaking of, or characterized by,the principles of Whigs.
A style of bookbinding in which the back is plain leather, thesides paper or cloth, the top gilt-edged, but the front and bottomleft uncut.
One who takes care of baggage; a camp follower. [Obs.] Sir W.Raleigh.

Any of several plants bearing thorns or stiff hookedappendages, which catch and tear the clothing, as:(a) The greenbrier.(b) Any of various species of hawthorn.(c) In South Africa, one of numerous acacias and mimosas.(d) The grapple plant.(e) The prickly ash.
The order of fishes which includes the Gymnotus or electricaleel. The dorsal fin is wanting.
One of the processes of the shell which project inwards andunite with one another, in the thorax of many Crustacea.
The quality or state of being penetrant; power of entering orpiercing; penetrating power of quality; as, the penetrancy of subtileeffluvia.
A dwelling or standing on something; fixedness; persistence.[Obs.] Shak.
An aqueous solution of formaldehyde, used as a preservative inmuseums and as a disinfectant.
One who inlays, or whose occupation it is to inlay.

The heterodox Hindoo religion, of which the most strikingfeatures are the exaltation of saints or holy mortals, called jins,above the ordinary Hindoo gods, and the denial of the divine originand infallibility of the Vedas. It is intermediate between Brahmanismand Buddhism, having some things in common with each.

An instrument for the mechanical registration and reproductionof audible sounds, as articulate speech, etc. It consists of arotating cylinder or disk covered with some material easily indented,as tinfoil, wax, paraffin, etc., above which is a thin plate carryinga stylus. As the plate vibrates under the influence of a sound, thestylus makes minute indentations or undulations in the soft material,and these, when the cylinder or disk is again turned, set the platein vibration, and reproduce the sound.
A vivid, picturesque description of scenes or events.
An unlawful diminution of the possessions of another.
A tribe of edentates comprising the sloths. They are noted forthe slowness of their movements when on the ground. See Sloth, 3.
A tender to a fleet, formerly used for conveying men, orders,or treasure. [Spain & Portugal]
To take the saddle off; to unsaddle. [Obs.] Jervas.
A kind of sexual union; -- applied to a blending of thecontents of two or more cells or individuals in some plants and loweranimals, by which new spores or germs are developed.
Dropping off or disappearing early, as the calyx of a poppy, orthe gills of a tadpole.
A suborder of existing ganoid fishes having numerous fins alongthe back. The bichir, or Polypterus, is the type. See Illust. underCrossopterygian.
The basis or principle of a treaty which leaves belligerentsmutually in possession of what they have acquired by their armsduring the war. Brande & C.
A saclike envelope of certain fungi, which bursts open as theplant develops.
A favorite; a paramour; an ingle. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A cetacean allied to the grampus; -- called also bottle-nosedwhale.
One who, or that which, purges or cleanses; especially, acathartic medicine.
One whose wealth gives him power or influence; one of theplutocracy.
To have time before pleading; to have delay for mutualadjustment. Blackstone.
The state or quality of being irreversible; irreversibleness.
One prone to sound or excite alarms, especially, needlessalarms. Macaulay.
Deprivation of authority or dignity; degration. [Obs.] Jer.Taylor.
To laugh boisterously. [Colloq. U. S.]We haw-haw'd, I tell you, for more than half an hour. Major JackDowning.
A lighter, or vessel for inland navigation. [Scot.] Jamieson.
One who practices or advocates strict conformity to law; intheology, one who holds to the law of works. See Legal, 2 (a).
A massive and fibrous mineral of a whitish color, chieflyhydrous silicate of lime.
A person who insists on the importance of a regular successionof events, offices, etc.; especially (Eccl.), one who insists thatapostolic succession alone is valid.

A violent whirling wind; specifically (Meteorol.), a tempestdistinguished by a rapid whirling and slow progressive motion,usually accompaned with severe thunder, lightning, and torrents ofrain, and commonly of short duration and small breadth; a smallcyclone.
A remaking or recasting; an adaptation, esp. of a literary workor musical composition.

The transference of the relation between one set of objects toanother set for the purpose of brief explanation; a compressedsimile; e. g., the ship plows the sea. Abbott & Seeley. "All theworld's a stage." Shak.
The outermost of the three small auditory bones, ossicles; thehammer. It is attached to the tympanic membrane by a long process,the handle or manubrium. See Illust. of Far.
The unlaid or ragged end of a rope. Ham. Nav. Encyc.
An officer whose duty it is to observe what escheats have takenplace, and to take charge of them. Burrill.
A minute jointed filament growing among the archegonia andantheridia of mosses, or with the spore cases, etc., of otherflowerless plants.
Having no jointed legs; pertaining to Anarthropoda.
A mass of timbers built into the bow and stern of a vessel togive solidity.
A person employed to walk over and inspect a section of tracks.
A gradual oxidation from exposure to air and moisture, as inthe decay of old trees or of dead animals.
To make worse; -- the opposite of improve. [R.] Jer. Taylor.
Divided into many chambers by partitions, as the pith of thepokeweed.
A metallic post attached to electrical apparatus forconvenience in making connections.
A chloride containing more than one atom of chlorine in themolecule.
A failure to make claim within the time limited by law;omission of claim.
A collection of the Novels or New Constitutions of Justinian,by an anonymous author; -- so called on account of its authencity.Bouvier.
Of or pertaining to a dwarf tree; shrublike. Da Costa.
A medicine tending to cause parturition, or to give relief inchildbearing. Dunglison.
One that cruises or roves the sea for plunder; a sea robber; apirate; also, a piratical vessel.
A projection on the outer side of the distal end of thehumerus; the external condyle.
An inflammation of the membranes or coats of the eye or of theeyeball.
The art of treating diseases of the hands and feet.
A box of the lowest tier in a theater.  Du Maurier.
A mental act or process; especially: (a) The act ofunderstanding; simple apprehension of ideas; intuition. Bentley. (b)A creation of the mind itself. Hickok.
An instrument, originally a series of bells on an iron rod, nowa set of flat metal bars, diatonically tuned, giving a bell-like tonewhen played with a mallet; a carillon.
. A kind of pillow lace, remarkable for the beauty of itsfigures; -- so called because chiefly made in Honiton, England.
A woman who is chief; a woman who has charge of the work orworkers in a shop or other place; a head woman. Tatler. W. Besant.

A denomination of weight, containing 100, 112, or 120 poundsavoirdupois, according to differing laws or customs. By the legalstandard of England it is 112 pounds. In most of the United States,both in practice and by law, it is 100 pounds avoirdupois, thecorresponding ton of 2,000 pounds, sometimes called the short ton,beingthe legal ton.
A small, overhanging structure for lookout or defense, usuallyprojecting at an angle of a building or near an entrance gateway.
A petticoat; the foundation skirt of a draped dress.
A female sovereign who is independent and absolute; -- a titlegiven to the empresses of Russia.
To strike, as the breech, with the open hand; to slap.
An embryonic insect which has twice cast its skin previous tohatching from the egg.
Liable to be perturbed or agitated; liable to be disturbed ordisquieted.
That loss of character, or public disgrace, which a convictincurs, and by which he is at common law rendered incompetent as awitness.
A flounder (Symphurus plagiusa) native of the southern coast ofthe United States.
Table linen; also, linen clothing, or linen in general. [Obs.]Gayton.
Vegetable tissue composed of thin-walled rounded cells, -- amodification of parenchyma.
To furbish up for sale; to set off to advantage. [Obs. or R.]B. Jonson.
Inconsiderateness; thoughtlessness. [Obs.] Chesterfield.
Facing outwards, or away from the axis of growth; -- said esp.of anthers occupying the outer side of the filament.
A woolly filament sometimes occuring with the sporules ofcertain fungi.
One of the four principal forms of clouds. SeeCloud.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a sulphonic (thionic) acidderivative of methane, obtained as a stable white crystallinesubstance, CH2.(SO3H)2, which forms well defined salts.
An alkaloid found in opium, and extracted as a whitecrystalline substance, tasteless and less poisonous than morphine; --called also narcotia.

A figure by which an adjective or verb, which agrees with anearer word, is, by way of supplement, referred also to another moreremote; as, "hic illius arma, hic currus fuit;" where fuit, whichagrees directly with currus, is referred also to arma.
An inflammable mineral resin, usually of a yellowish browncolor, found in roundish masses, sometimes with coal.

A paper having on it these letters, with a sum named, and dulysigned; -- in use in England as an acknowledgment of a debt, andtaken as evidence thereof, but not amounting to a promissory note; adue bill. Wharton. Story.
A class of articulate animals, nearly equivalent to Annelida,including the marine annelids, earthworms, Gephyrea, Gymnotoma,leeches, etc. See Annelida.
A group of ruminants whose horns are hollow, and planted on abony process of the front, as the ox.
A military mechanic, as a blacksmith, carpenter, etc.; also,one who prepares the shells, fuses, grenades, etc., in a militarylaboratory.
One who sends telegraphic messages; a telegraphic operator; atelegraphist.
One who rejects of renounces upon oath; one who swears a falseoath.
Causing a discharge of water; expelling serum effused into anypart of the body, as in dropsy.-- n.
Of or relating to one of the early races in Mexico thatinhabited the great plateau of that country at the time of theSpanish conquest in 1519.-- n.
The permanent subject of qualities or cause of phenomena;substance.
A dealer in fells or sheepskins, who separates the wool fromthe pelts.
One who defames; a slanderer; a detractor; a calumniator.
The act of foreshowing; foreboding. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Situated below the glottis; -- applied to that part of thecavity of the larynx below the true vocal cords.
A genus of gamopetalous perennial herbs, including the Jacob'sladder and the Greek valerian.
A South African burrowing mammal (Suricata tetradactyla),allied to the civets. It is grayish brown, with yellowish transversestripes on the back. Called also suricat.
Whiteness. Specifically: (Astron.) The ratio which the lightreflected from an unpolished surface bears to the total light fallingupon that surface.
The quality or state of being literal; literal import.

Designating, or pertaining to, a linguistic stock of SouthAmerican Indians, including the majority of the civilized tribes ofthe ancient Peruvian Empire with some wild tribes never subjugated bythe Incas. Most of these Indians are short, but heavy and strong.They are brachycephalic and of remarkably low cranial capacity.Nevertheless, they represent one of the highest of native Americancivilizations, characterized by agricultural, military, andadministrative skill rather than by science or literature, althoughthey were adept potters, weavers, and goldsmiths, and preserved bythe aid of the mnemonic quipu a body of legendary lore in partwritten down since the introduction of writing.

The union of the four attributes of the Evangelists in onefigure, which is represented as winged, and standing on winged fierywheels, the wings being covered with eyes. The representations of itare evidently suggested by the vision of Ezekiel (ch. i.)
Humbled by consciousness of inferiority, unworthiness, guilt,or shame.
Of or pertaining to Havana, in Cuba.-- n. sing. & pl.
Quality of being separable or divisible; divisibility;separableness.
To make or become big; to enlarge. [Obs. or Dial.] Steele.
Capable of being governed, or subjected to authority;controllable; manageable; obedient. Locke.
Native copper sulphide, called also copper glance, and vitreouscopper; a mineral of a black color and metallic luster. [Formerlywritten chalcosine.]
Making an angle with some line or plane; -- said of a line orplane.
One of an ancient sect who rejected St. John's Gospel and theApocalypse, which speak of Christ as the Logos. Shipley.
That property of a body by which it occupies a portion ofspace.
An insect of the genera Lepisma, Campodea, etc., belonging tothe Thysanura.
The science or study of human generation, or the origin anddevelopment of man.
A plain, stout, lustrous silk, used for ladies' dresses and forribbon. Goldsmith.
A broad embankment of earth round a place, upon which theparapet is raised. It forms the substratum of every permanentfortification. Mahan.
The act of abolishing; abolition; destruction. Hooker.
The quality or state of being vacuous; emptiness; vacuity. W.Montagu.
The quality of being angelic; excellence more than human.
An unlawful bargain; traffic in which money is exported asdiscount. [Obs.] Bacon.
The mineral azurite, found in fine crystallization at Chessy,near Lyons; called also chessylite.
An instrument for determining and recording the quantity ofwater discharged from a pipe, orifice, etc., in a given time.
A perfumed powder sprinkled upon the body to mask the odor ofsweat.
Formerly, the largest boat carried by a merchant vessel,corresponding to the launch of a naval vessel.
Skillful in forecasting the changes of the weather. Hakluyt.
A monk of the reformed branch of the Benedictine Order, foundedin 912 at Cluny (or Clugny) in France.-- Also used as a.
The representation of natural objects, scenes, etc., in such away as to show their most important characteristics; the study of theideal.
Light, fuel, or food for the whole night. [Obs.] Bacon.
The position of the king when he can not move without beingplaced on check and there is no other piece which can be moved.
To diminish the quantity of; to lessen. [Obs.] Shak.
Any symptom or occurrence in a disease, which serves to directto suitable remedies.
One of the dark race inhabiting principally the islands ofEastern Polynesia. Also used adjectively.
A favorite gambling game among Spaniards, played with dice orcards.
A stuffed or quilted coverlet for a bed; a comforter; acomfort. [U. S.]
Long-continued contraction of the pupil of the eye.
Without an anchor or stay. Hence: Drifting; unsettled.
(Biol.) A cytode without a proper cell wall, but with anucleus. Haeckel.
An elephant goad with a sharp spike and hook, resembling ashort-handled boat hook. [India] Kipling.
An alkaloid extracted from guarana. Same as Caffeine.
An instrument for removing an explode cap from a cartridgeshell.

The C.G.S. unit of density of magnetic field, equal to a fieldof one line of force per square centimeter, being thus adopted as aninternational unit at Paris in 1900; sometimes used as a unit ofintensity of magnetic field. It was previously suggested as a unit ofmagnetomotive force.
A plant of the Mint family and genus Lycopus; esp. L.Virginicus, which has mild narcotic and astringent properties, and issometimes used as a remedy for hemorrhage.
A person who appoints another to act for him as attorney infact. Burrill.
A tropical genus of rubiaceous shrubs which often havebrilliant flowers.
A clerk who registers passengers, baggage, etc., forconveyance, as by railway or steamship, or who sells passage ticketsat a booking office.
In a way tending to or indication consumption. Beddoes.
Having or existing in three different phases of color; havingthree distinct color varieties; -- said of certain birds and insects.
To tempt exceedingly, or beyond the power of resistance.Milton.
A name given to an elementary book for learners of Latin orGreek. G. Eliot.
Short and rapid breathing; a panting; asthma. Glanvill.
A description of lichens; the science which illustrates thenatural history of lichens.
A Latin idiom; a mode of speech peculiar to Latin; also, a modeof speech in another language, as English, formed on a Latin model.
A peasant or cultivator of the soil among the Egyptians,Syrians, etc. W. M. Thomson.
An earthy black oxide of copper, arising from the decompositionof other ores.
The abnormal change of an irregular flower to a regular form; -- considered by evolutionists to be a reversion to an ancestralcondition.
Of or pertaining to a palinode, or retraction. J. Q. Adams.
To put in a state of agitation; to excite or alarm. H.Swinburne.
A combination of absinthic acid with a base or positiveradical.
The presiding priest who initiated candidates at the Eleusinianmysteries; hence, one who teaches the mysteries and duties ofreligion. Abp Potter.
The spotted sandpiper. See the Note under Sandpiper.
The offer by a party of what he has in view as to an intendedbusiness transaction, which, with acceptance, constitutes a contract.
The act or process of weaving together, or interweaving; thatwhich is woven together. H. Brooke.
A pyramidal form under the rhombohedral system, inclosed bytwelve faces, each a scalene triangle.
An exaggerated estimate of one's own importance or merit, esp.as manifested by the conduct or manners; self-conceit.
One of a breed of small terriers with long, rough hair.
The painting or piece of sculpture above and behind the altar;reredos.
A nitrogenous substance, forming a heavy, sandy powder, whiteor nearly so. It is a derivative of pyridine.
Any one of numerous species of Urodela, belonging toSalamandra, Amblystoma, Plethodon, and various allied genera,especially those that are more or less terrestrial in their habits.

A hard, compact variety of mineral coal, of high luster,differing from bituminous coal in containing little or no bitumen, inconsequence of which it burns with a nearly non luminous flame. Thepurer specimens consist almost wholly of carbon. Also called glancecoal and blind coal.

One who having made a profession of Christian belief,deliberately and pertinaciously refuses to believe one or more of thearticles of faith "determined by the authority of the universalchurch." Addis & Arnold.
Belonging to a creature; having the qualities of a creature.[R.]
A seaman, usually a green hand or a broken-down man, stationedin the waist of a vessel of war. R. H. Dana, Jr.
A term used to denote all of the elements or factors whichconstitute vitality or vital energy. H. Spencer.
Proper to be added; positive; -- opposed to subtractive.
That partiality to himself by which a man overrates his ownworth when compared with others. Kames.
A perennial herb (Gypsophila Struthium) the root of which isused in Spain as a substitute for soap.
A gallery or passageway leading to several apartments of ahouse.
Charging with crime; accusing; criminatory. R. North.
Something placed in a book to guide in finding a particularpage or passage; also, a label in a book to designate the owner; abookplate.
Covered with a hard chitinous case, as the pupa of certainfiles.
An extinct genus of Bryzoa characteristic of thesubcarboniferous rocks. Its form is that of a screw.
A white crystalline nitrogenous substance (C6H4N4O5) obtainedby the reduction of parabanic acid; -- called also leucoturic acid.

According to the French and American notation, a thousandoctillions, or a unit with thirty ciphers annexed; according to theEnglish notation, a million octillions, or a unit with fifty-fourciphers annexed. See the Note under Numeration.
Coalescence of particles; growth; increase by the addition ofparticles. [R.] Sir W. Raleigh.
Belonging to Hawaii or the Sandwich Islands, or to the peopleof Hawaii.-- n.
; sing Cayuga. (Ethnol.) A tribe of Indians formerly inbabitingwestern New-York, forming part of the confederacy called the FiveNations.
Examination of the ear by the aid of the auriscope.
A continuous colonnade or arcade; -- applied to the decorativegroups of windows, as in Venetian palazzi.
A radical, C27H55 supposed to exist in several compoundsobtained from Chinese wax, beeswax, etc.

Orig., in Germany, the cellar or basement of the city hall,usually rented for use as a restaurant where beer is sold; hence, abeer saloon of the German type below the street level, where,usually, drinks are served only at tables and simple food may also behad; -- sometimes loosely used, in English, of what are essentiallybasement restaurants where liquors are served.
A fast dyestuff, C20H8O6, made by heating gallein with strongsulphuric acid. It dyes mordanted fabrics green.
A European species of Saint John's-wort; the tutsan. SeeTutsan.
An order of extinct flying reptiles; -- called alsoPterosauria.
The quality or state of being revealable; revealableness.
The state or quality of being invisible; also, that which isinvisible. "Atoms and invisibilities." Landor.
A dyestuff, resembling alizarin, obtained from naphthoquinoneas a red crystalline substance with a bright green, metallic luster;-- called also naphthalizarin.
Having no aril; -- said of certain seeds, or of the plantsproducing them.
Of or pertaining to a theopany; appearing to man, as a god.
That portion of an electrical apparatus, in which is theinducing charge or current.
A gallery in a church, where persons watched all night.
The act of impersonating; personification; investment withpersonality; representation in a personal form.
Applied to the ovaries of insects when they secretevitelligenous cells, as well as ova.
One of the legal tender notes of the United States; -- firstissued in 1862, and having the devices on the back printed with greenink, to prevent alterations and counterfeits.
An instrument for recording the respiratory movements, as thesphygmograph does those of the pulse.
The pulpy mass of semi-digested food in the small intestinesjust after its passage from the stomach. It is separated in theintestines into chyle and excrement. See Chyle.
Of secondary origin; -- said of certain rocks whose materialhas been derived from older rocks.
Of or pertaining to palms; of the nature of, or resembling,palms.
A sacred inclosure or temple; -- so called by the islanders ofthe Pacific Ocean.
A short pike, sometimes carried by officers of infantry,sometimes used in boarding ships; a spontoon. Tatler.

A rare element of the light platinum group. It is found inplatinum ores, and obtained free as a white inert metal which it isvery difficult to fuse. Symbol Rh. Atomic weight 104.1. Specificgravity 12.
Having the sensibilities deadened by excess or frequency ofenjoyment; sated or surfeited with pleasure; used up.
An artificial ulcer, usually made in the fleshy part of the armor leg, to produce the secretion and discharge of pus for the reliefof some affected part.
The bark, or a vegetable extract brought in solid cakes fromSouth America and believed to be derived from the bark, of the treeChrysophyllum glycyphloeum. It is used as an alterative andastringent.
An anvil; also, a smith shop. See Stithy. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
To change from prose into verse; to versify; also, to changefrom verse into prose. [Obs.] Dryden.
A term used specifically by seamen; a nautical word or phrase.
A home-made woolen blanket without nap. [Local, New York]Bartlett.
An order or subclass of cryptogamous plants; the mosses. SeeMoss, and Cryptogamia.
Haughty; purse-proud. See Cob, n., 2. [Obs.] Withals (1608).
Of or pertaining to that case (as the second case of Latin andGreek nouns) which expresses source or possession. It corresponds tothe possessive case in English.
The refuse left after screening sand, coal, ashes, etc.
Act of pulling out or removing the hair; unhairing. Dryden.
A coniferous tree of the genus Cupressus. The species aremostly evergreen, and have wood remarkable for its durability.
heathy land; land full of heather; moorish or watery land.[prov. Eng.]
The state of being internal or within; interiority.
A wig; -- so called, perhaps, from being made of, orresembling, Jersey yarn. Thackeray.
The somnolent state induced by animal magnetism. Thomas (Med.Dict.).
A small Asiatic mammal (Ailurus fulgens) having fine soft fur.It is related to the bears, and inhabits the mountains of NorthernIndia.
The wood of Diospyros ebenaster, a kind of ebony found inCeylon.
The act of converting into forest or woodland. Blackstone.
One who provides, furnishes, or supplies; one who procures whatis wanted.
A name for two tropical American weeds (Capraria biflora, andScoparia dulcis) of the Figwort family.

A division of the Bantus, dwelling between the Orange andZambezi rivers, supposed to be the most ancient Bantu population ofSouth Africa. They are divided into totemic clans; they areintelligent and progressive.
A man who tills the earth; a husbandman. [Obs.] Tusser.
Remaining unwithered through the winter, or retainingunwithered leaves until the leaves of the next year are expanded, aspines cedars, hemlocks, and the like.
A lock or curl of hair near the ear; a lovelock. See Lovelock.
A privy; especially, a privy furnished with a contrivance forintroducing a stream of water to cleanse it.
The office of director; also, a body of directors takenjointly.
One of two strong bars of timber, fixed horizontally on theopposite sides of the masthead, to support the crosstrees and theframe of the top; -- generally used in the plural. Totten.
Smallness; meagerness; slenderness; fineness, thinness. [R.]Paley.
Oak given a weathered appearance by exposure in an air-tightcompartment to fumes of ammonia from uncorked cans, being first givena coat of filler.
A curious fungus of the genus Geaster, in which the outercoating splits into the shape of a star, and the inner one forms aball containing the dustlike spores.
The rank or estate of a grandee; lordship. H. Swinburne.
Something made of, or covered with, parget, or plaster. [Obs.]Milton.
A telelectric apparatus for producing images of visible objectsat a distance.
Infantry soldiers belonging to select regiments called theGuards. [Eng.]
The act or the process of inspissating, or thickening a fluidsubstance, as by evaporation; also, the state of being so thickened.
An exhibition in which an actor sustains many characters.
A pit deceitfully covered to entrap wild beasts or men; a trapof any kind. Sir T. North.
Noting the system of crystallization which has three unequalaxes at right angles to each other; trimetric. See Crystallization.
Degree of atomic attraction; equivalence; valence; also (alater use) the number of atoms in an elementary molecule. SeeValence.
Contest for mastery; contention; strife. [R.] Arnway.
A metallic element found in the beryl. See Glucinum.

Plasterwork; esp.: (a) A kind of decorative plasterwork inraised ornamental figures, formerly used for the internal andexternal decoration of houses. (b) In modern architecture, theplastering of the inside of flues, intended to give a smooth surfaceand help the draught.
The division of Lepidoptera which includes the butterflies.
Nearly in the form of an egg, or of the section of an egg, buthaving the inferior extremity broadest; nearly ovate.
Excessive production; supply beyond the demand. J. S. Mill.
To deprive of shape, or of proper shape; to disorder; toconfound; to derange. [R.] Shak.

A mineral occurring in tetragonal crystals, and also massive,of a brown to green color, rarely sulphur yellow and blue. It is asilicate of alumina and lime with some iron magnesia, and is commonat Vesuvius. Also called idocrase.
The receptacle for honey in a honeybee. Shak. Grew.
To be in pain or sorrow. [Obs. or Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
One who carries and holds a leveling staff, or rod, in asurveying party. G. W. Cable.
Want of complacency or gratification; envious displeasure;dislike. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A drug, as ergot, which by exciting uterine contractionspromotes the expulsion of the contents of the uterus.
Not current or free to circulate; not in use. [Obs.] Sir E.Sandys.
One who tells tales or stories, especially in a mischievous orofficious manner; a talebearer; a telltale; a tattler.
One of several long-tailed Oriental monkeys, of the genusCercocebus, as the green monkey and grivet.
A European squill (Scilla nonscripta) having a scape bearing araceme of drooping blue, purple, white, or sometimes pink, bell-shaped flowers.
One sent in advance; an avant-courier; a precursor.
A yellow amorphous resinoid substance obtained by the action ofdilute acids on saligenin.
A confectioner. [Obs.]He will take your daughters to be confectionaries, and to be cooks. 1Sam. viii. 13.
To render (wood) proof against decay by saturating with asolution of corrosive sublimate in open tanks, or under pressure.
One who deals with or considers actually existing facts andconditions, rather than fancies or theories; -- opposed to idealist.J. Grote.
An alvine evacuation; also, refuse matter. [Obs. or Local]Holland.
Of or pertaining to the Macrura; having a long tail.
The minor or second proposition in a categorical syllogism.
The piece designed to protect the arm from the elbow to thewrist.
An instrument formerly used for taking the altitude of thestars, etc., at sea. I. Watts.
Of or pertaining to exhortation; hortatory. Holinshed.
A lead-gray or grayish blue mineral with a metallic luster,consisting of sulphur, antimony, and lead, with a small proportion ofarsenic.
A room, attached to any place of public resort, where cloaks,overcoats, etc., may be deposited for a time.
The axis or receptacle in certain ferns (as Trichomanes), whichbears the sporangia.
One who is versed in elocution; a teacher of elocution.
The holding a good opinion of one's self; self-complacency.
A kind of sweet bread or biscuit; a cake of pounded almonds andsugar. [Obs.]marzipan Shak.
A form of spore, usually elongate or falciform, and somewhatamoboid, produced by segmentation of the schizonts of certainSporozoa, as the malaria parasite.
Characterized by invection; critical; denunciatory; satirical;abusive; railing.
Any one of several species of small squirrel-like SouthAmerican monkeys of the genus Midas, especially M. ursulus.
A mode of adjusting or operating by repeated trials orexperiments. Knight.
A Southern Asiatic species of wild cattle (Bibos frontalis).
The interior slope of a fortification, against which thegarnison lean in firing.
A dark green pigment found in small quantity in humangallstones.
One who read lectures, or commented, on the Sentences of PeterLombard, Bishop of Paris (1159-1160), a school divine. R. Henry.

The breech mechanism in breech-loading small arms and certainspecial guns, as automatic and machine guns; --used frequently inreferring to the method by which the movable barrels of breech-loading shotguns are locked, unlocked, or rotated to loadingposition.
Of or pertaining to Friesland, a province in the northern partof the Netherlands.
A process projecting backward and downward from the acromion ofthe scapula of some mammals.
To change or translate from one dialect into another. [R.] Bp.Warburton.
A large two-handed sword used formerly by the ScottishHighlanders.
Resembling, or having the characteristics of, a ligament;ligamentous.
A plant with pedately lobed leaves; the lady's mantle.
Any one of the authors of the three synoptic Gospels, whichgive a history of our Lord's life and ministry, in distinction fromthe writer of John's Gospel, which gives a fuller record of histeachings.
Having the form of a sack or pouch; furnished with a sack orpouch, as a petal.

A movable, articulated organ of sensation, attached to theheads of insects and Crustacea. There are two in the former, andusually four in the latter. They are used as organs of touch, and insome species of Crustacea the cavity of the ear is situated near thebasal joint. In insects, they are popularly called horns, and alsofeelers. The term in also applied to similar organs on the heads ofother arthropods and of annelids.
To die, decay, or become gangrenous, as flesh or bone; tomortify.
A starlike body; esp. one of the numerous small planets whoseorbits lie between those of Mars and Jupiter; -- called alsoplanetoids and minor planets.
A figure by which arguments are placed in various points ofview, and then turned to one point. Smart.
Skillful in finding the way; well acquainted with the way orroute; wise from having traveled.
Esculin; -- so called in allusion to its fluorescent solutions.[R.]

The oxide of zirconium, obtained as a white powder, andpossessing both acid and basic properties. On account of itsinfusibility, and brilliant luminosity when incandescent, it is usedas an ingredient of sticks for the Drummomd light.
An oily liquid, obtained by distillation of calcium oleate, andprobably consisting of the ketone of oleic acid.
To deprive of oxygen; to reduce from the state of an oxide.
A hipped curb roof; that is, a roof having on all sides twoslopes, the lower one being steeper than the upper one.
Having styles of two or more distinct forms or lengths. Darwin.
A short, suppressed laugh; the expression of satisfaction,exultation, or derision.

A furnace, esp. one connected with a series of small chambersand flues of tiles or other masonry through which the heat of a firewas distributed to rooms above. This contrivance, first used in bath,was afterwards adopted in private houses.
The active principe of the cantharis, or Spanish fly, avolatile, acrid, bitter solid, crystallizing in four-sided prisms.
An order of freshwater fishes, including the true pikes,cyprinodonts, and blindfishes.
The art of drawing up an army, or any given number of men, inany geometrical figure, or of estimating or expressing the number ofmen in such a figure.
The condition of a vagabond; a state or habit of wanderingabout in idleness; vagrancy.
A genus of oceanic heteropod Mollusca, having a thin, glassy,bonnet-shaped shell, which covers only the nucleus and gills.
To doom to be taken for public use, under the right of eminentdomain.
An apparatus for determining the amount of oil contained in anysubstance, or for ascertaining the degree of purity of oil.

The formal examination of the matter in issue in a cause beforea competent tribunal; the mode of determining a question of fact in acourt of law; the examination, in legal form, of the facts in issuein a cause pending before a competent tribunal, for the purpose ofdetermining such issue.

The act by which, either in animals or plants, materialprepared by the generative organs the female organism is brought incontact with matter from the organs of the male, so that a neworganism results; impregnation; fertilization.
To think wrongly. [Obs.] "Adam misthought of her." Milton.
The science, or the scientific treatment, of synonymous words.
To strip off the roof or covering of, as a house. Shak.
An instrument out of tune or rudely constructed; music badlyplayed.
To defile; to pollute; to contaminate; to befoul. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
A form of cash carrier in which a small carrier or car travelsupon a kind of track.
The quality or state of being subjective; character of thesubject.
Any species of Paradoxurus, a genus of Asiatic viverrinemammals allied to the civet, as the musang, and the luwack or palmcat (Paradoxurus hermaphroditus). See Musang.
An apparatus for conveying heat, as a case containing materialwhich retains its heat for a considerable period.
One who, or that which, controls, governs, or determines. SirP. Sidney.
The organ in which pseudova are produced; -- called alsopseudovarium.
A sulphide having more than one atom of sulphur in themolecule; -- contrasted with monosulphide.
A California composite plant (Layia platyglossa), the flower ofwhich has yellow rays tipped with white.
One who courts widows, seeking to marry one with a fortune.Addison.

A function involving the coefficients and the variables of aquantic, and such that when the quantic is lineally transformed thesame function of the new variables and coefficients shall be equal tothe old function multiplied by a factor. An invariant is a likefunction involving only the coefficients of the quantic.
A special substance contained in tuberculin, supposed to be theactive agent of the latter freed from various impurities.
A temple tower of the Babylonians or Assyrians, consisting of alofty pyramidal structure, built in successive stages, with outsidestaircases, and a shrine at the top.
One of the bones of either the forearm or shank, theepipodialia being the radius, ulna, tibia, and fibula.
The science which treats of catadioptric phenomena, or of theused of catadioptric instruments.
An Australian name for the very hard wood of the Eucalyptuspiluralis.
Any one of several species of bivalves, which form holes inlimestone, in which they live; esp., any species of the genusLithodomus.
The act of aggregating, or the state of being aggregated;collection into a mass or sum; a collection of particulars; anaggregate.
The loose black particles collected from combustion, as on potsand kettles, or in a chimney; soot; smut; also, coloring matter whichrubs off from cloth.
A genus of cycadaceous plants, having the appearance of lowpalms, but with exogenous wood. See Coontie, and Illust. of Strobile.
A painful erection of the penis, usually with downwardcurvature, occurring in gonorrhea.
A wedge-shaped brick used in the building of an arch.
The longer wood for making or mending fences. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
Of or pertaining to iatrochemistry, or to the iatrochemists.
In a manner to be bragged of; finely; proudly. [Obs.] Spenser.
One who by gradual steps enters on, and takes possession of,what is not his own.
Uttered in a whisper, or with the breath alone, without voice,as certain consonants, such as p, k, t, f; surd; nonvocal; aspirated.
To give forth effluvium. [R.] "An effluviating power." Boyle.
The act of tabularizing, or the state of being tabularized;formation into tables; tabulation.
In the top; at the mast head, or on the higher yards orrigging; overhead; hence (Fig. and Colloq.), in or to heaven.
Designating an acid derived from silicic acid by the removal ofwater; of or pertaining to such an acid.
A poisonous American serpent (Ancistrodon conotortrix), closelyallied to the rattlesnake, but without rattles; -- called alsocopper-belly, and red viper.
As soon as the thing required may be done by reasonableexertion confined to that object. Bouvier.
an Australian eagle (Aquila audax), which destroys lambs andeven the kangaroo.-- To make bold, to take liberties or the liberty; to venture.
Having a kingdom or the dignity of a king; like a kingdom. [R.]"Twixt his mental and his active parts, Kingdom'd Achilles incommotion rages And batters down himself. Shak.
The head or uppermost member of a column, pilaster, etc. Itconsists generally of three parts, abacus, bell (or vase), andnecking. See these terms, and Column.
One who practices or excuses obtrusion. [R.] Gent. Mag.
An extinct order of arthropods comprising the trilobites.
One who struts; one who bears himself jauntily; a fop. [Obs.]Palsgrave.
A nitrogenous substance free from phosphorus, supposed to bepresent in the brain; a body closely related to cerebrin.
A low evergreen plant (Chimaphila umbellata), with narrow,wedge-lanceolate leaves, and an umbel of pretty nodding fragrantblossoms. It has been used in nephritic diseases. Called alsoprince's pine.
A name given to many umbrella-shaped fungi, mostly of the genusAgaricus. The species are almost numberless. They grow on decayingorganic matter.
The detachable or movable fore part of a gunstock, lyingbeneath the barrel or barrels, and forming a hold for the left hand.
A British Indian gold coin, of the value of fifteen silverrupees, or $7.21. Malcom.
A genus of shrubs with pretty white flowers, much cultivated.
Infertile; barren; unprofitable; unproductive. [Obs.] Glanvill.
Having six rays; -- said of certain sponge spicules. SeeIllust. of Spicule.
A genus of American Cretaceous pterodactyls destitute of teeth.Several species are known, some of which had an expanse of wings oftwenty feet or more.
Proceeding in a straight course or manner; not deviating;honest; frank.-- adv.

A small animal of Java (Paradoxirus fasciatus), allied to thecivets. It swallows, but does not digest, large quantities of ripecoffee berries, thus serving to disseminate the coffee plant; henceit is called also coffee rat.
Of or pertaining to a procurator, or proctor; made by aproctor. Ayliffe.
Shooting at pigeons liberated, or glass balls or clay pigeonssprung into the air, from a trap. -- Trap shooter.
A toxic alkaloid found occasionally associated with thepeptones formed from fibrin by pepsinhydrochloric acid.
Something that separates; a hedge; a fence. [R.] Bailey.
A board, or frame of planks, lowered over the side of a vesselto lessen her leeway when closehauled, by giving her greater draught.
Silver bromide, a rare mineral; -- called also bromargyrite.
Of or pertaining to Modena or its inhabitants.-- n. sing. & pl.
One destitute of wit or sense; a blockhead; a fool. [Obs.]Shak.
Ability of body or mind; force; vigor. [Obs. or R.]
The waste liquor remaining in the process of making beet sugar,-- used in the manufacture of potassium carbonate.
A fortress in or near a fortified city, commanding the city andfortifications, and intended as a final point of defense. Syn. -Stronghold. See Fortress.
In the manner of a conspirator; by conspiracy. Milton.
Of the same tenor or tone; equable; without variation.

A colorless crystalline substance, C4H6.(OH)4, of a sweet,cooling taste, extracted from certain lichens, and obtained by thedecomposition of erythrin; -- called also erythrol, erythroglucin,erythromannite, pseudorcin, cobalt bloom, and under the name phyciteobtained from the alga Protococcus vulgaris. It is a tetrabasicalcohol, corresponding to glycol and glycerin.
Any plant of a genus (Eriocaulon) of aquatic or marsh herbswith soft grass-like leaves.

The blind mole rat (Spalax typhlus), native of Eastern Europeand Asia. Its eyes and ears are rudimentary, and its fur is soft andbrownish, more or less tinged with gray. It constructs extensiveburrows.
A peculiar acrid and bitter oil, obtained from wood soot.
A fine kind of leather, prepared commonly from goatskin (thoughan inferior kind is made of sheepskin), and tanned with sumac anddyed of various colors; -- said to have been first made by the Moors.
Having the margin alternately curved inward and outward; havingrounded lobes separated by rounded sinuses; sinuous; wavy.

A genus of marine annelids, believed to be an ancient orancestral type. It is remarkable for its simplicity of structure andwant of parapodia. It is the type of the order Archiannelida, orGymnotoma. See Loeven's larva.
Having a division by fours; separated into four parts orseries, or into series of fours.
An order of ganoid fishes, including the sturgeons; -- socalled on account of their cartilaginous skeleton.

A rare alkaloid found in the bark of an East Indianapocynaceous tree (Wrightia antidysenterica), and extracted as abitter white crystalline substance. It was formerly used as a remedyfor diarrhoea. Called also conessine, and neriine.
To trifle with; to deceive; to mock. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
The quality of turning; instability; tergiversation. [Obs.] SirP. Sidney.
Close-handed; close-fisted; covetous; avaricious. [Obs.] Bacon.
Driven or actuated by a motor, esp. by an individual electricmotor. An electric motor forms an integral part of many machine toolsin numerous modern machine shops.
The entire covering of an invertebrate animal, as echinoderm orcoelenterate; the integument.
The chief harpooner, who also directs in cutting up the speck,or blubber; -- so called among whalers.
A morbid condition in which the eye stands wide open, giving apeculiar staring appearance.
Having, or resembling, bosom; kept in the bosom; hidden.
A mineral of a yellowish or greenish white color, consisting ofthe sulphate and carbonate of lead; -- so called from having beenfirst found at Leadhills, Scotland.
The quality or state of being overly; carelessness. [Obs.] Bp.Hall.
Such a due mixture of qualities in bodies as constitutes healthor soundness. Quincy.
One of the sections into which the hold of a ship is divided bywater-tight bulkheads.
To plow again, in the fall; -- said of prairie land broken upin the spring. [Western U.S.]
Of or pertaining to the notochord; having a notochord.
Any of a group of meteors appearing November 20-23; -- socalled because they appear to radiate from a point in Taurus.
A kind of spar; earth flax, or amianthus. [Obs.] oodward.
To come into a country of which one is not a native, for thepurpose of permanent residence. See Emigrate.

Any one of several species of finchlike birds belonging to thegenus Vidua, native of Asia and Africa. In the breeding season themale has very long, drooping tail feathers. Called also vida finch,whidah finch, whydah bird, whydah finch, widow bird, and widow finch.
The name of several different species of the genus Potentilla;-- also called five-finger, because of the resemblance of its leavesto the fingers of the hand.
A cellular layer derived from the nucleus of an ovule andsurrounding the embryo sac. Cf. Quintine.
The state or quality of being indigestible; indigestibleness.
One fond of his own opinious; one who holds an opinion. [Obs.]Glanvill.
A tower or other building with a powerful light at top, erectedat the entrance of a port, or at some important point on a coast, toserve as a guide to mariners at night; a pharos.
A banker; a money changer or broker; one who deals in bills ofexchange, or who is skilled in the science of exchange.
An order of Rhizopoda, in which the pseudopodia are thick andirregular in form, as in the Amoeba.
The burning bush; -- said to be called after a quack medicinemade from it.
The state of being a beau; the personality of a beau. [Jocular]Dryden.
A species of coarse potter's ware, glazed and baked.
Belonging to sutlers; engaged in the occupation of a sutler.Addison.
Any one of a series of nitro derivatives of aniline. In generalthey are yellow crystalline substances.
The principle or process of forming from given components theeutectic alloy, or alloy of maximum fusibility.
The act of isolating, or the state of being isolated;insulation; separation; loneliness. Milman.
Exhibiting differences of quality or property in differentdirections; not isotropic. Sir W. Thomson.
Cheerful; lively; gay; bright; pleasant; as, a cheery person.His cheery little study, where the sunshine glimmered so pleasantly.Hawthorne.
A gigantic clam (Glycimeris generosa) of the Pacific coast ofNorth America, highly valued as an article of food.
An epoch at the close of the Canadian period of the AmericanLower Silurian system; -- so named from a township in Clinton Co.,New York. See the Diagram under Geology.
One of a group of gastropod mollusks, with a shell composed ofeight movable dorsal plates. See Polyplacophora.
Separate existence; individuality; oneness. Fuller.
A name given to several dark-colored timbers. The East Indianblack wood is from the tree Dalbergia latifolia. Balfour.
A Utopian community, in which all should rule equally, such aswas devised by Coleridge, Lovell, and Southey, in their younger days.
Moving by inherent power, without the aid of external impulse.
The division of insects that includes the dragon flies.
Having the hip dislocated; hence, having one hip lower than theother. L'Estrange.
The husband of one's mother by a subsequent marriage.
A nerve or tendon, supposed to brace and sustain the heart.Shak.Sobbing, as if a hearstring broke. Moore.
Bending away from the ground; -- said of leaves, etc. Darwin.
One of the berries or drupes of the European buckthorn; also,the buckthorn itself.
An instrument for signaling by reflecting the rays of the sunin different directions. Knight.
Of or pertaining to both the rectum and the vagina.
A mineral of an iron-black color, and very sectile, consistingprincipally of sulphur, antimony, and silver.
To deprive of glory; to treat with indignity. [R.]Disglorified, blasphemed, and had in scorn. Milton.
An English coin of the value of half a penny; also, the valueof half a penny.

One of the arms of the male of most kinds of cephalopods, whichis specially modified in various ways to effect the fertilization ofthe eggs. In a special sense, the greatly modified arm of Argonautaand allied genera, which, after receiving the spermatophores, becomesdetached from the male, and attaches itself to the female forreproductive purposes.
A game of war, played for practice, on maps. Farrow.
The inside sole of a boot or shoe; also, a loose, thin strip ofleather, felt, etc., placed
Of, pertaining to, or containing, molybdenum; specif.,designating those compounds in which molybdenum has a lower valenceas contrasted with molybdic compounds.
In a manner to be discerned; perceptibly; visibly. Hammond.
A writer of martyrology; an historian of martyrs. T. Warton.
The art or rocess of making observations with the polariscope.
The century plant, a species of Agave (A. Americana). SeeAgave.
Of certain achromatic lenses, having the same focus for theactinic and for the brightest of the visual rays.
A small organ at the upper part of the vulva, homologous to thepenis in the male.
Offerings formerly made to the parish priest, or to the motherchurch, at Pentecost. Shipley.
Prophetic; oracular; pretending to foretell events.
The lower part or basement of a building or pedestal; -- usedloosely for several different forms of basement.
The act of beating upon, or as if upon, a drum; also, the noisewhich the male of the ruffed grouse makes in spring, by beating hiswings upon his sides.
An easy chariot or carriage, used by Roman ladies, and in whichthe vessels, etc., for sacred rites were carried.
Western Christians of the Latin rite. See Orientals. Shipley.
A keeper or feeder of sheep; also, an owner of sheep. 2 Kingsiii. 4.
Pertaining to, or designating, an amido acid related to lacticacid, and called also amido-propionic acid.
A sharp-edged, tubular, marine shell, of the genus Vermetus;also, the pinna. See Vermetus.
The quality or condition of being impure; impurity. Milton.
The American redbellied snipe (Macrorhamphus scolopaceus); --called also long-billed dowitcher.
The conversion of cell walls into a material which repelswater, as in cork.
The orb of the fixed stars; the most rmote of the celestialspheres.
A hamper to be carried in the hand; a hand basket used incarrying grapes to the press.
One who disbelieves, or refuses belief; an unbeliever.Specifically, one who does not believe the Christian religion. I.Watts.
The nonmetalliferous mineral or rock material which accompaniesthe ores in a vein, as quartz, calcite, barite, fluor spar, etc.; --called also veinstuff.
To become pale through disease or absence of light.
Madam; my lady; -- a colloquial contraction of madam often usedin direct address, and sometimes as an appellation.
Larceny committed in a shop; the stealing of anything from ashop.
To make opposition in words or argument; -- usually followed byto. Sir. T. More.
A secondary or additional product; something produced, as inthe course of a manufacture, in addition to the principal product.
To weary with labor or any bodily or mental exertion; to harasswith toil; to exhaust the strength or endurance of; to tire.
A method of attaining successively lower temperatures byutilizing the cooling effect of the expansion of one gas incondensing another less easily liquefiable, and so on.
Small crimson, purple, or livid spots, like flea-bites, due toextravasation of blood, which appear on the skin in malignant fevers,etc.
The act of carrying anything around, or the state of being socarried.
Retaining the accent; not enclitic; -- said of certainindefinite pronouns and adverbs when used interrogatively, which,when not so used, are ordinarilly enclitic.
Having seeds grooved lengthwise on the inner face, as in sweetcicely.

A judicial writ of execution, by which a defendant's goods areappraised and delivered to the plaintiff, and, if no sufficient tosatisfy the debt, all of his lands are delivered, to be held till thedebt is paid by the rents and profits, or until the defendant'sinterest has expired.
The furniture of a ship, as masts, sails, rigging, anchors,guns, etc.
Divination as to the destinies of one newly born; the act orart of casting nativities; astrology.
Arsenic sulphide, a mineral of a brilliant red color; redorpiment. It is also an artificial product.
A thick woolen fabric, watered or with embossed figures; --used in upholstery, for curtains, etc.
The condition of having an unusual intensity of color.
A solid resembling a pyramid; -- called also pyramoid. Barlow.
Having new vigor or strength; invigorated anew. [R.] Southey.
A book consisting of sheets each of which is folded into sixleaves.

A mass, usually of soft iron, but sometimes of some othermagnetic metal, as nickel or cobalt, rendered temporarily magnetic bybeing placed within a coil of wire through which a current ofelectricity is passing. The metal is generally in the form of a bar,either straight, or bent into the shape of a horseshoe.
The state of being seared or callous; insensibility. Bp. Hall.
